webTitle: English game looks good to Sven

fields.headline: English game looks good to Sven
fields.trailText: Sven-Göran Eriksson saw Manchester United move 13 points clear of their rivals yesterday and said he had been impressed with the standard of football he has seen in England so far, despite attending three fairly drab games at West Ham, Ipswich and Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Sven-Göran Eriksson saw Manchester United move 13 points clear of their rivals yesterday and said he had been impressed with the standard of football he has seen in England so far, despite attending three fairly drab games at West Ham, Ipswich and Old Trafford.

'I haven't seen the most beautiful games, but they have still been very interesting,' said England's new manager after United's 2-0 defeat of Aston Villa. 'But even if I had found them disappointing I would never tell you that.' He said he would not reveal which players had impressed him, either.

Eriksson appreciates the honesty of English football. 'The games I have seen have all been very correct,' he said. 'Two minutes added on at the end of a half, or one minute, once no time at all. That tells you players haven't spent much time on the ground, holding up the match, and that's good.'

Eriksson was deprived of the opportunity to see David Beckham - although he knew in advance he had been rested - but he saw Teddy Sheringham and Paul Merson maintain their impressive form this season before confirming age would not be a consideration when he named his first England squad for next month's game against Spain.

'I don't feel that 30 or 32 is too old when you have a World Cup qualifier coming up,' the Swede said, either overlooking or not knowing that Sheringham had just turned 34.

'You have to be fit, that's the main thing. I certainly don't have a special age beyond which I don't consider players, nor will I be sticking to players under 30. It's not fair and not very intelligent to do that, unless you have a friendly which isn't close to anything else, like Peter Taylor had at the end of last year. I don't think there was anything wrong with what he did, but I will simply be picking the best players available.'

webTitle: The money's there for u>direct deal

fields.headline: The money's there for u>direct deal
fields.trailText: Remember watching England's World Cup qualifier in Finland last October? The chances are you probably don't. Only a small audience watched when it was shown by a little-known pay-per-view broadcaster (and those who did see it gave the coverage a pretty good slagging off).
fields.body:
Remember watching England's World Cup qualifier in Finland last October? The chances are you probably don't. Only a small audience watched when it was shown by a little-known pay-per-view broadcaster (and those who did see it gave the coverage a pretty good slagging off).

So goodbye u>direct? Well, no. The independent pay-per-view broadcaster has become a warm favourite to win the contract to show 40 Premiership matches for the next three seasons.

Originally, the cable company ntl won the contract to show Premiership games on p-p-v for the first time from next season. But their £328 million deal with the Premier League, agreed last June, broke down in October when ntl's chief executive, Barclay Knapp, said his company had been unable to complete negotiations.

Most analysts agreed ntl would have found it hard to make money from the 120 matches, which would have cost nearly £2.75 million each before taking into account marketing and production expenses. Nor would the matches have been the most enticing with Sky having first pick of the fixtures for their 66 matches a season on their subscription channels.

Interest in the p-p-v rights was renewed at a much lower level than ntl's first offer. Ntl came in with a much-reduced bid and there was interest, too, from ONdigital, who show European Champions League matches on their subscription service.

But insiders believe that u>direct, whose shareholders include heavy hitters such as Pearson Television, Deutsche Bank and Nomura International, will be successful. 'They're not short of funds and they could quite easily afford it if they reckoned it was a decent shop window,' a source said.

webTitle: Perils and pitfalls on rocky road to El Dorado

fields.headline: Perils and pitfalls on rocky road to El Dorado
fields.trailText: Worldsport.com is a frightening role model, reports Jon Henderson.
fields.body:
Noisy may not sound the most obvious technical term, but it's just right to describe the precarious new world of internet sports sites. Things are definitely noisy. Insiders use the word a lot. But noisy should not be confused with successful or money-spinning. Quite the contrary. There have been some spectacular failures already and there will be more. Noisy means restless movement as the entrepreneurial class try to make money out of a medium that promised so much and has delivered rather less. So far, the only ones who have done conspicuously well out of sports sites are those who got in early and sold out for a fat profit - often to someone who then made a fat loss.

Those keen to invest have a frightening role model, worldsport.com, which had contracts to provide websites for dozens of international sports federations, but, embarrassingly, had its London operation closed down in the autumn while some of its staff were working at the Sydney Olympic Games. Worldsport.com was set up two years ago by Alan Callan, the one-time business manager for Led Zeppelin who made a fortune from rugby union TV rights and marketing, and, at the time, had seemed a sure thing. But the internet is much more of a gamble than TV, and by last summer worldsport was having to take cost-cutting measures to stay afloat and in October it sank. Those who thought purveyors of sports information teaming up with the internet was a match made in El Dorado were suddenly having to think again.

'The problem is that nobody apart from our friend Mr Gates has any comprehension of the cost involved with setting up a website, having to maintain the technology and continually go through market development,' says internet analyst James Lowry. 'In the internet industry, three weeks is equal to a year in other media and unless you're being continually innovative, which no one can afford to be in a start-up company, you don't have a product that's going to move forward.' Which is why, as they battle to survive, the sports sites are prepared to go to considerable lengths. Cricinfo, the globally popular cricket site, has established a base in India, where low wages keep down costs. Nearly all sites are desperate to do deals - with sports federations, broadcasters, other websites - just so long as there's money in it.

At the outset, sports site speculators pinned their hopes on making money through advertising. But this has never proved nearly sufficient to support the industry, even though last year the ad spend was about £120 million in the UK. Typically, an advertiser will pay £20 for a unit of 1,000 banner ad appearances - or £10,000 for half a million - which will be pulled in one at a time on each occasion someone makes an impression by requesting a page. Two years ago, when the internet still had some sort of novelty value for users, people would click on a banner advertisement 1.0 to 1.5 per cent of the time, a click-rate that is down to 0.4 to 0.5 per cent. That means for every 1,000 visitors to a page, only four will click on an advert. It might be spurious to compare that with newspapers, but for an indicator, that 0.4 per cent is competing with a figure of more than 100 per cent in the print media.

For every 1,000 copies of The Observer sold, advertisers would reach more than that number of readers in the sports section, because every copy is read, on average by more than two people, and well over half of those go to the sports section. 'It's getting a hell of a lot harder to get people to leave a website and go on to whatever you're trying to advertise,' says Patrick Griffith, of the online media agency i-level. But advertisers are not deserting the internet even if they are not turning it into the money-minting machine that it was expected to be. They still regard it as a valuable branding tool and it gives a feedback that no other medium does. 'Online is totally accountable,' says Griffith. 'You know exactly what's worked and what hasn't.'

Crucially, though, the advertisers have failed to make the sports site owners rich, or even bail them out in some instances, and other revenue possibilities have been unable to compensate. These include revenue share deals, which, through the technology that can identify the site that was responsible for a sale, enable that site and the manufacturer to divide up the profit; 'sports shops', whereby a site will act as a licensee to a manufacturer; sponsorship of a particular feature of a website - live score services are particularly popular; and syndication of content, such as journalism.

All of which has failed to stop new speculators entering the noisy world of sports sites, which, to be fair, is still a young one and as such is bound to have a high rate of failures (generally, new businesses are reckoned to fold at a rate of more than 80 per cent). One of the more interesting recent concepts is sports stars having their own sites, such as those run by icons.com, which launched last June and is already working with more than 100 footballers, including Ryan Giggs, Robbie Fowler and Marc Overmars, who used his site to announce his move from Arsenal last July.

James Freedman, the chief executive of icons.com, who established his reputation in the sporting media by successfully launching the Manchester United magazine, says: 'The trouble with lots of sports sites is they all have the same content so it's difficult to differentiate. What we provide is unique content. We are offering football fans direct access to their favourite players, who like this method of communicating because their words aren't taken out of context or sensationalised or treated in a scurrilous way.'

Through a combination of advertising revenue, e-commerce - the sale of merchandising - and a series of deals syndicating to a whole range of traditional media, Freedman says he is confident icons.com will become profitable in the next year to 18 months. And that would make him a bigger noise than most in the noisy world of sport in cyberspace.

webTitle: Online bookies in picture to make net gain

fields.headline: Online bookies in picture to make net gain
fields.trailText: I haven't had a bet in the bookies for two years, because of the internet. When it comes to the cold business of betting there is no comparison. No longer is the information superhighway a sheet of newspaper pinned to the betting shop wall. Punting has moved on forever to tax-free, spoilt-for-choice, secluded study, and in turn helped to bring its own changes.
fields.body:
I haven't had a bet in the bookies for two years, because of the internet. When it comes to the cold business of betting there is no comparison. No longer is the information superhighway a sheet of newspaper pinned to the betting shop wall. Punting has moved on forever to tax-free, spoilt-for-choice, secluded study, and in turn helped to bring its own changes.

One of the biggest could be on its way in March, when the Government decides whether to abolish general betting duty. It has been under duress to axe the tax ever since British bookmakers shifted all but their betting shops to offshore havens, where there is no need to charge the nine per cent deduction that now makes betting shops so unappealing. What kind of industry is it where Ladbrokes languish in Gibraltar, and William Hill work from Antigua? Idiosyncrasies like these are the work of the internet because one of the main drivers of the online revolution has been gambling, not Amazon or QXL. Easy access, rapid delivery, deep satisfaction at what once was the coalface, but is now the interface.

If betting duty vanishes then betting shops could be tax-free just like the online bookmaker, yet for all their allure they are already in danger of becoming the forgotten cousin. Money is being thrown at attracting a newer audience to betting, £5 million to online marketing in Ladbrokes' case, solely to target the 83 per cent of the population who never have a bet. On the understanding that worldwide telephone and internet betting could surpass £630m by the end of this year, and that every adult in Britain could have mobile internet access by 2010, it's quite a market. Another estimate from Dutch banker ABN-Amro puts internet betting within three years at £6bn.

Clearly some people are going to make a fortune from punters (who should be cautious - one British betting site, betachance.com, closed down last week. Punters logging on to the site were met with a message stating that no bets would be taken until 26 January because of 'a complete systems change'). To now there has only been a monopoly banker, the bookmakers, but built into the staggering ABN-Amro estimate is a mighty imponderable - interactive TV betting. This is part of the reason Sky could up the ante to £2bn for football rights or why Sky, with Channel 4, are willing to enter a deal worth £75m a year to cover horse racing, compared to the £18m racing earns at present each year for its terrestrial and satellite rights.

Once technology allows high-resolution live action pictures on the internet the belief is that sports broadcasts on the web's many platforms will generate betting in areas of the world totally unconsidered for business. The theory is that of satisfying the displaced fan. He is able to see the action and, if so inclined, bet on it at the same time, anywhere in the world. Investing in this dreamy landscape has already begun. Evidence abounds of websites trying to build a loyal following of surfers in the hope and expectation at some point of live pictures and betting. Those are the twin towers that will bring forth riches so long as the principal buyer of the rights plays ball.

Before that happens, established content websites like onefootball.com, cricinfo and sports.com operate in a certain state of limbo. They can carry news, views, interviews, games, hotlinks to bookmakers, even minute-by-minute bulletins of live games, but it all leaves the user crying out for pictures. It's like kissing your sister. Trial runs of live action have been hit and miss. Ascot held a webcast of the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Stakes in July, but it looked intermittently like a blizzard on a go-slow, then in November William Hill showed Celtic's Uefa Cup defeat to Bordeaux, with 'in-game' odds alongside on the same screen, to greater acclaim.

William Hill is one bookmaker that is ahead of the game as a strategic partner providing fixed odds betting to the live greyhound racing site at www.24dogs.com strategic alliances are the vogue. Did cable company ntl invest millions in Aston Villa, Newcastle, Celtic, Rangers and the Swansea and Newport rugby clubs because Mr Chairman likes a day out? The broadcast rights owned by the clubs are potentially worth a fortune. Tom Jessiman, managing director at sports.com has $62m of funding behind him to cover expenses in the wait for the future.

'The market for buying video rights is multi-billion dollar,' he said. 'We're going to have to partner with the rights holders and, as live video starts to work better online, the rights holders will soon see the income streams. We'll be doing that ahead of the traditional betting sites, its two to three years out, and there's definitely a market for pay-per-view for the displaced fan. I can see him or her shelling out £5 to see the Liverpool match, even if its on slightly delayed footage. 'But the big revenues will come from gambling, even bigger than pay-per-view, and especially from the Far East. The power of the Premiership as a global brand is immense.'

As access to the internet on TV and on mobile phones edges closer to the average consumer so the stakes in the race begin to grow. A couple of weeks ago the website intertops.com claimed its 15 millionth bet in five years since launch, or one every 10 seconds without fail. 'The phenomenal growth of the internet has had an incredible effect on gaming business,' said intertops' co-founder Simon Noble. 'We are experiencing a 30 to 40 per cent growth rate every year in bets taken on the popular sporting events, and this year will be no exception.' Intertops talks a good game. It reports 480,000 clients in 183 countries. Yet few punters in Britain have heard of it. It certainly has no string of betting shops.

Tony Smurthwaite is a staff writer and internet betting specialist for the Racing Post.

webTitle: Long wait for net profit

fields.headline: Long wait for net profit
fields.standfirst: 'Brilliant ideas, but no one knows how to make any money,' says an Olympic executive of new-media hype. Betting apart, will sport on the web ever take off?
fields.trailText: 'Brilliant ideas, but no one knows how to make any money,' says an Olympic executive of new-media hype. Betting apart, will sport on the web ever take off? asks Denis Campbell.
fields.body:
It has been billed as a revolution that will reshape the viewing habits of armchair sports lovers everywhere. In the future, fans will be able to see any piece of sporting action they fancy any time, any place, anywhere. Nicolas Anelka's unlikely return to Highbury in Arsenal's reserve game from your Singapore hotel room? No problem; just log in and call it up. Meanwhile, the players, clubs, ruling bodies, sports internet sites and television companies will make shedloads of cash for making that happen. So everyone wins. All through harnessing the wonders and benefits of the new media to sport's billions-strong global audience.

So much for the theory. The practice so far has been very different. All revolutions start somewhere and, almost unnoticed, this one began in Glasgow's East End on 24 August last year. Celtic v Jeunesse Esch of Luxembourg in the Uefa Cup qualifying round was the first time any football club in Europe, and possibly the world, had broadcast one of its games in live pictures over the internet. As an historic event, it was a serious letdown. It was less the quality of the game, a 7-0 walkover for Celtic, than the quality of the pictures. Initially good, albeit not television standard, they got progressively grainier and slower as more users joined the broadcast until this ground-breaking 'live transmission' became merely a succession of still pictures accompanied by a live commentary. Result: frustration for 33,000 Hoops fans who had been relishing the unprecedented opportunity of watching a match on their personal computer, at home or work, courtesy of celticfc.net.

Nevertheless this fledgling webcast was still sport's equivalent of Neil Armstrong's 'one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind'. Despite the problems, it showed that live pictures of sports events could be transmitted over the web - a breakthrough of potentially huge significance, given the internet's global reach. Racing and boxing also dabbled with live web broadcasts last year, to smaller audiences and in shorter bursts of action, and they, too suffered problems with picture quality. Iain Reid, project director of celticfc.net, said, 'It was a success in that we got it out there. But it was more of an experiment, a learning experience about what the internet is capable of at this stage, and especially about the technical difficulties of streaming a game. And obviously a useful service to the fans.' Those technical difficulties did not deter the supporters. When Celtic played Helsinki in the next round, 40,000 tuned in, 7,000 more than the first time. Fans around the world were glad to see something they would otherwise only have read or heard about.

That is a microcosm of the internet's appeal as a live sport medium for fans. It offers the chance to watch something you would otherwise not have seen, and to do so when, where and how it suits you. Despite Rupert Murdoch's best efforts, not every sports event in the world is shown on television - or not on a channel you can watch. Which is where the internet comes in and cleans up. In theory. A combination of all that unfulfilled viewing interest among sports fans and the increasingly prominent role of new technology in our lives has led to plenty of fanciful predictions. Not just that the internet will drastically alter fans' consumption of sport but that it will sweep away the huge power of the TV companies and make a lot of people a lot of money - by converting all of us into fee-paying subscribers. But will it happen? Kevin Roberts, editor of Sport Business magazine, says the potential of applying new technology to sport is vast, both for consumers and commercial interests. But he is sceptical of the idea that every fan will want to pay to receive alerts on their mobile phone telling them of the latest goal. 'Do fans really want all the things that they'll soon be able to get?' Roberts asks.

'Is it technology driving demand or vice versa? Look at the experience of WAP phones. They were heralded as a great revolution but they didn't live up to expectations. In future fans will have to pay for quality services, for anything other than a basic service offered by their club or sports internet provider. But will they do that? We don't even know that there's a market for this.' Nevertheless, Roberts thinks enough fans will eventually sign up to justify the mega-millions being invested in the sports internet sector. 'Fans want more than simply going into a chatroom to discuss why Teddy Sheringham has had a new lease of life. I suspect they will pay to see goals and have other services delivered to them, because the relationship between them and their club is so intense - but only if the pricing is right. If it is, the potential audience is huge. But everything depends on pricing.'

The investors believe that, just as millions of fans have subscribed to sports TV stations, so most of us will, eventually, pay for web-based services. Sports internet companies have been doing their figures, but none will say how much we will all be asked to stump up to see goals, highlights or exclusive interviews. To watch from your armchair will cost several hundred pounds a year, and mobile access will be extra. Stephen Nuttall, head of sport at Sportal, one of the biggest websites, reckons that within two years fans will be spending £10 a month to access all sorts of content through as-yet-unavailable handsets called personal digital assistants - a combined mobile phone, palm pilot and video player - which will offer users text, video clips and audio services on the team or sport they follow. Nuttall stresses that pictures will rapidly become the defining factor. 'People will probably not want to watch an entire match on their PDA but if they can't watch an event on telly, they'll use it for updates and maybe action. If there's been a big pile-up at the first corner at Silverstone, or Paolo Di Canio's been sent off, it'll tell you that and let you see it if you want to.'

Talk about price at this stage may well be premature anyway. Before details like that can be sorted out, two issues need to be clarified. When will the technology be easily available for access to all this stuff? And, when all the rights wars have been won and lost, what exactly will there be to watch? Sports internet companies insist that the much-heralded new means of watching webcasts, with pictures of TV quality rather than Celtic-Jeunesse Esch quality, could be available within two years. Graeme Ferguson, of Worldzap, says, 'In the beginning you could send text messages by mobile phone, then it was text and graphics, then came photos, audio and internet access. The imminent third generation of personal mobile devices means people will be able to receive far more data - especially pictures - than ever before.' Worldzap recently claimed a first when they delivered a goal from a Bundesliga match, 'as live' soon after it had been scored, to a futuristic mobile phone. But refinement of the technology will take some years.

Technologically, the key is the development of 'broadband internet', a hugely enhanced version of what most of us can get on our PCs already and will allow us to receive those TV-quality pictures. TV and internet technology will fuse through a process of 'convergence' which may, ultimately, render the difference between old and new media obselete. David Wood, editor of specialist newsletter Broadband, says convergence will really take off in the next decade, but not in the next three or four years. While text-based services will grow, action will be the real lure for people thinking about signing up. The technology already exists but is prohibitively expensive. Despite bullish noises about broadband becoming widespread quite quickly, in reality rollout is unlikely to happen until the price has fallen to make it accessible, probably around 2005. According to one survey, by then 80 million homes in Europe are expected to have been converted to it. Only then can the revolution really start.

Before then, there will also be a war between internet firms desperate to secure the rights to key competitions such as the World Cup, Premiership, Champions League and Formula One. That scramble will be intense because these companies need to recruit subscribers to raise the money to pay back investors who believed the hype and have sunk millions into them. Without attractive content, a sports website will die. But there are not enough events worth having to ensure everyone's survival. Leading clubs and ruling bodies will also launch their own paid-for services, using their own events as bait. Peter Kenyon, Manchester United's go-ahead chief executive, foresees a future where manutd.com has millions of users who, when the website merges with MUTV, will eventually start paying subscriptions, especially their vast army of fans outside Britain. It's easy to see how, given their global pulling power, United will earn many millions in extra income. Celtic hope to do the same, as do Arsenal and Liverpool through their links with Granada Media.

But how much can Aston Villa or Everton, for example, expect to make in this way? And outside football, Formula One and America's big games, how many sports have enough fans to benefit in any serious way? The revolution could simply make rich clubs and sports richer, and pass everyone else by. At the moment, confusion reigns. Last month the International Olympic Committee held a two-day seminar in Switzerland that was meant to answer all the difficult questions about sport's fast-evolving relationship with new media. How would fans be affected? Who would make money and how? Would the internet replace TV or complement it?

After endless presentations, discussions and analysis, Dick Pound, the IOC vice-president, admitted, 'We haven't the faintest idea what the new media rights to the Olympics are worth. The people in the industry have all these wonderful ideas, some of which are brilliant, but none of them knows how they're going to make money. And people don't seem to be willing to pay for content.' And the IOC's conclusion from two days of talks? No decisions on internet rights until 2010. It's too complicated.

webTitle: Time runs out on Gregory as Ellis effect takes hold

fields.headline: Time runs out on Gregory as Ellis effect takes hold
fields.trailText: John Gregory was sitting in his office at Aston Villa's Bodymoor Heath training ground on his first day in his new job when the phone rang. At the other end was the man he had just replaced in the job, Brian Little.
fields.body:
John Gregory was sitting in his office at Aston Villa's Bodymoor Heath training ground on his first day in his new job when the phone rang. At the other end was the man he had just replaced in the job, Brian Little.

The pair had worked together just 18 months earlier when Gregory had been Little's first-team coach before deciding to try his own hand at the managerial game with Wycombe Wanderers. Gregory asked for some advice from the man who had been there, seen it and worked with Villa's infamous chairman Doug Ellis - although he probably knew the answer before it was given.

'You've got three years at the most,' said Little, 'you need to win something within three years or start looking for a new job.' This advice has stayed with him throughout his tenure at Villa Park and has underpinned virtually every move he has made. From day one he has stamped his mark on the job - in the knowledge that the sword of Damocles could be cut loose at any time. He took a strategic decision to do the job on his terms. In that time, he's become a Holte End cult hero and put a bit of dash and bravado into a club that has become the epitome of Premier League conservatism.

However, he has discovered it harder to pull off than he first thought. To understand Gregory's problem, one has to get to grips with the men who employ him. Despite what the rank and file think, Ellis has done a fantastically good job at Villa Park. Yes, two decades ago Villa were the European Champions. But so too were Nottingham Forest. The club could not count itself among the six biggest in the Premiership, yet in terms of turnover it's the nineteenth-biggest in Europe. That was never the case when the self-made millionaire took over. The problem is that Ellis finds it difficult not to have a say in every part of the club - including the football. For example, Benito Carbone could have stayed at Villa for £30,000 a week. Gregory was told this figure would smash the wage structure and the deal was a no-go. The result? Two months later, David Ginola arrives for £3 million - on £35,000 a week.

Second, Gregory wants Benni McCarthy. The Ellis-led board harbours secret doubts about sanctioning an £8m deal, saying the fee is too high. They doubt whether South African McCarthy will play as many games as they hope because of his international commitments. Five months later, they stump up the cash to bring Colombian international Juan Pablo Angel to Villa Park for £9.5m. Privately at least, it is those double standards that are driving the Villa boss to distraction.

Former Villa manager Ron Atkinson is scathing about Ellis. His autobiography details the constant round of phone calls from the chairman. But even he once ate a piece of humble pie, making a pre-match call for unity on the PA system to a disgruntled Villa Park crowd when it sensed another potential signing, Dean Saunders, was going to slip from their grasp. Atkinson probably agreed with them but still swallowed his pride. Little, however, opted to meet as many of the chairman's requests as he could. Having followed Little closely for three years, I believe he came close to breaking point; he then tendered his resignation. Ellis will never win the war of words with Gregory in the fans' eyes; the manager is the man who really shares their ambitions. Gregory wants Villa to be the Manchester United of the Midlands.

But Ellis is only part of the problem. In the past, his behaviour could be tempered by secretary Steve Stride, who in pre-flotation days was a massively understated figure within the club. Gregory is close to Stride. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the financial director, Mark Ansell, Ellis's heir apparent. Ansell has the ear of the chairman and is known to be critical of Gregory's signings. He fears the £20m spent on thirtysomethings Dion Dublin, Paul Merson and Steve Stone will never be recouped. Yet if Gregory has alienated Ellis, the next man in line will have just as little hesitation in cutting the ties.

It is likely that Ellis will never relinquish the helm. Nevertheless, Ansell is building a power base that will probably see him take over. The most plausible forecast of what will happen should Ellis's reign end unexpectedly is that the shares Ellis holds will be put in trust for the club by a minimum of two trustholders. Ansell will be the first of those, Ellis's wife, Heidi, would be the second. The theory has been forwarded that any income from this 36.8 per cent shareholding would continue to go to the Ellis estate. The Villa chairman does have three sons, one of whom, Peter, was expected to take over his father's position. But a row over the family's business interests has left them barely on speaking terms, leaving the way open for former accountant Ansell. It puts Gregory in a distinctly uneasy position. When he needs friends, he won't find any at boardroom level with any muscle.

Yet the manager's record is good. He took over with the club at fifteenth and in his three seasons Villa have averaged a sixth-place finish and been to an FA Cup final - their first in 41 years. Gregory has spent a net amount of £4m per year on players. Ellis disputes the claim that Villa talk small and think big, but Gregory is trying to operate on a par with Chelsea, Leeds and Liverpool with the resources of a Coventry. The only thing that can keep him in a job is winning matches. A finish in the bottom half of the table, accompanied by an early FA Cup exit and a £9.5m striker flop could mean the end for Gregory. Ellis may have been accused of meddling but Gregory will find he is the weakest link - and we all know what that means: goodbye.

webTitle: An honest player makes up for all the tosh

fields.headline: An honest player makes up for all the tosh
fields.standfirst: Gareth Southgate gives you a reason for sticking with the tattered old game
fields.trailText: Gareth Southgate gives you a reason for sticking with the tattered old game.
fields.body:
You wonder, in weeks like this, why you still bother with it. Football a simple game? Try telling that to those trying to make sense of its corruption, tortuous reports of its transfer jungle; trying to work out what changes to lives and culture Sunday-night televised matches will make. And which beer bottlers will spend most money to allow the mixed-morals Premiership to promote its brand. Then you spend some time in the company of Gareth Southgate. Then you realise why.

But of him, more anon. A while back, no one really understood what the implications of the Bosman ruling would be, even if we grasped the acceptable theory of freedom of movement at the end of a contract. The price of civil liberty has been tedious year-long stories of will-he, won't-he go. Then, while poor Bosman himself tries to rebuild his impecunious life, ungrateful players cash in to an extent that would send Bruce Grobbelaar's envy a darker shade of Alan Green. Now, ironically in the week that marks 40 years since the maximum wage was abolished in this country, even the players you speak to - at least the older ones who have enjoyed their life in the game and can now see a bigger picture - believe the balance of power has shifted too far the other way.

They fear that if the transfer system breaks down totally, if players are allowed to hand in notice that they intend to move mid-contract for mind-boggling sums elsewhere, then their already-stretching loyalty will snap. Confronted by seasonal itinerants, spectators will tire of supporting a come-and-go collection purporting to represent their club. In Switzerland, Uefa and Fifa have fiddled all week as the smouldering threatens to turn into flames. Diplomacy and politics delayed compromise and solution, so that clubs refuse to spend large sums on transfers while an agreement with the European Commission is pending. Except some desperate English ones, like Leeds United and Aston Villa.

That may actually be no bad thing, come to think of it. Watching Villa play Newcastle United in midweek, what struck most was the sheer volume of average overseas players on view, particularly in the Newcastle midfield. Having written otherwise before Christmas, and seeing workaday Sunderland reach second place, I am coming round to the view that this is an ordinary Premiership. Surely managers can find cheaper, hungrier and teachable players just as average in the Nationwide League? At home, we hear of live and televised games being dotted wall-to-wall around the weekend TV schedules from next season, as if the current three-day event was not enough.

What used to be a treat is in danger of becoming mere trifle. The greater exposure to mediocrity could well backfire. And here, let me share the experience of taking my son to Tottenham v Newcastle a few weeks ago. He loved it, all six goals and three red cards of it, which was gratifying. Only one player, Kieron Dyer, lifted it above the knockabout, however. And it cost £96 for the two of us. Few can afford to take kids as regularly as in the past, which could spawn a generation of irregular attenders.

Then we come to the Premiership's sponsorship deal as they argue which is best, £13 million a season from long-time partners Carling - who have now pulled out of contract-renewal talks - or £15 million from Budweiser, an increasingly likely scenario. The debate, it seems, is about the money rather than the desirability of the English game being associated with those sponsors and the very product that has fuelled the country's disgrace at fixtures abroad. To cap it all, three judges decided that Grobbelaar, after all, had taken money to fix matches in the early Nineties. The FA were relieved when it went to judgment and went away; now it is back to open what Alan Partridge would call the whole nest of viper's eggs, fertilised by the bungs report.

Contemplating football's week again, my mind gratefully recalled an encounter with Gareth Southgate on Wednesday night. Paul Merson had invited me for a meal in a Villa Park lounge after the match and we talked with Southgate. He had been forced off the pitch just before half-time with damaged knee ligaments and sat in some pain. He blamed nothing but his own poor control, which had led to his overstretching for a ball. In his 40-odd minutes on the pitch he showed the consistent composure that continues to make him one of England's most reliable and constructive defenders.

This against a backdrop of his wanting a transfer, not for more money, but simply because he believes he would be more likely to win trophies elsewhere. Southgate has not agitated for the move, however, as some players might do, by refusing to play, or adopting a disruptive daily attitude that forces the manager to modify a prohibitive £10 million price tag and get rid of him. Nor does he shield behind an agent who might do it on his behalf.

Southgate has just got on with his job, trying to hold together a team that everyone knows is short of the top drawer. 'I can see it logically,' he admitted. 'Looking at it from the club's point of view, I suppose I wouldn't let me go either.' As Merson drove him home, Southgate stretched out on the back seat with his crutches. I asked him if he would like to be a manager one day. His reply was saddening. 'I would, but I'm not sure if you'll be in control of players, with all the changes coming into the game,' he said. And this is a man who would undoubtedly benefit from a change that would enable him just to hand in his notice.

The thoughtful decent Southgate certainly has all the credentials to make an outstanding manager. If men like him do not stay in the game, football will suffer. It could mirror politics, where some of the best brains, the most able men, are frightened off by the cynical, peripheral stuff and nonsense. Southgate and honest players like him are the reason why you do stick with the grand, tattered old game. fields.bodyText: You wonder, in weeks like this, why you still bother with it. Football a simple game? Try telling that to those trying to make sense of its corruption, tortuous reports of its transfer jungle; trying to work out what changes to lives and culture Sunday-night televised matches will make. And which beer bottlers will spend most money to allow the mixed-morals Premiership to promote its brand. Then you spend some time in the company of Gareth Southgate. Then you realise why. But of him, more anon. A while back, no one really understood what the implications of the Bosman ruling would be, even if we grasped the acceptable theory of freedom of movement at the end of a contract. The price of civil liberty has been tedious year-long stories of will-he, won't-he go. Then, while poor Bosman himself tries to rebuild his impecunious life, ungrateful players cash in to an extent that would send Bruce Grobbelaar's envy a darker shade of Alan Green. Now, ironically in the week that marks 40 years since the maximum wage was abolished in this country, even the players you speak to - at least the older ones who have enjoyed their life in the game and can now see a bigger picture - believe the balance of power has shifted too far the other way. They fear that if the transfer system breaks down totally, if players are allowed to hand in notice that they intend to move mid-contract for mind-boggling sums elsewhere, then their already-stretching loyalty will snap. Confronted by seasonal itinerants, spectators will tire of supporting a come-and-go collection purporting to represent their club. In Switzerland, Uefa and Fifa have fiddled all week as the smouldering threatens to turn into flames. Diplomacy and politics delayed compromise and solution, so that clubs refuse to spend large sums on transfers while an agreement with the European Commission is pending. Except some desperate English ones, like Leeds United and Aston Villa. That may actually be no bad thing, come to think of it. Watching Villa play Newcastle United in midweek, what struck most was the sheer volume of average overseas players on view, particularly in the Newcastle midfield. Having written otherwise before Christmas, and seeing workaday Sunderland reach second place, I am coming round to the view that this is an ordinary Premiership. Surely managers can find cheaper, hungrier and teachable players just as average in the Nationwide League? At home, we hear of live and televised games being dotted wall-to-wall around the weekend TV schedules from next season, as if the current three-day event was not enough. What used to be a treat is in danger of becoming mere trifle. The greater exposure to mediocrity could well backfire. And here, let me share the experience of taking my son to Tottenham v Newcastle a few weeks ago. He loved it, all six goals and three red cards of it, which was gratifying. Only one player, Kieron Dyer, lifted it above the knockabout, however. And it cost £96 for the two of us. Few can afford to take kids as regularly as in the past, which could spawn a generation of irregular attenders. Then we come to the Premiership's sponsorship deal as they argue which is best, £13 million a season from long-time partners Carling - who have now pulled out of contract-renewal talks - or £15 million from Budweiser, an increasingly likely scenario. The debate, it seems, is about the money rather than the desirability of the English game being associated with those sponsors and the very product that has fuelled the country's disgrace at fixtures abroad. To cap it all, three judges decided that Grobbelaar, after all, had taken money to fix matches in the early Nineties. The FA were relieved when it went to judgment and went away; now it is back to open what Alan Partridge would call the whole nest of viper's eggs, fertilised by the bungs report. Contemplating football's week again, my mind gratefully recalled an encounter with Gareth Southgate on Wednesday night. Paul Merson had invited me for a meal in a Villa Park lounge after the match and we talked with Southgate. He had been forced off the pitch just before half-time with damaged knee ligaments and sat in some pain. He blamed nothing but his own poor control, which had led to his overstretching for a ball. In his 40-odd minutes on the pitch he showed the consistent composure that continues to make him one of England's most reliable and constructive defenders. This against a backdrop of his wanting a transfer, not for more money, but simply because he believes he would be more likely to win trophies elsewhere. Southgate has not agitated for the move, however, as some players might do, by refusing to play, or adopting a disruptive daily attitude that forces the manager to modify a prohibitive £10 million price tag and get rid of him. Nor does he shield behind an agent who might do it on his behalf. Southgate has just got on with his job, trying to hold together a team that everyone knows is short of the top drawer. 'I can see it logically,' he admitted. 'Looking at it from the club's point of view, I suppose I wouldn't let me go either.' As Merson drove him home, Southgate stretched out on the back seat with his crutches. I asked him if he would like to be a manager one day. His reply was saddening. 'I would, but I'm not sure if you'll be in control of players, with all the changes coming into the game,' he said. And this is a man who would undoubtedly benefit from a change that would enable him just to hand in his notice. The thoughtful decent Southgate certainly has all the credentials to make an outstanding manager. If men like him do not stay in the game, football will suffer. It could mirror politics, where some of the best brains, the most able men, are frightened off by the cynical, peripheral stuff and nonsense. Southgate and honest players like him are the reason why you do stick with the grand, tattered old game. When it kicks off at 3pm on a Saturday (or a Sunday at 1pm, 4pm and possibly next season 7pm), the tosh of the previous seven days that surrounds it goes out of the window. Just don't keep trying our patience, though.

webTitle: Calais unable to find heart in Cup battle

fields.headline: Calais unable to find heart in Cup battle
fields.standfirst: Simon Kuper sees last year's heroes go down without a fight
fields.trailText: Last year's French Cup heroes went down without a fight this time around.
fields.body:
It was never going to happen twice. The march of fourth-division Calais to the French Cup Final last year was the most exciting thing to have happened to the French game since the World Cup, bigger, many thought, than winning Euro 2000.

It was the best story in European football.

Yesterday Calais tried to repeat it. About 9,000 of the town's citizens had come to Amiens in the Somme for this fourth-round cup-tie (Calais' own ground is not up to scratch) and most of them stood throughout. But this time their team were outclassed in a 3-1 defeat.

Last year was extraordinary. This town of 80,000 people, where unemployment stands at 15 per cent and many of those who do have jobs earn next to nothing selling drink to British daytrippers, where the communists have held the town hall for three decades, captivated France. The players had to beg time off from their bosses to get to games, but ended up playing in the Stade de France, where they held Nantes until the 90th minute of the final before succumbing to a ludicrous penalty. They even got to meet Zinedine Zidane! It was a French version of The Full Monty, complete with shirt-stripping after the semi-final.

Calais played yesterday with almost all of last year's heroes. They had hung on to them largely by promising them better jobs, which was not difficult since most of them worked in cash-and-carries and the like. Just after New Year, however, their playmaker Emmanuel Vasseur succumbed to the lure of big money. That is, he signed for Leyton Orient.

Calais were furious, and seemed to have delayed the transfer but they were without Vasseur yesterday, though he was said to be among the crowd. Nico Thiriot, a wine buyer for Sainsbury's in England, son of the Calais managing director Claude Thiriot, raged: 'He's got a little brain, unfortunately'.

Orient have offered to resolve the disputes by playing a friendly against Calais, but as Claude Thiriot noted: 'The whole world wants to play against us....'

Calais, playing in baggy red-and-yellow shirts reminiscent of long ago, certainly seemed to miss Vasseur. They tackled vigorously, but had trouble controlling the ball, which kept bouncing off the wrong bits of their bodies.

Sedan went ahead after 14 minutes. Moussa N'Diaye broke down the right, his cross beat the Calais defence, and Olivier Quint finished cleanly. At times Quint showed there is a difference between divisions, playing accurately at pace and creating several chances from the left wing. It's a shame that being a star in the French league nowadays means you have barely a chance of making the national team.

For much of the first half Sedan played with Calais. Then Calais scored out of nothing. On 41 minutes, they were granted a mysterious free-kick to the right of the Sedan penalty area. The ball was lifted across, there was a tangle of bodies, a couple of players fell over, and suddenly the referee was pointing to the spot.

The crowd roared, partly in disbelief. This was perhaps a compensation for the penalty that cost them the Cup last May. Reginald Becque placed the spot kick high in the side netting.

It was the sort of Somme evening that made you understand why First World War memoirs were so obsessed with the weather. It was so cold that every toe hurt, and in the second half the air grew white with freezing mist.

The match - the context aside - was depressing. Sedan are out of form and Calais are not very good. Though there was blood and guts and yellow cards, there were few fluent moves nor chances.

Gradually Calais tired and after 72 minutes Sedan scored again. A misunderstanding in the Calais defence allowed Cedric Janeau to appear in front of the Calais keeper Cedric Schille, and when they both fell over after a lawless tussle, Pius Sielenu N'Diefu drove into an empty net. In the 85th minute N'Diefu broke through the Calais defence at pace, edged the ball to Mionnet, who hit the post, and from the rebound Quint tapped in his second.

The upshot was that the little guys won. Sedan is a depressed Ardennes town a quarter the size of Calais and the club's rise from the French third division to fourth place in the Championnat is at least as remarkable as Calais' feat of last year.

Calais won't be too upset. Their coach Ladislao Lozano, says the main thing this season is to get out of the fourth division. They are currently lying top.

webTitle: West Brom keep up pressure

fields.headline: West Brom keep up pressure
fields.standfirst: League review.
fields.trailText: Below Fulham and Bolton, West Brom kept up the pressure on fellow contenders Birmingham and Blackburn - who meet today at St Andrews - with a 2-1 win over Sheffield United at The Hawthorns, courtesy of Lee Hughes's 83rd-minute winner.
fields.body:
Below Fulham and Bolton, West Brom kept up the pressure on fellow contenders Birmingham and Blackburn - who meet today at St Andrews - with a 2-1 win over Sheffield United at The Hawthorns, courtesy of Lee Hughes's 83rd-minute winner.

The home side had taken the lead through Ruel Fox after 62 minutes before Paul Peschisolido, on-loan from Fulham, scored on his Blades debut to equalise for the visitors, who were down to 10 men for almost an hour after Robert Ullathorne was dismissed on 32 minutes following a second booking.

Another man deemed surplus to requirements by Fulham is midfielder Steve Hayward, who signed for Barnsley on Friday on a three-and-a-half-year deal. He capped his debut for the Tykes with a 77th minute goal at Burnley, but the Clarets were already 2-0 up by then and Barnsley were unable to prevent Burnley registering their first league win in six weeks . Barnsley, too, were reduced to 10 men early in the second half with the sending off of Chris Morgan.

Crystal Palace's fabled fighting spirit, which has served them so well in cup competitions this season, rescued them in the league yesterday as they pulled back a 2-0 deficit at home to Gillingham.

Mark Saunders struck just before the break for the Gills and again on the hour as Palace, but substitute Dougie Freedman pulled one back for Palace and Mikael Forssell scored his eleventh goal of the season to level six minutes from time.

A dreary first half sparked into life on 44 minutes when the Eagles failed miserably to clear Nicky Southall's corner and Saunders nipped in to head over the line to put Gillingham into the lead.

After the break Asaba missed a sitter after being put clean through by Saunders and Paul Shaw and Chris Hope also missed useful chances before Southall doubled the visitors' lead on 60 minutes.

Southall's free-kick from the left was met at the near post by Saunders, who neatly tucked away his header giving Alex Kolinko no chance.

Gillingham were looking forward to their first ever double in the First Division when Palace, who looked second best, struck with two goals inside three minutes.

Freedman squeezed Andrejs Rubins' cross from the left just inside the post on 81 minutes and six minutes from time Forssell continued his prolific scoring run with a 20-yard low shot into the far corner.

It set up a pulsating finale but Gillingham held out to stretch their unbeaten run to seven matches and deny the Worthington Cup semi-finalists, who travel to Liverpool for their second leg with a 2-1 advantage on Wednesday.

webTitle: Said & Done

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Circulation wars: big boys rattled
fields.body:
Circulation wars: big boys rattled

The Non-League Paper - a 10-month-old publication for non-league followers - is out-selling Sunday Business for full price sales. The news came with the latest ABC circulation figures, calculated minus bulk/giveaway copies. Sunday Business are currently giving away/leaving in Happy Eaters more than 30 per cent of their headline sales - meaning they flog just 37,824 copies each week. The Non-League Paper, meanwhile, currently racks up 42,856 full-price sales - almost 25 per cent of the Independent on Sunday's figure, and closing fast.

Fifa & racism: quote of the week

Head of Communications Keith Cooper, explaining Fifa's inability to tackle racism in Serie A : 'I've asked colleagues in the Italian federation why it's such a problem? Italy is a sophisticated country and doesn't have a long tradition of racism.'

So Mussolini, his 1940s 'pure race' enforcers, the Roman slave merchants and the persecution of Jews are presumably not linked, then, to the spirit of the recent Olympic Stadium banner: 'Israel was your birthplace, Auschwitz is your home'.

United plc: net widens

Nastiest new Manchester United product of the week: The official MUFC Maths Workbook 4 - key stage 2 for 7-11 year olds. Inside, kids romp through sums and problems all relating to the Reds, and will especially love pages 12-13, titled 'Sarah and her friends visit the Manchester United megastore'. 'Jordan has £30 to spend,' asks one question. 'If he buys a pair of shorts, has he enough money left for a keyring and a programme?' Next, 'What change from £50 will Leanne get if she buys a shirt and a cap?' Kids are provided with full product price lists to help their mathematical development.

Girl power gets savage

Leicester's Robbie Savage has been voted third most attractive football babe in an online poll. Sky presenter Kirsty Gallacher came top with 44,720 votes on the football365 website, Louise second with 42,925 while blond stunner Savage beat Lisa Rogers, Caprice and S Club 7 singer Hannah Spearritt to bronze. Sports Minister Kate Hoey came in eleventh.

Maradona legs it

Argentine club Almagro have been stunned by the news that Diego Maradona - announced as new club manager 12 weeks ago, has denied it ever happened. Maradona was due to take charge in November, but now claims he never really said yes to the deal. It seems he lost interest shortly after making his first - and so far only - appearance at the club to meet his new squad. He still hasn't seen them in action. 'We just don't know what's happened,' says a spokesman. Recent tax distractions could have played a part: Maradona's agent last week demanded $8m for an exhibition match at Napoli, turned down a $250k offer to fly to Saudi Arabia, but could now be sending his man to Libya - if the price is right.

Mellor: may he rest in silence

It's finally happened: the 'vile, free-loading' 'profoundly irritating' 'unusually ugly' 'worm on an oil slick' 'sweaty oaf' David Mellor (as described by the Mirror, Times, House of Commons and official website) is finally quitting his Five Live phone-in. The move comes after months of pressure - and, rather like his 1997 election defeat speech, he's taken it with trademark bad grace. 'I don't suppose anyone will ever do such a long stint (on 606) again,' he wrote last week, 'even if Five Live's phone-ins survive much longer... which they may well not.' So who's to blame for the failure? 'Apart from being over the moon, or sick as parrot, [these callers] don't have much else to offer'. The words 'Out, out, out' spring happily to mind.

Leyton Orient: the winner

A massive response to last week's Herb Alpert/Tijuana Taxi competition: the answer was c) - Barry Hearn tried to replace the Leyton Orient pre-match classic with We Will Rock You, not Money Talks or Whiter Shade of Pale. The winner is Lol Ross of Walthamstow - Herb's greatest hits, produced by Randy Badazz, are on the way.

webTitle: Interview: Deborah Warner

fields.headline: The mother of all tragedies
fields.standfirst:
Deborah Warner is no stranger to bathing English theatre in the blood of the Greeks. But returning with a modern Medea, played by longtime collaborator Fiona Shaw, audiences are swooning in the aisles

More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: Deborah Warner is no stranger to bathing English theatre in the blood of the Greeks. But returning with a modern Medea, played by longtime collaborator Fiona Shaw, audiences are swooning in the aisles
fields.body:
More than a decade ago ago, I met Deborah Warner in Paris. She was 29. She was already celebrated for her splendidly gruesome production of Titus Andronicus for the RSC and was directing Fiona Shaw in Sophocles's Electra. It was the first time the two women had worked together. Warner told me then that she was in the grip of 'total obsession'. The production was wonderful: Shaw turned sorrow into a character; she brought Greek tragedy almost too close for comfort. What neither woman could have known then was that Electra also marked the beginning of a remarkable theatrical collaboration and friendship. Warner seemed aware, at that time, only that the intensity of her working life might prove unsustainable: 'I may surprise everyone one day and stop,' she told me.

It is an icy Friday night and we are having dinner in a London restaurant. It seems as though Fortune's wheel has come full circle: Warner and Shaw are at work on another Greek tragedy, Medea by Euripides. Yet from the way Warner talks, it seems that there is something valedictory in the air. The production began in Dublin last summer. When she first took it on, after nearly five years of work that was not 'text-based', she felt 'not high pleasure but dread. It was not a celebratory moment. I had thought I'd never revisit the Greeks'. She did not want to repeat herself and yet was conscious that this was a bad starting point for a piece of work. She wondered: 'What will happen if Medea needs the same vocabulary [as Electra]?'

Everything seemed to be 'spinning out of control'. They had worked on Ibsen (Shaw was Hedda Gabler), Brecht, Shakespeare, Beckett and T.S. Eliot (their performance of The Waste Land travelled the world). Perhaps there was nothing more to add. 'Fiona and I were afraid the fluency had gone. We were fearful that we had lost something. It wasn't obvious where to go next and we were both a little sad.' And in rehearsal, unusually, Warner found herself at a loss. 'I did not trust what bubbled up to the surface. It was so provocative and outrageous that I thought: this cannot be true. And I ignored it. But it was the heart of the thing.'

She has since had the strongest reassurance from Irish audiences and critics who have found nothing meretricious in her production. Now she is in rehearsal again, with a slightly different cast. Jonathan Cake (most recently seen as the romantic lead in Tennessee Williams's Baby Doll) plays Jason. She has come to trust Shaw's modern Medea who is, if reviewers have it right, frighteningly believable in her little black dress and who even, occasionally, elicits a laugh from audiences. But at the end, some people in the audience have swooned - one or two have even been sick - as Medea kills her little boys, to punish her faithless husband.

Deborah Warner does not look like a person drawn to the cruel verge of human experience. She is tall, elegant, resolutely untheatrical (she wears no make-up) with a cap of fair hair. She reminds me of a calm hostess who is concerned for her guests and knows that, no matter how anarchic the occasion, order must have its place. (There is something maternal, in this, too.) She would laugh at this description - quick to see unintended irony in everything.

She is far more interested in the work than in herself. She is less earnest than she used to be, more voluble and relaxed - if anything, less grown-up (a good thing). I scarcely know her but feel as though she is a friend. Is she still obsessive? 'Yes,' she laughs. I am struck by the way that she does not talk about 'directing' work; she uses, instead, the verb 'to make', as if pottery was her thing. It occurs to me that if I were to choose a single image for her, it would be earth. She is earth to Shaw's air, water and fire. She is the perfect foil to Shaw's volatile gifts.

During rehearsal periods she describes herself as 'blinkered' and 'utterly unable to do anything else'. She expects absolute commitment from actors, too. 'You can choose to create conditions in which there is no world outside the rehearsal room. Players who have a foot somewhere else are not that serious.' And yet she sticks her neck out to say that Medea is more relevant to us than the work of most contemporary playwrights. She was never sickened herself by the material, but is fascinated by people who faint on seeing her production. She surprises me by suggesting that it shows a profound identification with the material. 'We'd really like to know why they faint,' she says with a twinkle in her eye.

The night we meet, the story of Anna Climbie, abused and murdered by her aunt, has just broken. Warner has not had time to look at the newspapers but interrogates me, wants to know exactly how Anna was abused, why she died. I fudge the details. They are 'very close' and have a 'shorthand' but are watchful in order that the rest of the cast should not feel snubbed. Last summer, it all became too much for her. She was 'exhausted'. At last, she did what she'd threatened to: she stopped. It was her mid-life crisis, she says. She went to Hydra in Greece (favoured by Leonard Cohen), where there are 'no cars - only donkeys' and she was - most of the time - on her own. This was a new experience. She stayed for seven weeks, swam every day, read 30 novels. She finds London too distracting for reading. 'It is exciting - but we are having a bit of a party here, aren't we?' she says, with her best hostess smile.

Medea is at the Queen's Theatre, London W1 (020 7494 5040)

Warner's World

Childhood
Born 1960. Brought up in a Quaker family in Burford, Oxfordshire. Studied at Central School of Speech and Drama, London

1987 Joined the Royal Shakespeare Company as resident director
1989 Royal National Theatre as associate director

Awards
1989 Laurence Olivier and Evening Standard Awards for Best Director for Titus Andronicus
1992 Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres
1992 Laurence Olivier Awards for Best Director and Best Production for Hedda Gabler
1998 New York Drama Desk Award for The Waste Land; Evening Standard and South Bank Show Awards for The Turn of the Screw

What they say
Fiona Shaw 'Deborah plays the role of director as a cipher. It is a non-academic way of working'
Brian Cox 'Quite simply the best director of her generation'

Censored
1994 Production of Beckett's Footfalls at the Garrick was pulled after two performances by the Beckett estate because Warner didn't adhere to his stringent stage directions.

webTitle: Abbey lifts the tension

fields.headline: Abbey lifts the tension
fields.standfirst: Will Buckley sees Norwich win a grim relegation tussle
fields.trailText: Abbey lifts the Canaries' tension.
fields.body:
There is a major congestion at the bottom of Division One. Before the start of play yesterday only six points separated the 12 teams who make up the bottom half of the division. The conflation is such that bottom club Crewe have amassed sufficient points to put them in fifteenth place in the Premiership, sixth from last in Division Two or fifth from bottom in Division Three. It's a messy pile-up and stuck right in the middle are Norwich and QPR, both desperately in need of a flurry of victories to ease them clear of the trouble. This desperation showed at Carrow Road yesterday as Norwich edged home.

Neither side started well. There was haste when thought was required; hesitancy when there was a need for speed. But of the two Norwich were relatively the more impressive. Early on, Iwan Roberts played Chris Llewellyn into a promising position but he skewed his shot past the post. Next, a cross from Darel Russell was volleyed wide.

As for Rangers, everything revolved round Peter Crouch, who at six ft six in, and looking a tad undernourished, possesses the unlikeliest physique in the League. Good in the air, obviously, he is also no mug on the ground. Buoyed by being yesterday morning's cover boy in The Sun's Supergoals on Saturday (nickname at school 'Sticks'; 10 GCSEs; 'My Dad, Bruce, is about 15 stone and an inch shorter but even he has started calling me "Rodders" now!') he had a stormer, making light of the taunts of 'freak, freak, freak' aimed at him by the normally mild-mannered Norwich supporters.

It was his threatening presence - height-wise if not width-wise - that harried Darren Kenton into heading the ball towards his own goal only for Andy Marshall to tip over. It was also his lay-off that allowed Stuart Wardley to shoot and force Marshall to repeat the action.

Norwich, meanwhile, did little. A Lee Marshall shot from long range was never going anywhere other than over the bar and it was fol lowed by another that was never going anywhere other than wide. Some niggle entered the game, the fussy Mr Clatenburg intervened over often and the Norwich crowd screamed, 'You're not fit to referee.'

Then the impressive Russell - he can pass and he has pace, which made him doubly unique in such moderate surroundings - stormed down the left and crossed only for Coote to spurn the chance. So QPR gave them another, failing to head clear a Kenton free-kick not once but twice. It eventually fell to Roberts, who headed it back for Zema Abbey to score with ease. A minute later, Roberts nearly managed to divert his toe-poke past Ludek Miklosko. The half ended with Crouch, who had been in turn spearhead of the attack, midfield creator and right-back, making a tackle at left-back. Surely all that running should put some meat on his legs.

Rangers replaced the gloved and uninspired Steve Morrow with Sammy Koejoe after half-time to limited effect. There was more passion to their play but little precision. Norwich, somewhat complacently, seemed happy to sit on their lead. Time passed. Coote came off, Jean Yves De Blassis came on. Rangers ran, Norwich contained. Both sides won throw-ins.

To their credit, the Rangers fans kept singing, perhaps reasoning that where there's Crouch there's hope although the slim fellow, having run himself into the ground, was less effective in the second-half and it was he who wasted their best, indeed only, chance with a tired effort.

On it went. Koejoe missed out on an opportunity to be the subject of punning tabloid headlines, Roberts nearly scored by accident and fussy Mr Clattenburg suffered from cramp.

Norwich restricted themselves to shooting from long range: Russell impressively, Yves De Blassis less so. Clattenburg retired hurt. 'You're not fit to referee,' the fans reprised. Time was wasted.

But Norwich hung on and completed a good week for their chairman, Bob Cooper. On Thursday night, after a speech from Delia Smith, variously described as 'rousing' and 'show-stopping', he had easily survived a vote of no confidence at the AGM. Now he had three points to ease his team's worries.

webTitle: Arsenal's lame finish

fields.headline: Arsenal's lame finish
fields.trailText: Ten-man Foxes hold out.
fields.body:
Two teams struggling for confidence and form combined to produce a messy and ill-tempered match, 10-man Leicester the more pleased at having stopped the rot of three successive Premiership matches that began with a 6-1 thrashing at Highbury on Boxing Day. Rarely can there have been so much incident in a goalless draw, however.

For the home fans there were mixed feelings, satisfaction at having clung on for a point after the sending-off of Matthew Jones in the first-half but anger at the failure of referee Barry Knight to dismiss Silvinho for hauling back their debutant Dean Sturridge in the second in an episode that even Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger conceded might have yielded a red card.

Filbert Street's noisy displeasure was increased by Patrick Vieira escaping unpunished after a mistimed tackle on Robbie Savage, but then fans are by nature one-eyed. Besides, you never know where you are with Savage. Late in the game he went down as if shot after running into Martin Keown's elbow, an offence for which the hesitant Mr Knight issued an unmerited yellow card.

All these talking points cannot paper over the cracks in both teams, or perhaps the fragmented rhythm of the game was a reflection of their travails. Arsenal dominated territorially and as usual created a host of chances. As usual lately, they misfired. Leicester were content simply to contain, apart from an early period when Arsenal's sloppiness threatened to undo them.

'We are frustrated because we should have won,' said Wenger. 'But we lacked a little bit of sharpness in the box.' He was wrong. They, especially the wasteful Sylvain Wiltord, lacked a lot of sharpness in the box.

'It might have been an exciting game for some people because we held on for a point but I do feel that officials can ruin games,' said the Leicester manager Peter Taylor. He also had to explain away a row between Savage and Gerry Taggart just before half-time, which apparently spilled into the tunnel at the interval: 'they both care'. It says much about Savage that he is willing to take on a team-mate, and the towering Taggart at that.

Taylor is a believer in youth but his signing, and immediate awarding of a debut to the 36-year-old Italian Roberto Mancini, who had not played a competitive match for eight months, illustrated the desperation creeping in at the club recently. Mancini showed neat touches early on, as befits such a pedigree with Sampdoria, Lazio and national team, but struggled with the pace of the game.

It was in Mancini's first flourish that Leicester threatened. First, Andy Impey volleyed just wide then Sturridge, a £350,000 signing from Derby, took Muzzy Izzet's header off Mancini's toe when he seemed he only had a tap-in.

Otherwise, it was all Arsenal. After sending two ugly shots over the crossbar, it seemed that Wiltord had given them a lead when he sent a low cross-shot past Simon Royce after dancing past Gary Rowett and Matt Elliott, only for the ball to rebound from the far post.

When Jones was sent off for a spiteful ankle tap on Freddie Ljungberg after 38 minutes, having earlier been booked for fouling Wiltord, it seemed certain Arsenal would press home their advantage. Replacing Ljungberg for the second half, the elegant £6million Brazilian Edu began a promising debut, only to limp off with a hamstring injury 15 minutes into it. He is likely to be out for three weeks.

It was from his pass spread wide that Silvinho crossed and Robert Pires, a shadow of the dynamic figure of autumn, shot goalwards - Thierry Henry seeing his touch kicked away by Royce, who also beat away shots by Ray Parlour and Pires moments later. Henry also clipped the outside of a post from Parlour's low shot. His tame late shot straight at Royce ultimately summed up Arsenal's finishing, however.

Leicester's only real chance came when Sturridge looked to latch on to a clearance, only to be dragged back by Silvinho on the halfway line. Even if Lee Dixon was covering, it should have been a red card for plain old-fashioned cheating.

The home side's enduring spirit in adversity - they also lost Muzzy Izzet with a neck injury - was commendable but class should still have prevailed. The consolation for Arsenal was that captain Tony Adams came through unscathed after a three-match absence. If they are to halt a decline that has seen them take only three points in four matches, they will need his traditional banging of heads together.

Henry also clipped the outside of a post from Parlour's low shot. His tame late shot straight at Royce ultimately summed up Arsenal's finishing, however. Leicester's only real chance came when Sturridge looked to latch on to a clearance, only to be dragged back by Silvinho on the halfway line. Even if Lee Dixon was covering, it should have been a red card for plain old-fashioned cheating. The home side's enduring spirit in adversity - they also lost Muzzy Izzet with a neck injury - was commendable but class should still have prevailed. The consolation for Arsenal was that captain Tony Adams came through unscathed after a three-match absence. If they are to halt a decline that has seen them take only three points in four matches, they will need his traditional banging of heads together.

webTitle: Bolton help Owls down the slippery slope

fields.headline: Bolton help Owls down the slippery slope
fields.trailText: Wanderers make it seven wins in eight.
fields.body:
Bolton have been in the top six all season and after their run of seven wins from eight games indicate they are going to be difficult to dislodge from an automatic promotion spot.

Prior to the game Sheffield Wednesday fans were able to watch the 1991 League Cup Final victory against Manchester United. But the first-half performance was a long way from Wembley and shows how far in such a short period of time they have declined. In the first half they failed to trouble the visitors' goalkeeper.

Bolton were the more assured and their precise passing, coupled with the pace and power of Michael Ricketts and Ricardo Gardner, was a constant threat.

Both teams had good opportunities but the difference between the teams was that Bolton made theirs pay while Wednesday squandered their good positions. Bolton's pressure paid off after 19 minutes when a long ball out of defence was flicked on by Ricketts into the path of Gardner who held off his marker before unleashing a left-foot low shot past the advancing Marlon Beresford. The goal had a marked effect on both teams with Bolton's confident rising while Wednesday's receded. The visitors should have gone further ahead on the half-hour when Per Frandsen's through ball sliced open a static Wednesday defence, who were appealing for offside, into the path of Ricketts whose shot was turned round for a corner. Wednesday's defence were in constant trouble, not helped by the late withdrawal of Des Walker.

Bolton's play deserved another goal and it came five minutes before half-time. A long diagonal ball from Frandsen was met by Bo Hansen, who hit another looping ball into the path of Ricketts. He chested the ball down and drove home his 15th goal of the season.

After the interval Wednesday manager Paul Jewell took off a defender in Ian Hendon and brought on a forward in Owen Morrison, and Wednesday showed some improvements. Yet despite having the better of possession, it was Bolton who almost increased their lead. Wednesday were again prised open and Bolton's captain, Gudni Bergsson, was through on goal only to be foiled by a full-length save from Beresford.

Wednesday brought on another forward, Matthew Hamshaw, in an effort to salvage something and almost immediately nearly reduced the arrears. A cross by Hamshaw found Alan Quinn, but his header went straight into the arms of Bolton keeper Steve Banks. Two minutes later Gerald Sibon hit a 30-yard free-kick which beat Banks but hit the bar.

Two minutes from time Bolton put the game beyond any doubt when they scored a third. Substitute Ian Marshall received the ball from a throw-in, held off his marker and hit a volley on the turn six yards from goal.

Wednesday are in danger of relegation for the second successive season. In attempting to cut their financial cloth after relegation from the Premiership, they have failed to cope with life in the First Division. But not to worry, for the fans can keep watching the in-house videos.
