webTitle: Eriksson hoaxed again

fields.headline: Eriksson hoaxed again
fields.trailText: Eriksson endures the humdrum.
fields.body:
Just what Sven-Göran Eriksson needed, another cruel hoax. Sir Alex Ferguson decided to rest David Beckham on the day the new England manager came to Manchester United for the first time, and with Paul Scholes and Gareth Southgate out injured and Wes Brown and Andy Cole on the bench, a fixture that may have yielded an entire England team ended up featuring more possibles than probables.

One could be positive and argue that Eriksson already knows about Beckham, Scholes et al, whereas he now knows more than he did about the likes of Jonathan Greening and Lee Hendrie, though anyone present at this match could hardly fail to draw a couple of more depressing conclusions about the top of the Premiership. One is that the Theatre of Dreams stages its fair share of humdrum games, of which this was a prime example; another is that Manchester United can look incredibly ordinary without their star turns in midfield. If Beckham is really asking for £160,000 a week, a tape of this match might be all he needs to get United to pay up. And Scholes might soon be thinking of a number and doubling it as well.

Eriksson said the game had been like the two he saw last week: interesting but not beautiful. He can say that again. To all intents and purposes nothing happened in a featureless first half. Ryan Giggs was United's liveliest attacker without ever managing to deliver the telling final pass, while David James made a sharp early save from Ole Gunnar Solskjaer before demonstrating that Dracula jokes are not wholly unfounded - punching his first corner unconvincingly and scrambling a save from Teddy Sheringham after failing to cut out Giggs's cross.

That was the best chance of the first half until Greening shot over on the stroke of the interval. Villa, apart from one hopeful drive from Paul Merson, hardly bothered Fabien Barthez at all. The visitors gave the promised debut to £9.5 million Colombian Juan Pablo Angel, who predictably looked cold and out of touch despite showing one or two deft touches. Angel will need time, of course, but it is already being unkindly suggested that Villa already have David Ginola performing that function.

Unsurprisingly, the Frenchman was another absentee at the start. Those who interpreted John Gregory's comments last week as a thinly disguised hint to pack his bags must have been mildly astonished to see Ginola on the bench, although to judge by the kids and reserves keeping him company in the dug-out, Villa's player shortage has not been exaggerated. If Ginola is coming towards the end of his brief Villa career, however, it begs the question of why he was bought in the first place. As Duncan McKenzie said all those years ago: 'I can't understand why managers buy airy-fairy players like me then try to turn them into runners. If they want a runner, why don't they just sign David Bedford?'

Mercifully, the game showed signs of life after the interval. Perhaps realising United might be there for the taking, Villa came out looking for a goal and almost had one when Angel's dangerous cross caught Dion Dublin in two minds: lay off or shoot? Then a superb ball from Merson played Hendrie behind a square United defence but, while admiring the lightning reactions from Barthez in closing down the youngster, Villa really should have taken the lead. They were unlucky not to in their next attack when Greening had to clear off the line from the impressive Gareth Barry, but there was a certain inevitability about the rest of the game as Villa accepted they were unlikely to get a better opportunity.

Only James offered resistance, making a commendable triple save from Sheringham, Roy Keane and then Solskjaer, which must have impressed Eriksson. James was much less happy a minute later, unsighted by one of his own defenders as Gary Neville touched Keane's free kick past him at the near post for only the third goal of his career. Also unhappy was Hendrie, who claimed he had merely stood his ground when Keane ran into him for the initial free-kick.

Unhappiest of all, though, must have been Ginola, who was given just seven minutes to roll his sleeves up, enough time only to give Denis Irwin a glare for a heavy challenge, send a left-wing cross out of play, and watch Sheringham complete a one-two with Andy Cole to set the seal on United's win with his eighteenth goal of the season. An all-English one too, and Eriksson confirmed that in-form thirtysomethings would be considered for his first England squad. 'I'm not surprised, Teddy has been phenomenal this season,' Ferguson said. Although 14 points clear, United are still hungry, and it was a somewhat glum Ferguson who revealed his players had even declined a night out on last week's training break in favour of staying in the hotel and 'focusing'. On the Champions League, presumably. For the rest of the Premiership can be located through the wrong end of a telescope.

webTitle: Howey regains pride

fields.headline: Howey regains pride
fields.trailText: Howey regains City pride.
fields.body:
This was a stereotypical match between two sides threatened by relegation. There was passion, commitment, even the occasional flash of inspiration, but ultimately it provided the perfect illustration of why both sides are where they are.

It would be impossible to fault either because they each put so much into it but it is very hard to see them pulling away from danger and a fraught few months seems to be in store for both.

How Manchester City must wish there were points awarded for the support each club receives. Their travelling army was magnificent.

In contrast, the Derby fans seemed to be rather overwhelmed by the noise emanating from the away end of the ground and, apart from a few half-hearted boos every time their former favourite Paulo Wanchope touched the ball, they were unusually subdued.

But there was much amusement when Wanchope was lectured like a naughty schoolboy by the referee for having his shirt outside his shorts. The analogy seemed apt as all afternoon the Costa Rican was like an old boy returning to his former school determined to prove to his old headmaster (in this case, the Derby manager Jim Smith) that he really had done well for himself.

Making him even more determined to shine was the fact he was up against the Head's new favourite, Taribo West, and he tried every trick in his book to shine. But West had the measure of him and it was Darren Huckerby who came closest to breaking the deadlock of an otherwise nondescript first half when he worked an opening for himself in the 24th minute, only to curl his shot wide.

Therefore, it was something of a shock with what followed after the interval and the quality of the goals. First, Malcolm Christie raced down the right-hand flank, swapped passes with Deon Burton and then planted a cross on to the head of Darryl Powell, who from a yard out could hardly miss.

City were behind for just three minutes before Danny Tiatto hit a corner which the oncoming Steve Howey met with a powerful header which flashed past Mart Poom.

The match then resumed its earlier scrappy pattern, although Christie wasted two opportunities to win the game.

The first chance in the 62nd minute was the best: running on to Burton's flick but overrunning the ball past Nicky Weaver. With the second, 13 minutes later, he at least forced the City keeper to palm his effort wide as he attempted to lob him when he was through again.

webTitle: Ranieri gets message across

fields.headline: Ranieri gets message across
fields.trailText: Ranieri gets right message across.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri is beginning to make himself understood at the millionaires language school of Stamford Bridge. The Italian Chelsea manager steered his side to their sixth successive game without defeat after Ipswich had threatened to continue over-achieving before ultimately finding their level.

Ipswich remain in the Premiership top six and have accomplished their survival mission months ahead of schedule, but Chelsea move up to eighth and are increasingly looking a better bet to finish in a European qualifying place come May.

Ipswich initially defied Chelsea's formidable home form, nine wins in 10 games now, by starting the better side and were good for their 22nd-minute lead when Marcus Stewart extended his scoring run to seven matches with his 17th goal of the season. James Scowcroft won a tackle with Celestine Babayaro and the ball broke kindly for Stewart to win the race and poke a shot over the despairing Carlo Cudicini.

The Chelsea keeper would not be so exposed for the rest of the game, but Chelsea were were still far from convincing until they equalised through the outstanding Gus Poyet in the 45th minute. A Dennis Wise corner was headed by John Terry and cleared off the line by Gary Croft only to fall straight to Poyet, who scored with power from six yards out.

That changed the course of the game and Ranieri, who had left out Frank Leboeuf ahead of his imminent transfer to Monaco, seemingly further boosted Chelsea's confidence with a trademark shuffle of his pawns for the start of the second half, abandoning his 4-4-2 formation by replacing Eidur Gudjohnsen for Mario Melchiot.

Ipswich continued to press forward but looked increasingly out of sorts and it was all but checkmate 12 minutes after the restart.

Chelsea had been dominant from the outset and Wise gave Chelsea the lead, scoring from a well-worked Hasselbaink cross.

Hasselbaink helped end the game as a contest when he laid on Chelsea's third goal for Poyet in the 65th minute. The Dutch striker carried the ball from the half-way line and waited for Poyet to arrive in the penalty area to pass into his stride for a sliding finish from 10 yards.

Finally, the pasta boys were outsinging the tractor boys as Chelsea pursued more glory. It came in the form of a 73rd-minute Hasselbaink penalty, drilled into the middle of the net, three minutes after referee Andy D'Urso had surprisingly decided Fabian Wilnis had fouled Sam Dalla Bona and then sent off the Ipswich defender John McGreal for disputing the call.

The Ipswich manager, George Burley, also disagreed with D'Urso and accused him of affecting the scoreline but Poyet, representing Ranieri, rightly pointed out that the game was well won by then.

webTitle: Strachan left rattled

fields.headline: Strachan left rattled
fields.trailText: Toffees sew up victory in 30 minutes.
fields.body:
Delight for Walter Smith, whose skeleton side made a mockery of relegation talk with an emphatic victory. The win ended a run of just two points from seven matches and must surely point them in the direction of calmer waters.

Despair for Gordon Strachan, who has never faced a demonstration from the fans like the one after this wretched performance.

Everton, with 10 senior players injured and three more suspended, had everything sewn up in half an hour. Remarkably, they did so despite picking up two more casualties - Niclas Alexandersson carried off with a deep cut on the calf and Alec Cleland replaced after pulling a thigh muscle.

On came Phil Jevons for a lively first appearance of the season and 18-year-old Peter Clarke for an assured debut. With Kevin Campbell putting a stop-start season behind him Everton were dominant.

Coventry had no shape, no substance and at times no heart. There was also no excuse as Strachan admitted afterwards, while at the same time refusing to talk about his position other than to insist he had not considered walking away from it.

'I'll talk about the game and that's it,' he said, agreeing that the first 45 minutes were the worst he had experienced in the job. 'There is no hiding place for anyone. It was an embarrassment for the players, the coaching staff and for me. Even those who did not play should feel the same way because they were not even good enough to be picked. It is something that will stick in our memories for a long time.

Everton needed just eight minutes to end a five-year run without a goal at Highfield Road, Danny Cadamarteri playing Scot Gemmill through for a convincing finish.

Cadamarteri himself rounded off good approach work by Idan Tal and Alexandersson for the second to show that it is not just against London sides that he can score. His last eight have all been against teams from the capital.

Strachan pulled off Mo Konjic and replaced him with Carlton Palmer, just returned from a loan spell with Watford, but it made no difference. Jevons set up Campbell, who turned his marker and put the ball into an empty net when it broke loose.

Campbell was denied a fourth by a fine save from Chris Kirkland and although Coventry had more of the second half they never looked like getting back into the game.

Lee Carsley's first goal for the club five minutes from time after he was brought down by Thomas Myhre was too little too late.

webTitle: Stringless quartet

fields.headline: Stringless quartet
fields.trailText: Boksic outshines Reds' stringless quartet.
fields.body:
Gerard Houllier finally has a striking quartet to rival that at Old Trafford, or any other European club for that matter, but yesterday all four were found lacking against a resilient and motivated Middlesbrough.

Jari Litmanen, Emile Heskey, Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler may be a line-up to send office fantasy football competitors into apoplexy, but, for one half at least, they were outshone convincingly by Middlesbrough's Alen Boksic.

The grapevine has long since resounded to claims that Boksic lacks the heart and consistency to help Terry Venables' club out of their current, although admittedly easing, predicament. If that is so, every other Premiership manager should be so fortunate to have to put up with such a luxury item.

With the fluid and intelligent Christian Karembeu too elusive for Liverpool's flat back four, Boro could have had the game wrapped up before the interval with Boksic responsible for two outrageous and sublime moments.

Just after the half-hour, with back to goal the Croatian striker controlled a pass, back-healing it to twist past two markers before chipping the ball inches wide from 25 yards. Then, in first half injury time, he took Paul Ince's long ball in his stride, shooting in one movement and forcing Sander Westerveld into a good reflex save at his near post.

'Alen was excellent, he could have had a hat-trick,' said Venables after his team's eighth consecutive unbeaten outing. 'His chip looked in all the way, he had a couple of other great shots the keeper dealt with and he was a fraction off being on the end of a pass across the face of goal.

'We played excellently in that first half and gave them a few problems. Coming here we would have been happy with a point, but we could have been two or three up by half-time.'

The pattern of the game altered within two minutes of the restart when Michael Owen, brought on to replace the injured Emile Heskey, latched onto a poor back pass from Colin Cooper and sped through only to shoot over under pressure from Steve Vickers.

It was the first of three such one-on-one chances that were all uncharacteristically squandered by the England striker, twice he looked hesitant when bearing down on Mark Schwarzer, who responded with fine blocks.

webTitle: Yearning for Glenn

fields.headline: Yearning for Glenn
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle showed why so many Tottenham supporters want him to be their next manager as his Southampton team outpassed and outclassed Spurs, and were unlucky not to leave with all three points.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle showed why so many Tottenham supporters want him to be their next manager as his Southampton team outpassed and outclassed Spurs, and were unlucky not to leave with all three points.

In contrast to a home side who struggled to pass the ball with any conviction or create clear-cut chances, Southampton were full of bright, inventive football - the image of their manager when he was in his White Hart Lane prime.

It is 16 years since Hoddle played his last game for Tottenham and they have gone backwards since then. Much of the discontent from supporters is because of their current footballing style - or lack of it - and many of them see Hoddle as the man to bring back the club's traditional virtues of entertainment and flair.

There was little of that on show here, and what there was came mostly from the visitors. Southampton lost 7-2 on their previous visit, 10 months ago, but they have improved so much that they should have been three goals ahead by half-time yesterday. That they were not was down largely to the fine form of Ian Walker, making a rare appearance in goal in place of the suspended Neil Sullivan.

'Ian Walker played brilliantly and kept us in the game,' admitted Graham. Walker was in action as early as the third minute when he blocked a fierce low drive from Tahar El Khalej, and he made further fine saves to deny Hassan Kachloul and Kevin Davies. But his best save was a reflex stop from James Beattie at close range after the Saints striker ran on to a poor headed backpass from Gary Doherty.

Spurs' only shot on target in the opening 45 minutes was Stephen Clemence's volley, tipped away by the otherwise untroubled Paul Jones. Their attacking options were limited when Les Ferdinand limped off with a recurrence of hamstring trouble to be replaced by rookie Dave McEwen, who was playing for Dulwich Hamlet this time last year. He looked out of his depth, but at least Spurs reorganised at half-time and could have sneaked an undeserved win if Ledley King's header had not struck the bar midway through the second half. 'We were the better side and should have won,' said Hoddle quite reasonably. 'I was pleased with the performance but bitterly disappointed with the result.'

Graham preferred to be positive, pointing out that his side are now unbeaten in four games, their best run of the season. 'We haven't conceded a goal in three games, which is a miracle for us.'

webTitle: Jansen a hit at Jack's place

fields.headline: Jansen a hit at Jack's place
fields.standfirst: Blackburn's striker, once overlooked by Kenny Dalglish, now thrives under another Scottish manager
fields.trailText: Matt Jansen, once overlooked by Kenny Dalglish, now thrives under another Scottish manager.
fields.body:
Matt Jansen's season was going nowhere in particular until the last time Blackburn Rovers played Birmingham City, when he came off the bench and scored a couple of spectacular goals to earn a win and book himself a run in the team. Graeme Souness still reckons the 23-year-old is inconsistent, but Jansen argues, as politely as he dares, that 12 goals in his last 15 starts is consistent enough for most people. 'I'm not saying I can't improve,' he said. 'But I'm fairly happy with my form. I think I'm benefiting from the stability the manager has brought. The whole club is. I've only been here two years and I'm on my third manager. After Brian Kidd and Tony Parkes I think there was a need to impose some managerial consistency, and that's what Graeme Souness has done.'

Not many young footballers place such a high value on managerial continuity, but having served his apprenticeship at Carlisle United and Crystal Palace, you can understand Jansen's desire to check the same name is on the manager's office from week to week.

'Palace wasn't too bad, to be fair,' he said. 'Ron Noades was still around, Steve Coppell was manager, and I enjoyed my time there. Carlisle was a much crazier place. I was actually managed by Michael Knighton for a while. He certainly has some interesting ideas. I was amused by the bloke who rolled up in a battered old Cavalier to try and buy the club last week, but ultimately there's nothing particularly funny about being bottom of the League. I'm from Carlisle, even if I do support Newcastle, and I know the club should be doing better than that.'

Jansen's ties to Tyneside first came to light four years ago, when, after extensive scouting, Kenny Dalglish declined to make Carlisle an offer for their promising teenage striker, opting instead to bring another foreigner to St James' Park at five or six times the price. Dalglish was criticised for neglecting talent on his own doorstep, and a disappointed Jansen famously said he would have walked to Newcastle for the chance to play for the Magpies. 'I was disappointed, but I didn't get too despondent because I didn't know too much about what was going on,' he said. 'I heard the talk, but I wasn't kept informed.'

If Jansen still harbours a desire to play for the team he supported as a boy, he keeps it fairly well hidden. When he signed for Palace and Blackburn they were both Premiership clubs, and his only ambition at the moment is to return to the top flight. 'This club is geared up for Premiership football, nothing else will do, and I feel the same way,' he said. 'I do have one or two other ambitions, as a matter of fact. I'd like to play for England and I'd like to try playing abroad for a while, but returning to the Premiership is a necessary first step.'

Which brings us neatly to Birmingham this afternoon, and the first hurdle of a six-week programme that Souness reckons will determine the shape of Blackburn's season. 'Within the next month-and-a-half we are away to Birmingham, Bolton and Watford, and at home to Fulham and Sheffield United,' Souness said. 'We should know by the end of all that whether we are on course for automatic promotion or whether we will be looking at the play-offs.'

If it is to be automatic promotion, Souness is realistic enough to accept that only one place is likely to be available - the one behind Fulham. 'I keep waiting to see if they wobble or hit a bad patch, because most teams do some time, but they aren't making many mistakes at the moment,' he said.

Blackburn are well-placed to time a run, however, and with Jansen reunited with former Palace team-mate Marcus Bent, Mark Hughes around for experience and Nathan Blake almost back to full fitness, goalscoring should not be a problem.

On the delicate side for a striker at 10st 13lb, Jansen was predictably awestruck by close proximity to the 37-year-old manager of Wales. 'I can't believe the way he puts himself about, throwing defenders around the place,' Jansen said. 'I hope I can do all the things he can do when I'm his age. Not throwing defenders around, I don't think I'll be doing that no matter how old I get, but the amazing thing about Mark is how passionate he still is, how fired-up he gets for a game.'

The scorer of five goals since his free transfer from Everton in October is suspended this afternoon, a result of getting a little too fired-up at Norwich, but Hughes has seen enough of Jansen in action to form a positive opinion. 'Matt's a great talent, and everybody in football knows his potential,' he said. 'He burst onto the scene a couple of years ago and possibly found the expectations people had of him hard to deal with. He has improved under Graeme Souness, though, and his form this season has been sensational. He looks every inch a Premiership player.'

Just as well, since the last recorded wish of the late Jack Walker was that he wanted Rovers back in the top division, whatever it might take. It is 10 years to the week since football's most generous benefactor first became officially involved with Blackburn, a point in history at which Kenny Dalglish, Alan Shearer, the Premiership title and a totally transformed Ewood were undreamt of (except perhaps by Walker). But since his death last summer uncertainty has arisen over the ongoing funding of the club.

Walker always intended the club to stand on its own feet once established in the Premiership, even if that proved more difficult than he imagined, but speculation that he left a finite amount of money sufficient to finance only one or two further promotion bids has been denied by Paul Egerton-Vernon, the Jersey solicitor who is the chairman of the holding company to which Walker's Blackburn shares have passed.

'There is no diminishing pot where the amount gets smaller as the years go by,' Egerton-Vernon said. 'The football club is one of a number of businesses that Jack Walker acquired, and funds are generated by the success or otherwise of the other business interests he put in place.'

With Walker no longer around, though, Rovers' maverick days may be over. An AGM this week will be presented with plans to turn Walker's loans to the club into shares - a move that executives insist will improve long-term funding - and Rovers may be floated in the near future. 'Our priority is getting back into the Premiership, and then we'll see whether a flotation makes sense,' Egerton-Vernon said. 'But we don't need to float, that's the wonderful thing. The reason to seek a listing would not be because we can't afford to run the club, because we can. Jack Walker made arrangements to ensure that was the case.'

webTitle: Risen from weeds

fields.headline: Risen from weeds
fields.trailText: How Alan Curbishley has taken Charlton from the brink of extinction to Premiership safety.
fields.body:
Charlton Athletic are sitting comfortably in the top half of the Premiership, turning away several thousand punters a week because the ground is full to bursting, and oozing optimism. As Alan Curbishley drove into work his mind raced with questions: 'We're into the second half of the season and I was thinking what can we do now? What do we need? What will give us a lift?' All his thoughts stem from one goal. Staying up. So he challenges himself, analysing the details, searching for the nuggets that will ensure Premiership status.

Curbishley's approach has won him admiration enough to put him in the frame for Sven-Göran Eriksson's new England regime and he has emerged as a potential successor to Sir Alex Ferguson at Old Trafford. It has also kept him in his post at Charlton for a decade - which makes him the second-longest-serving manager in the Premiership after that peerless trophy gatherer in Manchester. Not bad going for a young man who figured, when accepting the post in 1991, that his first job would probably be his last. Most managers starting out are well aware that if they flounder at the first attempt they are unlikely to get a second go, and the Charlton that he took on 10 years ago were, in his own words, in absolute turmoil. The chances of success were wafer thin.

Sitting in his bright office overlooking the training pitch he casts his mind back to the day he was appointed. His predecessor, Lennie Lawrence, had upped sticks for Middlesbrough, leaving Curbishley and Steve Gritt, both player-coaches at the time, feeling obliged to apply for the job. 'We had no ground, no players and no money. We were just on the floor. Myself and Gritty were sitting in here, I looked out to see the 14 senior players walking out to start pre-season, and I said to Gritty: "I just can't imagine anybody coming in and taking this job." The club decided to give it to us two. I don't think they could have done anything else. We felt a bit like lambs to the slaughter but you have to take the chance when it comes along. I wouldn't swap it because the experiences hold you in good stead.'

Charlton were homeless (having quit renting at Selhurst Park and still weeding the terraces at the dilapidated Valley, they played at Upton Park in front of 3,500). They were also skint. 'Those days we couldn't order boots from people on the phone because we hadn't paid the bills and had to send them cash, and we couldn't stay in hotels we had previously been to in case we hadn't settled the bill. The whole thing was on the verge of collapse. If we'd have been relegated that year, which was on the cards...' Curbishley pauses, and chooses his words carefully, 'I think I can say we might not be here. In the end we came seventh and it took off from there. I still maintain out of the last 10 years that the first year at Upton Park was the most important.'

It speaks volumes for their progress that Charlton are now planning for the next 10 years. Says Curbishley: 'The biggest step for this club is to increase the size of the ground, that's our next major priority. The chairman is desperate to do that. We've got planning permission for behind one goal but we really need permission for behind the other goal as well, then we can wrap it around and get a 34,000 all-seater. When the chairman first got involved we were looking to become a QPR or Norwich, with the ability to challenge for a place in the top flight. Now our aim is to become a club able to compete with West Ham in this area. If you come back in two years' time, hopefully we'll still be a Premiership club, the ground will be done, and we'll be on our way.'

He is under no illusions that the catalyst to turn their dreams into reality is survival. Key discussions on stadium development are due in the summer. A bumper pay day from the new television deal, coupled with confidence that they are capable of avoiding the yo-yo that afflicts so many promoted clubs, may well give them the urge to go for it.

The other day, when last week's FA Cup replay at Dagenham and Redbridge fell victim to the weather and football's heart went out to the non-leaguers, was poignant for Charlton's manager. In a cold snap £150,000 of television money disappeared into thin air. Nobody except Curbishley gave a moment's thought to the fact that Charlton, too, had lost out on a nice little earner. At that moment he was struck by a sudden realisation that Charlton were no longer perceived as cash-strapped strugglers with a touch of the underdogs about them.

That humbling draw in the first game also made Curbishley recognise how much attitudes have changed. 'I saw the headlines and it really rammed it home to me that we are a Premiership club. I had letters from fans who have been supporting us for 50 years saying, "Being a Charlton fan I have never been as embarrassed as I was after Dagenham when I had to go back and face my mates." I was embarrassed when I was trying to sign players and we had Portakabins and no ground. I was embarrassed when we were playing in front of 3,500 fans at Upton Park. I was embarrassed when I was having to sell my best players to pay the wages. That was embarrassing - not the result against Dagenham and Redbridge.'

After 10 experience-packed years at Charlton Athletic, this job still has the capacity to surprise, to test and to push Alan Curbishley.

fields.headline: Great deals Down Under
fields.standfirst: Late bargains chosen by Desmond Balmer
fields.trailText: Late bargains chosen by Desmond Balmer.
fields.body:
The cost of flying to Australia and New Zealand falls dramatically this Easter. As the southern hemisphere goes into autumn temperatures cool off and so do the air fares. The cheap-flight agencies are offering a variety of low fares on major airlines for departures from 13 April, which is Good Friday, until 30 June. In every case bookings must be made by 6 February.

Austravel (0870 055 0223) has flights from Heathrow for £594 with Singapore Airlines to Auckland and Christchurch in New Zealand and Adelaide, Brisbane, Melbourne, Perth and Sydney in Australia.

Bridge the World (0870 444 7474) offers the same destinations from Heathrow with Singapore Airlines for £589. In addition two internal flights can be booked within Australia for £85 per person.

The Far East Travel Centre (020 7440 2600) has the same cities from London or Manchester for £595. If you prefer to travel in the other direction, the FETC also offers Air New Zealand flights from Heathrow via Los Angeles (stop-over permitted) to Auckland or Sydney for £595.

Flightbookers (020 7757 2468) has Singapore Airlines flights from £574 to Auckland and Christchurch, £585 to Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth and £587 to Sydney.

Quest (0870 442 2699) offers Air New Zealand flights to Auckland for £574 with two domestic flights available for £80. There are other attractive fares if you want to travel earlier than Good Friday.

Qantas Holidays (020 8222 9104) has cut the cost of British Airways and Qantas flights from Heathrow or Manchester to the five Australian cities between 16 February and 12 April from £740 to £623. Two domestic flights are available for £80 and a free stopover is allowed in Bangkok or Singapore.

Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) is selling Singapore flights to all the gateways in Australia and New Zealand up to 12 April for £622.

Cheapflights.com has a competitive business class fare of £1,869 with Swissair from Heathrow to Sydney (via Zurich). This a fully flexible fare valid all year.

... and elsewhere

Nepal: An escorted 14-night tour with Imaginative Traveller (020 8742 8612) leaving Heathrow on 2 February costs £990. This covers flights, coach transport, hotels and campsites.

Copenhagen: Travelscene (0870 777 4445) offers a two-night weekend at the three-star Hotel Copenhagen Star for £220 (saving £70). Includes BA flights and bed and breakfast. Available next weekend or 2 February.

Eilat: Pullman Holidays (08700 133085) has cut £90 on all holidays to the Red Sea resort for departures up to 11 February. Seven nights B&B costs £239 with flights.

Rome: Book before next Sunday and save £50 on a three-night stay at the two-star Hotel Embassy; £253 until 12 March with Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333). Includes flights, B&B and private car transfer.

webTitle: Boa Morte rides his luck to halt Watford revival

fields.headline: Boa Morte rides his luck to halt Watford revival
fields.trailText: Fulham once again asserted their dominance in this division yesterday by beating one of their promotion rivals with, in the end, some comfort. Not quite as comfortable as Boxing Day's 5-0 stroll against the same opponents perhaps, but then this is a different Watford team.
fields.body:
Fulham once again asserted their dominance in this division yesterday by beating one of their promotion rivals with, in the end, some comfort. Not quite as comfortable as Boxing Day's 5-0 stroll against the same opponents perhaps, but then this is a different Watford team.

When Watford are good they are very, very good, but when they are bad they're appalling. Last month's meeting came during an horrific losing streak. This followed three successive league victories and the difference in their confidence was apparent.

The home side dominated the first half, and would have taken the lead but for an extraordinary miss from the in-form Tommy Mooney, who saw his low shot somehow saved by Maik Taylor when unmarked four yards from goal. 'I didn't see it as a miss, I saw it as a good save,' said Graham Taylor charitably.

Both teams at this stage were playing against type, Watford passing the ball through midfield while their much-lauded opponents played hopeful long balls towards Louis Saha and Luis Boa Morte. It was not a position that Fulham have frequently found themselves in this season, and they became uncharacteristically rattled.

Boa Morte was booked after he followed a penalty-area dive with a handball and, as the half drew to a close, he was fortunate to escape a second caution after a foul on Allan Nielsen and another, even more blatant, dive. 'On any other day with any other referee he wouldn't have stayed on,' said Taylor.

It was perhaps inevitable that Boa Morte would decide the game in the second half. In the 60th minute Mooney headed against the bar and over from Nielsen's long throw, but, apart from a defensive lunge, the next Watford player to touch the ball was Alec Chamberlain, when he picked the ball out of his own net about 20 seconds later.

Taylor's goal-kick fell to Saha, who ran at the home defence only for Neil Cox to knock the ball out of his path. It fell though to Boa Morte, who rounded Chamberlain and scored.

Boa Morte's second, eight minutes later, was similar, as he received a perceptive pass from Lee Clark, rounded Chamberlain once more and again avoided James Panayi's lunge to score his 15th goal of the season.

Watford were briefly back in the game after substitute Heidar Helguson scored with a helping hand from, well, his hand, but Fulham made the game safe as Bjarne Goldbaek squared the ball to give Saha his 23rd goal of the campaign.

'We played against a side that are a class apart from the rest of us in the First Division,' said Taylor. 'They're very pacey and powerful and skillful. Today's game was much more like the Premiership where you have to think about everything and if you make one mistake they'll punish you.'

Watford need to stop making those mistakes if they are to establish themselves in the top flight. 'I don't think it's a disgrace for a club this size to be a yo-yo club,' said Taylor, 'but if you get it right one day you'll yo.' It is Fulham, though, who seem closer to getting it right.

webTitle: Pundits' pub prattle displays little logic

fields.headline: Pundits' pub prattle displays little logic
fields.standfirst: Alan Smith says enough already with the talking
fields.trailText: Alan Smith has had enough of talk without substance.
fields.body:
Much has been made of Mark Lawrenson's criticism of Peter Reid's Sunderland recently, and I have to say few people in football have much sympathy with the former Liverpool player on this one.

Reid, quite rightly in my opinion, was incensed when he heard Lawrenson on BBC's Match of the Day question his team's credentials or ability to sustain their position in the Premiership's top three.

It is hard to stomach this sort of thing when you have worked against the odds to bring a side up from the First Division and then not just survive in the top flight but also challenge for honours.

And it is particularly galling when the criticism comes from someone who has been a player and even dabbled in management, however brief and unsuccessful it may have been.

I am not averse to criticism, and firmly believe that if you cannot handle it you are in the wrong job as a manager. Nor do I think you need to have played at the highest level to be able to comment on the game - if something is not right on a football field, you can see it for yourself.

But Lawrenson really should understand that there is a lot more to management than simply putting 11 players on a pitch and hoping they do the right things.

There are so many aspects to it - dealing with chairmen, the bank manager, agents, the media, players and their families. It is one of those rare jobs where everybody thinks they could do it better, unlike, say, a heart surgeon.

Every football fan has an opinion on his or her club, but I think we have gone overboard in providing platforms for their views to be expressed. Radio phone-ins are a cheap and easy way of filling air time, but what else do they achieve? Most of the opinions are on the same level as pub conversation, when any little rumour or titbit is picked up and snowballs until it is assumed to be true.

For example, a story appeared in the papers recently that David Beckham is demanding £160,000 per week from Manchester United. The story was nonsense but it did not prevent it becoming a prime subject for debate - if you can call it that - on a number of phone-ins. The story is thus given credibility by association with the BBC.

Now it seems anyone can ring in and spout off about why their manager should be sacked and the bandwagon starts rolling. Chairmen listen and think, 'If that's what the fans think, I should do something about it.'

The presenters encourage this sort of thing. I don't usually listen to Richard Littlejohn's show on Radio 5 because of the nature of my job, but as we did not have a game last Saturday I went to West Ham and heard it on my way home.

I switched off in disgust eventually, after hearing Coventry fans calling for Gordon Strachan to be sacked. The man should be knighted just for keeping his side in the Premiership against all the odds over the past few years. For the likes of Coventry, Premiership survival is as great an achievement as one of the big clubs winning the title.

How often do you hear genuine analysis rather than uninformed, knee-jerk reactions on these programmes? I can understand why Alex Ferguson has had so many problems with Alan Green over the years. Green is the radio commentator who prides himself on being outspoken. Yet if United, for example, are struggling to cope with the tactics of some European opponents, do you think he understands that? I suspect not.

The best commentators understand the finer points of the game, both on and off the field, and get out and about among football people. Martin Tyler, Clive Tyldesley and Rob Hawthorne do their homework and actually ring up before games to ask about certain things.

I used to go on Tom Watt's radio show; Tom was well liked in football because he had written a book which involved going around the grounds and getting to know how football people thought.

The problem now, however, is that there is a new breed of pundits and journalists who can pick up all the stories they want from clubcall and the internet without leaving their desks. It is much harder to have the sort of rapport with them that you might have with those journalists you talk to regularly.

I prefer the approach of Trevor Brooking to that of Alan Hansen; Brooking uses his experience to analyse the situation and then lets the viewers make up their own minds. Some call it sitting on the fence, but I prefer that to some unqualified pundit being judge and jury.

webTitle: The kids are all right

fields.headline: The kids are all right
fields.standfirst: Joanne O'Connor selects a variety of ideas at home and abroad to inspire your holiday planning
fields.trailText: Joanne O'Connor selects a variety of ideas at home and abroad to inspire your holiday planning.
fields.body:
1 Pedal power
Take a leisurely cycling tour around the Austrian lakes with Freewheel Holidays (01633 681997). The tour operator is highlighting new routes in Switzerland and Austria which are good for families. The 11-night Austria itinerary - which is available from 7 July to the end of August - covers less than 100 miles on quiet routes, with 'non-cycling' days where families can enjoy excursions, mountain hikes or watersports. The cost for two adults and two children starts from £2,717.

2 In the swim
Why take pot luck with the weather when you can guarantee a constant 84 degrees Fahrenheit in a Center Parcs 'Subtropical Swimming Paradise'? Each of the three resorts featured in SeaFrance's European Life brochure (08702 424455) has a gigantic, dome-covered pool area as its centrepiece. While children splash about in waterchutes and wave pools, parents can enjoy a relaxing spa treatment or a round of golf. A seven-night self-catering break in high season at Les Bois-Francs village in Normandy starts from £890 for a family of four, including SeaFrance ferry crossings.

3 Farm fresh
Experience life down on the farm with Cartwheel (0870 241 1098) - a consortium of 200 farm-based holidays and attractions including self-catering cottages, B&Bs, farm shops, campsites and restaurants in the Southwest. Some farms will let children help out with feeding the animals, collecting eggs and watching cows being milked. Prices for a family of four range from as little as £160 for a week's self-catering in low season, leading in at £490 in high season.

4 Dive, dive, dive
It's now easier than ever for parents to share the pleasures of diving with their children. The new 'SASY' (Supplied Air Snorkelling for Youth) system uses a miniature cylinder and flotation device designed to allow children from the age of five to dive in the safety of a pool. While children aged 10 and over can now take the PADI Junior Open Water Diver course which follows the same format as the adult course. Contact the diving specialist Regal Holidays (0870 2201 777) for details of its family diving packages in the Red Sea.

5 Island life
Menorca's sandy beaches and shallow waters make it a popular family destination. Villa company Meon (01730 268411) has a good selection of beachside properties. Villa A2 Santo Tomas is a stone's throw from a long sandy beach on the south coast. It sleeps up to nine and has a 15-metre swimming pool and accommodation all on one level. Prices start from £395 per person in May rising to £689 per person between 30 July and 19 August, including flights and car hire.

6 High energy
Parascending, rafting, mountainbiking and surfing are just a few of the activities for teenagers being highlighted in Keycamp Holidays' new minibrochure (0870 7000 123). Holiday prices start at £444 per family at Argelès-sur-Mer in the Languedoc, inclusive of 12 nights' tent accommodation (£641 in a mobile home), ferry crossings and Children's Club, departing in May. Facilities include scuba-diving and kayaking lessons in the campsite pool and riding stables just outside the site.

7 On the road
Experience the freedom of the open road and spectacular scenery on a motorhome tour of western Canada. Lakes & Mountains Holidays (01329 844405) is offering 16-day touring holidays out of Vancouver or Calgary, departing any time in July. Motorhomes have all mod cons including air conditioning, shower, flush WC and fresh water tank and campsites are well-equipped. The cost of the holiday is £847 per adult and £740 per child including flights and 14-day motorhome rental with insurance.

8 Up country
Cottage agency Helpful Holidays (01647 433593) has no less than 42 West Country properties with indoor heated swimming pools to beat the rainy day blues and a further 33 which have outdoor pools. Prices for a former granary sleeping four near Huntsham in Devon start from £615 for a week during peak season. One of a cluster of five cottages, it shares two acres of grounds, a children's play area, pet's corner and a heated indoor pool. Horseriding and other activities can be arranged.

9 On safari
Kenyan hotel group Heritage Hotels has launched an Adventurers Club to give children aged four-12 years old an entertaining and educational introduction to African culture, wildlife and tribal life. The Club is provided free of charge at Heritage's safari camps and coastal resorts. Activities include bush walks, game drives, snorkelling and visits to tribal villages and bush schools. A seven-night all-inclusive package including five nights at the Voyager Beach Hotel and two nights at the Voyager Safari Camp for a family of four costs £2,884.20 with Kuoni (01306 747000) departing 6 May.

10 Helping hand
Simply Portugal (020 8541 2277) is introducing a new service this summer whereby RGEN- and NNEB-registered nannies can look after children in your villa, rather than in a crèche. The service is priced at £130 per child for five half days and £250 per child for five full days. One week staying at the Monte Bougainvillea villa near Anzinheiro in peak season (15 July-1 September) is priced from £434 per person based on four sharing. This includes return flights, seven nights' accommodation and car hire.

11 Fresh air
Swap the seaside for mountain streams and lakes on a summer holiday in the Alps. Family holiday specialist Sun Esprit (01252 618300) features the resorts of Morzine, Chamonix and Montchavin-Les Coches where summer tobogganing, a circus school, mountain-biking and white water rafting are just a few of the activities on offer. Adult prices for travel in June start from £310 per person and £155 per child, including Eurotunnel crossing, chalet accommodation with breakfast and five evening meals with wine, and babysitting on two nights each week. Child care starts from about £80 per child per week.

12 French toast
Brittany Ferries' 2001 Gite Holidays in France (0870 5143 537) brochure has 1,400 properties to choose from ranging from simple stone farmhouses in Normandy to luxury properties with pools in the south of France. Lead-in prices for one week in a traditional country house in Brittany, close to a beach and the Oceanopolis attraction in Brest range from £280 to £491 depending on time of year, with early booking discounts available before 15 February.

13 Irish eyes
Explore the byways and backwaters of Ireland from a horse-drawn caravan, a cruiser on the River Shannon or the comfort of your own car - it depends on how adventurous you are feeling. Ferry operator Stena Line (08705 747474) has a range of holiday suggestions with prices starting from £504 for a week's rental of a holiday home in Kerry in July, including ferry crossings.

14 Thrills and spills
Disney and Universal Studios have expanded their Orlando empires in the last two years with the addition of several major new parks, rides and attractions. Add Seaworld and Busch Gardens to the mix and you've enough to keep the most hyperactive children satisfied for a week. Follow it up with a week recovering on the beaches of the Gulf Coast. You'll need it. Funway Holidays (020 8466 0222) offers an Orlando/Gulf Coast two centre stay from £1,046 per adult and £345 per child in July.

15 Jungle lore
Go elephant trekking through the jungle, visit remote hill tribes and explore caves, palaces and temples on a new 15-day tour of Thailand. The escorted tour, which costs £1079 for adults and £716 for children, is one of several new itineraries being offered by Travelbag Adventures (01420 541007) which are aimed exclusively at families with children aged five to 12 years old.

16 Take it easy
Staff at the Crystal Cove in Barbados will keep children aged three to 11 entertained with safari style outings, treasure hunts, beach and pool games and movie screenings, while you enjoy the facilities at this four-star hotel. A 14-night stay on an all-inclusive basis with flights costs £5,376 for two adults and two children departing in July. Book with Caribbean Journeys (0870 709 3020).

17 Classic Greece
All-inclusive resort operator Club Med (0700 2582 633) will open a new village in Greece this summer, bringing its total to 88 worldwide. Located on the mainland about 50km from Athens, the Athenia village has a children's club catering for four to 14-year-olds, three swimming pools, and activities such as cycle hire, windsurfing, in-line skating, kayaking and football. A seven-night package departing on 22 July costs £626 per adult and £395 for a child aged between four and 11.

18 Beside the sea

A four-night break in July costs from £582 for a family of four and includes accommodation in a two bedroom woodland lodge and access to the waterpark.

webTitle: Benidorm gets tough on builders

fields.headline: Benidorm gets tough on builders
fields.standfirst: Benidorm has passed a new law designed to minimise the impact of building work on holidaymakers
fields.trailText: Benidorm has passed a new law designed to minimise the impact of building work on holidaymakers.
fields.body:
Half-finished hotels, eyesore building sites and noisy construction work are one of the biggest causes of complaint for British holidaymakers.

Under the new regulations local construction companies and developers must agree to stop all building work between the hours of 10pm and 8am, dispose of rubble and waste material quickly, erect dust screens and keep noise emissions below a certain level. The original package holiday resort, Benidorm has undergone significant development work in the last five years with 90 per cent of its hotels being totally refurbished and a major overhaul of its seafront promenade.

It is the first resort in Spain to introduce such a law and Federation of Tour Operators chairman Alan Flook said he hoped that it will act as a pilot for the rest of the Mediterranean: 'People don't want to go on holiday and find themselves staying in the middle of a building site. Benidorm has responded to the concerns of tourists and the object now is to persuade other resorts to follow suit.'

However, the Consumers' Association said the onus is on tour operators to ensure their clients are kept informed about poten tially disruptive building work. An association spokesman said: 'We get a lot of complaints about this issue. Building work in resorts is a fact of life. It's down to the tour operators to inform clients at the time of booking if there is any significant building work happening.'

Even if the tour operator finds out about the building work after the booking is made it should inform the client and offer them an alternative holiday or a full refund. The Consumers' Association advises people whose holidays are disrupted by construction work to complain in resort and ask to be moved. If this fails, keep a detailed diary of the disruption caused, take photographs or video footage and get the names and addresses of fellow holidaymakers who are similarly affected.

webTitle: A top hotel manager reveals all

fields.headline: A top hotel manager reveals all
fields.standfirst: Louise Collier, general manager of Woolley Grange Hotel, Bradford on Avon
fields.trailText: Louise Collier, general manager of Woolley Grange Hotel, Bradford on Avon.
fields.body:
What sort of guests do you attract?

Many of our guests work in London and bring their extended families here for a long weekend. We are a very child-friendly hotel and the kids can be left with our nannies in the Bears Den while the adults relax in peace. In fact, parents have been known to almost leave their kids behind, they have got so used to being without them.

What else is there for the kids to do?

Woolley Grange is a Jacobean manor house set in 14 acres of grounds so it is ideal for treasure hunts and games of hide and seek. While the hotel is grand and 'olde worlde', nothing is irreplaceable and children are more than welcome to roam around. Our resident springer spaniel, Molly, is great with the kids and often trots off with guests strolling into Bradford on Avon. They say never work with children or animals, but we have both!

... and locally?

The hotel is only eight miles from Bath and the Roman baths and abbey are popular with guests. We are also only a 20-minute drive from Longleat Safari Park, and the Wookey Hole Caves are nearby. People are often amazed to find that you can see the Westbury white horse from our outdoor swimming pool.

Any good stories to tell?

There have been some funny incidents arising from parents accidentally leaving baby monitors on long after the kids have gone to sleep. The children are a constant source of amusement, too. I once asked a small boy where his Daddy was, and he replied: 'Putting his wig on.' Conferences are sometimes held in the hotel, and during one such meeting the son of our proprietor, Nigel Chapman, was discovered hiding under the table waiting for everyone to leave so that he could watch the television.

Do you get many guests from abroad?

Not really, but there was an American gentleman who rang to say that he had arrived in West Yorkshire and could we possibly give him directions to Woolley Grange as he was having trouble finding it. He hadn't realised that there are two Bradfords in England.

Woolley Grange

01225 864705

Email: info@woolleygrange.com

Double rooms from £105 per room per night with full English breakfast. Children stay free in their parents' rooms.

webTitle: A perfect pitch - and no tent pegs

fields.headline: A perfect pitch - and no tent pegs
fields.standfirst: Reluctant camper  Bill Bradshaw found a mobile home preferable to canvas, and the bonus of football coaching proved a winner all round
fields.trailText: Reluctant camper Bill Bradshaw found a mobile home preferable to canvas, and the bonus of football coaching proved a winner all round.
fields.body:
The gauntlet was thrown down. Go camping en famille in France. My last joust with camping ended with a split big toe pumping crimson in the dead of night as I fought - and lost - a battle with a loose canopy while my inflatable igloo tent was lashed by wind and rain in the Lake District. As I flailed against the elements, I trod on a guy-rope peg and almost severed the offending toe.

That far-off night saw my girlfriend - now, perhaps surprisingly, my wife - walk out of the tent and straight into a cosy lakeside inn, vowing never to return. She took our bedraggled golden retriever with her and left me, beaten and bloody, to deflate the igloo and join her. Or else. What's a man to do?

So it was with some trepidation that I headed to France to experience 'luxury camping'. What a juxtaposition. How could those two words possibly be paired? Luxury and camping go together like Bernard Manning and political correctness, don't they?

I was reassured that, although there was canvas at these Keycamp 'luxury' sites, there were also fully equipped caravans to be had. Sorry, mobile homes. After two successive all-inclusive summer holidays in very decent far-off hotels, could I sell this idea of luxury back home? To help me was a new initiative by Keycamp, football coaching at several of their sites for children between five and 16. With a boy of nine and a tomboy of a girl aged seven it was a decent stash of extra ammunition. I didn't need it. To my surprise and delight, the family thought 'luxury camping' was well worth a try after the all-inclusive pamperings of '98 and '99 and were happy to give it a go.

We had a fortnight to survive at two sites - the first in the Vendée, a site surrounding a chateau at La Foret, St Julien, just 15 minutes drive from the coast; the second in the picturesque Loire Valley at Saumur, close to the river.

So was this spirit of adventure rewarded? Absolutely. From the moment we parked our car outside the mobile home at La Foret, my son, Kit, and daughter, Holly, were sold. Other parents don't need to be told - if you have happy children on holiday it invariably means a happy holiday for all.

Football had to wait until Saumur but, overall, the first week just edged it - and it was a close call - for two reasons. The La Foret site was smaller and friendly and no less well equipped but, more importantly, the Keycamp on-site couriers were magnificent, especially in their dealings with our children. They were made to feel special; that they had new friends. Kids' clubs, often viewed as a chore to be endured by our children, were must-have affairs - as was the evening kids' disco. Within 48 hours they had drilled me in the dance routine to S Club 7's 'Reach'. Quite a sight in the shadow of the chateau, I can tell you.

The brochure promised a holiday 'perfect for children with a wide range of activities right on our doorstep. Our campsites are like open-air hotels with pools, bars and restaurants and plenty of space for children to play safely - campsites to suit all tastes - some are small and peaceful, others large and lively with plenty of activities'.

Spot on. La Foret is a small-to-medium site but truly charming. In the outbuildings surrounding the main building were bars, the disco, offices, shop - hot croissants on offer each morning - cycle rentals, restaurant and separate take-away. Set in beautiful woodland it has a stunning lake as well as its own swimming pool. The short drive to the beautiful beach at Les Sables d'Olonne is a bonus.

Luxury? At La Foret, we pitched camp, as it were, in one of Keycamp's Supernova 29 mobile homes which came equipped with a master double-bedroom; open plan kitchen and dining area featuring cooker and fridge-freezer, gas fire; hot and cold running water, shower and toilet; a second bedroom with two bunks and facility to transform the 'lounge' seating into more beds; a gas-fired barbeque_ and a stereo radio-cassette mounted in the wall. Promising.

That promise was fulfilled. We were more than happy with that and very comfortable. There was not even a hint of a twitch from the old toe wound. The children were always occupied on site and there was more than one old-fashioned look from them when we decided to explore beyond the chateau. The small town of La Mothe-Achard was only four miles away with a hypermarket for provisions and an excellent market worthvisiting.

Week two, and off to Saumur, a busier, more spacious site on the north side of the Loire just a couple of miles from the historic town. It had a fine restaurant and an excellent, child-friendly fun-pool area. Here we were billeted in a Grand 3B (three-bed) mobile - Keycamp's five-star home to the Supernova 29's three-star-plus. My ratings, not theirs, and significantly larger and more luxurious, complete with CD system. On the downside, the couriers here were much more matter-of-fact which initially disappointedthe kids. At La Foret, courier Rachel Steele was the kids' club head honcho and treated it as a vocation. She was magnificent. At Saumur, they did a perfectly adequate job - no more, no less.

But then there was the football. My boy is determined not to follow his father as a committed football nut but even he enjoyed the fun, discipline and exercise that made up coach Stuart White's sessions on the football pitch at the top of the site.

Would you believe after only a couple of sessions he had eight-year-olds perfecting Cruyff turns? The kids loved it, even Holly, one of several girls made welcome on the course. All the youngsters had a chance to referee five-a-sides too, a smart idea. At the end of the week the children received the coaching certificate they had proudly earned. A welcome addition to the Keycamp itinerary.

So don't worry if the thought of camping alarms you. The Keycamp reality won't_ and they even throw in that football coaching these days at selected sites. Kevin Keegan once famously said of his job at Newcastle United 'It's not like it said in the brochure.' He obviously hadn't read Keycamp's.

What it costs

The Bradshaw family travelled with Keycamp Holidays (0870 7000 123). A two-centre holiday to the Loire and the Vendée with Keycamp Holidays costs from £737 per family in June, rising to £1,363 in August. This includes 12 nights' mobile home accommodation and return ferry crossings. This year, football coaching courses, run by Uefa-qualified coaches, are available at selected sites in Brittany and the Vendée.

webTitle: Lonely delusions of webheads

fields.headline: Lonely delusions of webheads
fields.trailText: Anyone who Attachments , the unerringly bad but probably true-to-life BBC series about an internet start-up company, will have learnt this: the reason so many internet companies fail is that the people setting them up may be enthusiastic but they are not necessarily bright.
fields.body:
Anyone who Attachments , the unerringly bad but probably true-to-life BBC series about an internet start-up company, will have learnt this: the reason so many internet companies fail is that the people setting them up may be enthusiastic but they are not necessarily bright.

There was a moment in the late Nineties when anyone with a smattering of webspeak, a bit of front, and an idea - any idea - was heralded as a potential millionaire; or, after a few Vodka Red Bulls, billionaire. Shares soared, bullshit burgeoned and among all the hype and hyperbole some pretty sloppy thinking was allowed to go unchallenged. And then, not before time, the investors started asking, 'Yeah, yeah, yeah, Jamie... just a second, Jamie... Jamie!!... Where do we make our money here?' Gratifyingly quickly the internet boom crapped out. Cue a host of disgruntled twenty-somethings staring into their latte and moaning about other people's lack of vision.

Sport was at the hub of this boom and the object of some misguided thinking that was muddled even by the barely coherent standards of Webland. There were three common errors.

First, the assumption that because money could be made from sport it followed that money could be made from any sport. If some sport is good all sport must be good. Well, yes and no. Jon Henderson mentions in his piece the embarrassing collapse of worldsport.com half-way through the Sydney Olympics. This came as a surprise but perhaps it shouldn't have. Only months before they were looking around for a korfball correspondent. Who would want to do such a job? Why would anyone want to employ such a person? What hope was there for a company specialising in such ephemera?

Second, the netmeisters seemed not the least concerned that the internet, which is something that people generally surf on their own, might not be compatible with watching sport, which is traditionally a communal activity. The internet is made for those who get their solitary thrills from looking at pornography. It is made for those people who sit on trains playing fiddly games on their mobile phones. It is a boon for shy people who take their pleasure from indulging in private pursuits. Watching sport, in contrast, is on the whole a sociable activity. As much about getting out of the house and having a chat with your mates as taking assiduous note of what happens on the field of play. Thus it is that, in my opinion, Tony Smurthwaite is wrong to predict the demise of the betting shop. He may prefer to invest his money in the privacy of his own home but others would rather have a bet and a chat and a laugh at the bookies' (or their own) expense.

Finally, the proponents of the new media blithely assumed that because the internet was so great all other media would shrivel up in the face of its greatness. Newspapers? Finished. Television? Old man's game. Radio? What's radio?

It hasn't quite worked out like that. Television coverage has expanded and improved and will continue to do so. What's more, as more sport becomes available it is at least possible that people will actually watch less of it.

And when they do they will prefer to watch the main event in the pub with friends than a nonsense event on the net. Anthony Burgess wrote that 'pub drinking remains the last of our creative acts' and if some live sport is thrown in for free then so much the better. It will take some pretty fancy thinking to break the habits of a lifetime and cajole people to forsake the pub for the computer. There is no sign of it yet.

webTitle: Chelsea wait on £12m Fowler

fields.headline: Chelsea wait on £12m Fowler
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler was afforded an emotional greeting by Liverpool supporters at Anfield yesterday, hours after the Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson revealed on television that his club had agreed a £12 million fee for the England striker before Christmas.
fields.body:
Robbie Fowler was afforded an emotional greeting by Liverpool supporters at Anfield yesterday, hours after the Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson revealed on television that his club had agreed a £12 million fee for the England striker before Christmas.

The revelation, confirming what had long been known to be intense interest in Fowler from Claudio Ranieri's club, merely serves to fuel the saga surrounding the player's future within an Anfield squad growing ever larger. It now seems likely that Fowler will stay at Anfield at least until the summer.

Aston Villa also inquired about his situation after they feared their move for Juan Pablo Angel had fallen through. Gerard Houllier - who yesterday voiced his worries over Michael Owen's level of fitness - asked Fowler if he would be interested in moving to the Midlands, but was told No.

Hutchinson explained that Chelsea's bid preceded Villa's interest, but Fowler has yet to reply to their offer, despite the £12 million figure meeting the Merseyside club's valuation.

Fowler has never lost his place in the hearts of the home supporters, who gave him a rapturous welcome as he warmed up along the touchline early in the 0-0 draw with Middlesbrough. When he came on as a 61st-minute substitute for Jari Litmanen - one of the four international strikers vying for places at Anfield - the noise from the crowd was practically deafening.

Liverpool's need to hold on to Fowler is not based purely on public relations. The club are in Europe and three domestic competitions, and have two cup ties this week, against Crystal Palace and Leeds.

Houllier also revealed that there are concerns about Michael Owen's general fitness as he recovers from a series of niggling injuries. He missed three clear-cut chances against Middlesbrough, for which Houllier blamed Owen's lack of match sharpness. He might leave Owen out of the squad for the midweek cup game with Crystal Palace.

Fowler, back at full fitness and looking sharp in his half-hour appearance yesterday, will clearly play an increasingly significant role as Liverpool progress on their four fronts. Thus, while Hutchinson's comments yesterday brought Fowler's future back on the agenda, he will almost certainly go nowhere until, at the very earliest, the summer.

webTitle: Arsenal in fight for new stadium

fields.headline: Arsenal in fight for new stadium
fields.trailText: Arsenal's move to a new stadium could be scuppered by a multi-million-pound dispute over a tiny parcel of land owned by a supermarket.
fields.body:
Arsenal's move to a new stadium could be scuppered by a multi-million-pound dispute over a tiny parcel of land owned by a supermarket.

The north London club last November unveiled plans for a 60,000 all-seat stadium on 20 acres of wasteland close to Highbury.

But Sainsbury's own a crucial 'ransom strip' in the middle of the Ashburton Grove site. Arsenal are trying to buy it but they have been outbid by two property companies.

It is understood that uncertainty over the £250 million scheme, which would become the most expensive club ground in the country if it went ahead, forced Arsenal directors to sound out Sir Rodney Walker, the new chairman of the Wembley National Stadium project, on the possibility of sharing the new national stadium.

Moving to Wembley, though, is the club's least preferred option. It would mean they would have to give up potential income from selling food, drink, and advertising in the ground.

The Sainsbury's board meet tomorrow to decide who to sell the land to, and a spokesman pointed out that the company have a duty to sell the eight acres to the highest bidder.

'We've been marketing the site for months,' said a senior Sainsbury's spokeswoman. 'We have three offers on the table. Arsenal's is not the highest. Sainsbury's is a commercial business. We don't want to wreck Arsenal's plans but we have a duty to our shareholders.'

It is understood Arsenal's offer is £2m lower than the highest bidder. The club, desperate to move out of their 38,000-capacity Highbury home, believe Sainsbury's are playing a game of brinkmanship to force them to pay more for the land.

Arsenal want Islington Council to say they will compulsorily purchase the land. If the council refuse to, warn those close to the scheme, the Gunners will abandon the Ashburton Grove project all together.

Well-placed sources close to the club say the site owned by Sainsbury's may be contaminated and whoever buys it will have to pay thousands to make it good.

Arsenal's tortuous search for a new home has lasted for four years. Anxious to generate more revenue through increased seating capacity, the club have considered moving to King's Cross, Finsbury Park, a Green Belt site outside the M25, and even the Millennium Dome in Greenwich - which is close to their original home in Woolwich, south-east London.

The club believe that without an extra 28,000 seats they won't be able to compete with Manchester United and other top clubs in Europe.

Arsenal will make millions selling their Highbury ground to property developers. But they are already facing opposition to their relocation from angry residents who don't want a waste dump close to their home.

If Ashburton Grove did go ahead, it would be one of the biggest regeneration projects in London and would bring thousands of jobs to the area.

webTitle: All together now...

fields.headline: All together now...
fields.standfirst: Robin McKie's trip felt all the better for dispensing with ski-school
fields.trailText: Robin McKie's trip felt all the better for dispensing with ski-school.
fields.body:
When it comes to oxymorons, there is little to beat the notion of a quiet family skiing holiday. The concept is as unlikely as an on-time charter flight at Gatwick.

Mornings are worst. Harassed parents rise early, coax their little ones out of bed, and dispatch them into the care of sinister-looking ski instructors. Invariably, at least one offspring departs in tears, leaving behind a pair of goggles or a glove. A parent races off with the missing garment, only to return to find that breakfast is over and their morning guide has just announced that their group will be doing the Sella Ronda both ways that day, so there will be no stops or breaks for the next eight hours.

In the evening, mother and father are exhausted, and the kids are querulous. The young ones have early dinners and retire reluctantly, only to reappear - once more in tears - during the adult sitting. The next time the family gets together is at dawn the next day, when the same ghastly cycle repeats itself. It is not so much a family holiday, more an exercise in sustained logistics and temper control.

Yet matters needn't be like this. With a little planning, you can ski and enjoy your children at the same time, as we did on our last trip to St Anton. Our trick was simply to go our own way, ignore ski-school and instead indulge in a few, carefully selected private lessons for our children. In the end, the cost worked out roughly the same.

The crucial point was that we had a family holiday, not a skiing trip for a disparate group of individuals. We took leisurely breakfasts, remained together during the day and stopped for breaks at the same time. Such communal experiences are not necessarily an unalloyed joy, of course. Despite 20 years of Alpine holidays, I discovered that my 12-year-old daughter Anna was already a much better skier than me, a fact she showed no inclination to keep to herself.

And I have to admit that Anna's expertise was gained, in part, by her having undergone the deadly cycle of ski-school traumas on previous holidays. But that does not mean parents have to suffer them every vacation. At some point you deserve to reap the rewards of your indulgence, and your offsprings' hard graft, by sharing the slopes with them. In a few years, they won't be seen dead with old duffers like Mum and Dad, after all.

The ambience of our hotel, the Rosanna, was a critical influence. It has an unhurried, pampered routine, with lavish dinners served for all the family and vast buffets in the morning. It was glorious to linger over coffee and watch, satisfaction tempered with pity, the hectic morning scramble, the lost gloves and purple-faced parents.

We were also aided by St Anton, which has retained its cosy Austrian charm despite the massive reconstruction inflicted on its centre for the 2001 World Skiing Championships. It remains a town to wander round, with the grounds of its ski museum and restaurant providing a particularly fine setting for prolonged snowball fights. There are also signs of real Austrian affluence here, of which our favourite example was the Harlekin coffee house we where drank hot chocolate in cups the size of wastepaper bins every evening and which were a particular favourite for Olivia (5) and Tom (9).

The queues that once marred the resort have disappeared since the construction of a six-person chair in place of the old two-seater from Gampen to Kapall and double chair lift replacing the mass T-bar at Rendl. These have opened up a vast pisted arena: daunting for beginners; fine for intermediates - and first rate for families skiing together.

What it costs

The McKies travelled with Mark Warner (08708 480482) to St Anton. A week at the Chalethotel Rosanna, costs from £406 for adults and £356 for children aged 7-10. Ski hire is £64 for adults and £47 for children and the lift pass is £117 for adults, £70 for children.
