webTitle: First-class to the Isles

fields.headline: First-class to the Isles
fields.standfirst: At the start of his round-the-world flight in small planes  Martin Buckley  takes off with a Royal Mail delivery to the Hebrides
fields.trailText: At the start of his round-the-world flight in small planes Martin Buckley takes off with a Royal Mail delivery to the Hebrides.
fields.body:
As the small plane scudded over the Outer Hebrides at 2,000 feet, Captain Jack Morrison made no attempt to disguise his pleasure.

Pilots aren't meant to have fun. Passengers like their flying unexciting, as predictable as pre-election tax-cuts. Ask any airline pilot: you take off - and switch on the autopilot. Then sit back and watch the instruments, making sure no one in the back gets a glass of Chardonnay in their lap.

But we were flying without autopilot, beyond the authority of air traffic control. We were flying the Royal Mails, over the sea to - not Skye, but Stornoway.

Captain Morrison is a big, bearish man, with a small moustache, crinkly eyes and the infinitely reassuring presence of a priest. On the tarmac at Glasgow airport at five o'clock on a January morning, he was clad in a black Loganair overcoat, so long it might have been a cassock. Indeed, Morrison was celebrating an aviation rite: the pre-flight visual check, prodding the plane's nether regions with the beam of a pen torch.

Postal workers were loading the Hebrides' first-class mail into the hold (second-class travels by boat). A few minutes later the runway lights were streaming beneath our wheels. I was jammed into the jump seat at the Captain's elbow. His First Officer, Mike Jardine, took us up.

I was starting my journey around the world in Britain's remotest skies, and in a ribbed, winged box with all the beauty of a flying freight container. 'Lovely plane to fly,' said Mike. 'Looks ungainly, but handles like a light aircraft.' In fact, the Shorts 360 is a direct descendant of the first powered planes ever flown: Shorts was set up in 1908 to produce the Wright brothers' Flyers under licence. Nowadays they make fuselages for the ultramodern Lear jet. We banked steeply over the sulphur ribbons of night-time Glasgow, and set course for Benbecula. An hour later we landed at a runway aligned by some murderous surveyor with the only two peaks for miles around. 'Great fun in fog,' commented Mike.

By the time we had unloaded, the sky was turning rosy. Continuing north past Taransay, where the BBC isolated its Castaways, we crossed the waters of the Minch to Stornoway.

I had persuaded the Post Office to let me hitch-hike with the mails to some of the most far-flung post-boxes in Britain. I went out with postman John Crawford, delivering vaccines from our flight to the hospital, and a large parcel to the Coast Guard. 'What do they want with a load of women's underwear?' I asked. John grinned. 'None of my business, even if it was.'

Eddie Mackenzie, the man in charge of the Western Isles mails, took me to meet Mrs Christina Bannerman, who must be the oldest postwoman in the world. In 1914 when she left school, she was given the job of delivering telegrams to the Admiralty. 'I remember the bay being full of grey battleships,' she told me. 'I'd to wear a uniform with a long skirt, and a belt with a big leather pouch. I'd collect the telegrams from the telegraph machine, and carry them in my pouch up to the admiral.' The telegram is a thing of the past - almost. Mrs Bannerman has her own telegram from the Queen.

At dusk, our dumpy cargo plane was waiting for the night mail. A new crew had taken over at midday, and the Short had spent the daylight hours ferrying passengers. In the evening the seats are stripped out again, and the hold once more carries mail. We took off, and slid south beneath a full moon. 'The climate in the Highlands is incredibly challenging,' Captain David Savage told me. 'It's real hands-on flying. Piloting these small planes about the islands is about as close to the days of pioneer flying as you can get in British aviation today.'

Just beneath us the snowy peak of Ben Nevis was gleaming.

 Martin Buckley is now heading south, to France. You can email him about his journey on mbwingingit@hotmail.com.

webTitle: For whom the cow bell tolls

fields.headline: For whom the cow bell tolls
fields.standfirst: Campbell Stevenson  finds that - as well as pricey - Swiss life can be noisy and breathtaking too
fields.trailText: Campbell Stevenson finds that - as well as pricey - Swiss life can be noisy and breathtaking too.
fields.body:
It would appear to be an admission of boredom, chiming perfectly with one's suspicions about the excitement of Swiss life, to suggest that the highlight of a high summer week in the Alps was a game of Poohsticks. But we'd never played it in such grand - and noisy - surroundings.

On one side of the narrow bridge over which the six of us threw our twigs, sticks and, in one overexcited case, small logs was a foaming pool of cold water, on the other a vertiginous drop, one of five cascades in a 650ft fall. We weren't going to see the end of the race - not without embracing certain death - but no matter. It's the taking part that counts.

We were at the Reichenbach Falls, where Conan Doyle tried unsuccessfully to kill off Sherlock Holmes. The spot of the detective's mano a mano battle with the dastardly Moriarty is marked by a white star placed on the cliffs, and can be reached by a muddy walk through thick forest. We had already walked far enough, so ambled back down to the cog-driven funicular railway that makes the ascent from Meiringen - home of the meringue, as our stomachs full of cream reminded us - a great deal less breathless.

Meiringen is only 14km from the village of Sorenberg, our base for the week, as the crow flies. But unlike the crow we can't soar over the 2,500m Brienzer Rothorn which looms above our farmhouse verandah. The mountains dictate that everywhere is further away than it seems. Back at the bottom of the funicular, I consulted my Rough Guide (you'd think they might have renamed it for Switzerland - you couldn't imagine anywhere less rough. Every time we passed the local police station, the officers of the law were engaged either in watering their many window boxes or taking flatpack Ikea furniture inside). Anyway, a quick flip through the section on the Bernese Oberland convinced me we should keep the waterfall theme alive and nip along to the Lauterbrunnen Valley, a must-see part of the Romantic poets' grand tour, lauded by Wordsworth, Byron and Shelley.

The journey to Lauterbrunnen ('clear fountains') takes us along Lake Brienze. Across the lake I can just make out the little steam train that chugs down from the top of the Brienzer Rothorn, from where the view down to the glassy, cobalt water and across to the snow-covered Jungfrau took what little breath I had left almost clean away the day before (I must remember not to smoke at the top of mountains). A left turn and we were heading up the valley, where the temperature fell, although not as steeply as the cliffs.

Out of sight above them sit the Jungfrau, Eiger and Monk. In summer, a lot of melted ice has to come down from there, and every last drop of it, along with scree and large chunks of rubble, roars down the Trumenbach Falls. Through this narrow series of gorges, fissures and water leaps some 20,000 litres a second drain off the glaciers. It's very loud. This is where immovable object - millions of tons of rock - meets irresistible force - the water. And the force wins, carving a contorted passage to the bottom. Water gushes out, up, around, folds back in on itself. It is, we all agree, absolutely awesome. If that doesn't capture the grandeur, I don't mind: Byron didn't do it justice either.

Of course, we did culture too. A day out in Lucerne, (using Swiss railways - clean, frequent, on time, cheap) where the graffiti is in three languages, all of them proclaiming that Jesus lives. And if it were in a fourth, it wouldn't be English but Japanese. The Japanese love Switzerland - perhaps because they can more easily afford it. We strolled across the Kappelbrücke, Europe's oldest bridge, which had to be rebuilt (in its original wooden style) in 1993 after it burnt down. We trudged along the battlements (lovely view from the main watchtower, which was torched by an arsonist in 1994) and before we returned to the spacious railway station (the original was reduced to cinders 30 years ago) intuition told me I shouldn't smoke in Lucerne either.

While we made full use of Switzerland's efficient transport (although it's not all cheap - the cable car and funicular up and down the Rothorn cost the six of us more than £100), the best way to see the land is to walk. Of our four children, only one has an allergy to using her feet, and even she can be coaxed by the prospect of a mountainside café. For those of us who are veggie, the food at these places tends to be rösti - the large potato pancake which is, needless to say, hearty if rather unappetising for the fourth time. At one café, every outdoor table had a fly-swatter. We looked on in envy at the cows, who have a more natural way of dealing with this problem.

We had the second floor of our chalet, Annie's farmhouse, to ourselves. Annie - who wasn't actually called Annie - had no English and we have no Swiss-German, but we bumbled along in French. Or rather I bumbled. She was fluent in at least three languages, as was every café waitress, most of whom took pity on me after a couple of minutes and happily conversed in idiomatic English.

Sorenberg itself is a quiet village, but a friendly one. When we ordered too much fondue (well, you have to eat it when you're there, don't you?), the restaurateur forced us to take the huge pot home with us to finish it off, trusting that we would return it some time before we left (we did).

In the evenings at the chalet, German MTV blasting out a variety of obscure Berlin hip-hop bands kept one teenager occupied, and a series of entertaining farm cats enthralled the other three children. I had plenty of time to read on the balcony as the sky darkened, watching thunder storms in the distance while a fledermaus flitted around the eaves. And here, as everywhere, the unmistakable background noise, as arrhythmic, multi-toned and omnipresent as stoned hippie drummers late at night at Glastonbury - those bloody cowbells. Honestly, how does anyone ever get any sleep in the countryside?

What it costs

The Stevenson family travelled with Inntravel (01653 629010) which offers self-catering properties in Switzerland, France and Italy. They stayed in Annie's Farmhouse, a self-catering apartment in a working Swiss farmhouse. The price is from £414 to £510 for a family of two adults and two children under 14 to include one week's accommodation and return Dover-Calais Channel crossings. A second week costs from £278 to £346 extra.

webTitle: Square deals in toytown

fields.headline: Square deals in toytown
fields.standfirst: Brian Oliver finds a top spot for water loving kids and a golfing parent
fields.trailText: Brian Oliver finds a top spot for water loving kids and a golfing parent.
fields.body:
An enjoyable part of a family holiday - any holiday, for that matter - is the planning, the poring over brochures months in advance and checking the best way to get from A to B, perhaps with a nice stopover at C on the way and D on the way back. But this time we wanted to keep it short, simple and un-adventurous: no overnight extras, no 30-hour journeys to Italy with the children bored silly, no motorway tolls, no long ferry crossings, no hassle.

Our brochure showed dots and squares all over Western Europe, with some dots having a far better grading than others and the orange squares looking the best bet - 'large holiday complexes with a vast range of sports and on-site activities, children's clubs, cr ches, entertainments, restaurants and shops'. Then there was an orange dot just across the water, halfway between Dieppe and Boulogne and as near to our Brighton home, as the crow flies, as Bournemouth.

The weekend before we left, we went to a wedding in Falmouth. It took eight hours to get there. The door-to-door journey to Belle Dune, our chosen holiday village on the Picardy coast, was three hours shorter, thanks to the new, fast, and very local Newhaven-Dieppe ferry. Everything was going to plan. It stayed that way, too, for two weeks. The only real quibbles were the size of the holiday homes and the golf score.

Of course, from a post-floods perspective, in the dark midwinter, summer holidays are always that much more enjoyable. So, to check on what really happened, it's over to Bonnie, aged seven, and Victor, three-and-a-half. What do you remember about the holiday in France?

'The swimming pool.'

What else?

'Lots of bike riding.'

And Victor?

'The slides.'

As in the swimming pool slides, indoors and out. The fact that he was allowed on them at all put the place miles ahead of so many pools in Britain where the local council's insurance policy can ruin a day out. Three slides, a wave machine, a toddlers' pool, a café that served chips, a shop that sold inflatables, an ice-cream stand and a sandpit. A mini-village all on its own, and so many hours were spent there it would have become boring for the grown-ups if it hadn't been such hard work slogging up the steps to the slide or trying to translate underwater handstand into Italian for Bonnie's latest friend (and she made plenty of them).

There was plenty of water elsewhere, with the village built around a small lake. This was where children of various age groups and nationalities would be taught how to sail, fish and paddle a canoe. And where children of one nationality - British - would regularly fall in, especially from the canoes. It was only a couple of feet deep, though, and they enjoyed their dip.

That was about as rowdy as it got, which was not that surprising considering what Belle Dune didn't have. Namely: no roads, so no cars or motorbikes and no car stereos; no large groups (families only); no loud teenagers (definitely not a cool place to be seen, so only the Dutch teens turned up in numbers); no 18 to 25-year-olds, no mobile phones going off all the time, no drunks, no swearing (except for one word from the boy in the Warrington Wolves rugby league shirt whose table tennis ball blew into the lake; and a few in the bunker on the 14th hole). If that sounds too sterile, don't go. For us, for two weeks, it was bliss.

Although I had a good night out in the launderette - enjoying a junk novel while impressing the ladies by showing them how to work the slots - the main action was down in the square. Here was the bar, which served all the usual French drinks, plus pints for the English. Next door was the restaurant, where the buffet dinners were more than adequate, and very exciting for the children when it came to pudding time. And outdoors were the tables from where you could keep an eye on the young cyclists, who usually stayed up till at least 11pm.

The square was also the epicentre for those great family fun nights - square dancing and that sort of thing - that provided staple entertainment in the evenings. The best night was the 'sports contest' when all members of the family team had to hit a golf ball into a kennel, catch a ball with an egg cup when it rolled out of the gutter, throw some darts, guess what was in the dustbin, catch a bottle with a fishing rod and so on. We came fourth, Bonnie's friends from Essex came third, and with an English family finishing first as well it was a great night for British sport. Those French, Dutch, Italians and Germans took a right pasting.

When the action was too hot down at the square, we'd saddle up and head into town. That meant Bonnie and Victor riding as fast as they could for a mile and a half along the footpath into the nearby village, the name of which has already erased itself from memory, while we chased after them.

The reason for their haste was the racing car ride at the permanent mini-funfair, and the ice-cream shop. There was also, in daylight hours, an exceptional beach. As there was at the other village, the other end of Belle Dune and the other direction on the mini-train which ran to the beach and back every half hour. And two very playable crazy-golf courses, a bi-weekly market (great kippers), and a riding centre that we attended six times. It was only Fr65 for Bonnie to spend an hour on a pony in a group session for absolute beginners, while Victor could sit on for a trip to the beach and back for Fr25. They loved it.

All these facilities, like the golf course, were accessible by foot, bike or mini-train. You didn't need a car at all, though of course the car radio was very useful on Saturday afternoon to tune in to live commentaries from Goodwood (good BBC reception is yet another advantage of staying close to the Channel). And it was much quicker to drive than take the train into town for croissants and baguettes in the mornings. But whatever you do, if you go, don't forget the bikes. You can hire them on site, but it's not cheap.

There are lots of other things you can do on site, too. Hire a boat, play tennis, play golf, pack the children off to the kids' club - various age groups, lots of activities on the water, at the beach and so on. Ours didn't like it, at least until they made friends, and some parents weren't happy with the level of supervision. But if you're not happy, or they aren't, you can do your own thing - like the pony rides.

The golf was one of the biggest attractions for the Brits. It was a spectacular course through the pines and dunes and cost less than £20 a round, which for me worked out at less than 20p a shot. Great value.

And finally? The quibble. The houses look like toytown dwellings, and I'm sure Noddy and the Teletubbies would find them very comfortable, but Big Ears and Dumbo wouldn't. The kitchens are just about passable, the balconies very pleasant, but there's next to no storage space. Don't rent a smaller one.

What it costs

The Oliver family travelled with Eurovillages (01606 787919). The cost of their 14-night holiday at a two-bedroom house sleeping six at Belle Dune was £2,095. This included a Hoverspeed return crossing from Newhaven to Dieppe for a car and up to five passengers. Prices for a one-bedroom apartment, which can sleep up to five start at £470 for one week rising to £1,088 in high season. This includes a P&O Stena crossing from Dover to Calais.

webTitle: US skiing prices go on climbing

fields.headline: US skiing prices go on climbing
fields.standfirst: British skiers may be attracted to North America by ever cheaper package holidays but they could be shocked by the cost of living in the resorts
fields.trailText: British skiers may be attracted to North America by ever cheaper package holidays but they could be shocked by the cost of living in the resorts.
fields.body:
A ski resort cost of living index by Thomas Cook shows that North American prices can be as high as the perceived expensive destinations like Switzerland and Scandinavia.

The cost of a six-day lift pass in the Canadian resort of Banff is - at £156 - the high est in the survey, while an area lift pass at Breckenridge in Colorado is going to cost as much as £125 in low season, the same price as Verbier. The Austrian resort of Kitzbühel comes in at £100, Sweden at £96, Risoul in France at £80 while the cheapest in Poiana Brasov in Romania at £40.

The survey confirms what all skiers know: that the cheapest resorts, if not the best skiing, are found in Andorra and Bulgaria.

webTitle: From: Carolyne (21 Jan)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Carolyne
fields.trailText: When you do get to South Africa, try if you possibly can to go to the Drakensbury Mountains via Sani Pass. We travelled by Baz Bus who arranged for us to get a 4WD up the first part of the mountain to Sani Lodge; an amazing journey under a star-lit sky.
fields.body:
Sam,

Just a very brief note to a fellow mountain lover. I'm enjoying reading your diary entries; I'm a student who's been well and truly bitten by the travelling bug and my only fix during term time is other people's travelling tales - thank you!

When you do get to South Africa, try if you possibly can to go to the Drakensbury Mountains via Sani Pass. We travelled by Baz Bus who arranged for us to get a 4WD up the first part of the mountain to Sani Lodge; an amazing journey under a star-lit sky to start off with. There's a fantastic hostel at the foot of the Pass, ignore the Sani hotel. It's run by some great people who fall over themselves to show you the mountains and take you on treks if you want to. We also travelled up to Lesotho, which is amazingly different from South Africa, stayed overnight wtih a Lesotho family in their mud hut and walked back down across the border the next day.

Hope the weather's getting better anyway - good luck!

Carolyne

webTitle: From: Pablo (21 Jan)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Pablo
fields.trailText: Try Byron Bay in Oz. It's a spectacularly beautiful, wonderfully introspective and outrageously outward looking place. If you go, stay at the Arts Factory. The beaches are incredible, the views second to none.
fields.body:
Milly,

Try Byron Bay in Oz. It's a spectacularly beautiful, wonderfully introspective and outrageously outward looking place. If you go, stay at the Arts Factory. The beaches are incredible, the views second to none.

I spent about five months there last year, living in a tent at the Arts Factory, working about one day a week to support myself. It has good surf, good diving and a cake shop open 23 hours a day. Its the most easterly point of Oz, and theres also a tea tree lake about six kilometres out of town.

fields.body:
Jack Nicholson was different from all of them. Jack is a stand-up guy and a savvy art collector, who bought things for no other reason than that he loved them. His collection, which spills from the 50s tract house he's always lived in on Mulholland Drive into the homes of friends, family, and women - current and former - includes masterpieces by Cézanne, Rouault, Chagall and Magritte. With me now headquartered in California, we became much closer.

Often I'd get a phone call from Bob Colbert, Jack's business manager, inviting me over to Mulholland. When I got there, Jack and Bob would be at the kitchen table, working on their cheeseburgers, catalogues at the ready.

'Here comes the Venusian!' Jack would shout, because he loved to tease me that I came from another planet. 'Come on, Tod, let's go shopping.'

And we'd go at it for hours, debating our picks and our strategy. The only thing that could interrupt us would be Jack's beloved Lakers. If they were on TV, Jack would glance at his watch and leave us with a laugh and a wink, 'Hey, gotta go now.'

The occasional bidding or buying I'd done for him evolved into an investment stash that Jack initially funded with $600,000, with which I was to buy, sell and barter art on our behalf. The two of us, he said, should have some fun, and if we made a few bucks together (as we did), so much the better.

One day, I came across a painting that said 'Jack' to me. It was by Maxfield Parrish, the celebrated American painter/illustrator from the turn of the century, and it depicted a grinning man struggling under the weight of a giant brown sack he carried over his shoulder. It was entitled The Sandman , after the fairytale figure that sprinkles grains of sands on the eyelids of children to put them to sleep.

I called Jack.

'I have something special I want to show you,' I said.

'Well, come on over, Babycakes,' he replied. 'Let's have a look.'

When I got to Mulholland Drive, Jack met me at his door. He took the painting from me and held it in his arms, taking it in. He scrutinised it.

Suddenly I saw that big tears were welling in his eyes. Still without a word, he turned from me and walked quietly up the stairs to his private domain. He went into his bedroom, and there he hung The Sandman over his own bed. It had moved him, he told me later. It had spoken to him of his childhood.

In my own childhood, growing up a poor Italian-American kid outside Manhattan in Yonkers, I'd never dreamed that I'd come this close to the magic and power of Hollywood. What I wanted was to become an artist, and when I was rejected by the school of my choice I took a job at a funeral parlour and then later as a stagehand at the Metropolitan Opera.

In my spare time, I spent whatever money I had on turn-of-the-century furniture and ceramics. Eventually, Stickley pieces were stacked to the ceiling in my tiny apartment off Washington, with the overflow stashed in the homes of friends and relatives. The more I collected, the more I came to believe that sooner or later Art Nouveau and Art Deco, the twin crazes of the 60s and early 70s, would run their course, and why couldn't these works I loved take their place? Finally, in partnership with my cousin Vance Jordan and armed with all the vigour and ignorance of youth, at 27, I decided the time had come to make my move.

In 1976, Soho was still a down-at-the-heels bohemia, but the minute I walked into the space at 457 West Broadway, I saw - imagined into being - my 'theatre of Art'. The ceilings dripped, the floors had holes in them, but the rent was dirt cheap, and there were 5,000sqft. After a few months of scraping money together, we transformed the space.

From my experience backstage at the Met, I knew what lighting alone could do. I showed off our works with beam shapers and pin spots, filtering them to warm up woods and bring up horizon lines on the paintings. Our pieces were restored and polished to a high dramatic sheen, and with them we designed vignettes - environmental ensembles of furniture, lamps, tapestries, and paintings - showing how a still unfamiliar art form might look in a Fifth Avenue apartment or a Soho loft. We mounted memorable exhibitions, like the Martin brothers show, when we turned our gallery into the salon where these eccentric and wildly talented ceramists worked in turn-of-the-century London. Horsedrawn carriages brought our celebrity guests down to Soho in period costume for the opening. The show was a sell-out and rescued the Martin brothers from a near-century of oblivion.

Validation is key in the art world, but it has to come from outside sources, including independent appraisers, academic experts, museum curators. The Metropolitan Museum of Art was planning to open a new Arts & Crafts wing. I convinced Nonnie Frelinghuysen, the Met's curator of American decorative arts, to accept a monumental Fulper piece from the Fulper family and commit to displaying it prominently. Now I only needed to get to the family and convince them to donate this magnificent example of American ceramics. I travelled out to Flemington, New Jersey, one afternoon to talk to them. They were intrigued, but how did I know the Met wouldn't simply stick the piece in the basement, never to be seen again? I gave them my solemn guarantee. The piece went into the Met's permanent display (where it still is) and as a result every self-respecting collector was clamouring for Fulper, raising the price on a Fulper vase tenfold - from $500 to $5,000 - in the course of a year.

Undoubtedly the most important validation comes from the great auction houses, Christie's and Sotheby's. News of the price fetched by a major piece in a Christie's sale reverberates throughout the art world, and it therefore became the goal to control and manipulate such events using a network of operatives. Auction houses need goods to sell, and I was delighted to oblige. Moreover, they were just as eager to have me participate in the biding, openly or secretly. The rising market for that speciality increased Christie's commissions - not only guaranteeing future auctions but also validating the work I sold. It was a cycle I influenced and profited from, sometimes rather questionably.

One of the most elaborately engineered schemes took place one afternoon in the early 80s at a Christie's auction. When I arrived, a fellow dealer handed me a catalogue in which selected items had been annotated in a code no one else would have understood. In effect, it told me what certain collectors intended to bid for certain items. I was interested in one item in particular, a handsome Stickley piece that came from a private collection. I knew a fair bit about it.

In the upstairs auction room, I sat in my reserved seat, prominently in view and ready to bid. Experienced collectors like to see a known dealer bidding, under the assumption that if a dealer bids X dollars, he must have a client ready to pay double that. When the Stickley piece came up, I joined in the early bidding. It started well below the estimate and rose slowly by $1,000 and $2,000 increments. But once it passed the estimate, the atmosphere suddenly became charged. I knew, from my coded catalogue, that there was one collector in the audience who was ready to go well beyond the top-end estimate, and, as it turned out, he even bid past his own maximum. But he didn't win the piece. The winning bidder was 'an unknown collector' from New York City. Not even Christie's knew who it was exactly, or that the unknown bidder worked for me. The only part of the secret arrangement that Christie's knew about was that it was the Jordan-Volpe Gallery that had put the piece on the auctioneer's block to begin with.

What was the point of secretly putting up a piece and then secretly buying it back? I wanted to raise the price of the rest of our Stickley inventory. The gallery had a lot of it, and it was lagging in value compared to its more ornate and striking counterparts. The drama of the auction, which I could point to and publicise, allowed me to more than double the price on every piece of Arts & Crafts furniture I owned.

We massaged the market. I pooled and price-fixed with other dealers. Sometimes we agreed to cover each other at auctions in cases where we might end up acquiring very expensive pieces. There were restorations passed off as originals, and even outright forgeries. But if there were times we may have crossed the line, the excitement we created brought thousands of works of art to levels of appreciation they had never enjoyed before. The decorative arts collections of major American museums possess innumerable pieces that once passed through our hands.

And yet the gallery rarely made the profits that people thought we made. We needed to keep our inventory up regardless of cost, and this was only part of the operation's mounting expense. I see now with the benefit of hindsight that I was another part of the problem. It wasn't that I didn't like money myself, but it just slipped through my fingers. And sometimes I gave pieces away for things far more important to me than money.

Back in the mid-80s the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe was a regular at the gallery. He used to drop in from his loft on Bond Street almost every day around five, and sometimes I'd lend him pieces - on approval - for his shoots, including a wonderful pedestal on which, I discovered one evening on visiting his loft, he was posing his black lover of the moment. But there was something I had that Bobby craved, a matching pair of colossal bronze heads of the god Pan from the French Belle Époque. At a Dionysian fete at the Palladium, Bobby approached me. I'd brought the price on the Pans down to $25,000 for him, but that was as far as I was willing to go. That didn't, however, deter Bobby.

'My pictures are in demand,' he said. 'How about it? I'll do you in exchange for the heads.' That day he followed me around armed with a small, ancient Leica camera that he advanced with a hand crank. I'd had the Pans delivered to my apartment for the shoot, thinking that I'd send them on to his loft the next day. But Bobby couldn't wait.

'I'm taking them with me,' he insisted, once the work was done.

So the two of us manoeuvred the Pans, one after the other, out on to the street and into a taxi, and off Bobby went, thoroughly delighted with them. The Jordan-Volpe gallery got nothing, but a decade later, when I lost almost everything, I managed to rescue from the wreckage of my life several portraits of me, signed by Robert Mapplethorpe, in frames chosen by the photographer.

I should have seen that the end was near for me when I was called to work for a man whose apocalyptic visions, complete with fireballs and chase scenes enacted in films like Top Gun and Bad Boys , had made him one of Hollywood's top producers. Don Simpson had been on Joel's early hit list for me, but with his drug-enriched paranoia (he eventually died of an overdose), it took him several years - and my work with the Bruckheimers' collection and, finally, Don Umemoto, the architect - to decide I was OK.

Umemoto's path and mine crossed often in Los Angeles, and inevitably we began to help each other out. One afternoon, Umemoto called me from Simpson's new house. 'He wants to see you right away.' I drove over to Bel Air and went in, through the gates, up the long driveway, to a massive stucco edifice with Spanish tile roofs. Renovations were in full progress, and the rooms were totally empty. Pacing the floor was Simpson, a hulking man of gargantuan vulgarity whose rubberised face was the legacy of countless plastic surgeons. His idea of fun, when bedding some new playmate, was to play erotic videos of himself screwing her predecessor.

'Now listen,' he said to me and Umemoto that day. 'Sixty days from now this place is gonna shake, rattle 'n' roll. I'm giving a housewarming party that'll rock the whole fuckin' town. You've got 60 days to finish it, and I don't want any screwin' around, is that goddamn clear?'

Then he turned to me.

'They say you're OK,' he said. 'Well, fit it up with your best stuff. Get it done. I don't give a fuck what it costs. Just don't screw me. I find out you're screwin' me, I'll cut your balls off.' The more I saw of Simpson, the more I believed that he might just make good on his threats.

He wanted dozens of everything - furniture, pottery, carpets, lamps - multiplied by every room in the house. I was at his house when the pieces got delivered, and I went from room to room, placing them carefully, only to find the next day that the control freak who was employing me had switched everything around during the night.

Simpson paid on time, which was good, since I sorely needed the money, but he took it out in abuse. Whenever he saw me with other people present - and there were always other people present - he'd start rolling up his sleeve, make a mock tourniquet, and say, 'Here comes The Pusher. He's worse than drugs.' Maybe that was some sort of insight into an addict's persecution complex: I was there only because he'd ordered me to fill up his house for him.

At least I got off better than Umemoto. 'Fucking gook!' Simpson was screaming one day when I showed up. He'd just decided that he hated the green marble that the architect had laid down in the entrance way. 'Wait till I get my hands on him! I'll kill that motherfuckin' son of a bitch!' People in a rage often threaten to kill, but with Simpson, when you saw the blood rushing to his remade face, and his twisted grimace, and you remembered that he snorted cocaine from morning till night till morning, it was something else again. Fortunately, the architect was nowhere to be found that day.

The 60 days passed, and somehow we got the job done. I have no idea whether Simpson's party rocked the town or not, since I wasn't invited.

And there you have it. I'd wanted to be a player, to sell art and make movies, but I was just Joel Silver's Art Guy. I'd tried to buy my way in. I'd rented a $6,500-a-month Tibetan palace on Castilian Drive in the Hollywood hills, complete with gardens, pool, a vintage Aston Martin, and Penny Marshall, David Lynch, and Rebecca De Mornay for neighbours. I spent a fortune remodelling it, and copied a lifestyle that my book-keeper calculated was costing me almost 10 times my rent.

Once the art market crashed in the early 90s, I found myself in deep trouble. My costs had sky-rocketed and nobody was buying. I decided my only chance was to move back to New York, certain that I'd have no problem getting back into the jet stream of the art world. But by 1993, the other dealers, whom in many cases I'd known and worked with for years, had no intention of letting that happen. Their take had shrunk as well, and there was no chance they were going to share it with a dealer who'd gone Hollywood. I kept up a bold front, took a room at the Regency; you can't let them see you weak, in either Hollywood or the art world. It didn't work;

I declared bankruptcy in 1995 with the assurances of my lawyer that I had to tell everything exactly the way it happened or else I'd never get a clean start. So in my bankruptcy proceedings I explained how I worked, how the art world worked, and my connections with celebrities.

The art world tends to balance its payments and receipts like a careless household. Holding on to consignment fees, taking from Peter to pay Paul, this is business as usual in the art world. What was I doing differently? One day a lawyer for one of my more aggressive creditors informed my lawyer that they were going to take their case to the FBI. Why? In a federal fraud case, the creditors have a better shot at restitution. More to the point, the FBI loves celebrity cases, the lawyer explained. They'd be just as thrilled as anyone to get a chance to knock on Jack Nicholson's door.

The FBI, prodding me to give names and access to major players in the New York art world and the Hollywood elite, investigated me for two years. It ended one morning in rural New Hampshire, when a squad of agents, armed and armoured, invaded the condo I was staying in with my companion and our little daughter. Not long afterward, I pleaded guilty to fraud on five counts, including one involving Nicholson's fund, and made restitution to Christie's and others.

I was sentenced to 28 months in the federal prison in Taft, California.

Meanwhile, I became a leper in Hollywood. With one month left to go in my prison term, I begged Joel Silver to give me a job, any job. All he could do was impart some Hollywood wisdom: 'When it's over, it's over.' I was worse than a leper: no one came near me, no one knew me. Terry Semel denied that I'd ever ridden in Warners' private jet.

I had, though - back in the days when he confided that he would've traded jobs with me. 'Why?' I asked. 'Because you have the freedom to live your life creatively,' he said. 'To make your own choices. I don't even have time to breathe.'

The life I'd chosen, the dream Joel had imparted to me that night in the Hollywood hills, ended with little room to breathe - I was disgraced, penniless, and serving out a more than two-year federal prison sentence. When I got out, Jack Nicholson was the only one who called to ask how I was doing. I'd thought of him more than once when I was in there. One day, I received an auction catalogue a friend from New York sent me, and I remembered Jack on the phone, poring over the catalogues, and me thinking that there was a whole world in his 'So?' - money, power, celebrity.

There was a Christie's auction coming up, but this time there wasn't going to be any auction madness with Jack, there was no shopping to be done. This was for 'The Barbra Streisand Collection: Important American Arts & Crafts, Architectural Designs, Art Nouveau and Works by Louis Comfort Tiffany'. The catalogue was an elaborate and beautifully illustrated book more than 200 pages long, and it included the three vases I'd brought Barbra that night at her house. The caption read: 'Provenance - Tod Volpe.' It brought me back, if only for a moment, to a world I had given almost everything to create.

I'd wanted to be a player, to sell art and make movies, but I was just Joel Silver's Art Guy. I'd tried to buy my way in. I'd rented a $6,500-a-month Tibetan palace on Castilian Drive in the Hollywood hills, complete with gardens, pool, a vintage Aston Martin, and Penny Marshall, David Lynch, and Rebecca De Mornay for neighbours. I spent a fortune remodelling it, and copied a lifestyle that my book-keeper calculated was costing me almost 10 times my rent. Once the art market crashed in the early 90s, I found myself in deep trouble. My costs had sky-rocketed and nobody was buying. I decided my only chance was to move back to New York, certain that I'd have no problem getting back into the jet stream of the art world. But by 1993, the other dealers, whom in many cases I'd known and worked with for years, had no intention of letting that happen. Their take had shrunk as well, and there was no chance they were going to share it with a dealer who'd gone Hollywood. I kept up a bold front, took a room at the Regency; you can't let them see you weak, in either Hollywood or the art world. It didn't work; I declared bankruptcy in 1995 with the assurances of my lawyer that I had to tell everything exactly the way it happened or else I'd never get a clean start. So in my bankruptcy proceedings I explained how I worked, how the art world worked, and my connections with celebrities. The art world tends to balance its payments and receipts like a careless household. Holding on to consignment fees, taking from Peter to pay Paul, this is business as usual in the art world. What was I doing differently? One day a lawyer for one of my more aggressive creditors informed my lawyer that they were going to take their case to the FBI. Why? In a federal fraud case, the creditors have a better shot at restitution. More to the point, the FBI loves celebrity cases, the lawyer explained. They'd be just as thrilled as anyone to get a chance to knock on Jack Nicholson's door. The FBI, prodding me to give names and access to major players in the New York art world and the Hollywood elite, investigated me for two years. It ended one morning in rural New Hampshire, when a squad of agents, armed and armoured, invaded the condo I was staying in with my companion and our little daughter. Not long afterward, I pleaded guilty to fraud on five counts, including one involving Nicholson's fund, and made restitution to Christie's and others. I was sentenced to 28 months in the federal prison in Taft, California. Meanwhile, I became a leper in Hollywood. With one month left to go in my prison term, I begged Joel Silver to give me a job, any job. All he could do was impart some Hollywood wisdom: 'When it's over, it's over.' I was worse than a leper: no one came near me, no one knew me. Terry Semel denied that I'd ever ridden in Warners' private jet. I had, though - back in the days when he confided that he would've traded jobs with me. 'Why?' I asked. 'Because you have the freedom to live your life creatively,' he said. 'To make your own choices. I don't even have time to breathe.' The life I'd chosen, the dream Joel had imparted to me that night in the Hollywood hills, ended with little room to breathe - I was disgraced, penniless, and serving out a more than two-year federal prison sentence. When I got out, Jack Nicholson was the only one who called to ask how I was doing. I'd thought of him more than once when I was in there. One day, I received an auction catalogue a friend from New York sent me, and I remembered Jack on the phone, poring over the catalogues, and me thinking that there was a whole world in his 'So?' - money, power, celebrity. There was a Christie's auction coming up, but this time there wasn't going to be any auction madness with Jack, there was no shopping to be done. This was for 'The Barbra Streisand Collection: Important American Arts & Crafts, Architectural Designs, Art Nouveau and Works by Louis Comfort Tiffany'. The catalogue was an elaborate and beautifully illustrated book more than 200 pages long, and it included the three vases I'd brought Barbra that night at her house. The caption read: 'Provenance - Tod Volpe.' It brought me back, if only for a moment, to a world I had given almost everything to create.

webTitle: Let loose in the unfrozen north

fields.headline: Let loose in the unfrozen north
fields.standfirst: Andrew Smith finds lots of open space with uncrowded beaches, great views... and a Hell's Angels convention nearby
fields.trailText: Andrew Smith finds lots of open space with uncrowded beaches, great views... and a Hell's Angels convention nearby.
fields.body:
That the Danish ferry timetable advertised itself as the 'Fartplan 2000' caused much hilarity in some regions of the family ('Oh come on, Dad, it's not that funny...'), but on the boat itself hilarity was not much in evidence. We were on our way from Hirtshals, which is Denmark's northernmost port, to Mandal on the southern tip of Norway, which meant it was a bit late to be asking myself what I knew about our host nation. I realised that the answer was confined to the melancholy playwright Ibsen, the depressive novelist Knut Hamsun and Munch's The Scream . I also knew that the Norwegians are trying to sell the region we were visiting as one of the world's more improbable sun'n'surf holiday destinations. And that I, alone it seemed, had believed them.

Topographically, Norway in the summer is something else. Rather like Iceland, the covers come off and the countryside, after so many months hidden and inaccessible, opens into a playground. Driving towards Mandal from the small port of Kristiansand, the first thing you notice is how many lakes are hidden among the pines; the second, how few fences. The Norwegians pride themselves on the fact that the land is available to all. And to a Briton, such freedom of movement is almost as remarkable as the third thing you notice, which is the number of Easy Rider-style Harley-Davidsons on the road. But we'll come to that shortly.

If we still had any doubts that this introverted place is not yet part of the European mainstream, they were dispelled the moment we walked into our rented cottage. The grounds were generous, the sky vast, the view over the adjoining lake and Hell's Angels festival in the next field unsurpassed... Sorry, have I mentioned the Hell's Angels yet? Possibly not, because next to the internal decor, clearly bulk-purchased as surplus from a 1970s porn set, they didn't seem that significant.

Then there were the dark etchings in the stairwell, with titles like Pain, which soon had my partner - intuitive in these matters - constructing elaborate theories about a haven that had fallen into disrepair when its wealthy owner's lover died traumatically, possibly beneath a falling tree. Prone to gloom herself, she was thrilled to find a place existed where everyone was as moody as she. I've seldom seen her so happy.

So that first afternoon I watched at the window while the children scrambled for wild raspberries in the garden, Sonya sprinkled lavender water through the house in an attempt to exorcise it of unhappiness, and the Angels lugged an ominously large generator down to the lake.

My thoughts turned to Sharon Tate and The Shining , and more frightening still that night we were given an ear-splitting account of the entire Black Sabbath catalogue, sung in Norwegian . You might say that the Fartplan was working. And we'd only been there a day. What more had Norway in store for us, we wondered?

In itself, the idea of southern Norway as the ideal location for a beach holiday is not so very absurd. In summer, the climate is much like our own in a typical year: unpredictable, but prone to sunny spells, during which it gets very warm indeed. The children (four and six) enjoyed the sand, the shallow water at the foot of the fjords and the dunes and pine forest that lay just behind, with endless rocks to climb. They didn't like the way Dad seemed to have endless reasons for not swimming in icy water ('Sorry, son, just polishing my eyeballs, ask me again in 14 years' time...') or the fact that, while Norwegian adults mostly speak flawless English if you absolutely force them to, young children don't. We had plenty of people to speak to. They were pretty much on their own, apart from us.

Our best day began on a rainy morning, when we decided to drive up the Mandal Valley and into the hills. By midday the sun was out and the rain had stopped and we were having a picnic beside a waterfall, clambering over heathery outcrops in search of wild raspberries, blackberries, blueberries, redcurrants and cranberries, with not a soul in sight to disturb the peace. We went home tired and happy, and that night the children made their own berry ice cream (recipe, with apologies to Nigella: buy tub of vanilla ice cream, tip berries in), after which we sat in the garden reading and watching a vivid late sunset. If this was all there was to it, Norway would indeed be an unimpeachable destination for overcrowded, overpaced Brits.

However, there is a sombre additional factor which we haven't yet discussed: prices. Everything is at least two-to-three times as expensive as at home and it's easy to let this get to you. You find yourself behaving as though you were in a Gary Larson cartoon, complaining about the cost of things you will never buy, exclaiming: 'Look, dear! Did you see the price of that rat poison? And what about those colostomy bags?' But it gets worse, because alcohol is between three and five times what we are used to, very hard to find and near undrinkable once located. We'd been warned and took some with us. I dropped a bottle of wine on the first day and could hardly speak for 24 hours.

What's more, the Norwegian diet is worse than any you are likely to encounter elsewhere in the world. They produce little of their own food, which is why prices are so high and may also be why the national dish is the hot dog. The only viable option is to stick to fresh fish. We ate simply and went home fitter and healthier and just that little bit hungrier, remembering all the things our parents had told us about life during wartime.

On our return, a friend wondered whether, if they granted national independence to a rehab clinic like The Priory, it might not resemble a holiday in Norway. I know what he means, but it would be wrong to dismiss the place completely. Our trusty Subaru estate could have carried far more supplies than we thought to take. Our children loved the adventure of travelling across on ferries and the space to roam once we arrived, while accommodation and transport are surprisingly reasonable.

Nevertheless, we decided that the best way to 'do' Norway would be to spend a few weeks in a caravan, following the craggy coast roads from south to north - and you couldn't do this with children. We've got it pencilled in for our retirement, by which time global warming might have worked its wonders and made the waters a little more temperate, too. I can hardly wait.

What it costs

The Smith family travelled with DFDS Seaways (08705 333 1116). A nine-night holiday in a Norwegian cottage starts at £984 in a specified cottage and £804 in an unspecified cottage in June. This includes return overnight crossings between Newcastle and Kristiansand in a four-berth inside cabin with ensuite, a night in a Kristiansand hotel with breakfast before returning to the UK and six nights in the cottage.

webTitle: Oh dear, I've lost my cool

fields.headline: Oh dear, I've lost my cool
fields.standfirst: Will Buckley gets hot and bothered
fields.trailText: Will Buckley gets hot and bothered.
fields.body:
I've always had a soft spot for the Portuguese since their bloodless revolution of 1974, which they accomplished with rare style and no little elegance. Not only were the revolutionaries so laid-back that they stopped their armoured tanks at red lights while storming Lisbon, but also, and clinchingly, the signal for the popular uprising to begin was the Portuguese entrant belting out the opening line of their Eurovision Song Contest entry. Magnificent. How different things might have been if at the moment the skirts had come off during Bucks Fizz's 'Making Your Mind Up' the people had risen as one, driven sedately through London - no point starting the new golden era with a traffic violation - stormed Capital Radio and turfed Margaret Thatcher out of Downing Street.

There was great happiness at home, therefore, when the chance arrived to spend two weeks doing as little as possible in the Algarve. Especially as it was being offered by the Travel Club of Upminster. This may sound like an outfit specialising in block-bookings for the undiscerning professional footballer, but it has been going for a long time as a tour operator. Back in 1936 Harry Chandler pretty much invented package holidays bicycling round Austria to ask the question that would become a standard for the industry: 'Is everything OK?'

Everything went more than OK for us longer than could possibly be imagined. The car rental people were helpful; the directions to the hotel were so detailed that there were only a half-dozen or so navigational errors; the hotel, as promised, was on the beach. Up to the room we hurried to unpack, but some dimwit had plucked the wrong suitcase off the carousel. I blamed Antler, on the ground that if you are in the luggage business you have some responsibility to distinguish your product from your competitors, but I might as well have been screaming at the moon. On the plus side, we made sufficient trips to the airport to iron out those navigational errors and the problem took less than a day to sort. Just as my wife Grainne had come round to the insurance-scam possibilities and had mentally bought her new wardrobe, the wretched Antler reappeared.

We were staying at the Hotel Garbe in Armação de Pera which, with the kind of serendipitous touch that gives you an early talking-point for the holiday, was the very hotel where my Mum and Dad spent their honeymoon. But when my parents had come here it had been one of only three hotels in the whole of the Algarve whereas, come the new millennium, it was one of perhaps 3,000. Not quite so romantic, then, especially as much of the development in Armação has, even according to Berlitz, 'unfortunately not been in the best taste'.

No matter, the Garbe has retained a faded Seventies charm: brown, smoky glass in the foyer and straight-down-the-middle-of-the-road entertainment in the bar in the evening. The kind of hotel where oldsters book in for a month in the winter to warm their bones. And very nice, too.

Our only problems were geographical and logistical. First, it was toe-curlingly hot. Walking on the beach was like joining up for one of those 'no pain, no gain' experience weekends. From midday to 4pm the best place to be was inside, and with three chil dren the easiest place to be inside, as there are only so many things you can do in a foyer, was the hotel room. We spent a lot of time in that room. Some of it quality. Some not.

Second, there's the dinner problem. This remains intractable. Either you stoke up the kids with sufficient chocolate to maintain their energy levels and run the risk of them - having consumed 13 Mini-Milks - taking one bite and throwing up all over the restaurant. Or you starve them, put up with two hours of three-way tantrums and watch them fall asleep face first in their pasta due to exhaustion. Either way it does not make for a relaxed eating environment.

Fortunately, this was a double-header holiday and just as we were despairing if we would ever eat dinner in this town again the second week arrived and we moved to a villa in the hills. This was fabulous. A private pool, room to sleep nine, a cleaner for three hours every morning. It was almost embarrassing. Less adventurous families would have stayed put. We, stupidly, felt compelled to explore.

Thus it was I spent my 36th birthday at Zoomarine in 40-plus temperatures queueing to watch dolphins, sea lions and a live parrot sketch. The following day we celebrated Grainne's birthday with a lunch in the hill village of Monchique followed by - after one tiny 50-50 mistake - a 90-minute impromptu detour on the most winding road in the Iberian peninsula.

There were no excuses. I was sacked as navigator. The next day on a trip to the beach Grainne took a plainly idiotic left and we ended up jamming the hire car in a sand dune. Even a passing stranger in a T-shirt with 'Strong' on the front couldn't help us out.We were jiggered. It was arguably, for this particular ex-navigator, the highlight of the holiday. When we finally returned to the villa we worked out that, if we moved, things went wrong, so to solve this we would stop moving. This worked fine until I was left in sole control of the children. What fun we had locking Little Mo in the car and spraying her with water. What fun she had playing with the controls. What a restful time we had as Mo kipped out in the car.

But how embarrassing it was to find when it was time to drive to the airport that our game had completely banjaxed the car battery. Once again, the kind people from the Travel Club came to the rescue. If the holiday had a theme, that was it, and they must have been thrilled to see the back of us. The trouble is, I think we might be back.

What it costs

The Buckley family travelled with the Travel Club of Upminster (01708 225000) staying for a week at a junior suite in the Hotel Garbe followed by a week at the four-bed Villa Quino, Caravela. The cost for this combination for a family of two adults, two children under 12 and an infant, ranges from £1,863.60 in low season to £3,230.40 in high. This includes return flights.

The costs for a similar family sharing a twin room at the hotel and staying in a two-bed villa ranges from £1,540.80 to £2,649.60. The charge for an infant under two is £20 for the flight. Hire of a group two car (Renault Clio) costs from £74 for a week to £128.

webTitle: Wetsuit riders of the wind

fields.headline: Wetsuit riders of the wind
fields.standfirst: Harold Frayman breezes out on the Solent and finds falling in can be as much fun as cresting the waves
fields.trailText: Harold Frayman breezes out on the Solent and finds falling in can be as much fun as cresting the waves.
fields.body:
You don't have to know the difference between port and starboard to enjoy being blown across the open water in a small boat. Which may seem obvious if you've never learnt to sail, but is pretty startling, even revolutionary, in the world where it's taught.

John Ely, principal of the UK Sailing Academy at Cowes on the Isle of Wight, goes further. His ambition is to offer sailing much as a garage might offer a hire car: 'At the start of the day I'd have a whole load of boats rigged and ready to go. People would walk in and say "I fancy that one today" and a few minutes later they'd be off.' Not that he's so far off fulfilling his ambition now. His tutors had a bunch of beginners, adults and children, sailing within a couple of hours of arriving at the academy - and a fair chunk of that time was spent struggling with the challenge of climbing into a wetsuit.

My nine-year-old son Jonathan and I had joined a group of half-a-dozen adults and their children for a two-day course one weekend in October. Our experience ranged from none to almost none; and I don't know whether Jonathan can now tell port from starboard, but I do know that he and the rest of us can sail single-handed on the open sea (well, given the right conditions).

Adults and children were separated during training, and it helped to know that we were all continuously monitored by tutors equipped with fast safety boats - the academy aims to have no more than six students to each tutor and we enjoyed a far more generous ratio than that.

The adults started in Wayfarers, a traditional training boat nowadays made of moulded plastic. The children used Laser Picos, tiny boats that raced through the water in the lightest of breezes. Jonathan says: 'The Picos were fun to ride and easy to sail. I didn't really enjoy having to capsize, though falling in was fine. Despite it being autumn, the water is at its warmest at that time of year.' At least one fellow student insisted that falling in was the best bit. And despite the emphasis on pleasure, we learnt plenty: some vocabulary, a bit about the rigging, a lot about the wind. By the end of the first day, adults and children had each taken charge while sailing on the open sea.

As well as beginners' courses, the academy teaches people how to sail some very big boats indeed - their latest toy, still only available in a handful of sailing schools, is a simulator which allows you to wreck an oil tanker in the Straits of Dover (it may do other things). And they teach instructors: some of ours had first stepped into a sailing boat only a few months earlier, but if they hadn't told us I would not have guessed.

On the second day the adults spent most of the time in bigger Lasers. By comparison with the Wayfarers, all the Lasers are lighter, more responsive and livelier or, as the tutors put it, less forgiving. Put your weight in the wrong part of a Wayfarer and you'll slow down; in a Laser you'll soon capsize. That knowledge is a great teacher.

As we raced across the mouth of the River Medina, listening to tutors insist that the Solent is one of the trickiest stretches of sailing in the world, it was difficult not to believe we were ready for a shot at ocean racing. Rubbish, of course, but a measure of their success at building our confidence. By the end of the second day, those of us who wanted - and there was no pressure at all - had had a go on the catamarans, taking the tiller or hanging out at full stretch over the water while wearing a trapeze harness.

It all fits perfectly with Ely's strategy. He recognises that sailing has an image which doesn't always appeal to customers looking for extreme sports. The academy offers kitesurfing (which looks like a cross between windsurfing and hang-gliding) and the rest, but the sailing has to be exciting too, and without a long induction. 'When we have children here for a week, we always try to make sure they get to sail a catamaran, fast, at least once before they leave. We want them to experience the thrill,' he says.

It seems to work. Jonathan says: 'I enjoyed going on, and helping to sail, a catamaran; I had a fantastic time sailing.'

Never mind him. It worked for me too. And if all this climate change means we're in for a lot more flooding, Jonathan and I will be well prepared.

What it costs

The Fraymans travelled with Wightlink Holidays (0870 582 0202), taking the Wightlink car ferry and staying at the Priory Bay Hotel, Seaview. A two-night break costs from £147, including half-board and ferry. UK Sailing Academy (01983 294941) courses cost from £225 per adult (£160 per child) including lunch and evening meal. A week costs £285 (£230).

webTitle: Curious past of internet adoption couple

fields.headline: If they'd kept quiet, would  they still have the twins?
fields.standfirst:
Nick Paton Walsh in Mold uncovers the curious past of the couple who chose to buy a bigger family, and finds neighbours less than impressed

Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: Nick Paton Walsh in Mold uncovers the curious past of the couple who chose to buy a bigger family, and finds neighbours less than impressed.
fields.body:
For Peter Shone, it was not the exorcisms, the menagerie of pets, the wild parties or the caravan park in the garden that was most annoying about living next door to Alan and Judith Kilshaw. 'It's the stray pot-bellied pigs,' the stable owner told The Observer last week. 'They keep escaping from their garden and coming over here to upset my horses.'

For two years, Shone has lived next to the Kilshaws, the couple who last week shot from anonymity in the Welsh village of Buckley to international infamy. The pair gleefully revealed last Tuesday that they had paid £8,200 to adopt twin American girls that had been put up for sale on the internet by their natural mother.

But instead of sharing the happy news, the world was horrified. Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, described the events as 'appalling'.

There was more anger when it emerged that the couple had apparently taken the twins, six-month-old Beverley and Kimberley, from a Californian couple, Richard and Vickie Allen, who believed they were the rightful adoptive parents. Loading the children into a people carrier in San Diego, the Kilshaws had driven more than 2,000 miles across America with the Allens in hot pursuit. After reaching Chicago, they booked flights home to Manchester before the distraught American couple could catch up with them.

It emerged that the Allens had already paid Tina Johnson, the head of an adoption brokers called the Caring Heart Agency, £4,000 for the babies. After two months caring for the twins, the couple claim they were tricked into handing the children back to their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, for a visit. Instead, she gave them to the Kilshaws. It is claimed that the British pair knew the Allens had already paid for the twins.

The 'adoption couple', as they have become known to weary locals in north Wales, will begin their battle for permanent custody of the twins on Tuesday at the High Court in Birmingham. The Allens have also called in lawyers, who said the FBI would see if any US laws had been broken.

Amid growing public disquiet, last Thursday night Flintshire social services, backed by police officers, swooped on the Beaufort Park Hotel near Mold where the Kilshaws were staying, courtesy of a US TV network. After a tense, three-hour confrontation between social workers and the couple, and in the glare of flashing cameras, the sleeping babies were removed under the terms of the 1989 Children Act. Within an hour, the twins were with foster parents - their fourth set of carers in their short lives. Amid chaotic scenes in the cramped hotel, friends of the Kilshaws fled in tears leaving the couple to angrily denounce the authorities who had applied to make the children wards of court.

It was thought yesterday that the Kilshaws had fled to France with the help of a tabloid newspaper, crowning a week of often bizarre and heated media interviews in which the couple had railed against a host of perceived enemies, blaming everyone but themselves for the debacle. They ignored worries that the twins' welfare might have been at stake during the punishing round of radio and TV appearances, a factor that finally persuaded social workers to act.

In a media frenzy, the couple quickly became objects of public hate as lurid details of their chaotic private lives spilled across newspaper front pages and television screens. Journalists fell on north Wales. Callers jammed radio chat shows savaging the couple. Their decision to publicise the adoptions was a PR disaster.

One man, though, had a more simple explanation for the farce. 'The Kilshaws are like kids in a sweetshop,' said Shone. 'If they want something - be it a horse, a car or even a child - they get it, and then they discard it once they're bored.'

Whitehouse Farm is not the typical country retreat of a practising solicitor. The only signs of Alan Kilshaw's reported wealth and respectability come from the Toyota MR2 sports car parked in the drive.

Last week a heap of manure lay near the front door. Shopping bags blew around the lawn and birds perched on two dilapidated cars rusting in the back yard. Through the dusty windows of a ground floor room, a fax machine whirred, yet another request for an interview.

With the couple and the accompanying media circus now gone, neighbours and disgruntled locals yesterday offered a glimpse of the sometimes bizarre life the Kilshaws have led. There was the ever expanding collection of tenants and pets, and a road rage incident in which they were said to have fought bitterly with another driver at the foot of their road.

One man grumbled about the caravan park the couple had opened in their back garden and muttered darkly about Judith. Then there was the 'the milky man', the apparition of an old man in a milkman's coat who the family were convinced haunted their home.

Judith, 47, moved into Whitehouse Farm with Alan, 45, two years ago. Before that she was a divorcee who had found solace in the clubs of Frodsham, Cheshire, near the estate where she lived. Alan was her white knight, whisking her and 18-year-old daughter Caley away to the detached expanses of the farm.

When Alan, Judith, their sons James, seven, and Rupert, four, and Caley moved in to the farmhouse, they held a party for friends and locals. About 50 people drank white wine in a marquee erected in the then immaculate garden. Shone, their new neighbour, felt comfortable enough with the latest additions to Well Street.

Then the pets came. 'They got a couple of dogs within the first month,' said Shone. Their cats quickly grew to 18 in number. They started buying up horses, most of whom were old, tired ponies bought from travellers at the horse market in Beeston, Cheshire. 'When they see an animal they like they just get it,' said Shone. 'Within the first six months they got to be overrun with 13 horses so they had to rent out a new field.'

Then the two pot-bellied pigs arrived, and began roaming the farm freely, often breaking out into the neighbouring property. Shone said Judith did not realise the smell of pigs distressed horses and, when her foals and ponies snorted, she thought they had gone mad.

Shone's stablehands often treated the Kilshaw horses. They recall them being poorly fed and ill. 'They weren't responsible animal owners,' he said.

Besides the occasional altercation, the Kilshaws kept their distance from other villagers. Alan, a director and spokesman for the obscure anti-European political group the Democratic Party, ran his solicitor's practice singlehandedly from the study - known as 'Whitehouse Chambers'.

He specialised in housing law, helping tenants take their landlords to court.

When the Kilshaws did socialise, it did not go that well. Twice, Judith went for a drink in the British Eighteen Club in Buckley, a reserved bar for ex-servicemen where even the stand-up comedians are asked not to use 'bad' language.

Judith first graced the club 18 months ago and, after a few drinks, was asked to empty her glass and leave after a complaint about language from a female member.

About a year later, Judith returned with Caley, who was then underage. After a few drinks she was again asked to leave after fighting in the ladies' toilets with a younger woman. She has not returned.

One of the Kilshaws' later parties at the farm - with a tarts and vicars theme - ended with equal embarrassment when police were called after a complaint about the noise. One partygoer recalls the Kilshaws taking a fair time to realise that the officers were genuine, and not stripogram entertainment ordered by their guests. Later, Judith added to her increasingly bizarre reputation in the village when she called in paranormal investigators after a vision of an old man in a dairyman's coat which one son had nicknamed 'milky man'. The investigation was even filmed.

The procurement of the twins was supposed to be the final step on a long and difficult journey for the Kilshaws, anxious to expand their family yet further.

Judith had had a lengthy search to overcome fertility problems. She looked for children to adopt in Thailand and China. She tried IVF a number of times. She admitted to one newspaper that she had given her husband's sperm to a friend who was having problems conceiving after giving birth to a stillborn child.

But the most curious attempt to conceive involved the help of her estranged eldest daughter. Even she was prepared yesterday to dish the dirt on her mother.

Louisa Richardson, 22, moved out of the former family home after the failure of Judith's first marriage to civil servant Mike Richardson. Yesterday she spoke of how she had raised a child without the support of her mother in a freezing cold caravan.

Yet this turn of events had not stopped Judith from making an astonishing request of her eldest child. Kilshaw asked her daughter if she could 'rent' her womb, and so have Louisa be the surrogate mother to her stepfather's child. Louisa says she was offered £3,000, and declined.

Flintshire social services declined to comment as to whether the Kilshaws had requested permission to adopt before, but it is understood the couple were older than the usual limits allow. They had certainly not been open about their new American arrivals. One of the lodgers who lives in their farmhouse told The Observer that he thought the twins were Judith's granddaughters, and not her adopted children. 'The first I knew about the adoption it was in the papers,' he said.

At 6pm last Friday night, a thick mist surrounded the phalanx of satellite dishes and TV crews at the Beaufort Park Hotel. The Kilshaws had been taking interviews from dawn till dusk. A policewoman arrived and knocked on their door. 'Mr Kilshaw, it's the police,' she said. There was no reply. It appeared the couple had forced the lock on the hotel room window, escaped on to the wall below and sneaked off into the arms of a Sunday tabloid, which has paid them handsomely for their story.
