webTitle: Hold on before buying your slice of Orange

fields.headline: Hold on before buying your slice of Orange
fields.standfirst: The mobile phone firm should get its flotation away, says  Heather Connon,  but the price won't be generous
fields.trailText: The mobile phone firm should get its flotation away, says Heather Connon, but the price won't be generous
fields.body:
France TÉlÉcom will formally launch the sale of a stake in its Orange mobile phones subsidiary tomorrow when it launches the prospectus for the share offer. It will be one of the most closely watched flotations in history.

That is not just because of its size - although, at up to €12 billion (£8bn) it will be one of the largest share offerings ever. Rather, it is because the flotation will be a crucial test of the appetite of international investors for shares in telecoms companies.

The significance of that goes far beyond France Télécom and Orange. Behind them is a queue of companies - British Telecom, Japanese operator DoCoMo, T-Mobile of Germany and KPN in the Netherlands among them - which between them want to raise more than £30bn. The success - or otherwise - of Orange's flotation will determine whether they should even bother to hire advisers.

A year ago, such nervousness would have been unthinkable. Mobile telephony was, it was agreed, the way of the future. Mobile use was growing faster than even incurable optimists such as Hans Snook, Orange's departing chief executive, could have predicted. Text messaging had become the in-thing among the world's teenagers, and the prospect of clever devices such as Wap phones, which would allow us to check share prices, get emails and even order pizzas, would fuel even faster growth.

So it did. Last year in the UK, Orange alone scored a net gain of 4.6 million new subscribers - a 70 per cent rise that took its total to 9.5m.. Other countries were growing almost as fast and Orange was taking more than its fair share.

But as subscribers mushroomed, so too did the cost of servicing them. That was brought home last spring when the UK government began auctioning 3G - third-generation - licences. The prices they fetched surprised everyone: Britain raised more than £20bn from five companies. Add in the cost of building the networks and it is estimated that mobile operators are committed to spending more than £200bn on 3G in Europe alone.

Then there is the technology. The much-hyped WAP phones have failed: they are so slow and cumbersome that even the most ardent technophile finds them all but useless. The hopes of the mobile operators are now pinned on the next Big Thing - General Packet Radio Services, which are both faster and permanently on, sparing the hassle of dialling the internet to go online.

The disappointment of Wap, combined with signs of slowing internet growth, means investors are sceptical about next big things. The worry is that 2000 was the glory year for mobile phones: from now on, growth will slow and operators will find it hard to generate enough revenue to cover their huge investments.

Small wonder, then, that Orange and its advisers sound nervous about the flotation. The timing is dictated by the fact that France Télécom needs to repay €14bn still owed to Vodafone, from which it bought the British Orange operation last August. While it could probably raise the money in the debt markets, lenders are, if anything, more nervous than equity investors about telecoms prospects.

And in telecoms, sentiment is all. As with most technology companies, it is impossible to analyse them according to any traditional technique. The numerous banks advising on the Orange flotation all come up with remarkably similar valuations. But that is not based on anything as fundamental as profits or cashflow - after tax and the costs of investment, there aren't any - but on such things as numbers of customers and how Orange stands relative to its peers.

Thus Vodafone is worth around €3,600 per subscriber, while Telecom Italia Mobil is worth €2,500 per subscriber. Orange is growing faster than Vodafone, but lacks its extensive network - in particular, the smaller firm has no US presence. Take a mid-point between the two and the valuation is around €90bn..

Alternatively, there is a multiple of the clumsy acronym EBITDA - earnings before interest, tax and depreciation. Even here, the valuations are based simply on projections of where they will be in three years' time - the first year in which it is likely to make a profit before tax - and compared with projections for its peers. Or how about cashflow - not last year's, of course, but an expectation for the next decade. Average these three and the analysts come up with a valuation of about €80bn.

It is easy to be cynical about such valuation models but, unfortunately for Orange and companies like it, they are all we have. The real question is: should we believe the figures? The answer depends on your view of the market's growth.

Orange is certainly in a powerful position - second only to Vodafone in its European coverage. It is Britain's third-biggest provider, but its fastest growing and, through Itineris, France's largest. Its financial performance is far ahead of that of many of its peers. In 2000, SG, one of the banks co-ordinating the flotation, estimates that EBITDA was €1.7bn, although this was wiped out by €2.6bn of depreciation and interest costs.

It expects this to treble to €5.5bn by 2003, based on forecasts of around 40 per cent growth in subscribers in France and the UK, and a gradual rise in revenue per unit as higher rates for new services compensate for falling rates for traditional services. Most crucially, however, it believes margins will jump from 14.8 to 27.9 per cent as existing customers use their phones more and the cost of acquiring new ones falls in proportion.

On the face of it, these are sober projections which do not depend on the wilder predictions for mobile usage that Orange is making. It sees itself not just as a telephone company but as the provider of a service which, as technology improves, will be a 'remote control for life' - used it for everything from ordering films to paying for shopping. And it will not be just phone clients who use its services. Already, Orange is automatically reading meters for electricity companies. Soon, all sorts of machines, from cars to central heating systems, could be using 'embedded, wire-free devices'. These may not yield much per reading but, multiplied many millions of times, they could be very lucrative.

The problem is that translating those earnings to the €80bn valuations being talked about does require some belief in those growth levels. A multiple of 13.3 times EBITDA for 2003 may not sound high when the average for the market is around 18.5. But that is earnings before tax and depreciation: factor in these and the multiple for 2004 becomes 100.

One analyst, unconnected to the float, offers some comfort. On his projections for growth in voice traffic alone, Orange should be able to pay the costs of buying and building the structure for its 3G licences. But is the fact that it may not run out of money enough reason to buy the shares?

The uncertainty about the future of the market outweighs three other factors which would at best unsettle any other float. First, Snook, the driving force behind Orange's growth, is to step down as chief executive and after the float will be merely a special adviser . Second, its international businesses - including the French one, already its most successful - will be rebranded Orange. That would be a challenge for any business, never mind one growing as fast as Orange. And third, Orange has been part of the France Télécom group for just six months: not long enough to determine whether it can be successfully integrated.

Most observers expect that Orange will get the flotation away, if only because investors realise the consequences of failure would be disastrous for the sector.

But the price is unlikely to be generous: it is already being talked down to around €60bn and if there is further bad news before before bookbuilding closes on 9 February, even that could look generous.

But private investors should ignore the lead of the big battalions. They have no obligation to keep the telecoms sector afloat. The shares could get a lot cheaper yet. There is no reason to chase them in the flotation.
fields.bodyText: France TÉlÉcom will formally launch the sale of a stake in its Orange mobile phones subsidiary tomorrow when it launches the prospectus for the share offer. It will be one of the most closely watched flotations in history. That is not just because of its size - although, at up to €12 billion (£8bn) it will be one of the largest share offerings ever. Rather, it is because the flotation will be a crucial test of the appetite of international investors for shares in telecoms companies. The significance of that goes far beyond France Télécom and Orange. Behind them is a queue of companies - British Telecom, Japanese operator DoCoMo, T-Mobile of Germany and KPN in the Netherlands among them - which between them want to raise more than £30bn. The success - or otherwise - of Orange's flotation will determine whether they should even bother to hire advisers. A year ago, such nervousness would have been unthinkable. Mobile telephony was, it was agreed, the way of the future. Mobile use was growing faster than even incurable optimists such as Hans Snook, Orange's departing chief executive, could have predicted. Text messaging had become the in-thing among the world's teenagers, and the prospect of clever devices such as Wap phones, which would allow us to check share prices, get emails and even order pizzas, would fuel even faster growth. So it did. Last year in the UK, Orange alone scored a net gain of 4.6 million new subscribers - a 70 per cent rise that took its total to 9.5m.. Other countries were growing almost as fast and Orange was taking more than its fair share. But as subscribers mushroomed, so too did the cost of servicing them. That was brought home last spring when the UK government began auctioning 3G - third-generation - licences. The prices they fetched surprised everyone: Britain raised more than £20bn from five companies. Add in the cost of building the networks and it is estimated that mobile operators are committed to spending more than £200bn on 3G in Europe alone. Then there is the technology. The much-hyped WAP phones have failed: they are so slow and cumbersome that even the most ardent technophile finds them all but useless. The hopes of the mobile operators are now pinned on the next Big Thing - General Packet Radio Services, which are both faster and permanently on, sparing the hassle of dialling the internet to go online. The disappointment of Wap, combined with signs of slowing internet growth, means investors are sceptical about next big things. The worry is that 2000 was the glory year for mobile phones: from now on, growth will slow and operators will find it hard to generate enough revenue to cover their huge investments. Small wonder, then, that Orange and its advisers sound nervous about the flotation. The timing is dictated by the fact that France Télécom needs to repay €14bn still owed to Vodafone, from which it bought the British Orange operation last August. While it could probably raise the money in the debt markets, lenders are, if anything, more nervous than equity investors about telecoms prospects. And in telecoms, sentiment is all. As with most technology companies, it is impossible to analyse them according to any traditional technique. The numerous banks advising on the Orange flotation all come up with remarkably similar valuations. But that is not based on anything as fundamental as profits or cashflow - after tax and the costs of investment, there aren't any - but on such things as numbers of customers and how Orange stands relative to its peers. Thus Vodafone is worth around €3,600 per subscriber, while Telecom Italia Mobil is worth €2,500 per subscriber. Orange is growing faster than Vodafone, but lacks its extensive network - in particular, the smaller firm has no US presence. Take a mid-point between the two and the valuation is around €90bn.. Alternatively, there is a multiple of the clumsy acronym EBITDA - earnings before interest, tax and depreciation. Even here, the valuations are based simply on projections of where they will be in three years' time - the first year in which it is likely to make a profit before tax - and compared with projections for its peers. Or how about cashflow - not last year's, of course, but an expectation for the next decade. Average these three and the analysts come up with a valuation of about €80bn. It is easy to be cynical about such valuation models but, unfortunately for Orange and companies like it, they are all we have. The real question is: should we believe the figures? The answer depends on your view of the market's growth. Orange is certainly in a powerful position - second only to Vodafone in its European coverage. Soon, all sorts of machines, from cars to central heating systems, could be using 'embedded, wire-free devices'. webTitle: Observer review: The Love of Stones by Tobias Hill

fields.headline: Her rubies are far above price
fields.standfirst: With his second novel, The Love of Stones, Tobias Hill establishes himself as a master of the historical thriller
fields.trailText: With his second novel, The Love of Stones, Tobias Hill establishes himself as a master of the historical thriller
fields.body:
The Love of Stones
Tobias Hill
Faber £10.99, pp397
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The 'stones' in Tobias Hill's magnificently managed second novel are jewels. His heroine, Katharine Sterne, is knowledgeable about many and obsessed with one, whose trail she follows; the Three Brethren is an arrangement of three balas rubies (whose matching perfection gives the jewel its name) and three pearls round a central diamond.

The opening of the book describes the jewel's commissioning - as a shoulder knot - in the early fifteenth century by Duke John the Fearless of Burgundy. Although unusual among great jewels, according to Hill, in not carrying a curse, the Three Brethren can't be said to have brought luck with them, either. The duke was wearing his shoulder knot when he was treacherously killed on the Bridge of Montereau by the Dauphin of France.

Elizabeth I is wearing the jewels in the 'Ermine' portrait reproduced on the book's cover. It would take a specialist to know just where Hill shades history into fiction, but certainly the Three Brethren become real to the reader in their progress through human lives. The author has steeped himself in the geology, physics and culture of covetable minerals. Being a poet, he savours the precise vocabulary of cuts (skew, skill, bezel, quoin) and the suggestiveness of the science; it's impossible, for instance, to touch a diamond, since it is a property of the stone to attract hydrogen from its surroundings, sheathing itself in another element.

The shoulder knot is composite, and so is the structure of the novel. Besides the history of the Three Brethren passed on by Katharine, and her search for information about where they might be now, there is also the story of two Iraqi brothers, Daniel and Salman Levy, who arrive in London in 1833 and set up business as jewellers. Hill's ability not merely to generate period detail but to inflect it, to make it his own, is remarkable: not the bare fact of gaslight but 'above him the lamp sighed like a woman turning in her sleep'; not just the props of an Antiques Roadshow desktop but 'he stopped writing, reached for the sand, and let it skitter across the page'.

Just how the two narratives converge is one of the secrets of the book. Hill sets up echoes of phrasing to keep curiosity sharp, though when the formula 'done and dusted' is put into the mouths of both a nineteenth-century court jeweller and a modern Japanese businessman taught English by Americans, the effect is jarring.

With The Name of the Rose and Perfume, a new sort of international bestseller emerged which combined esoteric and populist ingredients to produce robust hybrids: hermetic fables with a thriller dynamic. Hill's attempt to join those ranks with his tale of jewels, royalty, quests and betrayals is aided by his sinuous plotting and his superb conjurations of place (not just Iraq but modern Turkey and Japan). By having Katharine describe her obsession as 'a kind of love that no longer requires people', he covers himself against the likelihood that his readership may find her emotionally lacking.

Details of her background are few but precise, details of her appearance few and vague, released with a distracting slowness. She's not old (belatedly revealed as 25), not dark - her blue eyes regarded as unlucky in Turkey - and not small, which turns out to mean tall rather than wide.

We may, as she says, recognise ourselves in our ancestors by their making of jewels and weapons - embodiments of love and death - but Hill has a little trouble with those two subjects, or at least with their thriller derivatives, sex and violence. One distinctly uneasy chime between the narratives is that in each, an attraction is consummated only after the woman has suffered injury, before she has healed, and with penetrative brusqueness. Something about these scenes feels like duty to the thriller formula, carried out with a cold conscientiousness.

Peter Høeg in Miss Smilla's Feeling For Snow, another stylish recent blockbuster, was forever putting his heroine in danger and having her fight free of it. Katharine has a less traumatic time, but her escapes aren't always convincing. Having smashed an assailant's temple with a lucky blow of her elbow on a Russian train, she simply carries him out into the gangway, though he has been described as 'big' and 'heavy' and is now unconscious, if not dead. In scenes like these, sophistication finds itself unable to renegotiate a genre requirement - the physical victory of the underdog.

Still, Tobias Hill successfully finesses the ending, where wish-fulfilment demands that Katharine should hold in her hand the jewel for which she has given up so much, while sophistication prefers a dilution of triumph. What is confounding about The Love of Stones is not the occasional failure but an almost continuous success. It may be that the book, like Miss Smilla's Feeling For Snow, is as close to the apotheosis of a yarn as to a literary masterpiece, but it deserves the many readers it will win.

webTitle: Paperbacks: 21 Jan

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Howard Goodall takes us on a tour of great musical discoveries, plus In America, Wild Shore, Shame the Devil and Morocco
fields.body:
Big Bangs
Howard Goodall
Vintage £7.99, pp238
Buy it at a discount at BOL

One summer afternoon, Goodall lies on his bed in a small French village, suffering from composer's block. Then 'a bell for evening service in the cathedral started to chime - a persistent but unhurried F sharp'. Transcribing the flurry of chimes, he suddenly realises that the sounds he's hearing aren't 'simply a generalised wash, they had crystallised into a form. Now I could hear the bells as individual voices singing Sanctus.' This insight into the private epiphany of composition is a memorable caesura in Goodall's tour of great musical discoveries.

Elsewhere, we learn how 'sounds became ink' when the eleventh-century monk Guido devised musical notation; how notes became chords with the invention of harmony; and how the piano was invented. The book's origins - in the Channel 4 series of the same name - are evident in its chatty tone and slightly jumpy structure, but neither detracts from the author's intelligent, infectious enthusiasm.

In America
Susan Sontag
Vintage £6.99, pp387
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In 1876, Maryna Zalezowska, a famous Polish actress, emigrates to California intending to found a Utopian commune. When the experiment disintegrates and her fellow idealists return home, Maryna remains in the country, changes her name and begins a triumphant new career on the American stage. By any standards, this is a startling life story, yet ironically, considering the heroine's profession, it's told in a way that's almost entirely devoid of drama.

There is little suspense in the unfolding of the narrative; it's as though Sontag decided she disliked the contrived business of plotting and so chose to omit anything that might be suggestive of manufactured surprise. The absence of page-turning gimmicks makes In America a harder, slower read than it need have been, but there are compensations. Whenever ideas rather than characters take the stage, the prose catches light, with witty meditations on subjects as diverse as Utopia, theatre and marriage.

Wild Shore
Edward Marriot
Picador £6.99, pp282
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The bull shark is unusually ugly, even for a shark: snub-nosed, piggy-eyed and happy to chew its way through anything from human being to the half-rotted iguanas the Mestizos use as bait. It is also the only shark that can live in both fresh and saltwater, and as such, makes an ideal guide for Marriot on his journey along Nicaragua's Atlantic coast and up the San Juan river to Lake Managua.

The Nicaragua he discovers on his travels is itself unusually ugly: the lives of its fishermen desperately difficult and impoverished, the country still bearing the scars of civil war.

This particular tale of the relationship between man and fish is laudably devoid of the romanticism of Hemingway's Old Man and the Sea - and if the author's gaze is occasionally as myopic as that of the fish he is chasing, he nevertheless succeeds in creating a gripping, clear-sighted picture of a dark and peculiar world.

Shame the Devil
George P. Pelecanos
Indigo £6.99, pp307
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A sweltering afternoon in Washington DC - perfect conditions for a crime to end in catastrophe, which is exactly what happens when Frank Farrow attempts the robbery of a downtown pizza restaurant. Three of the staff are brutally murdered, Farrow's brother is shot by the police ('Oh sweet Jesus, I am hit'), and in the getaway, a young boy is run over and killed.

So far, so standard thriller; but what follows is a dazzling display of how much you can do within the confines of a genre. Pelecanos sustains the necessary pace and complexity of plot without ever relying on ciphers. Instead, he invents an extraordinary range of characters who conspire and grieve, against the backdrop of a city portrayed in all its dirty, speedy, addictive complexity.

The storyline and the dialogue are both wonderfully done, and there are some painfully insightful descriptions of drink, drinking and being drunk.

Morocco
David Flusfeder
Fourth Estate £6.99, pp312
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Set in an unnamed city at an unnamed period in history, Flusfeder's allegorically suggestive novel is revealed, on the very last page, to rest squarely on historical fact - the plight of the Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1941.

Yet despite its real-life antecedents, it's a disorienting read which makes seemingly random play with the distinctions between fiction and fictionalised fact. The story is most assured when occupying the mind of its heroine, Gloria, an ambitious young psychologist with two unlikely clients - Solomon Heller, tycoon and profiteer, and Igo Sym, movie star and collaborator.

As the forces of occupation engulf the city, Gloria's therapeutic and personal relationships mutate into the compromised loyalties of wartime. There is a creative logic for Morocco's spare, abstracted tone, not least in its clever use of the coolly objective language of psychoanalysis, but in the end, the novel's chilliness is excluding rather than encouraging.

webTitle: Death and honour

fields.headline: Death and honour
fields.trailText: Literature and untimely death are strangely linked.
fields.body:
Literature and untimely death are strangely linked. The roll-call of English writers - mostly poets - who are remembered almost as much for their premature taking off as for their individual contributions to the canon includes Sir Philip Sydney, Christopher Marlowe, Thomas Chatterton, John Keats, Arthur Hugh Clough, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Wilfred Owen, Joe Orton and, most recently, Ted Hughes. For the poet especially, an early death can be quite a good career move.

Hazlitt said: 'Death cancels everything but truth; and strips a man of everything but genius and virtue. It is a sort of natural canonisation.'

Death, of course, is one of literature's great themes, though now overshadowed by our fascination with sex. One of the finest books ever written on the subject, John Donne's Devotions Upon Emergent Occasions, expresses the transforming effect of mortality in literature perfectly - 'When one man dies, one chapter is not torn out of the book, but translated into a better language.'

Appropriately for the season that has seen the passing of Malcolm Bradbury, Lorna Sage and now Auberon Waugh, the Whitbread Prize, which will be awarded on Tuesday, is the one literary prize that's become associated with the grim reaper, though its well-scrubbed sponsors will not be overjoyed to hear this. Compared to the bright-eyed and eager-to-please expectancy of the Orange Prize, and the ancien régime hauteur of the Booker, a night out with the Whitbread can be more like a trip to the morgue - or the madhouse.

Partly this is because the prize, weirdly, invites all-comers (nominations in poetry, fiction, biography, history and children's books). As a result, the Whitbread has become the English literary prize, par excellence, in which human frailty has historically played an important role.

Two years ago, the prize was awarded posthumously to Ted Hughes for Birthday Letters. Ten years before that, it was presented to Christopher Nolan, the indomitable Irish quadriplegic, for his novel, Under the Eye of the Clock. The year before, Paul Sayer, a professional nurse, took the book of the year prize for his bleak novel, The Comforts of Madness.

From many points of view, the Whitbread is the prize which honours the triumph over adversity or the grave. All of which helps to explain why Lorna Sage, who died earlier this month, must be a strong favourite to win this year's Whitbread for her extraordinary memoir, Bad Blood, a fearless and thrilling investigation of her family's dark, Dickensian secrets.

There's another, slightly shameful, reason why, until the odds were dramatically shortened last week, Bad Blood was the best bet in a distinctly open race - it is fairly short (281 pages) and easily digestible.

This is important. In the world of prize juries, Whitbread is to Booker as Kwik Save is to Fortnum & Mason. Its jurors are numbingly popular, incredibly famous and astonishingly amateur. This year's panel, for instance, which is chaired by Sir Tim Rice, includes the oarsman Matthew Pinsent, the comedian Alan Cumming and the radio 'personality' Clare Balding. Say what you like about these fine citizens, they are not noted for their literary criticism.

What's more, unlike Booker, these judges will have played no part in the short list's pre-selection process, a murky procedure which does at least have the merit of comparing like with like. Anyway, with barely a month to digest an extraordinarily mixed bag of submissions, the Whitbread panel will have been handed a list of titles - poetry, fiction, memoir etc - and asked to make a selection.

This is an awesome, perhaps impossible, task. How, in all seriousness, do you compare Zadie Smith's White Teeth with John Burnside's The Asylum Dance?

The short answer is you settle on a book that does not try the patience of the reader, and which presents itself to the common reader with the twin virtues of brevity and literary respectability. Bad Blood has both these qualities in abundance, and will take some beating. Its chief rival, White Teeth, was unquestionably the fictional debut of the millennial year, but it's a long (542 pages) book, and it lacks the kind of approachability the Whitbread panel will be looking for. It is, however, the favourite by a short head.

But before you rush off to William Hill, it's worth remembering that, as in many horse races, in book prizes the favourite rarely wins. These are the latest odds:

Zadie Smith White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton) 7-4

Lorna Sage Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) 2-1

Matthew Kneale English Passengers (Viking) 5-2

John Burnside The Asylum Dance (Jonathan Cape) 8-1

fields.bodyText: Literature and untimely death are strangely linked. The roll-call of English writers - mostly poets - who are remembered almost as much for their premature taking off as for their individual contributions to the canon includes Sir Philip Sydney, Christopher Marlowe, Thomas Chatterton, John Keats, Arthur Hugh Clough, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Wilfred Owen, Joe Orton and, most recently, Ted Hughes. For the poet especially, an early death can be quite a good career move. Hazlitt said: 'Death cancels everything but truth; and strips a man of everything but genius and virtue. It is a sort of natural canonisation.' Death, of course, is one of literature's great themes, though now overshadowed by our fascination with sex. One of the finest books ever written on the subject, John Donne's Devotions Upon Emergent Occasions, expresses the transforming effect of mortality in literature perfectly - 'When one man dies, one chapter is not torn out of the book, but translated into a better language.' Appropriately for the season that has seen the passing of Malcolm Bradbury, Lorna Sage and now Auberon Waugh, the Whitbread Prize, which will be awarded on Tuesday, is the one literary prize that's become associated with the grim reaper, though its well-scrubbed sponsors will not be overjoyed to hear this. Compared to the bright-eyed and eager-to-please expectancy of the Orange Prize, and the ancien régime hauteur of the Booker, a night out with the Whitbread can be more like a trip to the morgue - or the madhouse. Partly this is because the prize, weirdly, invites all-comers (nominations in poetry, fiction, biography, history and children's books). As a result, the Whitbread has become the English literary prize, par excellence, in which human frailty has historically played an important role. Two years ago, the prize was awarded posthumously to Ted Hughes for Birthday Letters. Ten years before that, it was presented to Christopher Nolan, the indomitable Irish quadriplegic, for his novel, Under the Eye of the Clock. The year before, Paul Sayer, a professional nurse, took the book of the year prize for his bleak novel, The Comforts of Madness. From many points of view, the Whitbread is the prize which honours the triumph over adversity or the grave. All of which helps to explain why Lorna Sage, who died earlier this month, must be a strong favourite to win this year's Whitbread for her extraordinary memoir, Bad Blood, a fearless and thrilling investigation of her family's dark, Dickensian secrets. There's another, slightly shameful, reason why, until the odds were dramatically shortened last week, Bad Blood was the best bet in a distinctly open race - it is fairly short (281 pages) and easily digestible. This is important. In the world of prize juries, Whitbread is to Booker as Kwik Save is to Fortnum & Mason. Its jurors are numbingly popular, incredibly famous and astonishingly amateur. This year's panel, for instance, which is chaired by Sir Tim Rice, includes the oarsman Matthew Pinsent, the comedian Alan Cumming and the radio 'personality' Clare Balding. Say what you like about these fine citizens, they are not noted for their literary criticism. What's more, unlike Booker, these judges will have played no part in the short list's pre-selection process, a murky procedure which does at least have the merit of comparing like with like. Anyway, with barely a month to digest an extraordinarily mixed bag of submissions, the Whitbread panel will have been handed a list of titles - poetry, fiction, memoir etc - and asked to make a selection. This is an awesome, perhaps impossible, task. How, in all seriousness, do you compare Zadie Smith's White Teeth with John Burnside's The Asylum Dance? The short answer is you settle on a book that does not try the patience of the reader, and which presents itself to the common reader with the twin virtues of brevity and literary respectability. Bad Blood has both these qualities in abundance, and will take some beating. Its chief rival, White Teeth, was unquestionably the fictional debut of the millennial year, but it's a long (542 pages) book, and it lacks the kind of approachability the Whitbread panel will be looking for. It is, however, the favourite by a short head. But before you rush off to William Hill, it's worth remembering that, as in many horse races, in book prizes the favourite rarely wins. These are the latest odds: Zadie Smith White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton) 7-4 Lorna Sage Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) 2-1 Matthew Kneale English Passengers (Viking) 5-2 John Burnside The Asylum Dance (Jonathan Cape) 8-1 robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: In a Dry Season by Peter Robinson read by Neil Pearson and Anna Massey

fields.headline: In a Dry Season by Peter Robinson read by Neil Pearson and Anna Massey
fields.trailText: There is nothing ground-breaking or life-changing about this 'Inspector Banks' audiobook. It is just a thoroughly good listening experience.
fields.body:
In a Dry Season
Peter Robinson
Read by Neil Pearson and Anna Massey
Listening time 3hrs
Macmillan £8.99

There is nothing ground-breaking or life-changing about this 'Inspector Banks' audiobook. It is just a thoroughly good listening experience. The appeal is cemented by the charming, sexy voice of Neil Pearson as the attractively needy and rebellious Detective Chief Inspector Alan Banks, the insubordinate officer charged with the job of finding the person responsible for turning a sweet blonde land girl into a pile of mud-caked bones.

The scene of the murder is the village of Hobb's End. Now submerged beneath the waters of the Thornfield reservoir, it was once a hive of activity for American airmen and English good-time girls during the Second World War. But 40 years on, a long, hot summer allows the village to reappear, revealing baffling secrets that Banks is determined to solve.

The only person who can answer the necessary questions is Vivian Elmsley, a famous crime writer. Her part is read here by Anna Massey, whose clipped pronunciation is the grating antithesis of Pearson's boyish jocularity.

The plot is neat and the carpe diem attitude of the 1940s cleverly conveyed. It would be easy to become addicted to Robinson's agreeable but not too predictable stories, and have a cold Sunday afternoon warmed with images of DCI Alan Banks who, strangely, looks just like Neil Pearson in my mind's eye.

webTitle: Classicwatch: The Golden Gate

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Vikram Seth established himself as a major literary talent with this dazzling verse novel
fields.body:
The Golden Gate
Vikram Seth
(Faber £4.99, pp308)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

When Vikram Seth first published this enchanting novel-in-verse in 1986, he was known as the author of From Heaven Lake: Travels through Sinkiang and Tibet.

The acclaim Seth received for this exuberant and witty tale of twentysomethings looking for love, pleasure and the meaning of life in the sunshine state of California established him overnight as one of the really important new English literary voices of the 1980s.

Seth is now better known for his epic novel of India, A Suitable Boy (and also An Equal Music), but for those who have been daunted by the monumental challenge of the later work, this delightful one-off is the perfect hors-d'oeuvre to the feast.

The on-off love story of John and Claire is a narrative poem with a dazzling surface that conceals a serious grappling with the complexity of relationships and the pursuit of happiness. Although The Golden Gate now seems peculiarly of its time, it lives on as an unusually successful marriage of poetry with fiction and as a high-spirited assertion of the timeless values of storytelling and character.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: White Teeth

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Zadie Smith's first novel has managed to survive the hype and go on to acquire a raft of admiring reviews and literary prizes.
fields.body:
White Teeth
Zadie Smith
Penguin £6.99, pp542
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In spite of the whirlwind of hype that surrounded last year's publication of Zadie Smith's first novel, the book itself managed to survive the media frenzy and has gone on to prove its worth by acquiring a raft of admiring reviews and literary prizes.

Twenty-five-year-old Smith's ambitious, busy, comic portrait of immigrants in late twentieth-century London owes much to Salman Rushdie in terms of style, but the freshness and youthful vigour of the writing is all her own. Following the chaotic progress of three families - one Asian, one mixed English and Jamaican and one of Jewish origin - Smith explores the history of British colonialism and the fraught issues of genetic and cultural heritage, taking in hip hop, war, religious fundamentalism, hair extensions, poetry and racism along the way.

Especially impressive is Smith's ear for voices; she can reproduce the cadences of a Bengali or West Indian character without stumbling into offensive caricature; she is particularly good with the Raggastani demotic common to all adolescent boys in London regardless of background: 'Raggastanis spoke a strange mix of Jamaican patois, Bengali, Gudjurati and English.'

Smith was accused by some critics of an over-generous view of race relations and integration in the book, but the novel offers a semi-Utopian idea of what a multicultural London and, by extension, Britain, should and might be.

Her second-generation characters - the British-born Bengali twins Millat and Magid, the half-Jamaican Irie and the middle-class Josh - struggle at times in their quest for an identity that accommodates all their cultural influences, but become so closely enmeshed in one another's lives that distinctions of race or background begin to dissolve.

A strong contender for the Whitbread Book of the Year Award, White Teeth is a surprisingly confident, exuberant, occasionally sprawling novel from a young author who is being hailed as one of the prominent voices of her generation.

webTitle: Remembering Bron

fields.headline: Remembering Bron
fields.trailText: Kim Bunce talks to Laura Cumming, Kate Kellaway, Anna Ford, Naim Attallah, Fay Weldon and Muriel Spark
fields.body:
Laura Cumming was Waugh's deputy at the Literary Review from 1987 to 1989

You were interviewed for a job on Literary Review over lunch in Soho. Three right answers clinched it, though smoking was a plus: did I play chess, swear expressively and mind a glass of wine?

Bron was by far the wittiest and most liberal boss a girl could have. I once went to write a piece about the Western Sahara without any notice; another colleague disappeared for almost a week, having fallen in love. Bron was richly amused and encouraging of both.

He was fantastically, exorbitantly generous, threw birthday parties for us, paid at least one intern's pocket money and subsidised my salary with his. (Naturally, he never told me.) He was always helping younger people - getting them contacts, jobs and flats - but he also loved to mock your youthful solemnity. I was allowed to publish as much earnest left-wingery in the magazine as I liked, so long as it appeared in a special section that he christened 'Oppression'. Right-wingery was only permitted if tempered by jokes.

Shy and easily bored, he would sometimes pretend to be half-blind or deaf to avoid conversation. Although he could be melancholy, I remember him rallying bravely at the sight of a well-sugared tea, a new piece of copy or a fresh hand of cards - at 5.45, he'd fetch out a bottle from the leg of his desk and we'd play for joke stakes with passing contributors.

His fearless originality was the ideal example for novice journalists. Others found him ruthless, especially with the pompous. But he was never pitiless, like his father, except perhaps with himself.

Kate Kellaway was deputy editor at the Literary Review in 1986

I discovered straight away, to my relief, that he did not want to be humoured. He loved strong feeling; our conversations always seemed to be in italics. As a boss, he combined authority, wit, charm and hopeless disorganisation. I was devoted to him.

I would never have confided the disappointments of my love life to him, but one morning Bron pronounced me 'off-colour', put a bottle of pink champagne on my desk and proposed lunch at a fish restaurant, explaining gloomily that it was our strict duty to go there: 'Fish is good for the brain.'

When he occasionally commissioned an offensive piece, the best way to see it to the spike was with a yawn. If I had expressed outrage, he would have brightened up. To bore was the great sin. He was, I think, deeply (with the emphasis on deep) frivolous. It was hard to know what to do with the reviews written by pretty girls he had met on trains. 'Do you think we might use this?' he would wonder, wistfully.

There was always a sense that Bron had just mislaid something that might be quite important. He might pick up the phone and then forget who it was he had been ringing. It never mattered, though, as long as he was there.

Anna Ford was a friend for 20 years

He was the most sweet, solicitous and amusing company. For people who didn't know him, it was a surprise. The things he wrote were so vituperative that people thought he was bad-tempered and prejudiced. He was the kindest, most wonderful family man. He was always supportive and if I was getting a bad press he would ring and say: 'Don't believe it, none of it is true.' I shall miss his wit. He was a big critic of hypocrisy and one of London's great figures. A complete one-off.

Naim Attallah was Waugh's proprietor and friend

I knew him for 14 years and I loved him so. Our friendship grew and grew. I first met him after he wrote to me saying he had a beautiful daughter, Sophia, who wanted to go into publishing and would I agree to give her an interview. I was so touched by the fatherly warmth he showed that I agreed to see her. I liked Sophia and she joined Quartet Books. Then I met him and the friendship ensued.

Normally with an editor and a proprietor there are tensions, but in the 14 years we worked together we never exchanged a single word in anger. His public persona was totally different to his personal one. What he wrote was just contrary, to provoke and entertain. That was what Bron was all about.

He really and truly loved women. When he was in their company he always sparkled.

Fay Weldon was a long-time friend

He gave the best possible literary parties - not something to be overlooked. I held him in great esteem for his wit, kindness and loathing of cant and control-freaks. He always reminded me of Swift or Sidney Smith, in whose house he so fittingly lived and died. It worries me that he's gone: once his voice could seem facetious, but lately it rang simply true. Who else is left?

Muriel Spark was a friend for 40 years

I met him because his father was very taken with my work. I never met his father because I had heard he had bouts of rudeness and I was afraid and kept out of his way. Bron and I had a great rapport. He used to come to Italy to see me, and would bring presents. Our relationship was pure friendship and a very nice friendship. He was such a kind and amusing man.

webTitle: Observer review: The Collected Stories by Arthur C Clarke

fields.headline: Master of the Universe
fields.standfirst: A collection of stories from Arthur C Clarke is released with impeccable timing
fields.trailText: A collection of stories from Arthur C Clarke is released with impeccable timing
fields.body:
The Collected Stories
Arthur C Clarke
Victor Gollancz £20, pp966
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There is a delicious tale told of Arthur C Clarke who, on reading a news story about a plane-crash survivor rescued while still clutching one of his books, sent the cutting to his great sci-fi rival, Isaac Asimov. 'He should have been reading one of yours, Isaac. Then he would have slept through the whole thing,' wrote Clarke. A few days later, the clipping was returned with a new note: 'No, it should have been one of yours, Arthur. Then, if he had died, it would have been a merciful release.'

You could never imagine such a cheery exchange occurring between writers of anything other than science fiction, a form of literature that has never taken itself seriously, especially in its years of golden adolescence in the Fifties and Sixties. A sense of wonder about the universe, mixed with youthful jollity, prevailed at the expense of character development and social interaction. Intriguing individuals in a fantastic universe are a complexity to many, after all.

And no one got that mix better than Arthur C Clarke, who fuelled my youthful scientific sensibilities with tales of lunar colonies, mineral mines on Jupiter's moons and solar-powered sailboats racing to Mars. He wrote tales of plausible galactic empires with impish fun and a fierce belief that scientific knowledge would triumph over ignorance. And given that this is the eponymous year of his greatest triumph, 2001: A Space Odyssey, the appearance - at last - of a collection of his works of short fiction is as fine a millennium celebration as we Clarkites could hope for.

This is a mighty sandwich of a book, topped by his naïve early works and tailed by a few meagre oddities that have been put together by a man who, very sadly, seems to have tired of writing. In between, however, is a glorious meaty filling that contains some of the best science fiction ever written: 'The Sentinel', on which 2001 was based; his wonderful apocalyptic rib-tickler, 'The Nine Billion Names of God'; and his vision of the loneliness of the long-distance interstellar coloniser, 'Songs of Distant Earth'.

There is the odd anachronism, of course - vegetation on the Moon, astronomers using photographic plates (long ago replaced by electronic detectors), and the expectation that life would, by now, have been found on other planets. We should remember, however, that a third of these stories were written when talk of space travel was considered lunacy, while the last dozen were composed long after man had walked on the Moon. It is Clarke who has outlasted the doubters.

In fact, my greatest surprise was to discover that Clarke's finest tale, 'The Star', a delicate, deadly assault on Christian belief, was written for a short-story competition in The Observer. It didn't even make runner-up status, I am ashamed to report.

However, with the benefit of 20-20 hindsight, we can at least claim to have helped in the creation of an SF masterpiece, albeit with a little bit of help from the maestro himself.

webTitle: Observer review: The Satyr by Cephas Goldsworthy

fields.headline: Rake and ruin
fields.standfirst: Rochester's irregular life is poorly served by Cephas Goldsworthy in The Satyr
fields.trailText: Rochester's irregular life is poorly served by Cephas Goldsworthy in The Satyr
fields.body:
The Satyr
Cephas Goldsworthy
Weidenfeld and Nicolson £25, pp352
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is probably fitting that a poet of premature ejaculation should receive this missed opportunity of a biography. John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester, was the needling wit at Charles II's court, a man who drank deep, wrote sharp and died young. He is a figure of magnetic contradictions - enthralled and repelled by pleasure, prowling around amorous excess and the limits of reason. His reputation for coruscating obscenity is belied by the desolation of his best poetry.

Although indulged by Charles II, he kept finding new marks to overstep, conflating the king's irregular amorous and political potency ('His sceptre and his prick are of a length'). He gleefully tumbled love poetry's arcadia of nymphs and shepherds into the muck, portraying his Cloris frigging in a pigsty, but his great subject was nothing, the terrifying Absence lurking beyond worldliness.

Rochester's life defies conventional biography - there are simply too many gaps. Too many poems and letters of doubtful attribution and uncertain chronology; too many posthumous anecdotes forming an unreliable mesh of notoriety. Cephas Goldsworthy (who died shortly after completing this biography) takes much doubtful material at face value. More dangerously, he treats the poems as bulletins from the bedsheets, ignoring the poet's penchant for masterly ventriloquism. The letters may hint at bisexuality, but when a clockwork debauchee says: 'I storm and I roar and I fall in a rage,/ And missing my whore, I bugger my page', Goldsworthy finds only a 'confession' in this lacerating persona.

For all the occasional elegance of the writing, The Satyr founders on misquotation, scanty reference and speculation. Reading a raucous tribute to the dildo, Goldsworthy breathlessly picks up the scent: 'If Rochester did take one of them home... how was he going to use it, with whom and why?'

Pepys, ever wriggling with shame and lust, tucked a copy of Rochester's smutty verses in his desk. He later dignified the book by binding it with an account of the earl's dramatic deathbed conversion. Rochester's last-minute renunciation - 'From the bottom of my soul I detest and abhor the whole course of my former wicked life' - sealed his reputation. Goldsworthy argues that Rochester died of syphilis, which gnawed at his exhausted imagination to produce religious fervour. Perhaps, but it seems mean to deprive the poet's itchy intellect of a share in the process.

John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester, was the needling wit at Charles II's court, a man who drank deep, wrote sharp and died young. He is a figure of magnetic contradictions - enthralled and repelled by pleasure, prowling around amorous excess and the limits of reason. His reputation for coruscating obscenity is belied by the desolation of his best poetry. Although indulged by Charles II, he kept finding new marks to overstep, conflating the king's irregular amorous and political potency ('His sceptre and his prick are of a length'). He gleefully tumbled love poetry's arcadia of nymphs and shepherds into the muck, portraying his Cloris frigging in a pigsty, but his great subject was nothing, the terrifying Absence lurking beyond worldliness. Rochester's life defies conventional biography - there are simply too many gaps. Too many poems and letters of doubtful attribution and uncertain chronology; too many posthumous anecdotes forming an unreliable mesh of notoriety. webTitle: Observer review: World War 3.0 by Ken Auletta

fields.headline: Ruthless in Seattle
fields.standfirst: Ken Auletta's story of the fall and fall of Bill Gates, World War 3.0,  is a thriller but the man remains an enigma
fields.trailText: Ken Auletta's story of the fall and fall of Bill Gates, World War 3.0, is a thriller but the man remains an enigma
fields.body:
World War 3.0
Ken Auletta
Profile Books £17.99, pp439
Buy it at a discount at BOL

From hero to zero. Five years ago, Bill Gates, maker of Microsoft, was the all-American success story: fabulously rich, relentlessly revered, the altruistic fount of future wisdom. And now?

There's a new Hollywood thriller about to do the multiplex rounds whose arch villain is some nerdy Seattle computer magnate with a taste for murder and ruling the world: a bespectacled Blofeld. The name of the film is Antitrust. That real rise and berserk fictional fall, of course, is grotesquely overdone (in average movie manner).

Bill Gates still survives at the head of Microsoft - and Microsoft is still huge and profitable and the first name of the computer revolution. But it, and he, are also gravely damaged by almost half a decade in court, losing time and again to the lawyers the US Justice Department hired.

His giant baby (unless providence or George W. Bush intervene) is about to be carved in two by judicial decree. His days as an icon are gone. Ken Auletta of the New Yorker sets out here to chronicle this fall and fall. It is a rivetting story, a definitive corporate tale for our times, and Auletta has had the time and access to do a great job. He does not quite pull it off - because, as in his previous books, he is too keen on consorting with the rich and famous, a bit of a celeb collector - but he goes deep enough to raise the most profound questions. The foremost of which is: Has Microsoft had a raw deal? We are not, I guess, invited to jump to that conclusion. We are supposed to conclude that rapacity and ruthlessness and overweening arrogance - the arrogance of Gates - brought it down.

Who but a supercilious idiot would have dared to testify so self-incriminatingly on video before Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's court? Why tell so many obvious porkies? Why not settle out of court - at three times of asking - rather than bring his company to the brink of disaster through a mix of myopia and petty rages?

Auletta is not in awe of Microsoft, with its jackdaw ways, its profits built on the pioneering work of others; nor does he take Gates at the guru's own, blank-faced valuation. If we are told once that Gates missed the internet revolution until it was (almost) too late, we are told a dozen times. And yet there is still cause for wriggling unease which, with fairness, he expresses well.

What was it that Microsoft did that deserves such legal retribution? Is 'justice' what the Justice Department automatically delivers? This, in essence, was the war of the Netscape browser. Microsoft - too dozy over the potential of the net - saw a more brilliant competitor on a roll and used its clout (and Internet Explorer) to try to shut it out. Typical big boy behaviour; and thus a typical Microsoft way of doing business by trying brutally hard. But how hard do sharp elbows have to dig in in the scrum to rate a yellow card?

The customer was not complaining. He got a better, cheaper deal (and, like this customer, could still download Netscape on to his PC if he found Explorer too boringly clunky). Netscape was complaining, but hardly going broke - and, tellingly, would surely have used exactly the same tactics if situations had been reversed. Tied pubs, tied petrol stations, a dominant M&S selling only St Michael: when does formidable muscle turn antitrust? You may, like Ralph Nader, cheer as rich, choking bullies get their comeuppance: necessary and all too infrequent retribution in corporate America. Who weeps for Standard Oil? But there is, at least, a problem matching petroleum pipelines to the infinite channels of the net.

Bill Neukom, Microsoft's lead attorney, probably makes the case better to Auletta than he ever made it in court. 'Technology is a little like mercury. As I sit here, thinking of the technology business, I can't imagine a monopoly because technology is so fluid.'

Look back, with the business historian Pete Drucker, to the early days of computers; to Wang, IBM, Remington Rand, Unisys and more. They have all faded from the front row, victims of a fleeting hegemony. That, surely, was the perception that haunted Microsoft, an arrogance born of desperate insecurity. And among those names, perhaps IBM is the most telling of the lot - a company that underwent its own antitrust trial by fire and, through those flames, lost momentum.

Watch Microsoft, perhaps, go the same way. Auletta is best when he explores such issues - will AOL, for all its momentary might, endure? - and broods over the bizarre collection of young visionaries and old pros who built the Nasdaq. He is less good at trawling through the endless, essentially repetitive days in court or goggling at the silken skills of David Boies, the lawyer Justice hired before Al Gore hung his first chad.

The war of the suits (crisp, dark and expensive for Microsoft, crumpled blue for Boies) is trivial. So is the technological ignorance Boies and Judge Jackson share. The meat here is not legal, except in the way the law trails in the wake of pounding reality, but more philosophical. Auletta does not begin to explain the enigma called Bill Gates, to balance out the spoilt child, the crass politician and the driven business tycoon. Nor does he put his finger on the chemistry that underpins Microsoft and may now drain away.

A tragedy? Certainly, because a cannier chief executive would have sued for peace early on and got it. But would that brighter boss have created Microsoft to begin with? We have not reached the end of this saga. The courts - as in Florida - never end. The judges - as in Florida - change, and so do the political masters. There must be a second edition called World War 3.5 in the works. Meanwhile, Auletta has written more than a thriller of the new media frontier. He has, however patchily, pushed thinking about it to the outer limits.

webTitle: Observer review: Something Like a House by Sid Smith

fields.headline: Not your typical British soldier...
fields.standfirst: Sid Smith's audacious first novel, Something Like a House, tells the story of a soldier in Mao's China
fields.trailText: Sid Smith's audacious first novel, Something Like a House, tells the story of a soldier in Mao's China
fields.body:
Something Like a House
Sid Smith
Picador £12.99, pp216
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Westerners who write fiction about China have to tread carefully. The man-traps of post-colonial theory lie about, ready to snap shut should the author patronise, misunderstand, or otherwise 'orientalise' the subject matter. Chinese critics are also sensitive to the way their country is represented - the American Nobel Laureate Pearl Buck was accused in the 1930s of 'selling the heads of savages to Westerners' for her novels about the Chinese peasantry. And China does seem to bring out the worst in writers: I haven't read a good novel about China by a Westerner since André Malraux's masterpiece, Man's Estate, written in 1928.

Apart, that is, from Sid Smith's wonderful first book Something Like a House, which rightly arrives in the shops trailing clouds of pre-publication glory. Smith's audacity, and his originality, is to set his novel in rural China during the Maoist years, a period when few foreigners, save Communist sympathisers were allowed behind the 'Bamboo Curtain'.

Jim Fraser, a British soldier on UN manoeuvres during the Korean War, deserts and surrenders himself to the advancing Chinese army. He ends up billeted in a remote village populated by the Miao people (one of China's national minorities), under the supervision of Old Tao, an indigent village elder. The locals gradually come to accept the 'round-eye' and, save for the occasional visit from party apparatchiks and the sinister goings-on in a clinic, there is little to perturb Jim.

He settles into the rhythms of the countryside: working the land, tending the water buffalo and building himself something like a house. (The book's title makes more sense if you know the short lyric by Emily Dickinson which begins: 'Remembrance has a rear and front,/ 'Tis something like a house.') Ten years after his arrival in the village, China is plunged into the violent bedlam of the Cultural Revolution.

The novel is almost perfectly constructed, though to explain its structural appeal I would have to spill its secrets. It is also marvellous for its brevity, managing to span 35 years in little more than 200 pages without any sense of hurry or agitation. Smith writes with a chastity of style that is uncommon in contemporary fiction. He has a compressive imagination, able to abbreviate a landscape to a brace of images, or an image to a single word. An old cap left on a hook has grown within itself a 'green wig' of mould; a Chinese woman totters by on bound feet 'the size of fists'. Fraser watches as lice on a cat 'swim like dolphins through the fur of its head, seeking the right side'.

At no point is China's history, culture or landscape brandished for its own exotic sake. Shocking details do emerge - when a brigade of Red Guards take Fraser with them on their rampages, he forces pork down the throats of Muslims, wears a Mao badge pinned through the flesh over his heart, watches and inflicts tortures, and is witness to cannibalism - but they are made more forceful by the unsensational manner of their telling.

I suspect this book will be compared with Robinson Crusoe (the outsider building his own abode) and Lord of the Flies (the long-term effects of context on individual morality). It is a profound and sophisticated work of fiction.

webTitle: Observer review: 4 Blondes by Candace Bushnell

fields.headline: My fair ladies
fields.standfirst: Sex and the City author Candace Bushnell returns to familiar fixations in 4 Blondes - getting laid and getting rich
fields.trailText: Sex and the City author Candace Bushnell returns to familiar fixations in 4 Blondes - getting laid and getting rich
fields.body:
4 Blondes
Candace Bushnell
Abacus £6.99, pp307
Buy it at a discount at BOL

That 'the world is not right' or that 'the world made no sense' is a common complaint from the women in Candace Bushnell's new book. By this they mean that their limited world is failing to deliver what they think it owes them, or that it has somehow, mistakenly, given all the prizes to someone less deserving (by which they usually mean less beautiful, or - worse still - more beautiful and less talented).

Coupled with this skewed understanding of injustice is an ironic appropriation of Thatcherite sentiment, the repeated assertion that 'Society is dead'. In this world, however, that simply means that the coke-fuelled movie premieres are getting boring. But the unspoken emphasis on the primacy of the individual at all costs lurks on as the sub-text.

Bushnell's first book, Sex and the City, based on her popular New York Observer column and progenitor of the spectacularly successful television series starring Sarah Jessica Parker, saw its author hailed by some critics as the Jane Austen of the Upper West Side. But this new book brings her closer to Choderlos de Laclos and the machiavellian sexual ballet of Les Liaisons Dangereuses.

Her characters are morally cauterised; the moneyed Manhattan élite is a toxic fishbowl of sexual and financial avarice, conquest and competition; cynicism is rife, love a myth, happiness likewise, and every woman's goal is to ensnare a man on the basis of his assets. Those who do, meanwhile, discover that the Grail of marriage merely produces a new set of dissatisfactions and neuroses.

4 Blondes is also extremely funny, but it's a hard-boiled humour with a cruel edge. Tellingly, the two authors called on to provide the obligatory jacket quotes here are Helen Fielding and Brett Easton Ellis, but although in Britain Bushnell is as often compared to Fielding as she is to Austen, she belongs firmly in the Easton Ellis school. Her women are no less grasping and self-obsessed than the brash Wall Street cast of American Psycho, and they do not know how to laugh at themselves; there is no room here for gentle Bridget Jones-like self-deprecation about wobbly thighs. In this hard-nosed, hard-bodied New York society, wobbly thighs can mean the end of the world - or at least of a relationship or a career, which amounts to the same thing.

The four novellas here share a social landscape and a central pool of characters, but are linked more pertinently by the physiognomy of the female protagonists, who occupy different points on the same graph while keeping their thirty-something insecurities in common.

Janey Wilcox, heroine of the first story, 'Nice 'N' Easy', is a model and minor actress who, at 31, is clinging to her flimsy career by the tips of her exquisitely manicured fingernails. (She is also to be the star of Bushnell's next two books, for which she has reportedly signed a $1 million contract with Hyperion).

Janey's only concrete talent is her ability to slink into the affections of a man with a large summer house in the Hamptons, where she will be invited to spend the season as his mistress. Janey professes to the kind of jaw-jutting cynicism that is de rigueur among New York women with regard to relationships: 'The secret to getting rich men, which so many women never figured out, was that getting them was easy, as long as you didn't have any illusions about marrying them.'

But for all her theoretical savoir-faire, Janey is aware that time is running out. 'It was one thing to date rich men, but another to have people thinking you were a whore... Janey had learned that while most rich men thought women were whores deep down, they didn't actually want you to be one.' What promises to develop as a cautionary tale, however, changes direction halfway through; more by luck than judgment, Janey lands a lucrative modelling contract when her half-baked life philosophy - 'I don't know where I'm going, but I'm going somewhere' - is taken up as a mantra for all women of her type.

The second novella, 'Highlights (For Adults)', is the sharpest in the book and charts the slide of a literary marriage that appears, on the surface, to be the apotheosis of all right-thinking women's ambitions.

Winnie and James Dieke are successful journalists in their late thirties, with an attractive child, established careers and an enviable circle of famous friends. Why, then, are both so frustrated and angry with the world? The narrative shifts smoothly between a detached, almost mocking perspective ('Here are a few of the things they agree on: They hate anyone who isn't like them...') and the secret inner voice of both Winnie and James: 'He often wants to ask these other husbands what they think of their wives. Are they scared of them too? Do they hate them? Do they ever have fantasies of pushing their wives down on the bed and ripping off their underpants and giving it to them in the butt?'

As communication deteriorates, both Winnie and James - convinced that the root of all their problems is the other's failure to understand their needs - first contemplate, then enact, adulterous liaisons. This story offers Bushnell's most caustic and adroit dissection of the differences between men and women. She doesn't mince words; physically unpleasant elements of sexual experience are dealt with in the same deadpan, knowing tone as emotions and career ambition, but the end note is optimistic, suggesting that a successful marriage is possible, but only if its limitations are accepted, and it is not expected to fulfil every desire.

It is the final, short story that is the most intriguing. An unnamed American journalist, whom the reader is invited, knowingly, to identify as a Bushnell alter-ego, arrives in London. Believing that relationships between the sexes are more relaxed here, she proceeds to reinforce all the textbook transatlantic stereotypes, under the pretext of exploding them.

Bushnell deals in generalisations, both in New York and London, and while her caricatured portrait of media London is presumably funnier to Americans who have never been here (the love interest is called Rory Saint John Cunningsnot-Bedwards, and she does surmise that all Englishmen 'had sex with their socks on, possessed a microscopic willy, and came in two minutes'), it's not all that far off the mark (except, perhaps, that last bit).

In England the narrator lands on what might prove a definitive explanation for the dilemmas of the modern woman, one which flies in the face of feminist principle, but nevertheless contains an essential truth: that beneath the cynicism, women are by nature romantics: 'I wanted the story. I wanted the big, great, inspiring story about an unmarried career woman who goes to London on assignment and meets the man of her dreams and marries him. She gets the big ring and the big house and the adorable children, and she lives happily ever after. But stories are not reality, no matter how much we might wish them so. And that's not a bad thing.'

Paradoxically, of course (this being a story), as soon as the narrator claims to have given up the romantic dream and affirmed her own worth without a man, she goes ahead and meets one.

Like Wilde or Nancy Mitford, Bushnell has chosen to examine human behaviour in a world that appears at first implausibly one-dimensional. That she can elicit sympathy and indeed empathy for these characters is testament to her skill as a writer, particularly her gift for brilliantly waspish dialogue. You would not want to be any of her characters, but you can't help wincing occasionally in recognition.

What promises to develop as a cautionary tale, however, changes direction halfway through; more by luck than judgment, Janey lands a lucrative modelling contract when her half-baked life philosophy - 'I don't know where I'm going, but I'm going somewhere' - is taken up as a mantra for all women of her type. The second novella, 'Highlights (For Adults)', is the sharpest in the book and charts the slide of a literary marriage that appears, on the surface, to be the apotheosis of all right-thinking women's ambitions. Winnie and James Dieke are successful journalists in their late thirties, with an attractive child, established careers and an enviable circle of famous friends. Why, then, are both so frustrated and angry with the world? The narrative shifts smoothly between a detached, almost mocking perspective ('Here are a few of the things they agree on: They hate anyone who isn't like them...') and the secret inner voice of both Winnie and James: 'He often wants to ask these other husbands what they think of their wives. Are they scared of them too? Do they hate them? Do they ever have fantasies of pushing their wives down on the bed and ripping off their underpants and giving it to them in the butt?' As communication deteriorates, both Winnie and James - convinced that the root of all their problems is the other's failure to understand their needs - first contemplate, then enact, adulterous liaisons. This story offers Bushnell's most caustic and adroit dissection of the differences between men and women. She doesn't mince words; physically unpleasant elements of sexual experience are dealt with in the same deadpan, knowing tone as emotions and career ambition, but the end note is optimistic, suggesting that a successful marriage is possible, but only if its limitations are accepted, and it is not expected to fulfil every desire. It is the final, short story that is the most intriguing. An unnamed American journalist, whom the reader is invited, knowingly, to identify as a Bushnell alter-ego, arrives in London. Believing that relationships between the sexes are more relaxed here, she proceeds to reinforce all the textbook transatlantic stereotypes, under the pretext of exploding them. Bushnell deals in generalisations, both in New York and London, and while her caricatured portrait of media London is presumably funnier to Americans who have never been here (the love interest is called Rory Saint John Cunningsnot-Bedwards, and she does surmise that all Englishmen 'had sex with their socks on, possessed a microscopic willy, and came in two minutes'), it's not all that far off the mark (except, perhaps, that last bit). In England the narrator lands on what might prove a definitive explanation for the dilemmas of the modern woman, one which flies in the face of feminist principle, but nevertheless contains an essential truth: that beneath the cynicism, women are by nature romantics: 'I wanted the story. I wanted the big, great, inspiring story about an unmarried career woman who goes to London on assignment and meets the man of her dreams and marries him. She gets the big ring and the big house and the adorable children, and she lives happily ever after. But stories are not reality, no matter how much we might wish them so. And that's not a bad thing.' Paradoxically, of course (this being a story), as soon as the narrator claims to have given up the romantic dream and affirmed her own worth without a man, she goes ahead and meets one. Like Wilde or Nancy Mitford, Bushnell has chosen to examine human behaviour in a world that appears at first implausibly one-dimensional. That she can elicit sympathy and indeed empathy for these characters is testament to her skill as a writer, particularly her gift for brilliantly waspish dialogue. You would not want to be any of her characters, but you can't help wincing occasionally in recognition.

webTitle: Go see... Absolut Gallaccio

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: Absolut Gallaccio
fields.trailText: Absolut Gallaccio.
fields.body:
Many years ago, before London became a vast urban sprawl so heated by cars, buildings, people and pollution that it developed its own micro-climate, it would snow in the capital almost every winter. Unlike this year's brief flurry, the snow would settle on the ground and the Thames would freeze over for days, weeks on end, becoming an icy leisure centre for the city's inhabitants to skate, dance and party on.

Inspired, in part, by these ice fairs of the past, the British artist Anya Gallaccio will next week be creating a sculpture on the banks of the Thames, using three blocks of Arctic ice shipped in from the River Tome in Lapland, north Sweden - home to Absolut vodka, which is continuing its long association with the arts by sponsoring the event.

One of the young students from Goldsmiths' College featured in the now-famous Freeze exhibition organised by Damien Hirst in 1988, Gallaccio uses materials such as salt, chalk, candlewax, chocolate and flowers to make strange, ephemeral and thought-provoking works which change over time: growing, decaying or melting away.

Gallaccio has fitted a flower-patterned carpet around the trees of a bluebell wood in Oxford and erected a massive one-ton structure made of salt bricks on Bournemouth beach, which crumbled back into the sea when the tide came in. In this case, the ice will be made first into drinks glasses, then into a sculpture, which will gradually melt and trickle down into the Thames. How long it lasts will depend largely on the weather.

 Anya Gallaccio will start work on her ice sculpture outside the Design Museum at Shad Thames, London SE1 at 7pm on 24 January. Go along to see an artist at work - or to drink the free vodka cocktails being served in ice glasses by the sponsors
