webTitle: Mean Fiddler calls the tune

fields.headline: Mean Fiddler calls the tune
fields.standfirst: Rags-to-riches music king floats to fund digital channel. Profile of  Vince Power by Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Rags-to-riches music king floats to fund digital channel. Profile of Vince Power by Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Woe betide anyone who gets in Vince Power's way. This 6ft lump of Irish meat and gristle is the UK capital's most powerful music venue owner. And he didn't get there by being a pushover.

'I'm two extremes,' he whispers in one of his central London bars where, on a bitterly cold day, the heating has packed up. 'I'm very soft and I'm very hard and I'm trying to find the middle ground. If anyone tries to turn me over, I take a very hard view of it.'

Let's hope the heating engineer turns up pronto then.

Power (definitely his real name) once spent the best part of a year trying to gain revenge on a former business partner he believed 'shafted him' on a deal to run the Reading Festival. So what did he do? He bought the land on which the festival was sited. Job done.

Power's rags-to-riches story is the stuff of showbiz legend.

He rose from an impoverished background to own, under the Mean Fiddler banner, a dozen of the capital's top venues, including the Forum and the Astoria. He runs some of the country's major music festivals, including Reading and north London's Fleadh, plus a quoted internet broadcast business. His businesses and joint ventures combined turn over close to £40 million and make profits of about £4m.

In the 18 years since Power opened his first club - a Nashville-style honky-tonk auditorium in run-down Harlesden - he has crossed swords with, and defeated, established promoters, rival venue owners, agents and landowners to become a millionaire several times over.

'He has a team around him who are fiercely loyal,' said one rival promoter. 'A lot of them are family. That helps. But where Power scored is that he always went straight to the artist. He pissed off managers and agents, but he got the acts. And now they all have to deal with him, because in London there's only the Brixton Academy and the Apollo that he doesn't own.'

Last Tuesday, the man dressed in black jeans and leather and sporting a closely cropped beard entered the City big time. Power announced that he was reversing his meanfiddler.com operation into his other interests.

The deal values his venues, restaurants and bars at £32m. He hopes to raise £10m from the float, which he will use to fund a digital music channel based at his venues and to open more venues.

So within months Power will become chairman of a plc. Not bad for a man born into a poor Waterford family, one of 11 kids of whom four died at birth, including his twin sister.

Growing up in Fifties Ireland was hard. But at the age of 17, 'yer man' won a scholarship to study artificial insemination at a Galway agricultural college.

To the disappointment of his mother, Power decided that playing the role of a bull for the rest of his working life was not what God intended.

He left for the mainland, and his aunt found him a job as a Woolworths shop assistant in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire.

It wasn't until Power hit the smoke that life started looking up. His various odd jobs in Sixties London included night shifts in a Walls ice-cream factory - which ended in disaster when he fell asleep on the job - and a demolition job, smashing roofs for £2 a go.

At the time, swathes of London were being cleared to make way for modern estates. Power was amazed at how much furniture people abandoned, and he arranged for it to be sold on. Soon, he opened a shop.

His luck improved further when he bought an oil painting for a tenner. It was in the window for less than a day when someone offered £200 for it. Power realised he might be on to something and took it to Sotheby's. It fetched £7,000 - a tidy sum back in the Sixties.

After establishing a chain of a dozen second-hand furniture shops, Power thought the time was right for indulging his passion, music. While he couldn't play, he knew people who could.

Power opened the Mean Fiddler in 1982. It was a gleaming purpose-built venue in an Irish part of town at time when spit, sawdust and warm beer were regarded as the norm by most live music lovers. He installed a house band, but found he could pack the place out only at weekends.

So Power widened the venue's music policy and tried out new-band nights.

What started as a hobby grew into a multimillion pound business. But keeping to the style of a maverick, Power has always eschewed paperwork. 'I keep a lot of things in my head. I don't go writing notes or taking minutes. Perhaps that's all gonna change when I'm the chairman of a plc.'

Power's plc will, he believes, see its share price double within a few years. Becoming the only promoter from outside the US to beat the unions and run American music festivals gives him some cause for confidence.

'The unions wanted to put 10 blokes on your budget when one bloke can do the same job,' he said. 'I had all that in the first year, but we got it all sorted out. A lot of the leaders of unions are Irish, so we could talk.'

Power won't open venues outside London. He says no famous American artist wants to play 'two nights in Birmingham'. Instead he wants to take his Jazz Cafe brand into Paris, Barcelona and one other major European city.

But it's in digital television that he believes the real dough is to be made. Analysts predict that quality digital TV content providers will become valuable.

The UK has the best digital television sales in Europe, and viewers will soon be able to store favourite shows on set-top boxes' hard disks, rather than videoing them. For companies such as Mean Fiddler that means viewers being able to watch its concerts whenever they choose.

'In the long term this will be a profitable game,' says Jay Marathe, head of consulting at Durlacher, the technology incubator and finance house. 'At the moment, digital TV providers are adding local storage capacity to their platforms to grow the market. Premium content businesses like Mean Fiddler will be in demand and in the long-term will enjoy high margins.'

Power agrees: 'That's the way we think the business is going. We've done the feasibility studies. We're in negotiations with some of the big stations. It will cost millions to set up, but we think we can be profitable within three years.'

Ask Power to name the promoters and venue owners he admires and there is a long silence. At a push he'll name Bill Graham, the influential San Franciscan promoter and entrepreneur who's now dead. Of the many alive only Bob Angus, managing director of Metropolis Music, gets a mention.

'This is a fiercely competitive business,' Power says. 'If you're in the business of cardboard boxes there's not so much ego, but this business is driven by ego, and ego can cost you millions. I think we're all driven by it.'

But Power's excellent relationship with bands (The Pogues used to swear by him) may be changing.

'The business of being able to access acts on the internet makes a band more powerful,' he says. 'They don't have to sign lifetime deals with a record company. The band can just licence an album. Record companies have grown fat on back catalogues. That'll all be different in the future.'

In an industry famous for sex and drugs, Power is relatively abstemious. OK, he's got eight children from three partners, but his current partner is of 10 years' standing, and he says he has never taken a drug in his life.

You get the feeling he doesn't need chemicals. Power's preferred stimulant, it seems, is - appropriately - power. On leaving, he says he's off to 'a boring accountants meeting'.

But you know whose tune his accountants will be dancing to.

Profile

Name: Vince Power

Born: 29 April 1947, Waterford, Eire

Education: Awarded scholarship to study artificial insemination of cows

First Job: Woolworth's shop assistant, Hemel Hempstead

First Venue: Mean Fiddler, north London in 1982

Home: Kilburn, north London

Hobbies: Business, family and horses

Vince Power's top gigs

1) Roy Orbison

2) Limp Bizkit

3) Manic Street Preachers

4) John Prine

5) Dr John

webTitle: Tony Adams: I quit

fields.headline: Tony Adams: I quit
fields.standfirst: 'I owe it to Arsenal to end my England career,' he says
fields.trailText: Tony Adams, who captained England against Germany in their last international at Wembley Stadium, is retiring from international football with immediate effect. 'I have taken the decision to listen to my body,' he said last night.
fields.body:
Tony Adams, who captained England against Germany in their last international at Wembley Stadium, is retiring from international football with immediate effect. 'I have taken the decision to listen to my body,' he said last night.

Adams finally agreed a new contract with Arsenal last week and believes that he can no longer give his best for both club and country, at the age of 34 and with injuries having taken their toll on him over the past couple of years, restricting his appearances for both.

'Something has to give and it has to be the internationals,' he said. 'I want to give the benefit of the time I have left in the game to Arsenal. I can't keep being cruel to them by playing for England then missing club games. It's not fair on them because they have been very good to me.

'Even though neither Arsène Wenger nor anyone else at Arsenal has said anything about it to me, I feel obligated towards them. I owe them some games. I believe we can achieve something big over the next season or two and I want to play a full part in that. It will help if I can rest in international weeks.'

Originally, Adams hoped to see out the current England campaign, helping them to qualify for the World Cup finals this year before enjoying a swansong in Japan and Korea next summer. He recognises, though, that a series of injuries, which have included persistent neck, back, groin and ankle problems, will not now allow him to do so.

Adams's Observer Sport revelation will come as a blow to the new England coach Sven-Göran Eriksson as he plots the campaign. While he is being encouraged to bring in new players, he maintains that experience will be vital to the nation's chances.

The inspirational Adams - even if David Beckham is likely to be Eriksson's captain - would undoubtedly have figured large in Erikkson's thinking, since Adams has never had a problem serving under another captain, even though he always believed himself to be the best choice. Certainly when fully fit, he remains the best centre-back in the country.

Adams made his England debut as a 20-year old in 1987, in a 4-2 win over Spain in Madrid. He went on to win 66 caps, scoring five goals - the final one being England's last goal at Wembley, in a 2-0 win over Ukraine last May. He served under five managers - Bobby Robson, Graham Taylor, Terry Venables, Glenn Hoddle and Kevin Keegan - and was Venables's first choice captain, leading the national team to the semi-finals at Euro 96.

England's loss will be Arsenal's gain. With him in the Premiership this season, they have won 10 out of 15 games, taking 33 points; without him they have won only one of nine, taking just eight points.

Yesterday at Filbert Street, he made his return to the side after a three-match absence in a 0-0 draw against Leicester City. To the tune of Knee's Up Mother Brown , the Arsenal supporters sang: 'Who won all those caps? Tony Adams, Tony Adams, he won all those caps.'

webTitle: Richard Ingrams' week

fields.headline: What price juries' prudence?
fields.standfirst:
The Grobbelaar case only highlights how silly judges can be

Special report: trial by jury
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Grobbelaar case only highlights how silly judges can be
fields.body:
In the old days the verdict of a High Court jury was considered so sacrosanct that any failure on its part had to be attributed to the judge. If a re-trial was ordered, it was because the judge had misdirected the jury, never because the jury had simply got it wrong.

Obviously such a tradition grated on judges, who hate to be attacked. Living in a slightly unreal world where they are grovelled to by fellow lawyers hoping to get on in the world, they come to resent anything that looks like criticism.

It was perhaps this feeling that motivated those judges who in last week's appeal hearing ruled that the jury in the Grobbelaar libel action had been 'perverse' to award him damages of £85,000.

It is hard to know which is more perverse - the jury or these judges.

It will no longer be necessary for litigants to pore over a judge's summing-up, trying to find evidence of bias. All you will have to argue is that the jury, with typical perversity, got it wrong.

On this principle there could be quite a lot of us lining up outside the law courts before long asking for our money back. Whether this is what the Appeal Court judges want I don't know, as it could make the system look even sillier than it does now.

Waugh games

Reading the many fulsome tributes in the press last week to my friend Auberon Waugh, I was reminded of something he wrote in his memoirs: 'It is a sad fact of journalism that people only tell you your stuff is any good after you have stopped writing it.'

One of the reasons I think he was so good was that he never fell into the error of thinking that he was influential. In common with all the best journalists, he knew that what he wrote was here today and gone tomorrow and that its impact was minimal.

Like all of us, he had met that man who said: 'I did enjoy your column last week when you wrote about...' (He then discovers that he can't remember what it was you said. You then realise that neither can you.)

'It is always a bad sign,' Auberon wrote, 'for a journalist when he starts imagining that his work has any more important function than to fill up space in that day's newspaper.' Bron's special scorn was reserved for journalists, especially editors like Harold Evans and Paul Johnson, who took themselves very seriously and believed that governments could be shaken or even brought down by what they said.

Most contemptible of all in his eyes were those self-regarding journalists who sued for libel, and who included not only Harold Evans and Paul Johnson but this newspaper's former political correspondent, Nora Beloff, of whom Bron wrote in his Private Eye diary that she had slept with every single member of Harold Wilson's Cabinet, adding that 'no impropriety occurred'.

After a farcical court case, she was awarded substantial damages, and Waugh belatedly acknowledged that 'in a British courtroom an ordinary act like eating a sausage can be made under cross-examination to sound like some bizarre perversion'.

Hollow words

'It is my experience that people who genuinely want to die soon do so.' After some months of distress in which he became more and more troubled by his failing powers of memory, Bron, I think, was true to his word. He wanted to go and, mercifully for his family, his end came quite quickly. His death removes the one remaining reason for buying the Daily Telegraph . Like the Conservative Party which it continues to support, it is nowadays reduced to an ill-organised mess - a mixture of trendyness and fogeyism - trying unsuccessfully to appeal to everyone at once.

Perhaps the lowest point recently was the two pages of pro-Israel propaganda written by the proprietor's wife, Barbara Amiel. What self-respecting editor could remain at his post after having to print such a rant?

Even in their treatment of Auberon's death, the Telegraph showed that it no longer has any instinct for getting it right. fields.bodyText: In the old days the verdict of a High Court jury was considered so sacrosanct that any failure on its part had to be attributed to the judge. If a re-trial was ordered, it was because the judge had misdirected the jury, never because the jury had simply got it wrong. Obviously such a tradition grated on judges, who hate to be attacked. Living in a slightly unreal world where they are grovelled to by fellow lawyers hoping to get on in the world, they come to resent anything that looks like criticism. It was perhaps this feeling that motivated those judges who in last week's appeal hearing ruled that the jury in the Grobbelaar libel action had been 'perverse' to award him damages of £85,000. It is hard to know which is more perverse - the jury or these judges. It will no longer be necessary for litigants to pore over a judge's summing-up, trying to find evidence of bias. All you will have to argue is that the jury, with typical perversity, got it wrong. On this principle there could be quite a lot of us lining up outside the law courts before long asking for our money back. Whether this is what the Appeal Court judges want I don't know, as it could make the system look even sillier than it does now. One of the reasons I think he was so good was that he never fell into the error of thinking that he was influential. In common with all the best journalists, he knew that what he wrote was here today and gone tomorrow and that its impact was minimal. Like all of us, he had met that man who said: 'I did enjoy your column last week when you wrote about...' (He then discovers that he can't remember what it was you said. webTitle: Leader: Dubya is not to be trusted

fields.headline: Beware Bush's American dream
fields.standfirst:
This President is not to be trusted

The Bush Files
fields.trailText: This President is not to be trusted.
fields.body:
George W. Bush delivered his inaugural speech as the United States President who collected 537,000 fewer votes than his opponent. Without the intervention of a partisan, right-wing Supreme Court to ensure the election of a Republican, Mr Bush would now be a forgotten loser. The Observer considers his election an affront to the democratic principle with incalculable consequences for America and the world.

Mr Bush's inaugural attempt to assert his brand of one-nation, compassionate conservatism is bluster and hogwash. He has acted from the moment Al Gore conceded as if he had won a wholehearted mandate.

But the Bush cabinet is neither centrist nor compassionate. In home affairs, it is brutalist and reactionary - for tax cuts overtly biased towards the rich, against the protection of consumers, workers and the environment. In overseas affairs, Mr Bush has appointed Cold War warriors from his father's era who do not appreciate the nuances of a transformed international environment.

The departing President Clinton was in office during a record-breaking economic boom. However, a more accurate assessment of his legacy is that he has bestowed on the US the first Republican President and Republican-controlled Congress since 1952. For a President who supposedly made the Democrats respectable again, this is a bequest the world could have done without.

For all his cleverness and tactical political skills, Mr Clinton could not even deliver the limited Third Way philosophy developed in the late 1980s. He simply bought, as he acknowledged, essentially conservative policies with one or two small-scale, liberal micro-interventions.

As a result, the Republicans retained control of the political, intellectual and cultural agenda and plotted their return to power. Their success is embodied in the nomination of John Ashcroft as attorney-general. Mr Ashcroft is a southern-based, anti-abortion, anti-gun control, anti-gay religious fundamentalist peddling a reactionary brand of free market economics and American unilateralism. He epitomises the new centre of gravity in American politics.

Britain and Europe will find doing business with this administration tense, oppositional and unproductive. It would be difficult enough had Mr Bush won a mandate. Without it, we are in for a very rough ride indeed.

webTitle: Bush's hard men sweep  away the Clinton legacy

fields.headline: Bush's hard men sweep  away the Clinton legacy
fields.standfirst:
Americans wake up this morning with a new President. And, reports Ed Vulliamy from Washington, George W Bush brings with him a radical and deeply conservative view of the world his people inhabit

The Bush Files
fields.trailText: Americans wake up this morning with a new President. And, reports Ed Vulliamy from Washington, George W Bush brings with him a radical and deeply conservative view of the world his people inhabit.
fields.body:
The first babies of the George W Bush presidency were born yesterday into a country transformed by his predecessor. 'When I came into office,' said Bill Clinton, putting it the way he thinks people will most easily remember, 'the World Wide Web had only 50 sites.'

Their infancy will be spent in a country that is, for all the profusion of websites, less homogeneous, more complex, less white, more prosperous, less dangerous and more bitterly divided than that in which their fathers and mothers first met.

Bush only just made it to yesterday's inauguration, having lost the popular vote and won Florida by a hair's breadth. And so the Bush babies join a nation riven - as the election results and New Year census show - between city and country, black and white, women and men, over what should happen next, over whether to proceed with the Clinton era that ended yesterday or to change course. The latter side won. Just.

The story of the transformation of America under Clinton is familiar. The economy is the strongest in a generation, its expansion the longest in American history. A federal deficit of $255 billion a year has been converted into a record projected surplus of $236bn; 22 million new jobs created; a record number of families with access to health care, and so on. It's an America in which politics has been transformed by a President who could be all things to most men (and especially women), who wore an infectious smile and played the saxophone but was also a persuasive statesman and the major international force of his generation.

This was a President who at home faced down the barons of big tobacco, oil and guns, but who tangoed with the Merlin of the market, Alan Greenspan. Who swore he had never inhaled just as he swore he 'did not have sexual relations with that woman, Monica Lewinsky'. Who ruled a nation which had both the 'working families' and Wall Street as its bifocal points, and who presided over liberal capitalism's final conquest of most of the world.

Clinton was the President of an age of social democracy, wealth (in the West) and exuberance, and he headed an exuberant, if sometimes tumultuous, White House. Now he takes his last flight on Air Force One to Arkansas where it all began, while Bush, in white cowboy hat, bids farewell to Midland, Texas, with a 'local boy made good' routine. It takes a while for Presidents to establish their style as rulers of a superpower and there is acute curiosity as to how this relative novice to politics will shape up - let alone what kind of America he will shape.

But there are more than a few clues, starting with the festivities in Washington: goodbye Hollywood, hello Nashville! Goodbye Jack Nicholson and Sharon Stone, hello Sylvester Stallone; goodbye Aretha Franklin and Sheryl Crow, welcome back Loretta Lynn!

Most intriguing, though, is that phalanx of stolid men in colourless suits forever behind and beside Bush. Replacing the fresh faces that populated Clinton's White House are men with austere bureaucratic life stories, their big-framed spectacles glinting in the winter sunlight as they emerge from closed corporate boardrooms.

There is a generational oddity - even a Freudian dysfunction - in this presidential handover by the baby-boomer Clinton and his crowd. Now it is Bush's big moment, but he has invited all Daddy's friends to the party and sat them at high table: Vice-President Dick Cheney, Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, Defence Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, Secretary of State Colin Powell and more. Some served not only George Bush Senior but Ronald Reagan, Gerald Ford and even Richard Nixon. And between then and now they have put in long, lucrative stints behind those boardroom doors.

So the Bush babies have entered a time warp, born yesterday but flung back a decade to the Cold War, before the shooting stars of Clinton's shiny New Democrats, New Economy, New America and New World, of which these grey conservatives are the antithesis.

But this word 'conservative' is just as deceptive among Bush's entourage as the coupling Bush gave it: 'compassionate'. For Bush is launching a radical assault on American culture just as thorough, if not more so, than Clinton's.

The media tend not to notice Bush's conservative-radicalism since - being fairly well-off - the editorial sages define politics in social rather than economic terms. So an extreme economic right-winger such as Christine Todd Whitman, who also favours a woman's right to abortion, is welcomed as a liberal in the cabinet. Meanwhile, Gary Bauer - a blue-collar (black) social conservative who rails against abortion but who wants the minimum wage raised and opposes the privatisation of social security - is dubbed a right-wing lunatic, thankfully seen off at the primaries.

Whatever tightrope Bush can walk on social policy, his economic plan for America puts him on the hard, radical Right - vacuuming up ideas from hawkish Washington organisations such as the Heritage Foundation or American Enterprise Institute, and harnessing the relentless ideological brawn behind them, Newt Gingrich as was and now Tom De Lay. 'The Bush campaign,' says Jonathan Chait of the New Republic, 'is not a repudiation of the Gingrich revolution, it is the vehicle for its fevered, unredeemed aspirations.'

Two policies - on tax and social security - define the philosophy of Bush's America, which is this: the minimisation, de-legitimisation and ultimately abolition of effective federal government. The ultra-right National Review realises this better than the mainstream punditocracy: 'Bush,' it writes, reassuring its libertarian constituency, 'has been reliable on the issues that matter. His support for tax cuts and social security reform is more important than his spending initiatives because if he succeeds on taxes and social security, it will be easier to limit government.'

'It's conservative to cut taxes,' said Bush, 'it's compassionate to let people keep more of their money.' It sounds like a Republican 'Third Way'. But who is to 'keep more of their money'?

Contrast the federal tax system with that of Bush's Texas. At federal level a family in the bottom fifth of income levels pays less than nine per cent in tax; the top one per cent give 37 per cent of their income to the government. In Texas the tax burden drops as income rises: the poorest pay 13 per cent while the top one per cent pay less than five per cent to the Austin State Capitol.

Bush now brings an adaptation of the Texan tax model to Washington, with cuts as top priority as he and his team hurry to push his most urgent agenda through Congress. The top one per cent will enjoy a 43 per cent share of the $1.8 trillion tax cut, aimed at bringing about the 'trickle- down effect' attempted by his father and Reagan. To justify the cut, Bush reads the Ides of Recession, which he blames on his predecessor.

Bush pledges to 'reform' social security, but in fact he plans to transform the system. He has told the Houston Chronicle that his scheme to create private savings accounts 'could be the first step towards a complete privatisation of social security'.

The Bush babies are born into a 'pay-as-you-go' social security system: parents contribute their slice, which goes directly to someone's grandma. It's an intergenerational transfer payment. Bush's plan is one in which every individual provides for his or her own retirement with funds invested in stocks.

This is one of the most drastic alterations to the relationship between citizen and government - breaking an enduring connection - since the New Deal of the Thirties.

This abrogration of government will infuse every corner of life. Take guns, for example. Clinton banned semi-automatic assault weapons and did all he could to back legislation seeking to oblige manufacturers to fit child locks on all guns. In Texas you need to train for 150 hours to become a hairdresser, but only 10 hours to buy a gun. 'I guess,' says former Clinton adviser Paul Begala, 'that Bush trusts his fellow Texans with a .45 that can blow you away more than he trusts them with a blow-dryer.'

Bush signed a law allowing concealed weapons and repealed another which exempted specific locations from having to accommodate every Texan's right to carry a weapon - so everyone can 'pack heat' in church, hospital or at Houston's Astroworld theme park.

For all his initial talk about bipartisanship and unity, Bush has bypassed successive moderates to form a government which is opposed to governing. In Spencer Abraham, Bush has an Energy Secretary who in Congress sponsored legislation to abolish the department he now heads. In Tommy Thompson he has a Health Secretary who, as Governor of Wisconsin, failed to implement tobacco control initiatives and happens to have enjoyed close ties to the Philip Morris company for more than 14 years.

The Bush babies will grow up in America the Beautiful, a landscape of breathtaking power, comprising hundreds of millions of acres of wilderness, mighty desert, towering mountains, plunging canyons and all the wildlife they harbour. But will it stay that way?

A defiant scramble during Clinton's last days sought to ensure protection for several of these millions of acres under federal law, and an executive order to ban logging or road-building - in effect crippling any plans for oil drilling, mineral mining and suchlike. Bush said he already has lawyers examining 'every opportunity to reverse' these measures.

And so America will become a nation of shrinking wilderness and tarnished beauty. Bush is committed to the exploitation of energy resources in wilderness that just happens to be under the protection of Clinton's directives.

To administer the 500 million acres of federally protected land, Bush appointed Gale Norton, who boasts a long career of championing business interests against the federal authority she is now assigned to wield. Last week the stuffy Sierra Club (equivalent to the National Trust) joined a chorus of protest against Norton's appointment.

Bush's philosophy on the environment comes from Texas, where in 1998 the governor signed a 'Clean Air' Act he had negotiated with oil executives. This allowed companies to set their own pollution control standards. As he signed this law, the town of Odessa was engulfed in toxic clouds so thick drivers had to turn on headlights in daytime.

In the same speech as that promising to roll back Clinton's wilderness protection, Bush promised to reverse another ingredient of his predecessor's valedictory package - an endorsement of aid to Russia, aimed to help that country unlock the shackles of communism.

Bush's abrogation of Washington's responsibilities will not be limited to American citizens but extended to those of other nations. Clinton took easily to the world stage. He was busily engrossed in the Middle East, the Balkans, Russia, Asia, China, Haiti and not least Ireland. He was usually an ally and sometimes an inspiration to new governments in Western and Eastern Europe.

If Clinton had one great idea it was that trade is the most effective diplomat. He turned Uncle Sam's image in Latin America from that of adviser to torturers to trader in new markets. He prised Communist China open, likewise Indonesia, while chastising both for their grotesque record on human rights.

Bush's commitment to the international market can be even greater, unfettered by considerations such as human rights and Washington's responsibility to intervene in the world. Here again, there is a fundamental sea change under way. The idea that America is accountable to citizens of the world other than its own is as old and as idealistic as the nation itself. It is an almost moral calling. Henry Kissinger, of all people, writes in his new book: 'American Presidents have invoked their country's unselfishness as the crucial attribute of its leadership role.'

But Bush has seen little of the world. The new President is often described as an 'incurious' man, which is odd for one born to a political dynasty who took degrees at Harvard and Yale during the era of cut-price international air travel. 'There is [sic] madmen in the world,' said Bush, outlining his view to the Associated Press news agency last year, 'and there are terror'.

'Dan Quayle without the brains,' joked an outgoing senior White House aide, packing up his desk.

Although the avuncular and absurdly popular figure of Colin Powell will be the face of Bush's America on the world stage, the propeller behind Bush's foreign policy has been Condoleeza Rice, one of his father's advisers and an expert on Russia (though Bush was captivated by her during a talk about baseball). Rice alarmed European leaders by saying the US intended to pull its troops out of Kosovo.

In an article last year for the journal Foreign Affairs, she explained the difference between the Clinton and Bush plans for America-in-the-world. When foreign policy is centred on 'values', she wrote, 'the national interest is replaced with "humanitarian interests" or the interests of "the international community". There is nothing wrong with doing something that benefits all humanity, but that is, in a sense, a second-order effect.'

Rice's view is a radical departure from the traditions not only of Wilson, Roosevelt and Clinton but also Reagan, after a different fashion, and even Bush's own father. He did, after all, forge the coalition that fought the Gulf War (which Powell initially opposed).

It is unlikely, then, that Bush would have sent lieutenants to Ireland on a clandestine 'golfing trip' to canvass terrorists on either side on what it would take to do a deal. He will not pore all night over maps of the West Bank or Kosovo, or order GI Joe to hunt down war criminals.

Bush does follow world events from Texas, but he keeps returning to the same theme. As he told the Boston Globe: ' This is still a dangerous world. It's a world of madmen and uncertainty, and potential mental losses.'

Uncle Sam's defence policy will be not only to 'go home' but to build a stockade around that home, called 'National Missile Defence' - old name, Star Wars - and endorsed last week by Powell as the bedrock of US foreign policy.

This is enough to scare the Russians stiff and split Bush's European allies, for whom the prospect of a fearful, angry Russia is more worrying than a rogue North Korean missile.

It's all change in Washington

Out: A President whose middle name is Jefferson.
In: A President with the middle name of Walker.

Out: The 27th President with a training in law.
In: The first-ever President with an MBA (business administration) degree.

Out: A President who plays sax.
In: A President who prays.

Out: Armani.
In: Brooks Brothers grey and cowboy hats.

Out: 'I did not have sexual relations with that woman.'
In: 'Is our children learning?'

Out: First Lady who became a Senator and wants to be President.
In: First Lady who doesn't even want to be First Lady.

Out: Sheryl Crow, Quincy Jones, Stevie Wonder, Babs.
In: Ricky Martin and Loretta Lynn.

Out: Sharon Stone, Bo Derek, Jack Nicholson.
In: Sylvester Stallone, Arnie Schwarzenegger.

Out: Janet 'Sherman' Reno.
In: John 'Stonewall' Ashcroft.

Out: Tax breaks for the middle class.
In: Tax breaks for the upper class.

Out: Buddy and Sox
In: Spot

In the same speech as that promising to roll back Clinton's wilderness protection, Bush promised to reverse another ingredient of his predecessor's valedictory package - an endorsement of aid to Russia, aimed to help that country unlock the shackles of communism. Bush's abrogation of Washington's responsibilities will not be limited to American citizens but extended to those of other nations. Clinton took easily to the world stage. He was busily engrossed in the Middle East, the Balkans, Russia, Asia, China, Haiti and not least Ireland. He was usually an ally and sometimes an inspiration to new governments in Western and Eastern Europe. If Clinton had one great idea it was that trade is the most effective diplomat. He turned Uncle Sam's image in Latin America from that of adviser to torturers to trader in new markets. He prised Communist China open, likewise Indonesia, while chastising both for their grotesque record on human rights. Bush's commitment to the international market can be even greater, unfettered by considerations such as human rights and Washington's responsibility to intervene in the world. Here again, there is a fundamental sea change under way. The idea that America is accountable to citizens of the world other than its own is as old and as idealistic as the nation itself. It is an almost moral calling. Henry Kissinger, of all people, writes in his new book: 'American Presidents have invoked their country's unselfishness as the crucial attribute of its leadership role.' But Bush has seen little of the world. The new President is often described as an 'incurious' man, which is odd for one born to a political dynasty who took degrees at Harvard and Yale during the era of cut-price international air travel. 'There is [sic] madmen in the world,' said Bush, outlining his view to the Associated Press news agency last year, 'and there are terror'. 'Dan Quayle without the brains,' joked an outgoing senior White House aide, packing up his desk. Although the avuncular and absurdly popular figure of Colin Powell will be the face of Bush's America on the world stage, the propeller behind Bush's foreign policy has been Condoleeza Rice, one of his father's advisers and an expert on Russia (though Bush was captivated by her during a talk about baseball). Rice alarmed European leaders by saying the US intended to pull its troops out of Kosovo. In an article last year for the journal Foreign Affairs, she explained the difference between the Clinton and Bush plans for America-in-the-world. When foreign policy is centred on 'values', she wrote, 'the national interest is replaced with "humanitarian interests" or the interests of "the international community". There is nothing wrong with doing something that benefits all humanity, but that is, in a sense, a second-order effect.' Rice's view is a radical departure from the traditions not only of Wilson, Roosevelt and Clinton but also Reagan, after a different fashion, and even Bush's own father. He did, after all, forge the coalition that fought the Gulf War (which Powell initially opposed). It is unlikely, then, that Bush would have sent lieutenants to Ireland on a clandestine 'golfing trip' to canvass terrorists on either side on what it would take to do a deal. He will not pore all night over maps of the West Bank or Kosovo, or order GI Joe to hunt down war criminals. Bush does follow world events from Texas, but he keeps returning to the same theme. As he told the Boston Globe: ' This is still a dangerous world. It's a world of madmen and uncertainty, and potential mental losses.' Uncle Sam's defence policy will be not only to 'go home' but to build a stockade around that home, called 'National Missile Defence' - old name, Star Wars - and endorsed last week by Powell as the bedrock of US foreign policy. This is enough to scare the Russians stiff and split Bush's European allies, for whom the prospect of a fearful, angry Russia is more worrying than a rogue North Korean missile. It's all change in Washington Out: A President whose middle name is Jefferson. In: A President with the middle name of Walker. Out: The 27th President with a training in law. In: The first-ever President with an MBA (business administration) degree. Out: A President who plays sax. In: A President who prays. Out: Armani. In: Brooks Brothers grey and cowboy hats. Out: 'I did not have sexual relations with that woman.' In: 'Is our children learning?' Out: First Lady who became a Senator and wants to be President. In: First Lady who doesn't even want to be First Lady. Out: Sheryl Crow, Quincy Jones, Stevie Wonder, Babs. In: Ricky Martin and Loretta Lynn. Out: Sharon Stone, Bo Derek, Jack Nicholson. In: Sylvester Stallone, Arnie Schwarzenegger. Out: Janet 'Sherman' Reno. In: John 'Stonewall' Ashcroft. Out: Tax breaks for the middle class. In: Tax breaks for the upper class. Out: Buddy and Sox In: Spot Out: Chelsea: from gawkish adolescent to blossoming womanhood. In: The hyper-cool Bush twins, Barbara and Jenna: 'but don't even think about it,' warns Dad.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: High Fidelity | Woodstock | The British Avant-Garde in the Thirties | La Nouvelle Eve
fields.trailText: High Fidelity | Woodstock | The British Avant-Garde in the Thirties | La Nouvelle Eve
fields.body:
High Fidelity
(2000, 15, Buena Vista, VHS/ Rental, DVD/Retail)
Stephen Frears confidently directs the transposition of Nick Hornby's cult novel from London to Chicago and most things fit as John Cusack plays the dedicated, unprosperous proprietor of a specialist rock record store called Championship Vinyl. Cusack is anxiously excellent as always, and you don't have to know much about pop music to become involved in his morally complex world. Catherine Zeta-Jones figures in the hero's carefully annotated past.

Woodstock
(1970, Warner, DVD/ Retail)
Directed by Mike Wadleigh and co-edited by Martin Scorsese, this is the restored full-length version of one of the great concert movies and a major document about the 1960s ethos. It records the event that brought half-a-million young Americans to a New England farm in 1969 to protest against the Vietnam War and hear some of the decade's best rock and folk singers. The performers include Jimi Hendrix, Richie Havens, Arlo Guthrie, Joan Baez and The Who.

The British Avant-Garde in the Thirties
(1934-1939, E, BFI, VHS, Retail/Rental)
The British Film Institute has been doing admirable work these past couple of years making available on tape a century of crucial independent and experimental films. This three-hour compilation of 13 movies, arguably their best yet, contains four of the most important British documentaries, all produced by John Grierson. They are Basil Wright's poetic Song of Ceylon (1935); Cavalcanti's Coalface (1935) with music by Britten and lyrics by Auden; Edgar Anstey and Arthur Elton's Housing Problems (1935), in which, for the first time, working-class people stood in their homes and spoke directto camera about their lives; and Humphrey Jennings's Spare Time (1939), an at times surreal celebration of the working-class at play. In addition, there are pioneering animated pictures by Len Lye and Norman McLaren, silent agitprop films, and Tell Me If It Hurts?, one of the quirky comedies by Richard Massingham, the doctor and part-time movie-maker.

La Nouvelle Eve
(1999, 18, Tartan, VHS/Retail, Rental)
Strangely disturbing French film, written and directed by Catherine Corsini, starring Karin Viard as a predatory, unattached Parisian woman in her thirties pursuing a bald, happily married Socialist Party organiser. An unusual piece of feminist cinema and an endearing, exasperating heroine.

fields.standfirst: He wanted to know about porn; she wanted to tell him about her love life.  Lynn Barber  recalls her 30-year friendship with Auberon Waugh
fields.trailText: He wanted to know about porn; she wanted to tell him about her love life. Lynn Barber recalls her 30-year friendship with Auberon Waugh
fields.body:
Quite apart from the prigs and puritans and Polly Toynbees, I imagine that people who did not know Bron - the silent majority - must have been bewildered and probably irritated by the huge media outpouring of grief that greeted his death this week.

Much greater writers have died with less fanfare; I don't remember the Telegraph devoting five pages to Graham Greene's death as it did to Bron's. A friend of mine said rather sourly, 'I suppose he was the journalist's journalist' and of course, yes - that's exactly what he was. He stood for all the things that attracted me to journalism in the first place, all the things Polly Toynbee most disapproves of - long lunches and gossip and laughter and a mischievous (yes!), and above all irreverent (oh please!) response to pomposity and received opinion.

Obviously you needed a sense of humour to appreciate him which is why Toynbee drew a blank - but her claim in the Guardian on Friday that he was the head of some sinister right-wing coterie was risible for those of us who know how to ris.

He wrote to no agenda or party line. He did not believe it was the job of journalists to run the country or to advise politicians, but to nip at the heels of sacred cows and expose the inadequacy of the emperor's new clothes. He never pontificated about family values but he lived them, deeply. And however cruelly he wrote on occasions, he was unfailingly kind in real life. He believed that it was our duty to be happy as long as possible because tomorrow we die. He told me once: 'I'm just not prepared to be agonised by all the suffering in the world. There's no point in the world if we've all got to suffer with the suffering, because the whole point is that while some people suffer, others don't.' Hence his tireless crusade to add to the world's stock of jollity and laughter.

I first met him 30 years ago when I worked for Penthouse magazine. He wrote me a fan letter having seen me on Call My Bluff; I wrote back, and after that we had regular lunches, where I would ask about books and he would ask about Penthouse. I kept expecting him to make a pass but he never did - on the contrary, he listened sympathetically to the ups and downs of my love life.

He was a great listener, especially to the amatory woes of young women. He made me take him to lunch at the Penthouse Club in Shepherd's Market. I warned him he wouldn't like it but he insisted so I took him there and he was terribly upset when all the Penthouse Pets came and talked about their boyfriends and their father's new kidney machine - I think whatever fantasy he'd had about life at Penthouse died that day.

We did talk about books - A.N. Wilson claimed last week that Bron loathed books but I think that's unfair. He certainly had a great respect for Muriel Spark and V.S. Naipaul. But Wilson was probably right in saying that in other respects he was a total Philistine. My one attempt to expand his cultural horizons - I sent him a tape of Pulp's 'Common People' and urged him to listen to the lyrics - was an abject failure. When I asked a few weeks later if he'd listened to it, he said indignantly: "Certainly not!"

I was amazed last autumn, when he was already ill, to see him at the preview of the Apocalypse exhibition at the Royal Academy. Why, I wondered, would he want to spend some of his dwindling strength on an exhibition he was bound to loathe? I could get no clues from him, but when I mentioned it to Nancy Sladek, editor of the Literary Review, she said matter of factly: 'Well he wanted to see the rude video.' Oh of course!

When I rang round Bron's friends last Wednesday, many of them were in tears - Naim Attallah said he had been crying all day; Sladek could barely speak. Everyone knew he was very ill but still his death came as a shock.

The first signs that he was seriously ill came last summer - he lost an awful lot of weight and then collapsed at the judging of the Literary Review poetry prize. He managed to make it to the prizegiving lunch where Muriel Spark presented the award but he was obviously not on good form and gave a rather tetchy speech. Then he wrote a Spectator Diary in which he complained that everyone kept asking if he was dying and rambled pessimistically about why anyone should ever be remembered. That column was the first sign to me that his concentration was going - he had lost the great precision and clarity of thought that normally characterised every sentence. He also gave a regrettable interview (much resented by his family) to Deborah Ross of the Independent.

But the big shocker, for most of his friends, was the Bad Sex Awards party at the end of November when he looked terribly old and frail and retired immediately after Mick Jagger presented the award. That was his last public appearance - soon afterwards he went to hospital and then retreated to Combe Florey to die. Basically, his heart gave out, he was exhausted. He had been in fragile health, and probably in pain, for much of his adult life though he never spoke of it. On the last day, Tuesday, several of his oldest friends went down to Combe Florey to see him - A.N. Wilson and Richard Ingrams, Nancy Sladek and Sir Vidia and Lady Naipaul.

The future of the Literary Review must now seem doubtful. Naim Attallah insists he wants it to continue, because Bron wanted it to continue. Sladek, a Czech heiress educated at Heathfield and in Switzerland, has been effectively running it for five years. But it is a loss-making venture dependent on a handful of private benefactors - Sir Tim Rice, Sir John Paul Getty, Lord Hanson - to pay the bills. Attallah supported the magazine single-handed for 14 years but lost £2.4m on it and eventually asked Bron to rustle up more backers. But whether they were supporting Bron personally, or the magazine, remains to be seen.

Naim says the magazine only loses about £50,000 a year, and could break even or even make a profit if it had someone a bit more commercially clued-up than Bron in charge. But on the other hand, it never paid its contributors realistic fees - there must be many like me who were happy to write occasional pieces for Bron but would not normally thrill to the prospect of £50 for a thousand words. (I banked my cheques which was considered bad form - true devotees tore them up.)

Bron's cleverness was to get enough 'name' writers to make the magazine look authoritative, while also giving great freedom to young unknown writers to try their hands at reviewing. In fact it was a wonderful showcase for new talents, and many (including our own Kate Kellaway and Laura Cumming) launched their careers there.

Bron's devotion to the Literary Review puzzled some of his friends. But he loved having an office in Soho and the Academy Club next door, and an ever-changing cast of 'slaves' to do the office chores until such time as they either got disgruntled or graduated to the payroll. There were always long lunches, and friends dropping in, and occasional games of bridge, and jokes and laughter and conviviality. I suppose what he provided was a sort of drop-in centre for journalists, especially refugees from Wapping or Canary Wharf who had forgotten, if they ever knew, that journalism was meant to be fun. We face a much grimmer world without him - I fear the prigs and puritans and Polly Toynbees have won.

webTitle: President Bush pledges civility and compassion

fields.headline: President Bush pledges civility and compassion
fields.standfirst:
They poured in from the prairies and the plains to see Dubya take the oath as 43rd chief

The Bush Files
fields.trailText: 21 January 2001: They poured in from the prairies and the plains to see Dubya take the oath as 43rd chief, reports Ed Vulliamy in Washington.
fields.body:
George W.Bush punched the cold air with the palm of his right hand as he took the 35-word presidential oath on a freezing, rainswept Capitol Hill yesterday - concluding America's longest and most bitter election and launching the country on a new epoch.

Washington was invaded by hundreds of thousands of people, up for the first and only time from the prairies and plains to reclaim power for the Republican Party, and end the epoch of Bill Clinton.

Bush's eyes filled as he listened to the singing of 'America the Beautiful', before taking the pledge written by Thomas Jefferson - to which George Washington added the words, 'So help me God' - with a subdued Bill Clinton listening hard and Bush's father, George the First, shedding a visible tear.

The oath was administered by the man credited with having got Bush on to the podium in the first place, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, William Rehnquist.

As Bush descended from it, unseen by the crowds, he fulfilled his first presidential duty: receipt from a Pentagon official of a black brief case containing America's nuclear weapons codes, which only he is supposed to know.

In his inauguration address, with an attempted invocation of the rhetoric for which John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan are recalled, Bush invited the American people to be 'citizens, not spectators' in the nation under his navigation. He said: 'What you do is as important as anything government does. I ask you to seek a common good beyond your comfort; to defend needed reforms against easy attacks; to serve your nation, beginning with your neighbour.'

'I ask you to be citizens. Citizens, not spectators. Citizens, not subjects. Responsible citizens, building communities of service and a nation of character.'

He promised a 'new commitment to live out our nation's promise through civility, courage, compassion and character'.

As the curtain fell on the Clinton era, so did the sub-zero temperatures, the sweet notes of 'Shenandoah', sung by the choir of Louisville, Kentucky, drifting through the sleet.

In an unprecedented twist of history, Bush, the forty-third President of the United States, arrived at the White House from church for coffee and biscuits served by the man who defeated his father in 1992 and the man he had in turn beaten last year, Al Gore.

Clinton's namesake Thomas Jefferson established the etiquette of a peaceful transition of power, and at least they all spoke to one another, unlike Hoover and Eisenhower. The only 'frostiness' reported by insiders was between Clinton and Gore.

As Bush departed for the Hill, President Clinton left him the customary handwritten note on the desk in the Oval Office, and there was another for his wife Laura from Hillary. Many of their staff, however, left sticky chewing gum under theirs.

It was a ceremony across which other historic echoes sounded: Bush's father - the second President to see his son into high office - revisited his own inauguration, his wife Barbara shedding a moved tear as the limousines carrying both husband and son pulled up beneath the dome. Bush senior had jokily asked for a seat near the back so that no one would see him crying with emotion.

For a nation born from throwing off the chains of monarchy, the inauguration is traditionally elegant. And the lavish extravagance of yesterday's event spoke volumes: $35 million-worth of pomp paid for by roughly the same people who coughed up for the Bush campaign.

Around the new President, some 700,000 adoring Republican fans descended on the capital to mingle with squads of angry demonstrators carrying placards reading: 'Hail to the Thief'. Bush became the first President to run a gauntlet of protest on his coronation day, but the antis were easily swamped by the pros.

It was like a mighty wave crashing ashore - an invasion from the prairies and middle America, a restoration to recapture the capital which they regarded as illegitimately kidnapped from them for eight long years.

They were not only identifiable, they were like bulls in a china shop. The usually hushed tunnels of the Washington metro turned into a heaving mass of cowboy hats, eel-skin boots and crocodile formations of ecstatic schoolgirls with tooth braces.

At Union Station, into which trains ploughed through the driving, freezing rain, the crowds swarmed and lined up for hours in pursuit of badges sporting the new President's face. Choirs of scantily-clad ladies sang from the lobby steps, brass bands dressed in cock-hatted uniforms of the 1776 rebellion blew patriotic tunes.

Washington heaved with the steam of body heat as they gawped at the memorials, took a million photographs and jammed the Mall. For the Matthews family of Shawnee, Oklahoma, this was the first and only time they had left - and ever expected to leave - their home state. A joiner, Jeff Matthews had spent his life savings and all his frequent flyer miles to take himself, his wife Wendy and daughters Annie and Maud to Washington.

'George Bush is a very great man,' said Wendy, 'and he had brought our dreams comes true'.

Long before dawn yesterday, crowds in from Kansas, Colorado and Montana crammed onto trains to the Mall, to take their positions along the railings and sidewalks. 'Shame on you, sinner!' shouted one man at a group of punks assembled in the morning darkness with different intentions. 'Fuck you!' retorted the boys.

The final curtain on the Clinton era fell bitter and hard. The President had been sleeping only one or two hours a night in order to savour every waking minute of his last days in the world's most prestigious tied cottage, which he had come to love as his home more than most of his 41 predecessors.

As the Texans invaded, so an entire generation of Clinton officials left. All Friday, they had been sending emails to contacts and friends, detailing their post-administration particulars, some unable even to remain in town yesterday.

At a party of outgoing Treasury officials on Friday night, Larry Lindsey's team danced to techno music at a flat near Dupont Circle and laughed without mirth about how they had stuck chewing gum under the desks bequeathed to their unwelcome successors.

An era of scandal had come to its official close at the eleventh hour with a deal between the President and independent counsel Robert Ray which officially concluded the Lewinsky affair. It was as though a mighty storm had evaporated suddenly into nothing: a manoeuvre which on any other weekend would have captivated the world, but which now passed like a gust of winter wind.

The outgoing President promised America that he would work until the 'last minute of the last day', but no one thought he meant it literally. But he did: Bill Clinton was in the Oval Office, even as the cleaners were working their way through the White House.

He issued his final pardons, obliterating the criminal records of, notably, Patti Hearst, the magazine heiress-cum-guerilla, his brother Roger, convicted on drugs charges, and Susan MacDougal, a blast from the now distant Whitewater past.

Notable for their absence from the pardons list, however, were Leonard Peltier, Native American activist convicted of killing two FBI agents, Webster Hubble, former colleague at Hillary's legal firm, and junk bond tycoon Michael Milken.

As Bush took his oath - administered by Rehnquist of the Supreme Court, credited with having seized the Presidency for him - Clinton headed for Andrews Air Force base to take a Marine chopper to his new home in New York.

He asked the pilot to take a brief detour: a single, farewell circle over the White House.

Bush's eyes filled as he listened to the singing of 'America the Beautiful', before taking the pledge written by Thomas Jefferson - to which George Washington added the words, 'So help me God' - with a subdued Bill Clinton listening hard and Bush's father, George the First, shedding a visible tear. The oath was administered by the man credited with having got Bush on to the podium in the first place, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, William Rehnquist. As Bush descended from it, unseen by the crowds, he fulfilled his first presidential duty: receipt from a Pentagon official of a black brief case containing America's nuclear weapons codes, which only he is supposed to know. In his inauguration address, with an attempted invocation of the rhetoric for which John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan are recalled, Bush invited the American people to be 'citizens, not spectators' in the nation under his navigation. He said: 'What you do is as important as anything government does. I ask you to seek a common good beyond your comfort; to defend needed reforms against easy attacks; to serve your nation, beginning with your neighbour.' 'I ask you to be citizens. Citizens, not spectators. Citizens, not subjects. Responsible citizens, building communities of service and a nation of character.' He promised a 'new commitment to live out our nation's promise through civility, courage, compassion and character'. As the curtain fell on the Clinton era, so did the sub-zero temperatures, the sweet notes of 'Shenandoah', sung by the choir of Louisville, Kentucky, drifting through the sleet. In an unprecedented twist of history, Bush, the forty-third President of the United States, arrived at the White House from church for coffee and biscuits served by the man who defeated his father in 1992 and the man he had in turn beaten last year, Al Gore. Clinton's namesake Thomas Jefferson established the etiquette of a peaceful transition of power, and at least they all spoke to one another, unlike Hoover and Eisenhower. The only 'frostiness' reported by insiders was between Clinton and Gore. As Bush departed for the Hill, President Clinton left him the customary handwritten note on the desk in the Oval Office, and there was another for his wife Laura from Hillary. Many of their staff, however, left sticky chewing gum under theirs. It was a ceremony across which other historic echoes sounded: Bush's father - the second President to see his son into high office - revisited his own inauguration, his wife Barbara shedding a moved tear as the limousines carrying both husband and son pulled up beneath the dome. Bush senior had jokily asked for a seat near the back so that no one would see him crying with emotion. For a nation born from throwing off the chains of monarchy, the inauguration is traditionally elegant. And the lavish extravagance of yesterday's event spoke volumes: $35 million-worth of pomp paid for by roughly the same people who coughed up for the Bush campaign. Around the new President, some 700,000 adoring Republican fans descended on the capital to mingle with squads of angry demonstrators carrying placards reading: 'Hail to the Thief'. Bush became the first President to run a gauntlet of protest on his coronation day, but the antis were easily swamped by the pros. It was like a mighty wave crashing ashore - an invasion from the prairies and middle America, a restoration to recapture the capital which they regarded as illegitimately kidnapped from them for eight long years. They were not only identifiable, they were like bulls in a china shop. The usually hushed tunnels of the Washington metro turned into a heaving mass of cowboy hats, eel-skin boots and crocodile formations of ecstatic schoolgirls with tooth braces. At Union Station, into which trains ploughed through the driving, freezing rain, the crowds swarmed and lined up for hours in pursuit of badges sporting the new President's face. Choirs of scantily-clad ladies sang from the lobby steps, brass bands dressed in cock-hatted uniforms of the 1776 rebellion blew patriotic tunes. Washington heaved with the steam of body heat as they gawped at the memorials, took a million photographs and jammed the Mall. For the Matthews family of Shawnee, Oklahoma, this was the first and only time they had left - and ever expected to leave - their home state. A joiner, Jeff Matthews had spent his life savings and all his frequent flyer miles to take himself, his wife Wendy and daughters Annie and Maud to Washington. 'George Bush is a very great man,' said Wendy, 'and he had brought our dreams comes true'. Long before dawn yesterday, crowds in from Kansas, Colorado and Montana crammed onto trains to the Mall, to take their positions along the railings and sidewalks. 'Shame on you, sinner!' shouted one man at a group of punks assembled in the morning darkness with different intentions. 'Fuck you!' retorted the boys. The final curtain on the Clinton era fell bitter and hard. The President had been sleeping only one or two hours a night in order to savour every waking minute of his last days in the world's most prestigious tied cottage, which he had come to love as his home more than most of his 41 predecessors. As the Texans invaded, so an entire generation of Clinton officials left. All Friday, they had been sending emails to contacts and friends, detailing their post-administration particulars, some unable even to remain in town yesterday. At a party of outgoing Treasury officials on Friday night, Larry Lindsey's team danced to techno music at a flat near Dupont Circle and laughed without mirth about how they had stuck chewing gum under the desks bequeathed to their unwelcome successors. An era of scandal had come to its official close at the eleventh hour with a deal between the President and independent counsel Robert Ray which officially concluded the Lewinsky affair. It was as though a mighty storm had evaporated suddenly into nothing: a manoeuvre which on any other weekend would have captivated the world, but which now passed like a gust of winter wind. The outgoing President promised America that he would work until the 'last minute of the last day', but no one thought he meant it literally. But he did: Bill Clinton was in the Oval Office, even as the cleaners were working their way through the White House. He issued his final pardons, obliterating the criminal records of, notably, Patti Hearst, the magazine heiress-cum-guerilla, his brother Roger, convicted on drugs charges, and Susan MacDougal, a blast from the now distant Whitewater past. Notable for their absence from the pardons list, however, were Leonard Peltier, Native American activist convicted of killing two FBI agents, Webster Hubble, former colleague at Hillary's legal firm, and junk bond tycoon Michael Milken. As Bush took his oath - administered by Rehnquist of the Supreme Court, credited with having seized the Presidency for him - Clinton headed for Andrews Air Force base to take a Marine chopper to his new home in New York. He asked the pilot to take a brief detour: a single, farewell circle over the White House.

webTitle: Bishopstrow House, Warminster

fields.headline: Bishopstrow House, Warminster
fields.trailText: Bishopstrow House is a classic country hotel, formed from an old Georgian mansion, and set in vast grounds outside Warminster, near Bath.
fields.body:
Sounds like a vicarage. What is it?
Bishopstrow House is a classic country hotel, formed from an old Georgian mansion, and set in vast grounds outside Warminster, near Bath. There are tennis courts, a gym, sauna, croquet, a children's playroom and a large, luxurious Greco-Roman swimming pool that would have satisfied Caligula. There are also extensive grounds - reached by a special tunnel under the B3414 - that include a stretch along the river Wylye, where you can fish for trout or wander among the gazebos.

And inside?
Plush. Particularly impressive is the front hall which has been converted into an excellent wood-panelled bar, replete with an impressive range of malts and armagnacs and a log fire. Rooms range from luxurious suites to compact top-floor apartments.

Another stuffed shirt, swanky hotel then?
Nothing could be further from the truth. Bishopstrow may look old and rambling but its clientele is young, dress is casual, and there is no intimidating hush in any of the public rooms. This is a bustling, chirpy sort of place with the emphasis on friendly, efficient service. We arrived late with three hungry, tired children. They were immediately proffered children's menus, even though these were only supposed to apply to early supper sittings. As to the food, that was first class: roast scallops, grilled asparagus, rack of lamb and sticky toffee pudding. Breakfasts are equally impressive, and you can eat while watching your children cavort in the swimming pool next door. No better way to start the day.

And the price tag?
Suites cost from £295 a night, standard rooms from £185. However, the hotel offers all sorts of mid-week spa-packages which are worth checking out by phone.

Bishopstrow House , Warminster, Wiltshire BA12 9HH (01985 212312, fax 01985 216769). Email: enquiries@bishopstrow.co.uk.

webTitle: The Observer Profile: Eric Hobsbawm

fields.headline: The lion of the Left
fields.standfirst: The indomitable left-wing historian is embarking on his most ambitious project yet - the story of his own remarkable life
fields.trailText: The indomitable left-wing historian is embarking on his most ambitious project yet - the story of his own remarkable life.
fields.body:
It is a little over half a century since Eric Hobsbawm, the intuitive pattern-maker of modern history, gave his first lecture at Birkbeck College in London. When he returns tomorrow evening to deliver the college's 175th anniversary talk, there will be something of a sense of a circle closing, and ironies that will not be lost on him.

The subject of Hobsbawm's address is 'Birkbeck and the Left', but five decades ago his radical socialism almost kept him out of university life altogether. A lifelong member of the Communist Party, he suggests that he got in to academia 'under the wire'; a year later, after the Berlin Airlift in 1948, his story, he believes, would have been markedly different. As it was, partly because of his political affiliations, he did not get promotion to a professorship until 1970.

He has never needed any lessons, however, in the virtues of playing a long game. His landmark trilogy on the nineteenth century synthesised myriad competing social swells into great epochal waves: the Ages of Revolution, and of Capital, and of Empire. He has characterised his own time and tide as the Age of Extremes, the tempestuous force of which conspired to deposit him on the shore of the present as the Last Marxist; still, he refuses to believe himself beached. One old friend observes: 'Eric has long ago worked out his precise intellectual position and he's quite happy there, thank you very much.'

Talking to Hobsbawm now, at 83, his mind still in edgy overdrive, his body language made for compelling awkwardness, you have a strong sense of the history that he has measured on his own pulse. He was born in Alexandria to a middle-class Jewish family in the year of the October Revolution, 1917, and he has lived to see the full tragic narrative of the Bolshevik utopia unfold. It is characteristic of him that he remains sentimental about its origins, but clear-eyed over its outcome.

Before the war, his family moved first to Vienna and then to Berlin, where Hobsbawm came of age. He says he still recognises in himself the kernel of the 14-year-old boy who read on a newspaper board the headline announcing the accession of the Third Reich. 'Anybody who saw Hitler's rise happen first-hand could not have helped but be shaped by it, politically,' he says now. 'This is still there in me. That boy is still somewhere inside, always will be.'

Hobsbawm's parents both died during the Depression and he and his sister were taken in by his uncle, who worked for a Hollywood firm in Berlin. Almost immediately, the family moved to England, following his uncle's job, and for three years, Hobsbawm experienced what he has rarely felt since - that history was happening without him. He was bored and dislocated by the transition from the intensities of pre-war Germany to the complacencies of a south London grammar school. It was not until he got to Cambridge that he sensed he could carry on with the conversations that he'd started in Berlin.

Hobsbawm has defined and explained the progress of the last century as mankind learning to 'live in expectation of apocalypse'. He responded to those intimations in himself by joining the Communist Party. He would, he says, certainly have become a member earlier, but that his uncle was 'rather stiff' on the subject. 'He used to say, "You kids don't know what you are letting yourselves in for".' Hobsbawm smiles now, seeing his life unspooling in that prophecy. 'He was right, of course.'

You could imagine that the gangling young émigré, uprooted and orphaned, might have been attracted to the certainties of the party as a surrogate family and consequently begin to explain the strength of the attachment as a powerfully emotional as well as an intellectual one. Looking back, he suggests that 'probably that kind of security was one of the appeals', but also that he 'never felt short of family... it was more that you just felt things were going to pieces, and you felt it needed a revolution to re-create it, to put it back together'.

After the war, these political commitments no longer seemed quite so innocent. Hobsbawm applied for a series of Oxbridge jobs, and was 'turned down right, left and centre' He fetched up instead, happily, at Birkbeck, and found inspiration in the radicalism of J.D. Bernal, the maverick Marxist and physicist, 'by far the brightest man there, who looked like a sea captain with long, bushy hair, and who walked, as he said, like the pobble who had no toes'. In some ways, Hobsbawm still views the world as the semi-detached, cold warrior he was then, or at least the legacy of that rhetoric continues to inflect his memories. 'Of course, physics tended to be very Left,' he will say, recalling old common-room divides, 'and obviously so did crystallography'; or, speaking, of one mathematician colleague: 'I'm not sure if he didn't become a Maoist at about that time...'

One of his friends of that era at Birkbeck, Barbara Hardy, now Professor of English, remembers Hobsbawm in his late thirties, as 'very sexy and amusing, and wonderfully candid'. Lectures at Birkbeck, whose student body is part-time, are in the evenings and the challenge among the faculty was to keep its audience awake in the graveyard slot between eight and nine. Hobsbawm, by all accounts, achieved this effortlessly and sustained his intellectual energy after hours. 'When Eric was around there was always conversation,' recalls Hardy, suggesting that so much sherry was drunk in those days that she can now no longer look a glass of it in the eye.

There would be sudden jaunts to Ronnie Scott's (Hobsbawm was at the time an impassioned jazz critic for the New Statesman) or on, one occasion, she recalls, to listen to Billy Graham. 'Eric always wanted to be seeing something new,' she says, 'or to know something new. He was always fully engaged.'

Throughout this period, Hobsbawm maintained his commitment to communism, a fact which some of his colleagues, including Hardy, found, at best, mysterious. Though he never proselytised unlike many of his comrades, Hobsbawm did not leave the party after 1956. His concession was to argue that even the most monolithic members had, given events, to 'reconsider the equation: party = life'.

Hobsbawm appears to have resolved that equation for himself in part by pursuing a more limited kind of personal utopia. His standing in Central Europe and Latin America as an 'important revisionist' allowed him the freedom to travel and establish a network of friends, who later became regular visitors to his home on the flanks of Hampstead Heath. There were - are - dinners at which British intellectuals could find themselves outnumbered by German publishers, Czech historians and Latin American novelists. The driving force of north London's most distinctive Central European salon is Marlene, Hobsbawm's second wife, who, friends say, 'provides this remarkable gregarious atmosphere around him'. One regular recipient of this hospitality, Neal Ascherson, says: 'Eric is still very much a Fifties bohemian, in a way. He loves, say, the idea of some weird drink brought back from Slobodnia in an odd -shaped bottle. You have to watch yourself or you are falling over before the food arrives.'

In part, this stubborn microcosm of conviviality explains why Hobsbawm has kept the faith. As the walls were coming down in 1989, Hobsbawm was often asked to explain his continued commitment. Typically, he replied both as a conviction historian - 'I think the movement has achieved at least one absolutely major thing, and that includes the Soviet Union, namely the defeat of fascism,' - and as a rose-tinted loyalist: 'I don't wish to be untrue to my past or comrades of mine, a lot of them dead, some of them killed by their own side, whom I've admired [as] models to follow, in their unselfishness.'

The end of the Cold War and the new public relations-led world order that followed brought to a close Hobsbawm's particular influence over more domestic battles, too. In the Eighties, he had become the unofficial philosopher and intellectual conscience of the Labour Party as it fought for its soul and its future under Michael Foot and Neil Kinnock. But if he despairs of the present government, he tends to keep his counsel or employs a Zhou Enlai defence that it is 'too early to tell'. Though he concedes that Blair's populist anti-intellectualism 'gets on his wick', he can laugh when he says he 'finds it hard to envisage not voting Labour, put it that way'.

If Hobsbawm is saddened by the way things have turned out, he has enough professional detachment not to let it show. Having lived to tell the lucid tales of the past two centuries, he approaches the new one, the subject of his most recent, prophetic, book, with few grounds for optimism, but with great vigour. One of the antidotes to discontent for Hobsbawm has always been industry and he shows no signs of slacking. He regrets that recently he has had to cut back on his globetrotting - only 'a few trips to Europe and South America' - in order to concentrate on writing his autobiography. He hopes, he says, with some understatement, that it will describe 'different countries, what I know of 'em, how I got to know 'em, that kind of stuff'. Though he'll never make a blurb writer, you guess that, for some at least, it will be the essential Baedeker to the century.
