webTitle: Help - I'm wary about shopping online

fields.headline: Help - I'm wary about shopping online
fields.standfirst: About nine out of 10 people are put off shopping online because they do not know what to do if something goes wrong, says research by credit card firm Goldfish. But your rights are basically the same as they would be if you were shopping on the high street.
fields.trailText: About nine out of 10 people are put off shopping online because they do not know what to do if something goes wrong, says research by credit card firm Goldfish. But your rights are basically the same as they would be if you were shopping on the high street.
fields.body:
'Don't panic,' says Peter Neden of Goldfish, which spells out consumer rights on its site, www.goldfishguide.com. 'Your rights still apply, and if you can accept the internet as simply a different medium for buying products, like mail order or a shop, there's no reason why you shouldn't enjoy shopping on the web.'

You have a right to your money back if you do not get the goods, or they are faulty. But many dotcoms are running out of cash, and some are going bust. Being a creditor of an insolvent company can mean waiting months to get only a small proportion of what you are owed.

The Department of Trade and Industry's Consumer Protection (Distance Selling) Regulations 2000 says shoppers 'must be given clear information about the goods or services offered', and that 'after making a purchase the consumer must be sent confirmation'. There is a one-week cooling-off period. (See www.dti.gov.uk)

If an e-tailer goes under owing you money, goods or services, you should hear from the liquidator. If you spent more than £100 and paid by credit card, you should be covered under the Consumer Credit Act, and the card company should make you a refund.

To avoid difficult situations, consider these tips:

 Use established businesses. (Low costs make it easy for cowboys and people with silly ideas to start up sites.)

 Ensure the site gives its name, postal address, prices, delivery arrangements and the right to cancel the order.

 Be suspicious of sites which do not display a business address and telephone number.

 Try to buy from UK traders if you are worried. It should be easier to enforce your consumer rights.

 Ensure the site is secure - it should have a padlock icon - especially if giving credit or debit card details.

fields.headline: Magical realism ... and fakery
fields.standfirst: The ailing Nobel Laureate is writing the definitive account of his life, reports  Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: The ailing Nobel Laureate is writing the definitive account of his life, reports Vanessa Thorpe.
fields.body:
What is the true story of a life? Gabriel García Márquez, the man who for many is the greatest living storyteller, has always understood that fantasy is a big part of the way we explain what happens to us. Up until now, though, García Márquez's hands have been firmly on the reins of his own stories. True, he introduced the anarchic concept of 'magic realism' with his novels Love in the Time of Cholera and One Hundred Years of Solitude , but his surreal imagery just served to underline who was in charge.

In the past few weeks, however, a story has slipped away from the great man's control. An email has been circulating the English-speaking world which claims to contain his final words of farewell to his readers. A short letter accompanied by several plausible lines of lyrical verse has had García Márquez fans across the globe convinced that he was speaking to them for the last time.

'This is possibly, sadly, one of the last gifts to humanity from a true master,' the introductory note read, going on to claim that the 'truly moving' email had been sent out to the author's closest friends in its original Spanish.

It was already known that the Nobel Laureate had been ill for some months with cancer and that he was writing in private. The disease had first been diagnosed in July 1999 when he was admitted to hospital in his native Colombia, suffering from exhaustion. As a result, for many recipients the finality of the words in the email seemed apt and rather beautiful.

'If for an instant God were to forget that I am rag doll and gifted me with a piece of life,' it read, 'possibly I wouldn't say all that I think, but rather I would think of all that I say. I would value things, not for their worth but for what they mean. I would sleep little, dream more, understanding that for each minute we close our eyes we lose 60 seconds of light.'

In a further effort to convince, the valedictory lines went on to mention a Latin American poet, Benedetti from Uruguay, and the popular Catalan singer, Serrat. It ended with the words: 'I have learnt that a man has the right to look down on another only when he has to help the other get to his feet. From you I have learnt so many things, but in truth they won't be of much use, for when I keep them within this suitcase, unhappily shall I be dying.'

The writer has now denied authorship of the email through his Spanish agent, but rumours of his ill-health have persisted. Why has he been closeted in his Mexican home for so long, and what can we expect to hear of him next?

The Observer can reveal that García Márquez has been writing the definitive work of his life - and it has much more of the intellectual flavour and dry humour of his previous work than the email. The new project is an autobiography and its theme is the way we mis-remember and re-tell our own stories. In it, using a liberal dose of hokum and his own brand of special effects, García Márquez sets out a version of his life for readers to remember him by.

'From what I have seen, this is going to be very funny and fascinating. But it should be taken with a pinch of salt,' said Michael Wood of Princeton University, the author of a book on Love in the Time of Cholera. 'It has all his usual exaggerations, and it should perhaps be viewed as a study of the way we all mythologise our family histories.'

The tricks that memory plays, the writer argues, actually shape our lives. 'What matters in life is not what happens to you but what you remember and how you remember it,' García Márquez writes at the opening of his personal account.

Further on he demonstrates the point with an anecdote. He says that when his parents were married in 1926, his mother yearned for the little telegraph office house where she had spent her honeymoon. García Márquez says he and his brothers and sisters were soon able to describe it 'room by room as if they had lived there'.

As he approached the age of 60, the writer finally travelled to the place to look at the house and found it 'was not at all like the one in my memory at all'. All the same, today he can 'never visualise it as it is, but rather as I constructed it, stone by stone, without seeing it, through my mother's nostalgia'.

The phoney farewell email, now thought to have been penned by an American prankster, does not stand up to comparison with these fresh passages from a master. 'Personally I was not convinced by the email, which people have been sending me for some while,' said Wood.

The real work of the 73-year-old author, as he draws towards the end of his life, is far more playful. Even the title of the new story, To Live So I Could Tell, gently teases the reader.

'This has at least three possible meanings,' says Wood. 'In one sense it means that he has survived and so he can tell; in another it means that he has lived only for telling stories. But, of course, it also means that he is now continuing to live simply to write this book.'

The work begins by telling the 'real' story that inspired Love in the Time of Cholera - the tale of how his socially unequal parents courted and eventually married.

'It tells the same tale, in a fanciful way again, but this time they don't have to wait for most of their lives before they can get together.'

All the dates and names in this autobiography seem to be correct, however, and García Márquez scholars can look forward to a factual record of the life of the author who befriended many statesmen, including Fidel Castro and Bill Clinton, as well as winning the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982.

While the completed autobiography is likely to prove a more accurate historical document than the fake email that fooled so many, fans can rest assured that Marquez's own version of his life will still contain some bright red herrings.

His real words ... and the fake farewell:

From the genuine forthcoming autobiography

'What matters in life is not what happens to you but what you remember and how you remember it.'

From the hoax email

'If for an instant God were to forget that I am rag doll and gifted me with a piece of life, possibly I wouldn't say all that I think, but rather I would think of all that I say. I would value things, not for their worth but for what they mean. I would sleep little, dream more, understanding that for each minute we close our eyes we lose sixty seconds of light.

'I would walk when others hold back, I would wake when others sleep. I would listen when others talk, and how I would enjoy a good chocolate ice cream! If God were to give me a piece of life, I would dress simply, throw myself face first into the sun, baring not only my body but also my soul. My God, if I had a heart, I would write my hate on ice, and wait for the sun to show. Over the stars I would paint with a Van Gogh dream a Benedetti poem, and a Serrat song would be the serenade I'd offer to the moon.'

webTitle: Tim Atkin: The dangers of typecasking

fields.headline: The dangers of typecasking
fields.standfirst: It's a case of once a plonk, always a plonk - unless you can shake off the 'Bulgaria' syndrome
fields.trailText: It's a case of once a plonk, always a plonk - unless you can shake off the 'Bulgaria' syndrome.
fields.body:
In the wine business, everyone's scared of the Bulgaria syndrome. This might sound like a two-bit thriller set in an Eastern European nuclear power station, but there's nothing fictional about it. The syndrome refers to a country that started out selling loads of plonk, then discovered it had been typecast. Bulgaria has tried to burnish its image with 'heritage', new oak barrels, Australian flying winemakers, flange bottles. But the end result has been depressingly consistent: try to charge more than £3.49 for a bottle of Bulgarian Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot or Chardonnay and consumers start edging towards the door. Producers in Bulgaria must feel like character actors trapped in the same part in a long-running sitcom.

The New World country that has most to fear from the Bulgaria syndrome is South Africa. When liberal Brits decided, in the early 90s, that it was OK to consume Cape produce, sales of South African wine took off. What people bought was inexpensive and (a nice irony, this) almost entirely white. Made from second-division grape varieties, South African white wine became the stuff of bring (and invariably abandon) a bottle parties.

The world's sixth-largest producer still suffers from a cheap, not-so-cheerful image. Until recently, its 'fine' wines were vastly inferior to the stuff coming out of Australia, Chile and New Zealand. I once had dinner with an Afrikaner wine producer who believed that willpower alone would be enough to sell his baked Bordeaux blend at £14.99 a bottle in the UK. He's still looking for an importer.

There have always been a handful of stars in South Africa. But the vast majority of Cape was churned out by umambitious cooperatives, typified by the ultra-conservative KWV. It still is, to a large degree, but the list of good to excellent producers has grown exponentially in the last three years. I used to look forward to a line-up of South African wines with all the enthusiasm I'd bring to a Christmas dip in the Serpentine, but recent tastings have been a revelation. The wines being produced by the likes of L'Avenir, Vergelegen, Clos Malverne, Buitenverwachting, Graham Beck, Veenwouden, Steenberg, Springfield Estate and Yonder Hill have added another dimension to the South African scene.

Charles Back, who makes a string of brilliantly individual wines at Fairview, argues that South Africa has 'the potential to make world-class wines'. The problem, he believes, is twofold: the country's grape mix, still dominated by more than 70 per cent of white varieties in a world that wants to drink reds, and the power of the cooperatives. 'We've been playing catch-up for 10 years. Everyone is talking about planting the "big five"- Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Shiraz, Sauvignon Blanc and Chardonnay - but we've got to take risks by planting Zinfandel, Mourvèdre, Tannat and Malbec.'

He's right, but only up to a point. All of a sudden, South Africa has begun to compete with the rest of the world across a range of styles, be they classic, modern or off the wall. It could still go down with a bad case of Bulgaria syndrome, especially if the bottom falls out of the white-wine market, but I reckon it's well on the way to discovering an antidote.

webTitle: Nigel Slater: Reasons to be cheerful

fields.headline: Reasons to be cheerful
fields.standfirst: The January table: rhubarb, artichokes and silky sea greens are guaranteed to lift your spirits
fields.trailText: The January table: rhubarb, artichokes and silky sea greens are guaranteed to lift your spirits.
fields.body:
The farmers and their brave pickers are still managing to find us something worth eating in the freezing mud. Even now they are coming up with vegetables in good nick, as anyone who has been to market in the last week or so cannot have missed. Fabulous kale, its frilly leaves deep green or mauve; crisp and juicy carrots; stonking parsnips that roast sweetly, and Brussels sprouts, still small and tight despite the heavy rain that usually bloats them, are all there for the taking. It would be crazy to pass up such cracking stuff for a plastic tray of Zimbabwean mangetout.

The fishermen are netting good things for us, too, though understandably at a price. I pay up gladly, in the knowledge that nothing would get me on a boat in January unless it was packed to the gills with obliging stewards and merry widows bound for the Caribbean. Anyone who can fill a fishmonger's slab at this time of year deserves a big hand. Fat scallops, shimmering mackerel and some memorable Manx kippers have all ended up on my table this week - though I could also have had a bit of lemon sole, and the halibut looked just as tempting.

I spotted a box of fresh sea lettuce at Borough Market (near London Bridge station, SE1) last Saturday and pounced on it. I have been slowly but surely developing a taste for this and other seaweeds. A worrying trend, but there you are. If the thought of all that calcium, iron, magnesium and vitamins A and B are not enough to tempt (and they aren't), I should mention that much of it has a pleasing, silky feel in the mouth. Emerald-green sea lettuce ( Ulva lactua ) and ruby-red dulse ( Palmaria palmata ) are the most palatable 'sea vegetables' for the first-timer. The aptly named sea spaghetti ( Himanthalia elongata ) is for me still too reminiscent of the stuff one or other of my brothers used to chase me round the beach at Bournemouth with.

Think of these fresh, lightly salted seaweeds as brightly coloured spring greens with a faint taste of the North Sea. I make a soup that involves nothing more than adding a small handful of soaked and shredded sea lettuce or dulse to a bowl of steaming vegetable stock. It cooks in a minute. Seasoned only with pepper and plenty of lemon juice, it makes a clean-tasting and mildly invigorating lunch.

Soup is big right now - witness the soup shops opening up in the high street and the newfangled packaging in the supermarket chiller (tins are so yesterday). Warming bowl of the month must surely be artichoke. The knobbly pink Jerusalems around at the moment will, when simmered for half an hour with a little stock then blitzed in a blender, produce a velvet-textured broth of the finest Armani beige. Season it with lemon juice and lots of finely chopped spanking-fresh parsley. It is worth remembering that the red variety tend to be less sweet.

This is not the time for fresh herbs, but rosemary is still proud and, even without the sunshine that herbs need so badly, is surprisingly fragrant. A robust weekday supper might be some mature lamb chops with olive oil, well-crushed garlic and a crumbling of rosemary leaves, grilled till the fat has charred here and there. If you cannot face peeling potatoes to go with them when you come home, then try whizzing drained tinned chickpeas in the food processor with a little olive oil and a pinch of paprika. Hardly winter food - such ingredients reek of summer - but you can have one stew too many, if you ask me.

Pulses is not a word that lifts the spirits, but this is dried-bean weather, to be sure. I found whole broad beans the other day and made a winter salad by soaking them overnight then boiling them till they were completely tender (a good 40 minutes), then popping them from their skins. I dressed them while they were still warm with a mustardy French dressing, then stirred in some soured cream and chopped flat-leaf parsley and ate them piled it in big, lumpy spoonfuls on to soft ciabatta.

I almost dare not say the word salad, especially with most of the decent leaves coming in from elsewhere right now, but somehow I still want something leafy on a big white plate every evening. Simple salads don't have to be green. It is just that we tend to think of them that way. Red trevise or, more correctly, rosso di Treviso, is an exquisitely hued chicory of burgundy and cream, and has been in my salad twice this week, along with some earthy-tasting carmine-veined baby chard. It is not hard to find and has a tenderness about it that makes a change from the surfeit of rustic crunch we have been given to eating over the last months.

Winter always sees me making dressings that have a bit more punch to them. The mustard pot comes out more regularly and I often use a bit more vinegar, too, but this is also the time of year I crumble up salty blue cheeses such as Roquefort or Spanish Picos de Europa into crunch salads such as those with white leaves. Anyone for a crunchy chicory, walnut and blue-cheese salad with a thick and creamy, mustardy dressing?

Cheeses for January still include the voluptuous Vacherin in its wooden box. Molton curds hide under its golden crust, as if this cheese was secretly trying to turn itself into soup. Never has that well-worn line 'Serve with a piece of crusty bread' been quite so appropriate. But there's more. Many of the artisan-made British cheeses are eating well right now. Mrs Appleby's Cheshire - so mild, so nutty - and just the thing to go with the last of nuts in the fruit bowl is as good now as I have ever tasted it.

The food fashionistas decree that shaving Parmesan over your salad is a no-no, but what would they know about good eating? Try, if you will, the lovely pale English Tyning instead (Neal's Yard will do it by mail order - call 0161 831 7875). It has a similar texture to a young Pecorino or Parmesan, but with a milkier, fresher taste. Best salad of the week was the one in which I pared wafer-thin slices of Tyning with a vegetable peeler and tossed them with watercress, equally thin slices of smooth white fennel, and lots of coarsely chopped parsley with a textbook vinaigrette (5 parts oil to 1 part vinegar, a little salt, pepper and mustard). Winter at its freshest.

The other morning (icy wind, frost on the hedges), I suddenly had an uncontrollable urge for a kipper. I will occasionally let slip my personal boycott against anything from the Isle of Man just to get a taste of its mild and moist smoked herring. Manx kippers are undyed and have a golden-brown glow rather than the Belisha-beacon orange of the boil-in-the-bag supermarket variety. You can cook them head down in a big jug of boiled water, but I grilled mine briefly instead, with pepper and a judicious bathing of butter. It is a once-a-year thing, this kipper urge, and I sometimes think the reason I don't cook them more often is simply the boarding-house breakfast pong that lingers on the stairs afterwards like the family spook.

Clear the air with a bowl of poached sweet-sharp rhubarb. Along with gooseberries and damsons, it is the fruit I look forward to most. There is no easier fruit to prepare: just chop the fine pale-pink stems into cork-sized lengths and pack them into a baking dish with the juice of an orange or two and a fine sprinkling of sugar. You really don't need much with the tender rose stems, and bake in a moderate oven for 20 minutes or so till it is soft and syrupy. There will tons of exquisite juice to sup, too. If you have never had it cold, try it chilled for breakfast without yogurt, cream or extra sugar. A startling and rather effective alarm call.

The doorstep drop of food companies anxious to plug their products has actually turned up a few goodies this month. Namely some stunning chutney from Tamarind. Unlike most commercial glops-in-a-jar, these are bright tasting and with an unsullied ingredient list. Check out the Tomato and cardamom and Carrot and Raisin for their clean, sweet flavours and up-front spice. The Date and chilli is deliciously dark and smoky. I stirred the tomato and carrot varieties into a bowl of plain boiled basmati for a spare and gentle supper. I should admit that this sucker also fell for the neat packaging.

Now if you don't fancy the artichokes I mentioned as a soup, then try them baked instead: you will need 500g or so of artichokes, about 12, and remember to give them a good scrub with a vegetable brush. Boil them in salted water for 15-20 minutes until they are almost tender. Drain and scrape off as much of the skin as you reasonably can, then slice thickly. Generously butter a small gratin dish and lay the artichokes in it, pouring in just enough stock (vegetable, chicken or even something from a cube) to come just over halfway up the slices. Season with a squeeze of lemon juice, some salt and black pepper - I also tuck in a bay leaf or two - then bake the artichokes for 30 minutes at 390 C/gas mark 5 until completely tender. Now slide your dish out of the oven and scatter with a thin layer of grated Parmesan, turn up the oven to 200 C/gas mark 6 and let them cook for a further 15 minutes or so till they are lightly crusted and blissfully soft within. Eat them, spooning the baking juices over, with cold ham or rare roast beef. Enough for 4 as a side dish.

This is not the time for fresh herbs, but rosemary is still proud and, even without the sunshine that herbs need so badly, is surprisingly fragrant. A robust weekday supper might be some mature lamb chops with olive oil, well-crushed garlic and a crumbling of rosemary leaves, grilled till the fat has charred here and there. If you cannot face peeling potatoes to go with them when you come home, then try whizzing drained tinned chickpeas in the food processor with a little olive oil and a pinch of paprika. Hardly winter food - such ingredients reek of summer - but you can have one stew too many, if you ask me. Pulses is not a word that lifts the spirits, but this is dried-bean weather, to be sure. I found whole broad beans the other day and made a winter salad by soaking them overnight then boiling them till they were completely tender (a good 40 minutes), then popping them from their skins. I dressed them while they were still warm with a mustardy French dressing, then stirred in some soured cream and chopped flat-leaf parsley and ate them piled it in big, lumpy spoonfuls on to soft ciabatta. I almost dare not say the word salad, especially with most of the decent leaves coming in from elsewhere right now, but somehow I still want something leafy on a big white plate every evening. Simple salads don't have to be green. It is just that we tend to think of them that way. Red trevise or, more correctly, rosso di Treviso, is an exquisitely hued chicory of burgundy and cream, and has been in my salad twice this week, along with some earthy-tasting carmine-veined baby chard. It is not hard to find and has a tenderness about it that makes a change from the surfeit of rustic crunch we have been given to eating over the last months. Winter always sees me making dressings that have a bit more punch to them. The mustard pot comes out more regularly and I often use a bit more vinegar, too, but this is also the time of year I crumble up salty blue cheeses such as Roquefort or Spanish Picos de Europa into crunch salads such as those with white leaves. Anyone for a crunchy chicory, walnut and blue-cheese salad with a thick and creamy, mustardy dressing? Cheeses for January still include the voluptuous Vacherin in its wooden box. Molton curds hide under its golden crust, as if this cheese was secretly trying to turn itself into soup. Never has that well-worn line 'Serve with a piece of crusty bread' been quite so appropriate. But there's more. Many of the artisan-made British cheeses are eating well right now. Mrs Appleby's Cheshire - so mild, so nutty - and just the thing to go with the last of nuts in the fruit bowl is as good now as I have ever tasted it. The food fashionistas decree that shaving Parmesan over your salad is a no-no, but what would they know about good eating? Try, if you will, the lovely pale English Tyning instead (Neal's Yard will do it by mail order - call 0161 831 7875). It has a similar texture to a young Pecorino or Parmesan, but with a milkier, fresher taste. Best salad of the week was the one in which I pared wafer-thin slices of Tyning with a vegetable peeler and tossed them with watercress, equally thin slices of smooth white fennel, and lots of coarsely chopped parsley with a textbook vinaigrette (5 parts oil to 1 part vinegar, a little salt, pepper and mustard). Winter at its freshest. The other morning (icy wind, frost on the hedges), I suddenly had an uncontrollable urge for a kipper. I will occasionally let slip my personal boycott against anything from the Isle of Man just to get a taste of its mild and moist smoked herring. Manx kippers are undyed and have a golden-brown glow rather than the Belisha-beacon orange of the boil-in-the-bag supermarket variety. You can cook them head down in a big jug of boiled water, but I grilled mine briefly instead, with pepper and a judicious bathing of butter. It is a once-a-year thing, this kipper urge, and I sometimes think the reason I don't cook them more often is simply the boarding-house breakfast pong that lingers on the stairs afterwards like the family spook. Clear the air with a bowl of poached sweet-sharp rhubarb. Along with gooseberries and damsons, it is the fruit I look forward to most. There is no easier fruit to prepare: just chop the fine pale-pink stems into cork-sized lengths and pack them into a baking dish with the juice of an orange or two and a fine sprinkling of sugar. You really don't need much with the tender rose stems, and bake in a moderate oven for 20 minutes or so till it is soft and syrupy. There will tons of exquisite juice to sup, too. If you have never had it cold, try it chilled for breakfast without yogurt, cream or extra sugar. A startling and rather effective alarm call. The doorstep drop of food companies anxious to plug their products has actually turned up a few goodies this month. Namely some stunning chutney from Tamarind. Unlike most commercial glops-in-a-jar, these are bright tasting and with an unsullied ingredient list. Check out the Tomato and cardamom and Carrot and Raisin for their clean, sweet flavours and up-front spice. The Date and chilli is deliciously dark and smoky. I stirred the tomato and carrot varieties into a bowl of plain boiled basmati for a spare and gentle supper. I should admit that this sucker also fell for the neat packaging. Now if you don't fancy the artichokes I mentioned as a soup, then try them baked instead: you will need 500g or so of artichokes, about 12, and remember to give them a good scrub with a vegetable brush. Boil them in salted water for 15-20 minutes until they are almost tender. Drain and scrape off as much of the skin as you reasonably can, then slice thickly. Generously butter a small gratin dish and lay the artichokes in it, pouring in just enough stock (vegetable, chicken or even something from a cube) to come just over halfway up the slices. Season with a squeeze of lemon juice, some salt and black pepper - I also tuck in a bay leaf or two - then bake the artichokes for 30 minutes at 390 C/gas mark 5 until completely tender. Now slide your dish out of the oven and scatter with a thin layer of grated Parmesan, turn up the oven to 200 C/gas mark 6 and let them cook for a further 15 minutes or so till they are lightly crusted and blissfully soft within. Eat them, spooning the baking juices over, with cold ham or rare roast beef. Enough for 4 as a side dish.

webTitle: Restaurants: Heathers, London SE8

fields.headline: Heathers, London SE8
fields.standfirst: The vegetarian food at Heathers, in the wilds of south London, makes Jay Rayner eat his words
fields.trailText: The vegetarian food at Heathers, in the wilds of south London, makes Jay Rayner eat his words.
fields.body:
Telephone: 020 8691 6665
Address: 74 McMillan Street, London SE8
Dinner for two, including wine and service, £50.

I have often thought of Deptford in south-east London as the kind of place one might go to dump a dead body. It has that ragged, urban wind swept aspect to it that lends itself to the concealment of crimes. More recently, I have begun to wonder whether the next body dumped there might not be mine. The correspondence I have received from vegetarians, furious at a perceived lack of interest on my part in their culinary foibles, has been so rabid that I have concluded their belief in the sanctity of life does not necessarily extend to errant restaurant critics.

I have argued that I am not producing a guidebook, of which a certain comprehensiveness is required. I have explained that I am simply a columnist with my own gross prejudices. But it's all been to no avail. Still the abuse comes. Needless to say, I am a complete coward and, holding to the maxim that one should give the punters what they want, particularly when the punters are threatening, I decided to make amends.

And so to Deptford and a vegetarian and vegan restaurant called Heathers, which has been recommended to me by many of the readers who have, in the very same sentence, written to abuse me. It occupies the site of what was once a pub in a narrow lane just back from a dour stretch of the Thames, but is anything but dour itself: it is a light and airy room of white walls, stripped floorboards and subtle lighting with carefully spaced tables so that you feel neither hemmed in nor on the verge of agoraphobia. In the middle sits the buffet which, at a very reasonable £14 a head, covers all the stations of the cross from soup to pudding.

The wine list is even more reasonably priced than the food, and entirely organic. We chose one of the more expensive bottles, a Chteauneuf-du-Pape, and it still only cost £18. It proved a great accompaniment to what is, for the most part, stridently seasoned food. I began with a bowl of spicy lentil and coconut soup which possessed a depth of flavour that I do not normally associate with non-meat-stock based soups. Lesley, the career vegetarian in our group, had the leek and potato soup. 'It's robust,' she said. 'And robust is never a word I thought I would ever use about leek and potato soup.' Pat had the crudités, which came with ballsy purées of walnut and garlic, watercress and avocado and spicy pumpkin. It was all forthright and impressive stuff.

The star of the main courses was a rich and luscious stew of pumpkin and leeks - and I can tell you that I have never, for a moment, ever imagined myself writing such a sentence. A salad of cabbage, almonds and capers was simply a coleslaw by any other name, though fine for all that. Lesley and Pat were less than convinced by their slightly astringent puy lentils and aubergine, but I rather liked it.

The two comedy vegetarian dishes - a bean salad and that great 70s standby, the stuffed pepper - in fact proved just why they have been so popular. Sure, it was a bean salad, but it was borlotti rather than sad old kidney beans, and they had been perfectly cooked to a fine nuttiness. As to the pepper, it was stuffed with a terrifically light, curried mash.

It struck me that everything we had so far eaten was not just vegetarian but vegan, too. My opinion of vegans concurs with that of the New York chef Anthony Bourdain, author of the great memoir Kitchen Confidential : that they are the Hezbollah wing of the vegetarian movement and clearly hate food. Whatever good work the first courses had done to dissuade me, the puddings now destroyed. Each of them could have benefited from the use of eggs, cream and butter. The most successful was a steamed fruit pudding. Other than that, a nutty chocolate pudding was dull and dry, a banana pie cloying and a lemon tofu tart simply nasty. It was such an unnecessary way to end a great meal. The truth is that I went to a vegetarian restaurant and had a really nice time. All I ask is that none of you gloat.

PS

A lot of you wrote following my review of Volvona & Crolla, many to praise the place, some to damn. But the most interesting message, in light of our experiences with their inedible ham shank stew, was this from co-owner Mary Contini: 'We totally messed up. I remember rounding your bill down by £2 when you commented about the saltiness of the ham. When I then tasted it five seconds later, I nearly died. This was a new dish (to us) and the cook hadn't tasted the fresh batch of ham she'd soaked - hence the disaster. So, is there any excuse? Not really. All we can say is thank you for not suing.'

webTitle: Comment: Labour puts election victory before NHS

fields.headline: Politics that can kill
fields.standfirst: When it comes to my son's life, I'm all in favour of animal testing and when it come's to the nation's health, I cannot abide a Government that puts election victory before its people's welfare
fields.trailText: When it comes to my son's life, I'm all in favour of animal testing and when it come's to the nation's health, I cannot abide a Government that puts election victory before its people's welfare.
fields.body:
Last week I spent far too much time waiting in hospitals for the results of tests on my 18-month-old son. It did not trouble me that, at some point in their development, most or all of those tests were tried on animals. In a toss-up between the knowledge that my son has not been struck down by a life-threatening illness - which, thankfully, is the case - and the welfare of the animals bred to help give me that knowledge, I know which side I would come on.

Quite simply I value my son's life more highly than that of a laboratory rat's; in these circumstances, sentimentality over animals is a non-starter.

It seems this Government cannot say as much; or, to be more exact, that they are perfectly willing to wallow in the politics of sentiment when it suits their needs. Last week they finally - and feebly - came to the aid of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the animal-testing company whose future hangs in the balance this weekend after a concerted campaign of intimidation and abuse against institutional investors and their staff by anti-vivisectionists has pushed the firm to the very brink of insolvency.

Cambridgeshire police were given £1 million to meet the cost of policing at HLS and Ministers at the Department of Trade and Industry tried to encourage bankers not to pull the plug on multi-million loans upon which the company relies.

These moves would be more convincing, had it not taken the Government so long to get involved. But then companies which experiment on animals, however important they are to our science base and, in turn, our greater wellbeing, do not play brilliantly with certain elements of the public. HLS has been begging for help for months but it was only as the bailiffs were practically banging on the doors, that Whitehall took notice.

Part of the problem is Labour's historical relationship with the animal rights lobby, a movement which eschews intellectual argument in favour of the kind of treacle sentiment which has kept Hallmark greetings cards in business for so long. Eighteen years in opposition made Labour a rallying point for every shabby oppositionist cause going. Some have been hard to shake off.

For example, while representatives of the animal rights movement have managed to get meetings with Home Office Ministers to state their position, Andrew Blake, director of Seriously Ill for Medical Research, which argues the case of the sick and disabled for animal experimentation to help in the search for cures, has been rebuffed at every turn. 'They're just listening to the anti-vivisectionists,' Blake told me last week, 'and not the patients.'

If you wanted further proof of how confused New Labour is on this, you could find it last week in the chamber of the House of Commons where a ban on hunting was being debated. As the DTI was arguing the case for the supremacy of man over animals with the banks, every single DTI Minister who was in the House - including Stephen Byers - was voting for a ban on hunting.

Personally, I find hunting distasteful. On balance, I would prefer to live in a country where people did not feel the need to dress up and ride with snapping hounds specifically to rid the countryside of vermin. But my objection is, as I say, purely a matter of taste and that is not a good enough reason for legislating.

Funnily enough, two years ago the Government appeared to agree. In March 1998, Jack Straw was asked whether New Labour would be introducing a bill banning hunting. 'We do not have a mandate for it,' the Home Secretary replied, simply. 'I do not see a role for Government.' Mind you, in March 1998 no election was pending.

But even if there were a case for banning fox hunting there are many more important pieces of legislation which should be introduced first, such as, say, a fully functioning Freedom of Information bill. The Government clearly thought otherwise: last autumn it used a guillotine to curtail debate on the already neutered proposals, declaring a lack of parliamentary time.

They gave the same reason for guillotining the Countryside Bill and the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Bill. And yet - somehow - they still found time for last week's free vote on hunting despite the issue having already had one run as a Private Member's Bill. And don't even mention the fact that it will never make it on to the statute books because of that pending election. At least it showed the punters that Labour's bleeding heart is in the right place.

Because, as far as this Government is concerned, the art of statecraft means tapping into the emotions of the electorate, however dysfunctional they may be and however poor the governance that results. Last week a number of newspapers - excluding this one - published photographs of bodies laid out in the chapel of rest at Bedford Hospital. The mortuary was full. The temporary mortuary had broken down. And so, on a freezing winter's day with temperatures hovering around zero, the management decided to place bodies in the chapel of rest. It seems to me a perfectly reasonable thing to do.

The disturbed ones are those who took the photographs and the newspaper editors who, like travelling circuses displaying specimens of two-headed lambs, ran those pictures across their front pages screaming: isn't this a disgrace!

No, it isn't. Last week, in a major survey by the new medical website, Dr Foster, whose findings were accepted by the Government, Bedford hospital rated highly. Mortality rates there are 14 per cent below the national average. Ken Williams, the chief executive, must take some credit for that success. Instead, Health Minister Alan Milburn sniffed the air, sensed the mood and hung him out to dry. 'This was not a cash problem in the hospital,' he told the Commons. 'It was a management problem.' Williams resigned and a hospital lost a successful manager.

We are quick to damn the NHS in the media and often too slow to praise, but the paediatric department of King's College Hospital in South London did me and mine proud last week. They were concerned and efficient. What troubles me is that a Government too addicted to the caprices of public sentiment will, in trying to follow it, only make the jobs of hard-pressed doctors and nurses harder still. That kind of politics does nobody - not my family, not yours - any favours at all.

webTitle: Monty Don: Home and dry

fields.headline: Home and dry
fields.standfirst: Snowdrops and lilies, sweet peas and sunflowers - bulbs and annuals that won't make heavy weather of the rain
fields.trailText: Snowdrops and lilies, sweet peas and sunflowers - bulbs and annuals that won't make heavy weather of the rain.
fields.body:
In the penultimate column of this mini-series on transforming the muddy agonies of global warming into the ecstasies of a finely orchestrated (organic) garden, we arrive at bulbs and annuals. When you write a general, catch-all garden book, there is always a process during the proposal, treatment and synopsis when the garden is broken down into its constituent parts. These parts never quite square with the garden out the window. I don't know about your garden, but in my own, a narrow sweep of the eye will take in just about the whole range of expertise necessary to make the thing work as I want it to. Most cultivated areas have bulbs, perennials, shrubs and annuals growing shoulder to shoulder. So the usual subdivisions of shrubs/perennials/veg/top fruit/bulbs/annuals, etc is never really adequate. I apologise for the way that the last few pieces on these pages have been divided up and promise I will try to resist doing it again, here or elsewhere. But it's too late to turn back now.

Let's do bulbs first. As a rule, bulbs are not suited to wet or even damp, poorly drained soil. The standard advice, if you are planting bulbs on heavy ground, is to put some grit in first, so they do not have their bases sitting in wet for any length of time. But there are, predictably, exceptions to this rule and our damp, heavy soil has not stopped us planting lots of tulips, alliums, hyacinths or lilies, of which we lose very few. I suspect that is because we also add masses of compost to the ground so that the soil structure is good and open, but it also makes sense to concentrate on bulbs that will cope naturally with wet conditions.

The first ones to use are snowdrops, which are now just coming into their prime. Snowdrops not only prefer damp conditions but also need them to thrive, so they should never be planted around a large beech tree or holly, which will suck a lot of moisture from the ground and also shade it from rainfall. It is an oft-repeated piece of advice, but if you are new to snowdrops, they are best spread 'in the green' - which means digging a clump up and dividing it thinly, while they are still in flower or just after. They can, of course, be planted as bulbs, but they are very small and fiddly and you will have a much better success rate if you get hold of some now and establish them as plants.

The other common bulb that actually likes damp conditions is the fritillary. There are more than 100 different fritillaries, but the face we instantly put to the name is the snake's head fritillary, Fritillaria meleagris. This, as if you didn't know, has beautifully sinister drooping flower bells hanging from the thinnest of stems, looking as though a chequerboard has been smudged on to the delicate petals, coloured from pale pink to a dark, chocolate burgundy. They were once a fairly common wildflower, growing in great swathes in water meadows and damp hay fields across the country. But thanks to the brutal rhythm of modern agriculture, they have all but disappeared. Blame politicians, farmers and yourself for not caring enough to do anything about it. Now, far more grow in damp corners of gardens than the fields that once shimmered with them for a few magical weeks in spring.

The huge imperial fritillary does best in a rich clay loam that will hold moisture - so the kind of increased wet we are experiencing means this is precisely the kind of plant that will start to do well in drier, sandy or chalky soils that would not have been suitable for it before. Whatever the soil, they need lots of goodness and should be lifted every few years and the soil reinvigorated with a bucket of compost before replanting. I must do mine.

The summer snowflake, Leucojum aestivum, is another wet-happy bulb, although ours seem to be growing perfectly happily in the dry shade of a large hazel. Looking like monstrous snowdrops, they're at their best in April, are very easy, and grow just as well in grass as in a border.

I have never knowingly done anything to ours except plant them. Christopher Lloyd recommends planting them at the base of dogwood and I think I will try that.

The yellow flag iris, Iris pseudacorus, is really a bog or marginal plant, so does not fall within this brief, but Iris versicolor will grow in moist soil as well as the margins of a pond. I spent a good hour yesterday playing in the compost heap. This kind of therapy depends on all ingredients being to hand. webTitle: Mandelson helped Dome backer's bid for passport

fields.headline: Mandelson helped Dome backer's bid for passport
fields.standfirst: 2001: The Observer year
fields.trailText: Scoop of the year: The Observer story which led to the resignation of Peter Mandelson.
fields.byline: Antony Barnett, Gaby Hinsliff and Luke Harding in Delhi
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson helped a controversial Indian tycoon, who is currently facing corruption charges, to obtain British citizenship after he and his brother agreed to donate £1 million to bail out the Millennium Dome.

In what was last night being called a 'passports-for-favours' scandal, The Observer can reveal that Mandelson approached the Home Office to find out whether an application from Srichand Hinduja, who had already been turned down for a British passport, would be welcomed.

Hinduja duly applied in March 1999 and received his passport six months later - a third of the time a typical decision takes.

Calling for an urgent investigation, Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker said last night: 'We have a rich businessman in the middle of a corruption scandal who gets a British passport in record time after donating £1m to the Dome. It now appears the Minister responsible for the Dome helped to get him a passport. We need a clear statement on who lobbied the Home Office on the Hindujas' behalf and when.'

Alison Stanley, a senior immigration lawyer with the legal firm Bindmans and head of the Law Society's immigration panel, said: 'It appears highly unusual. The only time the Home Office fast-tracks a citizenship is if there are exceptional circumstances such as a parent without a passport who needs to visit a seriously ill child overseas.'

Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, last night issued a statement insisting his involvement had been only in finding out the lie of the land and denied he had lobbied for Hinduja to get a passport. 'To the limited extent that I was involved in this matter I was always very sensitive to the proprieties,' he said. 'The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship.'

Two days ago, Srichand and his brother Gopichand were granted bail by an Indian court investigating corruption charges, but they were refused permission to leave the country. Federal Indian police allege that the brothers sought British citizenship to frustrate any attempts to extradite. Gopichand was granted British citizenship in November 1997.

The two have networked their way to the heart of the British Establishment, inviting Tony and Cherie Blair as guests of honour to a lavish party celebrating Diwali. Four days after Srichand got his passport, they hosted a reception at their London offices in honour of the British legal system to which Mandelson was invited.

Mandelson was also a frequent visitor to their central London offices when he was a Minister without Portfolio and Trade Secretary, and one source recalls a dinner Blair and Mandelson had at the Hindujas' central London home before the election.

But their real entrée into New Labour society came through the Dome. Mandelson was Minister in charge of it when the Hindujas offered £1m to fund its faith zone. The brothers are understood to have approached Mandelson after the deal was concluded, asking him to find out how an application by Srichand would be received by the Government. He asked his private secretary at the Cabinet Office to make inquiries of the Immigration Minister.

The disclosure of Mandelson's role will raise questions about the relationship between New Labour and its rich business friends. The Observer can reveal that Keith Vaz, now Minister for Europe, also approached the Home Office to ask when a decision would be made in the case of Gopichand. Vaz refused to comment on his involvement in the affair.

Sources close to Mandelson insisted the approach came only after the negotiations over the brothers' involvement in the Dome were finished.

His account also clashes with that of Home Office officials who said Mandelson made representations in 'mid-1997', when negotiations over the Dome were likely to have been taking place.

webTitle: One TV watchdog? We'll ITC to it

fields.headline: One TV watchdog? We'll ITC to it
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: There was very little publicity this week for what was billed by its sponsor, the Independent Television Commission, as probably the biggest consultation exercise on public service broadcasting (PSB) ever undertaken. This was not an idle boast. With a combination of three citizens' juries, a survey of 6,000 people, a children's workshop, open meetings and 50 interviews with MPs, academics and journalists, the ITC's initiative was an impressive contribution to the debate on the Government's communications White Paper.
fields.body:
There was very little publicity this week for what was billed by its sponsor, the Independent Television Commission, as probably the biggest consultation exercise on public service broadcasting (PSB) ever undertaken. This was not an idle boast. With a combination of three citizens' juries, a survey of 6,000 people, a children's workshop, open meetings and 50 interviews with MPs, academics and journalists, the ITC's initiative was an impressive contribution to the debate on the Government's communications White Paper.

Its conclusions were unambiguous and may explain the deafening silence: 'The vast majority of respondents, including those with pay-TV, believed strongly in the key principles of PSB and felt they were still valid in the multi-channel age.'

In terms of news values, this probably ranks alongside 'dog bites man' for most news editors. And no doubt some conspiracy theorists will point to the commercial self-interest of certain media groups, which may not be best served by a continuing regime of regulated broadcasting. Reverse the results and the headlines would be instant: 'Get doddering do-gooders off our box, say telly viewers.'

Some cynics will also be tempted to discount the results as institutional self-interest, suggesting that ITC-sponsored research which demonstrates overwhelming support for regulated public service television is akin to Railtrack-sponsored research showing that rail passengers believe in rail privatisation. Apart from being unfair to the ITC's consistent record of first-class research, this would unfairly detract from two particularly significant results.

First, is the virtually identical responses of viewers who subscribe to multi-channel television and viewers who receive only the five terrestrial channels. The size of the sample meant that nearly 2,500 multi-channel viewers were included, allowing plenty of scope for valid comparisons. Half of these viewers said they still primarily watched terrestrial channels. Moreover, when multi-channel viewers were asked to rank the eight channels they watched most often, BBC1, ITV, BBC2 and Channel 4 took the top four positions.

This is extraordinary. The arrival of more choice and channel availability was supposed to undermine the very basis of continued regulation, or even of public funding. By offering upwards of 100 additional channels, cable and satellite operators were going to reshape people's thinking about television and produce a wholesale shift in attitudes away from the public service ethic.

Yet here are viewers who spend at least twice as much as the licence fee to subscribe to the new channels, and half of them still spend most time with the freebies. More to the point, the vast majority still endorse the public service philosophy. The revolution clearly has a long way to go.

Second, MPs are 'overwhelmingly supportive' of public service broadcasting. This may come as something of a surprise to those of us who have sat through parliamentary and select committee speeches about the benefits of unfettered free markets, the evils of regulatory bureaucracy and the antediluvian ideas of those who still believe broadcasting can be a force for cultural and democratic good - with a bit of help.

It is reassuring to see that our representatives are so in touch with the popular mood. When this White Paper, and indeed the future of the BBC, comes to be debated, we can presumably expect a parliamentary consensus for the principles of public service. All credit to the ITC for establishing beyond doubt that these principles are alive and well. It only remains to agree on how we deliver them.

On this point, the role of public consultation is more dubious. It is one thing to establish public opinion on a set of principles to ensure that your guiding philosophy is still rooted in the popular will. It is quite another to ask the public to get involved in the minutiae of how regulatory systems should operate. Unfortunately, the ITC could not resist. And its finding that the majority was 'in favour of a single regulator' may be just a little influenced by the White Paper commitment to a single regulator and the ITC's instinct for survival and expansion in advance of legislation.

Even more suspicious is the blunt statement that 'all respondents considered that the BBC should be brought into the same regulatory framework as other channels'. Leave aside the fact that no supporting evidence for this is given anywhere in the report; and that responses to this question would depend entirely on whether anyone pointed out to respondents the potential threat of such a move to the BBC's editorial independence and integrity.

What is really significant about this statement is the unmistakable clue it offers to the ITC's territorial aspirations. As the Romans might have said, beware the regulator, even when bearing gifts.

Steve Barnett is Professor of Communications at the University of Westminster

webTitle: Murdoch's big Sky blues

fields.headline: Murdoch's big Sky blues
fields.standfirst:
News Corp is betting the bank again, say Faisal Islam and Dan Milmo

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: News Corp is betting the bank again, say Faisal Islam and Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Flying in Bollywood beauties from Bombay, laying on a lavish eight-course Indian feast for 600 guests, and transplanting mock caves into an east London warehouse are hardly the actions of a cash-strapped corporation suffering from a dotcom hangover.

Indeed, guests at last Thursday's UK launch of Star, the Asian TV network, must have been puzzled by suggestions that the network's ultimate owner, Rupert Murdoch, had instigated a low-spending diet at News Corporation.

In truth, the corporate liposuction applied to a portfolio of underperforming News Corp dotcoms, which was first revealed in Observer Business last August, has been going on for several months.

'We've always been conservative on internet spending,' said James Murdoch, Rupert's youngest son, in London from Sydney to promote the launch of Star. He has been closely associated with the group's new media strategy. But an estimated $2 billion global spend has brought little tangible return.

His father's initial scepticism about the internet, briefly jolted by his wish to avoid becoming a 'snack' for the likes of Yahoo!, may have proved right. Yet if anyone should have made money from the internet, it should have been News Corp.

Since the shift in strategy there have been job cuts, a recruitment freeze, and a downturn in credit rating prospects that leaves News Corp debt dangling perilously close to 'junk bond' status. Driving this financial indigestion is a string of billion-dollar cash calls maturing at around the same time and a projected fall in its main revenue, advertising. All these problems could have been written off as short-term factors were it not for its immediate plans.

The end of the tycoon's brief flirtation with the internet goes to the heart of how News Corp hopes to regain the initiative over the next six months after sitting out the two biggest mergers of all time. Murdoch wants to bet on digital satellite as the dominant delivery platform in a multimedia future. It will be a battle for the type of little black box that channels content into the home.

But adverse financial conditions may scupper funding for the huge investments that will turn around the likes of Star TV, which, in dollar terms, cost a billion and has since lost a billion.

Over the past few years, Murdoch's empire has been outflanked in the global media game by the likes of Time Warner, Vivendi and young upstart AOL. News Corp has not shown the same vision or verve, but its belated bold step is the flotation of Sky Global Networks, which will be the biggest media initial public offering of all time.

News Corp will have to navigate choppy waters to fund its ambitious plans. Analysts predict a slump in US advertising revenue growth for the first half of the year. Last year's figures were inflated by the US presidential election and the Sydney Olympics, and the slowing US economy is likely to deepen the impact.

Although 70 per cent of its revenues come from the US, News Corp does not have to hit the panic button yet, according to an unlikely source. Heather Goodchild, the analyst at Standard and Poor's credit rating agency that recently threatened to downgrade News Corp to junk bond status, sees it surviving the downturn relatively unscathed . 'They are in a better position than others because the advertising growth outlook is stronger outside the US, and it is far better spread globally,' she said.

Yet News Corp is entering a critical phase, with short-term doubts over its most important revenue stream. It needs an upbeat news flow and an upturn in revenues for the Sky Global float. Advertising revenue apart, the group has numerous problems that are unique. The main issue - and the reason behind Standard and Poor's junk bond threat - is the combination of its growing debts and a number of exceptional cash demands.

Haim Saban, co-owner of News Corp's Fox Family network, has exercised an option that forces Murdoch to buy back his partner's stake for up to £1bn. On top of this, News Corp is paying £3.6bn for US TV operator Chris Craft, putting added pressure on its £6.2bn debts and alarming Standard and Poor's.

Murdoch's group must juggle these factors while ensuring it does not take its eyes off the main prize: DirecTV. Murdoch has long hankered after the US satellite station as the missing piece in the Sky Global jigsaw. And without this £27bn jewel, Sky Global will be far more difficult to market to potential investors.

'Sky Global is worth no more than £20bn without DirecTV because most of the non-BSkyB assets are collapsing. It will be very difficult to buy something worth £27bn, and the timing is very unfortunate,' said Marc Loneux, Commerzbank analyst.

DirecTV is owned by Hughes Electronics, a subsidiary of General Motors, and reaches about 9.5 million homes. Instead of outright acquisition, News Corp, which needs a US presence to live up to its name, will have to accept a minority stake.

'DirecTV has to be within Sky Global, and the only way to do it is to swap assets. You have to inject DirecTV into Sky Global,' said Loneux.

It is understood that GM and News Corp plan to become joint shareholders in Hughes Electronics, which will be renamed Sky Global when Murdoch's satellite assets are injected into it. A GM spokeswoman said the car giant would like a 'continuing relationship' with Hughes. It is expected to sell its holding to strategic investors over a period, allowing Murdoch to complete a reverse takeover.

The Sky Global web is tangled further by Vivendi Universal's 23 per cent stake in BSkyB, which must be sold following a ruling by European Union competition watchdogs following the French company's merger with Seagram. Any overhang on BSkyB's stock will drag down Sky Global's value, and it is just one of the 'moving parts' that Murdoch has blamed for delaying the flotation. Though a relatively small deal, Star's UK entry is a small illustration of the potential of integrating Sky Global networks.

But can the Murdochs afford the huge outlays required to shift Asia from an advertising to a subscription model? Even if Sky Global incorporates DirecTV, it will have gaps in mature markets such as continental Europe. The flotation is key to raising the funds, which is why the obstacles are so threatening.

News Corp has survived rocky waters before, when BSkyB's teething troubles threatened to bankrupt Murdoch's fiefdom in the early Nineties. The demands ahead will reveal whether its battle-hardened management has learnt its lesson.

Global networking

Star's UK launch of two of its channels - Star News and Star Plus - aimed at British Asians, illustrates how Sky Global Networks might work. The long-term plan is for SGN to copy BSkyB's subscription model, rather than relying on volatile advertising revenues.

Star TV is using Sky's distribution platform and marketing expertise. The cost of production is nil as Star News and Star Plus already run in India. In fact the £16-a-month subscription fee that will be charged from March (it is free-to-air now) represents almost pure profit of up to £10 million per year, if projections of subscriber numbers are correct.

Conversely, BSkyB can boost its British user base by offering marketing deals focused at Asian households.

Although this alone won't make Star profitable, when rolled out across other channels and other languages News Corp believes the numbers will add up.

Peter Mukherjea, James Murdoch's right-hand man in India, says: 'At the end of the day there will be four primary languages that will be global: Mandarin, Hindi, English and Spanish.'

This multipolar view of globalisation requires a two-pronged approach: development of high-quality delivery networks for bespoke media and a strong commitment to local broadcasting.

Star has invested heavily in Hindi and Mandarin programming. But, regulation aside, the introduction of a Sky-type service in Asian markets would require shifting revenues from advertising to subscription.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Piers' esteem
fields.body:
Piers' esteem

Piers Morgan is up to more mischief at the Mirror . In a moment of madness, City editor Suzy Jagger has confessed that her share tips are, er, not doing that well.

No change for the Mirror there, then. It was Suzy, remember, who broke the story of Piers' share-dealing that landed him in hot water last year and got the woeful Slickers the sack. But in a masterstroke, our hero simply poached Suzy to write the page instead.

But Piers is nothing if not sympathetic. 'Yes, I realise you're crap! But I'm getting you some help,' he responded to Suzy's blushes. 'It's a monkey, a pin and a copy of the FT. I'm paying the monkey in bananas. But if his tips turn out better than yours, he gets your salary and you get the fruit.'

Buy Del Monte and Pearson, sell Trinity Mirror.

Saints alive

Great interview with All Saints' Shaznay in Company magazine's February edition. Shazzer talks about how the tabs have it all wrong about the fab four. 'There was a story saying that we were split into two camps, that me and Mel are jealous of Nat and Nic being the showbiz ones.' Unfortunately, a millisecond after the interview hit the print run, naughty Nat and Nic walked out, splitting the group into, um, two camps.

Carrott stop

There are many things which stop TV presenters from furthering their careers, but Brummie comics aren't usually one of them. Until now. The massively popular Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan, who presents India's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, wants his show, watched by an unprecedented 100 million viewers in India, to be seen in the UK.

But Celador, the company which owns the rights to the programme, won't let two different versions screen in the same country. Much depends on whether its head honcho can be persuaded to change his mind. So who is this obstinate and omnipotent figure with the power to bring great joy to millions in the UK, not to mention Bachchan's bank balance? Step forward, media mogul Jasper Carrott.

webTitle: Blair to be 'empty chair' in TV debate

fields.headline: Blair to be 'empty chair' in TV debate
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Jonathan Dimbleby: Why Blair's not boxing so clever
fields.trailText: Tony Blair faces the humiliating prospect of being represented by an empty chair as ITV prepares to go ahead with a televised debate involving the leaders of the three main political parties.
fields.body:
Tony Blair faces the humiliating prospect of being represented by an empty chair as ITV prepares to go ahead with a televised debate involving the leaders of the three main political parties.

Incensed by the Prime Minister's decision not to take part after he had agreed in principle to appear, television executives will make the symbolic gesture of leaving an empty seat on the podium in a potentially damaging act against Blair, who has been accused of ducking his opponents.

The empty chair policy will raise the spectre of the infamous 'tub of lard' affair, when the producers of the BBC's Have I Got News for You used a packet of lard in place of the Labour peer, Lord Hattersley, who cancelled an agreement to appear on the programme.

William Hague, the Conservative leader, and Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, have been asked to take part in the debate in February even if the Prime Minister sticks to his promise to avoid television head-to-heads because they would appear 'too presidential'.

'This fight is not over,' said one executive. 'We have to make the point that ITV is watched by 48 million people a week and that the public has a right to see its leaders debate the issues on television. If Mr Blair is worried about apathy among voters, then what better way to enthuse people than with a totally new television format?'

Jonathan Dimbleby, who is tipped to host the debate, has also attacked Blair's decision not to appear. Writing in today's Observer, Dimbleby says: 'The Labour Party has thrown away a great opportunity to demonstrate that political leaders are not as contemptuous of the voters as they are so frequently thought to be.'

TV executives believe that a relaxation of the law which governs broadcasters during election campaigns allows them to hold debates even if all leaders do not agree to take part. Independent Television Commission rules suggest that, as long as each party is invited, they can have no complaint.

webTitle: Jonathan Dimbleby condemns Blair's TV debate pull out

fields.headline: Why Blair's not boxing so clever
fields.standfirst:
Backing out of the televised debate shows that the Prime Minister only likes politics he can control

Special report: election countdown
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Blair to be 'empty chair' in TV debate
fields.trailText: Backing out of the televised debate shows that the Prime Minister only likes politics he can control.
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell timed it impeccably as always. With the horses cantering across Parliament Square, our elected representatives huffing and puffing through the thickets of fox hunting, and with the Prime Minister on urgent business elsewhere, he let slip that his boss would not - after all - take part in the leadership debates to which, a few days earlier, Tony Blair had himself 'in principle' given his blessing.

But despite the fact that this was a more than usually busy political day, the story did not get buried.

On the contrary, the Prime Minister found himself under assault from all sides, roundly condemned for allegedly chickening out of an important opportunity to revitalise the British electoral process.

Inevitably the broadcasters - ITV and the BBC - are frustrated. Not so much because they first heard of the decision via a lobby briefing, but because the reasons subsequently advanced by the Labour Party for rejecting the proposal seemed so feeble.

In their view, and mine - as one of the two putative chairmen of the debates - the Labour Party has thrown away a great opportunity to demonstrate that political leaders are not as contemptuous of the voters as they are so frequently thought to be.

What was on offer? A unique opportunity for a huge number of voters to witness Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy cross-examining one another on the great issues of the election in front of a studio audience but in a format designed to ensure fairness and balance between the protagonists. Only the most jaded and cynical politicians could seriously believe that this unprecedented co-operation between the two major terrestrial broadcasters was merely a journalist stunt.

Each debate would have been broadcast for an hour at peak time, not only reaching many millions of viewers but providing ample time for the leaders not simply to rubbish their rivals but to lay out their wares with clarity and precision.

The principle task of the chairmen would have been to assist this process, both by ensuring fair play and by preventing the debate degenerating into the sound-bite punch-ups of the Wednesday afternoon rituals at Westminster.

For once, the voters really would have had the chance to carefully assess the competing arguments as well as to judge the contrasting personalities of the would-be prime ministers.

What price now openness and accountability in our spin-doctored political process? Labour's decision to duck out of the debate has not only killed off an important democratic encounter but in the process has frustrated a chance to re-enthuse those disenchanted and alienated voters whose political apathy so unnerves our elected representatives.

So why did Labour pull out? The official explanation is so much guff about the threat posed by these debates to the 'political and constitutional traditions of this country'. Forgive me but I had thought New Labour had sought to release the United Kingdom from the shackles of such traditions.

Nor does Number 10's sudden aversion to 'presidential' politics carry any greater conviction. Forget America for a moment, but remember that televised debates between party leaders have long been at the heart of elections elsewhere in the democratic world. Canada has been at it since 1962, Germany since 1969, Holland since 1977, Australia and New Zealand since 1984, and they were joined by South Africa in 1994.

Does New Labour seriously seek to contend that the pillars of parliamentary democracy in the mother of all these parliaments would have collapsed under the strain of taking the hustings into the television studios?

Of course the debates would have focused on personalities as well as policies. But I have not yet detected a great passion in New Labour to deflect attention away from its leader.

You will recall that in 1997, Tony Blair not only introduced the 1997 Manifesto, he WAS the Manifesto. In British politics, as elsewhere, the reality nudges ever closer to the image. Party leaders do indeed run their own shows: there is far more primus than there is inter pares. And, as they very well know, it is mere cant to suggest otherwise.

So why did Number 10 bottle out? No prizes for guessing that the decision had precious little to do with high principle but was much about low politics; or rather, the old politics that tells party leaders that when they are in front they should do nothing which might risk another catching up.

If the price of denying a rival the oxygen of publicity is to stifle public debate it is - according to the merchants of old politics - a price well worth paying.

I suspect this is the last gasp of such reactionary thinking. We got closer to a debate this time round than ever before. Next time I think the case for televised debates between party leaders will prove irresistible.

Meanwhile, be on your guard: the battle buses and baby-kissers will soon be among you.

webTitle: Lump-sum investment: why it isn't quite as simple as AVC

fields.headline: Why it isn't quite as simple as AVC
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean on the options available to those who want to top up their pensions
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean on the options available to those who want to top up their pensions.
fields.body:
One of the worst aspects of the Equitable Life scandal is that it seems to be punishing the most prudent. The biggest sufferers are likely to be the people trying to bump up their pension funds by investing in additional voluntary contributions.

Equitable handled about half of the AVC schemes in the country - 500,000 of the estimated 1 million fundholders. Now that they face a 10 per cent penalty if they switch to another investment house, many people will be wondering if AVCs are a good bet at all.

Donna Bradshaw, of financial adviser Fiona Price & Partners, believes the situation should be seen as unusual: "The Equitable Life scenario isn't going to happen to many other companies. There are lots of very strong companies out there."

Nevertheless, most financial advisers tell clients to diversify and consider alternatives. "You should diversify in all investments - even when planning for retirement," says Garry Spencer of Wilbury Financial Management in Worthing, West Sussex.

You should consider Individual Savings Accounts and possibly even property as well as AVC schemes to top up your pension. And for employees earning less than £30,000 a year, there is also the option of investing in the new "stakeholder pension" from April.

Advisers are less keen on the "free-standing AVC". "FSAVCs have become a bit of a dead duck,' says Bradshaw. While AVCs are set up by your employer to run in parallel to your occupational pension, you choose your own FSAVC from an insurance company. While most employers keep AVC charges on members down to below 1 per cent a year, FSAVC charges can be up to 3 per cent a year.

Charges on stakeholder plans, by comparison have by law to be 1 per cent a year or less. Payments are made net of basic-rate tax - so if you decide to go for the maximum amount of £3,600 in a year, you would only pay in £2,808 and the Government would top up the remaining 22 per cent of tax relief. Unlike AVCs, you can also take 25 per cent of the investment fund as a tax-free lump sum.

There is another disadvantage with AVCs. 'The problem is that annuity rates have halved in the last 15 years,' says Garry Spencer. Under current rules, you have to buy an annuity from your AVC, FSAVC or other 'money purchase' pension fund by age 75. If AVC rates are low, you still have to buy one - and the rate is fixed for the rest of your life. See Databank, page 18, for current annuity rates.

There is another flaw to annuities, as Ian Johnson of accountant Grant Thornton explains: 'Once you buy an annuity, you lose your capital.' So if you buy an annuity for £100,000 and die the next day, the insurance company pockets the cash. If you had built up £100,000 of Isas instead, your heirs would inherit the cash.

Although these drawbacks may be removed by the Government over the next few years, they are such big disadvantages advisers encourage clients to look at the alternatives. Calculations by Grant Thornton, however, suggest that the same sums of money put into Isas and AVCs would, if charges were equal but the investment yields were the same, produce better returns in AVCs.
