webTitle: UK 'is now ready for euro'

fields.headline: UK 'is now ready for euro'
fields.standfirst:
Leading think tank says UK meets Brown's five tests - but the price is 2p on income tax

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Leading think tank says UK meets Brown's five tests - but the price is 2p on income tax
fields.body:
The British and European economies have converged to the point where the Government can prepare for euro entry, the influential National Institute for Economic and Social Research claims. It concludes that membership would pose no serious economic problems for the UK.

The group's research demonstrates that, on key measures of convergence, and on the criteria set out in the Chancellor's economic tests for joining, the UK is ready. It The findings come two weeks after a Treasury report also indicated that the UK was becoming more convergent.

However, in a report commissioned from NIESR and six other economics institutes by the European Parliament, it is argued that if Britain joined in the next parliament it would - under current European rules - have to tighten fiscal policy. This would require either raising income tax by 2p or cutting public investment by £12 billion.

This is because the UK's fiscal 'Golden Rule' allows the Government to borrow money to invest in public services, running up deficits over the economic cycle. But the European Stability and Growth Pact requires governments to keep their budgets in balance.

The Treasury forecasts a budget deficit of 1.1 per cent of Gross Domestic Product by 2005 as government borrowing increases, driven by a rise in public-sector investment.

NIESR's Ray Barrell says government investment is planned to reach £41bn by 2004/5, and therefore would have to be cut back by £10-12bn to meet European rules.

Cuts in public investment of this scale - particularly in infrastructure - would be politically damaging: the Government has emphasised its commitment to spending. But the obvious alternative - income tax increases - would also be unpalatable.

The report is to be presented to the European parliament next week, where the group will argue that Europe's fiscal code should be loosened in line with Britain's Golden Rule.

'We will be saying that there are no good reasons why these governments should not be able to borrow for investment in the public sector,' Barrell said.

In an article in today's Observer, Barrell, along with the NIESR's Martin Weale and Nigel Paine, argue that the UK has converged with the euro area - particularly judged against two key requirements of the Chancel lor's economic tests: compatibility of business cycles and structural flexibility. They write: 'The reality is that the cyclical position of the UK is currently not very different from that of the euro area.'

They estimate that British economic output is close to its long-term rate - similar to the rates in France and Germany, and closer than in the past.

They also state that economic reforms, including Bank of England independence, mean that the UK 'will experience the greater economic stability seen on the continent in the past'.

The immediate difficulty is still the exchange rate. Barrell indicates that a strengthening of the euro may mean we are moving towards convergence. Other economists forecast that sterling will fall to levels consistent with entry in the medium term. Jonathan Loynes of Capital Economics predicts an equivalent exchange rate of DM2.80 by mid-2002.


We pass the tests. Now what, Gordon?

webTitle: Euro-vision contest

fields.headline: Euro-vision contest
fields.standfirst:
As the strong pound continues to take its toll on jobs, Oliver Morgan assesses the impact of exchange rate fluctuations on manufacturing

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: As the strong pound continues to take its toll on jobs, Oliver Morgan assesses the impact of exchange rate fluctuations on manufacturing
fields.body:
If you want to know the Government's plans for joining the single currency, it may be an idea to get a job in the boardroom of a major manufacturer that has decisions to make about investment and employment in the UK.

In MPs' minds, talking about joining the euro is high risk. But for industrialists such as John Cushnaghan of Nissan UK, waiting for a decision from Japan on whether it will build the next model of Micra city car in his Sunderland plant, or Sir Brian Moffat of Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker, who is pondering the closure of UK works, it is a matter of life or death - or, at least, growth or cuts.

In their meetings with Ministers and officials to discuss their plans, these bosses have a singular private opportunity to sound out Government thinking.

But even advanced knowledge of Government plans, which is vital to manufacturers who export to Europe and who find that the high value of sterling makes them uncompetitive, is insufficient help if the plans themselves are unfavourable.

One senior executive at one major motor manufacturer said: 'The Government should say that we are going into the euro and that this is what we are going to do to make the Chancellor's five economic tests for joining converge, rather than saying that if they are met, we will go in. If they used the first way, the markets would have adjusted and the rate would have eased.'

Industrialists do not suggest that the Government is cold on the issue. Our motor executive says: 'My impression from talking to them is that they want a referendum a year after an election.'

Indeed a recent Treasury report - released without fanfare - indicates that on crucial measures such as long- and short-term interest rates and Government debt, the UK is converging with Euroland.

But for the time being the man calling the shots is the author of the five tests, and he has said hold your fire.

While a ceasefire may make political sense, it comes at a crucial time economically. The outlook is uncertain, with the US facing a downturn in the first half of this year. The euro has recently edged around 10 cents higher against the dollar, to $0.94, and sterling has jittered slightly, partly because of concerns about knock-on effects for Britain of what is happening in the US. But a sharp American slowdown could dampen world demand for manufactured goods.

For the past decade, the exchange rate has arguably been the most important economic factor for UK manufacturers, and their experience of it may help signal what happens in future.

Douglas McWilliams of the Centre for Economic and Business Research (CEBR) says: 'The exchange rate has been a huge influence. In the period coming out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism after 1992, the pound fell until 1995 [to DM 2.16] and then rose dramatically [to DM 3.40] and has remained strong ever since. This has a major impact on manufacturers.'

Nick Cunningham, engineering analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, has examined the currency effect on engineering companies. Shortly after the 1992 devaluation, engineering shares rose in value on the stock market, outperforming the market as a whole by about a third until spring 1994. When sterling climbed between October 1996 and mid 1997, [from around DM2.30 to over DM3] the sector fell back by 20 per cent.

Cunningham also notes that while share prices react quickly, profits lag behind as companies take hedging positions. So engineering earnings took until 1995 to rise in response to the 1992 devaluation, and another two years to fall after 1997. But, though delayed, the impact is marked.

It works something like this. If 100 per cent of a company's costs are in the UK, 100 per cent of its revenues are in Europe and the company's margin is 10 per cent, then 90 per cent of its revenues are UK-based costs. If sterling devalues by 20 per cent, costs remain the same, but revenues rise from 100 to 120. Margins therefore shoot up from 10 to 25 per cent. The reverse is true of revaluation.

CEBR research in 1998 - when sterling headed over DM3.00 - into the steel and metal forging industries indicates how hard they were hit by the revaluation effect.

The CEBR found that the difference in the exchange rate in March 1998, compared with 1992-7, raised steel production costs (expressed in dollars) in the UK by nearly 4 per cent, while costs in France, Germany and Japan fell by between 9 and 13 per cent, making the UK 11.7 per cent less cost-competitive.

Research into the metal forging sector, a key supplier and cost to the motor industry, indicated a similar pattern: the sector would have had to cut profits by 13.6 per cent to remain competitive.

Ian Rogers of the UK Steel Association says: 'The problem has been the speed of the rise. We could live with DM 2.70 - probably even 2.90 now - but we are still 40 per cent above 1996 levels.'

Looking back to the early Nineties Cunningham notes: 'There are two impacts of devaluation. One is that businesses are more competitive so they can win volume. The other is margin, and people increase prices initially to get margins up.'

It is the balance between margin and market share that worries analysts and economists. Jonathan Loynes of Capital Economics says: 'The important thing about 1992 was that manufacturers played a short-term game. The depreciation gave a dramatic boost to UK goods in world markets. Either they kept sterling prices where they were and used the devaluation to gain a stronger foothold in world markets, or they played short-term and whacked up sterling prices to enjoy wider profit margins. They went for the short term.'

Economists agree that the results of this process - pursuit of margin over market share - have been partially masked so far by strong world demand, which has kept exportsin some sectors buoyant - although ot hers, including steel, have faced problems. In addition, some manufacturers have taken action themselves, often by cutting workforces. Corus, for example, last year axed 4,500 jobs in the UK. Neil Marshall, director general of the Confederation of British Metalforming, says: 'Before Christmas, many of my members were planning redundancy programmes.'

Manufacturers, particularly textiles makers, have also looked to shift cost bases to Europe and beyond. If Corus shuts a UK plant, it will effectively be shifting production to its Dutch operations, inside Euroland.

But headline export growth cannot disguise the vital importance of the currency situation. A Euro Strategies/CEBR survey of 121 manufacturers last September is gloomy: UK exports were 11 per cent lower than they would have been if the currency had remained unchanged, with £31 billion thus lost in export earnings.

The outlook is unclear. Share prices - for example, Corus's - have responded to the softening in exchange rates, but earnings, market share and competitiveness are likely to lag. And in any case a beneficial exchange rate effect could be offset by weaker world demand.

McWilliams says: 'Corus, for example, is one of the most efficient steel companies. But it has two problems - the exchange rate and world overcapacity in steel - ominous in the context of world demand. With a fair exchange rate, you could expect it to compete well. Without one, it is going to be very tough.'

Sterling may not come down quickly. Loynes estimates that it will fall to a DM 2.80 equivalent by mid-2002. That, of course, looks like a good rate for euro entry, but next year may be too late for many companies and their workers.

Perhaps the only way to speed convergence of the British and Euroland economies would be a political declaration in favour of early entry.

Robert Peston, editorial director of CSQuest.com, the online financial service for fund managers, says: 'The timing of the referendum is always going to be political.' But he believes global changes could shape the debate and break the present stalemate.

'The outlook for the US is looking less exciting,' Peston says. 'If you add to that a US President who is less sympathique and a Europe that is looking more interesting, the whole euro issue looks a bit more enticing for a Labour government.'

We shall have to wait and see. The question remains, as ever, for how long? And who will suffer in the meantime?

webTitle: We pass the tests. Now what, Gordon?

fields.headline: We pass the tests. Now what, Gordon?
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The euro's popularity remains low in the UK, and on the Continent it appears to be losing support. In the euro area countries this may be influenced by the weakness of the euro relative to the US dollar - something that could change if the euro continues its recent recovery.
fields.body:
The euro's popularity remains low in the UK, and on the Continent it appears to be losing support. In the euro area countries this may be influenced by the weakness of the euro relative to the US dollar - something that could change if the euro continues its recent recovery.

Attitudes in the UK are probably coloured by a view that our economy is more successful than those of our neighbours. But if you look at the evidence on productivity and living standards in countries such as Germany, this view cannot be supported.

The economic debate in the UK focuses on whether it makes economic sense to join and, in particular, on the third and fourth of the Chancellor's tests: 'Are business cycles and economic structures compatible so that we and others in Europe could live comfortably with euro interest rates on a long-term basis?' and 'If problems do emerge, is there sufficient flexibility to deal with them?'

In reality, however, the cyclical position of the United Kingdom is currently not very different from that of the euro area economies. Both have strong growth and low inflation, and unemployment is relatively low.

The OECD estimates that in 2000, output in the UK was less than 1 percentage point above its long-run sustainable level. But, since there are no current signs of inflationary pressure, this is questionable. The OECD estimates that on average the euro area economies are operating at around capacity, and we would judge this to be the case. There are of course differences within the area, but the economies are generally converging. France's output is estimated to be 0.3 percentage points above, and Germany's 0.7 per cent below long-run levels, and this may explain why French inflation is expected to be above that in Germany at present. The overall economic situation in the euro area looks very similar to the UK's.

The Chancellor's worries about diverging cycles reflect problems we have seen in the past, rather than the situation today, where cyclical fluctuations appear only moderate. Current circumstances should be contrasted with the last major economic cycle, a decade ago: in 1989 UK output is estimated to have been 4.7 per cent above the long-run sustainable level, while in 1992 it was 4 per cent below. The differences between the 'big three' are now small and well within margins of statistical error, whereas in 1991 the UK was in recession and France and Germany were booming.

Even if cyclical differences are small, it could be argued, economic structures may not be compatible. A monetary policy appropriate for the euro area as a whole could lead to excessive output fluctuations in countries whose economies are particularly sensitive to interest rate changes. It is often argued that the UK, because of its deregulated financial markets and the high degree of owner-occupation, is particularly interest-rate sensitive.

But the euro area economies have also introduced financial market reforms and are becoming more similar to the UK's, so monetary policies should have more similar effects in the future.

Over the past 20 years the UK has suffered from greater interest-rate volatility and greater output volatility than the current euro area countries. However, the UK has introduced new ways of managing the economy that are similar to those of its euro neighbours. The Bank of England is independent, and fiscal policy is set in relation to medium- term needs. With the sort of stable economic management delivered by an independent monetary authority, it is more likely that the UK will experience the greater economic stability seen on the Continent in the past.

The new institutional framework set up by this Government would have to change if we joined the euro. Of course the independence of the Bank of England would have to be maintained, but it would no longer set interest rates. Euro area membership also means signing up for the stability and growth pact on fiscal policy. This framework is similar to the Chancellor's code for fiscal stability, but would still mean changes in policy. The UK code allows borrowing over the cycle to finance public investment, whereas the euro area pact requires that budgets are in balance or surplus over the cycle. If we adopt the pact and have our budget in balance by 2004-5 (instead of 1 per cent of GDP as the Government has planned) then either taxes would have to rise by 1 per cent of GDP (a 2p rise) or public spending would have to be reined in.

But the other side of this is that interest rates would be lower. Cyclical convergence has so far been achieved with rates higher in the UK than in the euro area. This is probably the counterpart to the fact that long-term budgetary policies in the euro area are expected to be tighter. To adopt the monetary policy but not the fiscal constraints of the euro area could be destabilising.

Cyclical convergence does not, of course mean that economic growth rates need be much the same as on the Continent. The major continental economies are starting to undertake the sort of labour market reforms that Britain introduced in the Eighties and Nineties.

At present their unemployment rates are generally higher than the UK's, but they are falling, and over the past five years employment in the euro area has increased by 4.5 per cent, which is about 1 per cent more than in the UK. If countries such as France were able to reduce unemployment rates from 9 per cent to UK levels, they should be able to grow faster than us for some years.

On the other hand, productivity levels in the UK are low compared with those on the Continent; indeed most estimates suggest French workers are more productive than American ones. If Britain succeeds in raising its productivity to French levels, Britain would grow rapidly for a long period. Raising productivity toward French, German or Dutch levels depends on improving education and organisation, and these are the convergence issues that the Government should address.

It is these issues, not the choice of currency, that fundamentally affect national prosperity, and on which attention should be focused.

Ray Barrell, Nigel Pain and Martin Weale are from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Attitudes in the UK are probably coloured by a view that our economy is more successful than those of our neighbours. But if you look at the evidence on productivity and living standards in countries such as Germany, this view cannot be supported. The economic debate in the UK focuses on whether it makes economic sense to join and, in particular, on the third and fourth of the Chancellor's tests: 'Are business cycles and economic structures compatible so that we and others in Europe could live comfortably with euro interest rates on a long-term basis?' and 'If problems do emerge, is there sufficient flexibility to deal with them?' In reality, however, the cyclical position of the United Kingdom is currently not very different from that of the euro area economies. Both have strong growth and low inflation, and unemployment is relatively low. The OECD estimates that in 2000, output in the UK was less than 1 percentage point above its long-run sustainable level. But, since there are no current signs of inflationary pressure, this is questionable. The OECD estimates that on average the euro area economies are operating at around capacity, and we would judge this to be the case. There are of course differences within the area, but the economies are generally converging. France's output is estimated to be 0.3 percentage points above, and Germany's 0.7 per cent below long-run levels, and this may explain why French inflation is expected to be above that in Germany at present. The overall economic situation in the euro area looks very similar to the UK's. The Chancellor's worries about diverging cycles reflect problems we have seen in the past, rather than the situation today, where cyclical fluctuations appear only moderate. Current circumstances should be contrasted with the last major economic cycle, a decade ago: in 1989 UK output is estimated to have been 4.7 per cent above the long-run sustainable level, while in 1992 it was 4 per cent below. The differences between the 'big three' are now small and well within margins of statistical error, whereas in 1991 the UK was in recession and France and Germany were booming. Even if cyclical differences are small, it could be argued, economic structures may not be compatible. A monetary policy appropriate for the euro area as a whole could lead to excessive output fluctuations in countries whose economies are particularly sensitive to interest rate changes. It is often argued that the UK, because of its deregulated financial markets and the high degree of owner-occupation, is particularly interest-rate sensitive. But the euro area economies have also introduced financial market reforms and are becoming more similar to the UK's, so monetary policies should have more similar effects in the future. Over the past 20 years the UK has suffered from greater interest-rate volatility and greater output volatility than the current euro area countries. However, the UK has introduced new ways of managing the economy that are similar to those of its euro neighbours. The Bank of England is independent, and fiscal policy is set in relation to medium- term needs. With the sort of stable economic management delivered by an independent monetary authority, it is more likely that the UK will experience the greater economic stability seen on the Continent in the past. The new institutional framework set up by this Government would have to change if we joined the euro. Of course the independence of the Bank of England would have to be maintained, but it would no longer set interest rates. Euro area membership also means signing up for the stability and growth pact on fiscal policy. This framework is similar to the Chancellor's code for fiscal stability, but would still mean changes in policy. The UK code allows borrowing over the cycle to finance public investment, whereas the euro area pact requires that budgets are in balance or surplus over the cycle. If we adopt the pact and have our budget in balance by 2004-5 (instead of 1 per cent of GDP as the Government has planned) then either taxes would have to rise by 1 per cent of GDP (a 2p rise) or public spending would have to be reined in. But the other side of this is that interest rates would be lower. Cyclical convergence has so far been achieved with rates higher in the UK than in the euro area. This is probably the counterpart to the fact that long-term budgetary policies in the euro area are expected to be tighter. To adopt the monetary policy but not the fiscal constraints of the euro area could be destabilising. Cyclical convergence does not, of course mean that economic growth rates need be much the same as on the Continent. The major continental economies are starting to undertake the sort of labour market reforms that Britain introduced in the Eighties and Nineties. At present their unemployment rates are generally higher than the UK's, but they are falling, and over the past five years employment in the euro area has increased by 4.5 per cent, which is about 1 per cent more than in the UK. If countries such as France were able to reduce unemployment rates from 9 per cent to UK levels, they should be able to grow faster than us for some years. On the other hand, productivity levels in the UK are low compared with those on the Continent; indeed most estimates suggest French workers are more productive than American ones. If Britain succeeds in raising its productivity to French levels, Britain would grow rapidly for a long period. Raising productivity toward French, German or Dutch levels depends on improving education and organisation, and these are the convergence issues that the Government should address. It is these issues, not the choice of currency, that fundamentally affect national prosperity, and on which attention should be focused. Ray Barrell, Nigel Pain and Martin Weale are from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

webTitle: NHS to have its own Big Issue

fields.headline: NHS to have its own Big Issue
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Britain's hospitals are turning to Big Issue-style magazine-sellers to raise cash.
fields.body:
Britain's hospitals are turning to Big Issue-style magazine-sellers to raise cash.

Volunteers will tour hospital wards and waiting areas to sell a new magazine to patients and visitors. A portion of the sale price will be ploughed back into the health service.

Feelgood Magazine will be launched this week in 200 hospitals across the country. For every £1 copy sold, 40 pence will go to the local hospital. It runs on the same principle as the Big Issue, which the homeless sell to earn money.

Sales of the first edition are expected to be 150,000, but its founding editor, Dr Liz Wilkinson, hopes it will rise to a million copies a month, generating around £5 million a year for the NHS.

The magazine will contain 'optimistic' health stories, ensuring it does not frighten patients or become a 'hypochondriacs gazette'. It is aimed at answering questions that patients may not have time to ask a doctor.

Wilkinson, a surgeon at Moorfields Eye Hospital, denied it was a sign of desperation: 'Fundraising is part of the way the NHS is run. If we can do as good a job as the Big Issue, we'll be very happy.' The League of Friends - an umbrella group for hospital volunteers - already raises £30 million for the NHS.

Wilkinson insists that sick patients won't feel under pressure to buy the magazine. It won't be sold in intensive care wards.

A Department of Health spokeswoman insisted money raised would be in addition to government funding.

webTitle: Dear Richard, don't say we didn't tell you

fields.headline: Dear Richard, don't say we didn't tell you
fields.standfirst:
For Gtech, an in with the Bush family is worth more than anything lottery players have in their hand

Special report: the lottery
Special report: George W Bush's America
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: For Gtech, an in with the Bush family is worth more than anything lottery players have in their hand
fields.body:
Congratulations to George W Bush and to Camelot on their victories.

More than a year ago, we reported that the Government had decided to let Camelot retain control of the National Flutter in perpetuity. That was two weeks before the formal bidding process began. Despite our announcement, Richard Branson soldiered on, refusing, like the last dinosaur, to heed the voice whispering: 'Excuse me, but you're extinct.'

Yes, there was a moment in October when Oflot announced Branson as the putative winner. But I wasn't fooled. In 1968, a young George W. Bush, not the brightest campfire on the prairie, somehow got chosen to be a fighter pilot for the Texas Air Guard over hundreds of other young men eager to defend Dallas from bomber attack. The job, incidentally, carried an exemption from the Vietnam war draft.

Both Presidents Bush, past and future, deny that they used influence to get young George the Air Guard post.

Years passed. George fils became Governor of Texas. Gtech, already in control of the Texas lottery, was in hot water. An audit had questioned the company's proficiency as operator in Texas, its top sales representative was jailed in 1996 for bribery in New Jersey and, in 1997, the company was caught paying a consulting fee to the boyfriend of the Texas lottery director.

The remainder of the story may sound awfully familiar to Richard Branson.

The Texas lottery was opened up for bids, and a Gtech competitor was designated as having the best offer. Transfer from Gtech was subject only to review and negotiations. Then - surprise! - Bush's lottery commission dumped its new director, dropped the apparent winning bidder, and the head of the state Lottery Commission, Harriett Miers, announced it was best simply to stick with Gtech. Linda Cloud, executive director, said it offered the best deal.

Up until 1997, Gtech had a lobbyist, a politico named Ben Barnes, to whom Gtech paid more than $23 million. Some malevolent soul had written to the US Justice Department earlier claiming that Barnes had fixed for Bush Jr to get the Guard slot - information which Barnes allegedly used to lock in Gtech's lucrative Texas contract for good.

But that letter, and the accusations in it, remained buried until a year ago when, confronted with it, Barnes stated in an affidavit that, indeed, it was he who called the Guard for young George.

Barnes denies he used this information for Gtech. Bush and Gtech also deny any link between Bush's military service and the Gtech contract.

In the middle of Gtech's US troubles, it flew the Tory government's lottery regulator into Texas. Oflot's Peter Davis endorsed the UK's emulating the 'Texas Model' of lottery licensing. This model is based on granting almost all aspects of a lottery to a single licence-holder. The problem, say experts, is that once the initial operator is chosen, it is in practice impossible for anyone to win the licence.

In Britain Camelot, using Gtech's technology and operations, won that initial contest based on its Texas and other 'experience' over your raw crew, Richard. This was after, you may recall, Gtech's chairman, who has since resigned, tried to bribe you out of the competition.

Tony Blair, then in opposition, promised reform. That should have been your first warning, Richard. Labour, once in power, rather than force Camelot to dump Gtech, permitted the consortium to shuffle the corporate ownership, and transform Gtech, from lucrative partner into lucrative prime contractor.

Labour's 1998 reform of the Lottery Act kept the single-licence Texas Model.

And, just in case you did not get the hint, the new law provided no end-of-licence transition period, making it impossible to transfer the system to a new operator.

The fact that Labour effectively saved Gtech's bacon in 1998 has absolutely nothing to do with an idea mentioned in 1997 by a would-be Gtech lobbyist.

The lobbyist, Derek Draper, told me (into my hidden tape recorder) that his friend Peter Mandelson needed someone to 'sell tickets for this ridiculous Dome thing. Gtech is offering to do that via the National Lottery [ticket]-selling equipment.' Draper added: 'Now it doesn't take a lot to work out that if the Government thinks Gtech can sell government tickets for the Dome, it's got to be a legitimate firm to sell tickets for the lottery.'

Gtech's one and only use of its machines for a purpose other than the lottery was to sell Dome tickets, at no charge to the Government.

Labour's 1998 reform virtually locked in the Camelot-GTech group.

Nevertheless, Gtech nearly blew it by concealing a computer cock-up that ate some wagerers' winnings. That required another corporate reshuffle, with Camelot promising to sever its links with Gtech.

'Severing' Gtech, the Observer's Jamie Doward disclosed on Christmas Eve, means Camelot will pay Gtech about £230m under the new licence, more than it received under the last one. That's no surprise. Camelot's promise to cut off Gtech, as one industry wag said, 'is like promising to sever their arms and legs'. At an operating level, Camelot can't function without its technology.

How appropriate that the Lottery Commission confirmed the Camelot-Gtech group's new licence a week after Al Gore conceded his victory to George W. Bush. So who was the real winner of the presidential contest? Some might say Bill Gates. One of Dubya's first appointments was of the key Secretary for White House Matters: attorney Harriet Miers, the US lottery commissioner who dealt with Gtech's contract.

'Harriet was always flying to Seattle [home of Microsoft]', says Lawrence Littwin, the Texas Lottery director Miers fired in 1997. That's no surprise, as her law firm represented Gates at the time. Miers will, of course, have to give up her interest in the law practice while working for the White House.

Some wonder whether Bush, as President, will continue the Justice Department's push to break up Microsoft. Watch this space ...

Before the 7 November event that some Americans call an election, the Florida Governor Jeb Bush and his Secretary of State, Katherine Harris, ordered the removal of several thousand felons from the state electoral rolls. A little investigation on our part revealed that these 'arch criminals' had not, in fact, committed felonies. They were not innocent: almost all were confessed Democrats, and half of them were African-Americans. They lost their right to vote, costing Gore the White House.

The list of faux felons was provided by the firm contracted by the state to search records is ChoicePoint DBT. This company's board is stuffed with Republican bigwigs, though ChoicePoint denies it favours any party.

Our report caused some discomfort in the States. Of a thousand letters I received, one stood out: 'You pansey [sic] Brits think that the average American is under-educated and stupid. Yor [sic] story is full of outright lies.'

But rather than seeking a correction, the writer made some uncomfortable suggestions for the improper use of the Prince of Wales.

Now, a coalition of America's leading civil rights lawyers, acting for the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People, has filed a class action suit against the Florida Secretary of State, Katherine Harris and ChoicePoint for 'wrongfully purging black voters', which, it turns out, is a violation of the US Constitution. ChoicePoint says the claims are baseless.

The NAACP's lawyers thanked The Observer for uncovering the facts. Unfortunately, unlike our letter writer, they had no suggestions as to what we should do with the Prince.

webTitle: Woman arrested after Israeli youth lured to online death

fields.headline: Woman arrested after Israeli youth lured to online death
fields.standfirst:
Suspect seized by undercover troops posing as Palestinians

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Undercover Israeli soldiers posing as Arabs last night captured a young Palestinian woman suspected of luring an Israeli youth to his death via the internet.
fields.body:
Undercover Israeli soldiers posing as Arabs last night captured a young Palestinian woman suspected of luring an Israeli youth to his death via the internet.

The woman, a 25-year-old freelance journalist with an Israeli identity card, was arrested in the village of Bir-Nabala near the West Bank town of Ramallah, not far from where the body of the 16 year old was dumped.

Mona Najar was seized in a pre-dawn raid on her parents' home by troops from Israel's elite Duvdevan unit.

Najar is suspected of being involved in the internet exchange that led to the death of Ophir Rakhum, from the coastal town of Ashkelon.

'The Israeli army arrested the young woman who took part in the murder of this young boy,' a military spokeswoman said. 'She was arrested on Friday.'

A senior Palestinian security official said the woman had surfed the web from an internet cafe, but anyone could have used her computer terminal.

The murder of Rakhum shocked even those Israelis who thought they had become inured to the violence of the last few months of the intifada .

Despite the recent executions and arrests of alleged Palestinian collaborators with Israel, the woman's capture again demonstrated how thoroughly the Israeli security services have penetrated the West Bank and Gaza.

Friends of the murdered Israeli youth say the person who lured him to his death had told Rakhum in emails that she was an American tourist living in Jerusalem.

The two met in the city once, and Rakhum left his home again last week to meet her. He told friends that if he did not return the same evening he would be back in the morning 'and would tell them all the details'.

He was somehow lured to Ramallah, where the woman's accomplices shot him dead last Wednesday.

Security sources had speculated that the youth was deliberately enticed there to be killed.

Palestinian sources claim he was killed in an ambush by locals on his girlfriend's car. They say he was seized on a side road by Palestinians who then shot and killed him. The youth was reportedly to have taken a large sum of money with him to the meeting.

When the body was first found, both the Israeli Defence Force and the Palestinian Authority believed it was of a Palestinian killed for collaborating with Israel. Following police reports of a missing youth, the head of the District Co-ordination Office in Ramallah, Lieutenant-Colonel Amir Sfadi, asked Palestinian security officials to investigate.

After failing to get clear answers, Sfadi turned to high-ranking PA officials, including the commander of the Palestinian security forces in the West Bank, Haj Ismail.

The body was then identified as that of an Israeli youth who had been reported missing and handed over to the Israeli authorities.

The killing shook Israel because of its cruelty, and prompted Prime Minister Ehud Barak to briefly postpone consideration of a Palestinian offer of peace talks, which he eventually accepted yesterday..

Most Israelis believe Rakhum's killing to be a political murder, though it could be criminal, because of the money he was said to be carrying.

Israeli television said the Shin Bet security service was instrumental in locating the suspect using information they found stored in Rakhum's computer.

The arrest came as Israel's 'peace cabinet' decided to enter the peace talks in Egypt with the Palestinians. These could give a new push to peacemaking early in George W. Bush's presidency.

Israeli and Palestinian officials said the ministerial-level negotiations would begin late today in the Egyptian Red Sea resort of Taba, venue for talks on interim peace arrangements in 1995.

webTitle: Tories' backer offers £10m

fields.headline: Tories' backer offers £10m
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories' new donor has offered to double his staggering £5 million gift because William Hague needs the money 'pretty badly'.
fields.body:
The Tories' new donor has offered to double his staggering £5 million gift because William Hague needs the money 'pretty badly'.

Stuart Wheeler, the 65-year-old betting entrepreneur, said he had told Hague his money should be spent going 'flat out to win the election'.

He was prepared to offer up to £10 million - two-thirds of the cost of a campaign - if necessary, in a move raising serious questions over the dependence of a party on one person.

Although Wheeler has insisted he is not highly political and will not try to pull strings, he has strong anti-European views - he is an old friend and bridge partner of Rodney Leach, chair of the anti-euro group Business for Sterling - and admitted he would withdraw his support if a pro-European like Kenneth Clarke became leader.

'They need a lot of money pretty badly,' Wheeler said in an interview with the Sunday Telegraph. 'I think I used the expression to William Hague that "there may be more". But I wouldn't give more than £10 million.'

Wheeler, who as chairman of the spread betting company IG Index is worth £90 million, said he decided to make a donation when he read about how Labour had banked £6 million from three separate backers.

But the Labour party condemned the new offer. 'The Tories were the first to complain about our £2 million donations and attacked us for relying on a few wealthy people,' said one official.

'A donation of £10 million from one person would fund the Tories for virtually the whole campaign and dwarfs anything we've had.'

webTitle: Charlotte Rampling: The eyes still have it

fields.headline: The eyes still have it
fields.standfirst: Men, especially film directors, have always been seduced by her ineffable charms. After the break-up of her marriage and a nervous breakdown, Charlotte Rampling talks about her latest conquest
fields.trailText: Men, especially film directors, have always been seduced by her ineffable charms. After the break-up of her marriage and a nervous breakdown, Charlotte Rampling talks about her latest conquest
fields.body:
Charlotte Rampling hasn't changed. 'Yes, it's quite strange,' she says when I tell her this. 'I think I'm going to be like my father, who never really changed. I mean, he got older, but he's remained the same. Some people do that.' She still has that mysterious, feline grace with which she made her name, still has what her sometime co-star Dirk Bogarde described as 'the Look', an epithet not for her Sixties style, but for a certain action in her eyes which could, he said, express horror with extreme power. Visconti showed his cameraman how to frame her face, close up, like a visor, with chin and forehead lopped off.

Today, those eyes seem a screen of smoke or steel; she has a faraway gaze even when she is looking straight at you. There is an almost ethereal otherworldliness about her, and a contrastingly gritty sexuality. She has been living in France for more than a quarter of a century and says she prefers to be a foreigner, 'not to be completely connected anywhere'. The sultry, honeyed voice, the casually held cigarillo, the vague and thoughtful manner of her speech - these are the emblems of Rampling's persona.

She speaks in abstractions, and everything is either thrown into doubt or made so universal it becomes ordinary: 'It's like life,' she says broadly. 'How much actually do you know about much, really? Not very much'; or 'I'm not uncertain about things... I'm uncertain about everything, so I'm not really uncertain about anything.' It's hard to know whether to take these musings as barriers or communications, and difficult to see if they are the open-ended constructs of a philosophical mind or the flaky waftings of a Norma Desmond.

I try to navigate through them, interpreting her words according to what I think I know about her life. Pinning them down feels like a job of unusual indiscretion: initially, when speaking about her sister's early death, Rampling comments with a generalising flourish that 'everybody' is in mourning 'at some point'. Her break-up five years ago from her husband, the composer Jean-Michel Jarre, was 'difficult, like everybody's separation is difficult, but it's absolutely fine'. Her depression was just 'confusion... nothing special'.

Rampling's latest role, in François Ozon's Under the Sand, is that of a woman in denial. It is a wonderful film and, for Rampling, a remarkable return to form. Rampling's character - Marie, a sensual, apparently self-assured woman in her fifties - and her husband set off for their usual summer holiday by the shore, but on the first day, as she is sunbathing, her husband goes for a swim and disappears. Has he left her? Has he drowned? Was it an accident or suicide? Ozon, a young hotshot who directed Sitcom and Water Drops on Burning Rocks, filmed this first section without knowing what would come next.

Six months later, Rampling returned to shoot the rest of the movie, in which she denies her husband's death. What appears at first to be a mystery turns out to be a psychological portrait and, although it's not certain quite to what extent, the denial portion of the film was written in response to Rampling's performance in the earlier sequence.

Unlike most actors, who like to keep their identities separate from the parts they play, Rampling elides the distinction between herself and her roles. You can only play a character if you can find that person somewhere in you, she says, or if you feel ready to expose that part of yourself. Of the Ozon role, she comments: 'She could be me. I'm not acting Marie, I'm just being her.' Perhaps, then, Rampling has already said it all, since through her films it's possible not only to trace her life, but her moods as well, the many facets of her changing self.

Rampling made her screen debut in Richard Lester's 1965 sex comedy, The Knack, And How To Get It. She was 19. She had wanted to be a singer and, as teenagers, she and her sister had an act in which they sang French songs (their father worked in the army, so both had been to French schools on their travels). But when they were hired by a nightclub, their father put a stop to it and sent Charlotte to secretarial school. She was spotted in a typing pool and cast in an ad for Cadbury's chocolate; the movies came soon after. Her first main part was in a Boulting brothers comedy, Rotten to the Core, but she really shot to fame a year later, in 1966, when she played Lynn Redgrave's catty friend in Georgy Girl. She felt, she now says, 'very much of my time', and she had a look to go with it: sexy, coltish, skinny, free. She was a mini-skirted, Mini Coopered Chelsea girl, and she thought being famous was 'great fun'.

But the Sixties turned into the Seventies very dramatically. When Rampling was 21, her sister, who was only two years older, died of a brain haemorrhage and, as she puts it, 'my mother almost died out of grief'. 'So,' she comments with a bitter laugh, 'things suddenly weren't swinging any more, quite like they were. I think that's when I tried to understand what the hell was going on, and took parts like Night Porter, and other parts that sort of delved into the human psyche - they weren't just entertainment films. I didn't want to entertain any more. I became very aware of the other side of life, not just having fun.'

Luchino Visconti cast her in The Damned as a young wife who is sent to a concentration camp. A few years later, she survived the camp in Night Porter, still perhaps her most famous role. She played the wife of a successful orchestra conductor who recognises Dirk Bogarde, the night porter of their Viennese hotel, as the Nazi who had been her lover and oppressor during the war. The gruelling flashbacks end up matching the forward progress of the film, as the twisted lovers return irretrievably to their former selves.

She became a Bacall for the Seventies when she starred opposite Robert Mitchum in a remake of Raymond Chandler's Farewell, My Lovely, and she kicked off the Eighties as an entrancing depressive in Woody Allen's Stardust Memories ('I think they've been putting something wonderful in your lithium,' Allen whispers in her ear). This, perhaps perversely, is my favourite character of hers. In the film, it is said of her that 'two days a month she was the most fabulous woman in the world. The rest of the time she was a basket case'.

'Yeah,' Rampling says when I quote the phrase to her, 'those are Woody Allen's lines. But that's sort of me anyway. It was very much me, that part.' In her review of the film, Pauline Kael wrote that Rampling 'suggests a decaying goddess', and Woody Allen, who once said his ideal dinner party would include Rampling and Kafka, cast her because, as he put it, 'she reeks from neurosis'. Towards the end of the film, there is an extraordinary sequence of jump-cuts, a Bergmanesque series of close-ups of her face as she rambles and weeps, her moods shifting, her mind shutting down. 'It took a long time to get that,' Rampling now explains. 'It took a long time to work out how you show somebody breaking down.'

When I ask her about her own depression, however, she says: 'I didn't think I was depressive at all. I thought I was very confused, but I thought that was what life was about.' Rampling had a nervous breakdown in 1991. She says now that pure psychoanalysis doesn't suit her, that there are 'other ways you can jump-cut a bit, rather like the scene in the Woody Allen movie, and project people into their own reality quicker', though she is known to have spent some time in a psychiatric clinic in London.

'I thought life was not comfortable,' she goes on, 'and you were always on edge and you were always having difficulties with most things. There really weren't many times when you felt that you were confident about anything. But I thought that was what most people felt. It was nothing special.'

I suggest that she must have managed to avoid the loneliness of it, if she thought everyone felt like that. 'Well,' she replies, switching into the second person, 'no, you do. Yeah, you feel alone... also, at that time, there was very little help of the kind there is now, in terms of recognising symptoms in people and being able to talk about them. And so you think, well, it's either just me, or life will come along and help me out, things will happen that will make it different - and quite often they do.'

Rampling first married in 1972, to Brian Southcombe, her manager. They had a son, but by 1977 she had left him for Jean-Michel Jarre and had a child with Jarre. Along with his baby daughter by his previous wife, the new Jarre family set up home in a grand mansion in Versailles. They were the perfect couple of the moment - glamorous, jet-set, successful, in love, and they welcomed people into their house which, with its lawns that swept down to the Seine and its chic art deco furniture, was much remarked upon. Their separation 'evolved', Rampling says, 'over the last five or six years'. Jarre stayed in Versailles and she moved to Paris. Both are now in new relationships.

I ask her if the process has made her feel disappointed in marriage. 'No, not at all,' she says. 'We have a fantastic marriage - I don't see why I should divorce - I mean eventually, if I want to live with another man, but if not it doesn't really make much sense - if he doesn't want to, if I don't want to...

'Nothing stays the same,' she explains, 'but it doesn't mean to say it's been a mistake or that you even have to question it.'

Whether or not you take this demeanour at face value, Rampling certainly seems to have arrived at a fortress-like strength. If, as she does, you conjoin her parts and her personality, this is a character unrecognisable to those acquainted with her former neurotic incarnation. I tell her she seems impressively unworried about things.

'I'm not worried,' she replies, 'it's true. I was, highly, but now I'm not. It changes as you go along. And the main reason it changes is you decide not to be affected by it. Because you're the only person who has to hang in there with it: if you hate your husband, you have to live with that hate - he's not living with it, he's gone, and you have to live with the hate and the revenge. Unless you go and kill him, and then you're going to be in prison, so what are you actually going to do about it? If you see me calm now it's because you have to turn it right round. Because nobody gives a stuff what you're feeling like, really - nobody, probably in the whole world. That's what I've thought when I've felt really upset about things that have happened to me. It just eats away at you. Suffering is only subjective.'

She thinks for a moment, the bitter toughness melting into something else. 'You see, if you say, "Right, so your husband leaves" - he didn't leave me, it was a natural thing. And actually, what he did for me and how much he helped me no one will ever, ever know. And he needed a break. He didn't leave me, he just needed a break. It so happened that on that break things happened. He might have fallen in love with another woman, but I mean he might then fall out of love with another woman... it doesn't break what we have - that's eternal as far as I'm concerned.'

Rampling has taken a long break from filming. 'I didn't want to expose myself, that was all,' she says, 'and my business is total exposure.' She worked in television, things for which she wouldn't have to do publicity, keeping 'very much in the shadows' because she 'didn't want anyone to take any notice of me'.

The recent small parts she has played, such as Miss Havisham in the BBC adaptation of Great Expectations and Helena Bonham Carter's Aunt Maud in Wings of the Dove, have been older, ungenerous women. She was, until now, invisible as herself.

But she has hit a new streak. Earlier this month she was awarded an OBE, 'for services to acting and UK-French cultural relations'. Her character in Under the Sand is, as she puts it, 'much more open and gentle, and shows her fragilities more than other characters I've played'. Rampling says she is 'more willing now to show a lot of stuff that I wouldn't have shown before - it was not for the cinema'.

She is moving on - perhaps (or perhaps not) protecting herself from the past as she goes. She does not, for example, watch her old films ('One day I suppose I will - you need that emotional distance from it'), and when I ask her what she likes to read, she reflects that: 'I don't read biographies very much, perhaps I should. I don't like biographies. It's really rather funny, that, isn't it? Why don't I like to know about people's lives?'

It's loaded rhetoric, and though it is offered up with a casual laugh, her smouldering eyes can still only be seen through a haze of smoke, as Rampling takes comfort in being a stranger.

Under the Sand opens in France next month and here in April. Charlotte Rampling will be interviewed at the NFT in March

webTitle: They're playing our book

fields.headline: They're playing our book
fields.standfirst: The simple bit was writing a thriller with her husband. The complications began when Hollywood came calling, using Joseph Fiennes and Heather Graham as the bait...
fields.trailText: The simple bit was writing a thriller with her husband. The complications began when Hollywood came calling, using Joseph Fiennes and Heather Graham as the bait...
fields.body:
It is blue, cold, clean weather in the City of London. The streets gleam and the pale sun shines down between the corridor of tall buildings. People hurry about their daily business: men and women in suits or jeans; people carrying shopping bags, briefcases, newspapers, gloves; heads down against the wind. Cars, double-decker buses, lorries and cabs drive past. A horn sounds. At the traffic light across the road a bunch of pedestrians wait for the signal to cross. A young man in a battered leather jacket, with dark hair and dark eyes, stands in front of them, next to a tall, blonde woman with a sweet and lovely face. Strangers. They glance at each other and their eyes lock. You can almost feel the tremor of shock that passes through them.

The lights change, and they step out into the road together. At the other side they separate, but they do not stop looking at each other. They cannot. Is this love, this sudden jolting recognition of the other? Or madness? Can life so turn on a single glance, and everything that went before become muted and dull?

Can falling in love take a fraction of a second and yet bring the patient work of years crashing down?

At last, the young woman with the entranced face goes into the building where she works; he watches as she walks away from him and disappears from view.

I watch this scene - over and over again I watch it - and it feels infinitely strange to me. I know it and I don't know it. It is vivid and yet at the same time it feels far-off, a bit like a shred of a dream, or something lying underwater, shining and mysteriously refracted. It feels like memory.

'Cut!' shouts the director, and Joseph Fiennes and Heather Graham turn round, retrace their steps and it all begins again. There are hundreds of extras; a large production crew. The camera rolls along a specially-constructed track beside the two actors. People throw buckets of water over the road to keep it wet (in case it rains later and destroys continuity). Heather Graham snags her tights and has to change them. Someone else fiddles with the collar of Fiennes' jacket, making an invisible difference.

Everyone seems to know what they're doing. But I don't quite know what I'm doing. I watch the scene on the director's monitor, and it looks quite different from the scene being acted out a few feet away on the street. The camera changes everything.

Two-and-a-quarter years ago, Sean and I were driving to my parents' house in Shropshire. My mother had been very ill, frightening all of us. I had returned from our summer holiday early to be with her, but now she seemed to be slowly recovering (fingers crossed and pray to a God I don't believe in). We were in the middle of writing our third Nicci French (Nicci Gerrard and Sean French) novel together, a psychological thriller. It was going all right, but slowly, without that sense of urgency and fire. And it had been pushed into the background a bit by other events.

One of us (who? we can't remember any more) said to the other something about the blurred line between love and madness, passion and danger. Maybe we were discussing a recent case of stalking that had, perhaps, been in the news. Or we were arguing about A Midsummer Night's Dream, where the lovers go into a dark forest and let wild dreams grip them. Or about our own early relationship. Or maybe it's just one of those subjects that two people who talk to each other a lot discuss when on a long car journey towards an uncertain destination. And one of us said to the other: that would make a good basis for a novel. So the discussion became Killing Me Softly (except that wasn't its name, then).

We immediately jettisoned the work-in-progress and wrote the novel very quickly. It was the story of an English woman called Alice - who has now become the American Heather Graham, walking across the road - who has everything she thinks she wants (good job, nice and kind and reliable boyfriend, close group of friends) and throws it all up because she meets the gaze of a stranger on a crowded street. We wanted to express, in the novel, the weirdness of falling in love, its disorder and irrationality and danger.

I think that most of us have in some way or other experienced love as risk and loss of control. We let ourselves trust someone we don't really know. There's a click. We change our lives because of the way someone looks at us, smiles at us, listens.

Later, we must come out of the dark woods and return to ordinary life. We get mortgages, children, bank accounts, domestic squabbles and family routines. Our heart doesn't thump all the time. But it all begins with desire and longing and the sense that we can upturn our own life and begin afresh. So, in our story, Alice falls head-over-heels in love with Adam and puts herself in danger.

The process of getting a novel published is partly about letting go. Sean and I wrote it together, passing it to and fro on our computers, and it was a secret, intimate exchange - particularly so since the novel's subject was erotic intimacy and trust. Then (in more or less this order) it was sent out to our agent, our editors, copy editors, family, friends, reviewers and finally our readers. Our grip on the book weakened; we let it go.

That's the theory at least - but it's nothing compared to the letting go that takes place when a book is turned into a film. First the book was optioned by Montecito Pictures, a new production company created by Ivan Reitman (the director of Animal House and Ghostbusters) and Tom Pollock (who for many years was head of Universal Pictures). All that was a simple, uninhibited delight. 'Hollywood', you think, and you drink champagne (or sparkling wine, probably), and allow yourself a fantasy cast list, a dream of attending some glam premiere in a gown that miraculously makes you look like a film star yourself, a photograph in your addled head that shows you lying by a pool somewhere drinking cocktails.

Everyone tells you not to get too excited (because few books ever make it beyond the option stage). You tell everybody not to get too excited (because ditto). You try to be casual about it. Cool and intelligent. No chance. The novel was optioned before it was published and we immediately ran into a problem. Montecito Pictures did not like its title: Crazy For Me. They thought it sounded too like a comedy or a musical. They wanted us to change it. For the book as well as for the film.

We didn't mind that, as long as we could come up with a new name that everyone liked. We talked about it all the time, like expectant parents with a dictionary of names. We picked the brains of everyone we met. My eldest son was determined, for some unfathomable reason, that is should be called The Bus Driver. webTitle: Cowboys and Englishmen

fields.headline: Cowboys and Englishmen
fields.standfirst: The Claim is an epic western with a difference. It's made by a British team - and the story is by Thomas Hardy
fields.trailText: The Claim is an epic western with a difference. It's made by a British team - and the story is by Thomas Hardy
fields.body:
It is the defining moment in The Claim: Daniel Dillon (Peter Mullan), boss of the California gold rush town of Kingdom Come, is on his way to his wedding. And he is travelling on top of the house he and his bride will live in, a mansion being dragged through the snow-covered forest by the townsfolk who owe Kingdom Come's founder everything.

It is an astonishing sequence, and an event that speaks of Dillon's pride, and the power that is about to slip through his fingers. It also illustrates the sheer ambition of the British team who made the film: director Michael Winterbottom, his producer Andrew Eaton and writer Frank Cottrell Boyce (best known for Hilary And Jackie).

'The financiers kept trying to get us to take that sequence out of the script,' Eaton says, 'Like "do you really need to do this?" It was such a brilliant idea that we were loathe to abandon. The day we shot that was the best day of the film.'

'These things become totemic,' adds Cottrell Boyce. 'It shows you are still making the movie you want to make. And it looks great, just fantastic.'

That it looks fantastic is not surprising. Having a truly cinematic eye is one of the things that marks out 39-year-old Winterbottom, born and bred in Blackburn, from many of his British contemporaries. Mike Leigh and Ken Loach aside, Winterbottom is the most consistently interesting director based in Britain, switching from the big international scope of Welcome To Sarajevo to the seaside town psychodrama I Want You, and from the fiercely contemporary London of Wonderland to 1860s California for The Claim.

His films use the same social realist acting tradition as Loach and Leigh but have the visual edge. The Claim, which also stars the impressive Wes Bentley (the brooding boy-next-door from American Beauty), Nastassja Kinski, Sarah Polley and Milla Jovovich, is set between the Gold Rush and the coming of the railroads. It is a revisionist western based on Thomas Hardy's The Mayor Of Casterbridge. In this version, the life of town patriarch Dillon unravels with the return of the wife (Kinski) and daughter (Polley) he sold for a mining claim 20 years earlier.

'Western is not a fantastically appropriate description of the film,' Winterbottom argues. 'It's not constructed around the actors fighting a duel that resolves the story.'

Eaton, who made two TV documentaries with Lindsay Anderson about John Ford, disagrees. 'The first day we were filming there were all these guys going down the street on horseback, or dressed up as cowboys, and a guy wearing a big sheriff's badge, and we're going, "This is a western." We couldn't pretend otherwise.'

In its setting of a snow-covered mining town, with its town boss and its sturdy prostitutes, the film The Claim most resembles is Robert Altman's stunning deconstruction of the genre, McCabe And Mrs Miller. The Claim, though, has less contempt for its characters. Maybe that is where Hardy comes in.

'Westerns are great at grabbing stuff,' says Cottrell Boyce. 'There are westerns based on Shakespeare, Stagecoach is based on a Guy de Maupassant story, there are lots of westerns ripped off from Japanese sources, so to use Hardy is part of the tradition. Hardy is all about fate, and westerns tend to be about fate. Hardy has that epic sweep, and we wanted to make an epic western. And also, we're English guys making a western, so we needed to bring in a big English literary gun. But it's not based very closely on the book.'

The first time the trio tried to make the film - before Wonderland - it all went wrong. 'We were going to shoot it in the French Alps,' Eaton says. 'We had spent about a million quid of Polygram's money. We were all set to ship the sets off to France. At the eleventh-hour Polygram decided they didn't think the cast we had was exciting enough, so they pulled the plug.'

Winterbottom was chastened: 'It was late in the day when the money disappeared, and we went away and did another film. It didn't feel like something we could carry on with.'

Along the way, names like Robert De Niro, Isabella Adjani, Winona Ryder and even Madonna came and went. When the project restarted, production moved to British Columbia. Winterbottom was struck by one trip to a ghost town. 'It was once the biggest town west of Chicago and north of San Francisco and is now in the middle of nowhere. We had to fly, stay overnight in this logging town, then drive, and then walk up to this town. When you have that experience just to recce the place, you feel you have to get that into the film: how hard it is to get to these places, let alone build them or dig for gold. The people who went there had no expertise: they were people who lived in cities, came from Europe, heard there was gold and knew no more than we do about how to find it or how to mine it. They just set off and hoped for the best.'

Films like this are rarely masterminded from the UK. Cottrell Boyce thinks he knows why: 'Culturally, the British film industry avoids disappointment by aiming low, going for the charm of the minor key, the offbeat, the provincial. So to do this big, operatic thing is a dare. And I think maybe there is only Michael with the chops to try, and still be true to himself. There is no mistaking his work. I hope he does get some credit for the sheer courage of making it. There are lots of talented filmmakers in Britain, but not a lot of brave ones.'

The wearying experience of making the film is chronicled in immense detail - down to the exact length of footage shot - on a pioneering website, which also allowed visitors to comment on the script, help rename the film - previously Kingdom Come - and see daily rushes as they were processed. 'I wasn't on the set and I was sometimes able to look at the rushes before Michael,' Cottrell Boyce marvels.

'It was Michael's idea,' Eaton says. 'He said, "Why don't we do a site for the film, and make it really naked and open so you'd see the innards of a film?"'

With their western out of the way Winterbottom, Cottrell Boyce and Eaton have already moved on to something truly different: 24-Hour Party People, the story of Anthony Wilson and Factory Records, starring Steve Coogan as the mercurial Mancunian entrepreneur. Eaton explains the unlikely birthplace of the project. 'We were in a little logging town in British Columbia, in a redneck bar, and we were saying it would be fun to have a lot of music, but trying to avoid people bursting into song. And then we talked about Factory.'

Cottrell Boyce sees it as more evidence of Winterbottom's vision. 'You can imagine lots of British filmmakers doing the Ian Curtis story, or the Happy Mondays story, or the Hacienda. I can't imagine anyone else who would say, "Let's do '76 to '92, the whole lot in 90 minutes. There is a whole history of Britain in there." After all, once you've pulled a house up a mountain, anything - including rebuilding the Hacienda - should be easy.'

The Claim opens on 2 February

Great inspirations: movies with a literary source

Red River (1948) The classic John Wayne Western was a reworking of Charles Nordhoff's Mutiny on the Bounty.

Forbidden Planet (1956) Enduring sci-fi version of Shakespeare's The Tempest. Space commander Leslie Nielsen finds a megalomaniac scientist and his daughter on an isolated colony.

The Gambler (1974) James Caan stars as a apparently successful academic with a self-destructive gambling habit. Based on Dostoevsky's novella.

Roxanne (1987) Steve Martin updated and reworked Rostand's Cyrano de Bergerac into a sweet romantic comedy. Martin starred as the cerebral fireman who falls in love with Daryl Hannah.

Clueless (1994) Smart parody of LA teen mores and consumerism that was inspired by Jane Austen's Emma. Alicia Silverstone wants to become popular and fall in love.

Ten Things I Hate About You (1999) High school update of The Taming of the Shrew pits stubborn Larisa Oleynik against suave Heath Ledger.

'I wasn't on the set and I was sometimes able to look at the rushes before Michael,' Cottrell Boyce marvels. 'It was Michael's idea,' Eaton says. Eaton explains the unlikely birthplace of the project. 'We were in a little logging town in British Columbia, in a redneck bar, and we were saying it would be fun to have a lot of music, but trying to avoid people bursting into song. And then we talked about Factory.' Cottrell Boyce sees it as more evidence of Winterbottom's vision. 'You can imagine lots of British filmmakers doing the Ian Curtis story, or the Happy Mondays story, or the Hacienda. I can't imagine anyone else who would say, "Let's do '76 to '92, the whole lot in 90 minutes. There is a whole history of Britain in there." After all, once you've pulled a house up a mountain, anything - including rebuilding the Hacienda - should be easy.' The Claim opens on 2 February Great inspirations: movies with a literary source Red River (1948) The classic John Wayne Western was a reworking of Charles Nordhoff's Mutiny on the Bounty. Forbidden Planet (1956) Enduring sci-fi version of Shakespeare's The Tempest. Space commander Leslie Nielsen finds a megalomaniac scientist and his daughter on an isolated colony. The Gambler (1974) James Caan stars as a apparently successful academic with a self-destructive gambling habit. Based on Dostoevsky's novella. Roxanne (1987) Steve Martin updated and reworked Rostand's Cyrano de Bergerac into a sweet romantic comedy. Martin starred as the cerebral fireman who falls in love with Daryl Hannah. Clueless (1994) Smart parody of LA teen mores and consumerism that was inspired by Jane Austen's Emma. Alicia Silverstone wants to become popular and fall in love. Ten Things I Hate About You (1999) High school update of The Taming of the Shrew pits stubborn Larisa Oleynik against suave Heath Ledger.

webTitle: Last quill and testament

fields.headline: Last quill and testament
fields.standfirst: In his latest screen incarnation, the Marquis de Sade is less a sex maniac, more an obsessive writer
fields.trailText: Philip French: There's a splendid succession of scenes in which de Sade, deprived of quills and paper, manages to keep on writing
fields.body:
The Marquis de Sade, the subject of Philip Kaufman's film Quills, has been provoking, enraging and puzzling people for more than two centuries now. Libertine or libertarian? Liberator or oppressor? Dispenser of lies or revealer of truths? Even entering the language has not tamed him. His chief influence on the cinema had been through his admirer Luis Buñuel, whose films (even Robinson Crusoe) are steeped in de Sade's teachings.

But there has been a succession of movies touching on de Sade these past 30-odd years. The Russian ambassador in Kubrick's Dr Strangelove is called DeSadesky. Peter Brook made a remarkable film of Peter Weiss's The Persecution and Assassination of Jean-Paul Marat as Performed by the Inmates of the Asylum at Charenton under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade, a debate about revolution that had been the highlight of Brook's RSC Theatre of Cruelty Season in 1964.

In the 1969 American-German co-production De Sade, the marquis (a neurotic Keir Dullea) reviews his early life and the malign influence of his depraved uncle, the Abbé de Sade (John Huston), and in 1990 there was the surreal French comedy, Marquis, set in the Bastille on the eve of the French Revolution, with the actors wearing masks and de Sade conducting conversations with his penis. Most controversial of all Sadean films is Salo, Pasolini's transposition of The 120 Days of Sodom from pre-revolutionary France to the last days of Mussolini's Italy, which was banned from exhibition in Britain for 25 years but has now been granted an '18' certificate.

Adapted by Doug Wright from his own play, Quills is set in the early nineteenth century when de Sade (Geoffrey Rush), now in his late sixties, is imprisoned among the lunatics at Charenton, but is respected by its director, the Abbé Coulmier (Joaquin Phoenix) who encourages him to write plays for his fellow inmates. The story is, however, largely fictitious, a sort of fantasia in the life, work and ideas of de Sade, that alternates between the tragic and the farcical, the absurd and the almost sublime.

Kaufman's movies have always had an anti-authoritarian streak - he made his name with The Great Northfield Minnesota Raid, a western celebrating the James-Younger gang, and he played off the maverick Chuck Yeager against the conformist astronauts in The Right Stuff and made the literary rebel Henry Miller the hero of Henry and June. One can see the appeal for him of the marquis.

Rush's de Sade is a run-down aristocrat, a subverter of order, reckless enemy of authority and propriety, a revolutionary who doesn't believe in progress. He's an old roué whose deeds now take place in the mind, less a sex maniac than a graphomaniac, compelled to write. He's first seen in a brilliant, brief prologue observing from a window what we take to be a woman being happily ravaged by a masked man. The camera draws back to reveal she's an aristocrat about to be guillotined, and as the sadistic crowd roars, Kaufman cuts from her blood dripping from the blade to de Sade writing with red ink, the word and deed inseparable.

A simple laundry girl, Madeleine (Kate Winslet), smuggles the marquis's erotic fictions from the asylum, handing them to an equestrian messenger from his publisher. Napoleon, affronted by the books and their erotic politics, is persuaded not to order his death but to send the vicious Dr Royer-Collard (Michael Caine in chillingly malevolent form) to Charenton to effect a cure.

As monstrous as the doctor brought in to attend to the king in Alan Bennett's The Madness of George III, Collard is venal, self-seeking and a natural sadist with a child bride right out of one of the marquis's novels. A battle of wits ensues. He's initially opposed by the bien-pensant Abbé Coulmier, but eventually the self-deluding representatives of State and Church join forces against the self-destructive de Sade. Through his very intransigence, the marquis wins at several levels, though he's physically destroyed in the process.

There's a splendid succession of scenes in which de Sade, deprived of quills and paper, manages to keep on writing. He first writes in wine on bed linen for Madeleine (a virgin who lives imaginatively through Sade's wild fictions) to transcribe. Then, deprived of sheets and wine, he dictates the book sentence by sentence to the madman in the next cell, who passes it down the row until Madeleine puts in on paper at the end of the line. 'They might even improve it,' de Sade says about these lunatics transmitting his work. Finally, left naked in a dungeon, he writes on the walls in his own excrement. Quills strikes occasional false notes. One is not always sure whether certain lines are simply banal or are ironic jokes about banality. But it's a daring film in the ideas it embraces and in the manner in which it dramatises them.

Shot on location at Sutton Hoo, in the streets of Oxford, and at the Old Naval College, Greenwich, with the jail scenes filmed at Pinewood Studios, it has been given an elegant, stylised look by its production designer Martin Childs (who won an Oscar for Shakespeare in Love) and the Dutch cinematographer Rogier Stoffers. There's also an impressive score by Stephen Warbeck.
