webTitle: Kabila's killer is named as ex-boy soldier

fields.headline: Kabila's killer is named as ex-boy soldier
fields.trailText: The killer of Congolese president Laurent Kabila was identified last night as an 18-year-old former boy soldier, who shot his leader through the head after summoning him from a meeting. The youth was then shot dead himself.
fields.byline: James Astill in Kinshasa and agencies
fields.body:
The killer of Congolese president Laurent Kabila was identified last night as an 18-year-old former boy soldier, who shot his leader through the head after summoning him from a meeting. The youth was then shot dead himself.

Named only as Rashidi, the teenager had apparently been a follower of Kabila since the uprising in 1997 against President Mobutu Sese Seko.

The tentative identifcation of the killer, who shot Kabila in the courtyard of his Marble Palace, cast little light on the motives for his murder. Many observers suspect Kabila was killed as part of a wider plot.

His body, in a white-and-gold casket draped in the flag of the Democratic Republic of Congo, was flown to his home town of Lubumbashi yesterday, as it was announced that his son Joseph, 31, would be formally sworn in as his successor on Tuesday.

In the first official account of Kabila's shooting at his hilltop palace in Kinshasa last Tuesday, Justice Minister Mwenze Kongolo said the president had been talking to an economic adviserbefore the assassin entered the room.

'The guard came in and it was natural for Kabila to listen to what he had to say,' Mwenze told a news conference in Kinshasa, explaining why the president had leaned forwards as the gunman opened fire.

'One of the bullets went right behind the ear and came right behind the ribs. I think that's the one that killed him,' Mwenze told a news conference in Kinshasa. 'Two other bullets went in the stomach but were not fatal.

'Those are the closest bodyguards that the president had. They are usually armed. The door was open so that air could circulate,' he said.

Kabila, former revolutionary, dilettante and brothel keeper, who was thrust into the limelight as a figurehead for the invading Rwandan and Ugandan forces (with whom he latter fell out), will lie in state before being flown to the capital forthe funeral.

A band played sombre music as military and government officials filed past the open coffin displayed in front of the June 30 Building, where his hand-picked National Assembly met. Congolese television reported that the cortège had trouble getting to its destination because thousands of people wanted to touch the coffin.

It emerged that some West ern diplomats in Kinshasa had reported suspicions last week that the killing of Kabila showed signs of careful planning.

Kabila's body had been loaded on to the presidential aircraft under the eyes of his former ally, President Robert Mugabe, as a Zimbabwean military band honoured the assassinated leader.

A Congolese delegation escorted Kabila's body back to Congo. A state funeral is planned for Tuesday in Kinshasa. Mugabe, one of Kabila's key military allies, declared three days of mourning in Zimbabwe.

Mugabe said his troops would continue to defend Congo from 'acts of aggression', the state-controlled media reported yesterday.

Zimbabwe has 11,000 troops, backed by air power and armour, fighting alongside government forces in Congo's two-and-a-half-year civil war.

Angola and Namibia, which also back the government, have said that they too will keep their troops in Congo for the time being.

In Kinshasa the mood was one of resignation.'What do we care about generals and politicians?' said one shopkeeper, nervously on his guard against the thousands of government agents and informers that infest the city.

'We do not mind a coup that is for leaders. But we are afraid that, if the army does not accept the change, or if they are not paid, they will start looting.'

webTitle: 'If we do not lead the cause of freedom, it will not be led'

fields.headline: 'If we do not lead the cause of freedom, it will not be led'
fields.standfirst:
This is an edited extract from President Bush's inaugural address.

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: This is an edited extract from President Bush's inaugural address.
fields.body:
This peaceful transfer of authority is rare in history, yet common in our country. With a simple oath, we affirm old traditions, and make new beginnings. As I begin, I thank President Clinton for his service to our nation. And I thank Vice-President Gore for a contest conducted with spirit, and ended with grace.

I am honoured and humbled to stand here, where so many of America's leaders have come before me, and so many will follow.

Through much of the last century, America's faith in freedom and democracy was a rock in a raging sea. Now it is a seed upon the wind, taking root in many nations. Our democratic faith is more than the creed of our country, it is the inborn hope of our humanity; an ideal we carry but do not own, a trust we bear and pass along. And even after nearly 225 years, we have a long way yet to travel.

While many of our citizens prosper, others doubt the promise - even the justice - of our own country. The ambitions of some Americans are limited by failing schools, and hidden prejudice, and the circumstances of their birth. And sometimes our differ ences run so deep, it seems we share a continent, but not a country.

We do not accept this, and will not allow it. Our unity, our union, is the serious work of leaders and citizens in every generation. And this is my solemn pledge: I will work to build a single nation of justice and opportunity.

Today we affirm a new commitment to live out our nation's promise through civility, courage, compassion and character.

Some seem to believe that our politics can afford to be petty because, in a time of peace, the stakes of our debates appear small. But the stakes, for America, are never small. If our country does not lead the cause of freedom, it will not be led.

Together, we will reclaim America's schools, before ignorance and apathy claim more young lives. We will reform Social Security and Medicare, sparing our children from struggles we have the power to prevent. We will reduce taxes, to recover the momentum of our economy and reward the effort and enterprise of working Americans. We will build our defences beyond challenge, lest weakness invite challenge. We will confront weapons of mass destruction, so that a new century is spared new horrors.

The enemies of liberty and our country should make no mistake, America remains engaged in the world, by history and by choice, shaping a balance of power that favours freedom. We will defend our allies and our interests. We will show purpose without arrogance. We will meet aggression and bad faith with resolve and strength. And to all nations, we will speak for the values that gave our nation birth.

In the quiet of American conscience, we know that deep, persistent poverty is unworthy of our nation's promise. And whatever our views of its cause, we can agree that children at risk are not at fault. Abandonment and abuse are not acts of God, they are failures of love. And the proliferation of prisons, however necessary, is no substitute for hope and order in our souls.

Many in our country do not know the pain of poverty. But we can listen to those who do. And I can pledge our nation to a goal: When we see that wounded traveller on the road to Jericho, we will not pass to the other side...

What you do is as important as anything government does. I ask you to seek a common good beyond your comfort; to defend needed reforms against easy attacks; to serve your nation, beginning with your neighbour. I ask you to be citizens. Citizens, not spectators. Citizens, not subjects. Responsible citizens, building communities of service and a nation of character...

After the Declaration of Independence was signed, Virginia statesman John Page wrote to Thomas Jefferson: 'We know the Race is not to the swift nor the Battle to the Strong. Do you not think an Angel rides in the Whirlwind and directs this Storm?'...

This work continues. This story goes on. And an angel still rides in the whirlwind and directs this storm.

God bless you, and God bless our country.

webTitle: Osborne's widow looks on in anger as playwright is 'penalised for dying'

fields.headline: Osborne's widow looks on in anger as playwright is 'penalised for dying'
fields.standfirst: 'It seems bizarre to wait until just before the book's deadline to raise this matter'
fields.trailText: 'It seems bizarre to wait until just before the book's deadline to raise this matter'.
fields.body:
In life John Osborne was full of fury. His writing brimmed with vitriol and his first great stage hit, Look Back In Anger, inspired a whole literary generation of 'angry young men'. 'Anger is good,' he once declared.

Now, six years after the playwright's death, his work is once again at the centre of a storm of resentment. Osborne's widow, Helen, has received a 'bizarre and unfeeling' letter from her late husband's publishers, Faber and Faber, which has astonished her and many of the playwright's oldest friends.

The letter, from managing director Tony Faber, requested repayment of the full figure of the advance - £20,000 - that Osborne had been paid for the third volume of his autobiography.

'As part of a general review exercise,' the letter read, 'we have been going through the outstanding advances on undelivered titles. According to our records, Autobiography Vol. III Young Men Forget by John Osborne falls into this category.'

The first two volumes of Osborne's autobiography, A Better Class of Person and Almost A Gentleman, were published in 1981 and 1991, respectively. The third volume was under way, and the notes the author had prepared for it during his final illness are now kept at the University of Texas.

By taking action to recover the money in the last few months of 2000, the publisher appears to have hoped to act before a six-year cut-off point for repayment. As far as Mrs Osborne is concerned, it has also conveniently forgotten the internationally renowned work, including the plays The Entertainer, Inadmissible Evidence and A Patriot For Me, which it has benefited from publishing.

'He seems to be being penalised for dying,' the theatre director Richard Eyre said. 'They should remember that at one time he was certainly a major earner for Faber.'

Mrs Osborne's outrage has been shared by several of her husband's former friends and fellow writers, including the playwrights Harold Pinter and David Hare. She has also been advised by the theatrical impresario Robert Fox, brother of the actors James and Edward. 'We are still hoping that this can be resolved,' Fox told The Observer. 'I believe they may be meeting to discuss it this week.'

Mrs Osborne is trying to organise the repayment in instalments, but is believed to have been badly shaken by Faber's insistence. The Shropshire home she shared with the playwright during his final years has already been handed over to a charitable trust and his literary estate is now bankrupt.

Towards the end of last year, she telephoned Faber to argue that the contract had simply been terminated, or 'frustrated', by her husband's death. She explained that 'it seems a bizarre and unfeeling interpretation to wait until a few scant weeks before his deadline to raise the matter for the first time'.

Faber told The Observer he believed the matter could be resolved and he had suggested Mrs Osborne repay a proportion of the sum through deductions to royalties. 'It is simply not a sum we can afford to ignore,' he said.

Adrian Laing, a legal expert at HarperCollins, said that contracts with authors usually carried a clause covering the conditions for repayment of an advance in the case of non-completion.

'It is an unusual situation but sometimes amounts can be deducted from the advance and another writer can be hired to complete the work,' he said.

Fourth Estate is facing a similar problem. The firm had a six-figure deal with the QC George Carman and, after Carman's death earlier this year before the promised autobiography had been written, is now in negotiations with his son, the publisher Dominic Carman.

Osborne led a turbulent life and by the time he died he had been in financial difficulties for some years. In spite of his series of award-winning plays and the screenwriting prowess that was evident in Tony Richardson's 1963 film Tom Jones, for which Osborne won an Oscar, the couple ran out of money.

When Look Back In Anger, starring Alan Bates, Mary Ure and Kenneth Haigh, was first produced at George Devine's experimental Royal Court Theatre in 1956, Osborne was hailed as the brightest new talent in the country. The play gave birth to a whole new vocabulary and its central character, Jimmy Porter, became the archetypal 'anti-hero' of the age.

The impact of the play was marked by Kenneth Tynan's review in this newspaper; he famously said he could never love someone who did not want to see Look Back In Anger. 'Anger is good,' he once declared. Now, six years after the playwright's death, his work is once again at the centre of a storm of resentment. Osborne's widow, Helen, has received a 'bizarre and unfeeling' letter from her late husband's publishers, Faber and Faber, which has astonished her and many of the playwright's oldest friends. The letter, from managing director Tony Faber, requested repayment of the full figure of the advance - £20,000 - that Osborne had been paid for the third volume of his autobiography. 'As part of a general review exercise,' the letter read, 'we have been going through the outstanding advances on undelivered titles. According to our records, Autobiography Vol. III Young Men Forget by John Osborne falls into this category.' The first two volumes of Osborne's autobiography, A Better Class of Person and Almost A Gentleman, were published in 1981 and 1991, respectively. The third volume was under way, and the notes the author had prepared for it during his final illness are now kept at the University of Texas. By taking action to recover the money in the last few months of 2000, the publisher appears to have hoped to act before a six-year cut-off point for repayment. As far as Mrs Osborne is concerned, it has also conveniently forgotten the internationally renowned work, including the plays The Entertainer, Inadmissible Evidence and A Patriot For Me, which it has benefited from publishing. 'He seems to be being penalised for dying,' the theatre director Richard Eyre said. 'They should remember that at one time he was certainly a major earner for Faber.' webTitle: Focus: Tale of a struggling London school

fields.headline: It's all in a day's work
fields.standfirst:
Staff shortages are threatening to destroy the very schools where heads are working hardest to help underprivileged pupils. Tracy McVeigh joined the losing battle for a day

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Staff shortages are threatening to destroy the very schools where heads are working hardest to help underprivileged pupils. Tracy McVeigh joined the losing battle for a day.
fields.body:
It was just after 8am on Friday and Annie Hornsby was running out of time. With Nelson Primary School in East London due to open its doors in less than an hour, Hornsby, the deputy head, was desperately trying to secure sick-cover for seven members of staff. All had phoned in complaining of flu.

Outside her cramped office, the first of the school's 865 children were noisily arriving for morning lessons. The clatter in the concrete schoolyard grew louder as Hornsby wearily lifted the phone and called a fourth temp agency. It was a waste of time.

Putting a pile of papers to one side, the smartly dressed deputy got to her feet. There was no other choice: the crippling staff shortages meant once again that she would take morning classes. The growing pile of paperwork would have to be taken home with her. Her weekend would be a working one.

It was not the first time. Hornsby spent Friday morning the way she spends every morning, ringing round the teacher supply agencies in a dispiriting - and increasingly fruitless - search for staff. 'I have been in teaching for 15 years. I have never known it to be so bad,' she said after The Observer was given exclusive access to the school.

Nelson is desperately trying to keep its head above water. As severe staff shortages bite, particularly in London and the South East, anger among teachers and parents over the deteriorating recruitment crisis is reaching boiling point. Ofsted inspectors last week closed another London primary school after they found it 'stretched almost to breaking point' by staff shortages. The school, the inspectors found, lacked even enough staff to teach the national curriculum.

It is a fate that schools all over Britain, including Nelson, are desperate to avoid. Hornsby said: 'You come to work every day with this feeling of trepidation, fearing what will happen if someone is off. Last week I had a teacher who was obviously ill and had lost her voice, yet she was agonising about who would look after her class if she went home sick.'

Across the way from Hornsby's office, Tim Benson, the head teacher, was also preparing to take a class. The business of managing and maintaining such a large school - one of the biggest in the country - would have to wait while he stepped into the breach for one of his absent staff. But he wasn't complaining: 'The shortages put a huge strain on staff, but it is the children who suffer most.

'When a class doesn't have a permanent teacher it is quite noticeable, the children get fraught, their behaviour deteriorates,' he added. 'The perception is that inner-city schools are just daily grinds of challenging pupils and challenging parents; even the Ofsted inspector turned up here looking terrified. I think he thought he was going to get mugged.'

This 100-year old London primary school, like so many others in England and Wales, is almost always under-staffed. Benson has 28 teachers and 50 other staff in his care. Seven of his teachers are supply teachers: two Australians, two South Africans, two New Zealanders and a Canadian. 'I don't know what we would do without them,' he said.

They often work a 50-hour week and take plenty of extra work home. Half their pupils do not speak English as a first language and many have impossibly difficult backgrounds. Poverty is endemic: two-thirds of the children qualify for free school meals, and for some the school uniform is their only set of clothes.

Three years ago things were much worse. Fights erupted between pupils daily and racist name-calling was a major problem. Nelson also suffered regular breakdowns of discipline in the classroom and academic standards were in freefall. But a new and dedicated head teacher in Benson, coupled with investment from the Government and Newham local education authority, have turned it around. The Department for Education has even agreed to pay £1.4 million to fix the leaking roof.

'We have all worked amazingly hard and have the results to prove it,' said the head teacher last week. But the recruitment crisis is now threatening to reverse all the hard work and once again bring it to its knees. 'What we cannot beat is the crisis in staff. It is really quite frightening, the one thing which makes me feel closest to despair,' said Benson. By taking classes themselves, Benson and Hornsby, his deputy, have been able to avoid having to send children home. Such a move could trigger unwanted attention from Ofsted.

But these are desperate measures to shore up an ever-crumbling system and they cannot hold out for much longer. 'It is like putting a sticking plaster over a gaping wound,' said the head. 'The irony is that I have the money, I have a supply budget sitting in the bank, I cannot get staff, and when I do I have to maintain a massive charm offensive and an exhausting level of support in order to keep them.

'We have built something good here but it needs maintaining every day. It's very easy, especially in this recruitment crisis, for a school's standards to plummet quite quickly and the weak can only get weaker,' said Benson. 'But we have lovely children, lovely parents, this is a lovely building. Children are children are children wherever you are and they deserve the best we can possibly give them, but we are not always able to get them the best.'

Every year a large proportion of the children arrive speaking Ukrainian, Russian, Tamil, Albanian and Punjabi. They learn the basics of the language before beginning the long road to reach the standard of English, maths and science which the Government is demanding. There are also a large number of children with special needs, including those with dyslexia and severe behavioural problems.

Britain has always relied heavily on teachers coming to the UK from Commonwealth countries. Despite his seven supply teachers, Benson will be monitoring the results of a mission to South Africa this week by a group of heads desperate to recruit badly needed staff. One of Britain's biggest teacher supply agencies, TimePlan, said last week that 2,000 Australian supply teachers will be snapped up this year.

But even that outlet may soon run dry, leaving British schools even more badly exposed. Australian experts last week estimated their shortage of teachers would reach crisis point in the next four years. A campaign will soon be launched to persuade Australian teachers planning to head for Britain to stay at home instead.

The Australian move comes as Britain steps up its poaching efforts. Last week the Education Minister Estelle Morris announced the latest in a line of proposals to boost teacher numbers. Red tape will be cut to make it possible for overseas teachers to stay longer than the current four months in any one post. Plans are already under way to amend pension legislation to lure former teachers out of retirement.

The Government's recruitment drive will also have to convince foreign supply teachers to ignore the grim stories told by colleagues who have returned home, tired and demoralised after their time in Britain. Typical was Fiona Ballinger, from Queensland, who taught English and history at Forest Hill Boys School near Crystal Palace, south London.

'It was hard, hard, hard work,' she told The Observer . 'Every Australian teacher has a nightmare story to tell from England. We only get 10 sick days a year in Queensland, but in Britain the teachers seemed to be sick all the time. Us supply teachers didn't even have to wait for a call. We just went to work knowing there would be people off sick,' she said.

'Working in a school with closed-circuit cameras was bizarre. Never had anything like that in Australia. But a couple of times I was really scared and I understood why they had them. Two boys had a fight with saws and knives in my class one day, and this was about the time when the headmaster, Philip Lawrence, was stabbed to death.'

Differences in vocabulary and an unfamiliar discipline system were quoted by foreign teachers last week as the biggest problems in British schools. One said: 'The first day in a class I leaned over a desk and got a pencil shoved up my bottom from behind. Later I had a dog mess in my bag and my friend got a black eye from another kid. I quickly learnt that the laid-back Australian way was not going to work here.

'But I found the whole system so formal and the pupils just so unruly and downright nasty. The schools were in a fairly terrible state too, it wasn't pleasant and I got out as soon as I could - a shame because all I ever wanted to do was teach.'

Another gripe was teachers' pay. At Nelson Primary, a teacher with less than nine years' experience gets around £16,000, barely enough to get a mortgage on a one-bedroom flat in the area.

Benson was doing his best last week to stay positive. He knows that the years of good work to turn his school around could be at stake if the Government cannot attract more teachers. But at least on Friday, things were ticking over. Year One children sat quietly on their classroom floor listening to a story being read out by a BT employee, sponsored by the phone company to help provide children, especially Afro-Caribbean boys, with a black male role model.

Benson gestured through an open classroom door at one group of spellbound children. 'Learning, look, they are learning,' he beamed. 'There is the rewards of teaching. Just look at that.' He does not know how long it can last.

webTitle: Andrew Rawnsley on US-UK relations

fields.headline: America or Europe: Tony, the choice is yours
fields.standfirst:
The new right-wing order in Washington will force the Prime Minister to confront the dilemma he has so strained to avoid

Special report: George W Bush's America
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The new right-wing order in Washington will force the Prime Minister to confront the dilemma he has so strained to avoid.
fields.body:
The story sounds too good to be true, but I have it on excellent authority that this salutary tale is authentic. On his arrival at the Foreign Office, Robin Cook had installed a hotline to the American Secretary of State. With considerable satisfaction did the Foreign Secretary show visitors to his chambers the impressive-looking item of gadgetry that would connect him quicker than you could say 'Special Relationship' to his opposite number in Washington.

A fortnight passed and, rather to the disappointment of its proud owner, the wonder phone did not ring. At last, in the middle of a meeting, the hotline emitted its urgent trill. Amid much excitement, one of the Foreign Secretary's officials dashed to grab the receiver. The voice at the other end began to dictate an order for a takeaway pizza.

This government has been no more immune than its predecessors to self-delusion about Britain's place in the American scheme of things. To the arrival of George W. Bush in the White House, bringing with him a regime which challenges the cherished myths about the relationship, London has reacted by wrapping itself in a duvet of more illusion.

The inauguration of Dubya moves the Foreign Secretary to gush over the 'uniquely warm friendship' between the two countries. The relationship will 'renew and deepen', sighs Robin Cook, the erstwhile firebreath of the Left apparently so suffused with passion for this right-wing President that his empurpled prose suggests an alternative vocation as a writer of romantic fiction.

Diplomatic etiquette demands the maintenance of the pretence that nothing has really changed. Assuming that the briefers from the CIA have now cleared up any lingering confusion in Dubya's mind between Britain and Burundi, it will be superficial business as usual. Though Tony Blair clearly preferred Al Gore, Number 10 was careful to hedge its bets. Mr Cook took the precaution of meeting Colin Powell many months ago. Chris Meyer and his team at the British embassy in Washington have assiduously cultivated players of influence in the Republican White House.

On a personal level, Tony and Dubya can be expected to get along just dandy. George Bush Senior says of his son: 'He has no sharp edges. He is no ideologue, no divider.' That is a character reference which could be equally applied to Mr Blair. One of the Prime Minister's intimates assures me that any obstacles will be dissolved in a warm bath of personal chemistry. 'Tony is a nice guy. Bush is a nice guy. I'm sure they'll get along like a house on fire.'

The unpleasant reality that they are anxious to mask, as much from themselves as anyone else, is that the new order in Washington brings into vivid relief the question that has confronted Britain ever since it lost its empire. Does our manifest destiny lie with Europe or are our truest kith and kin across the bigger water?

This being a dilemma that Tony Blair does not want to confront, he describes it as a 'false choice'. His favoured metaphor, a construct originally patented by Churchill, is of Britain as 'the bridge' between America and Europe. The Prime Minister projects himself as Europe's representative to America, and Washington's ambassador to Europe. That conceit faces a test to destruction. The effort of spanning a conservative, unilateralist America and a social democrat, collectivist Europe will stretch even Tony Blair's legendary ability to straddle the mutually incompatible.

Dubya may be a smoothy, but he has packed his administration with characters who have sharply reactionary corners. From gun control to abortion, welfare to health, minds are not going to meet over an ocean of different values. The day Bush was sworn in, the Atlantic doubled in width.

On the environment, Dubya is surrounded by people who will not believe there is a threat from global warming until Texas has become a great lake. The dismal unwillingness of the United States to take its fair share of responsibility for despoiling the planet will get more pronounced. As the famously gutted John Prescott discovered at the aborted talks in the Hague, trying to broker the division between Europe and America was already an unforgiving job. It has just become mission near-impossible.

Defence, historically the tie that has most closely bound London and Washington, will be the most potent source of combustion. The tensions were manifest even when the White House was occupied by Bill Clinton. The conflict over Kosovo was Blair's crash course in both Europe's pathetic inability to wage serious war without American support; and the reluctance of the US to risk the life of a single American where they could not perceive a national interest.

The Americans ran an independent targeting operation, secret from Nato. They shared more confidences with Britain than other allies, but that is not saying a huge deal. The news of the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade was broken to the British Defence Secretary by his car radio.

Kosovo was a tutorial, to be repeated more searingly by the Bush administration, that even the true Brits are not wholly trusted in Washington. Number 10 is pretty desperate to put Tony Blair first in the queue of leaders to be received by the new President. But an early warning of his place in American priorities is provided by the testimony given to the Senate by Colin Powell during his confirmation hearings.

The man now in charge of American foreign policy referred to Britain only once, in the context of a history lesson about how Washington won the Cold War despite the Greenham Common protesters. In the world of Bush, the priorities will be China, Russia and the Middle East. The Pacific and Asia will engage more of its attention than Europe. Clinton's commitment to humanitarian interventionism, albeit patchy, will be abandoned.

The choice upon which Tony Blair is most anxious to avoid impalement is the American scheme for National Missile Defence. His Ministers at Defence don't believe that it can be made to work; his Ministers at the Foreign Office share the rest of Europe's alarm that it will unleash an arms race. The Prime Minister prays that this dilemma - does he aggravate Europe by providing British co-operation or infuriate America by refusing it? - will somehow just go away. It is a hope that is almost certain to be confounded by a Bush administration heaving with enthusiasts for Son of Star Wars.

Where the Americans are right, in my view, is to demand that Europe makes a greater contribution to the maintenance of peace in its own backyard. Schizophrenically, Washington then protests when Europe makes a modest step towards creating a capacity to act without American assistance by establishing the rapid reaction force.

About this, the French are fundamentally correct. The force, though it will have to grow much stronger to be effective, has to be able to act in areas and crises where the United States cannot or will not engage. It is meaningless for Europe to have a force independent of Washington if that force can never be allowed to act independently. That is another fiction to cloak another tough choice that Britain would presently prefer not to make.

Tony Blair told us recently that one of the lessons he has absorbed from office is that you cannot please all of the people all of the time. Abroad, he will nevertheless continue to smile from every aspect of the face. He wants to remain chums with his old frère Jacques and his old mate Ger while getting on the best of terms with his new buddy Dubya.

The flexible friend at Number 10 will strain himself to straddle the widening waters between America and Europe, but the painful truth begins to look inescapable. For Tony Blair, the Atlantic will be a bridge too far.

The Prime Minister projects himself as Europe's representative to America, and Washington's ambassador to Europe. That conceit faces a test to destruction. The effort of spanning a conservative, unilateralist America and a social democrat, collectivist Europe will stretch even Tony Blair's legendary ability to straddle the mutually incompatible. Dubya may be a smoothy, but he has packed his administration with characters who have sharply reactionary corners. From gun control to abortion, welfare to health, minds are not going to meet over an ocean of different values. The day Bush was sworn in, the Atlantic doubled in width. On the environment, Dubya is surrounded by people who will not believe there is a threat from global warming until Texas has become a great lake. The dismal unwillingness of the United States to take its fair share of responsibility for despoiling the planet will get more pronounced. As the famously gutted John Prescott discovered at the aborted talks in the Hague, trying to broker the division between Europe and America was already an unforgiving job. It has just become mission near-impossible. Defence, historically the tie that has most closely bound London and Washington, will be the most potent source of combustion. The tensions were manifest even when the White House was occupied by Bill Clinton. The conflict over Kosovo was Blair's crash course in both Europe's pathetic inability to wage serious war without American support; and the reluctance of the US to risk the life of a single American where they could not perceive a national interest. The Americans ran an independent targeting operation, secret from Nato. They shared more confidences with Britain than other allies, but that is not saying a huge deal. The news of the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade was broken to the British Defence Secretary by his car radio. Kosovo was a tutorial, to be repeated more searingly by the Bush administration, that even the true Brits are not wholly trusted in Washington. Number 10 is pretty desperate to put Tony Blair first in the queue of leaders to be received by the new President. But an early warning of his place in American priorities is provided by the testimony given to the Senate by Colin Powell during his confirmation hearings. The man now in charge of American foreign policy referred to Britain only once, in the context of a history lesson about how Washington won the Cold War despite the Greenham Common protesters. In the world of Bush, the priorities will be China, Russia and the Middle East. The Pacific and Asia will engage more of its attention than Europe. Clinton's commitment to humanitarian interventionism, albeit patchy, will be abandoned. The choice upon which Tony Blair is most anxious to avoid impalement is the American scheme for National Missile Defence. His Ministers at Defence don't believe that it can be made to work; his Ministers at the Foreign Office share the rest of Europe's alarm that it will unleash an arms race. The Prime Minister prays that this dilemma - does he aggravate Europe by providing British co-operation or infuriate America by refusing it? - will somehow just go away. It is a hope that is almost certain to be confounded by a Bush administration heaving with enthusiasts for Son of Star Wars. Where the Americans are right, in my view, is to demand that Europe makes a greater contribution to the maintenance of peace in its own backyard. Schizophrenically, Washington then protests when Europe makes a modest step towards creating a capacity to act without American assistance by establishing the rapid reaction force. About this, the French are fundamentally correct. The force, though it will have to grow much stronger to be effective, has to be able to act in areas and crises where the United States cannot or will not engage. It is meaningless for Europe to have a force independent of Washington if that force can never be allowed to act independently. That is another fiction to cloak another tough choice that Britain would presently prefer not to make. Tony Blair told us recently that one of the lessons he has absorbed from office is that you cannot please all of the people all of the time. Abroad, he will nevertheless continue to smile from every aspect of the face. He wants to remain chums with his old frère Jacques and his old mate Ger while getting on the best of terms with his new buddy Dubya. The flexible friend at Number 10 will strain himself to straddle the widening waters between America and Europe, but the painful truth begins to look inescapable. For Tony Blair, the Atlantic will be a bridge too far.

webTitle: Comment: the absurd is not a barrier to serious politics

fields.headline: A party that never laughs
fields.standfirst:
Somebody should tell Labour that a sense of the absurd is not a barrier to serious politics

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Somebody should tell Labour that a sense of the absurd is not a barrier to serious politics.
fields.body:
Two and a half years ago, standing at the counter of a bar near Victoria and winding up a job interview, the editor of the New Statesman, Peter Wilby, warned me of the biggest challenge that I would face as his deputy: 'humour'.

I would find, he explained, that with the exception of Nick Cohen, Francis Wheen, and the odd stand-up comedian turned writer, the Left had lost its sense of humour.

I didn't believe him, and commissioned happily away, certain that the pieties and platitudes of New Labour lent themselves so obviously to ridicule that we would find ourselves hooting with laughter time and again as our contributors punctured the pompous posturings of Tony and co.

I was wrong. The quality of writing was often high, no question; but the tone was almost invariably one of earnestness and irreproachable virtue. For the tongue-in-cheek caricature or the wittily poisonous put-down, we could rely on only a very few regulars - and on right-wing writers such as the late Auberon Waugh.

Waugh was delighted when an item in the diary he wrote for us - 'Does John Prescott wear a wig?' - sparked a furious reader's letter ('I don't buy my NS to read this fascist claptrap') and was taken up as a matter for national debate by the Daily Mail, which devoted a full page to a windswept photo of the Deputy Prime Minister. The writer's sense of the absurd would have been equally tickled by Polly Toynbee's reaction to his demise, last week. Writing in just the kind of 'no laughs please, we're left-wing' manner he despised, Toynbee bludgeoned the dead man from her high horse for - sin of all sins - poking fun at the ways of the world.

Such right-wing humourists cared only about 'a joke or two', she protested; they saw no reason to change the Establishment that catered for them. Theirs was an all-male all-white Oxbridge élite (and in many instances Papist, to boot) that plotted to while away its days drinking, smoking and laughing at the ghastly little man on the street.

Certainly, Waugh could be merciless in his attacks - on paper and in private. He thrashed bores and left them lying comatose in a pool of ridicule. But one need not subscribe to Bron's view of the world to see that his comic touch is something the Left would do well to adopt. As it is, too many seem to believe that good journalism is about worthy sentiments brown-sandaling their way across the pages.

Jonathan Swift, Voltaire and George Orwell proved that vicious humour can effect change as well as any do-gooder's campaign. Yet the Left still prefers the crusade to the satire; its adherents persist in preaching and ringing a bell, Salvation Army-style, to convert us to their view.

They do their beliefs a disservice: equal opportunities for all, a social contract whereby the haves help out the have-nots, a mistrust of the profit motive as sole indicator of wellbeing...these ideas don't need to be rammed down our throat - they appeal on their own.

Yet it is as if writers and journalists of the Left cannot quite convince themselves of the strength of their position - or perhaps they doubt the readers'/listeners'/viewers' ability to recognise its rightness. Instead of taking it as read that they have secured our allegiance on a number of points of principle - something the Right always does - and focusing their efforts on re-interpreting those points for us in an entertaining way - which, again, is the stock-in-trade of the Right - the Left goes for overkill, stating and restating its position in an effort to legitimise its claim.

This insecurity - which can reach near paranoid proportions in some - is rooted in 18 years spent on the sidelines, watching the Bad Guys getting away with it. The chip on the shoulder grew with the premature triumphalism that preceded the 1992 election: when you get things so spectacularly wrong, you can't help thinking that the future carries a degree of uncertainty.

After nearly two decades of this, the Opposition, which had its moments of glory with Spitting Image and the early Ben Elton, stopped having fun bashing the Establishment and slipped into despondent victimhood.

Today, its Man is in No 10 and the next election practically in the bag, but the years of being bullied have left their mark. Like Richard Nixon, who'd been kicked around too long, the Left has grown sullen.

Laughter, perhaps not surprisingly, is suspect: for too long, it has been directed at them. This means, firstly, that the Government can't handle being the butt of a comic's jokes - as comedian Mark Thomas is finding out; but, also, that many left-wing comedians and humorous writers, aware of their grandees' thin skins, spare them the spite that fuels successful satire. John O'Farrell, Rob Newman, even the normally pitiless Rory Bremner, have traded in their sharp blades for blunt ones, and could now practically pass the Alastair Campbell 'on message' test.

But it's not just Tony's Thought Police who muzzle the comics. Political correctness - a gift to the Right over the years, in terms of humorous potential - blights the Left. It confuses priorities, and, with huge taboos that loom at every step, threatens to paralyse any lively spirit lurking within the so-called tent. A joke at the expense of a woman, a gay, or a black - even when the individual in question may be in a position of power and crying out to be deflated - is a blasphemy, in the way that printing a vituperative attack on a middle-aged white male who has not been dead 24 hours is clearly not.

Humour feeds on the gap between great expectations and sorry reality. Given the state we're in, the Left has plenty to sink its teeth into. Why should the Right have all the fun?

 Cristina Odone is Deputy Editor of the New Statesman

webTitle: Heather Connon: Greenmailed? Not us, say the trusts

fields.headline: Greenmailed? Not us, say the trusts
fields.trailText: 'The affair of Sierra Trading, a New Jersey arbitrage fund which took funds in a number of investment trusts last summer, raises important issues.'
fields.body:
'Has nookie with you made thousands of people thousands of pounds?' So runs the catchline on an advert for investment trusts. But those with trusts in their portfolios could be forgiven for thinking that this industry is already cuddled rather too comfortably together.

The affair of Sierra Trading, a New Jersey arbitrage fund, raises important issues. The fund took stakes in a number of investment trusts last summer. It followed this up by requisitioning a resolution to be put to the annual meetings of four of them - Foreign & Colonial, Scottish Investment Trust, Bankers and Murray International - calling on the funds to buy back a hefty 70 per cent of their shares at 98 per cent of their net asset value.

Within weeks of the resolutions being tabled, all four trusts had bought Sierra's stakes, leaving it with a decent profit - and other shareholders, who were not given the same chance of an exit, with a nasty taste in their mouths.

One investor, Hermes, is asking whether the affair heralds the arrival in Britain of 'greenmail', a particularly nasty US practice in which one company takes a stake in another and threatens a full-scale bid or other unwelcome corporate action unless the target firm buys it out at a handsome profit.

Hermes is asking the trusts for an explanation of their dealings with Sierra Trading, which certainly have all the hallmarks of greenmail - although they deny all suggestions of it.

F & C, for example, points out that it offered all shareholders the chance to sell on the same terms as Sierra. Indeed, it bought in 36 million shares in one day, of which fewer than a third were Sierra's.

But Hermes questions why, in the case of Scottish, it was allowed to sell only 30 per cent of its holding when Sierra got a complete exit.

The trusts do deserve some sympathy. The sector is a favourite for arbitrageurs and, too often, their actions do little to benefit other shareholders. F & C points out that putting the resolution to its investors would have incurred substantial printing, advisory and legal costs- money which might well have been wasted.

But the trusts should be doing more to stop attacks by arbitrageurs in the first place. Trusts are vulnerable because of their discounts - the fact that their share prices are lower than the value of their underlying assets.

Abitrageurs aim to buy at big discounts and sell at smaller ones, or even force the break-up of a trust.

The best way to deter them, therefore, is to keep the discount as low as possible. Above all, that means performing well. But it also means ensuring their shareholders actually want to hold their shares. Too many shares in the large general trusts are in the hands of big institutions. Trusts should be buying back more shares, not just buying out arbitraguers such as Sierra, and doing more to sell themselves to private shareholders, for whom they are excellent investments.

The industry's 'its' campaign, of which the advert is part, has had a small impact. The rest is up to the trusts.

webTitle: Taking to the floor

fields.headline: Taking to the floor
fields.trailText: 'The phone rings and it's a woman wondering if by any chance I am considering 'exchanging' my kitchen in the near future. Exchanging it for what - a set of golf clubs?'
fields.body:
My wife is just in the middle of interrupting my perusal of the local paper to explain the advantages of spending an entire year's alcohol budget on a new roll of lino for the bathroom, while unpopular stocks last, when the phone rings and it's a woman wondering if by any chance I am considering 'exchanging' my kitchen in the near future. Exchanging it for what - a set of golf clubs? 'Do you mean replacing it?' I say.

Yes, she does. No, I say, we're very happy with it. Naturally I don't tell her about the horrible beige tiles abounding with illustrations of woodland fauns, or the million-watt arrangement of industrial fluorescent tubing under the cupboards, which make us look as though we should be employing someone to shout 'Action!' through a megaphone every time we switch the lights on. But hang on_ has she tried Posh and Becks, who are famously moving into our tightknit community and who even as we speak have got the builders in trying to make their recently acquired Georgian mansion look a bit more like the Palace of Versailles and a bit less like Strangeways. 'The local paper says they're thinking of adding a recording studio,' I say, adding excitedly that they're bound to be thinking about a modest rococo-style kitchenette for Victoria to microwave some well-earned mini kievs for her sound crew, hair coach and team of fingernail advisers. How we laugh, me with exaggerated heartiness, the woman with nervous exhaustion, possibly wishing she'd gone for the job standing in the doorway at B&Q and rugby-tackling customers with a view to convincing them that an Anglia Edwardian-style conservatory in white PVC is the acme of elevated living. But I am happy enough to detain her with the startling disclosure that the informal style of the new coffee shop in town is already paying dividends in so much as they received bookings for no fewer than two birthdays last week and that vandals have run amok in the school, stealing a regulation-sized football and breaking wax crayons.

My wife spoils the fun by waving a Stanley knife in my face, and sure enough no sooner has the woman on the phone made her excuses and fled without stopping to offer a free wall-mounted tin-opener to anyone tempted to take out a crippling loan on easy terms by the end of February than I am being helped upstairs with the inspiring news that the fitter is coming first thing Wednesday and the old vinyl will hardly rip itself up, will it? Needless to say this is a job every bit as quick, simple and inherently enjoyable as it sounds - ie, not in the slightest, especially the region behind the toilet and washbasin where ablutory germs lurk safe in the knowledge that the mop that can get its head round stubborn corners is still in the hands of Japanese scientists. 'You'll just have to rip it out by hand,' observes my wife, dashing off to do some urgent omnibus viewing of last week's Changing Rooms while I scrabble round the skirting boards for hours on my hands and knees tugging and sweating and cursing while the air dances with shit mites dating from 1972. My wife eventually appears with some binbags and the hoover. 'Better make sure you get all the glue up,' she says. I look up. 'And perhaps a shower?' she suggests, a hand covering her mouth.

But all is not lost. As a reward she suggests we meet up with John and Fiona for an evening's tenpin bowling, So off we go into our leafy nearby town, which has at last triumphantly just missed the 20th century by building a cladded leisure complex boasting a McDonald's, a multiplex and a handsome forecourt where teenagers can throw rubbish and spit. We make our way between the overflowing bins and soon we are inexpertly clattering balls down the lane, except John who is talking about finger technique and sending all 10 skittles flying in his usual enthusiasm for every sport going, even one that seems to have been conceived as a training aid for airport baggage handlers. Eventually we manage to divert him to the bar before he suggests we start our own league. The Guinnesses are on me. I do enjoy a night off the tiles.

webTitle: Fur flies as geeks neuter the CueCat shopping spy

fields.headline: Fur flies as geeks neuter the CueCat shopping spy
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The great thing about software is that it's pure thought-stuff. Anyone can create it: all you need is a computer and some programming tools, many of which are freely available on the Net. After that, the only limits are those set by your own ingenuity. That's why teenagers such as Shawn Fanning, the guy who invented Napster, are capable of moving mountains.
fields.body:
The great thing about software is that it's pure thought-stuff. Anyone can create it: all you need is a computer and some programming tools, many of which are freely available on the Net. After that, the only limits are those set by your own ingenuity. That's why teenagers such as Shawn Fanning, the guy who invented Napster, are capable of moving mountains.

Some people have a gift for programming, in much the same way as Mozart had a gift for musical composition. They can hack out computer code which has the power to overturn industries - and distribute it over the Net before its hapless victims even know what's happening.

Hackers can also take things apart, with equally embarrassing results. Consider the case of Digital Convergence, a Texan company which has to date given away more than a million barcode scanners called CueCats to computer users across the US. The company plans to hand out 39 million more of the gizmos by this time next year. Given that they cost around $10 apiece this adds up to a lot of dosh. So why are Digital Convergence doing it? Answer: because the company plans to make money by selling information about the users' purchasing habits gathered by the scanners.

It works like this. Scanning the barcodes on a packet of breakfast cereal, say, will send the user's internet browser to the manufacturer's website. (Let us leave to one side the question of why anyone in their right mind would want to visit such a site.) Each CueCat comes with a unique serial number. When installing its software, the user is required to register personal details such as name, email address, age, sex and postcode. This data can then be correlated with information gleaned by the CueCat about the products scanned by the user. The hope is that if enough people use CueCats, the accumulated consumer information will eventually be worth far more than the $400 million it will take to get a critical mass of scanners out there.

Now to some people (there is no accounting for tastes) a barcode scanner is a desirable object, especially if it is free. And it seems that some hackers, passing by the CueCat display in electronics stores, were unable to resist the temptation. From a geek perspective, however, the CueCat had two undesirable features. First, its software runs under Microsoft Windows, which in these circles is regarded rather as the spawn of the devil. Second, the scanner was designed to send personal data back to corporate HQ. Heap bad karma.

You can guess what happened. Geeks took their Cue Cats home, got out their screwdrivers and opened the lids. Inside they found the usual circuit board, EepRoms (erasable, programmable, read-only memory) and related devices.

The first thing to do was to 'neuter' the CueCat by disabling its serial number. There were two ways of doing this: by physically disconnecting one pin of a programmable memory chip, or (more elegantly) by resetting the serial number to zero. Either method deprived the device of the power to link individuals to CueCats. Step two was to write software to enable Macintosh and Linux users to use their free (now unencumbered) scanners without their consumption patterns being reported to corporate databases in Dallas.

Needless to say, the Digital Convergence suits were not amused. Lawyers were consulted. Cease and desist letters were dispatched. Licences were invoked. Vague threats were made about infringement of intellectual property and the like. All of which have had as much effect as a sermon in a whorehouse - and detailed autopsies of CueCats flourish on the Net. There's a lesson there somewhere.

fields.bodyText: The great thing about software is that it's pure thought-stuff. Anyone can create it: all you need is a computer and some programming tools, many of which are freely available on the Net. After that, the only limits are those set by your own ingenuity. That's why teenagers such as Shawn Fanning, the guy who invented Napster, are capable of moving mountains. Some people have a gift for programming, in much the same way as Mozart had a gift for musical composition. They can hack out computer code which has the power to overturn industries - and distribute it over the Net before its hapless victims even know what's happening. Hackers can also take things apart, with equally embarrassing results. Consider the case of Digital Convergence, a Texan company which has to date given away more than a million barcode scanners called CueCats to computer users across the US. The company plans to hand out 39 million more of the gizmos by this time next year. Given that they cost around $10 apiece this adds up to a lot of dosh. So why are Digital Convergence doing it? Answer: because the company plans to make money by selling information about the users' purchasing habits gathered by the scanners. It works like this. Scanning the barcodes on a packet of breakfast cereal, say, will send the user's internet browser to the manufacturer's website. (Let us leave to one side the question of why anyone in their right mind would want to visit such a site.) Each CueCat comes with a unique serial number. When installing its software, the user is required to register personal details such as name, email address, age, sex and postcode. This data can then be correlated with information gleaned by the CueCat about the products scanned by the user. The hope is that if enough people use CueCats, the accumulated consumer information will eventually be worth far more than the $400 million it will take to get a critical mass of scanners out there. Now to some people (there is no accounting for tastes) a barcode scanner is a desirable object, especially if it is free. And it seems that some hackers, passing by the CueCat display in electronics stores, were unable to resist the temptation. From a geek perspective, however, the CueCat had two undesirable features. First, its software runs under Microsoft Windows, which in these circles is regarded rather as the spawn of the devil. Second, the scanner was designed to send personal data back to corporate HQ. Heap bad karma. You can guess what happened. Geeks took their Cue Cats home, got out their screwdrivers and opened the lids. Inside they found the usual circuit board, EepRoms (erasable, programmable, read-only memory) and related devices. The first thing to do was to 'neuter' the CueCat by disabling its serial number. There were two ways of doing this: by physically disconnecting one pin of a programmable memory chip, or (more elegantly) by resetting the serial number to zero. Either method deprived the device of the power to link individuals to CueCats. Step two was to write software to enable Macintosh and Linux users to use their free (now unencumbered) scanners without their consumption patterns being reported to corporate databases in Dallas. Needless to say, the Digital Convergence suits were not amused. Lawyers were consulted. Cease and desist letters were dispatched. Licences were invoked. Vague threats were made about infringement of intellectual property and the like. All of which have had as much effect as a sermon in a whorehouse - and detailed autopsies of CueCats flourish on the Net. There's a lesson there somewhere. john.naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Porn on a plate

fields.headline: Porn on a plate
fields.trailText: 'Sometimes I look around a 'hot' restaurant, read another rampant recipe, or peruse the 70 different types of bread roll suddenly available at Sainsbury's, and wonder: What gives with some people and food?'
fields.body:
Sometimes I look around a 'hot' restaurant, read another rampant recipe, or peruse the 70 different types of bread roll suddenly available at Sainsbury's, and wonder: What gives with some people and food?

To certain readers out there that's probably a bit like saying: What gives with some cars and petrol? We all need food to live. That's a given, for anorexic supermodels and self-styled gourmands alike. However, we also need water, and, to my knowledge, nobody has ever written poetic reams on the sensuous delights of H 2 O. And that's because water, however presented, is always just water: Mother Nature's unimprovable design classic, which has always been viewed as a bit of a one-trick pony in the world of media-spin. By contrast, food is almost whorishly versatile in marketing terms. Moreover, while there has always been good and bad food writing, brilliant and lousy professional cooks, a new law seems to have been passed that an amateur obsession with food is in itself terribly sexy.

While, before, in the majority of British households, food was just fuel, increasingly, it can be anything you want it to be (baby). That's probably why so much modern food writing reads like overheated porn with added condiments ('Black pepper with that, sir? Are you absolutely sure?') It could also explain why there's so much pressure to join in. These days, food tries so hard to gratify the senses, that, like a bad dancer from the 70s, it seems that if you don't respond to every dish with a Linda Lovelace orgasm-face, or if you dare to admit that you're not interested in some new lettuce, you're somehow deemed to be Bad in Bed.

In the light of all this food-obsession, it seems strangely cheering that a new study reports a trend for young British professionals to choose flats which either have very small kitchens or no kitchen at all, preferring to eat out, or snack on takeaways, Big Apple style. In other words, the younger generation of high-flying Britons is simply not interested in cooking for themselves. Which lack of interest makes them several hundred times more interesting. For them, food is once again fuel, not some sad form of sex-substitute.

Maybe I should come clean. I was once (very briefly) a restaurant critic who got sacked for taking too much interest in the wine list. Moreover, for me, the scene in Arthur where Dudley Moore sits with a knife and fork surrounding a plate bearing a whisky tumbler was the point where it stopped being a funny movie and became a fascinating documentary about people like me. There is also the fact that when I read Hanif Kureshi's poisonous attack on his ex-wife in his novel Intimacy, which primarily focused on her being 'the kind of woman who reads recipe books in bed', the knee-jerk feminist in me said, 'Toe-rag' while some sneaky inner voice which could not be silenced, muttered, 'I'm on his side.'

So, clearly, I am not madly interested in food. What I am interested in is everybody else's ever-spiralling interest - which seems so obsessive that at times British society seems to be suffering some kind of collective food disorder in reverse. Based on what remains unclear. It certainly isn't merely a case of improved circumstances for the majority. While someone rightly pointed out to me that, unlike say Porsches, holidays, or designer clothes, nice food is an affordable luxury, a bolt of cheap glamour we can all enjoy, this still seems to automatically exclude the housewife on income support, budgeting for a family on the same amount of money a Chelsea frau would spend on the right kind of salad fungi. When it comes to a tray of dried ceps, or a bag of oven chips and a few tins of baked beans which will feed the kids for four days, both the rich and the poor know exactly what their choice would be.

Which, depressingly, seems to be the point. Food remains nowhere near as sensual as it is political. Even in these supposedly enlightened times, food is a socially divisive tool, class war on a dinner plate, which automatically, irreversibly, separates the middle classes from the working classes. That, it seems, is where our present obsession with 'good food' originates - the same bad place where privilege and snobbery have always come from. Why else would the middle classes of the 90s delight in intimidating the working classes with their obscure cheese shavings? Just as they once did with their finger bowls and their ridiculous gluts of unnecessary cutlery in the 70s? Because they're hungry, because there's a hole to fill? Of course they are and of course there is. Just not in the way they'd like you to think.

webTitle: No end to shackles

fields.headline: No end to shackles
fields.standfirst:
A campaign seeking debt relief for the world's poorest countries has had only limited success, reports John Madeley

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: A campaign seeking debt relief for the world's poorest countries has had only limited success, reports John Madeley
fields.body:
An international campaign to cancel the foreign debts of the poorest countries by 31 December 2000 ended with rhetoric and promises but only a tiny amount actually written off by creditor governments.

The London-based Jubilee 2000 coalition of 100 voluntary groups ran a four-year, high-profile campaign to cancel the unpayable debts of 52 heavily indebted countries and so release funds for anti-poverty projects. These countries have debts of $375 billion, of which Jubilee 2000 estimates that about $300bn is unpayable. In 1998 it cost them $23.4bn to service their debt. Most is owed to government departments in OECD countries, the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and aid agencies. As much of this debt has already been discounted, says Jubilee 2000, its cancellation would cost very little.

Despite huge international support, including the world's largest petition, signed by 24 million people in 166 countries, and backing from religious leaders and pop stars such as Bono and Bob Geldof, the campaign fell short of its objective but put debt on the international agenda. 'Faced with one of the biggest movements for change the world has even seen it's shameful that creditors have not done more,' said Jubilee 2000 director Ann Pettifor, who now plans to run a successor - Jubilee Plus. 'They have yet to give the world poor a fresh start in the new millennium.'

Among debt campaigners there is anger about the role of the World Bank and the IMF, which administer the heavily indebted poor countries (HIPC) initiative, the main debt relief vehicle. The limited nature of debt-reduction packages, which the World Bank and IMF topped up in late December, has now become apparent.

While the Group of Seven industrialised nations promised the cancellation of $110bn of debt, only one country, Uganda, has had debt cancelled, while reductions have been agreed for a further 21 countries. Packages for seven of these were only agreed at the World Bank and IMF the week before Christmas, although the HIPC initiative is four years old. Qualifying countries may have to wait for several years - until they have poverty reduction strategies that satisfy World Bank and IMF criteria - before their debt is finally written off. In the meantime, debt servicing - the amount they pay in interest and capital repayments - will be reduced from $2.8bn to $2bn a year.

'What we have achieved should not be minimised,' said World Bank president James Wolfensohn. But that's exactly what has been achieved - a minimal deal.

The 22 qualifying countries are relatively small, with a combined population of around 205 million. But the 52 most heavily indebted countries have a joint population of more than 1,030 million. Countries enjoying a reduction in annual debt servicing therefore account for only 20 per cent of the population of the 52 countries. Even more telling is that the reduction, some $800 million, amounts to a mere 3.4 per cent of the total annual debt service payment of the 52 countries.

Axel van Trotsenburg, manager of HIPC implementation at the World Bank, says that 'over time' the 22 countries can expect debt relief of $35bn. But this amounts to less than a third of the $110bn debt which the G7 promised to cancel.

Van Trotsenburg said that to the $35bn can be added about $20bn more from 'existing debt-relief mechanisms as well as the unilateral initiatives by the respective OECD countries', making relief of about $55bn over time. But even this would be half-way to the G7 promise.

According to Pettifor, the HIPC initiative 'is not deep enough to provide a lasting exit to the debt burdens faced by indebted countries. It moves far too slowly and is subject to increasingly discredited IMF austerity conditions'. Sixteen of the 22 countries with debt packages 'will still be spending more each year on debt than on health', she points out.

Mauritania will be paying $63m on servicing its debt, but only $51m on education and $17m on health. Tanzania will pay out $168m in debt servicing compared to $87m on health. Zambia, where one in five adults is HIV-positive, will even be paying more on average after the HIPC initiative than before.

Wolfensohn and IMF man aging director Horst Kohler said the Bank and Fund will continue working to bring debt relief 'to other poor countries that have yet to qualify for HIPC initiative assistance'. Among the 19 HIPC countries that have yet to qualify are war-torn states such as Burundi, Ethiopia, Sudan and Vietnam.

Chancellor Gordon Brown announced last month that the British government would renounce its right 'to receive any benefit from these historic debts owed by the 41 countries'. Debt payments owed to the UK would be held in trust for poverty relief when each country agreed a poverty-reduction plan.

But 11 countries lie outside the initiative, including Bangladesh, Haiti and Nigeria, whose debt profiles are not considered serious enough. According to Pettifor, however, 'all are in desperate need of debt cancellation'. Nigeria's debt per head is about $250, higher than at least six HIPC qualifiers and more than twice as high as Burkina Faso.Haiti is paying $60m a year to service its debt.

'While conditions for ordinary people are getting worse every day,' said Camille Chalmers of Haiti's Jubilee 2000 campaign, 'this debt payment to the rich is immoral and profoundly unjust.'

Jubilee 2000's success was to move debt cancellation close to the top of the agenda.'Nothing can stop us. The campaign has started something that will change many things this century,' believes Bishop Rodriguez Tegucigalpa of Honduras. The debtors can only hope he is right

'Lucky' winners

The 22 countries with debt relief packages are:

Benin

Bolivia

Burkina Faso

Cameroon

Gambia

Guinea

Guinea-Bissau

Guyana

Honduras

Madagascar

Malawi

Mali

Mauritania

Mozambique

Nicaragua

Niger

Rwanda

São Tome & Príncipe

Senegal

Tanzania

Uganda

Zambia

webTitle: Maria Scott: Mis-selling culprits pay nothing - again

fields.headline: Mis-selling culprits pay nothing - again
fields.trailText: 'It is hard to see how the insurance industry will really change its ways unless its highly paid directors have to take personal responsibility for mis-selling.'
fields.body:
Faced with increasing flak over its role - or lack of it - in the Equitable Life disaster, the Financial Services Authority must have been pleased to grab some headlines last week with an 'action' story.

It fined United Friendly Insurance and Refuge Assurance £350,000 each on Thursday for mis-selling endowment savings schemes. Both insurers, now part of the Royal London group, were found guilty of selling these long-term contracts to people who could not afford them, and where the exit penalties proved onerous if they wanted to get out early.

Compensation of £31 million is expected to be paid to 30,000 investors who were sold inappropriate products between 1 August 1997 and 21 July 1998.

The fines are among the heftiest levied for this type of misdemeanour but the unpalatable outcome is that compensation will be paid by United and Refuge policyholders, from the insurers' £9 billion with-profits fund. The company says this will not affect returns because there is sufficient surplus in the fund to absorb the costs. Maybe, but it is still policyholders, not management who are bearing financial responsibility.

Until recently the regulator has not had the power to fine individual directors, and the introduction of this power post-dated this case.

It is hard to see how the insurance industry will really change its ways unless its highly paid directors have to take personal responsibility for mis-selling. The FSA must use its new power at the earliest opportunity.

Proposals due shortly from the Government on 'catmarking' credit cards will be well timed. Card bills for our £8.4 billion Christmas spending splurge are landing on doormats now. The aim of the Government's proposals will be to produce a set of indicators that help unwary consumers choose cards that will not get them into difficulties.

Catmarking is unlikely to have a big impact on our increasing taste for buying on the never-never; the real problem is over-enthusiastic marketing of credit, and this is being considered separately by the Government.

But setting official minimum standards should concentrate the card companies' minds on simplifying and improving a product that has the potential to wreak havoc on our personal finances.

webTitle: Cyber adoption scandal: timeline

fields.headline: The week that was
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 16 January: The Sun reveals the Kilshaws bought twins Belinda and Kimberley through an internet adoption agency in California.
fields.body:
Tuesday, 16 January: The Sun reveals the Kilshaws bought twins Belinda and Kimberley through an internet adoption agency in California, though the babies had already been sold for £4,000 to Richard and Vickie Allen, from California.

The Allens, who had the babies for two months, were tricked into returning them to their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, right, and then to the Kilshaws.

The Kilshaws trade blows with the Allens on breakfast television in a satellite-linked 'debate'.

Wednesday, 17 January: Senior social workers from Flintshire County Council visit the family and vow to keep in regular contact with them.

Tony Blair describes the sale as 'disgusting'.

Thursday, 18 January: Kilshaws reportedly exploring the possibility of turning their story into a film.

Amy and Eddie White from NY state claim they had also been promised the girls by adoption broker Tina Johnson.

It emerges the Kilshaws had called in paranormal investigators to their house.

Social Services intervene, removing the twins from the Kilshaws and placing them under emergency protection.

The twins' mother says she wants them back, claiming that the Kilshaws are not fit parents.

Friday, 19 January: The Kilshaws say they will appeal against the Social Services' decision.

Saturday, 20 January: The council applies to the High Court in Birmingham to make the twins wards of court.

Tuesday, 23 January: The wardship hearing is set to take place.

fields.body:
As every schoolboy knows, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? was the title of a cult science fiction novel, filmed as Blade Runner , which questioned the reality of existence and the nature of self. Sir David Steel, though undoubtedly urbane, is no Harrison Ford, but he must have wondered last week if he too had strayed into a work of psychic imagination.

The presiding officer of the Scottish Parliament found himself embroiled in a strange procedural row which pitched him against Ministers of the Scottish Executive. He took responsibility for the earlier decision by his deputy, George Reid, which disbarred Finance Minister Angus MacKay from making a statement on the abolition of quangos.

His reason? The substance of the announcement had already appeared in the morning papers. This was an affront to the Parliament. The remedy of banning the Ministerial statement carried the penalty that it would allow the opposition more time.

But then it emerged that Reid's decision to make that ruling had itself been leaked to the press in advance. By whom, asked Parliament Minister Tom McCabe, none too politely? Could it have been Sir David's office or one of his two deputies?

Certainly not, the presiding officer replied. But Sir David, who had already apologised for not having given MacKay advance warning of the ruling, now found himself on the defensive. He escaped the wrath of Ministers and MSPs by promising further discussions in private: what has emerged, in essence, is a leaks inquiry that includes not just the Executive but his own office too.

Sir David noted that Betty Boothroyd, at Westminster, had fought a rearguard action against leaks at Westminster, eventually admitting defeat. He announced his own resolve to win the battle but now, more than a little bruised, sulks like David at the Cave of Adullam. But no army will rally to his cause: the harsh truth is that his is a lost cause.

The late Donald Dewar kept a small group of spindoctors and advisers. Team McLeish is using the full budget allocation. According to the wits in Deacon Brodie's pub, he has even brought a spin doctor up from London among whose duties is to advise on his coiffure. Spies say, also, that McCabe masterminds the media strategy.

Of course governments have always leaked. After the row over Westland helicopters, when Michael Heseltine resigned from the Cabinet, Mrs Thatcher and her spinmeister, Bernard Ingham, tried to draw a distinction between a 'leak' and 'authorised' guidance.

It was Ingham, indeed, who developed spindoctoring into a kind of profession. He combined slick organisational skills with hectoring and bullying. He once threatened that if I gave a tape of an interview with Mrs Thatcher to the World at One he would never let the Herald , which I then edited, inside the doors of Downing Street again. I did not believe that threat, but came to the conclusion that his essential point - that the interview had been granted for print journalism - had validity.

Labour has been obsessed about presentation ever since Michael Foot's election campaign, when his donkey jacket and discursive oratory made but a feeble impression on the nightly news bulletins. Thus the sound bite, part of America's political circus, made its transatlantic journey. Mrs Thatcher was perhaps the first British exponent of the technique, changing her voice and primping her hair.

Sir David would be well advised to set himself limited aims. It is hopeless to try to stop the 'guidance' which the Executive machine pumps out to the press, or the titbits it feeds to its favoured organs. At best he can draw a few lines beyond which Ministers will not stray. For example, it is still unacceptable at Westminster for the Chancellor to disclose his budget in advance, though guidance abounds in the form of inspired speculation. And if it turns out that the leak of Reid's ruling came from within the camp, then Sir David must admit, hands up, that the game's a bogey.
