webTitle: Henry McDonald on human rights in Ulster

fields.headline: Tale of two tribunals
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Two tribunals were held in Northern Ireland last week, one partially in camera, the other in absolute secrecy.
fields.body:
Two tribunals were held in Northern Ireland last week, one partially in camera, the other in absolute secrecy. In one hearing, the defendant had legal representation; in the other the prisoner had to defend himself. Cross-examination in one case was verbal with legal arguments between defence lawyers, senior police officers and NIO officials; the second involved the use of blunt instruments, boots, fists and knives.

The setting for the first trial was a heated room in a prison hospital, and food and drinks were no doubt available. The location for the other was a squalid back room of a pub whose thick walls could soak up the screams from the detainee. Both of the accused belonged to the same terrorist movement - the Ulster Defence Association. One was fighting to overturn a decision to keep him in jail for a further 22 months; the other was pleading for his life.

The Northern Ireland Human Rights Commission, set up to defend civil liberties in the North, had plenty to say about the first case and nothing at all regarding the latter. Brice Dickson, the NIHRC's chairman, expressed his concern that the human rights of UDA commander Johnny Adair were compromised. The muscular, heavily tattooed loyalist leader was seeking to challenge Peter Mandelson's ruling in August last that Adair be re-arrested and incarcerated in Maghaberry prison.

The Northern Ireland Secretary's patience had snapped following intelligence and media reports linking Adair to sectarian tensions at Drumcree, the interfaces of north and west Belfast, and his role as prime mover in last summer's UDA-UVF feud. Adair, in Mandelson's mind, had broken the terms of the early release scheme set up following the Good Friday Agreement.

Clearly, there are civil liberty concerns regarding what some see as the selective targeting of Adair last August. Paramilitaries have been engaged in terrorist activities, and particularly so-called punishment attacks. Brice Dickson is correct to focus public attention on the use of police intelligence rather than hard evidence to convict (or in this instance, re-convict) someone of a crime. Everyone who wants to see the new Northern Ireland embrace a human rights culture should support the basic principles on which the NIHRC was founded.

None the less, the Commission's silence on the torture killing of UDA member George Legge raises the wider issue of human rights' groups and their attitudes to paramilitarism. Legge was so badly beaten and slashed that the RUC could not establish whether he had been shot. His throat was cut so severely that he was almost decapitated. He died as a result of a UDA turf war over drug-running.

But like Adair, Legge had the right to a fair trial free from torture or coercion. The glaring contrast between Adair's legal rights and the spine-chilling way Legge lost his life should concentrate the minds of the human rights' community in the North. They must accept that the state is not the only party guilty or potentially guilty of human rights abuses.

When Amnesty International changed its policy in the mid-Nineties and decided to investigate abuses not only by the state but also by illegal armed groups, some in the North's civil liberties lobby were reluctant. The NIHRC now offers a fresh start, a chance to create a human rights culture in Northern Ireland. The Commission deserves support and encouragement. But it must be prepared occasionally to step on the bovver boots of the paramilitaries as well as the shoes of the state, otherwise people will lose faith in its ability to defend our basic freedoms.

Meanwhile, when is the RUC going to name the organisation orchestrating the pipe bomb attacks on vulnerable Catholic families in Larne and Coleraine? If, as most suspect, the UDA is behind this sectarian intimidation, then surely it is time for the authorities to say so? And if they have the backbone to do so, will they re-arrest any recently released UDA prisoner engaged in these Nazi-like activities?

webTitle: Tories in U-turn to fight cigarette advertising ban

fields.headline: Tories in U-turn to fight cigarette advertising ban
fields.standfirst:
Special report: smoking
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories will try to scupper a government ban on cigarette advertising tomorrow in a U-turn triggering a furious row over their links to the tobacco industry.
fields.body:
The Tories will try to scupper a government ban on cigarette advertising tomorrow in a U-turn triggering a furious row over their links to the tobacco industry.

At least five Conservative frontbenchers have taken free perks from tobacco firms during this parliament, including tickets to prestigious rugby and tennis matches.

Opposition arguments that the ban will not reduce smoking have been dismissed in leaked government papers, obtained by The Observer, which show that at least two Cabinet Ministers in the Major government argued for a ban after seeing evidence that it curbed the lethal habit.

Ministers are facing a bitter battle with the powerful cigarette lobby over their Tobacco Advertising and Promotion Bill, which they say could eventually save 3,000 smokers' lives a year by ending promotion of cigarettes.

Tobacco firms are already threatening to slash their prices to keep people smoking if the ban succeeds.

When the Bill has its second reading in the Commons tomorrow, the Tories will table an amendment to kill it, despite previous promises to accept a ban. That amendment is expected to fail, but determined attempts to water the measures down will continue.

'This is a leopard that hasn't changed its spots,' said the Labour MP and veteran anti-smoking campaigner Kevin Barron. 'It is quite clear from these leaked memos that people very high up in the Conservative Party have been in favour of bans for public health reasons. The only explicable reason why they don't support this current legislation must be their addiction to the tobacco industry.' The Tobacco Manufacturers Association, whose director of public affairs John Carlisle is an ex-Tory MP, is understood to have liaised closely with the Tories.

However shadow health secretary Liam Fox, a former GP with strong anti-smoking views, insisted policy was not swayed by the lobby. He was opposing the 'tokenistic' Bill to make the Government crack down on tobacco smuggling which flooded Britain with cheap products instead. 'We're saying to them they must come up with better evidence for a ban,' he added.

However, the leaked memo from the then Health Secretary Virginia Bottomley to Prime Minister John Major in 1993 argued the evidence showed 'tobacco advertising does affect total tobacco consumption' and that bans on promotion had a 'useful effect'.

She concluded that 'commercial freedom of expression' still outweighed health advantages. But a confidential memo from Michael Heseltine - backed by John Gummer - to Major reveals he believed a ban was 'the credible way forward', while William Waldegrave 'would not have opposed an outright ban' if proposed.

The plan was dumped, but revived by Labour in its manifesto - only for them to be severely embarrassed by the news that they delayed banning sponsorship for motor racing after Formula One chief Bernie Ecclestone gave the party £1 million.

The five frontbenchers who declare tobacco industry hospitality in the Commons register of members' interests insisted their views were not influenced by corporate largesse.

They are: Shadow Attorney General Edward Garnier, who had a day's shooting courtesy of the tobacco industry this month; pensions spokeswoman Jacqui Lait, taken to a rugby international by Imperial Tobacco in 1999; Nigel Evans, constitutional affairs spokesman, who went to the Wimbledon tennis finals with Imperial in 1999; Whip Geoffrey Clifton-Brown, taken on a day's shooting by the TMA in 1999; and home affairs spokesman Nick Hawkins, who enjoyed a clay pigeon shoot courtesy of Imperial.

webTitle: Flight clots could be killing 300 a year

fields.headline: Flight clots could be killing 300 a year
fields.standfirst:
New investigation shows pilots share in deadly risk as evidence mounts on dangers of long-haul air travel

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: New investigation shows pilots share in deadly risk as evidence mounts on dangers of long-haul air travel.
fields.body:
Alarming new evidence emerged yesterday that at least 300 people a year could be dying from flight-related blood clots.

Even though The Observer first warned of the dangers of economy class syndrome two years ago, airlines have refused to act. Now fresh research to be published in the British Medical Journal reveals that a tenth of blood clots treated at one London hospital were caused by sitting immobile on flights. If these figures were represented nationally it would point to 3,000 cases a year and 300 deaths, making death from a blood clot a greater risk than in a plane crash.

Our investigation has also uncovered the first evidence that British pilots and aircrew have been victims of Deep Vein Thrombosis. At least five have been affected, including two who developed potentially deadly pulmonary embolisms. The Civil Aviation Authority last night confirmed it did know of cases of pilots with blood clots, but declined to divulge any further information, citing medical confidentiality.

But one pilot, writing on the Professional Pilots' website, said: 'I can confirm that aircrew have in the past, and still do, suffer from DVT. I suffered a pulmonary embolism at the age of 37. Luckily, after three months off, the CAA reissued my class one. Recently a colleague suffered the same fate and luckily he survived as I did. I sincerely hope no one suffers the same fate, but unfortunately it does happen.'

Labour MP Tam Dalyell last night accused the CAA of 'passing by on the other side of the road' and described official attitudes to DVT as 'appalling'.

'I shall be putting down parliamentary questions to John Prescott and will write to him, showing him The Observer's evidence. I shall continue to raise this issue for as long as it takes,' said Dalyell.

'There is credible evidence of, at least, a serious problem. In a situation where airlines for financial reasons are under pressure to increase the number of bottoms on seats and therefore reduce leg-room, it is essential that we have objective medical opinion and a truthful statement of the number of air travellers who have suffered.'

Yesterday it emerged that the youngest-ever chief executive of advertising giant J Walter Thompson, Chris Jones, has taken early retirement after being stricken by flight-related DVT. He collapsed after stepping off a New York to Switzerland flight. Doctors told him he was lucky to survive.

British Airways has declined to take part in medical studies of 'economy class syndrome' proposed by Professor Kevin Burnand, head of surgery at Guy's, King's and St Thomas's Hospitals, and Dr Patrick Kesteven of Newcastle University. The doctors wanted access to the airline's passengers before and after air travel so that a scientific study of the relationship between flying and blood clotting could be undertaken.

In Australia, Professor Reginald Lord, a surgeon at St Vincent's Hospital and professor of surgery at the University of New South Wales, approached Qantas in 1993 to carry out a study but the airline's board rejected the proposal.

Research by surgeon John Scurr of University College Hospital, London, to be published shortly in the Lancet, will show that long-haul flights can cause blood clots. Some 200 passengers were tested by ultra-sound before flying and were found to have no clots. After flying, 10 per cent had blood clots.

Evidence gathered in the hospitals closest to Gatwick shows that doctors there see 100 people a year who suffer from deep vein thrombosis, of whom about 8 per cent die or are dead on arrival.

If the new figures from Ealing Hospital are represented nationally, the figure of 300 deaths could be a conservative estimate. Mr Scurr told The Observer: 'I suspect the figure of deaths caused by blood clots on flights to be in hundreds every year.'

The Observer knows of at least seven cases of people suffering blood clots on return flights. They are:

 Val Clark, now 60, of Gateshead, who flew back from the States in 1995. Doctors amputated her left leg below the knee because of a blood clot.

 Pamela Davidson, a healthy 64-year-old who flew from Australia to London for her daughter's wedding. She died on the return journey over Alice Springs in July 1998.

 Lord Graham of Edmonton who, flying Club Class from Australia, developed a severe pain in his right leg.

 Dentist Ann Egerton whose life was saved by her GP husband on a BA flight back from South Africa.

 Emma Christoffersen, a 28-year-old bride-to-be who died in October on a return flight.

 Policeman John Thomas, who died last year after a return flight from Hawaii.

 Angie Ruby, who died 14 days after stepping off the return journey from Cuba.

webTitle: Rogue foreign adoption couples face jail

fields.headline: Rogue foreign adoption couples face jail
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: Couples who go abroad to adopt children in order to evade stringent checks in Britain face up to three months in jail under a Government crackdown on the baby trade.
fields.byline: Gaby Hinsliff and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
Couples who go abroad to adopt children in order to evade stringent checks in Britain face up to three months in jail under a Government crackdown on the baby trade.

Ministers yesterday promised urgent reforms as the furore over Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the couple who bought their infant twins from an American broker over the internet, intensified.

The Kilshaw case exposed loopholes through which potentially unsuitable couples could dodge child welfare safeguards by adopting overseas.

Under measures to be rushed through by April, the Government will make it a criminal offence punishable by jail or a fine to adopt from other countries without first going through the same strict checks as couples wanting to adopt in Britain.

'Adoption is a service for children, it's not a service for adults,' said Health Secretary Alan Milburn.

"We want more children to be adopted which is why we are reforming the system to make it fairer and faster, but in doing so the interests of the child will always come first. That means children from other countries as well as our own."

Government sources insisted the legislation was already planned and was not triggered by the case.

The Kilshaws face a court hearing in Birmingham on Tuesday over the twins, for whom wardship proceedings were issued yesterday. Their solicitor, Dianne Miller, said they feared their two sons, James, seven, and Rupert, four, could be taken into care.

Campaigners welcomed the measures but said government guidance on reputable agencies and lawyers was also essential.

fields.headline: Cook date with Fischer set to reignite EU bitterness
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: One of Europe's most controversial political leaders will reignite the bitter debate over Britain's future in the European Union when he arrives in London on Tuesday for meetings with the pro-European Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook.
fields.body:
One of Europe's most controversial political leaders will reignite the bitter debate over Britain's future in the European Union when he arrives in London on Tuesday for meetings with the pro-European Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook.

In a move which threatens to reopen old government wounds on the issue, Joschka Fischer, the German Foreign Minister and a strong advocate of a European super-state, will use a joint press conference with Cook to discuss the future of federalism on the Continent.

Cook's agreement to appear will be seized on by Eurosceptics as evidence that he remains keen to take a leading role in the European debate.

The move will come after fresh criticism of the Government by one of the Continent's most respected military leaders over its agreement to join the European Rapid Reaction Force .

In an interview with The Observer , General Klaus Naumann, former head of Nato's military committee, said the project to deploy up to 12,000 British troops in European peace-keeping activities around the world was ill thought out and threatened Europe's relationship with the United States.

Fischer, a firm supporter of the new force, was damned by anti-European campaigners when he gave a speech last May saying that the EU would have to proceed towards a federal structure if it was to succeed. He is now viewed as the leading hate-figure by those on the Right.

A German embassy official said Fischer would be bringing his arguments about federalism to the heart of the British debate. 'We do not think federalism is a swear word,' he said. 'Mr Fischer has not changed his mind, and if he is asked about it he will talk about it. We know it is a difficult subject for many people here, but it should be debated.'

There is concern in government circles that the risky meetings between Cook and Fischer will put the focus back on the fraught relationship between the Foreign Secretary and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, who wants to keep control of the European debate. They have clashed repeatedly on the issue, with Cook being privately criticised by Brown over his vocal support for the euro.

The talks will come as Labour strategists are relieved that William Hague, the Conservative leader, has gone quiet on the subject.

Fischer arrives in Britain fresh from his controversial appearance at the trial of Hans-Joachim Klein, the German Marxist who was involved in a terrorist attack with Carlos the Jackal on an Opec Oil Ministers' meeting in Vienna in the Seventies. Three people were killed.

Fischer, a former colleague of Klein in a left-wing organisation, has been pictured in the German press fighting riot police during Seventies street protests. He has refused to resign.

Naumann's comments will be seen by critics of the Rapid Reaction Force as evidence of deep-seated concerns within Nato. Although he retired last year, he retains close contacts with senior members on both sides of the Atlantic.

'We have to be careful,' Naumann said about the development of the force. 'Should we fall into the trap that we have to be absolutely autonomous in our ability to act, then we will end up with a duplication of institutions. That would trigger a very bitter debate.

'It would reinforce the opinions of those in the United States who believe that the job in Europe is done and say we can turn our back on Europe. That would be a disaster for Europe because, in my view, the task in Europe is not finished.'

webTitle: Baghdad booms as Saddam turns sanctions into gold

fields.headline: Baghdad booms as Saddam turns sanctions into gold
fields.standfirst:
Jason Burke in the Iraqi capital finds Saddam stronger than ever and a class of entrepreneurs exploiting the UN embargo to make fortunes

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Jason Burke in the Iraqi capital finds Saddam stronger than ever and a class of entrepreneurs exploiting the UN embargo to make fortunes.
fields.body:
Khalil Al-Suhail has a problem. If he opens his restaurant too early it fills up with Western businessmen and he cannot seat the local officials whose influence he needs to keep the place open. But if he raises the fake drawbridge of the Castello - Baghdad's latest fashionable nightspot - too late in the evening the staff will not get the tips they have come to expect and they are likely to mutiny.

But al-Suhail knows it is not much of a problem. Jammed in the road outside the four-month-old fake fort are rows of Mercedes, BMWs and Japanese 4x4s. Most of his tables have been booked for days. 'I've been in worse situations in the last 10 years,' he says. He smiles and crosses his arms and his silver watchstrap reflects the neon that glares from the false battlements above.

He is not alone in his high spirits. From the nouveaux riches sampling the Castello's châteaubriand to the beggars who have barely tasted meat in a decade, everyone in Baghdad agrees that things are looking up. Once, the city's streets were full of rubble and stank of sewage, rotting rubbish, violence and fear. Now - as the trade embargo imposed after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait moves into its 11th year - they are full of traffic, brightly lit shops and consumer goods. There are still spots of appalling misery and deprivation, but everyone says things are changing, that the worst is over, that they have survived.

In fact, they have done more than survive. Baghdad is now a city where $35,000 cars are bought within minutes of being driven into showrooms, where women in leopardskin coats and miniskirts go to the National Theatre to watch the latest avant-garde plays, where you can get a PlayStation2 without waiting, where the cafés are full until late and markets open around the clock.

Baghdad is also a city that is proud: proud of having survived the sanctions, proud of having survived three bouts of bombing by US and British planes, and proud, above all, of the man whose heavy, jowly features are on a wall in every office and classroom, on a corner on every street, on 20ft-high posters, placards and banners, on book covers, newspapers and magazines.

Last Wednesday - the anniversary of the start of the air war in the Gulf - Saddam Hussein, now 63, received a 21-gun salute and addressed the nation on television. He spoke of the great victory won in the Umm al-Marrik (Mother of all Battles) against the 650,000-strong allied forces 10 years ago. The victory, he said, was continuing and growing. The Iraqi people, and the Arab and the Islamic worlds, could expect further greatness in the years to come.

Saddam's satisfaction is understandable. Ten years ago he was a pariah. Defeated militarily and diplomatically, his economy was in tatters and his hold on power looked shaky. Now everything is different.

The 500-mile-long road from Jordan to Baghdad cuts across one of the bleakest, hottest deserts in the world. Only when you reach the Euphrates, after 10 hours of driving, does green begin to spatter the dirty, blasted monotony of sand and rock. But, though long, it is a surprisingly easy drive. The road from the Jordanian capital of Amman may be crowded, bumpy and narrow, but once across the border, and past a recent statue of a sword-wielding Saddam on a rearing horse flanked by four flaring Scuds, you hurtle along a new six-lane motorway complete with laybys and picnic spots.

On the old road that still runs parallel, a stream of trucks and tankers rumbles west. They are carrying oil, dates, grain and dozens of other products out of Iraq and out of the United Nations- imposed embargo. Soon the sanctions-busters will not even need a road. Two or three times a week flights take off from Amman for Baghdad - again a contravention of the UN resolutions. Similar flights, all supposedly banned under the sanctions, are planned from Egypt and, it is reported, from Moscow.

There have already been flights into the newly re-opened Baghdad airport from almost every Gulf state. There have been planes from France, Italy and, indirectly, America and the UK.

The marbled lobbies of the five-star hotels in the capital are now packed with businessmen fighting over lucrative contracts. Two months ago 1,450 firms from 30 countries laid out their wares at a trade fair. Ironically, the US company SmithKline Beecham was selling its drugs at an exhibition last week to combat 'depression/anxiety, panic and obsessive compulsive disorder'.

At a government level, Iraq has signed new commercial agreements with Turkey, Russia and Libya. There have been secret negotiations with the Syrians, themselves suspected of receiving huge quantities of smuggled oil by rail in recent months. Last week the details of a huge, new trade treaty were being thrashed out with Cairo.

Even British companies have been negotiating with the regime. One consortium recently opened an office in Jordan - as close as they can get without breaking the embargo - so they are well-placed when the nation with the second biggest oil reserves in the world officially opens for business once more.

'The sanctions are crumbling,' said Professor Humam al-Shamaa, a key government economic consultant. 'They are becoming a joke.' Few, even in Whitehall and Washington, can honestly disagree with him. For four years after the Gulf War the Iraqi people suffered terribly. Many across Iraq, particularly in the south, are suffering still. UN reports suggest hundreds of thousands, particularly the young and old, died as a result of the embargo. Five years ago Saddam agreed to a deal that allowed him to sell oil as long as the earnings, placed in a UN-administered account in New York, were used to buy food and medicine. Much of the cash is soaked up by payments to the UN and war reparations to Kuwait. Red tape, and alleged wilful hindrance, have meant that shortages, particularly of drugs, are common.

The result has been serious damage to the country's health. And though the dying children in Iraq's hospitals are cynically exploited by a wealthy regime to impress visiting journalists, in many cases the UN supervisory system has failed. Permission to import equipment used to treat cancers - for fear of use in weapons programmes - is denied. But it is those weapons - and Saddam's unwillingness to reveal their details - that are at the root of the problem. If, the British and American governments say, Saddam allows international inspectors to check he is no longer able to make nuclear, chemical and biological weapons of mass destruction, then the sanctions will be lifted. They have hinted that the 'no fly zones' in the south and north will be ended too. But while the rest of the world is aiding the collapse of sanctions, Saddam has little incentive to make concessions.

One Western diplomat told The Observer : 'The British and the Americans have painted themselves into a corner. They can't lift the sanctions, because it will hand Saddam a major victory. But the system is collapsing anyway. Either way they'll end up looking like fools - and stupid, vindictive [fools] at that.'

Before Khalil al-Suhail invested in his restaurant he did some market research. 'Soon I knew I'd be fine,' he said. 'I knew I could rely on "embargo gold".'

The harsh truth is that the sanctions, in addition to inflicting suffering on millions, made many very rich. Uday, Saddam's psychotic eldest son, has run the bulk of the regime's oil-smuggling operation and made his father one of the richest men in the world. Sources estimate the dictator's wealth at more than £3 billion.

Through contracts and franchises handed out to associates, a wider circle of loyalists has made a fortune. Thousands of young Iraqi entrepreneurs have taken advantage of the distortions in demand and distribution caused by the sanctions - almost always with a nudge and a wink and a pay-off to the regime. The rationing system maintained under the 'Food for Oil' programme has allowed big farmers to make huge sums selling grain and other commodities. And the huge reconstruction projects - such as the motorways - have made many more rich.

Support for Saddam among the majority of Iraqis - despite his well-known brutality - is in no way diminished.

The al-Hashemi family are the sort of people Western planners hoped would oppose Saddam. Intellectual, politi cised, educated (and even with vital military connections), they remember 'the good days' before the wars and the sanctions.

'We have suffered a lot in the last 20 years,' says Mohammed, now a government servant whose $25 monthly salary, added to the government food rations, just about keeps a decent standard of living for his five-strong family.

He is scathing about the 'profiteers' and 'merchants of war' who now comprise Baghdad's elite. But he says - and given that he only agreed to meet in secrecy (his name has been changed) he is probably telling the truth - he is now a supporter of the President. 'As the grip has tightened on our country more and more, we have got closer and closer to our leader. He is now the embodiment of the spirit of our nation and we are proud of him.'

Such support is unlikely to erode soon. For a decade Iraqi schoolchildren have learnt about the great victory of Saddam over the vicious, Muslim-hating, neo-colonialist West. In recent months Saddam's prestige has been boosted by his outspoken support for the four-month-old Palestinian uprising.

At Friday prayers last week at the 700-year-old shrine of Sheikh Abdul Qadeer al-Gilani in old Baghdad a packed congregation heard a sermon condemning to hell those who stood by and allowed their fellow Muslims to be harmed. It was a sideswipe both at those who ignored the Palestinians and those who have failed to support Iraq. Afterwards the imam, Sheikh Afif, told The Observer that the Iraqi people had showed 'the patience of Job' in their suffering.

He recited an Iraqi proverb. 'A journey of a thousand miles starts with just one step,' he said. 'We started directly after the American and British aggression. Now our thousand miles are nearly travelled. Our victory is nearly complete.'

webTitle: El Salvador earthquake aftermath

fields.headline: The playground that became a cemetery
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: When the earthquake came, it took the children of Las Colinas. They were in the playground with their parents when the weight of the collapsing mountain bore down upon the suburb of Santa Tecla. Now the playground is buried.
fields.body:
When the earthquake came, it took the children of Las Colinas. They were in the playground with their parents when the weight of the collapsing mountain bore down upon the suburb of Santa Tecla. Now the playground is buried. Toys litter the site. Beneath the rubble, say locals, are the remains of their neighbours and their children.

César Valdés, a businessman, believes up to 700 bodies may be buried - 100 of them killed at what was once the playground. 'There were so many kids because it was 11.45 in the morning. Most were playing in that playground. We found a lot of little bodies.

'And there was a really big restaurant there too. At that time it was close to lunch. There were around 100 people right there and everyone was killed. And right by the top of the field was a construction site. Forty workers were there. We didn't find a single one.'

Cecilia Rodríguez, 22, has lost her mother, brother, sister-in-law and nephew - all perished when their house was wiped out by the landslide. Cecilia, a psychology student, was at the university at the time; her father was out and about. Now both are at the temporary morgue every day from 6am. Cecilia has looked at every body that has been recovered.

'It was very pretty and quiet here,' she says as we walk through the sludge that used to be her neighbourhood. 'But you never know what's going to happen.'

The massive landslide has transformed the geography of Las Colinas. The weight of the collapsing mountainside wrenched houses from their foundations.

Corpses of people who lived at the top of the slope are being found hundreds of metres down the hill. Houses, people and possessions are tangled together beneath the soil. The debris of everyday life is scattered everywhere: a pair of jeans; a red tie; photos.

Cecilia used to live here too. The community was tightly knit, she says. She knew most of the neighbours. Now she knows their tragedies: 'I have a friend and all his family died. His mother, father, two little brothers. Other friends have lost their parents. They are 16, 15 and the little one is 10. All the neighbours that survived, they are looking for their families. It's very difficult. Now they are just finding arms and legs and you have to recognise them.'

In the alleyway that is the temporary morgue, you start to recognise the same faces waiting every day.

Identification is now becoming almost impossible. Nearly all of the corpses are mutilated and decomposing. Recovered cadavers are bagged in bin-liners and carried in on stretchers. A cry of expectation goes up from the relatives when each new body is brought in. 'Hombre o mujer? Man or woman?'

Sometimes it's impossible to tell the gender.

A child-sized shape is rushed into the morgue. When the pathologists uncover it you see it is not a child, it is a pair of legs.

A hand comes in and is recognised by its watch. A decapitated man is rushed in, covered in mud. But there is a wallet in his pocket and a bank card reveals his name. The air reeks with the stench of death. Men in spacesuits blast the area with jets of lime. On Friday, Cecilia was identifying a body. 'It's her brother,' an onlooker said. Her father stood by the morgue barrier, awaiting the verdict. She shook her head.

'Are you sure?' asked her father. 'They said it was him.' She shook her head again. Identification has come down to recognition of personal effects. 'They only thought it was Jorge because that man was wearing jeans and a tee-shirt.'

'I found my mother,' she said with sadness and relief. I found my mother at 6pm. And at 3.15am I found my sister-in-law. It was so hard to recognise them. I recognised my mother because she was wearing a ring that I used to wear.' She identified her sister-in-law from a ballerina pendant. The bodies were not together and had been dragged far from where the house used to be.

Finding the bodies has brought some peace, but until her brother and his son are found there will be no rest. 'If we don't find them, we will stay all night.'

Consuela de Palencia feels the same. 'I am looking for my mother. I will come everyday until I find her,' she vowed.

Jamin Wight, 23, a Red Cross volunteer said: 'Sometimes I think we should give up and concentrate on the living, but then I think we owe the dead respect. It feels like its almost impossible, 'We're like blind people digging. If there's a strong stench you're pretty sure there's a body there.' Mounds of earth are being carried away by the hour. There is a new dump three kilometres outside Santa Tecla. Truckload by truckload, Las Colinas is being ferried away into the landfill. Rescue workers say they are careful that no body parts go to the dump but on Thursday people were sifting through the new site. 'Bodies,' says a taxi driver to a British aid worker as they drove by.

A cry of expectation goes up from the relatives when each new body is brought in. 'Hombre o mujer? Man or woman?' Sometimes it's impossible to tell the gender. A child-sized shape is rushed into the morgue. When the pathologists uncover it you see it is not a child, it is a pair of legs. A hand comes in and is recognised by its watch. A decapitated man is rushed in, covered in mud. But there is a wallet in his pocket and a bank card reveals his name. The air reeks with the stench of death. Men in spacesuits blast the area with jets of lime. On Friday, Cecilia was identifying a body. 'It's her brother,' an onlooker said. Her father stood by the morgue barrier, awaiting the verdict. She shook her head. 'Are you sure?' asked her father. 'They said it was him.' She shook her head again. Identification has come down to recognition of personal effects. 'They only thought it was Jorge because that man was wearing jeans and a tee-shirt.' 'I found my mother,' she said with sadness and relief. I found my mother at 6pm. And at 3.15am I found my sister-in-law. It was so hard to recognise them. I recognised my mother because she was wearing a ring that I used to wear.' She identified her sister-in-law from a ballerina pendant. The bodies were not together and had been dragged far from where the house used to be. Finding the bodies has brought some peace, but until her brother and his son are found there will be no rest. 'If we don't find them, we will stay all night.' Consuela de Palencia feels the same. 'I am looking for my mother. I will come everyday until I find her,' she vowed. Jamin Wight, 23, a Red Cross volunteer said: 'Sometimes I think we should give up and concentrate on the living, but then I think we owe the dead respect. It feels like its almost impossible, 'We're like blind people digging. If there's a strong stench you're pretty sure there's a body there.' Mounds of earth are being carried away by the hour. There is a new dump three kilometres outside Santa Tecla. Truckload by truckload, Las Colinas is being ferried away into the landfill. Rescue workers say they are careful that no body parts go to the dump but on Thursday people were sifting through the new site. 'Bodies,' says a taxi driver to a British aid worker as they drove by.

webTitle: Pakistani national park under threat

fields.headline: Shell threat to drill in Pakistan wildlife reserve
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: It is one of the most beautiful areas of Pakistan. Famed for its endangered animals and ancient wooded landscape, it is internationally listed and protected by law. But Kirthar national park is set to be exploited for gas and oil production by one of the world's most profitable oil companies, which spends millions of pounds trumpeting its environmental record.
fields.byline: Anthony Browne  in London and Rory McCarthy in  Islamabad
fields.body:
It is one of the most beautiful areas of Pakistan. Famed for its endangered animals and ancient wooded landscape, it is internationally listed and protected by law. But Kirthar national park is set to be exploited for gas and oil production by one of the world's most profitable oil companies, which spends millions of pounds trumpeting its environmental record.

The Anglo-Dutch oil giant Shell this week faces a court battle with environment campaigners determined to stop it. Shell has been given permission to explore for oil in Kirthar by former executives who now hold senior positions in local and national government.

The battle is likely to further tarnish the international reputation of Shell, which took a battering over its association with human rights abuses against the Ogoni tribe in Nigeria. The company has been making overtures to Saddam Hussein to develop the oil industry in Iraq, and has triggered protests in Bangladesh for its plans to survey the Sunderbans, the world's largest tiger reserve and an internationally protected wetland.

Shell Pakistan has got an exploration licence for 90 per cent of Kirthar, and has started a preliminary assessment before completion of a 12-month study into environmental side effects by the University of Melbourne.

Shell gained permission from the governor of Sindh province, Mohammed Mian Soomro, a director of Shell Pakistan until he became governor last year. Pakistan's oil minister, Usman Aminuddin, is a former executive of a Shell subsidiary, Burshane.

Campaigners say drilling threatens one of the country's largest wildlife sanctuaries. 'In the park we have a number of endangered species. We are very apprehensive,' said Farhan Anwar, a campaign leader. 'Drilling for oil and gas is a dirty business. It always hurts the environment.'

Kirthar is home to the unique Sindh ibex, a species of wild goat, as well as rare wild sheep, gazelles, desert wolves and leopards. Covering more than 740,000 acres, the park climbs up through valleys and forests into the Kirthar mountain range 80 miles from Karachi.

Water from the mountains flows into the Hub River, a water supply for the 14 million people in Karachi. The park contains archaeological sites dating back to 3500 BC.

'This project is illegal,' said Anwar. 'There is very clear and unambiguous legislation which clearly prohibits any kind of mining activity.'

Kirthar is protected against mining and cultivation under a 29-year-old Sindh government law. Yet in 1997 Pakistan awarded a mining and exploration licence to Premier Exploration, which two years later merged its operations with Shell.

Nine environmental organisations petitioned Sindh High Court in December warning 'a great ecological disaster is impending', and demanding the exploration licence be cancelled.

The case is due to be heard on Wednesday, when campaigners are hoping the court will at least issue an order delaying the work.

A spokesman for Shell International said: 'Premier & Shell Pakistan believe its actions so far, sanctioned by the government of Sindh, have been within the law. We have no further comment until judgment is made.'

webTitle: Leader: Put children first

fields.headline: Put children first
fields.standfirst:
We must move faster on new law

Special report: child protection
Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: We must move faster on new law
fields.body:
Tiny children touch all too exposed nerves in many of us. So it is unsurprising that the 'tragedy of internet adoption' has become an opportunity for political grandstanding. However, no political party can claim the moral high ground in the recent history of adoption law. The Conservative Party dropped new legislation from its last Queen's Speech in 1996, fearing embarrassment over the inevitable - and proper - need to recognise unmarried couples as adopters.

New Labour has been just as timid. What the current Parliament has passed, however, is the Adoption (International Aspects) Act 1999. This will provide protection for children adopted from overseas. It will also bring in sanctions for those who ignore its provisions. But the Bill has still not been enacted.

Whether the cause of the Government's delay has been sloth, incompetence or political cowardice, it should move swiftly now. But as Mary Riddell points out in What am I bid for this baby?, enactment will still not encompass adoption from America. The special 'designation' which provides this loophole should be abolished immediately. Then all UK residents bringing children from abroad would have to pass domestic adoption tests.

Babies Belinda and Kimberley would thus have been offered immediate protection upon their arrival in Britain last week. With infertility now affecting 10 per cent of couples and a tiny number of children available for adoption in Britain, we should have no prejudice against adopting from abroad. We should also set aside alarmist panic about using the internet, no more modern a form of communication than the fax was 20 years ago. It is all too easy to forget that properly-supervised adoption can offer desperately-needed stability to tens of thousands of children with appropriate new parents.

webTitle: Inauguration Notebook

fields.headline: Inauguration Notebook
fields.standfirst:
Ten-gallon Texans take over the town as stars melt away

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Ten-gallon Texans take over the town as stars melt away
fields.body:
Well there's Larry Gatlin, Linda Davis and Neil Carter. Say who? It seems the only star-power George W. Bush could pull - apart from Lord Lloyd Webber and Ricky Martin - was a relatively unknown bunch of country and western singers.

Inauguration 2001 isn't exactly Hollywood. This year it's next to impossible to find any significant star or mogul attending any inaugural parties, much less throwing them. No Jack Nicholson, Barbra Streisand or Warren Beatty, not even the traditional MTV bash. Bush just isn't hip enough - no question.

It's not as though the Texas brigade has courted the media and entertainment worlds either. Even Preston Padden, chief lobbyist for Walt Disney, was without an inaugural invitation. Media lobbyist Michelle Laxalt faced the same problem: 'Maybe it's my deodorant,' she joked.

TV network NBC, and its corporate bosses at General Electric, were alone in throwing a bash for the Bushies: GE chairman Jack Welch went on about the new President's 'great instincts' at the Friday afternoon fete - and it will probably pay dividends. New White House chief of staff Andy Card hinted that NBC can expect a sympathetic ear when it comes to keeping the regulators at bay.

 They've been calling Rick Meyers for weeks, but the Texan co-chairman of the Black Tie and Boots Ball has remained unmoved. Some corporate climbers have even sent cheques for $25,000 - only to have them returned with a polite note saying the barbecue bash sold out long ago when it emerged the new President would be attending. 'The phones just erupted,' says Meyers. Demand for Friday night's inaugural ball was so great some disloyal Texans sold out on the online auctioneer eBay.com, pocketing as much as $5,000 for their individual tickets.

 Some 9,000 guests showed up on Friday night at the Marriott Wardman Park hotel to chow down on two-and-a-half tons of beef brisket and smoked ham, shrimp, guacamole and 500lb of down- home peach cobbler for dessert. There was a genuine windmill, chuck wagon and a fibreglass mule replica known as 'Old Pete', which Meyers insists is a 'national monument' from his own home town of Muleshoe, to make everyone feel right at home.

 There's been a run on Texas boots and ten-gallon hats at Washington-area cowboy couturiers. Boot Village in Fairfax, Virginia, says sales of stetsons and other Texan accoutrements were up 30 per cent last week; same story at American Hatters in upscale Bethesda, Maryland.

 It's a culture clash of epic proportions - and it's got the capital's Georgetown salons in a tangled tizzy. But worried talk of the 'Big Hair Problem' is not limited to the salons of the A-list politeratti: even the hairstylists are fretting about four years of bleaching and backcombing. Stylists at Georgetown's Ilo, where the most minimal snip costs $155, were despairing of a new demand for gravity-defying Texas-style hair as hordes of rhinestone cowgirls invade town. Ilo owner Gary Walker says he's come up with a compromise to help the Texans blend in with sleeker Washingtonians.

'We came up with an interpretation of Texas hair - something fresher, more stylish, but still fun and fabulous,' he told the Washington Post . 'People were coming in wanting a Texas look, but they could tell it really wasn't going to work in Washington. We tried for something sexy, but big, and a little more sophisticated ...a tamed bigness, kind of Jennifer Lopez.'

Apparently other salons have refused the Texas look - 'no chance I'd be caught dead doing the big hair thing,' said someone at Cristophe, the Beverly Hills stylist who held up air traffic control by cutting the newly inaugurated President Clinton's hair on Air Force One at Los Angeles airport in 1993.

 Yet more evidence that the new President was born with a silver cutlery set in his mouth: 'I'm hopeful. I know there is a lot of ambition in Washington, obviously. But I hope the ambitious realise they are more likely to succeed with success as opposed to failure,' Bush told Associated Press last Thursday.

webTitle: Did the net black out California?

fields.headline: Did the net black out California?
fields.standfirst:
Silicon Valley tech giants are blamed for overloading a power system that is now on the edge of collapse

More net news
fields.trailText: A power struggle is raging in California where there is not enough electricity to keep the lights on, but more than enough blame to go around - even if a bickering array of politicians, financiers, environmentalists, consumers and technology moguls cannot agree on who or what sparked the energy crisis that has plunged large areas of the state into darkness.
fields.body:
A power struggle is raging in California where there is not enough electricity to keep the lights on, but more than enough blame to go around - even if a bickering array of politicians, financiers, environmentalists, consumers and technology moguls cannot agree on who or what sparked the energy crisis that has plunged large areas of the state into darkness.

One thing everyone can agree on is that the crisis, officially a state of emergency in what would be the world's seventh-largest economy, can only get much worse. The rolling blackouts are already reverberating through that economy - threatening everything from milk supplies to petrol deliveries. There is dark talk now of long queues and higher prices at the pump - and of recession.

'California is getting to the point where it's going to have a crisis that's a helluva lot bigger than the one it already has on its hands,' says Bill Greehey, the chief executive of Valero Energy, which supplies about 10 per cent of the state's petrol. 'It's going to be disastrous for our economy.'

Two-thirds of Californians polled by the Los Angeles Times say they expect a recession this year, and some Wall Street analysts have gone so far as to predict bank failures, chaos in the bond markets and a drying up of business lending, as well as job cuts.

So who is to blame? Most point to what they say is a greedy group of power generators cashing in on the state's now discredited deregulation scheme - and the politicians who passed the laws. The scheme forced utility companies to buy in electricity at soaring market rates but pre vents them from passing those costs on to consumers. Now the companies are just a filament away from bankruptcy - and no one wants to sell them any more electricity for fear they cannot pay their bills.

There is also the weather - a hot summer and a significantly colder winter - and drier than usual conditions in the Pacific North-West, limiting supplies of hydroelectric power to the US's most populous state.

Then there is the powerful environmentalist lobby, now taking heat for an array of green-friendly regulations, which have made building new power plants in California next to impossible. And, of course, consumers, who do not see why they should ever have to turn off a light when they leave a room.

And now there is a fresh target for the wrath of the newly powerless: the internet. Silicon Valley is accused of overloading California's power infrastructure.

A recent study suggests the internet now accounts for 8 per cent of national electricity consumption - and could come to consume between 30 and 50 per cent of it in 20 years . This statistic has been seized on by President George W. Bush as he seeks to justify an energy policy that will allow oil drilling and coal mining in the pristine wilderness of Alaska - but the figures are spurious, say some analysts.

The internet, after all, was supposed to conserve energy by making businesses run more efficiently - and it was widely believed that computers and wireless devices use much less energy than refrigerators or washing machines.

Not so, say the two free-market conservative analysts powering the blame-the-internet movement. Mark Mills and Peter Huber of the 'Digital Power Report' and the coal industry-funded Greening Earth Society, insist a Palm Pilot uses as much energy as a refrigerator - citing invisible 'back-end' network and telecommunications infrastructure such as routers, servers and digital transmission systems for the surge in electricity use. Power consumption in Silicon Valley, they say, has been growing at three times the rate of the rest of the California's - with Oracle, Intel, Sun Microsystems and the like using the same mega-wattage as 'a steel mill'.

But others say that's simply 'ridiculous'. Steven Taub, an analyst with Cambridge Energy Research Associates says: 'It doesn't take a lot of steel mills shutting down to offset increased demand from computers. You just can't blame my Palm Pilot for this crisis - it runs on two triple-A batteries! But the tech economy behind those devices has led to an unprecedented economic boom - and that means bigger houses, more appliances, more offices - and more demand for electricity.'

Jonathan Koomey, a scientist and the group leader of the End-Use Forecasting Group at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratories in Berkeley, says the blackouts are not related to any such rapid increase in demand. He cites statistics from the California Energy Commission showing only a 2 per cent growth rate in electricity demand in the late 1990s at the height of the e-boom, compared with a growth rate of 3.3 per cent in the late 1980s.

'The people who want to build power plants would like everyone to think that there is huge growth in demand so we can reduce environmental regulations,' says Koomey. 'I think we have to build power plants, yes, but I also think people are trying to create a sense of urgency to make it easier for them to argue for their interests.'

Intel chief executive Craig Barrett is among a growing group of tech billionaires now pushing for the construction of new power plants as they try to avoid 'blue screen death' - the loss of millions of dollars whenever power fluctuates, even for a fraction of a second, because the chips being manufactured can be ruined. Intel, which has been operating under what Barrett calls 'mood lighting' between 4pm and 7pm when the company turns half its lights off voluntarily to conserve electricity, has already threatened to move some operations to Oregon, Arizona, New Mexico and even Israel and Ireland - unless, that is, new power plants get built, and fast.

Other giants such as Sun Microsystems, MCI WorldCom and website host Verio have resorted to diesel generators to keep their businesses humming - a trend now so pervasive that environmental regulators fear that diesel exhaust could soon add significantly to pollution.

Last Thursday, California lawmakers approved a $400 million plan to turn the lights back on. The bail-out will allow the state to buy power on the open market and provide it to the near-bankrupt utilities - Pacific Gas & Electric and Southern California Edison - at low cost. But the money won't go far. State Senate leader John Burton said: 'We can only see it getting worse.'

With no end in sight to the crisis, Californians stocked up on flashlights, candles and firewood, while hardware stores were swamped with requests from small businesses for generators.

webTitle: Mary Riddell on adoption regulations

fields.headline: What am I bid for this baby?
fields.standfirst:
The furore over the Kilshaws masks the desperate plight of children waiting to be adopted in this country

Special report: child protection
Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The furore over the Kilshaws masks the desperate plight of children waiting to be adopted in this country.
fields.body:
Can there be a happy ending for the internet twins? As the authorities, from Arkansas to Flintshire, dissect their case, it is too early to speak of good outcomes. It is also, perhaps, too late. Assorted research shows that babies shuffled from one carer to the next may be traumatised and damaged for life.

Though the going rate for Kimberley and Belinda was set at the knockdown price of £8,200, the real cost of the deal is unquantifiable and, as yet, unpaid. Meanwhile, a spider's web of interests ensnares the girls. The Allens of California want them back. So do the final purchasers, the Kilshaws of North Wales. For now, social services have gained possession in the pass-the-parcel game of human life, and the long, messy legal battle begins.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw, who will take their claim to the High Court this week, may be perfect parents. It could transpire that they run a spotless home. It is possible that there were sound reasons for allegedly calling in ghostbusters to investigate paranormal phenomena chez Kilshaw. However, as Mrs Kilshaw said, with unusual prescience, she is now 'the most hated figure in Britain'.

But the real villains are the internet agencies, e-tailing's slave traders, supplying children to order. The market rate for Chinese baby girls is £10,800, whereas a healthy, white, American boy will set you back twice as much. It is no good pretending, as some have, that there is nothing much amiss with this extension of the retail business. In an age when courts assess whether we can buy bananas by the pound or purchase Levi jeans in Tesco, it is ludicrous to suggest that an unregulated trade in humanity is anything but vile.

Even so, there is a whiff of double standards. For a start, baby-selling scandals are nothing new. Exactly a year ago, Eunice, Lousiana, a quiet town in the Cajun heartland, was identified as the Wal-mart of the US baby trade. Rich British couples were reportedly contacted on the internet by facilitators offering children supplied by young, single mothers gathered from across America and housed in cockroach-ridden apartments.

The Eunice story attracted little interest. A new Act, passed in 1999, to regulate inter-country adoptions, has stayed mothballed on our statute book. The Kilshaw saga, illustrative of the spread of a globalised baby market, was a débâcle waiting to happen. The fact remains that the internet, legitimately used to match up children and adopters in Britain, is only a shop window for a covert trade that has been going on for years. As for money, inter-country adoption, whether shady or above-board, is, de facto, a luxury available only to those rich enough to pay in the region of £20,000.

A brokerage charge here, a contribution to a Chinese orphanage there. What constitutes a payment for a service, as distinct from a deposit on a life? The Government has dabbled before in the grey area of the human balance sheet by proposing a law outlawing paid surrogacy, only to realise that banning a private compact is as difficult as differentiating between an illegal bung and a legitimate expense.

The hard truth, in surrogacy as in overseas adoption, is that money buys children. In the normal run of events, this uncomfortable fact ruffles few feathers. Contrast the newspaper effusions over Hollywood stars, most recently Calista Flockhart, acquiring babies with the horror ('Revolting' - Jack Straw; 'Disgusting' - Tony Blair) over the Kilshaw case. Such fits of the vapours do not mask the fact that class and cash are the determinants of successful adoption, certainly overseas and, arguably, at home.

Of those who pass the (correctly) stringent tests to become adopters, the vast majority are white, married couples with an average age of 37. The perception of the ideal candidate - middle class and affluent as opposed to posh and pushy - persists. A new Adoption Act, following last December's White Paper, will force a debate the Government will not want to have on whether cohabiting and gay couples will, as they should, be deemed suitable potential parents.

Elsewhere, there is, finally, some action. Last year's Welsh child abuse scandal prompted Blair to promise changes to a rotten system in which potential adopters face 'agonisingly high hurdles' and vulnerable children are 'being let down'. The aim is to increase domestic adoptions by 40 per cent by 2005. A national register will be drawn up and legal processes streamlined.

In addition, the inter-country Act, once activated, should allow the ratification of the Hague Convention on adoption by early next year and close some loopholes in a scandalously leaky system. While babies like Kimberley and Belinda can now be slipped into Britain with no more paperwork than a completed immigration form and a stamp in a passport, children at known risk of abduction are spirited out, just as effortlessly, sometimes never to be returned.

Whatever gaps are plugged, the problem remains that America, a dreadful advocate of children's rights, is not a signatory to the convention. If babies can still be bought like groceries, a beefed-up British law will have to be vigilantly applied. But the adoption crisis is not only about prevention. It is also about enablement. The one hopeful thing to emerge from the twins' case is the glare cast on the shambles of our adoption system.

The Government has more or less promised quick legislation, but it will have to do more. If it truly wants to find parents for legions of British children, it must provide better financial backing for poor and unemployed people deemed suitable adopters. It will have to welcome the gay, the cohabiters, the elderly, the single (who account for only 6 per cent of all adoptions), and all those who fulfil stern criteria and who acknowledge that adoption is less about self-gratification than offering a child a better life.

Altruism is too precious to be squandered in a system where the supply of children vastly exceeds demand. The British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering estimate that 5,000 children in Britain are eligible for adoption every year. Policy decrees that after a while the rejects must, as gently as possible, be told the truth - that no one wants them.

The broader reality is that muddle and bureaucracy conspire to keep children in care, while prospective parents find it simpler to pursue their hunt abroad. Some just want to buy the best. Others, the majority, have entirely generous motives. Many would not wish, or be qualified, to take on an older child.

Even so, as we consider the grim fate of Kimberley and Belinda, it is worth also remembering those who would never constitute internet fodder. In Britain today, hundreds of boys aged between six and 10 await adoptive parents. They do not attract the wrath of rival claimants or the waft of cheque books. Few preach about their best interests and fewer seek to advance them.

Some of the children who wait are black, some white, some disabled, some not. The specification makes little difference. In the remaindered section of the adoption market, over-subscription is not a problem. Half of those boys will live out their childhood without attracting a single inquiry. For strays in Battersea Dogs' Home, the odds can hardly be worse.

webTitle: Leader: A future for the pigeon?

fields.headline: Pigeon fancy
fields.standfirst: A future for our feathered friends
fields.trailText: A future for our feathered friends
fields.body:
We thought People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals were going a bit far when they accused the Mayor of London of 'waging war against the symbol of peace' in Trafalgar Square. Presumably, the protesters had in mind the dove, Columba livia's refined cousin. True, all are close relatives in the family columbidae but everyone knows doves are clean and white and carry olive branches in their beaks while pigeons are grey and dirty and carry bits of spaghetti and hamburger bun from rubbish bins in theirs. Nor, as they strut and square-bash outside the National Gallery, dive-bombing for pigeon feed, do they seem particularly peaceful.

But the pigeon's champions have a point. The birds have been our close associates since 4500BC. Originally, we kept them as pets but soon learned to race them, use them as couriers, and eat them. Today (keep this quiet) they are important laboratory animals, furthering endocrinology research. Livingstone permitting, these hardy birds can live for 35 years.

We believe there is a Third Way: dispersal from central London and a voucher scheme for needy birds who might suffer if Mr Bernard Rayner loses his pigeon-feed concession. Our own street has a fine rowan tree which could house a couple of families. Readers may know of other suitable perches.

webTitle: The mountains always get their man

fields.headline: The mountains always get their man
fields.standfirst: Juggling with nitroglycerin in the Himalayas sets off a lot more sparks than the new Affleck and Paltrow outing
fields.trailText:
Vertical Limit (124 mins, 12)
Bounce (106 mins, 12)
Requiem For a Dream (102 mins, 18)
The Lost Lover (97 mins, PG)
Beautiful Creatures (86 mins, 18)
fields.body:
Vertical Limit (124 mins, 12) Directed by Martin Campbell; starring Chris O'Donnell, Bill Paxton, Robin Tunney, Scott Glenn
Bounce (106 mins, 12) Directed by Dan Roos; starring Gwyneth Paltrow, Ben Affleck
Requiem For a Dream (102 mins, 18) Directed by Darren Aronofsky; starring Ellen Burstyn, Jared Leto, Marlon Wayans
The Lost Lover (97 mins, PG) Directed by Roberto Faenza; starring Ciaran Hinds, Juliet Aubrey, Stuart Bunce
Beautiful Creatures (86 mins, 18) Directed by Bill Eagles; starring Rachel Weisz, Susan Lynch, Alex Norton, Iain Glen, Maurice Roeve

Martin Campbell has yet to direct anything in the cinema as good as his 1985 TV serial, Edge of Darkness, but he's proved adept at the large-scale action movie with the first Pierce Brosnan Bond picture, GoldenEye, the swashbuckling Mask of Zorro and now Vertical Limit, a mountaineering yarn with enough plot for half-a-dozen pictures. One of those half-dozen is Henri-Georges Clouzot's The Wages of Fear, from which it borrows the idea of transporting volatile nitroglycerin over difficult terrain, repeating a famous shot from that picture to show this is a knowing homage.

Shot mostly in New Zealand, it centres on a dangerous ascent of K2, the second highest peak in the Himalayas, planned by a rich Texas businessman (Bill Paxton) to coincide with the inauguration of a new route for his airline. Inevitably things go wrong and he's buried in a deep crevasse at 26,000 feet with an American woman climber, Annie (Robin Tunney), and the expedition's leader. The rescue must be carried out in 27 hours, and the rescue team is composed of people each with a private agenda, among them Annie's brother, Peter (Chris O'Donnell), who has to assuage the guilt brought about by the death of their mountaineering father; a mystic mountaineer (Scott Glenn), who looks like Geronimo and is searching for revenge and his missing wife's body; and a pair of happy-go-lucky Australian hippies. The nitroglycerin is needed to blow open the crevasse and to add yet another hazard to flaking rock, blinding snow, avalanches and so on.

Campbell sustains the tension pretty well and the settings are spectacular. More interesting than the characters, however, are two aspects of the dramatic background. The first is an isolated army post on a mountain peak from which ill-equipped Pakistani soldiers fire an artillery barrage every afternoon in the direction of India as an absurd daily ritual. The second is seeing rich, mindless Americans ruining a beautiful corner of the world in the name of self-discovery. They're a new class of anti-social climbers.

A couple of years ago, Don Roos made his directorial debut with the tough comedy, The Opposite of Sex. Sadly, he's lost his nerve and followed it with the conventional, sentimental Bounce. The Roos has come home to chicken. Ben Affleck plays a womanising advertising agent who, partly in order to spend the night with an available blonde, gives his plane ticket in the snowbound Chicago airport to a married man, eager to get home to Los Angeles for Christmas. The plane crashes with no survivors. Affleck takes to the bottle, starts to despise his work (his firm represents the airline involved), then arranges a chance meeting with the man's widow (Gwyneth Paltrow) and her young sons.

There's a current Hollywood belief (as shown in Blown Away, Random Hearts, Cast Away, Unbreakable) that there's nothing like being in, or just missing, a horrendous accident to make you appreciate the real things in life. But Bounce is factitious stuff. Unlike Bernard MacLaverty's Cal or Graham Greene's The Tenth Man, whose anti-heroes were responsible for the deaths of the women they come to love, the Affleck character has nothing really to hide.

Darren Aronofsky's follow-up to his impressive debut Pi, Requiem For a Dream, is a gruelling picture tracing four sad people in run-down Coney Island as they descend into a hell of drug addiction. A Jewish widow (Ellen Burstyn), becomes addicted to slimming pills she takes to appear on a TV show; her layabout son (Jared Leto) and his partner in petty crime (Marlon Wayans) plan to become big-time dealers, and the son's girlfriend, a middle-class drop-out, wants to open a dress shop. Their dreams drive them to drugs, the drugs destroy the dreams.

Co-adapted by Hubert Selby Jr, author of Last Exit to Brooklyn, from his own novel, Requiem For a Dream is a superbly acted tale of hopelessness and despair that runs through three chapters - Summer, Fall, Winter. Their Spring never comes. The final cross-cutting between the mother undergoing ECT at a New York psychiatric hospital, the son having his gangrenous arm sawn off in a Florida prison and the girlfriend submitting to painful anal sex at a Long Island orgy is hard to watch and impossible to recommend.

Roberto Faenza's Anglo-Italian The Lost Lover is a well-meaning, melodramatic story of a British couple, garage owner (Ciaran Hinds) and his historian wife (Juliet Aubrey), still grieving after 13 years in Israel for their three-year-old son killed in a London street accident. A neurotic young Israeli lad (Stuart Bunce) stumbles into their lives and has some curious therapeutic effect on the wife, before suddenly disappearing. The jerky narration and implausible events are accompanied by clunky dialogue that only Hands manages to deliver with conviction. One assumes it worked better on the pages of the novel by the distinguished Israeli writer A.B. Yehoshua.

Beautiful Creatures, the long-awaited first film of DNA, the company created by Duncan Kenworthy (producer of Notting Hil ) and Andrew Macdonald (Shallow Grave, Trainspotting), is a serious disappointment. This extremely violent black comedy stars Rachel Weisz and Susan Lynch as a pair of Glasgow-based girls in abusive relationships, whose paths cross by chance when one of them accidentally kills the other's brutal boyfriend. They get involved in a murky kidnapping scam, are pursued by a bent copper (Alex Norton) and the dead man's remorseless brother (Maurice Roeves), and more bloody deaths ensue. It resembles the first draft of a Bill Forsyth version of Thelma and Louise that has been rushed into production with Michael Winner directing. It doesn't belong in the same cemetery as Shallow Grave.

webTitle: Architecture: What'll the neighbours think?

fields.headline: What'll the neighbours think?
fields.standfirst: It breaks all the rules: no roof, bricks or windows are visible. But David Adjaye's house is more than a blank street front
fields.trailText: It breaks all the rules: no roof, bricks or windows are visible. But David Adjaye's house is more than a blank street front
fields.body:
For rather less than the price of a swanky kitchen, £80,000 to be exact, David Adjaye's startlingly original house in Whitechapel has breathed new life into an architectural species that looked to be extinct: the one-off house that doesn't cost a fortune.

Designing a successful house used to be the way that serious architectural careers began. Denys Lasdun for example, who died last week, started his long and distinguished professional life with a house that was as good in its own way as anything he ever did. In microcosm you could see in it everything that he was to go on to achieve in much larger, and apparently more complex, projects.

The restricted scale of the single house - a poem, rather than an epic - means that there is no room to hide behind size or repetition as you can in a bigger building, the architect has to get every single piece right. But since Lasdun designed his first house in 1938, the individual house has at times looked to be going the same way as portrait painting, reduced to a faint, provincial echo of a once distinguished art form. Partly it's the crippling cost of land, which has the effect of automatically turning even the most modest one-off house in London into a miniature species of mansion. And in the suburbs con temporary architecture is about as popular as Leylandii in the shrubbery. To try to build anything but very late Georgian, or split-level ranch is to invite years of wrangling with the neighbours about planning permission.

When the photographer Nick Knight commissioned David Chipperfield to remodel his house in a street full of glum semis he had half his neighbours mobilised in a bruising but ultimately unsuccessful bid to stop him that spilled over into the newspapers. Knight liked Chipperfield's quiet modernism so much that when his family grew he bought the house next door, and asked Chipperfield to rebuild it.

After the row over the first house, the constraints on planning consent for a new house were strict. It had to have a pitched roof, it had to have an integral garage like the house it replaced. The planners only stopped short at demanding Tudor-style half timbering. Chipperfield's design elegantly deals with all this on his own terms. It does have a pitched roof, but it is transformed with beautiful thick slabs of solid slate. There is a large shuttered opening at the front but it's not a garage door. It's the interior, connected to the original Chipperfield extension, which is most memorable. Immaculately made, handsomely proportioned rooms are focused on the lush green garden beyond in a way the old house could never match.

Ron Arad's experience was more disheartening. He designed what could have been one of London's most exciting new houses. But from behind their Dallas-style fibre-glass porticoes, the neighbours took such exception to it that, despite the support of English Heritage, they persuaded Haringey Council's planning committee to turn it down. Not surprisingly, his clients moved away. That didn't happen with Adjaye's project. Maybe Britain is finally in a mood in which newness does not automatically provoke outrage. Or perhaps inner-city Tower Hamlets is simply a more tolerant place than the leafy suburbs.

Adjaye, who used to work for David Chipperfield, is beginning to make a name for himself. He has just completed the conversion of the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment's offices, and has won a competition to design a performing arts centre in Boston. And when he was in partnership with William Russell, the practice designed houses for Jake Chapman and Chris Ofili.

The regular pattern of glass and brick set up by the rest of the street is abruptly halted by a mysterious brooding black obelisk. Its smooth shiny skin is actually specially treated plywood; but you would never guess if you hadn't been told. It could equally well be be steel, or lead, an ambiguity that increases its exotic quality. Inside the house, the cramped realities of Whitechapel street life slip away. The house is configured to present carefully framed views of the world, shutting out the mundane houses opposite, letting in the sky, and sunlight, that makes this an entirely personal space.

This was never an exclusively residential area. The terrace was punctuated at intervals to allow room for workshops and small factories. Adjaye's clients, two artists, bought one of them 10 years ago, and made it into a studio to live and work. Ten years later with two children, they had to reassess the way they lived. Why not build a house on the site that made better use of the space around it? The street has been chopped up into discontinuous sections by the intrusion of the local hospital.
