webTitle: Art: The glory that was Rome

fields.headline: The glory that was Rome
fields.standfirst: Caravaggio is the dark star of the Royal Academy's one-off show. It's a monumental achievement - and you'll never see its like again
fields.trailText: The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 Royal Academy, London SW1, until 16 April
fields.body:
The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 Royal Academy, London SW1, until 16 April

There are shows that you don't expect to see more than once in a normal lifetime, shows like The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 at the Royal Academy. Any survey that includes works by Rubens, Van Dyck and Annibale Carracci probably deserves to brag about genius, hardly too strong a word in the context of Rome circa 1600. This one also boasts 40 other artists and more than 150 paintings usually screwed above Italian altars or shielded by laser alarms in the Vatican, Prado or Met.

Well may the RA congratulate itself on having coaxed such art to London on our sole behalf - this show won't be going anywhere else. But the crowning glory of the entire event isn't even mentioned, never mind brandished in that triumphant title, namely the presence, from first to last, of Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio.

From his arrival in 1592 to his sudden departure in 1606 after killing a man in a brawl, Caravaggio was the defining genius of Rome. You see that in room after room of this show, as the lesser paintings seem to turn towards his art as the source of all light and heat. Nor is this just a modern hindsight, abetted by tales of his fiery life; Rome had him pegged as a genius even before 1600. The Church relied on Caravaggio to reinforce its latest theology; collectors resorted to monstrous tactics to acquire his work; and almost every contemporary painter in the Eternal City took something from his art.

The last major Caravaggio show was almost 20 years ago, and unless you were lucky enough to be in New York at the time, you probably didn't see it. Pilgrimage is practically the only way to get a view of his far-flung art - and for that you'd have to go to Rome, Naples, Malta, St Petersburg and Fort Worth at the least. Even that would be a partial view, since Caravaggios are still coming and going - stolen, used as collateral in drug deals or turning up, buried in grime, in some Jesuit refectory in Dublin.

That particular painting, The Taking of Christ (1602), is one of the wonders of the RA show. There are all the Caravaggian attributes, aped by others in weak pastiche: the strongly raking light, the dark cavern in which the figures gesture and twist, the sense of motion so vividly proleptic it seems about to burst right out of the canvas. Christ alone is still, hands calmly clasped in the brutal onslaught, as Judas and a rush of soldiers in black steel close in as if for the kill. Violent, crowded and tight, the event is caught in a flash-bulb glare - and there, at the far right, is Caravaggio himself, holding up the lantern that sheds that light.

Some people see mutiny in this self-portrait, a sort of take-me-as-I-am retort to a patron who may have been trying to control the image. Certainly, almost half of Caravaggio's paintings were too independent for the Church, although recent attempts to make an atheist of him wither with one glimpse of the stark piety that fires his art. Even at 100 yards, the effect is electrifying - witness St John the Baptist, hung at the far end of the long central corridor at the Academy.

This distant figure, naked in the wilderness, seems to have been struck by lightning. Although the eyes are downcast in sepulchral shadow, the sense of concentrated thought, of imminent action, is unimaginably powerful. Painted by Caravaggio, St John becomes again what he was in life - literally a beacon shining out of the darkness.

It's easy to see why everyone wants such strength on their side, why atheists seek to recruit Caravaggio, why artists have him as a proto-romantic or modernist, why socialists co-opt him as the painter of the common people, with their dirty toenails and sunburnt forearms.

It is even easier when you consider that his life is mainly told in other people's words. There are the police records of him wounding a waiter in a spat about an artichoke; murdering an enemy and then taking flight to Naples. There are the documents of his enrolment and subsequent defrocking as a Knight of Malta, and the newspaper accounts of his sudden death at 39 in 1610. Letters describe him as paranoid, irascible and preternaturally gifted. Only one suggests he might have been gay.

Anyone hoping for some clarification of this live-fast-die-young legend ought to go straight to the Royal Academy. For one thing, the Rome this show proposes is a violent, dark and unjust city, stalked by cutthroats, mercenaries and aristocratic thugs. Artists were not spared; their paintings give the picture.

Here is Artemesia Gentileschi's vengeance on the fellow artist who raped her and escaped sentence - he's the bleeding head in her mighty Judith Beheading Holofernes. Here is Cesari's grateful portrait of the lawyer who helped him when a cardinal had the painter falsely imprisoned in order to filch his Caravaggios. Look at Annibale Carracci's desperate self-portrait, no bigger than a playing card, and you see his melancholy death prefigured. Annibale may have painted some of the greatest of all frescoes for the Farnese Palace, but his patron threw him little more than derisory cash.

When Caravaggio arrived in Rome, late mannerism was still in its final flounce. But private collections were increasingly prestigious and originality was valued: enter Caravaggio with the first still lifes. The painting that launches this exhibition is also the first known Caravaggio - a boy with those characteristic Callas eyebrows peeling what looks like a wooden lime. If it is by Caravaggio, it only shows how swiftly he moved from here to the Boy With Basket of Fruit in a matter of months.

This is one of art's greatest invitations - how to choose between the youth, with his yearning mouth, enticing gaze and sleep-ruffled curls, or the ripe cornucopia he displays against his off-the-shoulder drapes? Caravaggio's contemporaries plumped for the fruit; you see that basket over and again, even arriving as if by FedEx to refresh the Holy Family on their flight to Egypt. But everything Caravaggio did was copied - the comic cardsharps, the fortune-tellers, the lute players and singers - as successive galleries of lacklustre imitations unfortunately show.

Rubens can take care of himself, along with Van Dyck, two artists who came south and prospered in Rome. But I'm not sure that Carracci is going to get the revival he merits (even Caravaggio admired him) given his low-level presence here. As for the rest, with the exceptions of Simon Vouet and the Gentileschis, father and daughter, how could they hope to compare?

This is only a fraction of Caravaggio's dynamic output, but even so you get the arc of his comet, how he moved from those still lifes and silent comedies to the absolute austerity of his religious art. The stage gets less cluttered, the light more sacramental, the gestures are so singularly pure and empathetic, they make you think of his contemporary, Shakespeare. Caravaggio knew the precise tilt of a suggestive nod as he now invokes the flinch of pain, the dire weight of a corpse or the out-fling of despair - all of them compressed in the devastating Entombment , borrowed from the Vatican.

In the final room is an altarpiece on loan from the Church of Sant'Agostino in Rome. It shows the Madonna and Child answering the door to a two ordinary pilgrims. If you want to see Caravaggio through his art, this awesome masterpiece can only inspire you to consider him as a visionary realist. The Virgin stands askance in stony shadows, Christ is just a true-born infant, and yet the kneeling pilgrims, with filthy feet and tired faces, are entirely transfigured. This painting would move anyone with eyes to see - which is its whole purpose: the greatest and most demotic image of hope and humility that ever came out of Rome.

webTitle: Dance: I'll have what she's having...

fields.headline: I'll have what she's having...
fields.trailText:
La Ribot South London Gallery, London SE5
Royal Ballet Royal Opera House, London WC2
fields.body:
La Ribot South London Gallery, London SE5
Royal Ballet Royal Opera House, London WC2

While ballet plays safe at the start of the year, aiming for family audiences, the avant-garde assumes that anyone prepared to brave the cold will put up with anything. Unpredictable Spanish performance artist La Ribot exposed herself under the banner of the London International Mime Festival, but she could equally well be in The Place's Resolution series of new dance.

If an ill-advised Resolution evening last Sunday is anything to go by, we're into voyeurism, questioning the male and female gaze. Barely able to keep my eyes open, I passed up an event at the Spitz Gallery offering 'the secrets of the envaginated eye' - the result of a woman inserting a camera into her vagina. But La Ribot's show, Still Distinguished, was promising, for she has never been earnest.

She offers her 'distinguished pieces' - solo vignettes lasting seconds or minutes - for sale as intangible art works (you are then given free tickets to see any performance of your piece). One was still up for grabs on Wednesday. I'm not sure whether it is the episode when she drinks a litre bottle of water, gradually descending, totally nude, from a standing to a lying position; or when she wraps herself in silver foil and writhes on a microphone.

She treats her angular, alabaster body (she is a natural redhead) objectively, a canvas for her tableaux vivants . She trusses it with cord and a London Heathrow label for 'Outsize Baggage', coats it with garlic, tomato and olive oil, decorates it with a merkin and green stiletto shoes. Meticulous rather than messy, she leaves an ordered trail of objects on the gallery floor. Without her enigmatic presence, they lose their fetish appeal. You can't buy La Ribot; you can only experience her.

Most people left the gallery smiling - though not as broadly as audiences do after La Fille mal gardée , Ashton's bucolic romance. The Royal Ballet's revival, which runs in repertoire through to March, provides the chance to see a host of dancers enjoying themselves, newcomers and veterans alike. Thursday's opening cast was tried and tested, from the sturdy Shetland pony to Irek Mukhamedov and Miyako Yoshida as the lovers, and Justin Meissner as a very cocky cockerel. Cheers rang out for John Lanchbery, back conducting the Hérold score he adapted and arranged for the Royal Ballet premiere in 1960.

This is a warmly detailed production in which everyone knows who and why they are. Vivid faces among the cast include the youngsters who have just made notable debuts in The Nutcracker: Marianela Nuñez, who replaced pregnant Darcey Bussell as the Sugar Plum Fairy; Ivan Putrov and Alina Cojocaru, ideal as the tender couple at the heart of the story. Nuñez was so fizzing with excitement at getting her big chance to dance with Roberto Bolle (brought in as a glamorous partner for Bussell) that she almost forgot to win us over. She could learn by watching Yoshida in Fille how to let an audience share in the joy of a performance.

webTitle: A book at bedtime

fields.headline: A book at bedtime
fields.standfirst: Sanjeev Bhaskar has progressed from 'Goodness Gracious Me' to the Kama Sutra - but it's as much about decorating as sex, he tells  Harriet Lane
fields.trailText: Sanjeev Bhaskar has progressed from 'Goodness Gracious Me' to the Kama Sutra - but it's as much about decorating as sex, he tells Harriet Lane
fields.body:
It was the first day on location in Rajasthan, and an interview with an eminent astrologer was scheduled. Sanjeev Bhaskar and the rest of the crew working on Position Impossible: In Search of the Kama Sutra arrived excitedly at the great man's door, only to receive some bad news. Forgetting that visitors were expected, the eminent astrologer had, that very morning, taken an 11-day vow of silence.

'I sat there for 10 minutes thinking, "I don't know what I'm doing here",' says Sanjeev (best known as 'Mr Cheque Please' and 'Mr Everything Comes from India' in the BBC's Goodness Gracious Me ), when we meet at his London club, Teatro. 'I thought, it's all going to be like this. Mental.' In the end, a go-between was found to decode the astrologer's scribbles, and the encounter, which could have been a disaster, was turned into something quite different: a surreal encounter that says a great deal about India, and Sanjeev's fond if bewildered feelings towards it.

It was his idea to make a documentary about the Kama Sutra. It's an idiosyncratic attempt to get past the myth of the book, beyond the smutty associations and the giggles, and explore its relevance: both to its original audience, and a modern one. After all, only a fifth of the book is concerned with bedroom gymnastics. Written in the fourth century by the Hindu sage Vatsyayana, it offers suggestions on a wide variety of social accomplishments: how to sing, fight, make lemonade, read the secrets of the night sky, and decorate your bedroom. 'In the fourth century, Europeans were living in mud huts and had just discovered brass,' says Sanjeev, 36. 'Whereas the Indians had this hugely complex society and were writing books about politics and economics and religion. So the Kama Sutra was written in that context - not as a dirty book, but as a book that tried to explain what a good citizen should do within or when forming a relationship.'

Seeking information from a range of commentators, some of whom shed more light on the text than others, Sanjeev is careful not to use them for cheap gags. The tantric sexpert, for instance, digs his own grave, leaps in, and lies there, quivering expectantly. Sanjeev says, half-regretfully, that he lacks Louis Theroux's courage, but he still manages to coax forth some Theroux-like revelations and, in the process, lets slip just as much about himself.

Over a latte, as on telly, he seems to have very little side: he is funny, relaxed, almost disconcertingly sincere.

Discussing the Kama Sutra 's attitude to marriage, he mentions that his parents had a go at matchmaking him, introducing him to a couple of nice girls, neither of whom seemed 'quite right'. He believes arranged marriage can work, but is pleased his parents have now accepted it's not for him. 'If they do talk about settling down or kids, I don't go, "Mum!" I tend to say I'm not averse to the idea, I'd quite like to settle down, I'm just not in any rush about it.'

'People always assumed that being Indian, I'd know all about it, along with tea and curry and Bollywood movies. I could get away with the other ones - 'It's coriander, you know' - but with the Kama Sutra, it was really tricky. So the easiest thing was to lie. Especially in the uni bar. As a technique, it's a little distracting: quite often, the expression on his face while on location says much more than his monologue does.

He had just weathered a sort of stag night in Lucknow, in which a young woman in a green sari danced for a roomful of giggly, slightly bashful men, force-fed him a samosa, and relieved all present of most of their cash. You can see it from his expression: a small, terrified smile that shrinks as the bosoms and buttocks come in for the kill.

In an attempt to get through the experience, he doggedly maintains eye contact with the lapdancer and makes a few lame conversational forays. 'Your hair is in lovely condition,' he says, and: 'Did you watch much of Euro 2000?' It wasn't exactly a meeting of minds, but it made him feel less uncomfortable. 'To be drawn in you have to want to investigate further, but what is left to investigate if someone has taken their clothes off and wiggled in front of you for a tenner? With the dancer in Lucknow, you couldn't help thinking, "When you gave me attention, did you mean it more than when you gave the other person attention?" It was silly, but harmless, and fun, whereas there was so much frustrated negative tension in the lapdancing club. If you go to clubs like that, you can only see women sexually. The Kama Sutra isn't perfect by any means - it's the woman who has to bend herself into all sorts of sexual positions while the man just has to twirl his moustache. But there is still a degree of respect, of equality.'

Sanjeev's foray into TV presenting, like his comedy career, wasn't part of a long-term plan. Neither were movies, but now there's a role in the next Merchant Ivory, The Mystic Masseur, based on V.S. Naipaul's novel and about to film in Trinidad, and a three-picture deal with Miramax. 'It's weird, and probably undeserved in my case, but if you just sit there, things do come to you. I guess I know the definition of good fortune.'

webTitle: You can buy posterity, but no one will actually remember you

fields.headline: You can buy posterity, but no one will actually remember you
fields.trailText: How often is public virtue the reflex of private vice? This week, we had two examples of munificence to ponder. The gambling magnate Stuart Wheeler gave the Tories £5million to help them win the next election, and the publisher Paul Hamlyn pledged £17m to redevelop London's South Bank. Wheeler, a betting man, is taking a suicidal risk; Hamlyn, more cannily, has invested in a certainty. In return for his donation, the Royal Festival Hall will be renamed in his honour.
fields.body:
How often is public virtue the reflex of private vice? This week, we had two examples of munificence to ponder. The gambling magnate Stuart Wheeler gave the Tories £5million to help them win the next election, and the publisher Paul Hamlyn pledged £17m to redevelop London's South Bank. Wheeler, a betting man, is taking a suicidal risk; Hamlyn, more cannily, has invested in a certainty. In return for his donation, the Royal Festival Hall will be renamed in his honour.

Corporations long ago co-opted our great arts institutions: at present the RSC is Allied Domecq's pet charity and AT&T (not content with owning the air we breathe and use for communicating with each other) proprietorially flies its flag above the Almeida. More recently, donors have cast off their corporate camouflage.

Philanthropists no longer perform good works dis creetly. Money now is handed over in return for personal publicity. In the British Museum's new Great Court, those whose cheques contained enough zeroes have their names carved into the marble wall above that staircase wrapped around the outside of the old Reading Room - the Sainsburys, the Clores, Vivien Duffield, Joseph Hotung. As far as I know, none of these people has ever written a book; their presence here, though chiselled not scribbled, is as impertinent as graffiti.

John Jerwood's foundation, disposing of the proceeds of dealing in cultured pearls, saved the Royal Court redevelopment scheme with a gift of £3m. In recompense, the foundation insisted on rechristening the building the Jerwood Royal Court. Chris Smith balked at permitting a publicly funded institution to be privatised; as a compromise, Jerwood was restricted to naming the auditoria, so the disputed building is now called the Jerwood Theatres at the Royal Court Theatre. Either way, Jerwood succeeded in bumptiously inserting his name above the title.

The stock-market entrepreneur Alberto Vilar, frittering away his Nasdaq spoils, has turned international opera into a personal fiefdom. The Royal Opera House compliantly named the Floral Hall after him, and the Metropolitan Opera in New York has done the same with its Grand Tier. This season, in the programme for the Met's new Fidelio, Vilar's name was emblazoned in a typeface larger than those of the conductor, director or any of the singers.

To amuse himself during the summer, Vilar has appropriated the Salzburg Festival. I hope they told him, after cashing his cheque, where Salzburg was: at a press conference there a few years ago, I heard him refer to it as the sacred site of 'the greatest arts festival in Germany'. A portrait of Vilar, smirking oleaginously as he sits enthroned in a gilded fauteuil, is inserted into the programme for every Salzburg performance. Because the portrait is an insert, it's easily discarded: by the end of the evening, innumerable images of the Cuban Mr Moneybags are besmirched by horse shit in the city's gutters.

Paul Hamlyn, having given the Labour Party £2m, already possesses a life peerage, but he is apparently in poor health, and must be speculating about the irrelevance of honours which expire when your life does. Paying to have a building renamed after you is like building a monument to yourself, as Ozymandias deludedly did. It is the rich man's way of buying immortality.

Let us by all means take Hamlyn's money, secure in the knowledge that what he thinks he's getting in exchange is not for sale. Next door to the RFH is a concrete acropolis of buildings and auditoria named after men who thought that they would live on in monoliths: the Hayward Gallery, the Purcell Room and the Lyttleton, Olivier and Cottesloe Theatres.

But posterity has already done some shrewd sorting out, selecting two of these names for commemoration and consigning the rest to oblivion. No one attending a concert or a play on the South Bank could tell you anything about Hayward, Lyttleton or Cottesloe, because they were merely bureaucrats - or suits with fat wallets in their breast pockets.

None of us will ever forget who Purcell and Olivier were, because they were great artists - and we don't need buildings to remind us of their existence.

webTitle: The boyz are back in town

fields.headline: The boyz are back in town
fields.standfirst: Teddy Kumakawa's breakaway from the Royal Ballet shook the dance world. But as  Jann Parry  reports, two bright new companies have emerged from the defections
fields.trailText: Teddy Kumakawa's breakaway from the Royal Ballet shook the dance world. But as  Jann Parry  reports, two bright new companies have emerged from the defections
fields.body:
When Tetsuya Kumakawa, 'Japanese wonderboy of the Royal Ballet', jumped ship from the company in October 1998, rumours flew that more defections were likely. 'Will this man break the Royal Ballet?' was the headline on one report. The Royal Opera House seemed to be listing as steeply as the Titanic. Sure enough, five of the ballet's leading men resigned the next month: principal dancers Michael Nunn, William Trevitt and Stuart Cassidy, soloist Gary Avis and first artist Matthew Dibble.

They handed their joint resignation letter to their Big Boss (as Kumakawa calls the RB's artistic director, Sir Anthony Dowell) just before curtain up at Sadler's Wells. The Royal Ballet was still homeless, its immediate future uncertain. There were threats of redundancies, radically reduced performance schedules, even closure, before the Royal Opera House reopened in time for the millennium.

Two of the defectors, Trevitt and Nunn, captured the soap-opera saga on videotape, including the gang of five's wide-eyed tension as they delivered their notice. The video-diary was screened by Channel 4 last year as a fly-on-the-wall series, Ballet Boyz. Now comes the sequel, scheduled for a primetime slot next Sunday. Ballet Boyz II: the Next Step tells how the defectors formed their own company, K Ballet, headed by Teddy Kumakawa. A Japanese television company gambled that he was famous enough back home to guarantee good box-office returns - and so it proved. K Ballet's performances in Japan sell out the moment the box office opens. But the adventure turned sour for some - Nunn and Trevitt, in particular, became disillusioned in the Far East.

At the time the 'boys' left the Royal Ballet, they were besieged by reporters, hot on the scent of yet another anti-Opera House story. The dancers kept their heads down, partly from nerves but also, they reckon, because there was no story. Kumakawa and his backer had made them an offer they had no intention of refusing.

'This was something we wanted to do anyway,' says Nunn. 'We'd been with the Royal Ballet for 12 years and a dancer's career is so short we couldn't wait any longer.' Trevitt agrees: 'If I'd turned down this opportunity, I'd be regretting it still, wondering what might have been.'

They were offered enough money (they won't say how much) to make it worth their while leaving secure jobs and pensions. 'Actually, our jobs weren't at all safe then,' Nunn recalls. 'They never are.'

Kumakawa was back in London when we met a week ago. He had been performing over the New Year as a guest with English National Ballet and rehearsing for K Ballet's next Japanese tour. It is apparently cheaper to bring Japanese dancers, who make up the female corps de ballet, to London than to rehearse in Tokyo. Besides, Kumakawa has kept on his Acton flat and his blue TVR sports car, 'which broke down this morning. English car.' He laughs disarmingly. 'Ask me what motors I have in Japan.'

OK, Teddy, what cars do you have in Japan? 'Two Ferraris and one Mercedes. Mercedes Jeep for picnics; black Ferrari F40 for posing; white 550 Marinello for racing.' I laugh. 'You think I'm making it up, don't you? It's a good story - I should write it.' (Two of the cars put in guest appearances in Ballet Boyz II ). Teddy, now 27, is still impish, sending himself up as well as me, though he has grown up a lot. His nickname comes from Royal Ballet dancers' initial difficulty with his first name, when he joined the company at 16 after two years at the RB School. His surname means Bear River in Japanese, so 'Ted' was inevitable as his English name.

He is a major star in Japan, thanks, he claims, to his exposure on TV, a Nescafé commercial and a film in which he appeared, rather than to ballet. 'Japanese paparazzi are worse than British. They want to know about my private life, so if I go out with a famous actress, they're trying to get me. So I wear a cap to hide myself.' Like Rudolf Nureyev, he has to dance at every performance in order to satisfy his public. 'Yes, I am responsible for K Ballet's success. Otherwise, we'd be on the street. I have to think what the fans want as well as what we want to do. It's hard being in the middle.'

Success has meant that the company has grown to 25 or 30 dancers, depending on the repertoire for each tour. He says his plans focus on his own career as a dancer. 'I'm not trying to develop the company. I've got to enjoy my life, do what I want to do. I've only got another 10 years as a dancer. So I choose what I want to dance; if people like it, then maybe the company gets bigger.' Relaxed, funny and charming, he is modestly dismissive, as though stardom hasn't gone to his head.

But here's the problem for some of the ex-Royal Ballet men who joined him. Instead of K Ballet being 'their' company, it is now Kumakawa's. He no longer needs a cohort of male principals to sustain the repertoire he selects. He invites female guest artists and takes the leading male roles himself in Frederick Ashton's Rhapsody and Symphonic Variations or Roland Petit's Carmen and Bolero . 'It's a challenge for Ted but not for us,' says Nunn, who has now left K Ballet. 'Yes, Symphonic Variations educated Japanese audiences who had never seen it before. But we'd already danced the supporting roles with the Royal Ballet.'

Trevitt is also leaving the company after the upcoming tour. He and Nunn admit that they may have been naive in expecting that they could dance all the works they wanted. 'Every good choreographer is booked up way in advance, so at first we had to rely on things we'd done before,' Trevitt says regretfully. 'But we wouldn't have done anything new at the Royal, so we didn't really lose out artistically.'

They gained so much in experience that they are starting up their own London-based company called George Piper Dances. George is Nunn's middle name, Piper is Trevitt's. They adopted the joint pseudonym years ago when they started taking photographs and making videos. Now in their mid-thirties, they are far less laddish than they appear in Ballet Boyz. They (and their TV producers) thought they needed to appear regular blokes, horsing around in front of the video-camera, rather than as dancers and administrators. They do themselves a disservice in their latest offering, entertaining though it is, by appearing clueless about the rigours of touring in Japan.

'K Ballet was a good progression for us,' says Trevitt. 'We've learnt so much over the last two years that we're as ready as we can be to set up our company.' Nunn chips in: 'We're not trying to recreate K Ballet. We want just eight dancers, plus ourselves, and we're already contacting choreographers.' Their immediate wish-list includes Michael Clark, Russell Maliphant and Paul Lightfoot (whose career has been with Nederlands Dans Theater).

Trevitt and Nunn talk a fabulous company. All they have to do is make it happen. 'We're excited, terrified but confident. That's the way to be,' says Nunn, who has discovered that he enjoys managing and producing. They have enough sponsorship to start raising more money for the launch of George Piper Dances, which they hope will be this autumn.

September-October could be an exceptional harvest period for dance, as new artistic directors take over at the Royal Ballet, ENB and Northern Ballet Theatre; K Ballet is negotiating a London season; Adam Cooper, who joins Kumakawa's Japanese tour, having created a work, Six Faces , for the company, has his own high-profile project for autumn. Add in George Piper Dances and the new millennium is rocking.

They want to know about my private life, so if I go out with a famous actress, they're trying to get me. So I wear a cap to hide myself.' Like Rudolf Nureyev, he has to dance at every performance in order to satisfy his public. 'Yes, I am responsible for K Ballet's success. Otherwise, we'd be on the street. I have to think what the fans want as well as what we want to do. It's hard being in the middle.' Success has meant that the company has grown to 25 or 30 dancers, depending on the repertoire for each tour. He says his plans focus on his own career as a dancer. 'I'm not trying to develop the company. I've got to enjoy my life, do what I want to do. I've only got another 10 years as a dancer. So I choose what I want to dance; if people like it, then maybe the company gets bigger.' Relaxed, funny and charming, he is modestly dismissive, as though stardom hasn't gone to his head. But here's the problem for some of the ex-Royal Ballet men who joined him. Instead of K Ballet being 'their' company, it is now Kumakawa's. He no longer needs a cohort of male principals to sustain the repertoire he selects. He invites female guest artists and takes the leading male roles himself in Frederick Ashton's Rhapsody and Symphonic Variations or Roland Petit's Carmen and Bolero . 'It's a challenge for Ted but not for us,' says Nunn, who has now left K Ballet. 'Yes, Symphonic Variations educated Japanese audiences who had never seen it before. But we'd already danced the supporting roles with the Royal Ballet.' Trevitt is also leaving the company after the upcoming tour. He and Nunn admit that they may have been naive in expecting that they could dance all the works they wanted. 'Every good choreographer is booked up way in advance, so at first we had to rely on things we'd done before,' Trevitt says regretfully. 'But we wouldn't have done anything new at the Royal, so we didn't really lose out artistically.' They gained so much in experience that they are starting up their own London-based company called George Piper Dances. George is Nunn's middle name, Piper is Trevitt's. They adopted the joint pseudonym years ago when they started taking photographs and making videos. Now in their mid-thirties, they are far less laddish than they appear in Ballet Boyz. They (and their TV producers) thought they needed to appear regular blokes, horsing around in front of the video-camera, rather than as dancers and administrators. They do themselves a disservice in their latest offering, entertaining though it is, by appearing clueless about the rigours of touring in Japan. 'K Ballet was a good progression for us,' says Trevitt. 'We've learnt so much over the last two years that we're as ready as we can be to set up our company.' Nunn chips in: 'We're not trying to recreate K Ballet. We want just eight dancers, plus ourselves, and we're already contacting choreographers.' Their immediate wish-list includes Michael Clark, Russell Maliphant and Paul Lightfoot (whose career has been with Nederlands Dans Theater). Trevitt and Nunn talk a fabulous company. All they have to do is make it happen. 'We're excited, terrified but confident. That's the way to be,' says Nunn, who has discovered that he enjoys managing and producing. They have enough sponsorship to start raising more money for the launch of George Piper Dances, which they hope will be this autumn. September-October could be an exceptional harvest period for dance, as new artistic directors take over at the Royal Ballet, ENB and Northern Ballet Theatre; K Ballet is negotiating a London season; Adam Cooper, who joins Kumakawa's Japanese tour, having created a work, Six Faces , for the company, has his own high-profile project for autumn. Add in George Piper Dances and the new millennium is rocking. Ballet Boyz II: the Next Step will be shown next Sunday on Channel 4 at 8pm

webTitle: Fair stood the wind for France

fields.headline: Fair stood the wind for France
fields.standfirst: At 30,  Sam Taylor has swapped the doubtful pleasures of urban England for the good (if scary) life in rural France
fields.trailText: At 30,  Sam Taylor has swapped the doubtful pleasures of urban England for the good (if scary) life in rural France
fields.body:
Why? people asking me incredulously. Why does a 30-year-old pop writer suddenly want to decamp to rural France? That's what they said to start with. When they learnt that I barely speak French, and my wife and I had chosen the area we wanted to live before we'd even been there, they tended to conclude that I must be mad.

Now, having moved here a week ago, I wonder if they were right. I'm in my new office, on the first floor of a large stone house, surrounded by unopened cardboard boxes, staring out of the window. In the garden, there are piles of logs and bare fruit trees; beyond it, fields of maize stumps and grass, hills covered by forest; and looming behind them, white on the horizon, are the Pyrenees. It's 20 minutes' walk to the nearest village (population 364), which has a school but no shop. Our closest neighbours are half a mile away. The only sound is the hum of my computer and, if I open the window, the twittering of birds. It's all beautiful but a little bit scary.

Six months ago, I was in Ibiza watching Kylie Minogue; now I'm living in a place where mobile phones don't work and most radio signals are just a blizzard of interference.

There have been times when I've wondered what on earth drove me to uproot my young family from the comfort and security of our home, job and friends in southern England and bring them to this remote place. My lowest moment so far was three nights ago, when my eldest son woke me up at 4.30am and I couldn't get back to sleep. I lay next to him in bed, in shuttered blackness, worrying about money and woodworm, insulation and isolation, septic tanks and verb-endings.

Another time, frustrated and exhausted by trying to feed the kids, get hold of an electrician and find the box containing our wellies among the 200 others littering the house, I did actually yell: 'Right, that's it! We're putting the house on the market and moving back to England!' But then the idea seemed so absurd that we started laughing.

My great escape began last year with those familiar pangs we all feel when we come back from a holiday - in the mountains or the countryside or by the sea - and get the Tube from Heathrow in the drizzle. The pangs didn't fade as they usually do but intensified with every walk to school in our Hertfordshire village, having to stoop down next to my son's face so I could hear what he was saying above the noise of traffic on the high street. We'd moved there five years earlier from east London, to 'get away from it'. But 'it' had followed us, and was now busy building an apartment block 30 yards from our front door.

Everything happened extremely fast, which helped prevent us losing our nerve and staying put. Last May, my wife and I spent two weeks travelling around Provence and Languedoc, peering hopefully into dozens of estate agents' windows. It was lovely, but almost as expensive as London. Then we read about a region called the Gers, in south-west France, where prices were lower and tourists fewer. We looked at the map and thought: that's where we'll live. After weeks spent sorting through property on the internet, we went over in October and saw five houses that we loved. The last of these was in a region south of the Gers, closer to the Spanish border, where prices were even lower and tourists even fewer. Thirty-six hours after selling our old house, we bought the new one.

If there was a kind of madness in the fervour with which we pursued this dream, there were also lots of sensible reasons for doing it now: my wife is French, my three children are still young enough to learn the language effortlessly, most of my family lives abroad (my parents in southern Spain, my brother and his family in Madrid), and the massive rise in house prices in south-east England over the past few years meant we could sell our Edwardian semi in Hertfordshire for twice what we paid for it and buy somewhere twice as big, set in five acres of land, for half that price. Now we have no mortgage, which is useful as my monthly income is currently less than I used to spend on the mortgage alone.

I had other reasons for escaping - not so easy to explain to financial advisers and social scientists. Turning 30 was part of it; the realisation that I was probably a third of the way through my life; the sense that I was playing things too safe. I had what in many ways was my dream job - writing about music for a national newspaper. Yet somewhere, swirling around my subconscious, was the dim fear of sleepwalking into my forties, numbed by comfort and routine. The times in my life I felt most alive, I realised, were when I was faced with a big new change or challenge - leaving home, falling in love, looking for a job, having children. According to an astrologer friend, this was my Saturn's return - the stars were influencing me to change my way of life. And before you start laughing, I should point out that I have an email from this friend, sent last May, predicting every major event of the last six months with startling accuracy.

Besides, however enjoyable my job, I felt that, to quote Philip Larkin, 'the toad Work' was squatting on too large a portion of my life. Contemporary sociological phenomena with names like 'the play ethic' and 'downshifting' are, essentially, just determined attempts to spend less time immobile under striplights, breathing recycled air, concentrating on something that will cease to be truly important the moment you have finished doing it. How you spend the time you save is up to you, but I realised I wanted to spend it making my kids laugh, chopping wood, writing books, digging up vegetables, skiing, feeding chickens, playing tennis, cooking over an open fire, or, just occasionally, sitting in the sun, drinking wine and gazing at the Pyrenees.

Other parents, not least my own, tend to look at me anxiously when I tell them this, imagining my three boys starving to death for the sake of my stress levels. I certainly have no illusions about poverty - it's a grind and no fun at all. But despite one of my friends predicting merrily that I would end up 'rotting in peasant oblivion', I can't really see us suffering hypothermia or malnutrition. We will have two fireplaces, a vegetable garden, dozens of fruit trees and freshly laid eggs. It will be fine. That's what I told myself, and other people, over and over again as they questioned the wisdom of the move last autumn. It'll be fine, I said breezily, feeling it, meaning it. I was relentlessly optimistic. We'll just have to make a few small sacrifices, I said. I'll give up parties and Sky TV. My wife will wear wellies instead of kitten mules. The kids will miss out on micro-scooters and Versace jeans and their Pokémon collections will be embarrassingly small. I think the scars will heal, somehow.

Then, the day in October that I learnt our house sale had finally gone through, another emotion hit me. I caught sight of my face in a mirror and noticed my expression: I looked frightened. Oh God, I thought, what have I done? The panic attack lasted just one evening. I sat on the rug in front of the fire in our living-room and stared into the flames, imagining a series of worst-case scenarios. What if the villagers hate us? What if we're snowbound and the boiler packs up? It was raining outside and there was no alcohol in the house to dull the fear. My wife watched me curiously. 'It'll be fine,' she said, with just a trace of irony. By the next morning, miraculously, it was.

I must confess that I rather enjoyed the bleak horrors of our last November in England - the floods, the rail delays, the circulating flu viruses. By this point, most people had stopped questioning my sanity and were asking slightly enviously about the place I was going to: a blessed little corner of south-west France made up of gently rolling hills, fields of corn and sunflowers, winding roads empty of cars and pretty little towns and villages, where, like the nostalgic myth of pre-war England, people don't bother locking their doors and always have time to talk to you. It's like an unspoilt Tuscany or Provence, and I'd better shut up now or I'll be responsible for spoiling it.

But nothing is as perfect or as easy as it seems in your dreams. However adaptable kids are, they still scream when you leave them in a school full of people speaking a language they barely understand. However relieved I feel to be free of traffic and train delays, I still have huge lists of 'things to do' pinned to the wall above my desk.

Even down here it still rains. Looking out of my office window, I see the clouds overhead are dark and thick but the ones on the horizon are brighter and more scattered. Amid all the lists on my wall is a printout of the email from my friend, the astrologer. 'By May, the pattern will have changed completely,' it says. 'It'll be like a load lifting off your shoulders, and you'll be smelling the flowers and earth on the winds of spring.'

He doesn't say anything about my book becoming a bestseller, though...

Sam Taylor will be writing occasional bulletins for the Review on his family's new life in France

webTitle: Moral Muse: Gay sex disgusts me. Am I prejudiced?

fields.headline: Gay sex disgusts me. Am I prejudiced?
fields.trailText:
I feel I have offended my gay friend and I want to know if my opinions are prejudice or normal. Despite liking someone regardless of their sexuality, I find the thought of sex between two men quite abhorrent (I am a heterosexual woman). I do not, however, find the idea of two women together abhorrent (although I wouldn't want to do it myself). I tried to explain that I felt it was a preference, not a prejudice, but he disagrees, believing that I think gay men are disgusting.
L.R., London
fields.body:
I feel I have offended my gay friend and I want to know if my opinions are prejudice or normal. Despite liking someone regardless of their sexuality, I find the thought of sex between two men quite abhorrent (I am a heterosexual woman). I do not, however, find the idea of two women together abhorrent (although I wouldn't want to do it myself). I tried to explain that I felt it was a preference, not a prejudice, but he disagrees, believing that I think gay men are disgusting.
L.R., London

If you have expressed your feelings as bluntly to him as you have here, I'm not surprised he has taken offence. If any friend of mine told me he thought my personal life was disgusting and abhorrent, I too would review the friendship. Everybody likes to think of him/herself as eternally lovable and admirable, and it's amazing how people can do so in the face of all the contrary evidence. If we saw ourselves as others see us, most of us would be permanently, terminally depressed.

For a person's self-esteem to be confident and sturdy, there needs to be a lengthy process of laborious construction, with reinforcements of approval received at regular intervals from one's friends. This is why, at vulnerable periods of one's life, like adolescence, it is so important to conform to the peer-group image. Stand out from the crowd and you'll risk rejection, with a demolition job on your carefully built edifice.

Many gay people go through life in such a state of insecurity, dependent on friends of all types to prop up their shaky self-belief. This is not an area where issues can be discussed with cold logic. The joy or misery of the moment is instantly affected by approval on the one hand or derogatory comments on the other.

Human sexual activity is peculiarly secretive and, as a result, we have many mixed emotions about others' sex lives, ranging from prurient curiosity to prudish revulsion. We'd rather not think about our parents making love, and young people think sex between old people is disgusting. If we were sexually liberated, like some chimpanzees, we wouldn't have all these problems.

As it is, humans have developed elaborate rituals of courtesy and correctness that serve to protect our more sensitive feelings. You may not be prejudiced towards homosexuals, but your frankness was indelicate and impolite. You should extend your tolerance and fine-tune your sensitivity. It's very likely your gay friend would find the thought of you engaged in heterosexual intercourse distasteful, but he's far too courteous to say so.

Readers; replies

It's not your fault if your friend can't distinguish between physical and moral distaste. As a gay man, I shudder at the thought of sex with a woman and am equally repelled by the idea of eating tripe or performing brain surgery. Yet I have nothing against people who do these things. If your friend prefers politically correct lip-service to sincerity you should consider how well you are matched as friends.
R.C., Perth

No, it is not homophobic per se to find unappealing the thought of gay male sex. But consenting heterosexual sex is generally above judgment, hence a gay person will rarely take kindly to a straight person commenting on his/her lovemaking. I suggest you say sorry and then let it drop. He'll get over it, we all do.
G.S., London

Next Week's Dilemma

Ten years ago, I finished a long-term relationship with a man who meant an awful lot to me. I am now happily married with two children.

However, for some nostalgic reason, I recently instigated an email correspondence with my old lover and we have begun to write regularly. He is also married and lives a long way away so it is unlikely we will ever meet.

The correspondence is nothing more than friendly but I feel as though I am betraying my husband. I enjoy reliving old memories with my ex-lover, but should I stop writing?
A.V., Portsmouth

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Acid comments from the top drawers

fields.headline: Acid comments from the top drawers
fields.standfirst: They come in all shapes and sizes - and the best are gold dust.  Peter Preston  assesses the art of the newspaper cartoon to mark the arrival of Dave Coverly, The Observer's newest recruit
fields.trailText: They come in all shapes and sizes - and the best are gold dust.  Peter Preston  assesses the art of the newspaper cartoon to mark the arrival of Dave Coverly, The Observer's newest recruit
fields.body:
There is the cream in the coffee, the salt in the stew - and the cartoon in your newspaper. Any editor who's done a little research knows that.

Cartoonists aren't optional extras - they are a vital part of the mix. See how you, the reader, have stopped over this page. It has a design grammar to it. The headline sizes and story placements tell you what to read in what order. Yet you do not, most of the time, obey such orders. Something, as the pages flip, catches your eye. It may be a tiny scrap of news or an arresting picture but, as often as not, it's a cartoon: an acid comment, a joke, a jab in the ribs.

Linger over that and the odds are that you'll backtrack and start to read the words which surround it. Cartoons are more than mere decoration. They are vital hooks of interest. Enter Dave Coverly, The Observer 's newest signing and a young global star of this difficult, immensely valuable art. He serves 200 newspapers around the world already and they know his worth. What he calls his 'speed bumps' slow you down.

Not all cartoonists plough exactly the same furrow. Some, like The Observer 's Chris Riddell, the Telegraph 's Nicholas Garland and the Guardian 's Steve Bell, carry a weight of history; they are the heirs of Hogarth and Gilray, full-dress commentators on the political times. Gerald Scarfe and Ralph Steadman didn't just happen. In their style, and sometimes their grotesque savagery, they sprang from a tradition. They have the power to move, shock and, sometimes, to destroy. When Bell drew John Major in Y-fronts, the image stuck.

The big, six-column boys depend directly on the news, as, do the pocket magicians like Matt in the Telegraph, Austin in the Guardian and Pugh in the Times. Six columns give you the space for frontal assault, for a kick on the knee; one column is an aside, a topical gag, a giggle among the gloom. (Take Matt last week, on the morning after the hunting vote: three mafiosi hounds in masks sitting round a table, and one of them says: 'OK fellas, we gotta take out a fox - but it has to look like an accident'.) Go to work on the leaders with a smile (and hope it lasts).

The humour, flowing inexhaustibly from his studio home in Michigan, is Friends and Frasier, a crisp, curt riff on the imbecile way we live. 'If you'd like to press one, press one... if you'd like to press two, press two.. if you'd like to press three, press three...' says the infernal telephone operator on 'The Instant Gratification Hotline'. Coverly belongs to a time but not to a defined place. (Two decades ago, interestingly, he'd probably have been too American for a British paper; now he's seamless).

He makes it look easy, the inspiration of a few seconds, but it never is. Cartoonists are some of the loneliest, most introverted people. They have to find a spark of creation every time they put pen to paper. And they all work differently. Steve Bell is one kind of wonder: the ideas, the words and the scabrous images are his alone in an amazing fusion. Austin does nine pocket drafts a day for you to choose from.

I once wrote a cartoon strip with the late, great Mark Boxer and his genius was in the curl of a lip and the tweak of a line. Anyone can turn a witty caption. It's what goes on top that matters. Dave Coverly, too, has that knack with a blend. A master of funny fusion.

Perhaps these are not the greatest days for cartoonists. The coming of newspaper colour has somehow driven them from the top of front pages. The march of new media has, in some ways, left them behind. But, when a paper sings with creativity, they are still the state of the art. What would one of the characters from Coverly country say as, moaning about her fallen arches, she plonked your eggs and hash browns on the diner table? Ah yes. Enjoy.

Dave Coverly's Speed Bumps begin next week in Comment

webTitle: L&G umbrella opens up Barclays' investment push

fields.headline: L&G umbrella opens up Barclays' investment push
fields.trailText: Why do so few of us buy investment products from our banks? Virtually all of us have a relationship of some kind with at least one of the high street banks yet, despite years of effort, the banks manage to sell less than one investment product in every seven we buy.
fields.body:
Why do so few of us buy investment products from our banks? Virtually all of us have a relationship of some kind with at least one of the high street banks yet, despite years of effort, the banks manage to sell less than one investment product in every seven we buy.

Barclays thinks the answer may be that banks come somewhere below estate agents in the list of those we would trust to give us a good deal, so it has decided to turn the business over to someone we appear to have a bit more respect for.

Out will go Barclays Life, Barclays Funds and even b2, rather expensively created just three years ago. In will come that rather reassuring multi-coloured umbrella from Legal & General. By the end of the year, any savings product a Barclays customer buys from their bank will carry the insurer's logo.

Indeed, so confident is it that its customers will prefer the L&G brand that it is forecasting a doubling of its investment business within four years.

Barclays will save £70 million a year by the end of 2002, albeit at a cost of £40m in redundancy and other closure costs. Neither L&G nor Barclays will disclose the commission to be paid on each product, but it is a fair bet that the bank expects that, plus the cost savings, to exceed the rather meagre profit it was making on its investment businesses.

For L&G, the benefits come from increased volumes - even without the growth Barclays is predicting, business from the bank will increase its annual premium income by a quarter. The more business it can put through, the lower the costs per unit will be.

It already reckons that it will be one of the few companies able to offer stakeholder pensions while still making a turn for itself. Deals like this will do that no harm - and should help it cope with government pressure to cut costs on other products too.

Of course, a marketing deal with Barclays pales by comparison with L&G chief executive David Prosser's vision of bancassurance, promoted with gusto just 18 months ago when he was eager to get into bed with NatWest. The world, he says, has changed - and not just because NatWest paid for its generosity by being swallowed by Royal Bank of Scotland.

The regulators are moving away from polarisation, - which forced companies to offer either one product only, or the whole market - to allowing a series of different ties. If that happens, L&G could strike Barclays-type deals with other banks or building societies.

The market's initial reaction was that Barclays had more to gain from the deal than L&G had, marking the bank's shares up while the insurer's fell slightly.

That is misguided. L&G is already one of the financial services businesses best-placed to survive in a cutthroat future. The deal with Barclays makes it more likely that it can prosper too.

One cheer

Let's have one cheer for John von Spreckelsen, executive chairman of Somerfield. 'This is the third turnaround of a food retailer I have been involved in,' he pointed out. 'They have never been achieved by cutting costs.'

That is a refreshing statement in a world where new bosses traditionally wield the axe before they even start to think about expanding the business. But we will reserve the other two cheers until he proves he can get sales in Somerfield and its Kwik Save discount chain solidly back on the growth track.

Last week's interim results show encouraging progress. Sales at both Somerfield and Kwik Save have been improving steadily for the past two quarters and, in the eight weeks to 6 January, Somerfield actually managed an increase, albeit only by 0.3 per cent.

But these were soft comparisons - this time last year, the business was ditching its boss and its strategy - so anything other than an improvement would have been disastrous.

Von Spreckelsen says he will never get them moving if he cuts back on stock for the shelves, store staff to serve the customer and head office managers dedicated to turning the business around. The trouble is, keeping the same costs on a low sales base meant it actually made an operating loss in the first half.

His strategy certainly sounds more sensible than that of his predecessor, David Simons, who bought Kwik Save and promptly ditched its name and discount formula.

Von Spreckelsen is revers ing that, giving stores a facelift and making some sensible changes to operations.

In Somerfield, he is pursuing the same strategy as he did, with success, at Budgens: making it a well-run, good-value high street store. That includes brightening the store, improving service and adding more convenience and fresh foods.

The trouble is, it has too many superstores - which it could not sell - to be purely high street, but not enough big stores to be truly competitive on price with its larger rivals. The risk is that it remains a chain with no niche in the market.

The task of finding a niche is getting harder all the time. Christmas trading statements from Tesco and Safeway - and Wm Morrison earlier in the month - showed that both are aggressively building market share. Some of that will be coming from Sainsbury's - which says it is not yet ready to go for sales growth - but much of it will be coming from the high street stores, which von Spreckelsen is trying to nurse back to life. If Sainsbury's does actually start going for growth again, life will get tougher still.

Peter Davis at Sainsbury's has warned that turning it round will take five years. Von Spreckelsen wants even longer - he thinks it could take five years to get Somerfield back into a decent condition. His patience certainly paid off at Budgens, which was all but written off when he took over.

Somerfield's shares have doubled recently, suggesting that investors are at least willing to take a bet on von Spreckelsen succeeding. But until he delivers a bit more sales growth, that is high enough.

webTitle: Putting the Spurs to a wayward beast

fields.headline: Putting the Spurs to a wayward beast
fields.standfirst: Buying Alan Sugar's stake in Tottenham could give Enic much-needed focus, says  Jamie Doward.  But will the City be as keen?
fields.trailText: Buying Alan Sugar's stake in Tottenham could give Enic much-needed focus, says Jamie Doward. But will the City be as keen?
fields.body:
When he picked up the phone on a Saturday afternoon in the middle of December last year, Daniel Levy's Christmas came early.

Levy's solicitors, SJ Berwin, were on the line with the news the lifelong Spurs fan had waited two years to hear. Alan Sugar, the beleaguered Tottenham Hotspur chairman, was throwing in the towel. Sugar wanted to know whether Levy's company, Enic, which owns stakes in five European clubs, was interested in buying him out.

The Amstrad founder had offered his stake to Levy twice before, as far back as 1998, but the chief executive of the English National Investment Company had balked at the price. However, this time Sugar was desperate to get out. He was jetting off on holiday and wanted an agreement before he hit the beach. Levy rushed out of his Chigwell mansion, summoned his advisers and decamped to Enic's HQ, just off London's Regent Street, where they hastily put together an offer.

Four days later, on 20 December, Spurs announced that Enic was to buy a 27 per cent stake in the football club for £22 million and that Levy would have a place on the board. Drawing on the clichés beloved by all millionaires when grabbing the keys to the stadium, Levy, a Cambridge economics graduate, talked about making Spurs great again. 'We believe that it can regain its position as a significant contender in both domestic and European competitions,' the 39-year-old said portentously.

Enic's shareholders, however, can be forgiven for wondering what's in it for them. Football clubs are notoriously flaky investments, and for Sugar to sell out at a huge discount to his original asking price (at one stage he wanted almost double what Enic was offering) suggests that even one of the UK's toughest businessmen isn't optimistic about the future of the beautiful game.

Enic's share price certainly hasn't shown much enthusiasm for the Spurs deal. No one has been quite sure in what direction the company is going. Observers who've tried to glean a better understanding have often come away confused. 'It's been like pulling teeth,' one said.

Formed five years ago, Enic, the brainchild of legendary Bahamas-based billionaire Joe Lewis, is a very strange corporate beast. Although Lewis is no longer involved in Enic, his son Charles, who cut his teeth opening franchises of the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain in South America, is an Enic director. In addition, the Lewis family retains a 21 per cent stake in the firm.

Enic has fingers in many pies. In addition to its football operations, Enic has an 80 per cent holding in the company that owns the 15-strong chain of Warner Brothers merchandising stores in the UK. It also has the rights to develop a worldwide restaurant franchise themed around cartoon characters such as Bugs Bunny and Tom and Jerry. The first restaurant is slap bang in the middle of the Las Vegas gambling strip.

Enic is also a fan of new media companies. It retains a 3 per cent stake in Autonomy, the internet software company currently worth more than £2.5bn. At one stage Enic owned more than 20 per cent of the Cambridge-based firm, which was once worth more than £5bn.

Then there is a 24 per cent stake in technology investment vehicle Paradigm Media Investments. Enic also owns 25 per cent of the internet gambling operations of Victor Chandler International and is in negotiations to buy the company outright.

It is also in talks to buy spread-betting firm Sporting Index to sit alongside UK Betting.com, the online bookmaker it bought for £500,000 a couple of years ago.

Last year Enic audaciously tried to buy Wembley stadium. It was also keen on owning a chunk of Manchester United when its former chairman, Martin Edwards, looked to sell.

Given its diverse portfolio of interests and the apparent confusion over its direction in this, the era of corporate focus, it is hardly surprising that the City has taken a dim view of Enic. True, it may have seen its value soar to more than £300m last year, but this was because its stake in Autonomy helped it ride the dotcom boom.

And, worryingly for Levy, his company is now trading at a significant discount to its net assets, which suggests concern about the management's strategy. Adding up all the various interests the company holds, in addition to cash reserves of around £25m, should give Enic a book value of £220m-£300m, a long way north of its current £110m market capitalisation.

But, with the exception of the Autonomy investment, too many of Enic's deals have failed to come off. Paradigm, for example, has yet to make an investment. Launched amid great hype on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) in March last year - just before the internet bubble burst, Paradigm's shares are today trading at 9p - where once they changed hands at 38p.

The performance of the Warner Brothers stores, even in the company's view, has been 'disappointing'. In a bid to retrench, Enic has switched out of running big stores into smaller ones. Soon its flagship store on Regent Street, over which Enic has its HQ, will go, to be replaced by a giant Esprit outlet.

Admittedly, the US restaurant in Vegas makes money, but it sucked in £11m of Enic cash to get going: the company is understandably reluctant to shell out more. And, despite the hype surrounding media sports rights and pay-per-view TV, most analysts would agree that football clubs have so far failed to become the cash cows many were predicting a couple of years ago.

In a bid to gain credibility with the City, Levy will now almost certainly look to restructure the company. The current deal to buy Victor Chandler outright looks dead in the water - Enic is now refusing to pay the £70m million asking price. The Sporting Index deal will go the same way unless a new price can be agreed.

Paradigm, meanwhile, is to focus on one major acquisition rather than the original plan to make several minority investments. Plans are being drawn up to hive off the Warner Brothers stores as a separate concern. The remaining Autonomy stake will go sometime, too.

Which pretty much just leaves the football interests. 'Now they've achieved a certain size, thanks to the Spurs deal, they can focus on their core expertise: developing brands in sport and the media,' one source close to the company said.

But even mighty Manchester United is cutting back on its licensing ventures.

At least Enic now seems to have found a focus. But, as one observer put it: 'If it didn't exist, you wouldn't invent it.'

webTitle: As California blacks out, will we see the light?

fields.headline: As California blacks out, will we see the light?
fields.trailText: We laughed, of course. All those Californians stumbling in the dark, wondering why the sun had left the Sunshine State, made for great schadenfreude. Silicon Valley, for so long held up as the powerhouse that powered all powerhouses, ran out of power. As California's governor declared a state of emergency, restaurateurs started a nice line in candlelit suppers.
fields.body:
We laughed, of course. All those Californians stumbling in the dark, wondering why the sun had left the Sunshine State, made for great schadenfreude. Silicon Valley, for so long held up as the powerhouse that powered all powerhouses, ran out of power. As California's governor declared a state of emergency, restaurateurs started a nice line in candlelit suppers.

But it's not really funny. Not when schools and businesses face blackouts. And it's especially unfunny given that such a crisis in the world's most developed country should never have happened.

We in the UK shake our heads in bewilderment. But we shouldn't feel too comfortable. US-style electricity deregulation may be over-priced and over-complicated but it is also coming over here. The fiasco in the US becomes more than a sideshow.

The Great Silicon Valley Switch-Off is testament to what happens when those in power meddle in the affairs of those with power. Deregulation of electricity might have looked good in theory - Uncle Sam loves free markets, after all. In practice it has proved nothing short of a disaster.

Despite the Valley's thirst for ever more megawatts to fuel all those server farms that underpin the internet, no new power plant has been built in California for 10 years - because the electricity companies have been scared. Put simply, they don't trust the federal and state governments, which have been ambiguous and ambivalent on how the electricity industry should be opened up.

The deregulation of the Californian electricity market three years ago split generation and distribution. But while the utility companies had the price they could charge to consumers capped, the wholesale electricity system that sold to the utilities faced no such restriction. When wholesale prices rocketed, the utility companies took a massive hit and had to supply power at huge losses. The result: two utilities face bankruptcy.

The US is not alone. Australian regulators have also capped prices with similar, if less disastrous, results.

Ofgem, the UK electricity regulator, will want to learn the lessons. In March, after two postponements, it will introduce the catchily titled New Energy Trading Arrangement.

Neta has been designed to make the electricity market more competitive and transparent. No longer will the price of electricity in the pool be held in a collar. Instead, prices will be chiefly determined by the conventional laws of supply and demand. This, it is forecast, will reduce consumers' bills up to 10 per cent.

But the problem with electricity is that you can't store it. In a free market its price will change dramatically, by the hour. As David Warwick of KWI, the trading and risk management company that advises energy firms, points out: 'Expect to see very high prices over certain periods. You could see some violent price swings.'

fields.bodyText: We laughed, of course. All those Californians stumbling in the dark, wondering why the sun had left the Sunshine State, made for great schadenfreude. Silicon Valley, for so long held up as the powerhouse that powered all powerhouses, ran out of power. As California's governor declared a state of emergency, restaurateurs started a nice line in candlelit suppers. But it's not really funny. Not when schools and businesses face blackouts. And it's especially unfunny given that such a crisis in the world's most developed country should never have happened. We in the UK shake our heads in bewilderment. But we shouldn't feel too comfortable. US-style electricity deregulation may be over-priced and over-complicated but it is also coming over here. The fiasco in the US becomes more than a sideshow. The Great Silicon Valley Switch-Off is testament to what happens when those in power meddle in the affairs of those with power. Deregulation of electricity might have looked good in theory - Uncle Sam loves free markets, after all. In practice it has proved nothing short of a disaster. Despite the Valley's thirst for ever more megawatts to fuel all those server farms that underpin the internet, no new power plant has been built in California for 10 years - because the electricity companies have been scared. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rolls faces strike
fields.body:
Rolls faces strike

Rolls-Royce workers are expected to back strike action when ballot results are revealed on Friday.

The workers, at Rolls' aero-engine research and development centre in Ansty near Coventry, are angry at plans which would see its workforce fall from 900 to 300, with some employees relocated to Bristol and Montreal, Canada.

The MSF professional union says the plans would involve compulsory redundancies, which it says are unacceptable. It has proposed an alternative which would see Ansty's workforce remain at around 550, without compulsory redundancies or relocation. MSF has balloted 800 members at the Ansty site, and expects a majority in favour of a strike. An unofficial ballot before Christmas indicated 86 per cent would vote to strike. MSF's Vince Butler said: 'Our expectation is that we will have a massive decision for strike action.'

Retail spending to fall

Consumer spending is set to take a serious knock this year, says the Ernst & Young Item Club quarterly report. It predicts interest rates will have to come down a percentage point by the first quarter of next year.

The forecast, based on the Treasury's economic model, shows personal spending growth slowing by a half over the next two years. Retailers' steady though not buoyant Christmas trading figures were fuelled by mounting debt and dwindling savings, according to the report.

'Last year's spenders will be in for a nasty shock when they assess their financial position over the coming weeks,' says Professor Peter Spencer, economic adviser to the Item Club. The report says the economy is already weak, growing only 0.5 per cent in the final quarter last year, because of lower capital gains from shares and unit trusts, a drying up of proceeds from demutualisation, a levelling off of house price increases, lower bonuses, and rising unemployment.

PowerGen targeted

Scottish and Southern Energy, the Perth-based utility, is sizing up PowerGen for a possible merger if the energy generator and supplier's talks with German utility E.ON founder.

A source close to SSE said: 'PowerGen is one of the companies SSE keeps its eye on. It would want a nil premium merger of equals, and if a deal with E.ON does not materialise it is likely to make an approach.'

Analysts say a deal would make a good strategic fit - with potential cost savings, a customer base of nearly 7 million, and a foothold in America through Kentucky-based LG&E, which Powergen bought last year for $5.4 billion.
