webTitle: Nestlé outsmarties rivals

fields.headline: Nestlé outsmarties rivals
fields.standfirst: World's biggest food producer swallows petfood and smells victory in perfume war.  Paul Farrelly  reports
fields.trailText: World's biggest food producer swallows petfood and smells victory in perfume war. Paul Farrelly reports
fields.body:
Last Tuesday, from its headquarters at Vevey on the picturesque shores of Lac Leman, Switzerland's sleeping giant finally stirred.

During 2000, Nestlé, the world's biggest food producer, had stood aloof as the industry carved itself up in a $50 billion frenzy of US takeovers not seen since the Gordon Gekko days of the lunatic late 1980s.

In the space of just 12 months some of the world's best-known grocery brands - such as Nabisco, Pillsbury, Quaker Oats, Knorr and Ben & Jerry's - fell to the likes of Philip Morris, Pepsico and Unilever, Nestlé's keenest rivals for supermarket space around the world. Yet from Nestlé barely a murmur was heard.

Under its fearsome former chief, Helmut Maucher, the Swiss giant was hardly a shrinking violet when it came to shoring up its vital interests in the 1980s and 1990s. It decisively saw off Germany's Jacobs Suchard in 1988 in the £2.8bn takeover battle for the UK's Rowntree Mackintosh. It also routed the super-rich Agnellis, owners of Fiat, and the French establishment in the £1.6bn tussle for Perrier four years later.

It was Maucher, too, who drove the maker of Nescafé, Milky Bar, Buitoni pasta and Branston Pickle aggressively into new growth markets like mineral waters, ice cream and petfood. And Nestlé's cereals venture with General Mills of the US, producing Shredded Wheat, Cheerios and Golden Grahams, has also now knocked the mighty Kelloggs off its pole position in the US.

But in the new millennium, it was as if his successor, new chief executive Peter Brabeck, was content to watch the steamers paddle lazily by in Nestlé's picture-postcard lakeside setting.

Then, on Tuesday, the apparent somnolence was over. Nestlé's $10.3bn bid for St Louis-based Ralston Purina - maker of Dog Chow, Meouw Mix and Tender Vittles, no less - means Nestlé takes the number one slot with Mars' Pedigree Petfoods in the business of feeding little furry friends the world over. Canned and dry cat and dogfood may not be glamorous. But it is a $25bn a year global market, growing twice as fast as food for mere humans.

You may not realise it, but the world's biggest purveyor of chocolate and instant coffee already owns Felix, Friskies and Winalot (with neat symmetry, Mars sells Whiskas and Chum). And last week's move in particular freezes out Procter & Gamble, the ultra-secretive US Fairy Liquid giant, which has cast avaricious eyes over this lucrative grocery trade.

It shows, too, that Nestlé has not lost the 135-year knack of looking ahead that allowed a tiny Swiss company to conquer the world in the first place. Let the also-rans scrap for the canned sweetcorn, powdered soups and packet cereals falling from the food consolidation table (from all of which Nestlé has done very nicely in the past, thank you). Under Brabeck - who took charge three years ago - the Swiss are now checking out higher margin, fast-growth areas like healthy nutrition, supplements and lifestyle food and drinks. And, as with Nescafé, baby formula and condensed milk in the past, so, the thinking goes, with Nespresso, internet cafes and Felix Gourmet catfoods in the future. In other words, where the developed world leads, fast-growing, emerging markets follow.

'Nestlé has always been remarkably long-term. One of the great advantages they have had is visionaries at the top able to shoulder a global empire,' says Kieron Mahon, European foods analyst at broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. 'While Peter Brabeck has yet to prove himself, there is little doubt he is a force to be reckoned with.'

Founded in 1866 by Henri Nestlé, a pharmacist-turned-entrepreneur, the firm looked beyond Swiss borders from day one. Its first overseas sales office was set up in London in 1867 and Nestlé now has 27 factories and distribution centres in the UK, which employ over 13,000 of its total of 230,000 staff.

In all, Nestlé now runs more than 500 food manufacturing plants in 77 countries worldwide.

In the beginning, Henri had a product everyone - from the Victorians to Tsarist Russians and colonial Australians - wanted: the world's first formula baby milk, made from dried milk and sugar and sold without frills as Farine Lactée Henri Nestlé.

In 1874, Henri sold out, meaning Nestlé has never had successive generations of squabbling, less-talented family members holding the firm back. And in 1905 came the first merger, with the Anglo Swiss Condensed Milk Company, which put a halt to vicious European competition in processed milk products.

Eighty years later, with the takeover of Carnation in the US, Nestlé returned to its roots (and accidentally got into petfood: Carnation had a thriving sideline in Friskies).

In 1929, chocolate joined the pot, with the takeover of fellow Vevey-based firm Peter-Cailler-Kohler, founded by a friend of Henri's who invented the process of combining milk with cocoa powder to make milk chocolate.

And in 1938, Nestlé's best-known product of all was launched. After eight years of research aimed at cutting Brazil's huge coffee surplus, the firm's chemists finally produced a soluble powder that revolutionised coffee-drinking habits worldwide. In short, Nescafe was born, and in the Second World War it quickly became the staple drink of American soldiers serving in Europe and Asia.

Since then, Nestlé - bankrolled by the cash cow of instant coffee - has never looked back. Worldwide, it now makes thousands of products with sales of £30bn a year. Of those, £2.3bn are in the UK, Nestlé's fourth largest market, with brands that also include Nesquik, Sarsons Vinegar and Sun Pat peanut butter.

'The main secret of Nestlé's success is that it has always been a company which looked at social need, used scientific research to develop products and used brands to make it happen,' says Nestlé's communications director Francois Perraud. 'It was helpful, too, to come from a small country so we had to drive sales internationally.'

Today, with nearly a fifth of the global market, Nestlé is still by far the biggest supplier of baby milk and infant foods, dwarfing the likes of Heinz and the Netherlands' Numico (owner of Milupa and Cow & Gate).

Not that young British mothers would readily link the Swiss with baby milk. Save for the quiet introduction of its Nestlé Junior toddler foods a year ago, Nestlé has steered clear of the UK since a global boycott was organised by London protesters in the 1970s.

The group, Baby Milk Action, still harries Nestlé over controversial Third World marketing practices, which have allegedly led to thousands of baby deaths after mothers mixed unsterilised water with powdered infant formula instead of breastfeeding.

Ever agile at marketing, however, Nestlé is now using its number one position in mineral waters - with Perrier, Vittel and San Pellegrino - to launch a new purified water, Nestlé Pure Life, for mass markets in China, Pakistan and Mexico.

After Nestlé's far-sighted expansion under Maucher, the new chief had until last week vowed to pursue organic growth, rationalising the far-flung empire to cut costs and boost returns. For Nestlé, Ralston Purina was just a bite-sized in-fill deal, but there are other itches that the ambitious Brabeck would certainly love to scratch.

He could do, for example, with a decent yoghurt - with all the healthy living connotations - to take on France's Danone. Nestlé bought Chambourcy in the 1970s, but this is now a 'double or quits market', analysts say. So watch out Germany's Müller.

Ice cream also needs sorting out. Nestlé jettisoned the Lyons Maid label in 1998, has tied up with Haagen Dazs and spent a small fortune on making its ice cream operations the world number two, but the division is barely profitable and still a long way behind Unilever's Walls.

For the health-driven future, GlaxoSmithKline's consumer health products, like Horlicks. Lucozade and Ribena, would figure on Nestlé's shopping list. Higher priority, however, are the Mead Johnson operations of US drugs giant Bristol Myers Squibb, which make nutritional food and drinks for infants, adults, hospitals and other health professionals. BMS, analysts say, may be a willing seller, but it first needs to find an acceptable pharmaceuticals merger.

BMS's Clairol hair care operation would also fit well with L'Oréal, Nestlé's ultimate prize. In 1974, the Swiss giant made its shrewdest ever investment, taking a 49 per cent stake in Gesparal, the family holding company that owns a controlling 54 per cent stake in L'Oreal. The French firm has since become the world leader in personal care. Nestlé has waited patiently for L'Oreal's ageing owner, Lillian Bettancourt, to give it the chance to buy the lot.

That deal would take Nestlé head to head with Unilever, with the added spice of knocking its European rival off its perch as the world's number one in consumer goods.

'Nestlé has no interest in canned beans, but it has an abiding interest in L'Oréal,' said Schroders' Mahon. 'Personally, I think Brabeck will be disappointed if he doesn't capture L'Oréal by the time he retires. Maucher built the world's number one food and beverage company; Brabeck dreams of the world's number one consumer company.'

Land where the gnomes are giants

For a small, land-locked country with just 7 million inhabitants, Switzerland has a surprisingly strong industrial and financial base. Several Swiss corporations apart from Nestlé are a force to be reckoned with - in drugs and banking, in particular.

Roche

Founded in 1896, Roche is the country's other sleeping giant. Once the world's biggest drugs company, Basle-based Roche has missed out in the merger wave that recently swept through the global pharmaceuticals industry.

With sales of £12 billion, Roche is now the world's ninth-biggest drugs company, with a thriving vitamins business including the Sanatogen brand. Still family-controlled, it is immune from takeover.

Novartis

Created in 1996 by the merger of Roche's Basle-based rivals, Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy, Novartis ranks among the world's top three drugs companies, with sales of £14bn a year. The group also owns consumer brands including Ovaltine and Isostar (sports drinks), plus Gerber, the number one baby food company in the US. The consumer brands are likely to be sold in the future if, as expected, Novartis merges with another rival to take on the might of Britain's GlaxoSmithKline and US drugs giant Merck.

Roche, of course, is one candidate for an all-Swiss solution. Nestlé, however, is likely to face competition problems in buying much of the consumer arm.

UBS

Formed in 1998 from the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corporation, UBS is the country's heavyweight in the world banking league.

Swiss neutrality throughout two world wars insulated the country from running up massive debts and provided a sound footing for Zurich's infamous gnomes to rival the Americans and the Germans in world banking.

In 1996, UBS snapped up Warburg, one of the grandest names in the City of London, to make a success of investment banking where British rivals have failed.

Last year, too, the bank bought Wall Street's Paine Webber for $12bn to cement its global position.

Credit Suisse

Frozen out by the UBS deal, Credit Suisse is to Swiss banking what Roche is to drugs: a strong number two with a huge international presence.

Its investment banking arm, Credit Suisse First Boston has long been a top-rank player on Wall Street. In 1997, CSFB also bought BZW, Barclays' investment banking arm, to underline Swiss, German and US dominance in the City.

webTitle: A little help from the Bank

fields.headline: A little help from the Bank
fields.trailText: When my good friend, Gordon Brown, first handed monetary policy over to the Bank of England, it was something of a surprise. His purpose was not entirely clear, especially since the Labour Party had bad folk memories of what an independent Bank got up to during the inter-war years.
fields.body:
When my good friend, Gordon Brown, first handed monetary policy over to the Bank of England, it was something of a surprise. His purpose was not entirely clear, especially since the Labour Party had bad folk memories of what an independent Bank got up to during the inter-war years.

Experience has clarified the position. The Chancellor handed economic policy to the Bank so that he could concentrate on running the country. And his interview with the Financial Times last week indicated that he had ambitions to extend his empire to continental Europe. True, as the FT pointed out, our non-membership of the single currency area would mean 'leading from the side'. But his ambitions are plain.

Given the rapid deterioration in economic confidence and industrial output in the US, where the Greenspan miracle appears to have had its day, Brown is right to argue that 'Europe has a new responsibility ... Europe must share the burden of generating both stability and growth'. (He was talking in a global context).

It is to be hoped, however, that in urging the EU to do 'as much as possible' to liberalise (ie deregulate) the European energy market he does not have the Californian precedent in mind. The electricity blackouts in that great state are the product of botched deregulation, and even Greenspan can do nothing about a situation where no new power station has been built in 10 years, while the Californian economy has reportedly grown by nearly 50 per cent.

Leading Europe 'from the side' is an interesting concept, which will test even the Chancellor's powers and ingenuity to the limit. The concept is a contradiction in terms, and may require the Chancellor to clarify his position. But that can wait for another week.

For the moment the interesting question is how the Chancellor and the Bank are going to handle matters before the election, given that they are widely credited with having done a good job, and, barring accidents, Labour is likely to win easily.

Accidents can happen. It was unfortunately bad trade figures that revived Labour's reputation for economic incompetence in spring 1970, when Sir Edward Heath scored a brilliant surprise victory for the Conservatives. Roy Jenkins had done a good job as Chancellor in trying to build Labour's reputation in such matters and, contrary to received wisdom, Labour's poll ratings improved after the spring 1970 Budget.

But not for long. As my colleague David McKie reminded us last week, following the November 1967 devaluation, the Conservatives had a huge lead over Labour throughout 1968 and 1969. The surprise was that Labour edged ahead at all in 1970, prompting Harold Wilson to go for a snap election, which, to his amazement, he lost.

The experience of the Conservatives under William Hague since 1997 has been very different from that under Heath in 1967-70. Any 'accident' that might erode Labour's huge lead in the polls would have to be very big indeed. Nevertheless, Gordon Brown is not a man to tempt providence, and promises a cautious Budget.

Which brings us back to the Bank of England and its Monetary Policy Committee. One of the points Treasury officials - not just Labour appointees - are fond of making is that there was a regular pattern in the Eighties and Nineties of Conservative Chancellors cutting interest rates, either on Budget day or a day or so after.

One of the good things about the new arrangement, they say, is that this kind of blatantly political manipulation of monetary policy no longer occurs.

Now, there is a growing clamour for interest rate cuts in the UK, and, by some amazing coincidence, the MPC will be meeting on 7 and 8 March, just after the Tuesday 6 March date currently pencilled in for the Budget. What a turn-up for the books it would be if we were back to the old days, and the MPC lowered rates that week! However justified such an action might be, it would all look, well, just a little political, I fancy.

But the MPC has one more meeting before that on, as it happens, Wednesday 7 February and the following day. This is the meeting at which the Treasury representative at the MPC will presumably give his official 'leak' of the fiscal shape of the Budget (not, I hasten to add, a leak of market-sensitive tax rates).

We know already that the Budget is going to contain a huge fiscal injection, which could be considered badly timed if domestic demand remained strong, but well-timed if it suddenly collapsed. However, both the Chancellor and the Governor of the Bank have stressed that they do not see the 'knock-on effect' from the US slowdown that many others worry about. And the National Institute of Economic and Social Research judges that the UK economy has been temporarily depressed by the effects of the rail crisis, but that 'this does not indicate a general slowdown'.

The temptation for the MPC must be towait and see. But if the economic outlook does deteriorate sharply, there is always an MPC meeting on 4 and 5 April - wonderfully timed to lift spirits with a rate cut at what could be the beginning of the election campaign.

Meanwhile, one welcomes the recent falls in the pound. The fact is that beneath the veneer of the Chancellor's economic success a lot of damage has been done. The volume of exports rose by 38.5 per cent between 1995 and October 2000, whereas the volume of imports shot up by 57.7 per cent. The OECD estimates that between 1995 and 2000 unit labour costs in the UK rose by 45 per cent relative to other countries.

Yet we still hear suggestions that 'manufacturing doesn't matter.' Oh yes it does. And rewriters of history could well consult an article by economist Gavyn Davies, written years ago, but reprinted in an interesting collection Double Takes (Wiley, IIMR) edited by John Goodchild and Clive Callow.

As Davies points out: 'It is wrong to suggest that Britain's manufacturing industry was in relative decline before the arrival of oil. In virtually every economic cycle from the beginning of the industrial revolution up to and including the early Seventies, manufacturing was the fastest-growing sector in the economy, increasing its share of real output in the UK on a continuous basis; and in no sustained period before 1979 did the level of manufacturing production ever decline.'

Exchange-rate policy, manufacturing and agriculture are crucially linked. Beneath the surface of this Government's economic popularity lie some disturbing trends. In 1999 manufacturing output was a mere 2.2 per cent above the 1995 level. That's simply not healthy for a serious economy.

webTitle: Corus faces £800m bill to clean up threatened plants

fields.headline: Corus faces £800m bill to clean up threatened plants
fields.trailText: The government is putting pressure on Anglo-Dutch steel giant Corus to pay clean-up costs that could run to hundreds of millions of pounds at steel works threatened with closure. The company is expected to announce swingeing job cuts within days.
fields.body:
The government is putting pressure on Anglo-Dutch steel giant Corus to pay clean-up costs that could run to hundreds of millions of pounds at steel works threatened with closure. The company is expected to announce swingeing job cuts within days.

In a series of crisis talks, senior Ministers and regional development agency officials have told Corus that it will have to meet the cost of making good land contaminated by decades of heavy industrial use.

The Observer has established that the two plants most at risk of closure - Llanwern in Wales and Redcar on Teesside - could each face decontamination bills of up to £400 million. Unions claim even this price would make UK closures cheaper than shedding jobs at Corus's Dutch plant at Ijmuiden.

Corus is arguing that most of the contamination occurred while its UK operations were run by nationalised British Steel, so the Government, rather than Corus shareholders, should pick up a large part of any liabilities. The company also claims that it cleaned up land around the Ravenscraig plant in Scotland after it was closed in 1992 for £20m. The ISTC steel union says this was only a small part of the real cost, which was closer to £100m..

Last Thursday, Corus chief Sir Brian Moffat held separate meetings with Welsh Secretary Paul Murphy and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers. Whitehall and Cardiff sources have confirmed that the clear-up issue was raised at the meetings.

Corus is obliged under the Environmental Protection Act to restore land to brown field status, but it has not made clear what the figures for Llanwern or Redcar would be.

Dr John Bridge, chairman of One NorthEast, the area's regional development agency, said: 'We believe the cost of making the site serviceable is between £400m and £500m. It is difficult to identify responsibility for this bill.'

RDA sources said privately that they are lobbying the Government to ensure that Corus, which is losing close to £1m a day, picks up the bill. Welsh Assembly sources said they believed the bill for Llanwern would be similar.

Both they and Welsh Office officials confirmed that ministers were pressing Corus to meet the bills in full.

A Welsh office source said: 'It is obviously in our interests to argue that these costs are real and high, and that Corus will have to meet them.'

An official from the ISTC said: 'Corus wants to clobber taxpayers as well as employees with the cost of its mistakes.'

webTitle: Bad sales tidings for Littlewoods

fields.headline: Bad sales tidings for Littlewoods
fields.trailText: Littlewoods, the catalogue and department store group, faces further setbacks in its struggle to revitalise following a flat Christmas and disappointing January sales.
fields.body:
Littlewoods, the catalogue and department store group, faces further setbacks in its struggle to revitalise following a flat Christmas and disappointing January sales.

The family-owned firm has cancelled its Christmas trading statement after sales in the first week of 2001 came in 25 per cent below budget.

And sales in the crucial five weeks to the end of the year rose by just 2.1 per cent, despite cheaper prices under Littlewoods' new 'better value' retailing strategy.

Littlewoods' continuing struggle comes as Mark & Spencer prepares to announce a further collapse in clothing sales this week. Industry sources say menswear sales are down by up to 15 per cent, womenswear by 11 per cent and childrenswear by 8 per cent.

The results from both chains demonstrate the problems that traditional high street names face in competing with new arrivals such as Matalan and New Look, and a highly successful Next.

In December, Littlewoods announced losses of £15.6 million following poor first-half trading and chaos at its catalogue warehouses. Around 200 jobs have already been lost in cost-cutting.

The problems have also forced it to shelve a planned flotation and Littlewoods' City advisers are reviewing all options for the future.

'We've launched our new spring/summer catalogues and revamped our High Street stores,' Littlewoods corporate services director Jim Donovan said this weekend. 'We are expecting to see positive signs from that.'

But internal accounts show sales barely moving in the first week of 2001, at £25.9m against £25.6m last year and a budgeted £34.4m. The poor start means the group is now £66m under budget, with turnover of £1.49 billion to date - lower than last year - against a hoped-for £1.55bn.

Insiders expect Littlewoods' board, headed by chairman James Ross and chief executive Barry Gibson, to face anxious questioning by the controlling Moores family over the new strategy.

At this rate, sources say, Littlewoods faces a further deterioration in profits and a decline in sales from £2.1bn last year. It could miss its £2.14bn current-year budget by an embarrassing margin.

webTitle: Tesco rolls out banking and pensions at the tills

fields.headline: Tesco rolls out banking and pensions at the tills
fields.trailText: Tesco is hoping to entice customers across the UK to bank, top up their pensions, and buy their cornflakes at the same time.
fields.body:
Tesco is hoping to entice customers across the UK to bank, top up their pensions, and buy their cornflakes at the same time.

The supermarket says it is so pleased with a pilot scheme that allows its banking customers to pay in cheques at the checkout that it is providing the service at all 650 UK branches from this summer.

It is also exploring the possibility of using the same technology to let its 1.8 million banking customers supplement their stakeholder pension contributions as they pay for their groceries. Stakeholder pensions, scheduled to come in this April, are the Government's low-cost pensions initiative designed to get more people saving towards retirement.

Since last summer, the half million Tesco Personal Finance customers with its instant access savings account have been able to pay in cheques at 99 branches across the country. One in five cheques is being paid into Tesco's savings account this way and more than 50 per cent of those using the service do so outside normal banking hours. Customers can pay in cash as well as cheques.

The retailer insists the process does not cause delays at the checkout and that customers' privacy is respected at all times. Those worried about flashing their cash in the checkout queue can perform the same transactions at customer services.

Tesco Personal Finance, the financial services arm of the supermarket chain, was launched in July 1997 as a joint venture with the Royal Bank of Scotland. It offers loans, mortgages, Isas and insurance products.

webTitle: Orange sells itself cheap

fields.headline: Orange sells itself cheap
fields.trailText: Orange will try to attract support for its troubled forthcoming flotation by giving small investors a chance to buy shares at less than the price to be offered to City institutions.
fields.body:
Orange will try to attract support for its troubled forthcoming flotation by giving small investors a chance to buy shares at less than the price to be offered to City institutions.

The move, which will be announced tomorrow when the mobile phone company publishes its prospectus, was typical practice during the privatisation programme of the Eighties, but is unusual outside Government sell offs.

Orange's owner, France Télécom, is keen to use the power of the company's brand in the UK, where it has more than 9 million customers, to attract as many small investors as possible. Fears over spiralling debt in the European telecoms sector, coupled with a re-evaluation of the worth of new media stocks, have diminished the City's' appetite for mobile phone shares.

At one stage last year, analysts were predicting that Orange might be valued at as much as €150 billion (£250bn). But the consensus among them last week valued it at between €70 million and €80m. Predictions from the industry's own experts now range between €60bn and €68bn.

But even this re-evaluation may now be too high. Nomura telecoms analyst Mark James puts the worth of Orange at €55bn. James feared other telecoms firms remained over-valued, something which could work against Orange.

'What we've tried to highlight is that investors need to take into account that Orange's peer group may trade down rather than Orange trading up,' he said.

James added there was 'no doubt' that Orange was a blue-chip stock and that its UK and French mobile interests were very good companies. However, there were questions hanging over the value of the rest of the business's mobile phone portfolio, which spans 19 countries and 30 million customers.

'There are an awful lot of loss-making businesses. Much rests on them moving into profitability, and frankly they may not,' James said.

The Orange flotation is seen as crucial to the success of other telecoms firms, which are looking to list their mobile divisions later this year.

Deutsche Telekom, BT and KPN Telecom all want to float their mobile interests over the next few months. A disappointing listing for Orange would scupper their chances of success.

France Télécom wants to float between 10 and 15 per cent of Orange. The company will support the float with a convertible bond offer.

fields.headline: Will Jazz Cafe's sax appeal translate from Camden to Paris?
fields.trailText: Jazz lovers on the Continent are about to get a taste of the Irish, writes Nick Mathiason. The Mean Fiddler organisation, run by Waterford-born Vince Power, who owns a dozen top London music venues, is to take its Jazz Café concept to Paris, Barcelona and another top European city. The company said last week that it intends to raise £10m through a stock market flotation. Based in Camden, north London, the Jazz Café is attracts top musicians including Courtney Pine and Dr John.

webTitle: Interiors: Spence House

fields.headline: Celebrity squares
fields.standfirst: Spence House has been called the 'greatest 60s space in Britain'. No wonder architect John Pardey couldn't wait to get his hands on Sir Basil Spence's masterpiece
fields.trailText: Spence House has been called the 'greatest 60s space in Britain'. No wonder architect John Pardey couldn't wait to get his hands on Sir Basil Spence's masterpiece.
fields.body:
As a student, the architect John Pardey developed a passion for Sir Basil Spence's Coventry Cathedral. Although the rebuilt cathedral, completed in 1962, was the British public's favourite building of the 20th century (according to a survey by English Heritage), its creator is nowadays largely dismissed and vilified. While his other buildings include the Sussex University Meeting House and the Beehive (the executive wing of the New Zealand parliament) in Wellington, his name is largely associated with concrete monstrosities of the 60s. Yet, in Pardey's eyes, Spence managed to fuse 'romantic with modernism'. 'At his best,' he says, 'Spence made things poetic.'

For Pardey, one of Spence's most poetic constructions was his own house, built in 1961 on the secluded and gently sloping north bank of the Beaulieu river in Hampshire. After Pardey himself moved to the same area some eight years ago, he decided to contact the present owners to ask if he could visit. 'Dear Spence House,' he wrote, 'I've long admired you and would love to come and see you.' In due course, a reply came from a London-based financier, and former architecture student, who had bought the house several years before in order to save it from certain demolition.

'I knew the house back to front from studying drawings and photos of it,' recalls Pardey, 'and when I wandered in there, it was very much like meeting an old friend after many years. It was so familiar, yet aged. So dignified, yet crumpled. What particularly struck me was the power of the landscape. I really had not been prepared for that.' As chance would have it, the owner was planning to refurbish and extend the house, and on meeting Pardey, decided to entrust him with the job.

Today, Pardey is a mine of information about the place. He tells you that Christine Keeler used to visit and that she carried out her affair with John Profumo just down the road. He also informs you that the round-the-world navigator Sir Francis Chichester attended parties there and that guests used to dive directly out of the first-floor window into the pool. 'It was quite a rocking place!'

Spence, who died in 1976, built the house as a weekend retreat on land he purchased from Lord Montagu. The original structure was a slightly mono-pitched cedar-clad box, cantilevered over a brick ground floor. The upper floors housed the living quarters, while the lower one was given over to boat storage and a workshop space. Spence only lived there for about five years, before moving to the Mediterranean, but during that time, made several alterations. He glazed in the first-floor balcony to enlarge the living space. He turned part of the ground floor into a kitchen and dining room, and added on an octagonal timber stair tower with a spiral staircase to the east end of the house. He even toyed with the possibility of building an extension. Although planning permission was granted, it was never built.

Still, it provided Pardey with guidelines when it came to the present renovation. Spence had planned to extend to the east and Pardey followed his lead, adding on a new wing with two bedrooms and a bathroom and connecting it to the original house via a glass bridge. Instead of imitating Spence's black timber, he clad the extension in natural, untreated cedar wood, which will turn grey with time, and made its dramatic focus the large bedroom window, which he claims is a sort of personal homage to the Italian architect Giuseppe Terragni. It also affords stunning views over the river. 'It would have been easy for the extension to be overpowered by the strong design of the Spence house,' he explains, 'and I wanted to have a single element to match its power.' The new wing provides a subtle, harmonious counterpart.

Over the years, the maritime climate had taken its toll on the original structure. Before renovation work could take place, the timber box was encased in a scaffold-roofed, bubble-wrapped enclosure. Then, insulation and all new services were installed from the outside. Asbestos and 'all the horrors of 1960s architecture' were also removed, and the octagonal tower's timber container stripped away and replaced by glass. For Pardey, the new staircase is a conscious reference to the 'Chapel of Industry' at Coventry Cathedral. 'It acts as a kind of jewel,' he says. 'It really shimmers in the summer.'

One particularly delicate feature proved to be the swimming pool, which was subsiding. In order to prevent the risk of the house sliding down towards the river, Pardey had to insert 47 poles into the ground in front of it before the new pool could be built. At the same time, the riverside pond was also rebuilt and a sculpture of a reclining woman commissioned for it from the artist Richard Lawrence. To the east of the garden stands a head carved out of Portland marble by Emily Young.

Inside, the house is the perfect example of Pardey's style - 'clean, simple, but not simplistic. I'm interested in natural forms and materials,' he says, 'and I fuse that with a love of colour.' Spence painted all the original doors cadmium yellow and parts of the brickwork ultramarine, and Pardey has brought bright hues inside the house, too. The top of the walls and ceiling of the master bedroom are painted sky blue and offset by a vivid orange canvas by French artist Bruno de Fourmantelle. The corridors of the extension are bright yellow, and the cupboard doors and walls of the new kitchen area respectively yellow and dark blue. 'The kitchen is intended to be more a kind of workshop for catering,' he says. 'I tried to make it very earthy'.

The adjoining dining room is more sophisticated with its Achille Castiglioni Frisbee light and dining table and chairs by Arne Jacobsen. The choice of the Danish architect's furnishings is far from arbitrary - the taps in every bathroom are also by him. Indeed, Pardey believes that Spence's design was largely inspired by two of Jacobsen's own residential projects - the Kofkelt House of 1957 and the Siesby House of 1959, which both explore the idea of a timber box perched over masonry.

Spence House's pièce de résistance , however, remains the large, open-plan living room, with its Swedish redwood ceiling, ruddy afazalia floor and incredible, bush-hammered concrete fireplace by Ove Arup. 'It's a hell of a cantilever,' says Pardey. 'There must be a ton of concrete there.' For the room, Pardey commissioned two rugs from Helen Yardley, whose previous projects have included the British embassies in Moscow and Jakarta, as well as the Metropolitan Hotel and Disney Corporation headquarters in London. Pardey, for one, seems to be delighted with the results. 'This is the best 1960s space in Great Britain,' he says. 'There really is nowhere else quite so coherent and uncompromising.' And Sir Basil wouldn't have had it any other way.

webTitle: Life support

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: When comedian Dave Gorman moved in with Danny Wallace he was looking forward to a life of tea and cocktails. But then a drunken bet put the pair on the road in a worldwide search to find 54 Dave Gormans
fields.trailText: When comedian Dave Gorman moved in with Danny Wallace he was looking forward to a life of tea and cocktails. But then a drunken bet put the pair on the road in a worldwide search to find 54 Dave Gormans.
fields.body:
Dave Gorman: About five years ago, Danny was interviewing different comedians about their shows. Weeks later we were at a party at the Edinburgh Festival and met as two strangers at a bar. We started talking and three hours later realised we'd spoken before. But even though we hit it off, being friends seemed forbidden because I knew he reviewed comedy.

I'd been living in Manchester and got a job producing for Channel 5. I needed to move to London and saw an ad for a flat in Harrow. I met a guy called Jaakko, and agreed to move in. Afterwards, I found out Danny also lived there. It was then that we became firm friends. When Jaakko married Yoko, Danny and I sort of married, too.

We moved into a flat in Bethnal Green. I thought flatsharing was something I'd left behind in my student days, but he's so easy to live with. Talk about women getting into the same rhythm, we have an odd synchronicity. We'll find ourselves both going to the kitchen for a cup of tea at the same time. Or we'll have a White Russian. He mixes a great cocktail.

I try to live a life of complete freedom and treat the shows like documentaries about things that happen to me. I'll go anywhere, do anything. Dan calls my bluff more than anyone. If I say, 'Wouldn't it be good to do this,' he'll say, 'Do it.'

Which is how the challenge to find 54 Dave Gormans came about. And that has led us into more than one scrape. We found a Dave Gorman who lived in New York State. He was trying to show us Clinton's new house when there was a huge bang, trees were hitting our car and coming down all over the road. We were in the middle of a tornado. I started shitting myself. We got back to our hotel and I was absolutely shaking. Only later, when we looked back at the tapes was it a funny thing.

In Danny, I have found my perfect collaborator by accident. I have written with loads of other people - Caroline Aherne, Craig Cash, Henry Norman and I used to write The Mrs Merton Show, which I loved - but working with Dan is more enjoyable because it happened by accident.

Danny Wallace: It has seemed like there have been too many coincidences for us not to be friends. In the first five minutes of meeting him at that bar, he was slightly surly. When we discovered we shared a sense of humour we were fine. We also share a taste in food. I always know what he is going to order off a menu, but we definitely have different tastes in girls. He likes pierced ladies, alternative chicks. Page Three is more my kind of thing.

With our sort of flatshare, even if we had bad habits they'd be forgiven because we'd probably both have the same. If I didn't live with Dave, I'd live within a mile of him. Luckily, we live in an age of text messaging, so my girlfriend can keep track of me. She does get jealous of him, but she can understand the point of going around the world meeting people who share your name, but your flatmate's name? It is stupid.

It was drunken bravado that started this off. We were playing cards, plus jokers, and he was telling me about this other Dave Gorman he'd been told lived in Scotland. So I challenged him to find as many as a pack of cards. Armed with a video camera I'd been given for my birthday, we went off to find him. It became an obsession.

We've found ourselves in Israel without money, we've lost our shoes in Norway, been in a tornado in New York, we've been on the road for six months. All for a stupid bet. I'm lucky my girlfriend hasn't finished with me.

We were up to 47 Dave Gormans and he couldn't find any more. I was getting a bit gloaty about it, saying I knew he couldn't do it. In one of his stage shows, early on, people had volunteered to change their names by deed poll. He called them, never for a minute thinking they would do it. Five of them came through, two of them women. We've asked ourselves why would they do it. Some people will think that they did it for TV, but we did all the filming and the stage show before it was even taken on by the BBC (BBC Choice, 23 January; BBC2, 18 February).

Dave paid for everything himself. I only ever forked out for about three pints. It's been Dave's quest, I'm just the idiot with the camera.

webTitle: Well being

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: finding your way around orientation, drying out sweaty palms and exercise for eyes
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: finding your way around orientation, drying out sweaty palms and exercise for eyes.
fields.body:
We are still in the 'dark' time of year, when according to the Native Americans and other pre-consumerist cultures, the Earth Mother sleeps in order to regenerate herself in readiness for pushing through the new life of spring. And we, 'her children', would, if following our natural seasonal rhythms (and presumably if living as Native Americans in, say, pre-30s Arizona or New Mexico), retire to our adobe dens for a few weeks and not make too much noise or fuss lest we wake her and in her wrath she blights next season's crops - doesn't bring us breakfast, in other words.

It is worth, then, discussing the phenomenon of momentary or semi- permanent disorientation, because we don't, on the whole, follow our natural rhythms, live for the most part in adobe houses, or know anything whatsoever about being quiet.

Nestled instead in our ubiquitous electric womb, we seem only to know how to make a great noise and bruhaha - phones beeping, TV sets blaring, pile-drivers (to lay more TV cable) pile-driving, engines revving and digitally generated tribal music mimicking the sound of all of the above, in an intensified and amplified sonic melange for us to celebrate as we dance.

Our homes, vehicles and to a lesser extent our clothing and footwear are all designed to not only shield us from the sensation of interacting with the elements, but to skew the experience till we all but forget there actually are any elements - until we experience the extremes of flooding and hurricanes. Even then it's mostly a TV experience. And if we don't like the weather here, we're never more than a few hours' worth of congested flight path from a heatwave happening somewhere on the planet. The whiff of anything remotely biological has been all but masked by scent, and short of a solar storm or worse knocking out the grid, we never have to worry about being in the dark again. This is all fine and dandy for those who are whole or part robots, but for the rest of us, whose ancestors so recently evolved from the running-semi-wild-in-front-of-the-cave state, this masking of the natural is obviously disorienting at a fundamental, existential level.

As well as being one or more steps removed from our natural rhythms and rhymes, we have even managed to deconstruct our weather patterns and render the integrity of our land masses questionable as the pace of every day life surges forth in an orgy of unbridled microprocessed acceleration. Indeed, the rules of the game of human existence are changing so rapidly it is redundant to talk of the everyday. That we will soon allegedly be witnessing the creation of animal-human hybrids might suggest that we are completing the creation circle and returning to the days of pure myth where centaurs roamed the land and nests of vipers in one's coiffeur would raise no eyebrows.

It is only to be expected, then, that during this upcoming partial crack in the schedule between TV programmes, you ponder your place in the grand scheme of things and may well experience moments of fundamentally unsettling, existential disorientation. Disorientation means literally a moving away from the east - away, in other words, from the direction of the earth's spin, which is not unlike sitting with your back to the direction of the train (not that you'd notice at the speed they're running).

So the first step in reorienting yourself and aligning yourself to some degree with the natural order and beginning to regain equipoise on every level, is to face east. Next, become aware of being on a planet in space rotating on its own axis at 1,000mph in the direction of your gaze, while simultaneously travelling in orbit around the sun at 66,000mph or 19mps. Once this meta-realisation of physical context has penetrated for even one micro- instant, you could find your sense of wonder and adventure return and with it perhaps the perspective of being on a long space voyage, during which you make as many friends as possible and amuse yourself and them as best you can for the duration. For when you finally disembark a few trillion miles down the line, it may appear somewhat of a waste to have spent precious chunks of the journey at odds with yourself and your environment.

In other words, don't let disorientation upset you or resort to habitually numbing yourself to it through shopping, sex or substance abuse. Instead use it as an automatic reminder to reorient yourself to what's actually going on here - a megasonic ride through space on an organically produced mother ship, supported by a crumbling biosphere with the most bizarre assortment of sideshows from all the best and worst sci-fi movies ever made, to stop us, the natives, getting too restless and trying to jump off.

Your questions

Barefoot! I'm 43 and in good health but have recently found it difficult to focus on the small print in magazines. If it turns out that I need glasses, is there an alternative?
Steven Hale, email

In Oriental medicine, it's believed that the eyes are the 'flower' of the liver and that when the liver weakens, so will the eyesight. That's why it's common for vision to weaken after 40 as the organs loose their strength. Acupuncture and Chinese herbs can be efficacious in this respect, but also start daily eye exercise. Slowly and gently, so as not to strain the retina, trace the shape of all the lines in the Union Jack, one by one, seven times each, then using your fingertips, massage around the orbit of the eye from the outer corners under the eyes to the inner corners and then over the eyes to the outer corners. Repeat 18 times. Also do this whenever the eyes are tired. Percussion on the back of your skull with knuckles also helps stimulate the visual cortex.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I suffer from sweaty palms at this time of year. Is there anything I can do about it?
Ben Taylor, email

Sweaty hands are a symptom of deficient kidney chi, as are anxiety and general nervousness. Martial-arts training can help strengthen kidney chi in the long term. Massage your kidneys with your fists in a circular motion a few times before, during and after every stressful situation. You can also try rubbing an astringent oil into your palms such as cypress or geranium.

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com.

webTitle: Sybil Kapoor: Boil in the bag

fields.headline: Boil in the bag
fields.standfirst: The great chieftan of the pudding race now comes in the guise of chic canapés
fields.trailText: The great chieftan of the pudding race now comes in the guise of chic canapés.
fields.body:
The only haggis I have ever eaten was at a Burns Night supper in south London, many years ago. As a result, I contemplate trying it again every year. Yet the thought of boiled lamb's lung, heart and a little liver, chopped and mixed with roasted pinhead oatmeal, onions, spices, seasoning and cooking liquor just doesn't appeal. The fact that it is stuffed into some Canadian ox casing, boiled for a few more hours and piped in on a silver platter doesn't help my timidity.

Nevertheless, across the world millions of Scots have ordered their haggis for Burns Night on 25 January. Premier haggismakers Macsween of Edinburgh sell everything from mini 20g canapé haggis - for chic cocktail parties - to 5.52kg (12lb) ceremonial monsters. The uninitiated are advised to study The Burns Supper Companion by Hugh Douglas (£6.95, Alloway) as a guide to the social niceties of when to stab your haggis with a skean-dhu during the recital of Robbie Burns's 'Address to a Haggis'.

Nick Nairn, a consummate banquet haggis carver, maintains that it is best enjoyed in the traditional manner, with fluffy mashed tatties and buttery bashed neeps, or swedes. 'I used to serve it with a whisky gravy,' he confides, 'although on Ready Steady Cook I did turn some haggis into egg-and-breadcrumbed patties. They were surprisingly good.'

John Macsween, managing director of Macsween, believes the key to good haggis lies in its texture and seasoning. 'You need to use pinhead oatmeal to ensure that it has an open, moist texture,' he explains. 'Finely chopped beef back fat is also better than suet, as it melts into tiny, juicy globules.' Its seasoning has been the cause of much debate between haggis aficionados. According to Nick Nairn, many people (usually professional sausage makers) are too heavy-handed with the cayenne, black and white pepper. Traditionalists like John Macsween prefer the more rounded spicy flavour of ground mace, nutmeg, coriander, black and white pepper.

Then again, you can always order one of Macsween's vegetarian haggises. 'They're pretty good,' says Nick Nairn. fields.bodyText: The only haggis I have ever eaten was at a Burns Night supper in south London, many years ago. As a result, I contemplate trying it again every year. Yet the thought of boiled lamb's lung, heart and a little liver, chopped and mixed with roasted pinhead oatmeal, onions, spices, seasoning and cooking liquor just doesn't appeal. The fact that it is stuffed into some Canadian ox casing, boiled for a few more hours and piped in on a silver platter doesn't help my timidity. Nevertheless, across the world millions of Scots have ordered their haggis for Burns Night on 25 January. Premier haggismakers Macsween of Edinburgh sell everything from mini 20g canapé haggis - for chic cocktail parties - to 5.52kg (12lb) ceremonial monsters. The uninitiated are advised to study The Burns Supper Companion by Hugh Douglas (£6.95, Alloway) as a guide to the social niceties of when to stab your haggis with a skean-dhu during the recital of Robbie Burns's 'Address to a Haggis'. Nick Nairn, a consummate banquet haggis carver, maintains that it is best enjoyed in the traditional manner, with fluffy mashed tatties and buttery bashed neeps, or swedes. 'I used to serve it with a whisky gravy,' he confides, 'although on Ready Steady Cook I did turn some haggis into egg-and-breadcrumbed patties. They were surprisingly good.' John Macsween, managing director of Macsween, believes the key to good haggis lies in its texture and seasoning. 'You need to use pinhead oatmeal to ensure that it has an open, moist texture,' he explains. 'Finely chopped beef back fat is also better than suet, as it melts into tiny, juicy globules.' Its seasoning has been the cause of much debate between haggis aficionados. According to Nick Nairn, many people (usually professional sausage makers) are too heavy-handed with the cayenne, black and white pepper. webTitle: Gym won't fix it

fields.headline: Gym won't fix it
fields.standfirst: Helen Foster warns of the perils of keep-fit excesses
fields.trailText: Helen Foster warns of the perils of keep-fit excesses
fields.body:
The exercise season is upon us, January being the busiest time of the year at any gym as old members work off the excesses of Christmas and new ones the excesses of the past five years. But experts warn that we should proceed with care: throwing yourself too vigorously into a new fitness regime can make you vulnerable to a number of health risks, including osteoporosis and reduced fertility.

'Exercise is a stress on the body,' says Dr Nick Webborn, medical advisor to the National Sports Medicine Institute. 'That's how it makes you fitter. You stimulate your body and it adapts to this stimulus by building muscle and strengthening the heart and lungs.' Done correctly, this will be one of the most potent things you can do for your health - moderate exercise has been shown to lower the risk of heart disease, some cancers and endless day-to-day ailments. Increasingly, however, research is demonstrating how many of our workout habits mean that the health benefits of regular exercise are being overridden by the negative effects - that is, by attempting to be too fit too fast, we don't strengthen our body through exercise, we actually attack it.

Problems occur for one of three reasons: we either work out too hard, for too long or too often. Of these, experts believe working too hard is the most damaging. If you work out really hard, all the ways in which your body is supposed to adapt to exercise stress go out of control. Take your immune system - ideally, exercise should stress it into producing more fighting cells, but if you work too hard this doesn't happen. Instead, it stresses it so much that the vital killer cells that are supposed to protect us are actually destroyed and for up to 24 hours any bug in the vicinity can take hold (one reason a third of marathon runners get sick after the race).

Outside of the immune system, you'll find that instead of reducing the effects of stress on the body, a high-intensity workout actually increases levels of the most harmful stress hormone, cortisol, causing endless problems for circulation and the nervous system. And while moderate exercise causes your bones to go into a process of recycling - during a normal workout, they are broken down by cells called osteoclasts ready to be mended by so-called osteoblasts afterwards - working out too hard knocks this process out of balance and the amount of bone broken down is increased. Add to this the fact that heavy exercise can cut oestrogen levels in the body, and it's easy to see why new research shows increasing numbers of athletes getting osteoporosis up to 20 years earlier than normal.

Another effect of overdoing exercise, is the overproduction of molecules called free radicals which rampage around the body attacking healthy cells. At moderate exercise levels, free radical increase can be fought by your body, but during an intense workout some areas of the body produce as much as 200 times more free radicals than normal, increasing free-radical damage to cells - a process which has been linked to everything from cataracts to cancer.

Preventing these problems is relatively easy. You monitor the intensity of your workout and so prevent yourself from working out too hard. 'The idea is to ensure that the majority of your workout is done at around 70 per cent of your maximum heart rate,' says Dr Ian Swaine, principal lecturer in exercise physiology at De Montfort University. 'You work this out by subtracting your age away from 220, then working out 70 per cent of this. This is the number of beats per minute your heart should beat, and it's the level at which you should exercise to maximise the gains made from exercise and minimise the negatives.'

This doesn't mean, however, that as long as you keep working out steadily, you can spend hour after hour in the gym. Working out for too long or too many times in a week can also cause problems. Ralph Pffanberg Jr and his team at Stanford University Medical School studied nearly 17,000 men and found that exercisers who burnt between 2,000 and 3,000 calories a week exercising (about three-and-a-half to five hours of moderate running or cycling) had significantly lower death rates from heart disease than non-exercisers. However, when men burnt more than 3,000 calories a week (about four 75-minute sessions), this protective effect began to decline and death rates started to climb again. Similar thresholds have been shown for women. The sensible exerciser, therefore, will aim for the 2,000 to 3,000 calorie mark - about about three-and- a-half to five hours a week, with no session lasting longer than one hour.

You should also make sure you rest for a day between sessions. 'Many people think this will lower your fitness level, but that's not true. The gains you make when you work out actually occur in the rest period for 24 hours afterward as your body repairs. It can't do this if you're working out again,' says Professor Mike Gleeson from the School of Exercise Science at the University of Birmingham. If you insist on training every day, Gleeson says, 'you should at least ensure a heavy workout is followed by a light day using different muscle groups.'

Of course, if you are training for an endurance event like a marathon, cutting back won't be an option. In this case, your protection comes from your diet. What you do or don't eat can make a huge difference to the effects that exercise can have. Start by supplementing with the antioxidant nutrients that will help fight free-radical damage. Studies at Washington University School of Medicine showed that exercisers given 600iu of vitamin E, 1,000mg of vitamin C and 30mg of beta carotene before they worked out produced 36 per cent fewer free radicals during their workout than normal. 'You can also cut immuno-suppression by ensuring you eat before a workout,' says Professor Gleeson. 'The immune system gets more depressed when people work out on an empty stomach.' He also points out that exercising in extremes of temperature increases the risk of immuno-suppression.

Finally, watch your equipment - if it's not up to scratch, you might find that it's not just your immune system you have to worry about. A recent Austrian study showed that 95 per cent of men who mountain-biked about 3,000 miles a year had developed deformities in the scrotum that could lead to fertility problems in the future. It was believed much of the problems were caused by knocks to the testes from bikes with suspension problems and hard saddles. This echoed findings that showed that high-duration cyclists were developing impotency due to damage to the nerve endings in the groin caused through crotch-to-saddle contact.

Of more universal concern is the increase in risk of injury to the the knees and back caused by wearing trainers that have lost their suspension. Make sure you replace training shoes every 500 miles of running, or about every 100 hours of any other exercise. If you aren't sure how many miles your footwear has logged, take them to a sports shop, try one new trainer and one old trainer at the same time and run, jump, walk - whatever - just concentrate on how your body feels as it hits the ground. If the new shoe feels dramatically bouncier, you need to buy new shoes.

Overall, what's important is to listen to your body and to aim to strengthen and improve it through sensible exercise. Doing so will bring many benefits, ranging from protecting your heart to creating better orgasms.

It's also worth bearing in mind that, according to Ian Swaine, 'the benefits of exercise are so powerful that even if you are working too hard you have less risk of major health problems than a couch potato. But for optimum gain, get the balance right.'

Take a break: work out too hard and you'll pay the price

Experts recommend that you look out for the following signs - if you are experiencing more than two or three of them then it's time to take a rest .

 Your resting heart rate is 8bpm more than normal. Regular exercisers should get used to knowing their heart rate by taking it first thing in the morning (while still in bed). If it increases by more than 8bpm over a day, your body is trying to tell you something - it could be that you're coming down with a bug, it could be that you're overdoing it. Either way, you need a rest.

 Has your workout got harder? If you're finding it significantly harder to do your normal programme, take it a bit easier.

 How are your POMS? The effects of exercise are not just physical. When looking for overtraining, experts measure something called the Profile of Mood States (POMs). If you find you're getting more depressed, having more mood swings, feeling irritable or experiencing loss of libido, take a break.

 Are you fatigued or having trouble sleeping? Both can be signs of overtraining.

 How's your health? Frequent infections (particularly respiratory infections) are a sign that your immune system is suppressed, which is a sign that you're working too hard. Be sure to take a break and include proper rest periods.

webTitle: Jane Clarke: Bone meals

fields.headline: Bone meals
fields.standfirst: How to beat osteoporosis, sort out your libido and heart, and tackle digestive disorders
fields.trailText: How to beat osteoporosis, sort out your libido and heart, and tackle digestive disorders.
fields.body:
The Christmas issue of Time magazine featured a photograph of Sir Elton John sporting a milk moustache alongside the words 'I'm still standing. Want strong bones?', as part of an advertising campaign to encourage Americans to drink more milk. The timing is apt, for at this time of year snow and ice can render many pavements treacherous, and a slip can be all that it takes to inflict life-threatening injuries on people who suffer from the brittle-bone disease osteoporosis. One in three women and one in 10 men in the UK suffer from this disease, and each year doctors treat 70,000 hip fractures, 50,000 wrist fractures and 40,000 spinal fractures, at a cost of more than £1.5bn a year to the NHS. This shocking expense could be reduced if we paid more attention to our diets, and particularly to our consumption of calcium, the easily absorbed nutrient that is essential for enabling the body to create new, and to preserve old, bone tissue.

The childhood and teenage years are the most crucial when it comes to preventing osteoporosis, because this is when we form the strong bones that will support us in later life. The recommended daily intake of calcium is 450mg a day for children up to six years old, rising to 550mg from six to 11 and shooting up to 800mg for girls and 1,000mg for boys thereafter.

After the age of 20, when the formation of new bone material ceases, the recommendation decreases to 700-800mg a day for both men and women. Although some children who have a confirmed milk allergy should not consume dairy products, for the majority of children these are a vital component of a healthy diet.

It generally makes little difference whether you or your children drink skimmed or the richest Jersey milk, low-fat or whole milk. However, I don't recommend that children under the age of three drink reduced-fat milk because they require fat to supply their bodies with fat-soluble vitamins, although semi-skimmed milk is usually fine after the age of three and skimmed milk after five. Remember that goat's milk contains slightly less fat than cow's milk, while sheep's milk contains a little more.

To achieve the recommended intake of calcium, a child could have 500ml of milk, 300g (2 small pots) of yogurt or 75g of cheese a day, while teenagers could have 850ml of milk, 500mg of yogurt or 125g of cheese. To glean 750mg of calcium, an adult would need to consume 650ml of milk, 400g of yogurt or 100g of cheese. You could also top up your calcium intake by eating almonds, spinach, seeds, tofu, canned fish and dried fruits.

Nutrition news: The zinc link

Over Christmas, my father brought a piece of recent research to my attention that will probably cause a rumpus in many households. According to a report made to the World Stroke Congress in Melbourne, Australia, having sex three times a week can halve a man's risk of having a heart attack or stroke. Contrary to the conventional belief that cardiovascular exercise should be taken at least three times a week and should last for 20 minutes or longer, according to leading specialist Sahr Ebrahim, it doesn't matter if the sex doesn't last very long - even a three-minute quickie could be good for a man's heart. By way of encouragement, while there is no scientific proof of a specific food's aphrodisiac qualities, most people can conjure up a sexy thought or two while swallowing an oyster, peeling a prawn or sucking an asparagus spear. Coincidentally, or maybe not, the oyster and other seafood is rich in zinc, a nutrient which if deficient can lead to a poor libido. Less sexy but equally zinc-rich foods include brown rice, crumbly cheeses and wholegrain bread.

Your questions

I have just been diagnosed as having a wheat intolerance. Does this mean that I can't eat oats, too, as I gather that they're related?
Martin Glover, Dulwich

You're right in thinking that oats and wheat are related, as they both contain a protein called gluten, which frequently causes food-intolerance and allergy symptoms. Oats contain far less gluten than wheat, however, as do rye and barley. The first thing to do is to check with the practitioner who diagnosed you whether you have an intolerance to wheat or gluten (the names are often misused). If you are unable to digest gluten, you will have to avoid all of its sources, including many manufactured products, such as cakes, pasta, sausages and foods that contain bread. Although product labels are required by law to declare the presence of gluten, if in doubt, contact the Coeliac Society (01494 437 278) for a list of products that are gluten-free. People who are sensitive to wheat alone may be able to eat oats, rye and barley. Although some people can tolerate a small amount of wheat, they find that their symptoms persist when they eat more than their guts can deal with. A stressed gut also reacts badly to the food that you're sensitive to, so if you avoid eating wheat-based products during the working week and reserve them for the weekend, for example, your body may be able to tolerate them better.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. If you would like her to answer any questions or address any issues in this column, please write to Jane Clarke c/o Life Magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email her at life@observer.co.uk. Please note that Jane Clarke cannot enter into any personal correspondence.
