webTitle: Caprice uncovered

fields.headline: Caprice uncovered
fields.standfirst: She's paid to turn up at parties, she's dated Tony Adams and she's revealed all on the front of countless men's magazines. Andrew Anthony meets the Valley Girl who's become famous for being famous for being famous
fields.trailText: She's paid to turn up at parties, she's dated Tony Adams and she's revealed all on the front of countless men's magazines. Andrew Anthony meets the Valley Girl who's become famous for being famous for being famous.
fields.body:
More than all the Hello! has-beens and OK! nobodies, more than the MTV presenters and society party girls, more than Craig from Big Brother or the 'Green Shield stamp heir' who used to escort Claudia Schiffer, more even than Elizabeth Hurley, Caprice Bourret embodies the late-postmodern age of British celebrity culture. She is not simply famous for being famous. She is famous for being famous for being famous.

Her renown has never been anything but knowing. It has always been, right from the instant she entered public consciousness, based on the self-evident absurdity of her being well-known. There was no backlift with the former bra model. No transition from obscurity to celebrity, no awkward limbo of semi-recognition. She arrived, fully formed, as an ironic icon, a camp conceit, a beautiful blonde media monster.

And it was not just the tabloids she colonised, like so many third-rate soap stars. She also became part of the lexicon of the up-market press. Last year the New Statesman called her 'the dream girl of the post-literate generation' and the Sunday Telegraph suggested that as a 'parodic celebrity' she was an ideal candidate to join the House of Windsor.

The novel question one asks with Caprice (the Bourret, as if to emphasise her status as a phenomenon, was long ago buried) is if she hadn't been invented, would she exist? If the media hadn't made her famous - by constantly asking why she is famous - would anyone, other than her family and friends, have the least idea who she is?

Of course, it's one of those imponderable riddles, like whether the light stays on when you close the fridge. It should also be conceded that, by definition, a magazine interview is not the best means by which to solve the puzzle. It's the self-defeating equivalent of opening the fridge door.

As it happens, I have already seen inside Caprice's fridge door (I seem to remember it contained a solitary yogurt), thanks to an intriguing documentary called Being Caprice. The programme, screened last year, called upon her to wear a concealed camera for 10 days as she attended parties, sat on the loo, and looked inside her fridge. She agreed to this extraordinary invasion of privacy because, she claimed, 'I think a lot of people have a misconception of Caprice's world.'

Perhaps for still more people, any curiosity they begrudgingly nurture for Caprice stems from the fact that she says things like 'people have a misconception of Caprice's world'. Increasingly, the most interesting aspect of celebrities is their celebrity, not what they are celebrated for. As Caprice's job is being a celebrity, being Caprice, she represents the purest form of fame: artifice untainted by art. Thus interviews with Caprice have been a number of things - vapid, silly, an excuse to publish photos of her without her clothes on - but never have they had to concern themselves with the numbing details of what she was actually doing. But now she has gone and spoilt everything by wanting to be a pop star.

'I'm not talking about the modelling,' Caprice said firmly, 'the modelling's in the past. And I'm not talking about my relationships. I'm talking about my music now.' We were sitting on the large comfortable sofa in the faintly showroom atmosphere of her modern, gated-community home in Fulham, when Caprice started to live up to her name.

Up until that point, I had been surprised at how well we were getting along. I had expected her to remain in 'character', like Sir Les Patterson or Ali G, and play the role of the hard-nosed bimbo in need of constant attention. But in her civvies of jeans and T-shirt, she was rather sweet and unsophisticated. Almost natural.

A great deal of speculation has centred on how much of Caprice is originally her and how much has been improved by medical science. There has been informed talk of nose jobs and breast implants, and one men's magazine editor who has worked with her told me he was convinced that she had received 'a total atomic makeover'. But in the morning, before the make-up artist had got to work at the photo shoot, she appeared persuasively organic.

At the shoot, in the vain hope of learning anything about the 'real' Caprice, I spoke to her publicist, a disarmingly boyish character called Ghislain Pascal. He wore a permanent expression of amusement, as if we were all playing a game and he was winning. I'd seen this look of good-humoured cynicism before on other entertainment PRs. It suggests to me that they know precisely how trivial the publicity business is, which is to say not quite as trivial as the journalism that it feeds.

He gave me his business card, a mini portfolio of the talent he represents (none of whom I recognised), with his company name in large type on the front: 'Panic'.

Pascal has been credited as the architect of Caprice's instantaneous public profile. He met her back in early 1996 at the Select model agency where he was the PR. A graduate of the LSE, and former charity worker, he quickly recognised her determination to become someone. 'I knew that we could work together. She wanted publicity.'

His first step was to get her on Daddy's Girls, a documentary about the charmed life of three spoilt, rich young women, including Tamara Beckwith (another of his clients). He then approached WonderBra and landed a promotion campaign, before overseeing Caprice's coup de grace, her arrival at the National Television Awards in a see-through dress. The tabloids, hungry for a new Elizabeth Hurley, went hog-mad. Britain has rarely seemed a smaller country. It was as simple as that.

At least that's how Pascal tells it. For Caprice the story is a little more complicated. She resents the 'famous for being famous' tag and wants to let you know how hard she has worked to get where she is. But at the same time, she also doesn't want you to get the impression that any of it has been planned or calculated. And that means she often contradicts herself or retreats behind vague memory or her favourite phrase: 'That's a matter of semantics.'

Not long after Daddy's Girl, in which she boasted that she was 'born' to polo fields, it became apparent that she was in fact more of a Valley Girl, who grew up in modest circumstances in a Los Angeles suburb and whose father left home when she was four.

The British, she was to learn, can be quite pedantic about social class. She now claims that she thought the programme was an acting job. 'I didn't know it was going to be real,' she told me. 'I just went with the flow.'

Even the circumstances in which she originally came to London have been known to change depending on how passive or active she wants to seem at any given time. Back in 1996, she told the Daily Mail that she came to Britain because of her boyfriend at the time, a property developer named Robert Tchenguiz. 'We met when I visited the Monte Carlo Grand Prix. He asked me to visit him in Britain for a weekend. So I did, ended up staying a month, got a flat, joined an agency and, boom, started making a life for myself over here. So that trip changed my life.'

Elsewhere she has said that it was Tchenguiz's partner, Robert Curtis, whom she met in Monte Carlo and who invited her to London. But she told me that she came to England to get tear sheets and because she thought she could be 'a bigger fish in a smaller pond'. And the decision, she insisted, had nothing to do with any man. Like she often says: whatever.

As I drove her home after the shoot, Caprice changed gear. I don't mean that she slipped into something more comfortable. Nor do I mean that she became more animated. I mean she shifted the car gears while I held the steering wheel.

I was conscious at the time of the surreal, not to say comic, quality of coasting through London as a pneumatic blonde celebrity took care of my gear stick. But in retrospect, compared with the forensic analysis of nonsense that was to follow, it was the day's most real moment.

It was after we arrived at her house that things turned weird. She told me, for example, that she was 'not in this business for the fame thing'. She told me that she had regrets about posing nude for Playboy but that she was happy to pose nude for magazines like GQ.

'There's a difference, Andrew, between showing the whole lot and showing nothing at all by covering up. There's a huge difference. There's one thing pushing the limit, but covering the bits up, and being really explicit and showing everything - at this stage of my career, I don't feel I need to do it, and I won't do it again.' She told me that she was changing her image from naked cover girl to something more 'minimalist'. 'You have to move on, just like Madonna. You've got to evolve.'

And so we came to the music, her music. Three years ago, at the height of her fame, she apparently signed a five-album deal with Virgin. I say apparently because only two singles have been produced in that period. Not since the heyday of progressive rock bands has anybody spent so long in the studio working on an album that still remains notional.

The delay has been partly caused by an artistic change in direction. The first single, 'Oh Yeah', released two years ago, only charted at number 24. It was deemed to be too poppy. What did she think of it? 'I thought it was a great campaign,' she said, sounding more like a politician than a pop star, 'and I was really happy with the results.'

Yes, but what about the song itself? 'At the time, I went with it, but afterwards it wasn't the direction I wanted to go in. And now the album's completely different, guitar led, much more raw.'

There was a limit to how much I could discuss her music because her management had seen fit only to send me one single, 'Once Around the Sun'. I suppose it would be described as easy listening, although I found it very hard listening.

Such is the abysmal state of British pop music these days, however, that it's not the worst song you'll ever hear. It's not even the worst song you'll hear this month. But it is blandly forgettable.

The transition from model to pop singer, while not as common as model-to-actress, has been attempted before. Naomi Campbell, the supermodel and novelist, had a go but, if anything, made more of a mark with her ghosted writing. Caprice dislikes the comparison.

Various attempts to carve out a TV career had come to nothing, when she discovered her passion for pop. Again, she didn't have the idea herself. A boyfriend suggested that she should make a record. Having never sung outside the shower, she says she was shocked. 'I swear I thought he was on drugs or something. "Are you out of your mind?" I said, but he kept persisting. I thought, "What have I got to lose?"'

She wouldn't tell me who the boyfriend was. She has an odd habit of bringing attention to her male friends and then coming over coy if you ask her about them. Last year the revelation that she had been to dinner with Prince Andrew gained a depressingly extensive amount of press coverage. Some reports identified Pascal as the source of the story. He denied it when I asked him, but he couldn't control his widening smile.

Caprice herself has also employed this strategy of implausible deniability. On TV in America, promoting her Playboy cover, she replied when asked about Andrew: 'Even if I have kissed him, do you think I'd tell you?'

She confided afterwards, in Being Caprice , about being questioned on Andrew: 'I wouldn't mind the attention if I had a record out.'

In London, she said to me: 'You know when it's bad is when you're promoting a record and all they want to talk about is you going out with Prince Andrew, do you know what I mean?'

Well, frankly, no. The stop-start publicity cycle of statement, denial, then counter-denial was beginning to exhaust and disorientate me. I asked her if she felt pop music was all part of the same continuum as modelling.

'No, no, no, because I was a product then. I was whatever the client wanted me to be.'

Did that include turning out to parties?

'Oh yeah, I made a lot of money showing up at parties. I would turn up in a very glamorous outfit. And that's it. That's it. I made a great living.'

How much would you be paid?

'I'm not going to tell you.'

Oh, come on.

'I'm not going to tell you.'

Why not?

'Because it's none of your business.'

I'll tell you how much I'm paid.

'No, I don't want to know. I was able to save a substantial amount of money and that's it.'

I love it when you come over prim, I said, in an effort dissipate the tension.

'I'm not going to tell you, you little shit. I'm not going to tell you. Don't bug me about it. I was really, really lucky, I was able to make a good living. And that's what it was all about, you know. People like glamorous people and that's what they hired me to be, the glamorous Caprice they saw on the cover of magazines.'

So no continuum between modelling and pop music, then?

'What happened,' she said, attempting to regain her composure, 'was I'm a very creative person by nature and,' she paused, as she searched for the right words, 'I didn't want to model.'

I tried to get back to the safer territory of music by asking her why she recorded the (still to be completed) album in Los Angeles.

'I was in LA so I was isolated and I couldn't go off and do a TV show or a modelling job, or be tempted, because they used to tempt me. They used to call me up and say, "You're going to make this much" and I'd go, "Oh!"'

How much?

'You little shit, I'm not going to tell you.'

I was asking about modelling money, not the appearance money.

'It's the same thing. I'm not going to tell you.'

It's a different question.

'It's the same thing, they're both jobs and I'm not going to tell you.'

But everyone knows that Linda Evangelista wouldn't get out of bed for less than $10,000. What kind of money wouldn't you get out of bed for? Let's say I phoned you up and said, 'Look, there's a couple of hundred quid in this, could be 300 if it all works out.' What would you have said? No?

There was a withering silence and then she said: 'Not necessarily. When you do a cover, that could be £150.'

That seemed to be as good a time as any to mention Tony Adams, the footballer. Through some kind of publicity osmosis, I had absorbed the news that they had been an item, but I think I assumed it was one of those urban-myth romances, like the lesbian folk singer and the famous children's TV presenter. Caprice has been 'linked' with countless men, among them Rod Stewart, Matthew McConaughey and, the week I met her, Dennis Quaid. But it turned out that Adams had really been a boyfriend.

In Being Caprice she put the record straight. 'I did have a relationship with him over a year ago. My publicist has already made a statement for me. I'll just say: "No comment."' To be a star, I suppose you have to act like one.

You and Tony Adams, I said, that was an incongruous relationship. There's Tony, England football captain and powerhouse of the Arsenal defence, and you, model, superstar. 'You know, at the end of the day, Andrew, put aside all the bullshit, all the England captain and model - it's about two people who have a connection, an understanding, a communication.'

At the end of our day, I think I found Caprice a slightly nicer and less neurotic person than the image I'd subconsciously formed from the ubiquity of her image. Yet I couldn't imagine someone with whom it would be more difficult to forge any lasting kind of connection, understanding or genuine communication.

For a start, you wouldn't know what to put on her birthday card. She told me that her birthday was 24 October 1972. Others have placed it much earlier than that, though I doubt it, and the same date in 1971 has also featured heavily as the real day. I asked her why there was a debate.

'That was initially because... I don't know why, there hasn't been a debate for the last three years.'

But why was there a debate then?

'I don't know. I don't know. I just don't remember.'

That's how the interview ended: with Caprice's mystery undiminished but her publicity unquestionably increased. The next day she was flying to the Bahamas, to a special celebrity-only party on Sol Kirschner's Paradise Island. After all, she's famous.

webTitle: The perfect scam

fields.headline: The perfect scam
fields.standfirst: Anil Bhoyrul, ex-City Slicker
fields.trailText: Anil Bhoyrul, ex-City Slicker.
fields.body:
My perfect scam kicks off by opening an account in the Cayman Island at a bank which automatically gives you an American Express Gold Card. Wearing my designer suit, I then go to a Ferrari dealership and ask to test drive one. Having seen my card, they happily lend me the car for half a day. A scam relies on a snowball effect, starting with having the right appearance. Once a few people think you're the main man, everyone else will follow. It's human nature.

Meanwhile, I've faxed several letters to various pop stars cancelling some fictional meetings. They fax me back saying they've never heard of me. I use their letterheads to write letters to myself, saying it was good to meet me or that they'd like to meet me regarding appearing on my music channel, Music Live, and outlining details of payments of £5,000 for my time and expenses. I fax all of these to the Grosvenor Hotel just before my arrival there in my Ferrari. I book the best room, and ask the manager if the mail I was expecting has arrived. He sees the faxes and puts the word around London that a millionaire is staying, sorting out acts to appear on his channel. The phone starts to go mad with every record company desperate to get their performers on my show. They're all happy to pay more than the rumoured £5,000 for my time and expenses to secure their acts. A week later I return the Ferrari, check out of the hotel and go to the Cayman Islands to wait for my cheques.

The key is to get out in time because if you do it for too long, you start to believe it.

 Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell lost their jobs as the City Slickers, financial columnists for The Mirror newspaper, last February. Both were accused of dealing in shares they tipped in their column. They have since published City Slickers: How to Make a Million in 12 months (£5.99, John Blake).

fields.headline: Going, going, gone!
fields.standfirst: With a list of Hollywood clients which included Jerry Bruckheimer, Barbra Streisand and Jack Nicholson, art dealer Tod Volpe thought he had it made. But that was before the FBI got into the frame...
fields.trailText: With a list of Hollywood clients which included Jerry Bruckheimer, Barbra Streisand and Jack Nicholson, art dealer Tod Volpe thought he had it made. But that was before the FBI got into the frame...
fields.body:
In 1986, high in the Hollywood hills, with the Los Angeles basin extending south as far as the eye could see, the city winked like some magic jewelled carpet before me, and Joel Silver promised that I could have it all. Joel had a round, oversized face, piercing eyes, and a full black beard. He was in his thirties and had just produced the fabulously successful 48 Hrs ; Lethal Weapon and Die Hard were just ahead.

'So?' he asked, grinning. 'Whaddaya think, babe?'

Joel was an art collector, and we were standing before his major acquisition - one not even I could ever hope to match for him. Storer House, named after its first owner, is the most spectacular of several poured- concrete residences Frank Lloyd Wright designed and built in Los Angeles in the 1920s. Climbing by terraced stages into the hillside near the summit of Holly- wood Boulevard, it resembles some great pharaoh's tomb, with falling water inside and out, a Wright trademark, and stunning Japanese gardens. Joel had restored it and brought the familiar Wright details to life. There were ponds stocked with koi, exotic palms, lava-rock fireplaces in the upstairs and downstairs living rooms, and halogen spots on dimmers mounted in the polished, wood-beamed ceilings.

But the rooms were sparsely furnished, and the walls were almost bare. This was where I came in.

'Over there,' Joel said excitedly as he led me through the downstairs rooms.

'That's where I want your Ali Baba vase. And the Goddess of Mars . That sculpture? I want it right here. It'll knock their socks off when they come in the door. And the Versey carpet here.'

'The Voysey,' I corrected him.

'Yeah,' he snapped, 'whatever you call it. And the Flying Saucer lamp, I want that. And I want a Whistler.'

'It'll cost you an arm and a leg,' I told him.

He stared at me for a second. 'Then I'll settle for an Inness.'

Despite his greed and his need for instant gratification, Joel knew, in a general sense, what would work in his magnificent hilltop aerie. But he needed someone to get it for him, someone with expertise, credentials, and creative flair. He needed his Art Guy, just like the Car Guy and the Garden Guy and the Pool Guy, and the legions of lawyers, managers, accountants, decorators, shrinks and plastic surgeons who cater to the Hollywood elite.

For the past 15 years, I had immersed myself in early-20th-century American art. My gallery in Soho had rediscovered and had championed the work of a whole generation of American artists and artisans: the paintings of Georges Inness and William Merritt Chase, the Mission furniture of Gustav Stickley, Rookwood ceramics, the glass and lamps of Louis Comfort Tiffany. It would have taken Joel years to find and assemble the treasure I'd already unearthed, and it would have cost him 10 times as much. But Hollywood people don't work in years - they want it now - and from the moment, just a few weeks before, when Joel swaggered into my gallery, he had found what he was looking for.

He called me not long after that first visit. He was interested in a number of pieces he'd seen.

'Do you want me to send you transparencies?' I asked him.

'Sure, send me everything,' he said. 'But I want you to come out here. We gotta talk.'

I was on virtually the next plane. I'd always been star struck, and the success and celebrity I'd enjoyed on the New York art scene had done nothing to diminish that. Jack Nicholson and Anjelica Huston strolled into my gallery earlier that year. Once I'd composed myself, we got talking, and I found out just how knowledgeable a collector Nicholson was. Eventually we became friends, when he started asking for my advice on auctions. The phone would ring at one or two in the morning, and it would be Jack out in California.

'Come on, Babycakes, you got the catalogue?' Jack would be thumbing through the catalogue for an upcoming Sotheby's auction the way most of us thumb through a clothing catalogue, poised to order. 'Go to Lot 24. What do you think of that hanging chandelier? What about 113, Tod? The painting? What do you think of that painting?' And on to the carpets and the Tiffany lamps. When I pointed out to Jack that if we got everything he liked and asked me to bid on for him, we'd be spending four or five hundred grand, he'd pause - I could hear the sly grin forming 2,500 miles away - and then he'd say, 'So?'

Nicholson's two-letter word evoked an entire way of being in the world for me. To have so much money and power that you didn't have to worry about the cost. That night with Joel in the Frank Lloyd Wright house, with the Valley at my feet, I saw everything I'd ever wanted was within my grasp.

'What do you want?' Joel asked me.

'I want to change my life,' I told him.

'Tell me your dream.'

'I want to make movies,' I said. 'I want to make a fortune and marry a movie star.'

I may have said it cavalierly, mellowed as I was by champagne, but it was in Joel's own interest to take me seriously.

'You can have it all,' he said. 'Listen to me. Here's the deal.'

We talked late into the evening. How much of the deal Joel had worked out ahead of time and how much he improvised that night I never knew, but the gist of it was this: I was to furnish Storer House with all the pieces Joel had already singled out from the gallery and others that I would find and buy for him, at minimal profit. In return, I would move my operation west, where Joel would open all the doors for me. 'I know them all, all these people with all this fucking money and no style. They live in these big, empty houses. That's where you come in, babe. You're gonna fill their mansions with all your shit! You're gonna make your fortune and marry your movie star!'

The only problem, a minor detail really, was that he didn't have the money to pay the hundreds of thousands of dollars for the pieces he had already earmarked. Sure, he was well paid at the time, but he was still a hired hand, and restoring the house had cleaned him out.

What he wanted was to make a down payment and pay off the balance over time. Shrewd as he was, Joel must have known I'd have done it for nothing down.

'Sell art,' he sang, 'make movies! It's all gonna happen!'

At 37, I was about to reinvent myself. And eventually I would lose everything I had, including my freedom.

It was late 1986 when I moved west, and Joel Silver, true to his word, opened doors for me: producers and executives like Larry Gordon, Terry and Jane Semel, Nancy and Bob Daly, Linda and Jerry Bruckheimer, Patsy and Steve Tisch; stars like Penny Marshall, Bruce Willis and Barbra Streisand. I became art guru to Hollywood's elite, and they didn't simply collect, they accumulated competitively.

Linda and Jerry Bruckheimer (partner of the infamous Don Simpson, with whom he coproduced a number of films, like Beverly Hills Cop and The Rock ) lived in a steel-and-glass fortress in Brentwood. Linda, a native Kentuckian who favoured leather skirts and stiletto heels, was Jerry's live-in girlfriend for years before they married in 1993. As soon as she learned that others were buying from me - particularly Patsy Tisch - Linda became an important, and demanding, customer. She even grilled me about some pieces she'd heard I'd brought to Tisch.

'What about that Fulper mushroom lamp?' she said. 'You promised you'd show it to me first.'

'I'm sorry,' I confessed. 'It's already spoken for.'

She was silent.

'I've got a drop-dead Teco piece coming in about a week.' I said, trying to appease her. Teco was the Chicago architectural ceramic Frank Lloyd Wright often used.

'I want it,' Linda said. 'I want you to promise - I want you to swear! - that you'll show it to me before her.'

I swore to it.

'She's insanely jealous of me, 'Linda added. 'She's never forgiven me for getting to Don before she did.'

'Don' was Don Umemoto, an architect catering to the same clientele I was wooing, who'd helped Patsy redesign her home in Pacific Palisades. Although a modernised, somewhat bastard version of the Prairie School, the house had style and space - and absolutely ravishing gardens. It also had Patsy, a beautiful blonde with a keen sense of style and an effortless sexuality that made her seem the quintessential trophy wife. I could see why she rattled other women. Having been raised in New England and having worked at Knoll International for a time, she was also smart, well educated, and enormously charming. We became friends of a sort. I remember asking her once, offhandedly, if she was happy.

'As happy as anyone can be in a place like this,' she said.

Steve was from the younger generation of the Tisch family, which, among other assets, controlled the Loews Corporation, with its large entertainment and real estate holdings. Steve's success at the time rested on the movie that had launched Tom Cruise, Risky Business .

Like many of Hollywood's wives whose husbands live for their work, Patsy was always looking for projects to fill her time. First there was the house; decorating it was next. As I did for most of my favoured customers, I often brought her objects I thought 'belonged' and simply left them there for a while, without immediately talking price. Usually, Patsy would buy one or two things, and I would take the rest away. More than once I'd heard the Tisches argue about one of Patsy's intended purchases.

'Do we really need another green vase?'

'Yes, Steve, we do.'

'How come?'

'Because I want it, that's how come.'

And Steve would wind up writing the check for 10 or 20 or 30 thousand dollars. It was what Hollywood husbands did to guarantee a truce with their wives.

But one day I brought Patsy a Tiffany dogwood lamp, a monumental Grueby vase, and a great Teco, and carried them through the house, placing them where I thought they looked best. A week or so later, I called, assuming that, as usual, she would keep only one of the three.

'I want them all,' she said.

'All of them? But what about Steve? They're expensive.'

I told Patsy the numbers.

'Don't worry about Steve,' she answered levelly. 'I'll handle him.'

She asked me to come over that afternoon. Patsy looked stunning as always, and we sat in her living room, chatting. It was a Sunday, and Steve, when he showed up, said something about wanting to catch a game on TV.

But when he saw me he stopped.

'You again,' he groaned. 'I'd better get the chequebook.'

'But don't you at least want to see what we're buying?' Patsy asked. 'They're very beautiful.'

'How much this time?' he asked. He was still looking at me. 'What do I owe you, Tod?'

It was Patsy who answered. 'Seventy thousand.'

Steve recoiled as though he'd been struck by a branding iron. 'You know I don't have that kind of money!'

Patsy had got his attention.

'Oh, come on, Steve,' she said. 'Who are you kidding?'

'Well, for Christ's sake, not in the cheque account!' he said. 'I don't have that kind of money in the cheque account!'

'Well then, get it,' Patsy's voice was full of scorn. 'Just get it.'

There was a moment of dead silence as they stared at each other across the room. Then Steve sat and took out his chequebook, signed the cheque, crumpled it, and tossed it to me.

'See ya, Tod,' he said.

Then he stormed out of the house. I slipped out a few minutes later, wishing I hadn't seen what I had. I'd been half in love with Patsy myself, but I'd just seen a side of her that made me feel oddly sympathetic toward Steve Tisch. I never saw them together again, but I did see this same story played out countless times in different homes. It was as though once the Hollywood rich built their mansions and filled them, there was nothing left for them to do but get divorced. A few years later, that's what happened to the Tisches. Patsy, I heard later, remarried. Steve secured his place in Hollywood when he attached his name to Forrest Gump .

I'd first run into Barbra Streisand at a country auction in New Jersey. She'd just begun to collect turn-of-the-century American art and, characteristically, she did so with a vengeance. Once I moved to California, I continued to bring her furniture and paintings for her Beverly Hills mansion. Frequently she called for advice when she was just about to buy something or had already bought it and was panicking that she had been taken. Early one evening, when I was back in New York, she called.

'I'm on my way to the Armory,' she said. The Winter Antiques Show is a major annual event held at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street. 'I'll call you later. I want you to come over tonight and look at some things I'm buying. I'll have the housekeeper fix us dinner,' she said.

It'll be just the two of us, I thought.

'Bring along something wonderful to whet my appetite.'

This was a first. I'd never been invited to Barbra's apartment alone, and certainly not for dinner.

It was almost 11pm when she called back to say she was just leaving the show. By this time my imagination had run amok. Who knew what could happen? Hadn't her hairdresser and sometime boyfriend, Jon Peters, become, at least for a time, an immensely powerful Hollywood producer?

I rang the bell at Barbra's Central Park West duplex a little after 11. The housekeeper let me in - Ms Streisand wasn't home yet - and ushered me into a sitting room furnished with big puffy sinking couches and little tables. There were photographs of Barbra, Elliott Gould (her first husband), her son and other members of her family. A little later, I heard the front door open, then slam shut, and the sound of things being moved around. Then Barbra swept in and kissed me on both cheeks, her face still cold from the night air.

'How good it is to have you here,' she said. 'We'll eat in a minute. Let's just chat for a while.'

She loved the three vases I'd brought. I have no idea what else we talked about, but I remember the intimacy and the soft timbre of her voice.

'Hungry?' she asked.

'Starving,' I admitted, smiling.

'Well, come on then,' she said gaily. 'Let's eat.' She led me back out through the entrance hall to the dining room. There were shopping bags she must have brought home from the Armory Show, and two chairs. I recognised them instantly. They were a matching pair of tall, spindle-back Frank Lloyd Wright side chairs. They were in perfect condition. But I recognised something else as I handled them: the unmistakable odour of varnish. They'd been refinished, and recently.

How much had she paid? I was afraid to ask. If they'd been redone, their value had dropped through the floor.

'What do you think, Tod?'

I wanted to tell her the truth, but who wants to tell the truth to Barbra Streisand when she's been crossed? Then, as I hesitated, she told me who'd sold them to her and what she'd paid.

'They're wonderful!' I said. 'Absolutely magnificent! Congratulations Barbra.'

I hated myself for saying this, but I knew the dealer who'd sold her the Wright chairs. We worked together all the time. If I'd told Barbra the truth, she'd have demanded her money back publicly. No one in the art world willingly refunds customers, so the dealer would certainly have wanted to know why she wanted her money back now. Barbra would have named me, the dealers would have denied it, and we would have found ourselves in an embarrassing scandal.

She was delighted by my approval.

Maybe my lie was why the night went sour so quickly. A question of karma, or self-delusion. The minute we finished dinner Barbra started to yawn. She glanced at her watch, then at the front door. My time with Ms Streisand was clearly up. Once I'd approved the chairs, I was superfluous.

Maybe my lie was why the night went sour so quickly. A question of karma, or self-delusion. The minute we finished dinner Barbra started to yawn. She glanced at her watch, then at the front door. My time with Ms Streisand was clearly up. Once I'd approved the chairs, I was superfluous. Read the second part of 'Going, going, gone!' here

webTitle: Jonny, I hardly knew you...

fields.headline: Jonny, I hardly knew you...
fields.standfirst: An early-morning phone call from Australia forced Kathryn Flett to confront her feelings about motherhood, jealousy and the baby brother who'd grown up without her
fields.trailText: An early-morning phone call from Australia forced Kathryn Flett to confront her feelings about motherhood, jealousy and the baby brother who'd grown up without her.
fields.body:
I discovered I was about to stop being my mother's only child moments after walking through customs at Canberra airport in December 1980 (flight SQ84: memorable because the journey from London had taken three days, instead of the sched uled 27 hours). I was greeted by my mother, who had an enormous growth in the area of her midriff and was therefore unable to administer the hug I sorely needed. Intellectually, I knew what this growth was, of course, but emotionally I was confused. I hadn't seen my mother since the previous April, shortly before she and her partner, Arthur, had departed for a new life in Australia, the country of her birth (leaving me to move in with my father in London), though I'd spoken to her often enough on the phone.

'What's that?' I said, pointing at the swelling.

'That's your brother, Jonathan.' She replied, full of faux cheeriness. She was 42 years old, eight-and-a-half months pregnant and hadn't wanted to tell me on the phone. I never thought she made the right decision, neither at the time nor retrospectively: it had been painful enough losing her but, even as we were reunited, I felt not only separated again, I felt replaced. The secrecy also indicated a confusing degree of guilt and denial on her part. We had always been so close, physically and emotionally, throughout my childhood and my parents' divorce, but now I felt somehow betrayed.

Three weeks later, on the night she went in to labour, I woke swiftly. The bedroom light had been switched on to reveal my mother hovering in the doorway with a towel between her legs. I knew what this meant, I'd seen enough films: it was time to boil kettles and make tea and panic, quietly but capably. We were stuck out in the bush, not exactly handy for the hospital (closest village: Bungendore, infamous for its deadly brown snakes; pop: few, if you discounted the snakes). I couldn't drive and my mother, obviously, was in no fit state to do so, while Arthur was at that point out cold, fully dressed, on the bed, having chosen this particular evening to go on a whisky bender. It was all a bit Mike Leigh. After some tea-drinking, contraction-timing and telephoning, eventually my mother ended up being driven to the hospital in Canberra by her brother, my uncle David, with a bleary Arthur bundled in the back. Meanwhile, I went to bed, drained but relieved. There was nothing to stay up for, after all - I knew the baby was a boy, and now he was on his way.

I saw him the next day: Churchillian and crumpled, he looked just like a baby, albeit a rather sweet baby, but even his incontrovertible cuteness seemed unconnected to the extraordinary, unprecedented wave of emotion that this small creature immediately inspired. I was denied any choice in the matter - looking at him, I instantly loved him completely, consumingly and, given the context at least, quite irrationally. Nothing had prepared me for the solar-plexus-churning physicality of unconditional love, that fierce lionness kind of love more usually the preserve of new parents than reluctant siblings. But this was, I suppose, partly the result of the 16 years and nine months that separated our births and the fact that, though I had extremely ambivalent feelings about the way my mother had failed to prepare me for his arrival, these feelings were directed at her (and to a lesser extent, Arthur). No longer abstract, I didn't resent the reality of Jonny at all. Instead, I felt an instant and unbreakable bond.

I returned to Australia for his first birthday. We shared a room and he woke me every morning, giggling and rocking back and forth in his cot. I was delighted by him, but even as I bonded with my brother, relations between me and Jonny's father were irreparably soured. I despised Arthur's drinking and the Mr Hyde beneath the sober and charming Dr Jekyll it invariably revealed. One 32 C day, while I was sunbathing in the garden, he appeared in a beery fug and hissed: 'She doesn't want you now, you know. We've got a new life here.' And though I strongly doubted whether this was true, nonetheless I didn't see my mother or brother for another six years. And I never saw Arthur again.

Shortly after Arthur's death from cancer in 1990, I returned to Australia, to Goulburn, NSW ('Australia's first inland city', pop: 24,000), where my mother and brother were now living. Jonny was nine and I'd brought him lots of books because, when I was nine, books were all I'd ever needed to distract me from Big Bad Things. But I couldn't have got it more wrong: Jonny gave the covers a desultory, disappointed glance, muttered a muted, 'Thanks, plain-face' (his nickname for me, coined when he'd visited me in London for the first time at the age of seven. Diplomatically, he'd explained that it didn't mean I was plain in the normal sense of the word, just that I had a disconcertingly un-Aussie paleness. Either way, I've always liked its Native American ring) and then retreated straight to his bedroom and Scalextric, leaving the books on the sofa.

'He's just been diagnosed as severely dyslexic,' explained my mother, apologetically. 'He can write his name and that's about it, though he's very good at maths.' I was mortified. Not only had Jonny just lost his father, but his strange and unfeasibly ancient sibling had just compounded this misery by pointing out yet another reason for him not to be cheerful. I tried to make it up to him over the next few weeks, attempting to tease the sad little boy out of thinking about the loss of his dad. Mostly I think I failed.

Since then, I've seen Jonny three times: aged 14 and about 5ft 6in, on the uncomfortable, monosyllabic cusp of adolescence, sporting a pudding-basin haircut and a too-big blazer at my wedding. Then, less than two years later, in Australia, when the marriage had finished and I needed my mum, by which time Jonny was 5ft 10in or 11in. Voice long-since broken, he sported a nascent six-pack, chequerboard Crazy-Coloured hair and was branded head-to-toe by Nike in honour of his hero, Michael Jordan. The beautiful, green-eyed, freckled boy-child was all but gone.

And then, last October, I came home from an early-morning dogwalk to find two messages on my answering machine. The first, predictably short and vague, was from Jonny: 'Hi, how ya going? Give me a call_'; the second, equally short but slightly weary-sounding, was from my mother: 'Hello darling. Hope you're well. Call me as soon as you can_' My tiny, fractured family is not given to phoning very often, so a call from both my mother and brother on the same day was unlikely to be a coincidence. I phoned my mother first. 'What's up?'

'Ah, well, I think you should speak to Jonny_'

I persisted: 'Look, obviously something's up. God forbid he's getting married or_' I paused, shuddered, 'becoming a dad!' But even as I said it, it sounded absurd. There was a weary sigh from 12,000 miles away.

'Yes, the latter. And, what's more, it's due in November. I've only known myself for a few days_'

But I'd already burst into reflexive tears before I'd even worked out exactly why I was crying, though as I talked to my mother she helped me to articulate it. Our emotions were oddly similar - which also meant, confusingly, that I was responding to this news more like Jonny's mother than his sister. The first emotion was a wave of semi-maternal disappointment (that a bright young man's life should be even potentially circumscribed by such a banal and unnecessary development); the second emotion was a very un- sisterly anger at the girl (how dare this 18-year-old strumpet - whom I'd never met and knew almost nothing about - attempt to trap my golden boy), while the third emotion was out-and-out, pure, unadulterated, old- fashioned envy.

I'm not particularly proud to admit that, by the end of the call, it was the envy that resonated the most. And I think you know where I'm going with this, so let me take you straight there: I'm 36, gainfully employed, live in a spacious flat in a leafy part of London with my beloved dog, Possum. It is, by no stretch of the imagination, anything other than a privileged life and it would be absurd to pretend otherwise_ and yet even as I get more comfortable within this life (and by extension, less likely to adapt to any other sort), news of my brother's impending fatherhood put me in touch with the darker side of sibling rivalry for the very first time: all I could think was, 'My mother's first grandchild should have been mine_ the thunder-stealing little sod.' And then, just as I was hating myself for thinking this, my mother said, quietly, through the ether: 'It should have been you, darling. Even Jonny said that to me.'

She meant it sweetly, of course, not judgmentally. She has never been one of those mothers who pester about the possibility of grandchildren, not even when I was married and it would have been appropriate. But lately both my parents, quite independently of each other, have taken to finishing phone conversations with the words 'And give Possum lots of kisses from Granny' or 'Grandpa', albeit ironically.

I don't want to be the 'mother' of a dog, I want to be the mother of a child and discover the true depth of the feelings that Jonny's own arrival prompted 20 years ago. An experience that those friends of mine who are now mothers accept as a given and which threatens - if only from my perspective - to create a divisive gulf of experience between us. I want to have a baby not simply because my periods are becoming an increasingly painful and unpredictable reminder that my biological cliché is ticking - no, I want one partly because I think I might (finally, amazingly) be nearly grown up enough to make a reasonable job of it. But though I'm ready to be considerably less selfish, this relative unselfishness also extends to wanting a child within the context of a strong relationship because, however unfashionable an opinion, I think that's where children are most likely to thrive. Obviously, I don't know if the ideal set of circumstances will ever present themselves, so I guess this fresh, ugly, bubbling sibling jealousy was about Jonny now having immediate access to a life-altering experience that I may not have. He was clearly about to relinquish his baby-brother status and become, suddenly, my teacher, and I wasn't quite ready for that. But, like having children, I guess there's never a right time.

'I suppose I'd better call Jonny,' I said to my mother eventually, when the sobs had subsided. 'And say all the right things. Whatever the hell they are_'

'Don't say anything you don't really feel,' counselled my mother. 'I know I didn't.'

So I called him straightaway and sobbed and said lots of sisterly, 'supportive' and 'understanding' stuff I didn't really want to be saying. And after the short conversation (in which I did most of the talking because, even if he was about to become a father, Jonny was still a teenage manchild of few words, especially when confronted by a crying woman), I put down the phone and was furious with myself. All I'd really wanted to say was: 'Get out now, Jonny! Run as far and as fast as you can! Think Nike: "Just Do It"! The relationship won't work out. You're both children. Please, please, please don't Do the Right Thing_ Go and get a life instead.' But of course I hadn't said any of that.

I spent quite a lot of the next few days on the phone to my mother. I went round to see my father, who is very fond of Jonny. 'Oh dear!' he said. 'What a shame_' which was pretty much all there was to say, really. And my male friends - metropolitan middle-class media thirty- and fortysomethings to a man - had similar reactions, along the lines of: 'Blimey! What's he going to do? You wouldn't see me for dust in that situation_' - which didn't come as much of a surprise. Those who are fathers had, for the most part, got around to it pretty late (and occasionally reluctantly), so the thought of becoming a parent in their teens was, presumably, incomprehensibly terrifying.

However Jonny is (thankfully) not a metropolitan mediasomething but the product of a small Australian country town. So, perhaps, doing The Right Thing wasn't for him quite the unspeakable horror it had immediately appeared to be to me and the majority of my uncompromisingly sophisticated and indulgently self-absorbed friends. Maybe, for Jonny, Just Do It is less an advertising slogan than it is a code of honour.

The baby, a boy - Jordan, in honour of Michael - was born a week later, five weeks premature. There were complications, blood loss and breathing difficulties, so his mother, Felicity, had an emergency C-section at Goulburn hospital and then, within the first few minutes of his life, Jordan was airlifted to a prem-unit in Canberra with Jonny by his side. As Felicity recuperated in Goulburn hospital, father and son camped in Canberra.

'I can't hold him yet,' he told me, when I called the hospital the next day. 'But I can sort of stroke him.'

'It must have been a bit scary?'

'Yeah, bit hairy. He'll be right, though.'

And so, in awe, I cried different tears when I listened to my baby brother who was no longer a boy but, suddenly, 150 per cent a man. I didn't send flowers, teddies or babygros, but I did make arrangements to visit, arriving on 17 November, which had been Jordan's due date. I spotted my mother, Jonny, Felicity and Jordan at Canberra airport before they saw me, which bought me a bit of time. There were echoes of 20 years ago, but on this occasion, at least, I knew I was wearing the right expression. After introductions and hugs, I held the small, crumpled squawking Jordan very briefly. I didn't cry. In fact, I didn't feel anything. If holding my brother for the first time had put me in touch with something bigger than both of us, then holding my baby nephew was_ like holding any baby. While he had certainly been the catalyst, it wasn't for this baby I had flown 12,000 miles.

A few days later, after spending some time with my mother, who now lives in the bush an hour and a half away from Jonny, I went to stay overnight with the new family in Goulburn. In the evening, I had planned to take Jonny out for our first-ever restaurant dinner à deux, while Felicity stayed in with Jordan and Erin Brockovich on video. I changed into high heels, at which Felicity took one look and demanded that Jonny iron a shirt. After restaurant suggestions from Felicity and her mother (who, at 35, is a year younger than me. Which information, needless to say, came as a bit of a shock but explains a lot), Jonny drove us both, still undecided, into Auburn Street, small-town Goulburn's low-rise main drag.

'Where we goin' then, sis? The Blue Plate and The Steak House both sound,' he glanced at me, pulled a deliciously teenage face, 'a bit neeeurgh!' I laughed: 'Sod it, kiddo, let's go to the Fireside Inn.' At Goulburn's poshest restaurant, Jonny ate king prawns in chilli sauce followed by his very first duck and, because he was driving, drank only orange juice. We talked incessantly, greedily.

'Tell me about the night I was born. I've heard the story so many times from Mum, about her going into your room when her waters broke and stuff, but where was Arthur? He's always sort of missing from the story.'

I debated internally, briefly, whether or not to tell him, but it was a no-brainer, really. If Jonny was old enough to be a father himself, he was old enough to know the truth about his own.

'Completely pissed. Out cold. But rest assured, he was there for your birth!'

Jonny nodded. 'I thought it was something like that. But he was sober for the last few years, you know_' I told him I was glad. And then I asked if he felt like a grown-up now, since the arrival of his son. Which was really a polite way of asking if he felt trapped and miserable.

'It's more like a sense of responsibility towards Jordan,' he said, levelly. 'Before, I'd just spend money on me and not think about it. Now I know I have to work_' And then he concentrated on the newly arrived sticky date pudding and caramel sauce which meant, I think, that he missed seeing my eyes well up. I was on my third glass of South Australian Chardonnay and felt sincerely sentimental:

'I think you're an extraordinary young man,' I said suddenly, snuffling a bit. 'And that's not just because you're my brother.' He blushed to his peroxide roots, but he grinned, too.

Jonathan David Berkeley Williams is now a handsome 6ft one-and-a-bit inches. He has four discreet tattoos, including a gothic 'J' (for Jonny and Jordan) on his back. Like his sister when she was his age, he still dyes his hair ridiculous colours and remains branded by Nike (in these fickle times, I think Jonny is the most singularly label-loyal young man I've ever met: he wears the Nike swoosh as a ring, and has had it dyed into his hair). He can read now (but prefers not to) and despite his obvious difficulties, made his mother very proud by staying at Goulburn High until he'd got his Higher School Certificate (the equivalent of A levels). He wore black tie, tails and green hair to his Graduation Formal, which is a bit like a Prom.

He doesn't smoke (though I've never dared ask him about drugs) and, until he was a passenger in a car accident a couple of years ago, which damaged his spine and put paid to his professional dreams, he was also a very serious jock. He listens to trance and techno (though I don't know if he dances), drives a metallic purply-blue, customised 80s Nissan Pulsar, with which he tinkers lovingly in the vast garage of the small rented house (rotary clothesline, rose bushes, a brick barbie and three bedrooms) in the 'burbs of Goulburn, where he lives with Jordan and Felicity - no strumpet, after all, but a bright, self- composed young woman.

After leaving school, Jonny went on a bar-tending course and currently works four nights in a nightclub in Goulburn and six shifts a week in a towel-making factory. He wants to learn how to mix a thousand cocktails and then hopefully become a professional mixologist, or manage a bar or restaurant. I have no doubt he will do both. I also think he could model if he wanted to, but when I mentioned the idea to the photographer who took these Beckhamesque portraits of Jonny and Jordan, he said: 'No, you want to keep him away from all that fashion crap. It might ruin him.'

In fact, I don't think anything would ruin him, but at the same time I'd be sorry if he slipstreamed into the urban fast lane because he is, indeed, pretty much perfect as he is: a man amongst boys - sweet, smart, funny, honourable and steadfast. Last November, I finally met my extraordinarily ordinary grown-up baby brother and, though I never thought it possible, I love him even more.

As Felicity recuperated in Goulburn hospital, father and son camped in Canberra. 'I can't hold him yet,' he told me, when I called the hospital the next day. 'But I can sort of stroke him.' 'It must have been a bit scary?' 'Yeah, bit hairy. He'll be right, though.' And so, in awe, I cried different tears when I listened to my baby brother who was no longer a boy but, suddenly, 150 per cent a man. I didn't send flowers, teddies or babygros, but I did make arrangements to visit, arriving on 17 November, which had been Jordan's due date. I spotted my mother, Jonny, Felicity and Jordan at Canberra airport before they saw me, which bought me a bit of time. There were echoes of 20 years ago, but on this occasion, at least, I knew I was wearing the right expression. After introductions and hugs, I held the small, crumpled squawking Jordan very briefly. I didn't cry. In fact, I didn't feel anything. If holding my brother for the first time had put me in touch with something bigger than both of us, then holding my baby nephew was_ like holding any baby. While he had certainly been the catalyst, it wasn't for this baby I had flown 12,000 miles. A few days later, after spending some time with my mother, who now lives in the bush an hour and a half away from Jonny, I went to stay overnight with the new family in Goulburn. In the evening, I had planned to take Jonny out for our first-ever restaurant dinner à deux, while Felicity stayed in with Jordan and Erin Brockovich on video. I changed into high heels, at which Felicity took one look and demanded that Jonny iron a shirt. After restaurant suggestions from Felicity and her mother (who, at 35, is a year younger than me. Which information, needless to say, came as a bit of a shock but explains a lot), Jonny drove us both, still undecided, into Auburn Street, small-town Goulburn's low-rise main drag. 'Where we goin' then, sis? The Blue Plate and The Steak House both sound,' he glanced at me, pulled a deliciously teenage face, 'a bit neeeurgh!' I laughed: 'Sod it, kiddo, let's go to the Fireside Inn.' At Goulburn's poshest restaurant, Jonny ate king prawns in chilli sauce followed by his very first duck and, because he was driving, drank only orange juice. We talked incessantly, greedily. 'Tell me about the night I was born. I've heard the story so many times from Mum, about her going into your room when her waters broke and stuff, but where was Arthur? He's always sort of missing from the story.' I debated internally, briefly, whether or not to tell him, but it was a no-brainer, really. If Jonny was old enough to be a father himself, he was old enough to know the truth about his own. 'Completely pissed. Out cold. But rest assured, he was there for your birth!' Jonny nodded. 'I thought it was something like that. But he was sober for the last few years, you know_' I told him I was glad. And then I asked if he felt like a grown-up now, since the arrival of his son. Which was really a polite way of asking if he felt trapped and miserable. 'It's more like a sense of responsibility towards Jordan,' he said, levelly. 'Before, I'd just spend money on me and not think about it. Now I know I have to work_' And then he concentrated on the newly arrived sticky date pudding and caramel sauce which meant, I think, that he missed seeing my eyes well up. I was on my third glass of South Australian Chardonnay and felt sincerely sentimental: 'I think you're an extraordinary young man,' I said suddenly, snuffling a bit. 'And that's not just because you're my brother.' He blushed to his peroxide roots, but he grinned, too. Jonathan David Berkeley Williams is now a handsome 6ft one-and-a-bit inches. He has four discreet tattoos, including a gothic 'J' (for Jonny and Jordan) on his back. Like his sister when she was his age, he still dyes his hair ridiculous colours and remains branded by Nike (in these fickle times, I think Jonny is the most singularly label-loyal young man I've ever met: he wears the Nike swoosh as a ring, and has had it dyed into his hair). He can read now (but prefers not to) and despite his obvious difficulties, made his mother very proud by staying at Goulburn High until he'd got his Higher School Certificate (the equivalent of A levels). He wore black tie, tails and green hair to his Graduation Formal, which is a bit like a Prom. He doesn't smoke (though I've never dared ask him about drugs) and, until he was a passenger in a car accident a couple of years ago, which damaged his spine and put paid to his professional dreams, he was also a very serious jock. He listens to trance and techno (though I don't know if he dances), drives a metallic purply-blue, customised 80s Nissan Pulsar, with which he tinkers lovingly in the vast garage of the small rented house (rotary clothesline, rose bushes, a brick barbie and three bedrooms) in the 'burbs of Goulburn, where he lives with Jordan and Felicity - no strumpet, after all, but a bright, self- composed young woman. After leaving school, Jonny went on a bar-tending course and currently works four nights in a nightclub in Goulburn and six shifts a week in a towel-making factory. He wants to learn how to mix a thousand cocktails and then hopefully become a professional mixologist, or manage a bar or restaurant. I have no doubt he will do both. I also think he could model if he wanted to, but when I mentioned the idea to the photographer who took these Beckhamesque portraits of Jonny and Jordan, he said: 'No, you want to keep him away from all that fashion crap. It might ruin him.' In fact, I don't think anything would ruin him, but at the same time I'd be sorry if he slipstreamed into the urban fast lane because he is, indeed, pretty much perfect as he is: a man amongst boys - sweet, smart, funny, honourable and steadfast. Last November, I finally met my extraordinarily ordinary grown-up baby brother and, though I never thought it possible, I love him even more.  Kathryn Flett travelled to Australia courtesy of The Australian Tourist Commission and Air New Zealand. webTitle: Virtual relationships

fields.headline: Virtual relationships
fields.standfirst: Logging on to love
fields.trailText: Virtual relationships.
fields.body:
I was on a flight to San Francisco writing an outline for a documentary film I was making on chatrooms - software that allows two or more people to have live conversations via the internet. Suddenly, a voice blithely volunteered, 'That's me.' The man in the adjoining seat had obviously been reading the text on my laptop in which I had described the story of a married man in Brighton who was poised to begin an affair with a woman he had met online.

We got talking. He was returning from New York, where he'd been on business and had driven out to New Jersey to meet a woman he had met in a chatroom several months earlier. He had been married for 12 years and had two children, 10 and seven. 'Unless I can get from my marriage what I'm getting from this woman, then I don't think there's any point in going on.'

What struck me most was not the fact of his online affair nor that he and this woman had enjoyed chatroom sex. (Chatroom sex takes place when each partner types descriptions of what they are doing to the other - the textual equivalent of phone sex - which usually ends in what the chatroom community jokingly refers to as 'one-handed typing'.) I had by then talked by phone to dozens of people, single and married, who had met people in chatrooms and carried on relationships involving online sex. What struck me most was that he had described his marriage as 'not unhappy'.

Chatrooms are becoming immensely popular in the UK. A recent survey for a woman's magazine found that one in 10 women who use the net at work form a relationship and have sex with a man they first met online. It's hardly surprising. Chat seduces one, however unsuspectingly, to share one's thoughts immediately with another person. I had experienced this when I first logged on to AOL and started talking with someone called punklove13. (Everyone in chat has a 'handle', or nickname.) I found myself effortlessly sharing intimacies with her even though I later learned that she was nearly 20 years younger than me. According to Sue Thomas, director of the trAce Online Writing Community based at the University of Nottingham Trent, the medium creates, quite literally, a meeting of minds. 'There's a feeling of connectedness online that's not just, "Oh, I'm getting on well with this person." There's a deeper level, a moment of real intensity. I call it a mind meld.'

'Inhibitions tend to slip away online once you're in a chatroom. There's no need to hold anything back,' says Kevin Watson, a married, 43-year-old postal manager with two teenage daughters from Withernsea, outside of Hull. After only a few weeks of chatting, Kevin, who frequents a room called 'Married but Love to Flirt', agreed to share a coffee with a woman from the Midlands. While he insists that it was only a friendship, Kevin was surprised how quickly they connected online. 'It's frightening that somebody can be inside your head, and you allow them to be.' Ella Kik, a 53-year-old retired proofreader from Rotterdam, found herself enmeshed in an affair with a Canadian that shook her solid marriage to the core. 'It's very easy talking online. And then, without trying, a real relationship starts up.' Simon McMullen, a 40-year-old call-centre operator in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire told me: 'Even when it's not overtly sexual or dramatic, there's something so intimate about it that is somehow deeper, richer and more meaningful than any intimacy I've known.'

Simon left his wife a year after going online, although he emphasises that the software only made explicit their incompatibility. But would the marriage have ended if Simon hadn't discovered chatrooms? He thinks so, but I'm less sure. The internet makes available all kinds of things that we might otherwise not be able, or willing, to access. Last month, I ordered an obscure book for my mother over the net. A stockbroker friend now looks at online pornography almost daily, whereas before, he only bought Playboy on occasional business trips. Now relationships, and even a form of sex that practitioners find unusually satisfying, are available online. And because those new to chatrooms assume - falsely - that a relationship over a computer is only 'virtual' (as if sharing one's thoughts and feelings is somehow not 'real'), it is easy to see why so many people are sliding into affairs. But holding the net responsible for marital discord is just the latest in a long tradition of blaming new technologies for social ills. As Simon, who has thought about 'chat' far more than most sociologists, puts it: 'Yes, the internet is a significant factor in contemporary divorce. But chat isn't responsible for my divorce. My wife and I are.'

 Henry Singer's film, sex, lies & cyberspace , will premiere on Channel 4's new channel, E4, at 10pm on 27 January.

webTitle: The cost of... Having your own gym

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: Having your own gym
fields.trailText: Having your own gym
fields.body:
In the film American Beauty, an integral part of Kevin Spacey's reinvention is when he starts working out in his garage. The same is true of millions of us. We all believe we can become better people by working out: more successful, more desirable. I work out therefore I am.

Of course, it never happens, because that would mean going to a gym. And going to a gym means walking into a huge bright room to be deafened by brain-numbing techno and surrounded by mirrors and the sort of shiny, happy people you have spent your life avoiding. The answer is to save £35 per month on gym fees and clear that garage out.

If you're only going to make a token effort, just spend £25 on a pair of dumbbells. Start off gently with 10 repetitions of various curls and presses every other day, adding weight and series of repetitions as you become more toned. After a month you'll either give up or you'll be addicted to the endorphins released in your brain by exercise. If so you'll want to add to your gym. Treadmills are fairly complex pieces of equipment, so expect to pay around £530, while rowing machines (£260) are perfect for recreating those Olympic moments in the privacy of your own home.

You should spend £140 on an adjustable bench if you intend to add to your selection of weights. This will allow you to start bench pressing. It is now only a small step to becoming a proper, hormonally confused bodybuilder. Rather than shell out for illegal steroids though, buy a mouthwatering tub of creatine food supplement. Two months worth is just £45. (Tip: don't forget to exercise on this stuff unless you want to look like a sumo wrestler.) A complete gym system, with pulleys and a 'pec deck', costs at least £439.

Motivational problems may be solved by a personal trainer. Top-notch trainers can charge £60 per hour and will probably have some sort of specialism, such as Tae-Bo or getting-off-with-lonely-celebrities. Of course, you could always prop a couple of mirrors against the wall and turn up the latest Ministry of Sound compilation.

Dumbbells £25
Creatine £45 (two months)
Personal trainer up to £60 per hour
Rowing machine £260
Treadmill £530
Gym system £439
Bench £140

webTitle: Loafer's guide

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Julia Query
fields.trailText: Julia Query.
fields.body:
Query by name and by nature?
Indeed. Ms Query is an American lesbian labour leader with a fondness for the limelight.

Sort of a cross between Ellen de Generes and Karl Marx?
In a sense, but with fewer clothes. Working at the Lusty Lady strip club in San Francisco to fund her comedy career, Julia Query became less than satisfied with her working conditions. The daughter of a feminist doctor who crusades for the health rights of prostitutes, Query and her colleagues set about raising the consciousness of their fellow strippers. They campaigned for sick pay, an end to disciplinary action for 'failure to have fun' and a crackdown on secret videotaping by customers. When management resisted their attempts to organise by firing people, the strippers staged 'No Pink' Day, driving the punters away in droves.

'No Pink' Day?
It's probably best not to think about that.

Oh... Right! But her mum must have been delighted?
Regrettably not. Dr Wallace's first inkling of her daughter's career was at the International Conference on Prostitution where they were both due to speak. Her mother was horrified at Query's collusion in what she saw as the victimisation of women and refused to speak to her. Query's defence and their eventual resolution provide an emotional parallel to the labour struggle that forms the basis of her film, Live Nude Girls, UNITE!

And did they?
The strippers formed the first ever Exotic Dancers Union and embarked on a period of strikes, lockouts and tussles with the Lusty Lady's union-busting lawyers.

But they lived to fight another day?
They did and have the film, T-shirts and website (www.livenudegirlsunite.com) to prove it. Query still strips but has hung up her placard in favour of graduate school and the chance of a film about lesbians trying to get pregnant.

 Live Nude Girls, UNITE! will be shown as part of the Sheffield International Documentary Festival on tour at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 from 25-28 January (020 7928 3232)

webTitle: My money: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown

fields.headline: A nest egg - what's that then?
fields.standfirst: Writer Yasmin Alibhai-Brown talks to Rosalind Golding
fields.trailText: Writer Yasmin Alibhai-Brown talks to Rosalind Golding.
fields.body:
Writer and broadcaster Yasmin Alibhai-Brown does not respect money the way many of her fellow Ugandan Asians do. She believes the rich are still, wrongly, the most valued members of society.

She's even called the media's annual lists of the richest people in Britain 'obscene and an insult to the poor'. Yet people assume that as a Ugandan Asian she must be rich. This irritates her: 'There was no money. Most people who see me now have no idea how difficult it was.'

While now she's a highly successful member of the centre-left intelligentsia, much in demand for her expertise on race and social policy, as a child she struggled in a family which was untypical, and 'very odd'.

Her mother was born in East Africa and her father moved there from India in the Twenties. 'As Asians we were never meant to be poor, but we were greatly impoverished,' she says. 'I didn't even have my own bed until I was a teenager. My mother had to work, which was very unusual, and we were always in debt.'

This happened because Alibhai-Brown's father was not interested in making money. He was a bohemian. 'He would go out to buy cigars and disappear for three years.' Meanwhile her mother would attempt to keep up appearances.

'We couldn't live in the poor housing that Africans lived in,' she explains. 'So my mother became very skilled at keeping debtors at bay. It was so humiliating for her; she was utterly violated.'

Friends helped the family. 'My school cost 10 shillings (50p) a month and friends supported me... Because I was clever, parents were happy if their children had me as a friend, hoping some of it might rub off.'

At, 16 Alibhai-Brown resolved never to depend on anyone else. She earned money teaching while doing her A-levels and then won a scholarship to university.

'It's made me passionate about having my own money,' she says. 'I have been married twice now, so of course I have shared property. But I have never shared a bank account. It's sometimes hard on my husband - for example, if I run out of cash in my handbag, I'll insist on going to the bank instead of borrowing a £20 note from him.'

But she is happy to let her husband, who chairs the consumer panel of the Financial Services Authority, invest her money. 'He does it all,' she says, 'and being a left-of-centre person he makes a lot of ethical investments. He's made all the pension choices because I don't believe in pensions. The idea of nest-eggs is strange to me, because I grew up in a country where life expectancy was short.'

Alibhai-Brown says she doesn't earn a large amount. She still lives in the one-bedroom flat in London which she bought 22 years ago.

'Ugandan Asian friends with their manor houses and seven cars think I'm very stupid not to have used my brain to make money,' she says.

But in this way she seems proud to be like her father, who she now knows came to England each time he disappeared. She understands why: 'I would have loved to live here after the war when there was equal access to health and education. Even when I first came here, there was some discretion about money. Now, the message is, you are what you have.'

Alibhai-Brown says living in a rich country and being privileged makes her feel guilty. I try to give a lot of my time and money. I never forget how it was when I was growing up.'

webTitle: What's the catch?

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Free ISPs.
fields.body:
You may think that because you have signed up to a free internet service provider you are guaranteed free connection at all times. But you could end up paying through the nose for certain sites even if your provider does not charge.

The sites in question, called premium rate services, require you to disconnect from your ISP and connect to a number with premium rate charges. The practice is used by some sports results sites, weather pages and sites with sexually explicit material.

Premium rate services, which can be identified by their 090 dialling codes, vary in cost from 10p per call to £1.50 per minute. Around 320 million telephone and internet calls are made to such services each year.

So how can you you avoid these expensive sites? The telephone services watchdog, Icstis, has brought in measures to alert you when you switch to a premium-rate service. It requires such sites to display terms and conditions and clear, prominent cost information both before and during connection.

Access to sites should stop automatically if the total cost of connection reaches £20. Icstis has free leaflet, 'Premium Rate Services on the Internet: A Guide for Consumers'. Copies are available from Icstis, Alton House, 177 High Holborn, London WC1V 7AA.

webTitle: Lump-sum investment: Buy and then let the profits roll in

fields.headline: Buy and then let the profits roll in
fields.standfirst: Rental property is still a money spinner in the long run, Graham Norwood reports
fields.trailText: Rental property is still a money spinner in the long run, Graham Norwood reports.
fields.body:
Buy to let property investment is no longer the licence to print money that many believed it to be in the late-1990s but it can still create a modest rental income and some spectacular capital gains.

There is no data about buy-to-let investment performance produced by Arla, (Association of Residential Letting Agents) because it did not need to work hard to persuade buyers between 1995 and 1999. Membership exploded as some £4bn was lent in buy-to-let mortgages to around 30,000 people during the period. Many long-term property investors bought to let without mortgages, expanding the supply to saturation in a few places.

Knight Frank and the University of York have produced statistics showing the residential market to have performed better than the FTSE All-Share Index when property appreciation is taken into account.

But if rental income alone was matched against the performance of equities the FTSE would have come out on top in four of the past five years, demonstrating how big a role property appreciation plays in making the lettings market an attractive option.

Arla is still bullishly saying all buy-to-let is likely to be profitable, but more level-headed advisers say you have to choose your market.

Rupert Smith is director of Investment Concepts, a Home Counties firm that specialises in buy-to-let.

'If you want a return in three or four years, go elsewhere,' he says. 'But if you're looking for rental income to cover your mortgage and provide a small profit, plus a probable significant capital uplift over five, 10 or 15 years, then buy-to-let is a sound investment.'

He adds: 'In the SouthWest or the north of England you could get high rental returns on a low initial outlay because property is relatively inexpensive, but then you wouldn't maximise your capital uplift on re-sale. In the South-East you would need at least £100,000 to get a reasonable property, and you might have difficulty in ensuring the rent covers the running costs. But you'd make a lot on re-sale.'

Smith insists potential investors have to be realistic about the rental yield. 'Some people claim 10 per cent or 12 per cent yield, but it's never that great. When you deduct management fees, insurances, ground rent, utility and safety cover, and then factor in at least some weeks void each year, the figure comes to between 4 per cent and 7 per cent. But that is still a profit and always remember the capital appreciation over that time.'

Trevor Abbott, who runs a photographic business in London, used to rent out a holiday cottage in Dorset but was disappointed by the poor yield. So he sold it and bought four flats and a maisonette over 12 months around Weybridge in Surrey.

'I've got interest-only buy-to-let mortgages on each of them, partly because they can be offset against tax and partly because interest-only means I have to make only modest repayments, which can be covered easily even if the rental market gets tougher in future,' he says.

So far his investment has paid off. The properties' combined capital value has increased around 25 per cent since the first one was purchased in spring 1999. Tenant-vetting, rent collection and routine maintenance of the properties are all left to a management agency, whose costs are tax-deductible.

University cities like Exeter, too, have become buy-to-let havens, with brisk demand from students.

'In the first half of 2000 investment property prices shot up,' says Robert Williams, an Exeter estate agent and surveyor.

'Investment property prices rose 20 per cent compared to the rest of the housing market, rising between 10 per cent and 15 per cent, and something like that figure is certainly sustainable for the year to come,' he predicts.
