webTitle: Lump-sum investment: Happy returns are a matter of trust

fields.headline: Happy returns are a matter of trust
fields.standfirst: Lisa Bachelor asks the experts to tip their favourite funds
fields.trailText: Lisa Bachelor asks the experts to tip their favourite funds.
fields.body:
If you're fortunate enough to have a lump sum, the only real hurdle is finding a good home for it. But with 1,898 unit trusts and 368 investment trusts, the decision can be tricky.

It will be made easier, however, if you narrow the choice according to the amount of risk you want to take and decide whether there are specific areas you wish to invest in - or avoid. However, if you're totally in the dark, it's a good idea to consult the professionals.

'I think the crystal ball is particularly cloudy this year given the possibility of a US recession,' says Mark Dampier of Hargreaves Lansdown. 'I think it will be extremely important to choose good-quality stock-pickers which aren't totally obsessed with a financial benchmark.' One of Dampier's top tips is investment trust Aurora, which he describes as a 'little known fund with a tremendous record'. On the unit trust side he opts for Matrix Quantock UK Growth, one of the top funds in the UK All Companies sector. 'The portfolio has a mix of blue-chips, mid caps and smaller companies,' says Dampier.

Bruce Jamieson, of Jamieson Financial Management, favours ABN AMRO Equity Income unit trust. 'This is very consistent and a medium-risk which could be a good complement for those who already have trackers,' he says.

Despite recent falls in many technology stocks, some advisers are still bullish about tech-focused funds. 'For people who are willing to take a higher risk than usual, Aberdeen Technology would be my tip,' says Colin Jackson, IFA with Baronworth Investments. He believes that in the medium- to long-term technology funds will produce excellent returns.

Artemis New Enterprises is also technology focused but in the UK All Companies sector, and is rated by Whitechurch Investment's Warren Perry. 'This fund was only launched in May 2000 and has grown by 29 per cent in a difficult period,' he says, warning that it is probably best suited to the more adventurous investor.

If you do fall into this category but don't feel confident about technology, Jamieson sees the Framlington Health unit trust as an excellent alternative. This fund has produced returns of nearly 400 per cent over five years and nearly 300 per cent over one year.

For those who want slightly less risk and a basic exposure to international equity markets, Julian Crooks of The Financial Planning Service in Sheffield tips investment trust Witan. This is one of the largest and oldest trusts, managed by Henderson Global Investors. 'It has provided solid, steady returns,' says Crooks.

Take control

If you're confident enough to make your own investment decisions, it is increasingly easy to save money when you buy funds. One way is by using a fund supermarket.

There are five main UK players - Interalliance, Egg, FundsNow, FundsNetwork and Virgin Money. Fund supermarkets allow you to mix and match funds from a variety of managers in one Isa.

The biggest site, Interalliance, offers a choice of 700. And charges are low: many impose no initial charges on certain funds.

Discount brokers have been the traditional route for investors making their own decisions. Because they don't offer advice, they don't charge commission if you buy through them.

Many discount brokers have teamed up with the fund supermarkets to offer more choice and, in many cases, online buying.

webTitle: Lump-sum investment: Is their word their bond for returns?

fields.headline: Is their word their bond for returns?
fields.standfirst: A mix of risks is safer but watch that tax bill, says David Hunt
fields.trailText: A mix of risks is safer but watch that tax bill, says David Hunt.
fields.body:
Investors who want higher returns than building societies pay but without the risk of investing in the stock market may find lump sum with-profits bonds a popular choice. A phenomenal £20 billion-plus has gone into them in the past two years.

But with insurance company bonus rates on the decline and the problems of Equitable Life in the news, are the bonds as safe and attractive as people thought?

Offered by leading life insurance companies, with-profits bonds are lump-sum investments - usually a minimum of around £5,000 - which go into a mixture of equities, fixed-interest investments, property and cash.

Like the regular premium version, returns are paid as annual bonuses and a terminal bonus on encashment or death.

Payouts are smoothed out, so that some of the profits from good years are held over to boost returns when conditions are less buoyant. Once a bonus is added, it cannot be taken away.

All proceeds have basic-rate tax deducted at source, so this is not an investment for non-taxpayers, but the bonds are attractive to people in, or coming up to, retirement because of their income flexibility. Basic-rate taxpayers can withdraw up to 5 per cent a year from the bond, with no further tax to pay. Higher-rate tax payers withdrawing 5 per cent a year can defer any liability until all the bond is withdrawn. By then, they may have become basic-rate tax payers and have no further liability.

Withdrawals above 5 per cent can again be taken with no tax implications for those on the basic rate, although higher-rate payers would have to pay the equivalent to the difference between higher and basic rate in the year following the withdrawal.

Any withdrawals exceeding the level of the annual bonus, however, could erode the capital. Those not needing an immediate income can simply let the returns accumulate.

Quoted returns range from around 4.5 per cent to 8.5 per cent or more.

But the headline rate can be misleading. A lower rate may represent only the current annual bonus; whereas a higher one could include elements of terminal as well. Also, some firms have a history of paying larger annual bonuses and smaller terminal ones, while with others the reverse is true.

Past performance needs to be considered but, with Equitable Life in mind, investors need to consider the financial strength of the provider and its charges.

There are many variations in fees. If the charges on one bond looks much lower than on others, it's probably because the provider is making up for them elsewhere, through lower allocation rates (the amount of your money that is actually invested) or early surrender penalties. Investors should check out discount brokers. These do not offer advice (although several publish free guides to with-profits bonds) but they do rebate a large part of the initial charge.

With-profits bond investors should have at least a five-year term in mind. Some bonds will actually penalise you if you take your money out earlier.

In some instances, usually in the early stages of a contract and when stock market conditions have been poor, companies may apply what is called a Market Value Adjuster (MVA), which allows them to pay less than the bonus rate announced. This is not usually applied to withdrawals due to death or if investors regularly take out sums below 7.5 per cent a year.

So are with-profits bonds still a good investment? Stephen Aaron of the David Aaron Partnership of independent financial adviser thinks so: 'Returns have fallen, but by much less than with traditional investments.'

'In most cases the real returns after inflation are considerably higher than five years ago.'

Patrick Connolly of IFA Chartwells is also a fan. 'Perhaps there is rather more emphasis on terminal bonuses nowadays, making them a shade more risky, but overall, returns have held up very well and, in a number of cases, have improved.'

The first choice for both Connolly and Aaron is the Prudential with-profits bond. 'Company strength is the main factor, followed by factors such as past performance and charges,' says Connolly.

Aaron, with half an eye on a possible demutualisation windfall, also likes the bonds from Liverpool Victoria and Standard Life, while Connolly opts for Norwich Union, Scottish Mutual and Clerical Medical.

 Guides to with-profits bonds are available from Chartwell (01225 321710, free of charge), and for £1 from the David Aaron Partnership, Shelton House, High Street, Woburn Sands, MK17 8SD.

webTitle: Lump-sum investment:

fields.headline: Something ventured, for risky gains
fields.standfirst: VCTs offer generous tax breaks for wise investors, says David Budworth
fields.trailText: VCTs offer generous tax breaks for wise investors, says David Budworth.
fields.body:
This year looks set to be a boom one for venture capitalists. A record number of venture capital trusts, which invest in unlisted firms and companies on the Alternative Investment Market are being launched to meet growing demand. At least £500m is expected to be invested by the start of April - almost double that raised in the previous tax year.

High-rolling entrepreneurs who are selling a stake in their business; beneficiaries of company share schemes and ordinary investors with a lump sum to put away, are all attracted to the VCT's raft of tax perks.

The most useful is the ability to defer capital gains tax. Investors can escape up to 40 per cent CGT by sheltering gains made within the previous 12 months in a VCT. The tax does not have to be paid until the shares are sold - by which time, with careful management, the bill can be reduced.

If you buy new VCT shares you also get income tax relief at 20 per cent. This means that if you invest £10,000 in new issues, you get a £2,000 tax rebate. Share dividends also avoid income tax, and you do not pay tax on any gains made in the trust.

But to qualify for the full tax breaks, the shares must be held for at least three years if bought after 6 April 2000, and five years if bought earlier.

The Government is keen for investors to pump money into companies when they are small and strapped for cash. Investing in unquoted companies is risky - many small businesses don't succeed - so the Government offers these tax breaks as carrots.

Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of London independent financial adviser Bestinvest, says: 'On top of the tax benefits, there is the fact that VCTs are diversified funds. Most invest in 12 to 15 companies. Provided the venture capital portfolio is adequately diversified, it is difficult to see that VCTs should be regarded as high risk investments.'

VCTs don't have to be fully invested from day one. VCT managers have three years to invest at least 70 per cent of their portfolio in unquoted firms. In the meantime, most of the funds go into low-risk investments such as cash and bonds. Even after three years most VCTs hold 80 per cent in unquoted firms and 20 per cent in fixed interest to reduce risk.

Hollands says: 'VCTs are no higher risk than a smaller companies unit trust. Around 25 per cent of an investment portfolio should be in smaller companies, and VCTs should be counted as part of the smaller-company exposure.'

But Martin Churchill, research director at VCT specialist publication Tax Shelter Report, says VCTs are not for the novice: 'You should have major exposure to other equities before you consider investing in a VCT.'

Investors should always look at the sectors and companies a VCT invests in to see if it fits in with their existing portfolio. There are three basic types: generalist funds invest across a number of industry sectors; Aim-based funds invest in Aim stocks and technology funds invest mainly in unquoted technology companies.

VCTs with a technology element have performed well in the past, while Aim funds have done better than generalist funds, but, Churchill expects generalists to stage a comeback. VCTs are open for a couple of months at most, and issues are on a first-come, first served basis.

For VCTs currently on offer call Allenbridge Group on 0800 339 999. Bestinvest is on 0800 0370 400.

webTitle: Lump-sum investment: Beat the shares gloom

fields.headline: Beat the shares gloom
fields.standfirst: In the first of a special feature, Helen Pridham reports on the best time to buy
fields.trailText: In the first of a special feature, Helen Pridham reports on the best time to buy.
fields.body:
If you have capital to invest now, you face a dilemna. Most UK and overseas shares fell in value last year. The FTSE 100 Index, which measures the share price movements of the UK's 100 largest companies, ended the year lower than it had started for only the third time since it was set up in 1983. So far there is little sign of recovery.

This could be the perfect time to invest because you will get the full benefit of any rise in the stock market when it comes. But it may seem safer to wait until things have settled down.

Alternatively, there is a 'third way'. You could invest your money in stages so that if share prices do decline further you will lose less and get better value by buying some shares cheaper.

This approach would certainly have helped investors last year. Someone who invested £1,000 in an FTSE All-Share Tracker fund on 1January 1999 would have lost 6.6 per cent by the year end. If the same amount had been invested in monthly instalments, the fall in value would have only been 1.5 per cent.

However, many investment professionals advocate investing straight away. Jason Hollands of independent investment adviser Bestinvest says: 'Many investors have been thinking about defensive investments. But we think the doom and gloom has been overdone and the markets are near the bottom. Now is the time for investors to be bold.'

Past experience favours this approach. Figures from Virgin Direct show that following the last two stock market downturns, in 1990 and 1994, shares climbed by more than 25 per cent a year for the next three years on both occasions.

Virgin Direct's Andrew Stronach says: 'Our view is that if you have a lump sum to invest, then do so as soon as you can. We all know that buy low and sell high is the name of the game but judging the right time to invest is all but impossible. We believe it is time rather than timing that counts.'

Research by Fidelity, the UK's largest fund manager, found that stock market returns tend to be concentrated in a relatively few trading days each year and that some of the strongest rises come immediately after sharp decline. If you are not invested during these upswings, you lose out.

The Fidelity figures, based on movements in the FTSE All Share Index over the last 13 years, show that missing the best 40 days over this period would reduce investors' average total returns from 14.4 per cent a year, if they had been fully invested to 5.6 per cent. Similar results applied in other international stock markets such as the US and Germany.

Fidelity admits that if you can be out of the market on the worst days, though, your returns will be even better.

However, switching your investments in and out of the market requires more time and effort than most people have, and there is always the risk that you will miss the best days.
So Fidelity also examined the effect of when an investment was made. For this study it went back 30 years and tracked the results of three identical investments made at the same time each year - at the high point in the market, the low point and on 1 January. It found that while there was a difference in returns - investing at the low points achieved returns of 17.2 per cent a year, against only 15.2 per cent if investment took place at the high point - it was not as much as one might expect.

Naturally, history does not necessarily repeat itself. Tony Dolphin, director of global economics at Henderson Investors, says that although the odds are on markets rising over the coming year, there are also complications.

He explains: 'There has only been one period in the last 55 years when the main US stock market index, the Standard & Poor's 500, has gone down for two years running and that was in 1973 and 1974. Circumstances are different today.

'Moreover, markets usually pick up when interest rates are being cut which is what is happening in the United States. However, the fact that the technology bubble is still bursting could continue to be a dampener for the first half of this year. Markets are also more concerned about earnings than in the past, and the earnings outlook for the next three to six months is negative.

'So the next few months will be difficult ones for equity markets and if the US economy does go into a recession there is a danger of another negative year.'

One way of hedging your bets is to spread your investment over several months. Most unit and investment trust companies will accept regular savings. If you want to invest all your Isa allowance before April, Henderson and Fidelity will do the job for you. They take your full investment, place it in an interest-bearing cash account in an Isa and gradually move it into the funds of your choice.

webTitle: Alternative Investments: Ephemera

fields.headline: Tickets to history
fields.standfirst: Old scraps of paper tell stories of the hats and the hangings which make up the minutiae of everyday life, says John Windsor, and they could be making money for you
fields.trailText: Old scraps of paper tell stories of the hats and the hangings which make up the minutiae of everyday life, says John Windsor, and they could be making money for you
fields.body:
I left my first meeting with Maurice Rickards, founder of the Ephemera Society, with a copy of a letter in his collection, shakily handwritten on 11 May 1752 by a distressed maidservant.

'My lady, I am very sorry for ye disapontement [sic] but I think every servant goes in danger of their life,' it begins. 'I am determined never to see my l[or]d no more _ I cannot stay longer than the latter end of the week for fear of his return. I am your ladyships duttyful ser[van]t, [signed] Eliz Metcalfe.'

'This', explained Rickards, a scholarly man with a twinkle in his eye, 'is ephemera - the minor, transient documents of everyday life'.

His definition has stuck. But to him, Elizabeth Metcalfe's despair was neither minor nor transient. Although we shall never know whether she had committed theft or was the victim of her lord's dalliance, her tremor, as I held her letter, seemed as palpable as it must have been in 1752.

Rickards, an ex-graphic designer and photographer, had paid £4 for it at an Ephemera Society fair. 'However mercurial a scrap like this,' he told me, 'I would feel ashamed to destroy it. I would feel almost that I had killed a person. I know it's a flight of fancy, but I mean it.'

When we met in 1989 , he had been compiling an encyclopedia of ephemera for 12 years. He died in 1998, his life's work still incomplete. Now, however, his Encyclopedia of Ephemera has been published by the British Library, having been edited and completed by Professor Michael Twyman, director of the Centre for Ephemera Studies at Reading University. In it, under 'Handwritten Ephemera', one of 500 headings in the 402-page book, is Elizabeth's letter.

Such comprehensive, first-ever guides - the encyclopedia is one of three recently published and reviewed here - are a boon to collectors. Whether about antique fishing tackle, twentieth-century factory ceramics, jigsaw puzzles or slot machines, they identify, discriminate and categorise, often creating a buoyant market for collectors.

The encyclopedia wisely makes no attempt to assess prices - among collectors, a printed Victorian charity ticket for a bag of coals might change hands for £3, an exquisitely engraved seventeenth-century trade card for £4,000, while every transaction in manuscript ephemera is unique. But it does give context and status to those scraps, elevating them into primary historical sources that convey a flavour of the times that dry statistics cannot match.

Historians Lord Briggs and Eric Hobsbawm make full use of ephemera to illustrate social history in their books. Such was Rickards' aim, too.

Those charity tickets for coal, soup, meat or bread, for example, (the encyclopedia illustrates a coal ticket), would be called vouchers today. They tell us that Victorian charities did not trust the poor to spend money wisely, or were at pains to avoid unseemly scrambles for food and fuel. Although the approved supplier of the charity goods and an expiry date were printed on the ticket, the name of the ticket holder was not inscribed, so they were transferable.

Judging also by the dirty, scuffed and limp condition of the Victorian coal ticket in my collection, such items circulated in exchange for money among the poor, no doubt at a discount, or as an alternative currency. So the charity bigwigs avoided soiling their hands, and the less deserving poor got their beer. At the end of the line, someone got some coal. One grubby little scrap of ephemera can tell a lot.

Under dietary tables, the encyclopedia reveals a recipe for gruel - that Dickensian and much-hated institutional stomach-filler. Everybody has heard of gruel. But what exactly was it? According to the dietary tables of Derby County Jail of 1844, prison gruel consisted of oatmeal and water, sweetened on alternate days with molasses or sugar, and seasoned with salt. Ugh!

The minutiae of everyday life, as revealed by the encyclopedia, make it not just a reference book but a fascinating read.

In the period 1870 to 1914, your draper or haberdasher might claim he was short of farthings for change and try to palm you off with a packet of pins marked 'farthing change with thanks' (the origin of 'pin money'?) or a 'farthing novelette'- eight pages of smudgily printed tales of the upper classes. Both pins and novelettes, bought in bulk, yielded him a profit of 6d (two and a half pence) per gross.

There are throwaways such as Tyburn tickets - to watch hangings - inn tallies, waybills, notices to quit, dance tokens, visiting cards, winkle bags, tangerine wrappers, club flyers and disinfected mail, as well as passports, fez labels, receipts for taxes on hats and dice, and ephemera intended to be collected such as cigarette cards, the first of this kind. Then there are affidavits for burial of the dead in wool - enforceable by law from 1667 until 1815.

The book leaves a mystery unresolved. In 1820, according to its accounts, a Liverpool workhouse received £149. 6. 9. (£149.33)for 'urine collected in the house'. Who might have bought it? Farmers? Tanners? Answers on a postcard, please.

Leslie Lewis Allen's book, The World's Show , is about commemorative items, such as medals struck in celebration of the Crystal Palace and events that took place in it. You can still buy examples in street markets for under £10, but this is the first book to catalogue them. It contains more than 500 and promises good hunting.

Allen, a retired accountant, began his own collection when he was given a Coronation Medal worn by a friend who had been one of 100,000 children who greeted the newly crowned King George V and Queen Mary at the coronation f te at the south London palace in 1911. That number is a clue to the enormous scale of the building and grounds, originally built in Hyde Park in 1851 to house the Great Exhibition, but moved to Sydenham, where it was burnt down in 1936.

Joseph Paxton's soaring, barrel-vaulted design of iron and glass, jotted down in minutes and built in weeks after the rejection of a committee's design for what looked like a brick lavatory, was arguably Britain's most sublime building.

It still stirs collectors' hearts, especially when contrasted with the Dome, which achieved 6.5 million visitors in a year, compared with the Great Exhibition's 6 million in six months - in a country that then had little more than 20 million people. The Great Exhibition made a profit of £186,000 - equivalent to £50m today.

Among the Crystal Palace medals are some worn by children taking part in the annual national school orchestra competition. Lewis values participants' medals, showing a somewhat camp semi-draped Apollo with violin, at a mere £8. The top price quoted is £2,000 for a presentation set of five Great Exhibition Council bronze medals.

What building could house such a competition today? And what of the brass bands, gymnasts and the exhibitions of cats, canaries, rabbits, poultry, honey bees, all of whose medals are catalogued in the book? Crystal Palace gave them status.

It is as though everyman's age of achievement was incinerated when it burned down. This book will make them more collectible.

Lastly, we go upmarket, to Simon Khachadourian, of the Pullman Gallery in London, who has published a guide to his collection of 1,000 vintage cocktail shakers, all for sale at between £750 and £20,000.

The book, The Cocktail Shaker, is a genuine first, charting the development of these adult toys - in the shape of penguins, lighthouses, dumb bells or fire extinguishers - which were the playthings of the flappers and swells of the Twenties and Thirties. Today, newly rich young things with an eye for kitsch are ordering Screwdrivers and Moscow Mules in hotel bars and keeping an eye on markets and silver shops for classically designed shakers that could be worth thousands. This guide will enable you to do the same.

'The Encyclopedia of Ephemera', price £35 (plus £1.50 p&p) is available from British Library Bookshop, 96 Euston Road, London NW1 2DB (tel: 0207-412 7332).

'The World's Show: Coincraft's Catalogue of Crystal Palace Medals and Tokens, 1851-1936' is priced at £29.50 (plus £4.50 p&p) from Coincraft, 44-45 Great Russell Street, London WC1B 3LU (0207-636 1188).

'The Cocktail Shaker' is published by Philip Wilson at £29.95 (plus £7 p&p), from the Pullman Gallery, 14 King Street, London SW1Y 6QU (0207-930 9595).

webTitle: Money writes: Widows gave  my personal details to a stranger

fields.headline: Widows gave  my personal details to a stranger
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I have paid into a Scottish Widows pension scheme for years but received no communication about the company's demutualisation. On complaining, I discovered that my letter had been sent to an address in the North East where I have never lived.

I confirmed to Scottish Widows in writing that I wanted a loan note, but after demutualisation I received a cheque. I have not cashed it as I would incur a large capital gains tax bill.

I have written to head office six times since and received only one acknowledgement. However I have had a phone call from someone with a non-qualifying Scottish Widows pension, living in the North East with a similar name to mine. He received my initial communication and, when he telephoned, Scottish Widows gave him my name, locality and precise value of the payout.

How can I get Scottish Widows to respond?
BQ, Altrincham

Scottish Widows is in a dreadful mess with compensation payments following the merger with LloydsTSB. Many readers have contacted Money Writes about its mistakes and missing money.

Although the cut-off date for requesting loan notes was final, the Inland Revenue is allowing Scottish Widows to backdate notes where it sent out cheques by mistake. If you return the cheque, the insurer will, in the next few weeks, send you loan notes. Regardless of when these arrive, you will earn interest from 23 August.

Scottish Widows is quite rightly horrified that it breached the Data Protection Act by disclosing your confidential information to someone else. The department involved is in trouble.

As compensation for these problems, Scottish Widows is sending an additional cheque for £100.

TV licence offer: Blank screen

I have received a fax offering free TV licences for six years to the first 250,000 coupons returned. It then talks about a coupon/application form, but does not say what for. Do you know anything about this?
AL, Lapworth

This outfit, called the Free TV licence initiative, is a mystery.

TV Licensing, the official body, says it does not issue blank licences. It is not possible to buy them in bulk and give them away as prizes, as they are not transferable, apart from in the exceptional circumstance that a husband or wife dies with the licence in their name.

TV Licensing had already been alerted to this offer and tried contacting the people who sent the fax, but without success. There is no address or telephone number on the advert and no one responded to its faxed letter.

The fax number is a national BT rate call, so does not come within premium-rate rules. TV Licensing is interested in hearing from other readers who may have received this fax. Its helpline is 08705 763763.

Endowments: Standard strife

I took out two Standard Life endowment policies in the Eighties with my Leeds Permanent mortgage. The problem is that the policies mature in 2007, a year after my mortgage is due to end.

The Halifax [which now owns Leeds] said a firm called Advizas arranged the policies and it acted on their instructions. I wrote to Advizas but the letter came back marked, 'gone away'. Standard Life takes no responsibility.

I will have to pay another year's mortgage interest while I wait for the policies to mature.
PH, Felixstowe

Even though your annual mortgage statement says: 'The remaining term outstanding on your original loan as at October 2000 is five years 10 months,' Halifax insists the endowment loan is repayable only when the policies mature in 2007.

The element repayable earlier is the additional loan you took in 1995. You are adamant that you asked for this to coincide with the rest of your mortgage, but the Halifax application form shows an 11-year loan to 2006. You are repaying capital and interest as you go, so the loan is automatically cleared on the last day.

It is costing you more each month than a 12-year loan, but overall it is cheaper because you pay one year's less interest.

Advizas is now owned by Towry Law, which is still earning renewal commission from Standard Life on your endowments but, despite searching its entire database, has not been able to locate your file.

They are still looking.

Tessa trouble: Hassle at Halifax

Our Halifax Tessa accounts matured on 5 January and the next day we visited our local branch to collect the proceeds and open a Tessa Isa with another provider.

We were told that we had to wait until maturity certificates had been issued through the post. We are still waiting.
DF, Cheltenham

Manual maturity certificates are available on the spot, and the cashier who told you otherwise has been put right. Because the staff did not follow procedures, Halifax has agreed to pay the interest you would have earned if you had been able to reinvest the money immediately.

Let Halifax know where you are putting the money and it will reimburse the interest from 6 January to the date of investment.

Writeback: Ice axe man cometh to grief

There was bad news for the reader who was charged Customs duty on his own ice axe, bought in the UK.

Chris Dawes had been hiking 2,600 miles along the Pacific Crest Trail from Mexico to Canada. In Sierra City, California, he posted his ice axe home to Telford to avoid carrying it any further. Parcel Force demanded £22 duty and, when Chris refused to pay, it took away the axe. He tried phoning Customs & Excise to explain but found the number constantly engaged. Chris was charged because he had written the original purchase price $80 (£54) on the Customs declaration slip. Customs & Excise has now discovered that, while Chris was constantly dialling, its Coventry office returned the package 'to sender'.

Officials assume it is now lost but, admitting their phone lines were continuously busy before Christmas, have agreed to refund the $80. Chris has asked the postal officer in Sierra City to post back the axe.

If it arrives, he will auction it for Harvest Help, a charity that supports rural communities in Zambia, for which he was raising money by walking in North America.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose self-addressed envelopes or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

The Halifax [which now owns Leeds] said a firm called Advizas arranged the policies and it acted on their instructions. I wrote to Advizas but the letter came back marked, 'gone away'. Standard Life takes no responsibility. I will have to pay another year's mortgage interest while I wait for the policies to mature. PH, Felixstowe Even though your annual mortgage statement says: 'The remaining term outstanding on your original loan as at October 2000 is five years 10 months,' Halifax insists the endowment loan is repayable only when the policies mature in 2007. The element repayable earlier is the additional loan you took in 1995. You are adamant that you asked for this to coincide with the rest of your mortgage, but the Halifax application form shows an 11-year loan to 2006. You are repaying capital and interest as you go, so the loan is automatically cleared on the last day. It is costing you more each month than a 12-year loan, but overall it is cheaper because you pay one year's less interest. Advizas is now owned by Towry Law, which is still earning renewal commission from Standard Life on your endowments but, despite searching its entire database, has not been able to locate your file. They are still looking. Tessa trouble: Hassle at Halifax Our Halifax Tessa accounts matured on 5 January and the next day we visited our local branch to collect the proceeds and open a Tessa Isa with another provider. We were told that we had to wait until maturity certificates had been issued through the post. We are still waiting. DF, Cheltenham Manual maturity certificates are available on the spot, and the cashier who told you otherwise has been put right. Because the staff did not follow procedures, Halifax has agreed to pay the interest you would have earned if you had been able to reinvest the money immediately. Let Halifax know where you are putting the money and it will reimburse the interest from 6 January to the date of investment. Writeback: Ice axe man cometh to grief There was bad news for the reader who was charged Customs duty on his own ice axe, bought in the UK. Chris Dawes had been hiking 2,600 miles along the Pacific Crest Trail from Mexico to Canada. In Sierra City, California, he posted his ice axe home to Telford to avoid carrying it any further. Parcel Force demanded £22 duty and, when Chris refused to pay, it took away the axe. He tried phoning Customs & Excise to explain but found the number constantly engaged. Chris was charged because he had written the original purchase price $80 (£54) on the Customs declaration slip. Customs & Excise has now discovered that, while Chris was constantly dialling, its Coventry office returned the package 'to sender'. Officials assume it is now lost but, admitting their phone lines were continuously busy before Christmas, have agreed to refund the $80. Chris has asked the postal officer in Sierra City to post back the axe. If it arrives, he will auction it for Harvest Help, a charity that supports rural communities in Zambia, for which he was raising money by walking in North America.  Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose self-addressed envelopes or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Britannic Retirement Solutions With-Profits Annuity
fields.trailText: Britannic Retirement Solutions With-Profits Annuity.
fields.body:
Contact Available through independent financial advisers

Aim To give pensioners potentially higher future income by equity investment, using the with-profits process to smooth out the peaks and troughs of the stock market.

Bells & whistles Uses the Britannic Assurance With Profits Fund, 'one of the top performing funds over recent years'. The insurer will tell clients exactly how the with-profits fund has performed each year, and how much it intends to hold over or pay out to smooth that year's returns. It also guarantees not to reduce bonuses if policyholders live longer than expected.

How it works On reaching retirement age, you use the money in your pension fund to buy an Britannic annuity policy. This will provide a variable income for the rest of your life by investing in equities, property, fixed-interest and other investments. Britannic will try to offset stock market fluctuations by 'smoothing' - holding back some of the profits from good years to boost returns in poorer years. Your income is drawn partly from your original capital, partly from profits. This income can fall as well as rise.

Minimum £10,000

Charges No initial charge; annual charges guaranteed to be less than 1 per cent a year throughout the policyholder's life.

Tax Income is liable to tax at the policyholder's top rate.

Risk Low/medium

Should you invest? Stuart Bayliss of specialist annuity adviser Annuity Direct says: 'It's a good product and answers some of the questions on the opacity of with-profits annuities, but it will require a lot of explanation by the adviser.'

Nick Bamford of Cranleigh adviser Informed Choice says the product could appeal to people disappointed with conventional annuities: 'The performance of Britannic's with profits fund has been fine, and the level of risk is not as substantial as a unit-linked annuity or income drawdown.'

Points out of 10 Bayliss - 7.5, Bamford - 6.

webTitle: Pensions: Investors get fairer deal on drawdowns

fields.headline: Investors get fairer deal on drawdowns
fields.standfirst: Regulators want to avoid another mis-selling drama, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Regulators want to avoid another mis-selling drama, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
New rules designed to make income drawdown pension plans less restrictive are about to come in. From the end of January, plan holders will be free to switch to another provider if they are unhappy with the performance or administration of their own.

The news comes as the Financial Services Authority, the City's watchdog, reveals that it is still concerned that income drawdown plans are being mis-sold. It will be policing firms again to ensure they are not slipping up.

Income drawdown plans were introduced a few years ago as an alternative to buying an annuity on retirement. They enable retired people to keep their pension pot invested and draw an income from it until they are 75, when it becomes compulsory to buy an annuity.

The idea is that the pot will continue to grow through wise investment even after the income has been taken out, enabling the planholder to buy a bigger annuity when he or she reaches 75. Under current drawdown rules, people cannot move from one provider to another.

News of the change to the law will be of particular interest to Equitable Life members with income drawdown plans, who until now have not been able to switch to another company.

There are also a lot of investors who may want to move funds, not necessarily because they are poorly performing, but because they are the 'wrong' type of fund.

Many people may have been overly cautious with their income drawdown pot, choosing to invest in cash and gilt funds rather than equity-backed ones, which have the prospect of higher growth and income.

You can check how your drawdown plan is doing by looking at the 'critical yield' - an estimate of the investment return required to maintain the income stream. A yield of 6 or 7 per cent is fine but a figure of 10 per cent could mean you are taking undue risk.

Relaxation of the income drawdown rules means that investors should take even greater notice of the charges their financial adviser takes, often up to 6 per cent of the value of the fund.

The danger is that the opportunity to switch providers will allow some unscrupulous financial adviser to transfer your plan unnecessarily, something advisers have been accused of doing with investments such as unit trusts, purely to line their own pockets. Make sure you establish what is in it for you if you transfer to a new provider.

The FSA has had its eye on income drawdown for some time now due to the product's high-risk nature. The regulator conducted a series of visits to firms selling the pension product to check that record-keeping was in order and clients were being made aware of the risk.

The risk arises for two reasons - possible changes in the marketplace and the equity-based nature of some plans. Postponing the purchase of an annuity may mean that you forgo present annuity rates for future ones that are even lower.

Equity-based plans, which can offer higher returns, are risky because they also expose the pension fund to dips in the stock market.

Despite its visits over the last couple of years, the FSA is still not satisfied that drawdown customers are getting a fair deal.

It has decided to do some 'follow-up work' in this area, although the exact form this work will take is not yet clear. It says firms may be subjected to triannual visits to see that they are toeing the line.

So would you be better off getting an annuity when you first retire? The drawdown option is still attractive when viewed against annuity rates, which have hit a 30-year low, although advisers specialis ing in income drawdown suggest the risks are too great for people with funds of less than £250,000.

Provided that your fund is big enough and you do not need all the income an annuity provides, there are some good reasons to choose income drawdown:

 Your pension fund continues to grow, so you have more with which to buy an annuity eventually;

 The older you are when you buy an annuity, the better rate you get;

 Your beneficiaries can inherit your fund. (Once you buy an annuity, the insurer keeps your capital.)

It is important to remember that if you do go for an income drawdown plan, stay with it as long as possible, so so your investments have time to grow and counterbalance the outgoings.

Also, ensure you are not withdrawing so much that it eats into your capital and that you have enough capital to afford the risk, otherwise you will end up with less for the eventual annuity.

The Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau, a London-based independent financial adviser, recommends the income drawdown products of Eagle Star and Scottish Equitable due to the performance of their funds and competitive charging structures.

 The IFA produces a free leaflet and can be contacted on 020 7401 2040.

webTitle: Occupational schemes: Cap'n Bob, pension protector

fields.headline: Cap'n Bob, pension protector
fields.standfirst: Maxwell's plunder led to safer funds, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Maxwell's plunder led to safer funds, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
It is nearly 10 years since Robert Maxwell fell off his yacht and plunged the pensions industry into crisis.

It emerged that the Mirror Group tycoon had been plundering his staff pension funds to prop up his failing empire. Rafts of legislation were introduced to protect the 14 million members of other pension schemes from future Maxwells.

Yet 'not a lot of it would prevent another Maxwell,' warns actuary Bryn Davies of Union Pension Services. 'You can never overestimate the ingenuity of people in working out how to defraud other people. You can't stop crime.'

Specialist pensions solicitor Robin Ellison of Eversheds agrees: 'Having a law against murder doesn't stop people killing each other.'

What should reassure members of employers' pension schemes, however, is the Pensions Compensation Board, a post-Maxwell creation ready to pay out in cases of negligence or fraud. If a scheme cannot meet its liabilities, the company behind it is now bound to make up the shortfall. If this forces the firm into liquidation, the compensation board will pick up the rest of the bill.

So far this has happened only once: a £60 million bail-out in 1998 for members of the Warwick Group pension scheme, whose leisure firm employer, like Maxwell, invested heavily in the company itself.

Davies believes the board's existence should free pension scheme members of worry. But there are other dangers. The Equitable Life crisis shows there do not have to be villains involved for members to lose money. Equitable, which manages half of Britain's additional voluntary contribution schemes, misjudged the amounts it would have to pay on some of its other policies and suddenly found itself unable to cap its liabilities on them.

Once one of the best- regarded UK life companies, it became a symbol of blinkered, outdated management. But it had, in the meantime, won a huge business in AVCs, the top-ups that must be offered by all organisations that run a pension scheme. Last month, Equitable imposed a 10 per cent penalty on most AVC scheme members wanting to transfer their funds to another insurer.

Like Maxwell, this crisis has tested the pensions industry. The good news is that most schemes that used Equitable Life to manage their AVCs are setting up new arrangements, which they hope to have in place by the end of the financial year.

The bad news is that it shows how little interest most members take in their schemes. They could be pressing for more choice to be built into their pension and AVCs so if, for instance, they were worried about one AVC firm they could pay into one that seemed safer.

But even now there seems to be little push for this. One trustee who tried to introduce this kind of choice was met with reluctance from members: 'People cannot bring themselves to choose.'

But if you do want to watch your company pension and AVC plans, there are simple steps you can take.

'Ask for a copy of the accounts,' says Nick Edmans of the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority (Opra). 'At least that will make it clear that there are some accounts.'

The most common problems that Opra finds are late payment of employees' contributions and delay in publishing accounts. Mostly, the cause is inefficiency, but these can be early warnings of fraud or grievous negligence.

Members are entitled to an annual trustees' report as well as a statement of their own benefits. But the trustees' report is usually just a potted version. A 'full statutory report only has to be given on request', says UPS's Davies. You can also ask for a full actuarial report, produced by an independent firm. This covers the solvency of the pension scheme and what size the employer's contribution ought to be.

If you are worried about the way your scheme is run, telephone Opra, which accepts anonymous tip-offs and has staff happy to chat informally.

Another useful body is the Occupational Pensions Advisory Service (Opas), which helps with individual concerns or disagreements between you and your trustees. It can help you complain to them. If this fails, the Pensions Ombudsman can rule on your complaint.

Another protection should be the trustees nominated by scheme members. Under the 1995 Pensions Act, one third of them should be elected by staff. 'Make sure you have member-nominated trustees you can trust,' says Davies. Some firms encourage malleable people to do this job.

Opra is aware of the issue, too. 'Member-trustees can be overpowered by others, especially those from the employers,' says Edmans.

Apathy has stopped the appointment of many more member-nominated trustees, but new rules are to ensure there are more by ending an opt-out for schemes where staff lack enthusiasm for electing their own representatives.

Members can make their presence felt by campaigning to alter scheme rules to end an injustice. The Civil Service Pension Scheme, for example, does not pay out a widow's or widower's pension in cases of unmarried or same-sex couples. Seven years' protests are paying off.

Other potential campaigning issues could be the low benefits paid to some members (see box) or the way low-paid workers often get particularly low pensions.

Whatever his legacy is to the media, Maxwell has had a huge effect on pensions. Pensions legislation is now thought to be twice the size of the Bible, much of it enacted after that fateful November day in 1991 when Cap'n Bob vanished beneath the waves.

BAE tops up

British Aerospace Systems has just struck a deal to help 2,000 of its oldest pensioners - some of whom have been drawing pensions of less than £15 a week, despite spending 30 or 40 years of their working lives in the company.

Campaigners, glad to get a deal at last, are still disappointed that it took them a decade to persuade the company to help the pensioners, mostly octogenarians. 'About half of these pensioners have died in the last five years,' says Peter Ward, a former employee and trustee of the pension scheme.

Inflation is the constant enemy of pensioners, who are reliant on pensions where there is inadequate annual uplift to match rising prices. Many older BAES pensioners also missed out on a deal to improve the benefits of those retiring after 1987. Their case was taken up by Ward and the Pensioners' Committee, which organised letters and petitions.

The committee commissioned Bryn Davies, an actuary with Union Pension Services, to look at pension surpluses and to see how much could and should be used to fund the older pensioners. A group of volunteers paid for Davies's report.

At the end of last year, agreement was reached to increase the pensions for some of the older workers. The £5bn pension scheme will be paying an average of £10 a week more to the pensioners affected. But the deal is not extended to those on pensions already worth £35 a week or more.

Ward says: 'There are many retired members of company pension schemes up and down the country who are being denied proper entitlement from their savings in their pension fund. These funds are making a considerable saving out of pensioners, many of whom are living in relative poverty.'

Pensioners have little leverage. They cannot draw a deal into a wages agreement, for example, and therefore have to fall back on moral arguments.

Who will help

Occupational Pensions Advisory Service helpline 0207 233 8080
Pensions Ombudsman 0207 964 1000

webTitle: Cashpoints

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Juicy stake | Study study | Leaving home
fields.body:
Juicy stake
Find out what the introduction of stakeholder pensions this April will mean for you in a free booklet produced by the Financial Services Authority. The booklet, entitled 'Stakeholder pensions and decision trees', answers questions such as where you can get a stakeholder pension, which one to choose and what they are. You can order a copy on 0845 606 1234. The Pensions Advisory Service also has a helpline on 0845 601 2923.

Study study
Current undergraduates will owe £7,026 each on average by the time they finish, according to a new study. The Student Living Report from Unite, provider of student accommodation, and Mori, also found that 30 per cent of students do part-time work, 16 per cent spend their free time on the Internet and only half plan to look for a job in the UK.

Leaving home
Transport problems and bad weather are spurring more people into buying second homes abroad, says Abbey National's overseas mortgage service. It saw buyers double in 2000 thanks to the strength of the pound, cheap flight deals and mortgages interest rates starting at 4.45 per cent. It is bracing itself for another bumper year this year with train delays making getting to Bordeaux as easy as getting to Bristol. The most popular locations for holiday homes are southern France, especially the Cte d'Azur, Italy, Spain and Portugal. For more details ring 0800 44 90 90.

Fund focus
Fund manager Gartmore is launching five investment funds, each based on a small number of stocks. Gartmore says the concentrated portfolios will give the 'potential to deliver enhanced performances, but they are risky.' The 1.5 per cent annual management charge will be waived if you invest in one of the 'focus' funds before 30 April. You can choose from American, European, global, Japan or UK-based funds. The range is aimed at more aggressive investors, or those with core holdings who want to enliven their portfolio. Gartmore investment helpline: 0800 289 336.

Mass mortgage
Broker Charcol is introducing bulk-buying to the mortgage market. It negotiates a mortgage deal under which the lender agrees to improve the terms of the mortgage as more and more people apply for it. The final enhancements, such as more cashback or bigger discounts, are passed on to all people who eventually take out the mortgage. Borrowers can check the progress of their mortgage towards the enhancements at any time on www.charcolonline.co.uk Call Charcol on 0800 71 81 91.

White stuff
Andorra has again topped Thomas Cook's ski index for being the best value ski destination both on and off the piste. The holiday operator says Andorra offers varied skiing and snowboarding, lively night-life and tax-free shopping. It also recommends North America and Canada for excellent snow, stunning scenery, but high prices. If the après ski is high in your priorities, Eastern European countries such as Romania are probably your best bet: beer costs from 60p a bottle. To book a last-minute skiing holiday with Thomas Cook ring 0870 752 0044.

Fast find
If you would like to visit an independent financial adviser (IFA) but don't know where to find one, a new website can point you in the right direction. www.ifawindow.co.uk lets you search for an IFA by name, postcode and area of expertise. You will receive a response within seconds, and there are links to IFAs' own websites. All of the firms on the site are regulated by the Personal Investment Authority.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: I'm itching to fly the family nest

fields.headline: I'm itching to fly the family nest
fields.standfirst: She's a student living at home, but longs to buy a flat and save to get married, Melanie tells  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: She's a student living at home, but longs to buy a flat and save to get married, Melanie tells Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Melanie Aung Htut

Age 22

Lives in Stanford-le-Hope, Essex

Occupation Student

Earns £135 a month from Saturday job at Marks & Spencer

Mortgage None

Debts Student loan

Investments Isas, Share Save scheme, Premium Bonds

Pensions Recently became member of M & S scheme

Aims To buy own property and save for wedding

Melanie is anxious to gain her independence. She lives at home with her parents in Essex while studying media production and technology at the University of Greenwich. She can't wait to start working: 'I am desperate to make money and buy a flat as I feel the time is nearing for me to leave the family home after graduating in the summer - I must be getting expensive for my parents to run!'

She hopes to find a job in the media and does not mind whether it is in print or TV journalism, public relations or with an internet company. Her final project has involved designing a website for local politicians. She feels work experience on a local newspaper and in the PR department of her local council will stand her in good stead.

Her other aim is to buy a flat. Although she has a boyfriend and they are hoping to marry in a year or two, they do not intend to live together beforehand. In fact, ideally she would like to put money aside to pay for the wedding. She does not want to burden her parents financially.

Her only earnings at present come from a Saturday job at Marks & Spencer she has been doing for two-and-a half years. She has recently joined the company's pension scheme and contributes £10 a month to an M&S share save scheme that runs until next January.

Her only debt is a student loan of £1,700. This money was put in a cash Isa so she could gain from the difference in interest between the loan and the savings account. She is keen to pay it back quickly and may do so out of money she earned working at M&S over Christmas.

Her older brother helps by giving her £15 a month to put into the Isa. Her other savings are a Halifax Tracker Isa and some National Savings Premium Bonds. Her parents pay for her upkeep but she does contribute from time to time by bringing home groceries or replacing broken items, such as the microwave.

Adviser 1: Steven Price

Melanie is following a very sensible course by building up her savings and concentrating on establishing a cash deposit through an Isa.

She should continue to save what she can. Her objective should be to save up to £5,000 as a minimum cash base. This could eventually form the basis of a deposit against a property purchase.

However, the critical issue in buying a property is her level of earnings. Mortgage lenders will be reluctant to lend until she has consistent earnings from a full-time and regular job. The basis of lending is a multiple of salary, usually around 3.25 times earnings.

Unless she enters into an arrangement with her parents, brother or partner - either by the others acting as guarantor for any loan made, or by basing a loan on their earnings - there is little chance she will be able to buy a property in the next six to 12 months. She would be better to concentrate on gaining a position in her chosen career as soon as is practicable after graduation.

Once a pattern of earnings is established, lenders will be more willing to offer a loan. She will also have a better idea of a location convenient for her job.

She may also have to prioritise her financial objectives. I do not believe the resources she will have available will give her the freedom to save substantial sums for a property and for a wedding in what is a relatively short time.

Furthermore, she should not be in such a hurry to settle her student loan. It is the cheapest source of finance around, so when resources are scarce they should be used elsewhere first.

Steven Price works for Towry Law Financial Services

Adviser 2: Amanda Davidson

Melanieshould continue saving in a mini cash Isa. This is the most suitable home for short-term savings, and she has a lot of short-term demands.

However, she needs to shop around for a better rate. Halifax's top rate is currently 6.4 per cent, compared with Nationwide's 6.55 per cent and Britannia's 6.85 per cent. If she uses the internet, Smile is paying 7.25 per cent.

The larger the deposit Melanie can save towards her property purchase, the more competitive a mortgage deal she will get. With a 10 per cent deposit she will also be able to avoid the expense of a mortgage indemnity premium, which many lenders charge.

But until she has held down a full-time job for some months, it is unlikely that she will find a lender anyway.

Perhaps she would be bet ter off renting accommodation if she intends to move when she gets married. The cost of buying and selling can make it uneconomic to buy for a short time only.

As regards her student loan, she can afford to bide her time. The interest is very low and she may be better advised to wait until she knows what her future plans are before rushing to repay.

Melanie's Halifax Tracker Isa is designed for medium- to long-term savings as shares can be volatile in the short term. Maybe she should encourage her brother to contribute to this rather than to her cash Isa, although she must be prepared to leave the money invested for at least five years. When she has a job, she should review her financial situation again.

Amanda Davidson works for financial adviser Holden Meehan

webTitle: Property: Green light for brownfield sites

fields.headline: Green light for brownfield sites
fields.standfirst: You need to do some homework if you buy a property on reused land, says  Anne Caborn
fields.trailText: You need to do some homework if you buy a property on reused land, says Anne Caborn.
fields.body:
A new home in the country is the dream of many buyers. Yet the Government wants more homes built on re-used 'brownfield' sites.

There is no chance that on an island of 60 million people, everyone can live on a greenfield site, said Philip Wilbourn, of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics).The Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions wants 60 per cent of all new homes on brownfield sites by 2008. In many places 80 per cent of new housing is on previously developed land.

Even homeowners whose first preference would be for a greenfield development may be thinking again in the light of the recent floods and the ordeal of rail commuters during the prolonged Railtrack maintenance crisis.

In the South there were many who felt certain greenfield sites shouldn't have had planning permission because they were in flood plains. But Keith Hamilton, former president of the Planning Officers' Society and a planning officer for Greater Manchester, says: 'In my neck of the woods, the major flood problems have involved brownfield areas', such as York.

A great deal of brownfield development is along riverbanks or in flood plains, so flood risks should always be assessed. A recent report by the Commons committee on the Environment, Transport and Regional Affairs called for conditions to be imposed when permission was given for building in areas at risk. It recommended that allowances be made if there were flood defences and anti-flooding designs or construction techniques. These include using solid rather than plaster board walls and electricity fed from ceiling level.

But brownfield does not necessarily mean urban. At Blenheim Grange in Essex, for example, Bovis Homes has converted the site of a former British Telecom radio station alongside the former Ongar-to-Epping railway line. The development includes a golf course with clubhouse and a small park. At Chorley, in the North West, Barratts and Redrow are spending £400 million on converting a former Ministry of Defence base into Buckshaw Village, which promises good communications links plus offices and community facilities.

Urban brownfield developments may offer advantages such as proximity to jobs and social amenities. Concerns about schools, transport or crime can be overcome with thorough research, but don't just rely on a solicitor or estate agent.

Land may be contaminated, and need cleaning up before building can start. But that is the developers' problem, says Pierre Williams of the House Builders' Federation, whose members build between 70 and 80per cent of all new UK homes. 'The standards for decontamination are very high,' he says. 'The land will have to be thoroughly tested, thoroughly cleaned up to an absolute standard.'

However, the issue is not that simple, according to Landmark, a company providing information about the environmental risks of buying and selling property. It warns that some unlucky homeowners could end up paying.

Since last April local authorities have had to identify contaminated land which is a threat to health. If the original polluter has gone, councils may have to require the current owners to clean it up.

This warning is backed by Philip Wilbourn of Rics, who says the onus is on the purchaser to be as informed as possible: 'Wherever you live, be it the Orkneys or Orpington, Rics always recommends that property buyers now carry out some form of environmental due diligence.'

'What you might need to know is not about the site itself, but about activity on the other side of the fence,' says Hamilton, the planner.

Although an environmental assessment is carried out before the developer pur chases the site, it is difficult to tell the level of clean-up needed before work starts. The builders want the Government to underwrite at least part of the risk.

Checks for potential buyers are reasonably easy. Just enter the postcode of a site on the Environment Agency website to find out the flood and existing pollution risks.

Wilbourn at Rics also points to the £39 Landmark 'Envirosearch,' which covers past and present contamination, mining, landfills, or nearby areas of ground that may have been filled, as well as flood risks. It can be ordered by your solicitor or directly from the Landmark website.

First, do some digging

Don't forget the basics: commission a structural survey whether or not the property has an National House Builders' Council warranty.

Don't just rely on the usual local authority search carried out by your conveyancer or solicitor. Take a quick trip to the library and check the local newspapers: major property developments and concerns about contamination make good copy.

The library is also a good source of information about Ofsted reports, schools' exam results and crime figures, as well as any plans to improve, or scale down, transport services and other facilities.

Check the details of the planning consent from the local authority - and whether any conditions were placed on it.

For information about flood risk visit the Environment Agency website at www.environment-agency.gov.uk. If there is a chance of flooding, check what safeguards are in place and whether the house was designed with this in mind.

Details of the comprehensive Landmark Envirosearch service, as well as a free online facility, can be found at www.undermystreet.com.

webTitle: Take care: Why you may not need to get a life

fields.headline: Why you may not need to get a life
fields.standfirst: Term assurance premiums are   falling, but that mean it has to be a good buy
fields.trailText: Term assurance premiums are falling, but that mean it has to be a good buy.
fields.body:
If you have a life assurance policy, you may want to think of hunting round to see if you can find better premiums. 'Lots of companies are losing money on pensions and endowments,' says independent financial adviser Garry Spencer of Wilbury Financial Management in Worthing. 'So more of them are moving into the term assurance market. There is a price war going on.'

Premiums have come down by more than 10 per cent across the term assurance market in the last year, according to research by MoneyFacts . A 35-year-old non-smoking woman would now pay an average monthly premium of £12.38 on a £100,000 sum- assured, 20-year policy - down from £13.67 a year ago. Canada Life is one insurer that has just cut its rates by an aver age of 18 per cent - partly achieved by tightening its definitions of smokers to include pipe and cigar smokers.

If you do not have life cover, you may not know the difference between the two main types. Term (or temporary) assurance is bought to cover you for a particular period - most often the 25 years of a mortgage term so that, if the breadwinner dies in that period, the property can be bought outright for the dependents to live in. Whole life, by contrast, is more expensive and is bought to pay out on death, whenever that occurs. Both types of cover get more expensive as you get older - since you are that much more likely to die.

Term cover is described as 'basic and cheap' by Sally West in her book Your Taxes and Savings - 2001: A guide for older people . Whole life cover is 'often unnecessary and expensive', she says. 'For anybody over 50, it should be considered only when there is a potentially serious Inheritance Tax liability, and all other steps to minimise that liability have been taken.'

In the past, sales forces exerted moral pressure on people to buy cover. Even single people were urged to buy cover so that they could leave a mortgaged property as a legacy to their parents if they died. Nowadays, most advisers accept that single people without dependents do not need life cover.

The cover is primarily there to protect young children. To keep the costs down, you should look to see if you get life cover through your work.

'Normally, there is a maximum payout of four times your salary,' says Maxine Harvey of adviser Torquil Clark. This may be enough to cover you. Read your pension scheme booklet to see what would happen if you died. If you belong to a final salary scheme, your partner may get a widow's pension, and if you are in a money purchase scheme, your heirs would receive the value of your fund.

Anyone buying life cover should also explore the possibility of getting guaranteed rates, where the premiums and benefits are index-linked or fixed in some other way at the start of the policy for the duration of the contract. Premiums vary between different insurers and depending on the terms of the policies they offer. In a trawl of the market across 17 companies, Garry Spencer found quotes ranging from £14.69 to £21 a month on a £100,000 sum assured over 15 years for a 41-year-old non-smoking male.

 Information on rates is available in the monthly magazine 'Life and Pensions Moneyfacts', costing £10 per issue, on 01603 476102.

webTitle: Take care: Peace of mind - at a price

fields.headline: Peace of mind - at a price
fields.standfirst: Knowing that you'll have income if you can't work will cost you dear
fields.trailText: Knowing that you'll have income if you can't work will cost you dear.
fields.body:
Permanent health insurance would be better known as 'income replacement for long-term conditions'. Most policies pay out if an illness stops you working for a long period, usually at two-thirds of your salary.

But unless you are partic ularly worried about this possibility, it is not the sort of cover to make a priority.

Even Kevin Morgan of financial adviser Litecastle, who has this cover himself, admits: 'The chances of anything happening are remote.' But for peace of mind, he pays about £25 a month for a policy to pay half of his salary once he has been off sick for a year - restrictions which keep the cost down.

He estimates that he would pay £50 a month for cover that paid out after six months. 'Most blue-chip companies offer their people good packages on long-term illness. They often get their full pay for the first six months, and a lower sum between six and 12 months', and frequently some discretionary amount thereafter.

If you had to stop work without some sort of cover or critical illness policy (see page 4) you might have to move to a smaller house or cut your spending in another way.

It is worth thinking about what you would do. Have you a partner who could earn more? Could you let a room in your house? Is there some other, less demanding work that could earn you money? Could you draw your pension early? Would state benefits be enough?

PHI premiums depend on age, job and health. A 36-year old male, non-smoking accountant would pay between £16 and £59 a month for index-linked cover that gave him about half his £40,000 salary, says a survey by Litecastle.
