But for peace of mind, he pays about £25 a month for a policy to pay half of his salary once he has been off sick for a year - restrictions which keep the cost down. He estimates that he would pay £50 a month for cover that paid out after six months. 'Most blue-chip companies offer their people good packages on long-term illness. They often get their full pay for the first six months, and a lower sum between six and 12 months', and frequently some discretionary amount thereafter. If you had to stop work without some sort of cover or critical illness policy (see page 4) you might have to move to a smaller house or cut your spending in another way. It is worth thinking about what you would do. Have you a partner who could earn more? Could you let a room in your house? Is there some other, less demanding work that could earn you money? Could you draw your pension early? Would state benefits be enough? PHI premiums depend on age, job and health. A 36-year old male, non-smoking accountant would pay between £16 and £59 a month for index-linked cover that gave him about half his £40,000 salary, says a survey by Litecastle.

webTitle: Our father, who art inept

fields.headline: Our father, who art inept
fields.standfirst: In two tales of childhood, one was fundamentally flawed, the other sumptuously slow
fields.trailText:
Everyman: Hallelujah Kids BBC1
In A Land of Plenty BBC2
A Touch of Frost ITV
The West Wing C4
fields.body:
Everyman: Hallelujah Kids BBC1
In A Land of Plenty BBC2
A Touch of Frost ITV
The West Wing C4

Lafontaine, Indiana is a tiny backwoods town with the flimsy 2D appearance of a temporary movie set and a church both big and robust enough to cater to the town's entire population of 1,000 souls, hallelujah. It's the brainchild - godchild, even - of passionate evangelical pastor Mike Walters and his keepin' it in the family, fire and brimstone preachin' sons, Shaun, 19 and Jacob, 10.

'They will come,' said Mike of his potential congregation, enthusiastically showing us his 'overspill' room - waiting in case they not only come, but keep on comin'. Like Kevin Costner in a god-fearin' remake of Field of Dreams , Mike believes his faith is more than enough to provide. Through donations he finds $2,000 a month to keep the show on the road in states where the radio ad voiceovers solicitously ask: 'Have you been raped, incested [sic] or molested? You can be freed from your past hurts. The "Point of Pain" package is yours for a gift of just $49 or more...', while phone-ins lament the black arts practised by Harry Potter. You couldn't make it up.

Christopher Morris's Everyman was a pretty, wistful, sad and slightly surreal follow-up to a film he made for Children's BBC five years ago - An O Brother Where (fore) Art Thou? , with shades of David Lynch's The Straight Story . Back then, Shaun was a ferrety-faced 14- year-old close to perfecting that idiosyncratic southern preacher's pulpit delivery: 'Hallelu-ya, I-ya-have-a dream-a...', while covering 400,000 miles in a Cadillac driven by Mike, living in motels, eating in diners and casting out demons, as ordained teenagers are wont to do. Five years on and the Walters have upgraded to a shiny RV, with younger son Jacob now a part of the act.

Walters has made demons the speciality of his House: 'With Mike it's all devils and demons,' said his ex-wife, Sheila, who despairs of her eldest son's future: 'He should be havin' a job, datin' girls'. But now Shaun, an introverted young man who really only comes alive in the pulpit, has been diagnosed as mildly autistic and is persistently haunted by the tools of his trade. 'Am I happy? Not really. Devil's fought me way too much. Tried to destroy my life too many times.'

In less sensitive hands this could easily have been a freak show, but viewed in the week of the hideous Jerry Springerish circus surrounding the adoption of the 'internet twins', Belinda and Kimberley, it was clear that Mike Walters was not the Parent from Hell - his love for his sons and his faith in the Lord were all-too tangible - but simply out of his depth. Jacob even appeared to be flourishing - as well as could be expected of any child from a broken home who was about to be ordained as a child minister at a clapboard 'Love Cathedral' on the wrong side of Cleveland's tracks.

None the less, the viewer was left knowing that Shaun's prospects for any kind of a normal life were receding faster than the two-lane blacktop in the RV's rear-view mirror. Even his mother recognises that Shaun urgently needs both sustained professional help and 'a pair of glasses'. Blind faith indeed.

After a languorous opener I'd expected the second episode of BBC2's 10-part drama In a Land of Plenty might start indulging us with a bit of a plot, but we only got one in the final few minutes when Helen McCrory (as troubled matriarch Mary) dived out of a heavily-leaded window in slow motion - made to look considerably easier than one suspects it must be. Still, this tale of rich and boorish northern industrialist Charles Freeman, his fragile, sleepwalking, poetry-writing wife, Mary ('doom spins a grey halo around disconsolate heads'), and the four variously neglected and indulged children all clattering purposelessly around a 28-room house, is such sumptuously gorgeous viewing that everything that doesn't happen happens very seductively indeed.

The slowest of slow motion, richly saturated colours (though that may just be my TV, which tends to give even a naked 40-watt light bulb a full-blown Spielbergian glow), lingering close-ups and a wonderfully rich use of music (from kitschy latin bossa novas to the theme from Z-Cars wafting from an off-screen TV as Mary's car made a late-night getaway), have all conspired to sustain interest and create a pretty momentum. But another eight parts?

So far I don't feel as though I'm watching episodic dramatised snapshots of the Free man's lives, but that I've been invited round for supper and then, somewhat reluctantly, kidnapped. So slowly do events unfold that, given that the plot now hovers around 1969, by the end I could well be in my sixties.

But, if you've already been seduced, for as long as In a Land of Plenty remains just the right side of pretentious, I'd advise sticking with it. TV drama too often fills up all the available empty spaces as if afraid of its own potential visual strength, but by allowing the gaps to weave their own story Plenty pretty much takes the opposite approach - fittingly, since its subject is childhood memory and the games that memories can play. It's really quite brave.

Still, this softly-softly approach ensures ratings of 2.2 million, as compared with, say, 14.2m for last week's exhaustingly densely-woven A Touch of Frost. Indeed, this was so plot-heavy that the only way David Jason could justify an on-screen snack was because even the sandwich turned out to be responsible for another complicated strand of sub-plot.

Meanwhile, was the woman whose hand had been amputated before she'd been mashed to a pulp on the railway line (and who worked for Simple Simon's Sarnies) part of the plot featuring a nasty female heart-surgeon, Dr Gibson ('No one in my team is going into his chest without excluding other inter-cardiac anomalies.' So there!), whose post-operative patients kept dying, especially if they were put in bed five?

Unfortunately I wasted far too much time trying to make a link here, thus missing most of sub-plot three (ish), about the unpleasant young man smuggling cigarettes and rubber ducks and intimidating the owners of Denton's corner shops. But I rallied just in time to worry about Jack Frost's new sidekick, methadone-using Falklands war veteran Reid, who had nearly killed himself trying to arrest a Det Insp Jack Frost impostor who (in sub-plot one) had been busying himself groping Denton's female population. Then I faded again by the time we'd uncovered sub-plot four: the hospital's waste management scandal (timely shades of Bedfordshire here, with body parts, not to mention dead female heart surgeons, left in highly unsuitable locations overnight).

The Serbian doctor turned out to have murdered Dr Gibson, of course. And, in sub-plot five (come on, keep up!), Anne turned out not to be Frost's long-lost daughter after all, which was a shame.

Since the demise of Morse, Frost is now the pre-eminent late middle-aged male detective with a sorry past and no life to speak of, so we must make the most of him. But, if only for the sake of viewers' health, he ought to relax and take up whisky and Wagner in at least a couple of scenes each show.

But then along came The West Wing, the long-awaited (on terrestrial TV, at least) and now nostalgically Democratic White House drama, which made the complexities of A Touch of Frost suddenly look like the test card as viewed on a particularly quiet Monday afternoon in 1974.

I know this was the pilot, so every character not only had to be introduced, provided with a back story and a job description and then given something else to say, too... but hey! guys! like, slow down!

Was it Leo or C.J. who was chief of staff? And what, if any, was his working relationship with Rob Lowe's deputy communications director, Sam? And who is Senator Russell? And was the escort agency girl a plant to lure Sam into a honeytrap, or was she really keen on him? And who was the guy who suddenly arrived at the end of the show, reciting the first commandment? Nope, it wasn't Mike Walters, it was Martin Sheen as a President whose clearly absurd levels of decency and commitment were indicated by the saccharine violins that accompanied him - revealed, in the credits, to have been over-orchestrated by my very favourite inspirational TV music maestro. So, congratulations on making it all the way from thirtysomething to the White House, W.G. Snuffy Walden - there's hope for the Free World yet.

webTitle: Take care: Helping the aged get help

fields.headline: Helping the aged get help
fields.standfirst: Insurance could plug the gap in the parlous state of care for the elderly
fields.trailText: Insurance could plug the gap in the parlous state of care for the elderly.
fields.body:
Should you buy a long-term care plan? It should probably not be a priority if you are still at work. 'People under 60 or 65 should buy cover only if they have everything else sorted,' says Peter Gatenby, director of Age Concern Financial Partnerships, Age Concern's long-term care arm. 'What they should do first is to build up the best possible pension for when they retire.'

A 65-year-old man buying a plan through Age Concern to pay out an index-linked £10,000 a year would either pay a lump sum of £7,136, or a monthly premium of £61. A 65-year-old woman would pay either £12,278 or £74 a month. Women pay more because their life expectancy is five years longer.

If this sounds bleak, the truth is that care of the elderly is in a parlous state. Local authorities will pay for people who cannot afford nursing-home fees, but there are waiting lists, and councils can not afford the fees demanded by most homes, typically £400 a week.

If you are dependent on the state, you may find that your choice is limited - and that you end up sharing a room, for example.

The reforms in the Health and Social Care Bill - due to come into force on 1 October - are a disappointment to Help the Aged and other charities.'Nursing care' will be provided free - but it will probably exclude the costs of staying in a home - apart from duties performed by a registered nurse. If someone else administers medicine or supervises a resident with dementia, those costs will not be covered.

It is worth reading Age Concern's helpful free leaflets - available on 0800 009 966 or on www.ageconcern. org.uk. The Nursing Home Fees Agency, a firm of independent financial advisers, specialises in providing quotations from insurance companies about their policies. It can be contacted on 01865 733000.

But, if you really want to plan for the future, do your best to keep fit and avoid the need for nursing care.

You should try to stay in your own home as long as possible by, for instance, developing a network of family and friends who can help you. Get to know other people in the local Age Concern group.

Finally, make sure you have someone tough to argue your case with the local social services; elderly people can easily get dumped in the worst homes and be given sedatives just to keep them quiet if they do not have someone sensible outside fighting their corner.

webTitle: Take care: Critical blow  to a budget

fields.headline: Critical blow  to a budget
fields.standfirst: If you are blessed with good health,   think twice about cover for illness
fields.trailText: If you are blessed with good health, think twice about cover for illness.
fields.body:
If you see a financial adviser, there is a high probability he or she will raise the question of critical illness cover. The rationale for buying it is that 'one in four men is likely to suffer a critical illness before they reach retirement age', says Peter Kelly of product provider Allied Dunbar. Put another way, advisers say your chance of getting a serious illness is 2.5 times higher than your likelihood of dying by retirement age.

Maxine Harvey of adviser Torquil Clark says that homeowners should have 'enough critical illness insurance to pay off the mortgage - especially if it is a single mortgage payer'.

A critical illness policy will pay you a lump sum if you suffer a 'dread disease' such as cancer, heart attack or stroke. But, unless you buy it in a joint package with some life cover, you need to survive for a certain period - usually three to six months - for the policy to pay out. In practice, the monthly payments can be very expensive. On a standalone policy, a 35-year-old man would expect to pay about £22 a month to buy £100,000 of cover.

Many critical illness plans are sold to homeowners in a joint package with an endowment policy. They can be bought quite cheaply this way - costing an extra £2 or so a month on a 25-year £50,000 sum-assured plan.

Cautious people who have the money may be tempted to buy this type of cover - especially if they have dependents and a large financial liability such as a mortgage. But they should be wary about being encouraged by a financial adviser to buy too much. The cover on stand-alone policies is expensive and if premiums were directed to a pension scheme instead, they could build up a significant fund.

Garry Spencer, of Wilbury Financial Management in Worthing, West Sussex, only recommends 'guaranteed rate' products to his clients - products where you know in advance what the monthly premiums and the benefit will be for every year the contract is in place. But he also aims to 'rebroke' policies annually for clients - since a continuing price war is pushing premiums down. 'You can always rebroke on to a product with guaranteed rates,' he says. Another feature he always looks for is a policy that covers diabetes. While many policies focus on conditions that are ultimately life-threatening, some will have wider application.

A practical factor to take into account is your health. If you are an overweight, heavy-drinking smoker who never takes exercise you are more likely to have call on a policy of this type.

Researching the market can be difficult without a financial adviser who knows his or her way round this part of the financial services sector. Some insurers will be competitive in a certain aspect of the market but much less keen in rates. You do not want to buy a product just because your neighbour thought a provider offered good deals three years ago.

 A starting point is the MoneyFacts monthly publication 'Life & Pensions MoneyFacts'. A copy, at £10, is available on 01603 476102.

webTitle: Take care: Matters of life and  death

fields.headline: Matters of life and  death
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean's  guide to buying only the insurance you need
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean's guide to buying only the insurance you need.
fields.body:
If you go to see a financial adviser, nearly always expect them to mention insurance. Sometimes, people do need it. If you are the sole breadwinner for six young children who would be sent to a hostel if you die without life cover the case is clear-cut. But in many cases, it is not.

Over the next few pages, we tell you about four kinds of cover you may want to consider: life, critical illness, permanent health and long-term care. We explore developments that may reshape the insurance market in the next decade or two. You will want to think about the implications, particularly if you are young, since many financial advisers will urge you to take out policies now to lock into cheaper rates than you would get in middle age.

Life expectancy is key. Babies born in the UK at the start of this millennium can hope to live to see in 2100. While men can now expect to live until they are 74 and women until 79, life expectancy is growing dramatically. At times in the last century, it was rising two years every decade.For the insurance world, this will mean a diminishing emphasis on life cover.

In the past, insurers - who always like to have a moral case - told customers they had a duty to provide for their dependents in case they died.

The firms even used to make this case for single people who had no dependents but might, as the insurers saw it, want to ensure that all their bills were paid so that if they died young, their parents did not have untidy finances to clear up.This nonsense is now dying out, and most financial advisers now accept that childless singletons have little need of life cover.

But generally as people live longer, premiums should go down on term assurance - life policies that cover a particular period, usually the lifetime of a mortgage.

Work and disability

In the past, an injury or illness could have ended your job as a miner, nurse or maid. But John Knell, of the Industrial Society think-tank, says: 'As jobs shift from physical work to being knowledge-based, fewer people will find that having a bad back or a chronic problem with their knee stops them doing their job.'

This means fewer people will need to claim on permanent health plans for losing their jobs because of ill health.

Changes are already starting to work through here. The Disability Discrimination Act of 1995 made it illegal to discriminate against people who have long-term medical conditions. Many cases have been brought under this law, and employers are increasingly trying to accommodate workers who have diabetes, industrial accidents, depression and other problems.

A demographic shortage of twenty-something workers is making employers search harder for older employees. 'The balance of power has changed in the South of England,' says employment lawyer James Davies of solicitor Lewis Silkin. Employers now have to work far harder to retain staff.

The bosses' changed attitudes will, in turn, raise the employment rate among disabled people. Only half of the disabled of working age now have jobs, though some groups do better: 68 per cent of the country's 300,000 diabetics are employed, for example.

As employers become better informed and better equipped to deal with individual cases, employment rates will rise among other disabled people.

Breakthroughs

One of the biggest medical stories so far this year has been the successful work in the search for a cure for Alzheimer's disease. Since an estimated 700,000 people suffer from dementia, the implications of scientific research are enormous.

A cure for Alzheimer's would change the equations that long-term care insurers build into their formulae for setting premiums. Govern ment campaigns to reduce the numbers of cancer deaths could also have a significant effect. And if you live in an area that has a first-rate approach to the treatment of stroke sufferers, your chances of maintaining a good quality of life after such an illness will also be substantially improved.

Yet people do have to die of something in the end. The ideal would probably be to go suddenly after a lifetime of good health, but we cannot be sure this will be the pattern after we reduce the impact of the current big killers. One of the spooky questions for the new millennium will be to discover the modern causes of death after science does away with the traditional ones.

The NHS

Promising 7,000 new NHS hospital beds by 2004 and 100 new hospitals by 2010, the Government is increasing health spending.

But will this, in the long run, make us healthier? And might this policy change if the Conservative Party ever came to power again?

British politicians are unlikely to dismantle the NHS much further, although they have already privatised discreet areas such as dentistry, says Brendan Donnelly, former Tory MEP and healthcare specialist.

'The NHS is one of the things that defines us as a country,' he says. 'If there are going to be fundamental changes to the NHS it will be because the Labour Government spends a lot more money on health and concludes that the extra did not make a difference.'

Genetic testing

The principle was accepted last November that insurers would be able to make use of some kinds of genetic testing information. If such tests become more widespread and insurers are given greater access to the results, a lot of the insurance market could disappear altogether in the long run.

If buildings insurers jack up premiums on houses in floodplains, you can bet the same will happen to vulnerable people's medical cover, permanent health insurance, critical illness, life cover and long-term care plans.

Well-cushioned against the worst

William Stolten is one of that unusual and quite small band of people who are quite happy to pay large sums of money to insurance companies to buy protection.

William, a 43-year-old recruitment consultant from Ashford, Kent, pays about £50 a month into a permanent health policy, which would pay out about £400 a month if he was struck down by a serious illness and unable to continue to work.

This PHI plan - arranged through his financial adviser, Torquil Clark - is a relatively uncommon form of insurance for ordinary people to buy.

There are about 1.5 million PHI policies in place in the UK, according to the Association of British Insurers.

'It makes you feel a lot better knowing that there is a cushion,' William says.

'I can see that if you don't have this type of cover, you are possibly looking at a fair amount of misery.'

The £400 a month he would get would not cover all his bills, but it would help maintain his standard of living.

As insurer Friends Provident puts it in its literature: 'Statutory sick pay and other state benefits provided by the Government may help. However, they are principally designed to protect against poverty, and do not provide sufficient income to maintain most people's standard of living.'

Although he is happy to pay for the cover, he did not get around to it until Torquil Clark raised the issue with him. He was then very positive about it - particularly since 'my mortgage has been rising over the years'.

Not only did he buy the permanent health cover, but he also bought a policy to pay his mortgage in the event of accident or sickness.

He accepts that all this cover costs him a fair amount, but has no doubt that it is worth while.

'You get what you pay for,' says William. 'These policies do cover quite a few things.'

webTitle: Classical: You knew they were die-hard Schnittke fans. Nobody coughed...

fields.headline: You knew they were die-hard Schnittke fans. Nobody coughed...
fields.trailText: Schnittke Weekend Barbican, London EC2/ Radio 3
fields.body:
Schnittke Weekend Barbican, London EC2/ Radio 3

Alfred Schnittke said that his goal as a composer was to bridge the gap between serious music and music for entertainment, 'even if I break my neck doing it'. Today that ambition may strike us as a less literal risk than would have been the case in the Soviet Union of the 1970s and early 1980s, when Schnittke's compositional powers were at their height.

His relationship with the grim regime was always volatile, his music at turns the object of adulation and condemnation. Officialdom governed his every move (or, more often, failure to move, since for much of his life he was forbidden from travelling outside the Soviet Union, even to hear performances of his own music). If, for most of us today, that era of Soviet state control has faded to mere reported memory, its painful legacy was felt afresh at the Barbican's Schnittke extravaganza last weekend. Every note of his music, even at its buoyant best, carries the ironic shadow of adversity. Wit becomes a weapon.

The BBC's annual Composer Portraits have long been a pleasurable obligation in the January calendar. Judging by the surreal silence and absence of arbitrary bronchial display which attends each concert, these marathons attract only dedicated music lovers. The joy is that this species, supposedly threatened, is determinedly alive; many of the concerts were sold out.

All were well attended and hungrily received. To spend three evenings and two days in the Barbican, or communing with Radio 3 which broadcasts the entire proceedings, requires a certain staying power. Yet the prerequisite for enjoyment is curiosity, not expertise. A sense of shared discovery unites the audience. An excellent complementary programme of talks and films (Schnittke wrote some 66 film scores) exists to fill any gaps in our knowledge. No one should feel daunted.

'Seeking the Soul' was an appropriately ambiguous title for the weekend (who was doing the seeking - the composer or his audience?). Schnittke's chameleon ability to change mode and mood has made his musical dialectic seem unfairly elusive or superficial. A German-born Russian, a Jew who embraced Roman Catholicism and Russian Orthodoxy, throughout his life (1934-98) he sought a homeland, a place of acceptance.

His eclectic use of jazz, baroque, mainstream classical and Russian Orthodox chant, tossed together in a bubble-and-squeak of musical variety, might seem to dash any hope of finding the real Schnittke. The reverse is true. Immersion in his music, from expansive, collage-like symphonies to unadorned chamber or choral works, merely confirmed the singularity of his artistic vision. His mission, always, is to wrestle with the musical tradition he has inherited, both within Russia and beyond.

In his favoured form, the concerto grosso, he borrows from the Italian baroque, not to imitate as a neoclassicist ( à la Stravinsky) might, but to explore a type of music which Russia itself never possessed. The string quartets survey the Austro-German tradition, as if sampling Beethoven's entire output and reconfiguring it, refining and redefining it in his own terms. The Keller Quartet gave haunting accounts of Quartets Nos 2 and 4 in St Giles's, Cripplegate, one of the weekend's many highlights.

In similar vein, at the frenzied climax of the Violin Concerto No 4, the soloist has to mime virtuosity, his bow sawing crazily above the strings, as if silenced grotesquely by his accompanists. Here, the violinist was the work's dedicatee, the dazzling Gidon Kremer, who added spice and brilliance to several concerts during the weekend. He was accompanied by the BBCSO under Martyn Brabbins, who in the same concert negotiated the mesmerically theatrical Symphony No 1 with assurance and skill. In this raw, explosive work, scored for huge orchestra, the players walk on stage one by one, then off, then on again, tuning frantically in parody of symphony concert conventions.

At one point, the music is interrupted by a pianist and violinist (Daniel Hope and Simon Mulligan) who come and start their own anarchic jazz improvisations while the conductor looks on, bewildered. When performed with the kind of conviction shown here, Schnittke's anarchy achieves strange and compelling grandeur.

The BBC players, who valiantly mastered a formidable number of works for the occasion, were less secure in the late Symphony No 8, written in 1994, four years before the composer's death when he was already incapacitated by a series of strokes. Nevertheless, a few fluffs could not cloud the spare intensity and transparent textures of this remarkable work, here conducted by Eri Klas in its UK premiere. In the BBC Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, the BBC Singers (who performed the inspiring Choir Concerto ) and BBC Philharmonic, the London Sinfonietta and a group of fine soloists, Schnittke had the best possible advocates.

Last week, the death was announced of a legendary teacher and musician who spent much of the twentieth century promoting the works of living British composers. In 1931, Anne Macnaghten gave her name to a famous series of concerts based at the Mercury Theatre, Notting Hill, where works by the young Benjamin Britten, Elizabeth Maconchy and Elisabeth Lutyens were premiered. She also founded a string quartet, at one time all-female, but later admitting brave men to its ranks.

As a young woman, she rebelled against her smart Kensington upbringing and joined the Communist Party, defying her family by becoming a musician, when to do so was a betrayal of class. She continued teaching until recently and died, aged 92, as the result of a fall when out distributing Labour Party leaflets.

Life has improved, for women musicians and for living British composers alike. Anne Macnaghten and a few like her sowed the seeds of change more than half a century ago. Unlike Schnittke, she espoused communism by choice, yet modernism in music does not easily thrive in either free or chartered soil. It needs such heroes and heroines to make its flowers grow.

webTitle: Live Pop: 69 songs... and only one lemon

fields.headline: 69 songs... and only one lemon
fields.trailText: The Magnetic Fields Lyric Theatre Hammersmith, London W6
fields.body:
The Magnetic Fields Lyric Theatre Hammersmith, London W6

Stephin Merritt (no relation) and his band The Magnetic Fields used to be the best-kept secret of the New York underground music scene, a shibboleth for the cognoscenti. Then they go and produce their epic triple CD 69 Love Songs, and suddenly they're the critics' choice in every publication on both sides of the Atlantic, strangers are stopping you in the street to tell you that you must go and buy it, and if you want to retain that recherché aura you're now obliged to play only the very early albums, or drop casual references to Merritt's aliases (The 6ths, The Future Bible Heroes, The Gothic Archies).

69 Love Songs was conceived as a theatrical revue, and the decision to perform it over two nights (twice) as a complete opus, as if it were Wagner's Ring Cycle, is a kind of ironically self-aggrandising joke, but one in which the audience can feel complicit. The band's chamber-music style of performance belongs to small venues, and the Lyric is intimate enough to appreciate the acoustic feel of the set, which is largely due to the absence of a live rhythm section.

In addition to Merritt, who sings 44 of the songs and plays guitar and ukelele, The Magnetic Fields are manager Claudia Gonson on vocals, piano and keyboard, Sam Davol on cello and John Woo on lead guitar and banjo, with the odd rice-shaker, plastic bottle and lemon brought in for special effects. The three guest singers from the album - Dudley Klute, L.D. Beghtol and Shirley Simms - and accordion player Daniel Handler, all sit on sofas at the back of the stage, smoking and reading, in a mock lounge with an art deco lamp and an entirely redundant hat-stand.

It's impossible to describe 69 Love Songs without reference to as many other artists, since each song is in part a homage to (or is it a send-up of?) the variety of musical styles the genre embraces. Influences range from Phil Spector to avant-garde composers John Giorno and Steve Reich, with pastiches of Johnny Cash, Johnny Rotten, the Human League and Scottish folk song. Merritt has been labelled the greatest songwriter of his generation by the US music press, and it's compulsory to compare him with Cole Porter and Irving Berlin, though vocally his murky subterranean baritone is Leonard Cohen chain-smoking Camels. One resourceful LA critic has described the album as 'Roland Barthes's A Lover's Discourse set to music by the combined population of Tin Pan Alley and the Brill Building [with] liberal doses of meta-commentary', which comes close, but doesn't do justice to Merritt's cynical humour and deft lyrics, which rival Tom Lehrer's for audacious rhyming.

On the first night the audience appears to be taking it all terribly seriously (as you might expect from people who like songs about Ferdinand de Saussure). The set gets off to a difficult start with the chirpy 'Absolutely Cuckoo', a song not designed for live performance due to a complete lack of breathing opportunities, which Gonson gamely acknowledges, but other songs seem better suited to the stage than the studio, such as the heartbreaking 'All My Little Words', which goes to show not all these love songs are intended as a cynical undermining of the genre (though 'How Fucking Romantic' and 'Yeah, Oh Yeah' are firmly in that vein).

By the second night the audience seems to have got the hang of it; the polite applause has turned into whooping and whistling between each song. It's mainly Gonson who keeps up the anecdotes, while Merritt perches atop his high stool or wanders vaguely around the stage, smoking, with a faint air of boredom. The songs are getting more laughs too, from 'For We Are The King Of The Boudoir', in which Beghtol (who looks like Meatloaf and talks like Julian Clary) appears in a velvet smoking jacket and threatens to steal the show, to the splendidly ludicrous lyrics of the final song, 'Zebra', which heralds a riotous standing ovation.

69 Love Songs, for all its postmodern in-joke status, is a major achievement. If you missed them this time, you can still buy the album, and will find yourself wondering how The Magnetic Fields managed to stay a secret for so long.

webTitle: Pop: Stars in his eyes

fields.headline: Stars in his eyes
fields.standfirst: We have 'Nasty Nigel' on Popstars. The US has Lou Pearlman, the biggest Svengali of all
fields.trailText: We have 'Nasty Nigel' on Popstars. The US has Lou Pearlman, the biggest Svengali of all
fields.body:
If you've watched ITV's Popstars, you'll know all about Nigel Lythgoe or 'Nasty Nigel' as the tabloids have dubbed him. LWT's entertainment chief turned pop impresario reckons he can spot talent or a malleable wannabe at 20 paces. Maybe, but the ratings-grabbing experiment is a pale shadow of the real thing. The modern pop Svengali plans his teenyboppers' introduction to the public with an efficiency that would impress Alastair Campbell.

Lou Pearlman is the current master of hitmaking. The 46-year-old former airline executive is perhaps the most important man in American music. He discovered and moulded Backstreet Boys, NSync and LFO who between them have sold almost 50 million records. (The bestselling album in America last year was NSync's No Strings Attached, which sold 10 million copies.)

But Pearlman doesn't trawl the clubs and bars looking for the next big thing. In the Eighties, he made the travel arrangements for New Kids on the Block, but when he saw how much money they earned he decided to switch careers.

Now he recruits the bands through ads and then puts them through his hit factory, Trans Continental, in Orlando, Florida. It's a kind of latterday Motown which teaches everything from syrupy harmonies to charming the media, although the end product is inferior.

There is method behind his Midas touch. Each band comprises five basic types: one bashful, one rebel, one nice, one heartthrob and one 'ethnic' type. The model first worked for the Backstreet Boys, which he formed in 1993. Since then, Pearlman has become a very busy and rich man. Pearlman's protégés are characterised by their slick, sanitised r'n'r, regimented dance steps and lavish promos.

'Every group starts out as a lump of clay,' says Frank Sicoli, the executive vice-president of Trans Continental. 'Someone comes to us with their talent and we can match them with the necessary resources - the right choreographer, producer, vocal coach, stylist, photographer. But with each artist what happens could be different if you did the process 100 times. And though people view this as an assembly line, it would be impossible for us to do that.'

Nothing is left to chance. For instance, hairstylists ensure that the James Dean figure has a roguish quiff while Mr Nice has a sensible cut. Since last year, Americans have been able to watch Pearlman in action on television in Making the Band , a kind of proto Popstars. The series followed eight young guys living together and vying for five spots on a new Pearlman band called O-Town.

As in Popstars , the contestants underwent a rigorous audition process as they were whittled down from 1,800 hopefuls. Viewers were engrossed. O-Town have since enjoyed a run of hits while the series returns later this year. Pearlman has been a regular on the show, but unlike Nasty Nigel, the paunchy, balding pop mogul presents himself as an avuncular figure who is affectionately nicknamed 'Big Poppa' by the band.

Not everyone has such fond memories of working with Big Poppa and his empire has been shaken of late. His two biggest signings, NSync and Backstreet Boys, recently left the stable in acrimonious circumstances.

webTitle: Theatre: It's about Alzheimer's and it's funny

fields.headline: It's about Alzheimer's and it's funny
fields.trailText:
A Wedding Story Soho Theatre, London W1
La Lupa The Pit, London EC2
BlackSky White International Mime Festival
fields.body:
A Wedding Story Soho Theatre, London W1
La Lupa The Pit, London EC2
BlackSky White International Mime Festival

Raise your glasses, please, to Bryony Lavery for A Wedding Story. Best men, take a tip from her (she writes fantastic speeches). Brides and grooms, ditto (she has thought hard about marriage). I was rocked by this play, tipped between laughter and dismay. It is lavishly scattered with jokes, like gaudy confetti, but its subject matter is drastic. It is about what happens when the words 'love', 'honour' and 'obey' are lost to Alzheimer's disease.

That is not all. It involves two generations of one family: the beginning of a lesbian love affair, the end of a long marriage. What does it mean to pledge yourself to someone for life? Evelyn (Kika Markham) was once a doctor, now she is the patient. At times she sounds like a medical reference book - only no one is consulting her, she is merely discharging herself of facts. Markham manages beautifully to convey a mind that partly knows what is happening but is powerless to control itself.

The glaring question is: who should look after her? Her husband (a sympathetic Andrew Hawkins) seems to love her dearly - we're reminded of his promise to look after her in sickness and in health - but she is too much for him. Her children are not up to it either.

Lavery knows that laughter is possible even in terrible circumstances, a tonic even when it cannot be a cure. Her humour is wild and impossible to predict and Annie Castledine directs with perfect comic pitch.

Evelyn's daughter Sally (Jackie Clunes) is gay - in every sense. Clunes has tremendous presence with her sweep of badly dyed red hair, huge blue eyes and lopsided punchline of a grin. And she sings brilliantly. But she is not as tough as she would like. She wants to control her love affair with Grace (Aicha Kossoko) and keep it light. But love is not always obedient and Grace has other ideas. Kossoko gives a great performance. She looks wonderful, too; a wry African Queen in burgundy velvet with a trailing curtain of dreadlocks. Sally's brother Robin (Brendan O'Hea) is also excellent. He turns every calamity into a film synopsis, a gag that never runs out of steam.

I prefer to avoid plays and novels about Alzheimer's. But this should not be missed. I liked Lavery's conclusions about love and the dangers of trying to second-guess fate. Sometimes, she suggests, it is essential to live incautiously.

It looks as though a Mediterranean snakes and ladders may be about to begin at the Pit - or wolves and ladders. The atmosphere of Simon Gonella's production (designer Nicky Gillibrand) of La Lupa is strange, poised between rural tedium and danger. As shadows give way to harvest light, peasants introduce themselves through dance: a man converts two scythes into a bull's horns; a woman makes her apron animate - as if she had suddenly acquired a new limb.

This is a community where nothing escapes. There is no such thing as a private life or a secret lust. A nimble old lady (Janet Whiteside) kicks up her heels and tells alarming fairy tales; men are giddy with lust and boredom; young women watch themselves, for they are easy prey.

This slender tragedy, by the Italian playwright Giovanni Verga (1840-1922), is expertly translated by David Lan. His aridly prosaic style has a power of its own; there is no decoration to distract.

The drama is at its most involving when La Lupa herself (Brid Brennan) starts to dominate. In this close Catholic environment, her sexuality is seen as feral. She is a predator, a widow, a beauty in early middle age. She has a smiling, distant look, as if enjoying a seductress's private joke. Her daughter, Mara, is a shy version of herself and she proposes to give her away to win Nanni Lasca. Declan Conlon is excellent as the irresolute man who can neither trust nor blame himself.

Mali Harries is marvellous, too, as Mara. When she marries, she looks like a traumatised corn dolly in her makeshift veil; her eyes swim with tears. Later, she is a harvest herself: happy and fruitful but not for long. Brid Brennan is formidable at the end: she looks at once like a little girl and an old lady. She is poised but lost forever.

The 22nd International Mime Festival kicked off - or shuddered to a start - with BlackSky White from Moscow, at the Purcell Room. The show was like a preview of hell: it showed how it might feel to be robbed of speech but with a body on red alert. Masked faces struggled and failed to speak; only their bodies chattered in torment. When the yelling started, it was beyond them, part of a bodiless soundtrack that seemed to come from some groaning, roaring foundry. These clowns from Hades, juggling what looked like blood grapefruits, became tedious. Yet there was skill involved: everything, including gender, seemed to bend. A nightmare on the Embankment.

webTitle: Clinton grants full pardon to Patty Hearst

fields.headline: Clinton grants full pardon to Patty Hearst
fields.trailText: The one-time revolutionary and kidnapped heiress Patty Hearst, Bill Clinton's brother Roger, and his Whitewater business partner Susan McDougal were among 140 Americans pardoned in one of the final acts of Clinton's presidency.
fields.body:
The one-time revolutionary and kidnapped heiress Patty Hearst, Bill Clinton's brother Roger, and his Whitewater business partner Susan McDougal were among 140 Americans pardoned in one of the final acts of Clinton's presidency.

The orders, which erase criminal records, were signed two hours before he left office also cleared the cloud of scandal from two former Cabinet confidants - the ex-CIA director John Deutch and the ex-housing chief, Henry Cisneros.

Until yesterday, Deutch had been discussing a possible plea deal with Justice Department prosecutors to settle allegations he mishandled classified government information.

The list also was notable for those it did not include: Webster Hubbell, a former law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton convicted in the Whitewater investigation, had not sought a pardon; Jonathan Pollard, a former Navy analyst imprisoned for spying for Israel; the one-time Wall Street financier Michael Milken; former senator and Abscam figure Harrison Williams; and Leonard Peltier, convicted of killing two FBI agents on an Indian reservation in 1975.

Clinton, himself spared from indictment in a deal Friday with prosecutors, also commuted the prison sentences of 36 people.

Hearst, the daughter of newspaper tycoon, Randolph Hearst, briefly became the most famous woman in the world when, as a 19-year-old student of art history in Berkeley, California, she was kidnapped by eight members of a revolutionary terrorist group.

For 57 days, Patty Hearst lived in a cupboard at a safe house. She was blindfolded, sexually assaulted, then raped repeatedly. Her only conversations were lectures from her captors about the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA).

On the 58th day of her ordeal Hearst tried to win her freedom by joining the SLA, a revolutionary group, and ended up carrying out bank robberies for them.

When most of the SLA were tracked down by the FBI and burnt to death in their safe house, Hearst survived. One year later, she was captured by the FBI,and convicted for robbery. She spent two years in prison before President Carter commuted her sentence.

She later married and had two children. In recent years she has had parts in two John Waters films and has modelled clothes on the Paris catwalk.

webTitle: Call girls to be questioned in cricket scandal

fields.headline: Call girls to be questioned in cricket scandal
fields.standfirst: Match-fixing probe deepens as former Test star says sexual favours and lavish presents were offered to top players
fields.trailText: Match-fixing probe deepens as former Test star says sexual favours and lavish presents were offered to top players.
fields.body:
British investigators probing cricket's deepening corruption scandal are to question prostitutes who performed sexual favours for top players agreeing to fix matches.

The women were used by illegal bookmakers to lure some of the game's best-known players into throwing games or to reward them for under-performing on the field, according to a former Pakistan Test batsman. He alleges prominent players, including national team captains, had sex with the call girls as part of crooked deals that have destroyed cricket's honourable image.

The prostitutes included a doctor, nurse, travel agent and glamorous television presenter. All were Australian apart from one Pakistani and a Chinese.

Anti-corruption investigators of the International Cricket Council led by Sir Paul Condon, ex-commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, plan to interview the women next month in Australia.

The revelations come as law enforcement agencies and cricket bodies worldwide intensify efforts to find out how deep-rooted the culture of players throwing matches for money has become in the game. Many big names have already been implicated.

Ex-England captain Alec Stewart has recently been questioned by Condon's team over claims he received £5,000 for passing information to an Indian bookmaker, which he has denied.

Scotland Yard's Serious Crime Squad is probing claims by ex-England all-rounder Chris Lewis that he was approached by Indian sports promoter Aushim Khertepal to persuade three England colleagues to throw an Old Trafford Test against New Zealand in 1999.

Condon and his team will take a list of 23 prostitutes when they fly to Melbourne for the ICC's quarterly meeting on 9 and 10 February. Condon's team, composed mostly of ex-senior police officers, will brief cricket's world governing body on the progress of inquiries before seeking to interview both prostitutes and illicit bookmakers also on the list.

The list has been provided by Qasim Omar, a Pakistani player in the Eighties who appeared in 28 Test matches alongside such sporting greats as Imran Khan, Wasim Akram and Javed Miandad. He has told investigators about the sex for match-fixing set-up and has provided addresses and telephone numbers of all the women to Condon's team.

Omar claims that, from the mid-Eighties, the prostitutes were supplied to the players by an Australian bookmaker through two madams in Sydney and that the network of prostitutes for players stretched across Australia from Brisbane to Perth.

A spokesman for the investigating unit confirmed to The Observer that the list will be among the documents it will take, and said: 'There are other people we want to speak to, which we will try to do while we are out there.' It is an opportunity to speak to as many of these people as possible.'

Omar has also provided information about an identical sex scandal in New Zealand, again organised by a bookmaker, who has also been named.

The Pakistani veteran was the first prominent player to blow the whistle on corruption in international cricket back in the mid-Eighties. He offered to give the authorities details of who was involved. But he was not asked for information and nothing was done about his claims.

Omar has alleged that an Australian bookmaker lavished money and gifts on players - both Australian and visiting overseas stars - who did what he asked. According to him, batsmen were paid up to £3,600 for throwing their wicket away, and received jewellery, watches, gold pens and bottles of spirits as extra perks.

Omar has named one world-class batsman who was offered £9,000 to throw his wicket away in the first four Tests of a five-match series, and a Test skipper who pocketed bungs for advising the bookmaker about the team he intended to field.

In addition, he has also identified one top Asian bowler who deliberately under-performed in several matches in Australia because he needed the money to finish building a house.

He claims deals were struck in hotels, such as the Sheraton in Sydney, a restaurant in the city's red light district and McDonald's in Melbourne.

Condon's investigators will seek to interview Omar, who is now based in Britain, when they return from Australia. The six-strong anti-corruption team, which began its inquiries last September, hopes to present the ICC with an interim report into worldwide cricket corruption by mid-2001.

It has been given three years by the ICC to root out corruption and set out how it can be banished from the game.

webTitle: Letter: Bouncing euro

fields.headline: Bouncing euro
fields.trailText: Australians are not the slightest bit worried about the alleged problems of the euro. After all, the euro has survived for many thousands of years. Euro: a wallaroo; any of several types of large kangaroo.
fields.body:
Australians are not the slightest bit worried about the alleged problems of the euro. After all, the euro has survived for many thousands of years. Euro: a wallaroo; any of several types of large kangaroo. (Chambers, 1995.) Next time, try a non-ambiguous name for your wobbly currencies?
Len Clarke
Uxbridge, Middx

webTitle: Letters:  Air traffic safety

fields.headline: Air traffic safety
fields.trailText: In the article 'Air Travel Disaster Imminent' (News, 7 January), the document you refer to is not 'secret'. The European Commission High Level Group Report is in the public domain and was considered by Transport Council Ministers inDecember. Ministers reacted positively to the preliminary conclusions and agreed that while safety levels remain high within Europe reforms need to be made.
fields.body:
In the article 'Air Travel Disaster Imminent' (News, 7 January), the document you refer to is not 'secret'. The European Commission High Level Group Report is in the public domain and was considered by Transport Council Ministers inDecember. Ministers reacted positively to the preliminary conclusions and agreed that while safety levels remain high within Europe reforms need to be made.

We recognise the need for improvements in Europe and that is why the UK is actively participating in the European Commission's Single European Sky initiative.

Europe in general, and the UK in particular, has an excellent safety record and we will do our utmost to ensure this record is maintained while increasing capacity. UK and European skies are not heading for disaster.
Malcolm Field,
CAA
London WC2

The main point of the High Level Group reports, which your sensationalised reporting largely obscures, is that Europe does need to take urgent action to avoid further escalation in air traffic delays and ultimately 'gridlock' in the whole system. The flow of air traffic in Europe is severely hampered by the current fragmented system of management by a multitude of separate national authorities. The High Level Group has recommended a number of important reforms to deal with this problem: strong independent regulation; better use of airspace as a common resource; uniform approach to safety; new environment for ATC providers and more co-operation between them; greater emphasis on human resources and social dialogue; and more effective incentives.
Roy McNulty
National Air Traffic Services Ltd
London, WC2

The European Commission High Level Group Report is in the public domain and was considered by Transport Council Ministers inDecember. Ministers reacted positively to the preliminary conclusions and agreed that while safety levels remain high within Europe reforms need to be made. We recognise the need for improvements in Europe and that is why the UK is actively participating in the European Commission's Single European Sky initiative. Europe in general, and the UK in particular, has an excellent safety record and we will do our utmost to ensure this record is maintained while increasing capacity. UK and European skies are not heading for disaster. Malcolm Field, CAA London WC2 The main point of the High Level Group reports, which your sensationalised reporting largely obscures, is that Europe does need to take urgent action to avoid further escalation in air traffic delays and ultimately 'gridlock' in the whole system. The flow of air traffic in Europe is severely hampered by the current fragmented system of management by a multitude of separate national authorities. The High Level Group has recommended a number of important reforms to deal with this problem: strong independent regulation; better use of airspace as a common resource; uniform approach to safety; new environment for ATC providers and more co-operation between them; greater emphasis on human resources and social dialogue; and more effective incentives. Roy McNulty National Air Traffic Services Ltd London, WC2

webTitle: Letter:  The real thing

fields.headline: The real thing
fields.trailText: In 'Hallucinogen cure for addicts linked to deaths' (News, 7 January) the 'ibogaine' that you quote price and dosage for is not ibogaine itself, but an extract of the rootbark of the plant source,   the rainforest shrub Tabernanthe iboga.
fields.body:
In 'Hallucinogen cure for addicts linked to deaths' (News, 7 January) the 'ibogaine' that you quote price and dosage for is not ibogaine itself, but an extract of the rootbark of the plant source, the rainforest shrub Tabernanthe iboga.

This product is usually known as the 'Indra iboga extract' and is a complex mixture of the alkaloids that occur in the rootbark of the Tabernanthe iboga plant. It is scientifically recognised that there are more than 10 active alkaloids present in the rootbark, ibogaine itself being merely one. This extract was produced in great quantity in Denmark in the mid-Eighties, whence it has made its way across Europe and, in scientific analysis, has been found to contain levels of actual ibogaine varying between 0 and 8 per cent. This product is simply not ibogaine.
Nick Sandberg (website owner www.ibogaine.co.uk)
London, W1

webTitle: Letter:  Basque terror

fields.headline: Basque terror
fields.trailText: In 'Eta's loyal youth dreams of martyrdom and freedom' (News, last week), the article   refers to 'Basque youths' in generic terms. That seems out of focus.
fields.body:
In 'Eta's loyal youth dreams of martyrdom and freedom' (News, last week), the article refers to 'Basque youths' in generic terms. That seems out of focus. A survey by the Basque autonomous government says that 87.8 per cent of Basque youths are against the use of violence as a means to a political end, whereas 9 per cent justify it 'only in certain circumstances', and 0.6 per cent 'in all circumstances'. Your article glamorises this fanatical part of the young population.

I suggest you find out why the greater part of Basque youth do not feel free to express their political views.
Carlos Sanchez
The Spanish Embassy
London SW1

webTitle: BT's frustrated rivals set up shop next door

fields.headline: BT's frustrated rivals set up shop next door
fields.trailText: In recent weeks residents of numerous leafy streets in London have opened their front doors to find strange men offering to buy their homes. The door-stepping tactics owe much to the location of the properties, rather than a re-emergence of a 1980s-style housing boom.
fields.body:
In recent weeks residents of numerous leafy streets in London have opened their front doors to find strange men offering to buy their homes. The door-stepping tactics owe much to the location of the properties, rather than a re-emergence of a 1980s-style housing boom.

Fed up with BT's reluctance to share space in its local telephone exchanges, the telecom giant's competitors, who want access so that they can introduce new technologies that turn phone lines into high-speed internet networks, are embarking on a bit of DIY.

BT has been forced by regulator Oftel to allow rival firms access to the local exchanges. But the process has been dogged by controversy, and BT's rivals accuse it of being slow to open up to competition. Now they are looking to buy houses close to the local exchanges so they can install their own hi-tech equipment nearby and avoid further time-wasting from BT.

Just before Christmas Martin O'Neill, chairman of the Department of Trade and Industry Select Committee, quizzed representatives of Cable & Wireless, Energis, Kingston Communications and Thus about the fact that some of his constituents had been approached by anonymous parties interested in their homes. O'Neill was told that under their new 'mix and match' policy, BT's rivals would continue to try to gain access to BT exchanges but also band together to build their own alternatives.

Band-X, a London-based company that allows firms to trade telecoms capacity, has been charged with finding the locations to site the exchanges.

webTitle: Top UK law firm sued for £1bn

fields.headline: Top UK law firm sued for £1bn
fields.trailText: Clifford Chance, Britain's biggest law firm, is being sued for up to £1 billion by a Canadian construction magnate over alleged negligence, improper conduct and conflict of interest.
fields.body:
Clifford Chance, Britain's biggest law firm, is being sued for up to £1 billion by a Canadian construction magnate over alleged negligence, improper conduct and conflict of interest.

The claim, by Joseph Zappia and his Zappia Middle East Construction Company, relates to military and civil construction projects in Abu Dhabi in the mid-Eighties.

The case, which is bound to stir controversy as to how huge City law firms handle conflicts of interest, is set to come before the London High Court at the end of the month.

In his writ, served on 199 Clifford Chance partners, Zappia alleges that the firm improperly acted for the powerful Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA) while advising him on a $1.7bn claim in which ADIA was a defendant.

The businessman, who once stood stood for the leadership of the Canadian Conservative Party, also alleges that Clifford Chance breached 'Chinese walls' by disclosing confidential details of his case to the Abu Dhabi authorities.

He alleges, furthermore, that the law firm failed to declare its conflict of interest and to be candid about its dealings with Abu Dhabi. 'The defendant deliberately or negligently preferred the interests of ADIA and its proprietors to the interests of the claimants,' Zappia's writ says.

The law firm's conduct, he claims, cost him the opportunity to reach a negotiated settlement worth at least $200m with the Middle East emirate.

This weekend Clifford Chance, which is denying liability for damages, was dismissive of Zappia's action. 'I can't comment. It's a complex case,' said litigation partner Perry Simpson. 'It's a case as far as the claimant is concerned which generates a lot of heat and light. I don't want to add to that heat and light.'

The controversy concerns the construction of three military camps, a 22-storey Chamber of Commerce building and the new headquarters of the Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank.

After making no headway in his $1.7bn claim, Zappia instructed Clifford Chance in May 1992. Later that year, however, the law firm also retained ADIA as a client. Clifford Chance only resigned over its admitted conflict of interest in 1995. By then, action against Abu Dhabi had been started in the US courts.

Zappia originally issued his writ against Clifford Chance in 1995, but halted it until the US courts decided last summer that the claim against the Abu Dhabians was outside their jurisdiction. He recently issued an amended writ against the law firm.

Clifford Chance originally admitted a conflict of interest and breach of duty, but denied it had caused the Canadian any loss.

Five years ago the firm unsuccessfully tried to strike out Zappia's action. It was censured by a High Court judge for the 'arrogance' of its legal manoeuvring.

Zappia's London solicitors declined to comment before the case came to court.

webTitle: Oil threat to Darwin's isles

fields.headline: Oil threat to Darwin's isles
fields.standfirst: Environmental catastrophe looms in Pacific paradise where theory of evolution was created
fields.trailText: The Pacific islands whose unique wildlife helped Charles Darwin to develop his theory of evolution are facing environmental tragedy from oil spewing out of a stranded tanker.
fields.body:
The Pacific islands whose unique wildlife helped Charles Darwin to develop his theory of evolution are facing environmental tragedy from oil spewing out of a stranded tanker.

The Jessica, carrying 243,000 gallons of diesel fuel, ran aground on the ecologically fragile Galápagos Islands last Tuesday. On Friday, it began leaking oil into a bay on San Cristóbal island that is teeming with unique marine species.

As the emergency spun out of control, Ecuador, which owns the islands, yesterday pleaded for help from the United States to prevent an environmental disaster. It is feared that high tides could soon overturn the tanker, greatly increasing the size of the oil spill. Rough weather is forecast for the next couple of days, which could hamper clean-up efforts and further disperse oil into the waters off the nature sanctuary.

The Galápagos archipelago, 600 miles west of mainland Ecuador, is the country's main tourist attraction, famous for its giant tortoises and uniquely evolved birds and plants found nowhere else in the world.

'We are asking for official help from the US Coastguard, which has the specialised equipment for these types of operations,' said Ecuador's environment minister Rodolfo Rendón.

'We have taken all the necessary measures available to us to prevent any possible tragedy - and I would call it a tragedy - that might occur in the coming hours,' he added.

Floating barricades have been set up around the tanker, but officials said the slick still appeared to be widening. Workers have removed 20,000 gallons of fuel from the ship, but the authorities would not disclose how much has leaked into the bay.

Elicier Cruz, the Galápagos National Park Director, said the spill was 'getting worse because of strong waves forecast' to hit the archipelago.

The tanker is thought to have run aground on the easternmost island in the group because of navigational error. Workers initially thought it had leaked machinery oil, but Cruz said: 'By the afternoon it was confirmed that it was the fuel and that it was spilling.'

The situation was grave because Ecuador did not have the right equipment to deal with the emergency, and there would be 'tremendous contamination' if high tides overturned the ship.

Cruz said the spill threatened colonies of sea lions, marine iguanas, birds such as blue-footed boobies, sea gulls, masked boobies and sea life, including sharks and lobsters.

However, the authorities quickly came under attack from fishermen for not taking action quick enough. The leak started three days after the tanker ran aground.

'Galápagos fishermen denounce to the world the irresponsibility of certain organisations in charge of conservation that have not taken action to avoid prob lems since Tuesday night,' said Alfonso Lozada, president of the San Cristobál fishermen's co-operative.

The Galápagos, discovered in 1535 by the Bishop of Panama, Tomás de Berlanga, are a series of volanic islands that straddle the Equator. The ruggedness of the arid landscape is accentuated by high volcanic mountains, craters and cliffs.

Its giant tortoises live for up to 150 years, thought to be among the longest life spans of any creature on Earth.

The islands became internationally famous as a result of Darwin's visit in 1835. Their unusual fauna contributed to the groundbreaking theories on natural selection published in his book On the Origin of Species in 1859.

They were designated a national park in 1959, and Unesco added them to its list of world heritage sites in 1978. In recent years, they have attracted 60,000 visitors a year, leading to warnings from environmentalists that the islands' ecologyis being damaged.

webTitle: Big business 'losing fight to militants'

fields.headline: Big business 'losing fight to militants'
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest companies 'have no effective strategy' to deal with direct activists and are losing the battle against the new breed of militants, a new study shows.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest companies 'have no effective strategy' to deal with direct activists and are losing the battle against the new breed of militants, a new study shows.

Activists 'represent a growing threat to organisations of all shapes and sizes', the report says. By 'generating bad publicity and encouraging boycotts, they cause severe disruption, including damage to reputation, sales, profitability, employee satisfaction and share price'.

Big companies 'tend to be unprepared, do not know how to respond and either fail to respond at all or respond ineffectively to activist groups. They have a tendency to bury their heads in the sand and hope the activists will go away. All the evidence is they don't'.

There are 30,000 direct action groups targeting small private firms, such as Huntingdon Life Sciences, as well as global giants, including McDonald's and Shell, and international financial institutions, the report, Managing Activism by communications analyst Denise Deegan, says.

In their campaigns, groups avoid detailed scientific data and 'focus on influencing feelings by using emotional arguments. Language is chosen carefully for optimum emotional impact. Messages are kept simple and powerful and are repeated regularly'.

By ignoring activists or dismissing their arguments as unworthy of response, firms 'effectively hand control over to them, allowing issues to spiral out of control. Managers should ask themselves whether they can afford to ignore groups'.

Aggressive tactics - such as taking activists to court or seeking to cut off their funding - can make them martyrs. 'Groups prosper when threatened. In a David versus Goliath battle, the public often sides with David. An organisation's reputation can be badly damaged by being publicly presented as a bully.'

Instead of fighting back directly, the study recommends that companies 'learn to think like their "enemies" before trying to engage them in negotiation'.

'Learning to manage activists involves learning about activists. If dealt with in the right manner, activists have been shown to change their approach from aggressively confrontational to co-operative.

Activists often move from direct pressure to a more trusting attitude at the first sign of an organisation's willingness to negotiate.'

Companies including BP, Shell, Monsanto and McDonald's have lost hundreds of millions of pounds after successful campaigns by direct activists against their business practices. Meetings of the G7 group of the world's richest nations, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have been disrupted by anti-globalisation protesters.

john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

'Managing Activism' is published by Kogan Page

webTitle: British men stay single longer to play the field

fields.headline: British men stay single longer to play the field
fields.trailText: New figures have revealed what women have long suspected: men are staying single longer so they can enjoy the delights of a bustling sex life.
fields.body:
New figures have revealed what women have long suspected: men are staying single longer so they can enjoy the delights of a bustling sex life.

The average age of marriage for men has risen above 30 for the first time since records began, from 26 two decades ago. If the trend continues, 61 per cent of all men between the ages of 25 and 44 will be unmarried within 10 years, backing government predictions that Britain will soon need 500,000 new homes.

Sociologists put the rise down to increasingly affluent single lifestyles and a desire to experience more partners before taking the decision to settle down.

Marj Thoburn of Relate, the counselling service for couples and families, said: 'Even 20 years ago people were getting married just to have a long-term sexual relationship. It's not necessary now. You can bonk anyone you like.'

Latest figures from the Office for National Statistics not only show a reluctance to marry, but also a trend towards single living among young people.

Women, who in 1983 married at an average age of 24, are now postponing the event until 28.

'It is difficult to know yet whether this represents an abandonment of marriage or a postponement of marriage,' said a spokesman at the Government Actuary's Department.

Thoburn said there could be other reasons for the delay in tying the knot. 'We're aware that many more people are reluctant to marry until the biological clock is ticking and children are a consideration. Large numbers of people in their twenties and thirties have witnessed their parents' relationships break up. That can put them off.'

Typical of the new breed of affluent single men is Tim Dean, a 28-year-old accountant from East Sussex. 'I've had three serious relationships but I don't feel under any pressure to settle down permanently.

'My current girlfriend has her own flat and we see each other a lot, but we both like space and our own time.

'There is still almost another decade before we have to be worried about having children. But I would still feel cagey about marriage. It's a signal of the end of independence and ties you in a very messy way.'

Pete Leahy, a 45-year old lecturer from Belper in Derbyshire, intends to get married later this year after living with his partner for 16 years. 'It's very much an economic thing now. If I die there's a vast difference in the pension my partner Anna will receive. I'm not getting any younger and we have an 11-year-old son.'

Ceridwen Roberts, of the Family Policy Studies Centre, said: 'Now marriage is often of real advantage only to the relatively wealthy because things like pensions and inheritance matter to them. That's one reason the gay community want it.'

'If people are thinking harder about settling down in order to be sure about who they're marrying,' said a Church of England spokesman, 'that's a good thing. However we still continue to teach that our perception of God's ideal is a choice between celibacy and lifelong monogamous marriage.'

Few people appear to be listening. The latest British Social Attitudes survey showed just nine per cent of people believe sex before marriage is always wrong.

Almost 30 per cent of households in Britain now consist of a single person living alone, up from below 10 per cent in 1960. Of the expected 4.4 million unmarried men between 25 and 44 in England and Wales in 2011, 11,000 will be widowers and 536,000 will be divorced.

webTitle: Holocaust Day mired in protest

fields.headline: Holocaust Day mired in protest
fields.standfirst: Britain is under diplomatic fire for including Armenians killed in 1915 in its memorial day for genocide victims, writes  Kamal  Ahmed
fields.trailText: Britain is under diplomatic fire for including Armenians killed in 1915 in its memorial day for genocide victims, writes Kamal Ahmed.
fields.body:
Plans to remember millions of victims of the Holocaust next weekend are facing fresh controversy after the Government said the disputed Armenian massacre of 1915 would be included in the day's events.

Home Office sources said the slaughter of 1.5 million Armenians by the Turks will now make up part of the Holocaust Memorial Day on Saturday, which will be attended by Tony Blair and Prince Charles. Last night Turkey objected 'in the strongest terms' to the inclusion.

The huge event will be the first time there has been an official day to remember genocide victims, with particular emphasis on Jewish suffering. Stars who have agreed to attend the ceremony include Emma Thompson, Bob Geldof, Antony Sher and Ian McKellen.

The climbdown came after pressure from Armenian groups which discovered that they were to be excluded from the memorial day because the deaths did not 'come within the right time frame'.

They complained they were being ignored because of government sensitivities about Britain's relationship with Turkey, a Nato ally whose air bases are used to attack Iraqi targets. The Refugee Council also said the day was supposed to remember 'all victims of genocide'.

The Government's capitulation now threatens a diplomatic row with Turkey which insists that the death of the Christian Armenians living in the Ottoman Empire should not be compared with the killing of six million Jews by the German state during the Second World War.

Last week Turkey withdrew its ambassador from Paris after the French National Assembly voted to recognise the Armenian massacre as an act of genocide.

'This is the first we have heard about the Armenians making up part of the day,' a spokesman for the Turkish Embassy in London said.

'It was not genocide, it was different. It was not a systematic attempt by a government to destroy a people. The figures about the number of people who were killed are inaccurate, that is not an opinion, that is a fact.'

But the Home Office denied the move could backfire. 'Everything will be mentioned [on the day],' one Home Office official told The Observer, distancing the Government from original plans to allow only atrocities committed after 1939 to be part of the ceremony. 'That was always the plan.'

The BBC, which is covering the event and has controversially given overall editorial control to the Home Office, has also made it clear the events in Armenia will make up a section of its broadcast. Veteran BBC reporter John Simpson has been told to mention the massacre during his commentary on the day.

'This is an inclusive event and that means all victims of genocide will be remembered,' a BBC spokesman said, adding that Cambodian, Rwandan and Bosnian victims of genocide would also be included.

The row reveals the delicate sensitivities that surround the event, which has been criticised for focusing too exclusively on the suffering of Jewish people.

The ceremony, which will be held annually, was originally to be called International Genocide Day but the name was changed when the Government became nervous that not enough recognition was being given to Jewish deaths.

The Home Office initially said that there would be a historical cut-off point for victims of genocide, saying the day would concentrate on the Holocaust and later massacres.

That rule was relaxed after the event was seen to be in danger of descending into an unseemly row over recognition between different groups.

kamal.ahmed@observer.co.uk

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: MacColl is mourned | Rally against Vauxhall |  Princess home with a smile
fields.body:
MacColl is mourned

The music world said goodbye to singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl, 41, killed in December when she was hit by a speed boat while swimming off the Mexican coast with her two sons, at a memorial service at St Martin-in-the-Fields, London. Among those at the service were U2 front man Bono, comedian Phil Jupitus and musician Billy Bragg, who sang A New England, one of her best-known hits.

In recent years she had become very involved in the campaign to get the US sanctions against Cuba lifted and Bragg said this was typical of her spirit. 'I considered her not just a friend but also a comrade.'

Opening the service, the Reverend Nicholas Holtam said although MacColl's death had been deeply shocking there was much to celebrate about her life. 'Many of her songs touched the big questions of life,' he told the congregation.

Rally against Vauxhall

Thousands of protesters staged a huge rally and marched through Luton against the decision by Vauxhall to end production of the Vectra in a year's time, with 2,000 direct job losses and thousands more in the wider economy. Car workers from across Europe and from other British companies, including Rover and Ford, swelled the crowd to 10,000, according to union officials. The rally heard that Vauxhall's parent company, General Motors, would face a prolonged campaign of action if it did not reverse its decision.

Princess home with a smile

A smiling Princess Margaret left King Edward VII Hospital, London, on the arm of a nurse after 10 days' treatment for a suspected stroke.

Margaret, 70, was helped into the back of a Rolls-Royce and driven to Kensington Palace. She intends to return to Sandringham tomorrow.

River Thames to get lifeboats

The Royal National Lifeboat Institute is to provide three lifeboats on the Thames in London. The move has been welcomed by the relatives of 51 people who died in the Marchioness disaster in 1989.

Flocking back

Sheep are to graze the Malvern Hills for the first time in 150 years in the hope that they will bring back wildlife, notably skylarks and meadow pipits. Shepherd Richard Smith will tend a flock of 150 animals.

Church death

A man was found dead in a pool of blood in a church in Finglas, north Dublin. Police said that the man had met a violent death.

Freud's couch goes on show at the Tate Modern

It is the most famous sofa in the world. For 62 years, Sigmund Freud's consulting couch has remained in the north London house where he lived and died after fleeing Nazi persecution in Austria, writes Vanessa Thorpe.

Now it is to leave its Hampstead home for a show at the Tate Modern. As part of 'Century City', sponsored by The Observer, it will form the centrepiece to a Viennese exhibit that will include samples of the art inspired by Freudian analysis.

'This couch is the sacred relic of the last century and it is the first time it has been moved since Freud was alive,' said Richard Calvocressi, one of the curators of the show.

 The Freud Museum is at 20 Maresfield Gardens, London NW3 (tel. 0207 435 2002).
