webTitle: Inside the labs where lives hang heavy in the balance

fields.headline: Inside the labs where lives hang heavy in the balance
fields.standfirst: As a mystery financial backer steps in to rescue the Huntingdon Life Sciences labs,  Martin Bright sees the operating rooms and breeding centres where animals live and die for medicine - and commerce
fields.trailText: As a mystery financial backer steps in to rescue the Huntingdon Life Sciences labs,  Martin Bright sees the operating rooms and breeding centres where animals live and die for medicine - and commerce
fields.body:
The marmoset looked almost human. With bright, inquisitive eyes and a cheekily cocked head, it was fascinated by the world around it. The animals' odd resemblance to little people made South American primates such as this the model for Gremlins , the Hollywood horror movie, in which cute-looking alien beasts mimicked the humans they proceeded to terrorise.

It is also these qualities that have led scientists to consider marmosets the near-perfect laboratory animal - although, in the case of the marmoset at Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS) scuttling around a cage last week, it was the humans rather than the animals who were in control.

The Observer was given unprecedented access last week to one of the HLS laboratories at the centre of the vicious, escalating row over animal testing. Scientists working there have received death threats and lobbying by activists forced the Royal Bank of Scotland to withdraw a £22 million overdraft to the company, only for a mysterious American backer to step in and prevent HLS from going bust. The Government yesterday welcomed the deal, saying it would safeguard 1,100 jobs.

The activists, in turn, have vowed to find the new backers - thought to be a US financial group - and launch an equally strident campaign to 'out' those responsible for saving the company.

Not that this meant much to the marmoset being handled by Sharon, a worker at HLS who is regarded as an evil torturer by animal rights activists. Thrusting a heavily gloved hand into the cage, Sharon took hold of the mammal inside. The marmoset tried to resist, screeching and clinging on to the bars. But it finally stopped struggling and allowed her to carry it into the stark lights of the laboratory.

Sharon's boss, a scientist identified only as Peter, explained what would happen next to the marmoset. 'We can dose it orally by mixing substances into its food or with a catheter inserted through the mouth directly into the stomach or intravenously into the leg veins.'

Skin reactions were tested by shaving an area of skin and applying the chemical directly to the bald patch. At the end of each experiment the marmosets were killed, dissected and the tissues examined for signs of damage. A barbaric waste of a pre cious animal life or the necessary prelude to the next great medical breakthrough?

Marmosets are a convenient size for animal researchers - about as big as a large rat. They weigh less than a kilo and tests can often be carried out by a single handler. Government guidelines say that all new medicines and vaccines must be tested on two distinct species of mammal; researchers usually begin with mice or rats and move on to dogs or monkeys. A rat-sized primate is therefore something of an ideal mammal in the world of vivisection.

The marmosets are kept in a carefully monitored artificial environment, initially in family groups and then separately as the offspring reach maturity. Each cage is about two metres high, with enough room for the animals to exercise on hoops and ropes built into the cages. Feed is also sprinkled on the floor to allow them to forage as they would in the wild. Temperature is constant and the industrial striplighting flicks on and off in a regular 12-hourly cycle of laboratory night and day.

Apart from their size, the beauty of marmosets for companies such as HLS is that they can be bred in captivity in Britain, unlike their larger Far Eastern primate cousins, which have to be imported. 'The animal rights movement has intimidated all the airlines out of flying primates into this country,' said Brian Cass, managing director. 'The marmoset will never completely replace the beagle or the larger primate, but they are an important new alternative.'

At HLS marmosets have become an essential part of the rescue package for the firm - that and yesterday's £22m loan. Just outside the village of Eye in Suffolk, away from the publicity of the main Cambridgeshire site, scientists from HLS are breeding a colony of marmosets for use in tests on pharmaceuticals and chemicals. The species comes from Brazil, but there is also a pure Suffolk breed entirely raised for animal testing. Today protesters from the Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty have organised a national demonstration at the company's Eye facility, which will shift the focus to the Suffolk institute.

Last week The Observer obtained exclusive access to the Eye facility, a sprawling collection of warehouses and huts surrounded by razor wire deep in one of the bleakest corners of the Fens. We also visited the HLS main site outside at Alconbury, Cambridgeshire, where the testing on beagles and macaque monkeys is done.

No animal-lover would find a visit to an HLS lab anything other than upsetting. There are marmosets that have never seen a jungle; beagles that have never been taken for a walk in the countryside; all manner of mammals, small and large, being bred so that they can be pumped with chemicals and then killed.

Yet in our visits to the HLS sites we encountered a dedicated workforce determined to face down the threats from animal rights activists. Katrina, an animal technician who works with rats at Eye, said she came to HLS because she wanted to work with animals. 'I'm reluctant to say where I work, but it's frustrating because I'm proud of what I do,' she sighed.

Her colleague Angela has received hate mail from protesters because she has shares in the company. She has to turn off her phone and fax when she goes to bed because otherwise they ring all night. She has also had her name printed on posters plastered around her village naming her as an 'animal abuser'. 'I believe in peaceful protest,' she said. 'But this can become very intimidating when you are just trying to do a job.'

We encountered nothing other than well-regulated scientific procedures and animals being cared for as well as could be expected consid ering the fate that awaited them in the name of medicine.

But this has not always been the case. HLS has been rocked by a series of undercover investigations, which revealed abuse of animals. The company's financial woes began in 1997 when a Channel 4 documentary, It's a Dog's Life , showed workers at Huntingdon shaking and punching beagles as they struggled to avoid having blood-samples taken.

After a Home Office inquiry, the company was allowed to continue trading, but not before the collapse of its share price and the withdrawal of several large financial backers, including the Labour Party's pension fund.

Then, last September, documents were leaked about experiments carried out at HLS for the Cambridge-based company Imutran, specialists in the new science of 'xenotransplantation'. The company aims to transplant the hearts of genetically engineered pigs into humans, but experiments on monkeys at HLS showed that more than a quarter of animals died on the operating table and in one case a monkey was mistakenly given a frozen heart. The monkey died.

As a result of pressure from animal rights groups, the Home Office has been forced to investigate the xenotransplantation experiments at HLS. Imutran has now taken out an injunction against Dan Lyons, who led the campaign of animal rights group Uncaged, and the documents cannot be published in this country.

The targeted action of groups such as Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac) and Uncaged has been highly effective. But senior executives at Huntingdon believe that the campaigners have been infiltrated by 'terrorist' elements, who have planted incendiary devices under the cars of lab staff.

Shac demonstrators outside HLS last week said talk of terrorists undermining important medical research was a ploy by the company to distract attention from the genuine abuses uncovered by campaigners.

'What has been lost in this debate is that this is a contract laboratory,' said Les Stevens, an activist. 'It is a commercial operation. Most of the work done here has nothing to do with medical research. Its main work is testing household products and agrochemicals.'

The client list of HLS is a closely guarded secret, but is known to have included giant pharmaceutical companies such as Glaxo-Wellcome and Roche in the past as well as the GM crops company Monsanto. But HLS's own in-house brochure confirms Shac's clams that a large proportion of its business comes from testing industrial chemicals such as paints, solvents, adhesives, dyes, detergents and flame-retardants.

There is now no doubt that extreme elements in the animal rights movement are now prepared to intimidate and threaten people who work in animal laboratories. As The Observer reported last week, Scotland Yard's anti-terrorism branch is convinced that groups such as the Animal Rights Militia and the Justice Department are prepared to cause physical harm in pursuit of their aims. Last week they confirmed that a spate of bombings across the north of England over the past months is believed to be the work of animal rights activists.

Last week, The Observer was also invited to the Ipswich Animal Rights campaign, one of a loose coalition of groups that will be demonstrating today at Eye.

At the home of Meals On Wheels volunteer Dorren Brand, art teacher Diana Marshall and retired physiotherapist Jane Higgens, we watched Shac footage of abuses at HLS labs in Britain and the US.

Marshall, who acts as a spokeswoman for the group, has been described by Huntingdon staff as 'a demonstrator of the cuddly, furry variety'. As the atmosphere of conspiracy heightens, she has become convinced that the firebombings may be the work of agents provocateurs . 'It suits them to label us all as terrorists so that they can bring in more laws to stop demonstrations. When you hold up a placard saying "silent suffering," how threatening is that?'

The threats against staff at Huntingdon continue; some staff have received letters telling them they hope their children die of cancer. Tonight a Channel 4 documentary about the history of the animal rights movement will show an interview with a wheelchair-bound Huntingdon shareholder, Andrew Blake, who is hoping that scientists will find a treatment for his rare condition of Friedreich's Ataxia. He has received letters from protesters calling him a 'spastic' and a 'sick cripple'.

Such is the emotive nature of the debate: on the one side visions of a holocaust of beagles and marmosets; on the other a man in a wheelchair waiting for a cure.

martin.bright@observer.co.uk

A short history of animal rights

Live exports 1994-95
The campaign against the live export trade at Shoreham, Sussex and Brightlingsea in Essex culminated in mass demonstrations against the trade in veal calves. The trade initially switched to Coventry airport, but the campaigners eventually suceeded in stopping exports.

Huntingdon Life Sciences 1997
Undercover TV reporter Zoe Broughton worked at the laboratory for six months and filmed workers punching beagles while taking blood samples. This led to an investigation of the company and the prosecution of two workers. The subsequent four-year campaign by Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty brought the company to the brink of financial ruin.

Barry Horne 1998
The hunger strike of convicted bomb-maker and Animal Liberation Front supporter between October and Christmas 1998 split public opinion, but highlighted the plight of animals.

Shamrock Monkey Farm 2000
The farm in Small Dole, West Sussex, imported monkeys from Mauritius and China for use in animal experiments.Shamrock closed in March last year after a concerted campaign from animal rights activists. The escalation of the campaign against Huntingdon Life Sciences can be dated from the closure of Shamrock

webTitle: Government to support emotional literacy campaign

fields.headline: Antidote to the stiff upper lip
fields.standfirst: New Labour's best minds want to help you find your inner child, reports  Anthony Browne
fields.trailText: New Labour's best minds want to help you find your inner child, reports Anthony Browne.
fields.body:
How are you feeling today? In touch enough with your inner emotions to run the economy, the health service and the criminal justice system? Good. Then let us begin.

An audacious bid will be made this week by many of New Labour's leading lights to put 'emotional literacy' at the heart of the political agenda. Antidote, the self-proclaimed 'Campaign for Emotional Literacy', will launch its manifesto at the Houses of Parliament on Wednesday.

The aim is no less than to wipe away generations of stiff upper lips, bulldog spirit, clenched jaws, explosive tempers, football hooliganism, and sons who call their dad 'sir'.

Or, as Antidote puts it: 'To create an emotionally literate culture, where the facility to handle the complexities of emotional life is as widespread as the capacity to read, write and do arithmetic.'

The manifesto goes on to proclaim: 'Connecting to our feelings is neither a soft nor an easy option. Disconnecting from our feelings is not Clever.' It says we should all, 'strive to value people for who they are, and enable them to realise the many dimensions of themselves.'

Many of the Government's most famous and influential supporters are backing it.

Founder members include the internet Minister Patricia Hewitt; New Labour's favourite human rights lawyer, Helena Kennedy; its favourite film producer, David Puttnam, and its favourite thinker, Professor Anthony Giddens, director of the London School of Economics.

Antidote's advisory board includes its favourite MEP, Glenys Kinnock, and is also supported by Labour's favourite media mogul, Clive Hollick. Also closely associated is New Labour's most fashionable think-tank, Demos, which came up with the idea for 'Cool Britannia'.

James Park, the director of Antidote, told The Observer: 'It always matters that we are sufficiently in touch with our own emotions to be in touch with those of others. The pace of change is so fast now that people need emotional literacy to steer them through the choices and be able to cope with it.'

Antidote aims to create a 'listening culture', putting emotional literacy at the heart of the education system. But it does not stop there. It aims to create emotionally literate economic policies, declaring: 'Market-centred forces persuade many to deny support for those public services and welfare measures that promote the well-being of the wider community.'

After Tony Blair's 'third way' - somewhere between left and right - Antidote are in effect proposing a 'fourth way': the emotional way.

'Emotional literacy is becoming the political issue of our time, but it's emerging quite gradually as something with a hard-edged political dimension,' said Tom Bentley, director of Demos.

Its advocates say emotional literacy is being rubbed out by modern life. 'When we had real communities, shipbuilding and mining, we did not need counsellors because we had natural counsellors, aunties or grannies, and there was more emotionality,' said Professor Cary Cooper of the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology.

Cooper believes the decline of emotional literacy is responsible for the reluctance to marry and the high level of divorce. 'We lead such frenetic lives now, we're very functional in our relationships, and that applies to the family. People are working harder and longer, and communicating less. We're missing out investing in relationships,' he said.

Antidote insists it is not party political, but Tony Colman, Labour MP and supporter of Antidote, said: 'This new thinking is part of New Labour, although it's not overtly Government policy. It's a thread of sanity and a holistic approach that defines New Labour.'

The new thinking has attracted support from the Liberal Democrat speaker of the Northern Ireland Assembly, Lord Alderdice. 'In Northern Ireland, relationships and feelings are very important for the peace process' he said.

Antidote has failed to attract any supporters from the Conservative party, and gets little sympathy from right-wing thinkers. Madsen Pirie, president of the Adam Smith Institute and a Thatcherite intellectual pin-up, said: 'Is it not so "me", an obsession with self? It's almost self-indulgent. Society is governed by rules, not by feelings. Feelings are capricious, and law has to be impartial and objective.'

Pirie also said it was good to think: 'Thinking has been given a bad press. Feeling did not devise a law of gravity: thinking did.'

webTitle: Blood test may help to detect schizophrenia

fields.headline: Blood test may help to detect schizophrenia
fields.trailText: Pinpricks of blood could soon reveal if a person is suffering from schizophrenia, the most debilitating of all mental illnesses.
fields.body:
Pinpricks of blood could soon reveal if a person is suffering from schizophrenia, the most debilitating of all mental illnesses.

Scientists have revealed they can detect differences in levels of the brain chemical dopamine - closely linked to schizophrenia - in individuals' blood streams. The researchers claim the test is sufficiently accurate to pinpoint whether that blood came from a schizophrenic or a healthy individual.

'We were able to differentiate between blood taken from 14 schizophrenics and a group of 10 people who were unaffected by the disease,' said Professor Sara Fuchs, of the Weizmann Institute in Israel. 'However, we have to make sure this is a reliable indicator of the disease before we can go any further, and have now launched trials on a much bigger sample.'

At present, diagnoses of schizophrenia are based on observations of patients' behaviour. Typically, they feel their lives are being controlled, and their thoughts directed by others. They hear voices and can form delusions about the world around them.

Just 1 per cent of the population suffer from the condition, which is known to involve the activity of dopamine, a chemical involved in communications between nerve cells. Dopamine locks on to receptor molecules on brain cells and directs their behaviour. The more dopamine receptor cells that a person has, the more likely that person is to have developed schizophrenia, researchers have found.

'However, it is virtually impossible to count the dopamine receptors in a person's head,' added immunologist Fuchs, whose team's study is published in the current Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences . 'The only way would be to remove their brain cells, and count their receptors - which is not really practical.'

However, the discovery that dopamine receptors are also found on the surfaces of white cells, which circulate in our bloodstream and help protect the body from invading bacteria and other microbes, has opened up new prospects for medical researchers.

'Isolating white blood cells is a lot easier than sampling brain cells of living people,' said Fuchs. 'But counting dopamine receptors is still tricky.' So the Weizmann team analysed the genetic material that controls the making of receptors instead - and found a significant difference in one particular type, known as D3 receptors.

It was found schizophrenics had, on average, more than three times the amounts of dopamine of healthy individuals, with levels varying from between 2.4 to 7.1.

Pinpointing mental status from blood could be a powerful tool in dealing with psychiatric illnesses. But Fuchs warned the technique would have to be rigorously tested before being brought into widespread use. In particular, there could be a danger if tests gave too many false positives, labelling individuals as schizophrenic when they were actually unaffected by mental illness.

'It's unlikely to be used to screen populations to uncover potential schizophrenics,' added Fuchs. 'It is unlikely to be accurate enough. However, it can take psychiatrists months to use behavioural criteria to diagnose the disease. This test could cut that dramatically.'

webTitle: World in brief

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Hungary's pop king mourned
fields.body:
Hungary's pop king mourned

Tens of thousands attended the Budapest funeral of Imre 'Jimmy' Zambo, the 'king' of Hungarian pop.

Rain prayers

Muslim faithful gathered in mosques throughout war-ruined Afghanistan to pray for rain and snow to end the worst drought in 30 years.

Kremlin aide denies charges

Ex-Kremlin aide Pavel Borodin will answer Swiss investigators' money-laundering charges if he is released from detention in a New York jail, said Moscow's US ambassador, adding that Borodin 'denies all charges'.

Korean leader hints at reform

North Korean leader Kim Jong-il has declared that China was right to launch economic reforms, according to the Beijing leadership at the end of his visit to China. This was taken as a sign that Kim is considering economic policy changes in his impoverished communist country. He toured car and computer factories and the stock exchange in Shanghai.

Tribesmen set hostage free

Yemeni tribesmen have released a German engineer they were holding hostage in a remote province.

The man, who has not been named, works on an oil exploration project run by Germany's Preussag Energie, a unit of Preussag AG.

The authorities declined to comment on whether the kidnappers' demands had been met.

Three killed by bomb at peace rally in Bangladesh

At least three people were killed and nearly 40 wounded when a bomb exploded at a rally of the Bangladesh Communist Party in Dhaka. The rally had been called in protest against growing crime and terrorism.

Deadline for Hindu temple

Hindu leaders have set a deadline of March 2002 for the building of a temple on the site of a mosque in Ayodhya, northern India. After zealots destroyed the mosque in 1992 about 3,000 people were killed in nationwide riots. Muslims, who make up about 12 per cent of India's population, want the mosque rebuilt.

webTitle: Philippines: Estrada to stand trial for plunder

fields.headline: Estrada to stand trial for plunder
fields.standfirst: Two toppled Presidents, one murdered, the other pushed out of office by people power ... a special report on the countries, the political intrigues and the economic chaos left behind
fields.trailText: Two toppled Presidents, one murdered, the other pushed out of office by people power ... a special report on the countries, the political intrigues and the economic chaos left behind.
fields.body:
Disgraced Philippine President Joseph Estrada is to face a judicial investigation for economic plunder, an offence punishable by death.

Left isolated in his palace and surrounded by tens of thousands of angry demonstrators, Estrada yesterday accepted a Supreme Court decree stripping him of his title and left office.

Unable to travel by road because of the huge crowds outside, the former movie actor left ignominiously by barge. He did not flee the country, however, as had been expected - some diplomatic sources said he might go to Australia - but returned to one of his private homes in suburban Manila.

Within minutes Vice-President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo was sworn in as the country's 14th President at an impromptu ceremony in front of tens of thousands of anti-Estrada protesters at the Edsa shrine in the capital, Manila. This was the focus of the first 'people power' movement in 1986 that toppled the dictator Ferdinand Marcos.

'I accept the privilege and responsibility to act as President of the Republic,' she told the masses, many of whom had camped there overnight. 'I do so with a sense of trepidation and a sense of awe.'

Asked if Estrada would face charges, she said she would 'let justice take its course'. But later in the day government ombudsman Antonio Desierto, who possesses prosecuting powers, announced he would start a judicial investigation.

Estrada has been accused of skimming tobacco excise taxes and taking bribes from illegal gambling syndicates. Eighteen other people, including his wife and son, face the prospect of similar charges before the ombudsman.

According to opposition sources, Estrada had been looking for a pardon before agreeing to hand over power. Military chief General Angelo Reyes, whose decision on Friday to rally to Estrada's opponents triggered his downfall, called for 'no vindictive aftermath'.

Along with Reyes, most of the Cabinet, the armed forces and police withdrew their support for him in the face of massive street protests sparked by public outrage at the President's sabotage of his own impeachment trial on Tuesday, when senators voted narrowly to suppress key evidence against him.

Defiant to the end, Estrada did not actually resign, but the Supreme Court took action when tens of thousands of people marched to the palace after he refused to accept an opposition deadline to quit by 6am local time yesterday, despite his isolation.

He issued a statement saying that he had 'strong and serious doubts about the legality and constitutionality of her proclamation as President', but that he would give up his office to avoid being an obstacle to the nation's healing process.

Arroyo stressed the need for national healing and reconciliation in her acceptance speech. To rapturous applause she said that fighting poverty and restoring a sense of morality and honesty to government would be her priorities.

She will be no stranger to the Malacanang presidential palace when she moves in as the new head of state tomorrow; she lived there as a teenager from 1961-65 when her father, Diosdado Macapagal, was President.

However, this diminutive (at 5ft 1in) academic with a PhD in economics is unlikely to enjoy a long honeymoon on her return to the nation's leading address. Not only is the country on the brink of economic collapse, but the population is polarised.

'Gloria's first task will be to heal the social divisions created in the last six months,' said political analyst Conrado Dequiros. 'Amid all the hype and hysteria we should not forget that there are a lot of people out there who do not like her.'

This dislike does not merely stem from the fact that Estrada still commands widespread support. There is a common perception that the new head of state is fast burning up her own support base.

Arroyo, 53, won the vice-presidency in 1998 with an even bigger majority than Estrada won the top job, thanks partly to campaigning on the fact that she looks like the country's most popular screen goddess. Since that zenith, she has made enemies for several reasons.

Many people see this extremely devout Roman Catholic mother-of-three - she said yesterday that she became President only because God had ordained it - as a political vulture.

When she resigned from Estrada's Cabinet in October last year and started campaigning against him, it was seen as a move by someone hungry to grab power for herself. Although she has been noticeably quiet since the second people's power movement exploded into life on Tuesday night, the suspicions still linger.

Then there are the allegations that this lover of ballroom dancing is not as clean as she makes out to be. Filipino political culture is notoriously venal and a certain amount of mud has stuck to her, although none of it has been proven.

Part of the concerns stems from the wider allegations of corruption against her husband, Mike Arroyo. Within minutes of her taking the oath of office yesterday, mobile phones were buzzing with messages warning people to be watching the new first husband like a hawk lest he develop grand designs to enrich himself.

The President, who was in the same class as Bill Clinton at Georgetown University in Washington DC, has however got off to a promising start.

In her first half-day in office she has been delivering all the right soundbites and appearing suitably gracious to the millions of street protesters whose actions catapulted her into the presidency.

The unravelling of Estrada's presidency began in October after a botched attempt to assassinate his former drinking buddy, provincial governor Luis 'Chavit' Singson. The police hit squad made a miscalculation - Singson had a bulletproof car and used a mobile phone to summon help.

Taken to a police station, he held an impromptu press conference and blew the whistle on the President's involvement in raking off millions of pounds in commissions from illegal gambling syndicates, tobacco taxes and bingo games.

But criticism of Estrada's decadent, corrupt and immoral lifestyle had already been mounting. At his impeachment Estrada was charged with stealing about £8 million. But a well-informed journalist reckons that the total could be £275 million. 'I guess we'll just never know.'

The Philippine Centre for Investigative Journalism (PCIJ), a non-profit independent agency, started investigations in the first half of 2000 when it decided to probe gossip about fancy mansions being built for presidential mistresses and Estrada taking cuts from various business deals.

Their findings were so explosive none of the quality newspapers or television stations would touch them. 'We discovered that the President, his family and mistresses had interests in 66 corporations that could not be explained in state assets and income taxes,' said PCIJ executive director Sheila Coronel. 'He also had links to 30 town houses built recently in suburban Manila with none of the necessary permits.'

The proportions of one of these, built for one of his mistresses and the three children he fathered with her, were mind-boggling.

The master-bedroom complex was 255 square metres, the kitchen 90 square metres. There was a 60 square metre 'fitness' area including a massage room, gymnasium, beauty parlour and a sauna, and the theatre was big enough to seat 30 people.

But a well-informed journalist reckons that the total could be £275 million. 'I guess we'll just never know.' The Philippine Centre for Investigative Journalism (PCIJ), a non-profit independent agency, started investigations in the first half of 2000 when it decided to probe gossip about fancy mansions being built for presidential mistresses and Estrada taking cuts from various business deals. Their findings were so explosive none of the quality newspapers or television stations would touch them. 'We discovered that the President, his family and mistresses had interests in 66 corporations that could not be explained in state assets and income taxes,' said PCIJ executive director Sheila Coronel. 'He also had links to 30 town houses built recently in suburban Manila with none of the necessary permits.' The proportions of one of these, built for one of his mistresses and the three children he fathered with her, were mind-boggling. The master-bedroom complex was 255 square metres, the kitchen 90 square metres. There was a 60 square metre 'fitness' area including a massage room, gymnasium, beauty parlour and a sauna, and the theatre was big enough to seat 30 people.

webTitle: Kabila's body flown home as mystery of his death deepens

fields.headline: Kabila's body flown home as mystery of his death deepens
fields.trailText: The body of assassinated Congolese President, Laurent Kabila, was flown to his home town of Lubumbashi yesterday as mystery deepened over the circumstances of his murder and his son Jospeh's succession.
fields.byline: James Astill in  Kinshasa and agencies  in Lubumbashi
fields.body:
The body of assassinated Congolese President, Laurent Kabila, was flown to his home town of Lubumbashi yesterday as mystery deepened over the circumstances of his murder and his son Jospeh's succession.

The white and gold casket, draped in the flag of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, was flown from Zimbabwe where he had been flown immediately after being shot, allegedly by one of his own bodyguards.

The body was taken to Lubumbashi, where Kabila spent most of his time while ruling Congo.

The former revolutionary, dilettante and brothel keeper, who was thrust into the limelight as a figurehead for the invading Rwandan and Ugandan forces (with whom he latter fell out) will lie in state there before being flown to the capital for the funeral.

A band played sombre music as military and government officials filed past the open coffin displayed in front of the June 30th Building, where his hand-picked National Assembly met. Congolese television reported that the cortege had trouble getting to its destination because thousands of people wanted to touch the coffin.

When and where Kabila died still remains unclear, with Congolese and Zimbabwean officials contradicting one another. It emerged that some Western diplomats in Kinshasa had reported suspicions last week that the killing of Kabila showed signs of careful planning.

Kabila's body had been loaded on to the presidential aircraft under the eyes of his former ally President Robert Mugabe as a Zimbabwean military band honoured the slain leader.

A Congolese delegation escorted Kabila's body back to Congo. A state funeral is planned for Tuesday in Kinshasa. Mugabe, one of Kabila's key military allies, declared three days of mourning in Zimbabwe.

Mugabe said his troops would continue to defend Congo from 'acts of aggression,' the state-controlled media reported yesterday.

Zimbabwe has 11,000 troops, backed by air power and armour, fighting alongside government forces in Congo's two-and-a-half-year civil war. Angola and Namibia, who also back the government, have said they too will keep their troops in Congo for the time being.

Rebels discontented by Kabila's rule launched the war in 1998 with the support of Rwanda and Uganda, who entered the Congo under the pretext of pursuing the Hutu rebels responsible for the Rwandan genocide in which 800,000 people died.

In Kinshasa the mood was resigned. 'What do we care about generals and politicians?' said one shopkeeper. 'We do not mind a coup d'état that is for leaders. But we are afraid that if the army do not accept the change, or if they are not paid, they will start looting.'

At a press conference in Kinshasa, UN Special Representative Kamel Morjane said all sides in the conflict had agreed to cooperate with the UN peacekeeping mission, sent to monitor a 1999 cease-fire agreement.

On Friday, Congolese Communications Minister Dominique Sakombi announced that Kabila's son Joseph, who was named temporary head of government after his father was shot, would soon be sworn as President.

To most Congolese, the younger Kabila remains a mystery. His installation as Kabila's replacement was rejected on Friday by rebel representatives and opposition groups in Belgium, Congo's former colonial ruler, who called for talks on Congo's political future.

Details of last Tuesday's attack at the presidential palace in Kinshasa were still murky. A member of Kabila's security entourage has said a bodyguard shot the President. A number of bodyguards were arrested in the aftermath of the shooting along with senior members of Kabila's administration, relatives said.

Former Belgian Foreign Affairs Minister Louis Michel later said he had received reports that Kabila was killed after a disagreement with some of his army generals. Kabila's hold over the army had grown increasingly tenuous, in recent months, with some troops reportedly threatening to revolt over pay demands.

Prospects of a stabilisation of the long-running crisis in the Congo following Kabila's death were dashed yesterday by Information Minister Sakombi who said the late President had wanted to pursue the war. He said Kabila had wanted the forces to remain disciplined and calm, to protect the population, to defend Congo's integrity and 'to kick the aggressors out of the country'.

All sides in the war have violated the Lusaka ceasefire, and the UN has balked at sending in troops until fighting stopped.

Kabila came to power in May 1997 in a Ugandan and Rwandan-sponsored rebellion against the late dictator Mobutu Sese Seko. He was initially welcomed as an alternative to Mobutu's deeply corrupt, decades-long rule, which left the nation in ruins.

webTitle: New surgery to cure severe blushing

fields.headline: New surgery may be a sweat but it can save the lady's blushes
fields.trailText: Forget trying to build up your self-confidence and social poise; forget the pills and whisky. Those afflicted by severe blushing can now have a surgical operation to cure it overnight.
fields.body:
Forget trying to build up your self-confidence and social poise; forget the pills and whisky. Those afflicted by severe blushing can now have a surgical operation to cure it overnight.

People who have had the operation say it has transformed their lives. The only drawback is that, instead of blushing, they sweat a lot more.

Blushing has only recently been recognised as a medical condition, although the symptoms can devastate lives. For thousands it develops into a severe social phobia. Many sufferers are unable to work and avoid all social contact, some times leading to depression and suicide.

Sufferers have often turned to psychological treatments, acu-puncture or Prozac to seek con-fidence. But many have found the treatments ineffective.

Now an operation - performed using keyhole surgery through each armpit - is available in the UK, making it almost physically impossible to blush. 'Endoscopic thoracis sympathicotomy' involves cutting the 'sympathetic chain' of nerves that stretches across the rib cage and controls blushing in the face.

Sufferers may feel embarrassed, but they will not show it. The operation is performed in 20 minutes under general anaes thetic, and patients can return to work two days later.

Sarah Adams, 26, a retailer from London, had the operation two months ago and says it has changed her life. She used to blush so much she could not take part in seminars at university and had to change jobs several times because she couldn't go to meetings. 'I used to get really embarrassed. I'd feel my face go bright red and I'd really hate it,' she said.

However, the nerve controlling blushing also controls sweat. Sweat glands stop working above the nipple and in the arms, but work twice as hard in the lower part of the body.

'You have a risk of going from blushing to sweating - but 85 per cent of patients say they are totally satisfied. They don't blush, or so little it's not a problem,' said Dr Lars Rex, who carries out the operation at the Scandinavian Medical Centre in London. Not yet available on the NHS, it costs £4,000 privately.

 The Scandinavian Medical Centre is contacted on 020 7636 7780.

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Asian blood feuds spill into Britain

fields.headline: Asian blood feuds spill into Britain
fields.standfirst: The murder of a London greengrocer has revealed how warring families will seek revenge over thousands of miles
fields.trailText: The murder of a London greengrocer has revealed how warring families will seek revenge over thousands of miles.
fields.body:
The only remarkable thing about Abdul Raja was the way he died. The greengrocer from Mitcham, south London, was found in a pool of blood soon after opening his store one Monday morning. The first shotgun blast tore through his chest into his heart. But his killer wanted to make doubly sure, firing a second shot at point-blank range into Raja's head.

Police feared Raja had been the victim of a bungled robbery: shopkeepers on the street had complained of rising crime and two armed raids had taken place at nearby stores in the previous week. The truth, when it finally emerged, was altogether unexpected. Raja had been gunned down because of a medieval-style blood feud which had erupted on the other side of the world - a feud many fear is far from resolved.

The case is the first of its kind in the UK but immigration officials believe it could herald the start of a terrifying trend. Dozens of men living in Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities in Britain have already been earmarked for death, often as part of disputes which go back decades.

One couple, Kanwar Ahsan and Riffat Afridi, who hail from rival Pakistani tribes which have been warring for 80 years, were forced to flee to Britain and go into hiding after receiving more than 6,000 death threats. Ahsan narrowly escaped death when Afridi's father and brother shot him three times outside a Pakistani courtroom.

But while some know only too well of the threats against them, others are blissfully unaware of any potential danger because the disputes involve distant family members with whom they have little contact.

Blood feuds are by no means restricted to Asia: thousands of the Albanian refugees who have fled to Britain in recent years claim to have done so to escape brutal vendettas in their homeland which claim at least 1,000 lives a year.

Such feuds are notoriously complex: they can revolve around issues of honour, land rights or family problems. A murder automatically leads to 'bad blood' between the families of the victim and the perpetrator which can only be 'cleansed' by more killing. Because blood feuds are not about simple revenge but honour, the victim need not be the person responsible for the crime. Any male sharing the same blood line is a potential target - and grandfathers, uncles and distant cousins have all been targeted.

There is also no specific number of killings that need to be carried out to cleanse a single death. 'There is a saying in Pakistan,' says Mohammed, a friend of Raja's family, 'that you never forget the blood of your relatives. The only rules in blood feuds are that the victim should not be attacked from behind and that a promise not to kill a specific person should never be broken. If you do either of these things, the bad blood comes back to haunt you.'

The feud that led to the death of Raja began in the small Pakistani village of Bulani in the summer of 1999. Samir Rahmen-Adam, 23, had travelled from London to Bulani to take part in an arranged marriage to Raja's nephew, Mohammed Aslan. The marriage was not successful and after a few weeks Rahmen-Adam returned to London and asked for a divorce. Unusually, her father supported her in the move and agreed to let her remain in Britain. A few days later, on 5 August, he was shot dead by three men. The killers allegedly included members of Raja's family.

Two months later, Rahmen-Adam's elder brother, Suleman, with whom she lived in London, had begun plotting revenge and selected Raja as his target. Raja has been sending back money to support Rahmen-Adam's former husband and was therefore seen as the main UK representative of the family.

Suleman secured a second mortgage on his property and used the money to set up an alibi for the murder. By November he had purchased a car, acquired a sawn-off shotgun and then travelled to Paris, telling friends he was going on a long holiday. On 28 November, the day before the murder, he slipped back into the UK and blasted Raja to death minutes after he opened up for business. Suleman then fled back to Pakistan via France and Holland.

Four days after Raja died, Suleman phoned Raja's distant cousin, Javid Sharif, the man who had organised his second mortgage. 'Do you like my work? I shot him,' Suleman said. When Javed protested, he continued: 'He had to go. He's the top man. I knew you would not like it. I'm going to go back to kill a few more.'

Back in Bulani, Suleman was equally boastful. As Raja's funeral procession passed through the village, he stood on a nearby rooftop and fired an AK47 rifle into the air while shouting out that he had killed him. Suleman was eventually arrested while trying to return to the UK via Holland.

During a seven-week murder trial which ended last week, a new picture of Raja surfaced. He had come to Britain in 1992 leaving his first wife and four children behind. While living in Bulani, he was said to have worked as a henchman for a local MP and had spent time in prison for crimes including kidnap and extortion. Raja was also said to have been responsible for the death of a bus conductor whom he killed in a fight following a quarrel.

According to Suleman's brother, Qamar, they were the ones who felt threatened. 'It was well known that the person who had murdered our Daddy wanted to murder us too. Raja was a dangerous man. He had committed numerous murders and had numerous enemies in Pakistan,' said Qamar.

Last Wednesday Suleman Adam was convicted of murder and sent to jail for life. Qamar and Samir, who had stood trial for murder and conspiracy to murder respectively, were both acquitted.

The officer in charge of the case, Detective Chief Inspector Paul McAleenan, told The Observer : 'It is the end of a very sad chapter for both families. One side lost their father in the feud, the other lost Raja. But feuds of this kind cannot be allowed to continue in this country, regardless of what motivates them.'

webTitle: Letter: Score flaw

fields.headline: Score flaw
fields.trailText: What a shocking editorial you wrote (Comment, last week), saying English football should copy America, with salary caps and the distribution of emerging players. Whatever happened to the principle of survival of the richest?
fields.body:
What a shocking editorial you wrote (Comment, last week), saying English football should copy America, with salary caps and the distribution of emerging players. Whatever happened to the principle of survival of the richest? At least you didn't suggest local councils own their city's teams, as Green Bay owns the Packers. Britain (indeed Europe) must not import American ideas that are so dangerously socialist.
Frank Desmond
London W6

webTitle: Obituary: Observer journalist Gavin Young

fields.headline: Footloose, unusual - and such a talent
fields.standfirst: Mark Frankland  on The Observer's Gavin Young, who died last week
fields.trailText: Mark Frankland on The Observer's Gavin Young, who died last week.
fields.body:
Gaving Young, who died in London last week at 72, was a star foreign correspondent of the postwar Observer, who went on to become a famous writer. Unusually for a journalist he was made a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. Less unusually for a journalist of his generation he was also, briefly, a member of MI6.

He scarcely fitted the popular idea of a journalist when he arrived at The Observer 's poky offices in Tudor Street, off Fleet Street, in 1959 from a job in Morocco with Radio Maroc. His new colleagues thought the tall, well-built young man with a silk handkerchief in his breast pocket looked like a 'successful young brigadier'.

David Astor, then editor, often employed people with little experience of journalism. The Observer quickly helped him discover his own passion for writing, but he was already aware of the other great passion in his life - travel.

England never meant much to him. Educated at Rugby and Oxford he seldom talked about either. Inspiration came from the Celtic fringes, holidays in Cornwall and Wales. National Service with the Welsh Guards in Palestine gave him a taste for the Arab way of life.

His father was a professional soldier, but other Youngs had travelled the world as traders. Young seemed to be following their example when in 1951, aged 22, he joined a shipping company in Basra in the Persian Gulf, but two encounters changed his life.

He met the explorer Wilfred Thesiger, who laughed at Young's suggestion they cross the Saudi desert by camel, and instead took him to the Marsh Arabs of Iraq where Young stayed for two years. And he was recruited into espionage by a pair of enterprising MI6 officers, Nigel Clive and Alexis Forter. Young learnt from Thesiger to travel simply, and to treat all he met as equals. Clive and Forter showed him how power worked. They failed to interest him in conventional politics, and he came to ridicule most writing about it as 'political knitting'.

He once hinted he was involved in the Anglo-American operation that restored the Shah of Persia to his throne in 1953. He was neither guilty nor proud about his short association with the spies, who lost their attraction for him when he started to travel and write for The Observer.

In 1961 he trekked into the mountains of north-east India to meet Naga rebels who were resisting the Indian government. The achievement involved more than courage and physical toughness. When growing up he had come across books by Conrad. It was a remark of Conrad's that summed up the essence of the unusual young correspondent's talent: 'By the power of the written word to make you hear, to make you feel - it is before all, to make you see.'

The one place Young's readers caught little sight of was New York, where he was posted later in the Sixties, for he filed few, if any, stories from there. New York suited his sociable nature. A 'life enhancer' (his expression), he admired this quality in others, and his parties were attended by the likes of Norman Mailer, Gore Vidal and Mary McCarthy.

He had friends in show business and jazz (he played jazz piano himself). He knew, and almost wrote a book about, the American wits such as Groucho Marx and Jack Benny. Young won awards for stories about the subcontinent, Africa and the Middle East, but Vietnam meant most to him: on his first visit there in 1965 he met a Vietnamese family he was bound to for the rest of his life.

He came across its young men during a violent demonstration by Buddhist students in the old capital Hue. Later they took him home to meet the family's matriarch. The slight and dignified Madame Bong drew confidence from the correspondent who used his physical presence to inspire calm rather than threat.

Young liked teasing friends. He teased the Bong tribe, too, but the amused look that in New York or London might signal a barbed remark reflected only admiration and affection for his Vietnamese.

By 1975, when Astor retired as editor, Young was losing his taste for journalism. He went back to the Marsh Arabs and wrote a book about them, but his breakthrough as a writer came with Slow Boat to China and its successor Slow Boats Home.

His agent and publisher dismissed as boring his idea of making a voyage to China and back by whatever ships came to hand, and he was in gloomy mood when The Observer' s literary editor Terry Kilmartin took him to lunch with the agent Gillon Aitken. Just back from abroad, Young spent most of the lunch opening his mail, but Aitken liked his idea, and they became friends.

Young enjoyed the fame the books brought him.He treasured two later books, In search of Conrad (winner of the Thomas Cook Travel Book Award) and A Wavering Grace, a memorial to Vietnam and the Bong family written after two painful postwar visits.

fields.bodyText: Gaving Young, who died in London last week at 72, was a star foreign correspondent of the postwar Observer, who went on to become a famous writer. Unusually for a journalist he was made a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. Less unusually for a journalist of his generation he was also, briefly, a member of MI6. He scarcely fitted the popular idea of a journalist when he arrived at The Observer 's poky offices in Tudor Street, off Fleet Street, in 1959 from a job in Morocco with Radio Maroc. His new colleagues thought the tall, well-built young man with a silk handkerchief in his breast pocket looked like a 'successful young brigadier'. David Astor, then editor, often employed people with little experience of journalism. The Observer quickly helped him discover his own passion for writing, but he was already aware of the other great passion in his life - travel. England never meant much to him. Educated at Rugby and Oxford he seldom talked about either. Inspiration came from the Celtic fringes, holidays in Cornwall and Wales. National Service with the Welsh Guards in Palestine gave him a taste for the Arab way of life. His father was a professional soldier, but other Youngs had travelled the world as traders. Young seemed to be following their example when in 1951, aged 22, he joined a shipping company in Basra in the Persian Gulf, but two encounters changed his life. He met the explorer Wilfred Thesiger, who laughed at Young's suggestion they cross the Saudi desert by camel, and instead took him to the Marsh Arabs of Iraq where Young stayed for two years. And he was recruited into espionage by a pair of enterprising MI6 officers, Nigel Clive and Alexis Forter. Young learnt from Thesiger to travel simply, and to treat all he met as equals. Clive and Forter showed him how power worked. They failed to interest him in conventional politics, and he came to ridicule most writing about it as 'political knitting'. He once hinted he was involved in the Anglo-American operation that restored the Shah of Persia to his throne in 1953. He was neither guilty nor proud about his short association with the spies, who lost their attraction for him when he started to travel and write for The Observer. webTitle: French told to pity the poor concierge

fields.headline: French told to pity the poor concierge
fields.trailText: There is nothing quite like them in Britain, but if you crossed Nora Batty's rumpled stockings with Hilda Ogden's fondness for gossip, you might get the idea. In France's popular imagination at least, concierges are middle-aged female busybodies who steam open tenants' letters on the sly and spend their lives sitting in ground-floor lodges of apartment buildings, their net curtains twit-ching as life passes them by.
fields.body:
There is nothing quite like them in Britain, but if you crossed Nora Batty's rumpled stockings with Hilda Ogden's fondness for gossip, you might get the idea. In France's popular imagination at least, concierges are middle-aged female busybodies who steam open tenants' letters on the sly and spend their lives sitting in ground-floor lodges of apartment buildings, their net curtains twit-ching as life passes them by.

But a very different picture of France's 90,000 concierges emerged last week from the 34th conference of their biggest union, the Syndicat National Indépendant des Gardiens d'Immeubles, Concierges et Professions Connexes. Far from the overbearing tyrants of French legend, they were portrayed as bullied, low-paid, over-stressed workers often treated with contempt by their employers.

While much of France is experiencing the biggest economic boom in 30 years, many concierges are suffering from harassment, fear of unemployment and low pay.

'Concierges continue to be left behind with salaries which don't exceed 4,500 francs net a month [about £420] and in working conditions that are sometimes deplorable,' said union president Jacques Simakis.

Speaker after speaker at the conference referred to the insecurity of their employment, the low salaries and the often disgusting behaviour of some tenants and residents in apartment buildings.

Concierges, 25,000 of whom live and work in Paris, have been assumed to be a dying breed in recent years. The French rapper MC Solaar even wrote a song four years ago called 'Obsolete' in which he lamented their replacement by digicodes and entryphone systems. Automated systems have served to halve the number of concierges in the past 20 years.

But reports of their death have been exaggerated. Yes, digicodes - which allow residents to punch a number into a keypad at the entrance to open the door - have made many redundant, but many survive, albeit precariously.

Today's concierge is less responsible for checking on the comings and goings of suspicious characters but they still clean hallways and staircases, pull the wheelie bins into the street for collection and often deliver post to each flat in their block. Some might even clean your flat, look after your cats or do some baby-sitting or ironing - for an additional fee. Some, on the other hand, might try to get you evicted for harbouring pets.

Many office apartment blocks still employ concierges - mostly men - who sit in glass-fronted offices with one eye on the television and the other on who's coming through the front door.

Estate agents report that flats are easier to sell or rent if they are in a building that has a concierge. But it is in residential apartment buildings that most of the problems have arisen. 'There's often a problem with owners who demand too much,' said Jacques Caille, a former concierge. 'Assaults can happen anywhere, but the rudeness of apartment owners who take out their aggression on defenceless concierges is unacceptable.'

He and his wife Rolande, from Orange in the south of France, recently retired from concierge work after 15 years in their last apartment building. Complaining of the anti-social behaviour of many of those they worked for, they said they had found rotting fish left under windows, eggs smashed in the lift and excrement in the hallway.

According to a survey of 2,500 concierges commissioned by the union, incidents involving verbal abuse or violence have doubled in the last three years. Eighty per cent of those surveyed had suffered verbal attacks and 20 per cent physical assaults.

Simakis said police and other public authorities rarely do anything to help. 'The managing committees of owners often behave as though they have a divine right over concierges and dismiss anything that doesn't seem a problem to them.'

webTitle: Norway: Rescued wolves face slaughter

fields.headline: Rescued wolves face slaughter
fields.trailText: It has already provoked thousands of protests and raised the ire of its own press. But now Norway's bid to kill 20 of its grey wolves - an endangered species only recently restored to the Scandinavian wilderness - has triggered a major diplomatic spat.
fields.body:
It has already provoked thousands of protests and raised the ire of its own press. But now Norway's bid to kill 20 of its grey wolves - an endangered species only recently restored to the Scandinavian wilderness - has triggered a major diplomatic spat.

Swedish Environment Minister Kjell Larsson last week protested to his Norwegian counterpart, Siri Bjerke, about a plan by the Norwegian ministry to use helicopters and marksmen to hunt down two of Scandinavia's 10 wolf packs in Hedmark province.

Larsson said his country felt 'deep unease', a considerable understatement given that Sweden actually wants to raise Scandinavia's wolf population from around 80 to 500 over the coming years. Even the Swedish Hunters' Association has condemned the cull.

By contrast, Norwegian Environment Department officials are under strong pressure from farmers to kill 20 of the present 100 wolves. The farmers say that last year they lost 827 animals - mostly sheep - to wolves. The 50 wolf cubs expected to be born this year represent a serious threat to their livelihoods.

But environmentalists point out that a total of 33,000 farm animals were killed last year by other predators, mainly wolverines - in fact, a species related to the weasel - lynx and bears. 'Wiping out wolves will solve nothing,' said Rasmus Hansson of the World Wildlife Fund.

He was supported by the Norwegian newspaper Dagbladet, which warned that if the country - already criticised for hunting whales and seals - now kills wolves, 'the world will see Norway as a land of half-crazed Vikings and barbarians'.

The grey wolf is the largest of the species and in fact ranges in colour from pure white or black through to all shades of grey, to tan and brown. They roam in packs of between two and more than 30 over territories of up to 13,000 square miles.

The females give birth to litters of between three and 10 cubs, though the mortality rate of the young in the wild is up to 60 per cent.

The Norwegian Environment Department has already received more than 6,000 emails protesting about the cull. These were dismissed as 'predictable' by Stein Lier-Hansen, a senior official. The protesters 'take for granted that Norway wants to wipe out the wolf. We don't'. Despite the cull, the wolf population would remain at a sustainable level, he said.

The dispute between the two countries goes beyond attitudes to wildlife. In Sweden, farmers tend to fence in their animals. In Norway, they graze freely.

'Norway supports country-folk. The price is that they compete with the wildlife,' said Marie von Zeipel of the WWF in Sweden.

There is a long history of environmental rifts between the countries. In 1988 a documentary about the Norwegian seal cull, which had been banned in Norway, was shown on Swedish TV. A court in Norway ordered the TV company to pay damages.

The controversy over the wolves came in the same week that Norway agreed to allow exports of whale meat.

Its Environment Department said it planned to carry out the cull before the spring thaw, so that the wolves could be tracked easily in snow. 'We honestly don't know when the decision [to go ahead] will be made,' said one official.

webTitle: Letters: The tragedy of Anna damns the Government

fields.headline: The tragedy of Anna damns the Government
fields.trailText: The comment by a social worker that Anna Climbie was smelly and disfigured, not a child that anyone would want to go near including some social workers, is appalling and explains why she was so neglected and died.
fields.body:
The comment by a social worker that Anna Climbie was smelly and disfigured, not a child that anyone would want to go near including some social workers, is appalling and explains why she was so neglected and died.

That social worker is wrong. A child so described is exactly the child that anyone with any humanity, and indeed any intellect, would want to protect. Intellect tells us that every child of eight years old that smells of 'urine and faeces' is being neglected. Humanity does not reject disfigurement.

The people who turned away from Anna thought only of themselves and had lost their focus on the child. It is at this level that changes need to be made to protect children.
Margaret Laughton
London SE27

Your reporting on the case of Anna Climbie omits one salient point. Lisa Arthurworrey, the young social worker involved, according to a report on television news, receives £9,000 per annum, approximately equal to the weekly pay of a spotty-faced lager lout in the City of London. If the salary of social workers was trebled by a Government who thinks it a greater priority to waste billions on such fripperies as the Millennium Dome, perhaps a career in social services might appear attractive to persons of high calibre and recruitment could be a deal more successful.
Stanley Trevor
Nairn

I, like other parents, am sickened and outraged at the vile level of cruelty perpetrated on innocent children. One of the reasons nothing changes is that these defenceless victims are not voters. Another is the total inadequacy of the bureaucratic social services system. Anyone fresh out of university with a degree in sociology can become a social worker. I would like to see a mothers' army of new recruits with a lower age limit of about 30, and without a single degree between them, get behind those closed doors. Will this Government get off its backside and swap bureaucracy for common sense?
Pat Smith
Worcestershire

Whatever the rights and wrongs of social worker Lisa Arthurworrey's behaviour in the case of Anna Climbie, we shouldn't overlook the way Haringey's social services came through a joint review by the Audit Commission and HM Social Services Inspectorate with flying colours a few months earlier. None of the problems now widely publicised were flagged up in a way that would indicate the crisis levels which clearly exist and are now being cited as causal to this tragedy.

Senior staff and ruling Labour councillors need to explain why they thought everything was fine when clearly this was a tragedy waiting to happen.
Lynne Featherstone
(Liberal Democrat) Leader of the Opposition Haringey Council

webTitle: O for a muse of office fire...

fields.headline: O for a muse of office fire...
fields.standfirst: Firms are looking to art workshops to ascend the brightest heaven of employee creativity, says  Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: Firms are looking to art workshops to ascend the brightest heaven of employee creativity, says Jim Pollard
fields.body:
Ever since the teachings of the Dalai Lama topped corporate America's reading list last year, Mammon, it seems, has been getting spiritual. Shell has a Buddhist priest; Boeing offers study classes in the Torah, the Koran and the Bible. Spirituality and creativity - its more productive soulmate - are the latest buzz words, but are they any more than management-speak repackaged to squeeze that last ounce of blood from an overstretched workforce?

Richard Reeves of the Industrial Society has been examining this trend for his forthcoming book, Happy Mondays. He says: 'Today's trendy management books all talk about spirituality at work. The sceptical view is that now business has our bodies and our minds, it wants our souls too.'

For the board of Lotus Cars this meant reliving the battle of Agincourt. Former theatre director Richard Olivier uses the Shakespearean role in which his father was so acclaimed, Henry V, as a case study in leadership. 'I directed Henry V at the Globe,' says Olivier, 'and was interested by what a 400-year-old play had to tell us about leadership. Pilot course participants told me they'd learned more from Henry than from any management guru.'

Now Olivier is on the way to becoming a guru himself. 'We don't just talk about ideas; we use the story to involve participants emotionally, and theatre skills to involve them physically.'

Olivier, who also offers courses based on Julius Caesar and Hamlet, sees his work as part of an emerging arts-based type of training that is replacing the old adventure training model. 'Instead of dropping people in a field with a toothbrush, we drop them in the middle of Shakespeare,' he says.

However, it is not just big corporate players that are interested in tapping into workers' creativity. A £5 million Art's Council project has seen hundreds of businesses all over the country, including fish and chip shops, sewage farms and even Brighton and Hove Albion football club get their own artist in residence.

'Point of Sale', a verse diary by poet Peter Sansom lyrically records his time as poet-in-residence for Marks & Spencer. Unlike fellow poet David Whyte's workshops, Sansom's involve not reciting poetry, but writing it.

'When I started doing this 15 years ago it was pretty rare in this country,' he says, 'Now it is becoming commonplace. At M&S, I worked with people across the business - accountants, people who design soup labels, people on the shop floor - most of them would no more write a poem than hang-glide. Many of them expected me to read to them but instead we wrote - there and then.'

Sansom describes the process as 'meditation with a finished product', adding: 'It brings things to the surface. Writing allows you to get to grips with what's troubling you, albeit indirectly.'

What his work has in common with Olivier's and Whyte's is the use of metaphor. 'Someone may write a poem about a shoe that doesn't fit, but perhaps they're concerned about a job that doesn't fit,' Sansom says. 'Of course, you don't have to deconstruct it any more than you have to deconstruct a dream. However, just as you benefit from dreaming whether you deconstruct it or not, so you benefit from writing. Most people tell me they go back to their jobs feeling more awake and alive.'

So tapping into our spiritual side at work may be natural and - as we spend more time at work in increasingly secular societies - necessary, but what does the company get out of it? Olivier is clear: 'The key skill managers need today is creativity - to manage change and apparent chaos. The arts can teach business a lot about this.'

Whyte agrees. 'Every organisation wants vitality and adaptability in workers, and you can only get that if you unlock their creativity. The problem is the language of the workplace is not broad enough; the language of the arts and literature is.' Reeves welcomes any initiative that focuses on personal development. 'Our spiritual dimension is bound to impact on our work and the way we do it,' he says.

'Cadbury's, for example, was founded on Quaker principles. The Industrial Society was started by a priest. More and more people are looking for work that fits the sort of person they are. That's good. But I worry when people try to train people in spirituality or standardise creativity.

'It is clearly better for a firm to be a fun place to work, but you don't achieve that by sending everyone on a "how to have fun" course. The same is true of spirituality. You can't impose it.'

Indeed, could it not be that for many people, an interesting job, a reasonable workload and a quiet room with time to sit and think may be all that is required to unlock their creativity? 'Once more unto the breach' may do it for some; once more unto the coffee machine for others.

Poetry and emotion

Poet David Whyte is not afraid to use a stream of Anglo-Saxon language in the management workshops he has put on for clients including Arthur Andersen and American Express. The eighth-century epic Beowulf is just one of 300 poems including 50 of his own that he recites, often by heart, to trigger off what he describes as 'a no bullshit conversation around creativity'.

'I avoid using the word spirituality because it provokes such allergic reactions. I prefer to talk about soul, and how you feel you belong to the world. Good leadership is at the frontier of this conversation. His workshops, which he runs on both sides of the Atlantic, encourage participants to 'live their own lives not someone else's'.

Whyte, who has written four books of poetry, is not a natural friend of corporate America. 'I grew up in radical South Yorkshire and had a deep scepticism about the business world. I soon found that the business world had similar prejudices about poets. But I've discovered since I started doing this in 1986 that bringing together two things which don't usually go together creates a chemistry and this leads to all sorts of good stuff coming out.

Whyte goes on: 'Many managers find they have left their original technical competency far behind and that most of their work involves structured conversation - something in which they have no training. That's where I can help.'

Whyte believes that the best modern managers are what he calls 'apprentices in the phenomenology of human belonging'. He adds: 'At its simplest, people give more if they feel like they are more than cogs in a machine. More importantly, we spend more time at work than anywhere else - and if we're not asking the bigger questions about the soul at work, when are we going to do it?'

Contacts: David Whyte - www.davidwhyte.com;
Richard Olivier - richardolivier@bt.internet.com;
Peter Sansom - edit@poetrybusiness.co.uk

Olivier, who also offers courses based on Julius Caesar and Hamlet, sees his work as part of an emerging arts-based type of training that is replacing the old adventure training model. 'Instead of dropping people in a field with a toothbrush, we drop them in the middle of Shakespeare,' he says. However, it is not just big corporate players that are interested in tapping into workers' creativity. A £5 million Art's Council project has seen hundreds of businesses all over the country, including fish and chip shops, sewage farms and even Brighton and Hove Albion football club get their own artist in residence. 'Point of Sale', a verse diary by poet Peter Sansom lyrically records his time as poet-in-residence for Marks & Spencer. Unlike fellow poet David Whyte's workshops, Sansom's involve not reciting poetry, but writing it. 'When I started doing this 15 years ago it was pretty rare in this country,' he says, 'Now it is becoming commonplace. At M&S, I worked with people across the business - accountants, people who design soup labels, people on the shop floor - most of them would no more write a poem than hang-glide. Many of them expected me to read to them but instead we wrote - there and then.' Sansom describes the process as 'meditation with a finished product', adding: 'It brings things to the surface. Writing allows you to get to grips with what's troubling you, albeit indirectly.' What his work has in common with Olivier's and Whyte's is the use of metaphor. 'Someone may write a poem about a shoe that doesn't fit, but perhaps they're concerned about a job that doesn't fit,' Sansom says. 'Of course, you don't have to deconstruct it any more than you have to deconstruct a dream. However, just as you benefit from dreaming whether you deconstruct it or not, so you benefit from writing. Most people tell me they go back to their jobs feeling more awake and alive.' So tapping into our spiritual side at work may be natural and - as we spend more time at work in increasingly secular societies - necessary, but what does the company get out of it? Olivier is clear: 'The key skill managers need today is creativity - to manage change and apparent chaos. The arts can teach business a lot about this.' Whyte agrees. 'Every organisation wants vitality and adaptability in workers, and you can only get that if you unlock their creativity. The problem is the language of the workplace is not broad enough; the language of the arts and literature is.' Reeves welcomes any initiative that focuses on personal development. 'Our spiritual dimension is bound to impact on our work and the way we do it,' he says. 'Cadbury's, for example, was founded on Quaker principles. The Industrial Society was started by a priest. More and more people are looking for work that fits the sort of person they are. That's good. But I worry when people try to train people in spirituality or standardise creativity. 'It is clearly better for a firm to be a fun place to work, but you don't achieve that by sending everyone on a "how to have fun" course. The same is true of spirituality. You can't impose it.' Indeed, could it not be that for many people, an interesting job, a reasonable workload and a quiet room with time to sit and think may be all that is required to unlock their creativity? 'Once more unto the breach' may do it for some; once more unto the coffee machine for others. Poetry and emotion Poet David Whyte is not afraid to use a stream of Anglo-Saxon language in the management workshops he has put on for clients including Arthur Andersen and American Express. The eighth-century epic Beowulf is just one of 300 poems including 50 of his own that he recites, often by heart, to trigger off what he describes as 'a no bullshit conversation around creativity'. 'I avoid using the word spirituality because it provokes such allergic reactions. I prefer to talk about soul, and how you feel you belong to the world. Good leadership is at the frontier of this conversation. His workshops, which he runs on both sides of the Atlantic, encourage participants to 'live their own lives not someone else's'. Whyte, who has written four books of poetry, is not a natural friend of corporate America. 'I grew up in radical South Yorkshire and had a deep scepticism about the business world. I soon found that the business world had similar prejudices about poets. But I've discovered since I started doing this in 1986 that bringing together two things which don't usually go together creates a chemistry and this leads to all sorts of good stuff coming out. Whyte goes on: 'Many managers find they have left their original technical competency far behind and that most of their work involves structured conversation - something in which they have no training. That's where I can help.' Whyte believes that the best modern managers are what he calls 'apprentices in the phenomenology of human belonging'. He adds: 'At its simplest, people give more if they feel like they are more than cogs in a machine. More importantly, we spend more time at work than anywhere else - and if we're not asking the bigger questions about the soul at work, when are we going to do it?' webTitle: How to become a volunteer

fields.headline: How to become a volunteer
fields.trailText: 1 Think carefully before you rush out to fulfil Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's wishes that we should all do two hours of voluntary work a week. If there is one thing potentially worse than paid work, it is unpaid work. You may hate your boss and your day job - but at least you know where you stand in the pecking order, people can pull rank to get tasks done and the business probably breaks even. In voluntary groups, you can find yourself in a group of underqualified, over-opinionated, incompetent do-gooders, unable to fire each other and, as often as not, squandering the money.
fields.body:
1 Think carefully before you rush out to fulfil Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's wishes that we should all do two hours of voluntary work a week. If there is one thing potentially worse than paid work, it is unpaid work. You may hate your boss and your day job - but at least you know where you stand in the pecking order, people can pull rank to get tasks done and the business probably breaks even. In voluntary groups, you can find yourself in a group of underqualified, over-opinionated, incompetent do-gooders, unable to fire each other and, as often as not, squandering the money.

2 Decide whether you want to be in the front line - manning an Oxfam shop or a Samaritan telephone, perhaps - or if you prefer to be on a management committee or in some other long-term, campaigning or eminence grise role. Even unpaid shop work has its stresses: Oxfam has a fully-fledged feedback, forums and complaints support system for its 22,000 UK volunteers.

3 Work out what skills you can contribute if you're going down the management committee route - understanding finance, perhaps, motivating people or local knowledge. Find out whether the group can get you more training: understanding committee procedures and chairing meetings are invaluable skills for any human being who participates in collective decision-making. 'You have to be honest about what skills you can bring to the party, other than just enthusiasm,' says Bruce Picking, the voluntary treasurer of the Finsbury Park Partnership's £25 million regeneration budget.

4 Expect the going to be particularly tough in small groups. If a management committee is supported by a staff of 100, they will often get the red carpet treatment. But running a team of three workers often means that you make the tea yourself, draw up the employment contracts, arbitrate on grievance procedures and do other grisly administrative jobs. If there is money around, expect regular assaults from gold-diggers who want to take over the management committee.

5 Decide what you want out of the deal - usually experience, meeting other active people (mainly over the age of 40) and the satisfaction of making progress. Some people start a new career by this route - learning fund-raising, green campaigning or whatever takes their fancy. If you are working on a good project with people you like, voluntary work can revitalise your life.
