webTitle: Ode on a reason to earn

fields.headline: Ode on a reason to earn
fields.trailText: I have written a poem to express my frustration at not being able to claim all the Working Families Tax Credit for which I could otherwise qualify because my mother, not a registered childminder, looks after my daughter when I am at work. 'I have seen the adverts on ITV/ About the benefits available to people like me/ As a hard-working single parent struggling to get by/ For the working tax credit I did apply/ ...But instead of relief all I received was more stress/ Leaving me wondering if working is the option that's best... [After 28 more lines the poem concludes] So ladies and gentlemen and to one and all/ With no help from this government I have hit my brick wall.'
fields.body:
I have written a poem to express my frustration at not being able to claim all the Working Families Tax Credit for which I could otherwise qualify because my mother, not a registered childminder, looks after my daughter when I am at work. 'I have seen the adverts on ITV/ About the benefits available to people like me/ As a hard-working single parent struggling to get by/ For the working tax credit I did apply/ ...But instead of relief all I received was more stress/ Leaving me wondering if working is the option that's best... [After 28 more lines the poem concludes] So ladies and gentlemen and to one and all/ With no help from this government I have hit my brick wall.'

Under the rules, you miss out on up to £70-a-week that you would be able to claim if your daughter were cared for by a registered childminder. (If you had more than one child, the sum would be £105 a week.) The only way round this would be for your mother to register as a childminder with her local authority - but she would have to convince them she genuinely wanted the job and would take in other children as well. Registration should take three months but is taking longer in some parts of the country. Her premises would also be inspected.

By September this year, Ofsted is due to take over the registration of childminders to enforce national standards.

Useful contacts include the National Childminding Association's helpline on 0800 169 4486 and the Daycare Trust helpline on 0207 739 2866 (www.daycare.trust.org.uk)

webTitle: Doctor - or snake oil salesman?

fields.headline: Doctor - or snake oil salesman?
fields.standfirst: It's lonely and confusing at the top. That's why gurus thrive, says  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: It's lonely and confusing at the top. That's why gurus thrive, says Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
It's easy to be cynical about management gurus. According to a 'Thinkers 50' survey by management website FTdynamo.com, the stars of the burgeoning executive speaking circuit can earn $100,000 a day, putting them among the highest hourly earners on the planet.

Deliciously, even anti-guru Scott Adams, creator of the cynical Dilbert cartoon, clears $15,000 for telling corporate audiences not to believe a word more orthodox colleagues say.

Is it worth it? Most people would be sceptical. As the survey suggests, apparently 'new' ideas often turn out to be old ones in trendy (sometimes even non-existent) new clothes. Some are short-lived fads, and others are dubious or just plain wrong - they can't all be right, after all.

But the issue is more complicated - and interesting - than that. Start from the fact that gurus past and present are hugely influential, if often at an unconscious level. Every large manufacturing company owes something to the thinking of FW Taylor and Henry Ford II, for instance. To paraphrase Keynes, every company is in thrall to some defunct management theorist. This conventional wisdom may be 'free', but that doesn't necessarily make it a bargain.

Indeed, breaking out of the prison of past ideas may be cheap at any price. As Polaroid inventor Edwin Land once put it, moving forward is often due less to a blinding stroke of genius than 'a sudden cessation of stupidity ... not having a new thought, but stopping having an old one'. Some gurus (eg Tom Peters, No 5 on the list) fall into this category.

But here's the next problem. Which way to go? One reason that gurus and their nostrums flourish is that, as another of their number (although not in the top 50), John Kay, points out, management is much like medicine in the mid-nineteenth century: some of it is known (routine operations, accounting and finance), but a lot is uncharted. There are plenty of assumptions but no accepted overarching theory. The corpus of management knowledge is a mixture of empirically researched hypothesis, inspired insight, guesswork and superstition - promising territory for the snake-oil salesman as well as the genuine doctor.

The gurus are thus the embodiment of a burgeoning market for management ideas. In this perspective, the composition of the Dynamo list is striking. Although a few gurus are primarily theoretical (the influential Michael Porter, No 3) and another minority has successfully parlayed a single big idea into fame and fortune - Kaplan and Norton with the balanced scorecard (15), and, par excellence, Michael Hammer and James Champy with re-engineering (23) - the majority of the top 20 are firmly people-focused.

Following the admirable Peter Drucker, whose balance of American optimism and European historical and political sensitivity is a lodestar for the entire discipline, Peters and Handy, Hamel and Prahalad, Mintzberg, Senge, Ghoshal, Bennis, Kanter, Ridderstrale and Nordstrom, Covey and Barnevik all view management through a people-focused lens.

If anything, this trend is getting stronger. Ghoshal (12) and Bartlett, who began their influential work on multinationals by looking at top-level structures and processes, have over the years brought analysis down to the individual. They now argue not only that individual emancipation and empowerment are the corporation's bedrock sources of energy, but that they are a just and desirable cause in themselves.

So that's all right, then? Well, not quite. If the most influential thinkers are impeccable humanists, how come so many of their consulting clients run companies that are oppressive to work in? One answer may be that the cacophony of competing guru sales pitches makes it hard to concentrate for long on any one. One short-term change programme succeeds another before the first has had a chance to prove itself. Some companies have have as many as 10 or 12 going on at the same time.

Disillusion with one idea creates a market for an equal and opposite reaction. The downsizing abuses carried out in the name of re-engineering, for instance, were followed by a wave of books with titles like Healing the Wounds. The presence of Scott Adams and Dilbert on the list (31 - above Sir John Harvey-Jones) is testimony to a regrettable (to some) or healthy (to others) dose of cynicism among consumers.

The preponderance of human-focused gurus could also (alas) be a variant on the 'people as most important-asset' syndrome - an expression of wish rather than reality, which has little traction when the going gets tough. Certainly, the two top practising businessmen in the list, Jack Welch and Bill Gates, didn't get where they are now by being nice. GE operates some unforgiving staff practices, and Bill Gates' contribution to management is brilliant technology strategy combined with equally cold-eyed use of share options. Europeans Percy Barnevik and Sir Richard Branson reflect a softer approach: but they are also less influential. Yet it would be hard to argue that the gurus were a force for evil rather than good. Although opportunists and charlatans exist, Warren Bennis' defence of fellow guru Tom Peters against a snide Fortune article rings true for many of the top 50: 'Peters has never given up his passion for a better, more humane, more respectful [not only to shareholders] corporate world. What's wrong with that?'

Name Claim to fame

1 Peter Drucker Founding father

2 Charles Handy Future of work

3 Michael Porter Strategy

4 Gary Hamel Competing for the future

5 Tom Peters Permanent revolution

6 Jack Welch GE

7 Henry Mintzberg Anti-MBA

8 CK Prahalad Core competences

9 Bill Gates Microsoft

10 Philip Kotler Marketing

1 2 Sumantra Ghoshal Transnational corporation

13 Warren Bennis Leadership

14 Rosabeth Moss Kanter sociologist

15 Robert Kaplan/David Norton Balanced scorecard

16 Nicholas Negroponte MIT Media Lab

17 Jonas Ridderstrale/Kjell Nordstrom Funky Business

18 Steven Covey Self-help

19 Percy Barnevik ABB
